site_title: HDB resale prices flat in Q1 amid Covid-19 outbreak: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices remained flat in Q1 2020, matching the last quarter of 2019, amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The resale price index was 131.5. Experts attribute this to the fact that most people purchase flats for themselves, not for speculation. The government's Resilience Budget may help sustain housing demand and keep prices stable. However, the outbreak may negate the positive impacts of policy changes implemented last year, leading to limited upside for major price growth this year.

site_title: FairPrice closes Bedok Mall outlet for cleaning after employee diagnosed with Covid-19
summary: NTUC FairPrice is closing its FairPrice Finest outlet in Bedok Mall for a three-day deep clean after a staff member tested positive for Covid-19. The employee, who works in the store's back-end operations, has minimal customer contact. All staff in the affected outlet have been put on leave, and the store will reopen on April 4. This is the latest measure by FairPrice to combat the spread of the coronavirus, following previous measures including cleaning high-touch surfaces and temperature taking for staff and suppliers.

site_title: Two-thirds of Lufthansa staff to shorten work hours due to coronavirus
summary: Lufthansa has announced that two-thirds of its global staff, approximately 87,000 employees, will work reduced hours due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline has applied for state aid to keep staff employed, with the equivalent of 700 aircraft grounded. Lufthansa has also reached agreements with its works council and trade unions to introduce short-time working for 27,000 cabin and ground staff. The airline's executive board has waived 20% of their compensation in solidarity with employees.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust forms committee for talks with lenders, strategic review
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has formed a special committee of directors to oversee its strategic review and negotiations with lenders. The committee, comprising all independent directors and the CEO of the managers, will engage with Bank of America and syndicate lenders to discuss a forbearance agreement and a consensual strategy. The trust has temporarily suspended payment of its distribution to stapled security holders due to a demand for immediate repayment of a $341 million loan, and is working to achieve the best outcome for its security holders amid a dire global hospitality environment.

site_title: Thailand expects more rice exports as virus outbreak troubles competitors
summary: Thai rice exporters expect to increase sales in the second quarter due to global food security concerns and competitors' export bans or lockdowns. The spread of coronavirus has disrupted India's export plans and Vietnam's rice export contracts, creating a better outlook for Thai rice. Thailand's rice exports are expected to improve, with a forecasted 7.5 million tonnes export target for 2020, as benchmark Thai 5% white rice prices reach their highest levels since August 2013, at US$481.50 per tonne.

images.alt_text: Thai rice exporters expect to increase sales as the spread of coronavirus sparks global food security concerns and major competitors face export bans or go into lockdown to battle the outbreak.

site_title: S&P says major Australia banks not at risk of downgrade amid pandemic
summary: Major Australian banks are not at risk of downgrade due to the pandemic, according to S&P Global. The agency expects credit losses to more than triple in 2020 but believes major banks can withstand losses surging to six times 2019 levels. Capital at most banks is expected to remain stable despite lower net earnings and dividend payouts. However, a more severe and longer-lasting downturn could trigger downgrades. The Reserve Bank of Australia's actions and the prudential regulator's loosened capital requirements also support the banks' resilience.

site_title: Bid rigging by 3 Singapore firms in swimming pool tenders for condos, hotels: CCCS
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has proposed an infringement decision against three firms, CU Water Services, Crystalene Product (S), and Crystal Clear Contractor, for bid-rigging in swimming pool maintenance tenders for condominiums and hotels from 2008 to 2017. The firms allegedly colluded through cover-bidding arrangements, submitting higher quotes than intended, and denied customers competitive pressure. The CCCS investigation began in 2017 and the companies have until then to make individual representations.

site_title: Singapore banks face first test on credit cost projections amid virus outbreak: Citi
summary: Singapore banks are facing their first test on credit cost projections amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced measures to provide relief to distressed property owners and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), including deferments on debt repayments and payments on insurance policies. Citi analyst Robert Kong views this as a "first real test" for how Singapore banks project against a broad macro downturn, given new accounting standards that reflect a certain amount of procyclicality.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge up for the day, but mark worst quarter in 18 years
summary: Europe's stock markets ended higher on Tuesday, closing up 1.7% for the day, despite marking their worst quarter in nearly 18 years due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Stoxx 600 index lost 23% for the quarter, with energy and travel stocks leading gains, while Italian and German stocks suffered significant losses. Analysts remain cautious, citing a volatile trading environment, and warn that the gains may not hold.

site_title: Auto industry races to make ventilators during virus crisis
summary: The auto industry is rapidly producing medical ventilators to address the global shortage during the coronavirus pandemic. General Motors, Ford, PSA, Renault, and Formula 1 engineers are joining forces to manufacture ventilators, with the goal of producing 10,000 units in France by mid-May. However, some experts question the suitability of car manufacturers for assembling medical equipment, citing their reliance on overseas suppliers and limited experience in medical device production. Despite these concerns, car manufacturers claim they are up to the task, with Renault developing a prototype using state-of-the-art equipment.

site_title: 3M to boost US production of respirator masks to 50m as demand soars
summary: 3M plans to ramp up US monthly production of N95 respirator masks to 50 million in June, doubling capacity to meet surge in demand from healthcare professionals battling the coronavirus pandemic. The company aims to produce 2 billion N95 respirators globally within the next year. The US Department of Health and Human Services has ordered 500 million masks, and 3M is working with hospitals to safely clean and reuse respirators.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher but virus uncertainty casts shadow
summary: Asian markets were mostly higher on Wednesday, despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and uncertainty about the global economy. The region's stocks have been volatile, with some countries experiencing a return to growth, such as China. However, lockdowns and containment measures are expected to persist, fueling concerns about the economy's outlook. Investors are weighing trillions of dollars in global stimulus, but the risk of prolonged weakness and permanent damage remains.

site_title: Trump calls for US$2t infrastructure spending
summary: President Donald Trump proposed a $2 trillion US infrastructure spending package, citing low interest rates and the need for jobs and rebuilding the country's infrastructure. This comes a week after signing a $2 trillion economic relief bill. While Republicans have been skeptical, Democrats support the idea, which is gaining traction due to soaring unemployment. Economists warn that businesses will struggle to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1% at the start of trade on Wednesday, following a sell-off on Wall Street, amid investor concerns over the coronavirus crisis. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 23,365.90, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses follow a global market downturn and come as investors continue to be rattled by the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Citigroup to pay HK$8,000 bonus to some Hong Kong staff
summary: Citigroup will award a HK$8,000 bonus to approximately 75,000 employees globally, including those in Hong Kong with an annual base salary of HK$470,000 or less. The bank aims to support staff affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic. Additionally, Citigroup is extending the deadline for using carry-over vacation days to the end of December.

site_title: Singapore private home prices fall 1.2% q-o-q in Q1 2020: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private home prices fell 1.2% in Q1 2020, according to the URA flash estimate. This marks a decline from the 0.5% increase in Q4 2019. Prices of non-landed properties eased 1% quarter-over-quarter, while landed properties dropped 1.7%. The decline is attributed to the COVID-19 outbreak, with restrictions on foreign buyers and job security concerns affecting local buyers. Experts predict a further 2-3% decline in the overall private home price index this year.

site_title: JPMorgan launches FX trading engine in Singapore
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has launched an FX trading and pricing engine in Singapore, aiming to speed up trade executions for clients. The platform, supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, covers a full range of FX and precious metals, and is JPMorgan's fourth electronic FX trading infrastructure platform. This launch is part of the central bank's efforts to develop Singapore into a global price discovery and liquidity centre for FX during Asia trading hours. The platform is expected to support increased trading flows in Singapore, particularly with market volumes and volatility at record levels.

site_title: Fed gives central banks wider access to US dollars with repo agreement
summary: The US Federal Reserve has expanded access to US dollars for foreign central banks, allowing them to exchange US Treasury securities for overnight dollar loans. The programme aims to support the US Treasury market and provide an alternative source of US dollars, particularly for central banks with less widely traded currencies. The facility, which will last for at least six months, is expected to help stabilize foreign dollar markets and bolster broader market confidence, ultimately benefiting the US economy.

site_title: How technology is maintaining human connections during tough times
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, technology has played a crucial role in maintaining human connections among SMEs in Singapore. The government's initiative to develop business continuity planning (BCP) guides has encouraged flexible work arrangements, which were previously a concern for SME owners due to the impact on team dynamics. However, technology, particularly cloud solutions, has helped SMEs overcome this challenge by fostering seamless teamwork, enabling real-time communication, and providing essential tools for collaboration and decision-making. As a result, technology has not only helped SMEs cope with the pandemic but also improved productivity, communication, and stakeholder connections.

site_title: Private equity can't just hide out in a wooded bungalow
summary: Private equity firms, which have seen record-high capital commitments, are facing challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic. Investors are fleeing, and SoftBank's Vision Fund is seeking billions to support its portfolio companies. The firm's debt-heavy investments are under pressure, and lenders are struggling to provide aid to smaller companies. With blue chips drawing significant credit lines, lenders may not have the bandwidth to assist smaller firms. The pandemic is expected to exacerbate corporate defaults, with Moody's warning of a global default rate of 16.1% if economic conditions mirror the Great Recession.

site_title: Shanghai steel tumbles as coronavirus crisis clouds demand
summary: Shanghai steel futures plummeted to their lowest in 3.5 months amid the coronavirus pandemic, with hot-rolled coil (HRC) prices dropping 2.5% to 3,181 yuan per tonne. Demand from manufacturing sectors such as autos and home appliances is weak, and exports of China's steel products slumped 27% in January-February. Some steelmakers plan to increase production capacity, which could further pressure prices. The decline is attributed to the pandemic's impact on global demand and supply chains.

site_title: Oil prices fall as US inventory build-up heightens oversupply concerns
summary: Global crude oil prices fell further on Wednesday, nearing their lowest since 2002, amid a bigger-than-expected rise in US inventories and a widening rift within Opec. US crude inventories rose 10.5 million barrels last week, and Brent crude was down 47 cents, or 1.8%, at $25.88 a barrel. The market remains bleak due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis, with analysts forecasting a 36% decline in Brent prices for 2020. A rift within Opec and the US administration's decision to lease out space for energy companies to store oil in the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve also contributed to the downward pressure.

site_title: Dean & Deluca files for bankruptcy protection from creditors
summary: Dean & Deluca, a US gourmet grocer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors due to liabilities of up to $500 million and assets of $50 million. The company, which was struggling amid competition and lackluster sales, listed Thailand's Pace Development as its owner. The bankruptcy filing comes after the owner defaulted on $412 million of debt last year, further exacerbating the company's financial struggles.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on upbeat China data
summary: Australian shares ended 3.6% higher on Wednesday, led by the energy and mining sectors, following upbeat China data. China's factory activity improved in March, but growth was minimal, and the country plans to step up fiscal and monetary policy adjustments. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level since March 17, with financial stocks closing 2.6% higher. Despite concerns over China's recession, investors remain optimistic about the market's potential for recovery.

site_title: No Signboard shuts Clarke Quay restaurant for at least a month to 'control costs'
summary: No Signboard, a Singapore-based seafood restaurant chain, has temporarily closed its Clarke Quay restaurant for at least a month to control costs amid a challenging local food and beverage industry due to the global coronavirus outbreak and travel restrictions. The company cited uncertain economic outlook and expected negative impact on tourist and consumer spending from the second quarter of 2020. The closure is part of its efforts to improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise at open
summary: Australian shares rose 3% on Wednesday, marking the first positive day in the new quarter, as investors expect stimulus measures to soften the economic impact of the coronavirus. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 2.2% to 5,188, driven by energy stocks, including Woodside Petroleum and Santos Ltd, which rose 9.3% and 10.2%, respectively. Despite economists predicting a recession, the Australian government's A$320 billion stimulus package and the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate cuts have boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Ascott chief takes on additional remit as lodging CEO at CapitaLand
summary: CapitaLand appoints Kevin Goh as chief executive, lodging, effective April 1, 2020, in addition to his role as chief executive of The Ascott, which he has held since January 2018. Goh's focus will be on growing the lodging business, a key pillar for sustainable growth. He has been with CapitaLand since May 2007 and previously held roles at The Ascott. The appointment follows the company's regulatory update, which also mentioned its growth strategies.

site_title: SingPost confirms 6th virus case among staff, none are postmen
summary: SingPost has confirmed its 6th staff member tested positive for the coronavirus, with none involving postmen or public contact staff. The employee, a team leader, works at a mail sorting facility and uses a separate entrance, minimizing risk. The company cleaned and disinfected its facility over the weekend and has no evidence of mail-related transmission. One person has recovered from the virus, and several staff members in contact with confirmed cases are serving quarantine orders. Mail processing and deliveries remain unaffected.

site_title: Singapore firms to cut hirings while increasing training, flexi-work arrangements: poll
summary: Singapore firms are reducing hiring spending while increasing training and flexible work arrangements to cope with the COVID-19 outbreak. 232 firms polled plan to reduce spending on hiring, while 12% and 13% increase budgets for training and flexible work arrangements. Only 1% consider retrenching staff, and a third of firms have cut or revised pay increments. Real estate and construction sectors are hit the hardest, with salary increments reduced by 0.8%. Despite this, companies remain committed to protecting employees' livelihoods.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Fu Yu to 'hold' amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Fu Yu Corporation to "hold" due to a 25% estimated fall in FY2020 earnings due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The bank-brokerage lowered its FY2020 revenue forecast to S$157 million from S$175 million. Despite this, Fu Yu's shares have fallen by 30% since January, making it an attractive merger and acquisition target. The downgrade is mainly due to global supply chain disruptions and an economic slowdown.

site_title: Australia to charter planes full of fresh produce to markets including China, Japan, Singapore
summary: Australia's government will charter planes to transport fresh produce to key markets, including China, Japan, and Singapore, with an initial investment of A$110 million. The flights will depart from Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, and Perth, and will also carry medical supplies, medicines, and equipment back to Australia. Demand for Australian produce in China and other Asian markets has started to recover as restaurants reopen, and the support aims to reduce job losses and aid economic recovery.

site_title: Museum world's King of Memes brings humour to Covid-19 lockdown
summary: The Royal Academy of Arts in London used humor to cope with the COVID-19 pandemic lockdown by asking Twitter users to draw the best ham, resulting in dozens of creative submissions. The social media editor, Adam Koszary, has been praised for his quirky approach to online engagement, which has inspired other museums to follow suit. Koszary's unconventional methods, including a tweet about a "absolute unit" sheep, have garnered significant attention and even landed him a job at Tesla before he returned to the Royal Academy.

site_title: LYS Energy obtains S$14m green loan from UOB
summary: LYS Energy, a Singapore-based solar company, has obtained a S$14 million green loan from United Overseas Bank (UOB) under the bank's Green Infrastructure Framework. The loan will be used to finance LYS's solar energy assets in Singapore and support the company's expansion in the region. Founded in 2012, LYS has deployed over 50 MWp of solar photovoltaic systems and has a pipeline of over 500 MWp in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: Keppel Land China selling mixed-use property for 473.5m yuan
summary: Keppel Land China is selling a mixed-use property in Jiangyin, China for 473.5 million yuan (S$94.5 million). The buyer, Aoyuan Group Chongqing Property Co, will pay 278.8 million yuan and an additional 194.7 million yuan to repay a loan. The sale is part of Keppel Land China's strategy to recycle capital and rebalance its portfolio in high-growth cities in China, with no expected impact on Keppel Corp's financials. The transaction is expected to complete in the third quarter of 2020.

site_title: OUE offers retail tenants up to 25% rent reductions, flexible payment
summary: OUE, a Singapore property group, offers retail tenants up to 25% rent reductions and flexible payment schemes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company will also pass on government property tax rebates to tenants in full. Additionally, tenants will receive a waiver of gross rental for the month of April. OUE's deputy CEO, Brian Riady, stated that the company is prepared to introduce further rental relief initiatives if necessary.

site_title: Fifa studying coronavirus 'assistance' to world football
summary: Fifa is planning to offer assistance to world football due to the coronavirus pandemic's financial impact. The global governing body has $1.5 billion in reserve and is studying various forms of assistance with members, federations, and partners. A support fund may be announced before the weekend, and a working group has been established to aid continental governing bodies affected by the crisis. This move aims to support football seasons and leagues that have been postponed or disrupted by the pandemic.

site_title: Australia to subsidise air freight for agri exports to offset virus freeze
summary: Australia's government will spend A$110 million to subsidise air freight for agricultural exports to China, Japan, and other countries due to the global COVID-19 pandemic's disruption to flights. The subsidy aims to support farmers and fishers hit hard by the crisis. About 90% of air freight in Australia is usually used for tourist transportation, but this will be redirected to export agricultural products such as Wagyu beef, rock lobster, and cherries. The funding is part of Australia's first economic stimulus package, worth A$1 billion, to respond to the pandemic.

site_title: Covid-19: New Bill to give temporary relief from contractual obligations
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Bill to provide temporary relief for six months to individuals and businesses struggling with contractual obligations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Bill, which will be introduced in Parliament next week, will allow tenants to avoid eviction, deposits to be spared, and bankruptcy thresholds to be temporarily raised. The measures cover various types of contracts, including leases, construction contracts, and loan facilities, and will be in place until October 2020. The goal is to provide "breathing space" for companies to navigate the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Shell slows refining, takes up to US$800m hit after oil crash
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has slowed refining output and expects a US$800 million hit due to the coronavirus-driven drop in oil demand. The company lowered its refining output by 13% and expects 25% lower consumption compared to 2019. Shell also lowered its oil and gas price outlook and reported a post-tax impairment charge in the range of US$400 million to US$800 million. The company's shares rose 5% in early trading.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit manager's chief investment officer quits
summary: Thierry Leleu, 52, the chief investment officer of Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust, has resigned on September 25 to focus on his entrepreneurial activities. Leleu joined the company in 2017 and played a key role in its post-listing success, overseeing acquisitions and divestments. His departure follows the completion of two recent deals, including the acquisition of German properties and the sale of 12 European assets. Units of Cromwell E-Reit fell 2.8% on the news.

site_title: Museums scramble to document the pandemic, even as it unfolds
summary: Museums worldwide are documenting the COVID-19 pandemic, collecting firsthand accounts, photographs, and objects to preserve everyday life during the crisis. In Finland, the National Museum of Finland is tracking the situation in the Uusimaa region, while in Denmark, the Vesthimmerlands Museum is collecting diaries and photographs of daily life under lockdown. Other museums, such as the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, are also acquiring objects related to the pandemic, including devices for hands-free opening and consumer culture artifacts. The goal is to capture the historic moment for future generations, despite the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: US: Dow ends lower, suffers biggest quarterly loss since 1987
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended Tuesday at 21,917.16, down over 400 points, marking its worst quarterly loss since 1987 amid the coronavirus outbreak. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also suffered significant losses, with the S&P 500 shedding 1.6% and the Nasdaq shedding 1%. The US economy is expected to enter a recession due to government shutdowns and declining consumer confidence, with the Conference Board reporting a 23% quarterly loss for the blue-chip index.

site_title: Gold rises 1% on flight to safety driven by pandemic fears
summary: Gold prices rose 1% to $1,587.31 per ounce on Wednesday as investors sought safety amid worsening coronavirus fears and expectations of monetary easing by central banks. The rebound was also driven by US President Donald Trump's remarks that the next two weeks of the pandemic could be painful for the US. The US Federal Reserve expanded access to US dollars for foreign central banks, increasing liquidity and supporting gold's rally. Meanwhile, physical gold supply was limited due to production suspensions in Switzerland and Russia.

images.alt_text: Gold rose on Wednesday as fears over a worsening coronavirus pandemic triggered a flight to safety, with expectations of further monetary easing by central banks adding support.

site_title: UK reports record 381 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours
summary: Britain reported a record daily coronavirus toll of 381, surpassing the previous 24-hour high of 260. As of March 30, 1,789 people have died in the UK, with 25,150 testing positive for the virus. The true death toll may be 24% higher, according to data from the Office for National Statistics. The government's social distancing guidance remains in place, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson stating that the situation will worsen before it improves.

images.alt_text: Britain reported a record daily coronavirus toll of 381 on Tuesday, more than double the number of nationwide deaths posted in the previous 24 hours.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, OUE, Yanlord, Ascendas Reit, Hong Leong Asia
summary: Keppel Corp sold a mixed-use property in China for S$94.5 million, with shares gaining 1%. OUE lowered rents by 15-25% for retail tenants amid the coronavirus outbreak. Yanlord Land Group reported estimated pre-sales of S$572.7 million, while Ascendas Reit acquired a 25% stake in Galaxis for S$102.9 million. Hong Leong Asia's net profit grew 39.1% to S$34.4 million. Other stocks saw changes, including OUE C-Reit, SATS, and No Signboard.

site_title: Electricity tariffs to fall 5.1% in Q2 on lower energy costs: SP Group
summary: SP Group announced a 5.1% decrease in electricity tariffs for Q2, averaging 1.22 Singapore cents per kWh, due to lower energy costs. Households will see a decrease in their electricity tariff from 24.24 to 23.02 cents per kWh, resulting in a S$3.89 reduction in average monthly bills for four-room HDB flats. Additionally, SP Group will defer increasing network costs for one year to help manage costs during the Covid-19 outbreak, reducing the electricity tariff by 2.5%.

site_title: Fed takes on role of world's central bank by pumping out dollars
summary: The Federal Reserve is taking on a key role in the global financial system by providing dollar liquidity to combat the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The Fed is establishing a temporary repurchase agreement facility to allow foreign central banks to swap Treasury securities for cash, helping to prevent a liquidity squeeze and supporting the US government debt market. The move aims to mitigate the risks of emerging-market borrowers facing a dollar crunch, while also considering the potential downsides of a stronger dollar on US exports and the global economy.

site_title: Xerox abandons US$35b hostile bid for HP
summary: Xerox Holdings Corp has abandoned its $35 billion hostile bid for HP Inc due to the coronavirus outbreak, prioritizing employee health and well-being over the takeover campaign. The decision marks a victory for HP CEO Enrique Lores and a defeat for Xerox CEO John Visentin. Xerox had faced significant financial and strategic benefits in a potential combination with HP, but the market turmoil fueled by the pandemic led to a halt in mergers and acquisitions.

images.alt_text: US printer maker Xerox Holdings Corp walked away from its US$35 billion hostile cash-and-stock bid for HP Inc on Tuesday, after the coronavirus outbreak weighed on its campaign to take over the PC and printing equipment manufacturer.

site_title: Macau's gaming revenues tumble 79.7% in March, hit by coronavirus
summary: Macau's gaming revenues plummeted 79.7% in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the government reporting 5.3 billion patacas (S$944.8 million) in revenue, a 79.7% drop from the previous year. Casinos are struggling to stay afloat, with daily losses ranging from $1.5 million to $4 million. The government now expects a 56% drop in annual gross gaming revenue this year, down from 260 billion patacas forecast last year, with many analysts predicting further declines until the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Pandemic has thrown up unexpected issues of the digital age
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the challenges of the digital age, with the spread of disinformation and panic-inducing information posing significant threats to public health and economic stability. The use of advanced surveillance methods has raised concerns about government intrusions into individual privacy, while the rapid dissemination of information through social media has made it difficult for governments to control the narrative. As governments navigate this new landscape, they must balance the need to protect public health with the need to safeguard individual freedoms and prevent the misuse of technology.

site_title: New York transformed as US virus death toll exceeds China's
summary: The US virus death toll has surpassed China's, with over 1,000 New Yorkers dying from COVID-19. Emergency field hospitals have been set up in New York's Central Park and the US Open venue, with a goal to triple hospital capacity to prepare for the pandemic's peak. The city has seen over 181,000 cases and 3,606 deaths, with Governor Andrew Cuomo warning that the fight to defeat COVID-19 will be a long one.

images.alt_text: Emergency field hospitals have begun going up in New York's Central Park and at the home of the US Open, as the number of coronavirus deaths in America on Tuesday surpassed those reported by China.

site_title: SPH Magazines offers free 3-month digital subscriptions
summary: SPH Magazines is offering free 3-month digital subscriptions to Singaporeans due to the COVID-19 outbreak, providing access to various titles including beauty, fashion, and luxury lifestyle magazines. The complimentary subscriptions are available through the myNEWSSTAND app and can be redeemed online. The move aims to "encourage and inspire" Singaporeans during the challenging times.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.5% to 2,467.95, its worst quarter since the Global Financial Crisis. Losers outnumbered gainers 85 to 24, with Genting Singapore trading flat and ESR-Reit falling 1.7%. The US Dow suffered its worst quarterly loss since 1987, while European stock markets also clocked their worst quarter in nearly 18 years.

site_title: March marks market's worst showing since GFC
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced its worst performance since the 2008 global financial crisis in March, with a 16% decline. The market capitalization of the Singapore stock universe fell to S$711.7 billion, and blue-chip stocks lost 17.4% in value. The top 10 losers included banks, telcos, and real estate investment trusts, while Top Glove and the Singapore Exchange were among the top gainers. The decline was attributed to rising credit costs, falling interest rates, and the global pandemic.

site_title: Coronavirus the worst global crisis since WWII: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres described the coronavirus pandemic as the worst global crisis since World War II, citing its threat to global stability and economic impact. The pandemic's scale and economic impact are unprecedented, with a recession likely to have no parallel in recent history. Guterres expressed concern that the crisis could trigger conflicts worldwide, making it the most challenging crisis since WWII.

site_title: American Airlines to apply for US$12b in government relief
summary: American Airlines is the first US carrier to request federal aid under the US$2 trillion "Cares" Act, seeking US$12 billion to survive the global downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline aims to use the funds to avoid deep layoffs and maintain essential services. With air travel severely impacted, the US Transportation Security Administration reported 154,080 travelers on Monday, down from nearly 2.4 million last year. The airline industry is expected to lose US$252 billion in revenues in 2020.

site_title: US investigates video conferencing app Zoom over porn hacks
summary: The US is investigating video conferencing app Zoom after users reported being startled by porn and hate images during meetings. The FBI has received multiple reports of "Zoom-bombed" schools, including a Massachusetts high school where a person with swastika tattoos appeared on screen. Zoom has seen a surge in popularity during the pandemic, with 4.2 million downloads in the US in March. The company has promised to take steps to ensure users' privacy and security, and New York Attorney General Letitia James is working with Zoom to resolve any issues.

site_title: Singapore banks may see worst-case hit of 14-18% on revenue over consumer relief: Jefferies
summary: Singapore banks may see a 14-18% hit to revenue in 2020 due to consumer relief measures amid the virus crisis, according to Jefferies Research. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced measures to defer debt repayments for distressed property owners and SMEs. Jefferies analyst Krishna Guha expects DBS and OCBC to see a 14-16% hit and UOB a 18% hit, respectively, but notes that lower credit costs will cushion the negative impact. Despite the concerns, Jefferies maintains its "buy" call on DBS and OCBC and "hold" recommendation on UOB.

site_title: Apple doubles China donations for Covid-19 recovery efforts
summary: Apple has doubled its donation to China's Covid-19 recovery efforts to over 50 million yuan (US$7 million), according to CEO Tim Cook. This comes after the company donated 10 million masks for health professionals in the US and Europe. Apple had previously pledged 20 million yuan to support six hospitals in Hubei, including the Leishenshan hospital in Wuhan. The company's donation will support longer-term public health recovery efforts in China.

site_title: US, South Korea scramble to seal defence cost-sharing deal as thousands put on unpaid leave
summary: The US and South Korea are scrambling to reach a defence cost-sharing deal, with over 4,000 local workers placed on unpaid leave due to a dispute over the US's demand for Seoul to pay up to $5 billion annually. USFK Commander General Robert Abrams urged negotiators to quickly resolve the issue, while a South Korean negotiator expressed regret over the US's decision to proceed with the furloughs. A potential agreement could be announced as early as Wednesday, according to Yonhap news agency.

site_title: Airbnb to pay out US$250m to hosts to help ease coronavirus cancellation pain
summary: Airbnb is allocating $250 million to help offset losses by hosts due to the coronavirus pandemic. The aid will pay hosts 25% of their normal cancellation fees for bookings cancelled between March 14 and May 31. The payments are being funded by Airbnb itself and will begin in April. The company also established a $10 million relief fund for its top-rated hosts and worked to secure support for hosts in the US stimulus bill. CEO Brian Chesky expressed confidence in Airbnb's recovery after the pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says rupiah rate 'adequate', will try to prevent fall
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the current rupiah exchange rate of 16,410 per US dollar is "adequate" and that authorities are prepared to prevent a historic low. The rate was previously forecasted to drop to 17,500-20,000 per US dollar in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic. Warjiyo clarified that there are no plans for capital control, but the central bank may ask exporters to convert earnings into local currency.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Boosting our immunity to fight off COVID-19
summary: Dr. Julian Ng, a resident doctor at DTAP Clinic Group, discusses the importance of strengthening our immune systems to protect against COVID-19. He emphasizes that a healthy diet, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep can boost our immunity. Dr. Ng also highlights the role of nutrition in fighting off the virus, suggesting that foods rich in antioxidants and omega-3 fatty acids can help. By taking proactive steps to improve our immune systems, we can reduce our risk of contracting COVID-19 and other illnesses.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei tumbles on growing virus concern
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 4% on Wednesday, mirroring an Asia-wide decline, due to growing concerns over the coronavirus outbreak and potential lockdowns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 4.50% to 18,065.41, its third consecutive drop. A key survey showed Japan's manufacturers' confidence plunged into negative territory for the first time in seven years, with the Bank of Japan's Tankan business survey reporting a minus-eight reading among major manufacturers. Market sentiment remains fragile, with traders watching infection figures and awaiting a possible Tokyo lockdown's impact.

site_title: Solstad Offshore, creditors agree on draft restructuring plan
summary: Solstad Offshore, a Norwegian offshore service vessel supplier, has agreed on a draft restructuring plan with creditors. The plan involves converting 10 billion Norwegian krone (S$1.38 billion) of debt into equity, with secured lenders, leasing companies, and bondholders expected to sign a binding agreement by the end of April. The company aims to reduce its fleet by 37 older vessels, keeping about 90 vessels, and retain up to a third of shares for existing industrial shareholders. A successful restructuring will enable the company to adapt to reduced global offshore activity.

site_title: Taiwan to spend NT$1.05t fighting virus, to donate 10m masks
summary: Taiwan has increased its estimated spending to combat the COVID-19 pandemic to NT$1.05 trillion (US$35 billion), with a focus on stimulus packages and mask donations. The government plans to donate 10 million face masks to needy countries, including the US, European countries, and countries with formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan. Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen emphasized the need for global cooperation and support for medical workers, while also highlighting the island's efforts to share its knowledge and experience with the world.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds: The quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds has not been mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: UK banks scrap dividends on coronavirus fears, pressure on bonuses
summary: UK's top banks, including Barclays, HSBC, and Lloyds Banking Group, have suspended dividend payments due to pressure from the regulator to conserve capital amid the economic fallout from the novel coronavirus. The move is expected to free up £8 billion for lending to businesses and consumers. The Prudential Regulatory Authority (PRA) also asked banks to halt senior staff bonuses. The decision follows similar moves by the European Central Bank and several European lenders.

site_title: US dollar firms as investors brace for global downturn
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies, driven by its safe-haven status amid the coronavirus pandemic. The dollar rose 0.2% against the yen, euro, and pound, while easing against emerging markets. However, its value remains below multi-year peaks. The US Federal Reserve expanded dollar liquidity measures, and analysts expect a grim economic outlook, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a 34% sequential decline in US GDP this quarter. Factory activity in Asia contracted, and manufacturing data from Japan and South Korea showed the biggest declines in about a decade.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was a touch firmer on Wednesday, buoyed by its safe-haven status with the world staring at what is likely to be one of the worst economic contractions for decades as it locks down to fight the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower following US losses
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Wednesday, extending losses on Wall Street amid a broader market rout over the coronavirus outbreak. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.9% and the Topix index fell 1.8%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 2%. The US economy shut major parts of its economy, leading to a 23% loss in the blue-chip index for the quarter. Investors are cautious due to concerns over the new coronavirus and US shares, with the dollar trading at 107.36 yen.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened lower on Wednesday, extending losses on Wall Street amid a broader market rout over the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: WeWork offers half off to some tenants signing longer leases
summary: WeWork is offering half off rent to some tenants signing longer leases, particularly those on month-to-month contracts, to minimize cancellations during the pandemic. This is part of a larger effort to reduce expenses, following the company's decision to cut 250 jobs. WeWork's financial targets for 2020 have been adjusted due to the pandemic's impact on the global workforce. The company is also competing with WeWork competitor Knotel Inc, which plans to reduce its headcount by half.

site_title: StanChart says its US$100b AUM target is still on track
summary: Standard Chartered's private banking assets are on track to reach US$100 billion in the next two to four years, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, according to senior executive Didier von Daeniken. The bank has been reshaping its Asia-focused private banking business, hiring 40 bankers annually since 2016 and automating its platforms. Underlying operating income grew 12% to US$577 million in FY19, and assets under management rose 14% to US$67.1 billion. The bank aims to be a top performer in terms of return on tangible equity and is targeting a higher average client asset size of US$20 million.

site_title: London landlords dump holiday lets on residential market
summary: London landlords are dumping short-term holiday rentals on the traditional letting market due to the Covid-19 pandemic, resulting in a surge of available properties and a decline in rents. In the two weeks ending March 9, inner London areas saw a 10%+ increase in properties with asking price cuts, with the richest boroughs experiencing the largest declines. This shift is expected to put financial pressure on landlords, particularly those relying on short-term rentals, and could lead to excess selling in the market, pushing prices down.

site_title: Australian shops ration booze to foil hoarders amid virus shutdowns
summary: Australian retailers have implemented limits on alcohol purchases amid a surge in drink buying due to social distancing measures and panic buying. Supermarket chains Woolworths Group and Coles Group agreed to restrict sales for each shopper to prevent hoarders from stockpiling liquor. The measures follow the initial panic buying of toilet paper and other household essentials during the coronavirus shutdown. Authorities have assured that there is enough product available, but the retailers are taking steps to prevent shortages and maintain fair access to essential items.

site_title: The role of Asia's central banks is being challenged by Covid-19
summary: Asia's central banks responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by implementing monetary policy actions, including rate cuts and asset purchases. Following the Federal Reserve's lead, central banks in the Asia-Pacific region lowered their policy rates and increased their asset purchases. However, fiscal responses are growing, and harder questions about central bank limits are emerging. The emphasis on fiscal policy will likely increase, and Asian central banks may become more integrated into their national teams, potentially leading to a shift in the balance of power.

site_title: Shipping industry is sailing into rough seas
summary: The international shipping industry is facing significant challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Several cruise ships, including the Holland America Line's MS Zaandam, have reported outbreaks of the virus, resulting in four deaths among elderly passengers. Crew members are also at risk, with more infected than passengers, due to their close living quarters. The cruise sector is largely shut down, and countries have banned cruise calls, while some operators are still selling sailings. To support the sector, Singapore has announced economic relief measures, including extending port dues concessions to passenger vessels until the end of the year.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's Wilson says retest of S&P 500 lows unlikely
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief US equity strategist Mike Wilson predicts the S&P 500 Index won't retest its lows due to forced liquidations in the market. Unlike previous downturns, such as the 2018 December rout, Wilson believes a new liquidation phase is unlikely. He forecasts the S&P 500 to end the year at 2,700, about 3.5% higher than current levels. Wilson attributes the market's resilience to unprecedented fiscal and monetary stimulus efforts, which he believes will cushion the economic blow from the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Fearless Girl statue stands in front of the New York Stock Exchange near Wall Street. Some investors are wondering if the worst is over as dramatic price swings ease amid unprecedented stimulus efforts.

site_title: The rent is due but many Americans can't pay the bills
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted millions of Americans, leaving them unable to pay rent and other bills. Many, like Brittany and Matthew, a New York couple, have had to make difficult decisions, including paying only minimum credit card balances and applying for student loan deferment. The federal government's $2.2 trillion aid package will help ease the economic pain, but many face uncertainty until the second half of April when $1,200 checks are set to arrive. A record 3.3 million Americans have filed for unemployment, and some, like Tammy Devitoe, are turning to crowdfunding to make ends meet.

site_title: Japan's factory output expected to drop in March
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 0.4% in February, slower than the 1.0% increase in January, but factories expect a 5.3% decline in March. Retail sales rose 1.7% in February, while job availability fell to a near three-year low. Economists predict a deep stagnation and possible recession, citing the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, with some forecasting a deeper contraction in April-June.

site_title: Met Museum extends staff pay until May 2 amid virus outbreak
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City has extended staff pay until May 2 amid the coronavirus pandemic, providing job security for its 2,200 employees. The four-week extension aims to support staff financially during the crisis. The museum, which had previously guaranteed salary payments until Saturday, is exploring options to dip into its $3.6 billion endowment fund. Other museums, such as the American Museum of Natural History, have also taken measures to support staff, including reducing pay and requiring employees to take vacation days.

site_title: Oil giants in standoff over price and supply: Who will blink first?
summary: Oil-producing countries Saudi Arabia and Russia are in a standoff over price and supply, amid the global coronavirus crisis. Saudi Arabia, led by Opec, wants to cut oil supplies by 1.5 million barrels a day, while Russia refuses, citing US shale oil producers' interests. The dispute has raised concerns about the global economy and the US shale oil industry's survival. US President Donald Trump plans to speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin to resolve the issue, potentially leading to a hard bargain and a favorable outcome for the US.

site_title: Ascendas Reit takes 25% stake in Galaxis for S$102.9m
summary: Ascendas Reit has acquired a 25% stake in Galaxis for S$102.9 million. Located in Singapore's one-north precinct, Galaxis is expected to generate a 6.2% net property income yield. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit. Galaxis, a 17-storey building with business park and office space, is 99.6% occupied by tenants including Canon, Oracle, and Sea. The remaining lease tenure of the land is around 52 years.

site_title: AGMs must include live webcast; two possible ways to satisfy quorum: SGX RegCo
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has mandated that all annual general meetings (AGMs) held before April 30 must include a live webcast for attendees. Additionally, issuers can satisfy quorum requirements by attending with up to 10 people or any director/senior management holding shares, whichever is lower. This new rule aims to enhance transparency and accessibility for AGM attendees.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar scores best month since 2003 as local rates hold up
summary: The Hong Kong dollar experienced its largest monthly jump in 16 years, rising 0.5% in March, driven by the city's widening interest rate advantage over the US. Local interest rates firmed, leading to a 107 basis point lead over the US one-month interbank rate, and allowing for "carry trade." This, combined with mainland China's increased inflows into Hong Kong's stock market, contributed to the currency's gain. However, experts predict a less promising month in April as the currency approaches its trading limit.

site_title: IPS proposes to sell Kallang factory to StorHub for S$26m
summary: International Press Softcom (IPS) proposes to sell its Kallang factory to StorHub for S$26 million in cash, considering the property's under-utilisation and diminishing leasehold period. The six-storey factory, with a land area of 4,998 sq m, is valued at S$35 million and has not generated significant rental income. The sale will use the net proceeds for general working capital, future acquisitions, and investments. The deal is subject to shareholder and JTC approval and is expected to complete within 12 weeks or four weeks from JTC's approvals.

site_title: Guidelines out on deferment of secured loan, mortgage payments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that qualifying small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can defer principal payments on secured term loans until December 31, 2020, with over S$40 billion of borrowings eligible. This measure aims to provide relief to businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Distressed property owners can also defer both principal and interest payments, while consumers can convert outstanding balances to term loans at a reduced rate of interest. Insurance policyholders can defer premium payments for up to six months, and banks have set out their own relief packages with varying criteria.

site_title: IHH Healthcare invests in telehealth startup Doctor Anywhere
summary: IHH Healthcare co-led a US$27 million Series B investment in Singapore-based telehealth startup Doctor Anywhere, with other lead investors including Square Peg and EDBI. The investment aims to expand the platform and grow regionally.

site_title: As rest of world locks down, China tries to get shoppers out
summary: China is attempting to boost consumer spending after months of lockdowns, with authorities distributing vouchers and offering subsidies. However, the response to the campaign has been lukewarm, with many Chinese still hesitant to return to their old lives due to concerns about safety and financial pressures. Retail sales have plunged 20.5% in the first two months of the year, and the economy faces a second blow from a drop in overseas demand. Local governments are urging citizens to spend, but experts warn that more direct stimulus is needed to sustain the recovery.

images.alt_text: China needs to get the world's biggest consumer market spending again now that its outbreak has been officially contained.

site_title: Yanlord nets 2.8b yuan in pre-sales for Nanjing and Nantong apartments
summary: Yanlord Land Group achieved an estimated 2.8 billion yuan (S$572.7 million) in pre-sales for its apartment units in Nanjing and Nantong, China. The developer sold 209 apartments for 914 million yuan, 126 units for 999 million yuan, and 278 units for 910 million yuan, respectively. This reflects a progressive recovery in buyer sentiment in the Chinese property sector, with chairman Zhong Sheng Jian attributing the success to the group's ability to deliver quality developments.

site_title: TPG's market launch may end up as just a flash in the pan: analysts
summary: TPG Telecom has launched its first commercial price plan in Singapore, offering a SIM-only product for S$10 a month with 50GB of data, 300 local call minutes, and 30 SMS messages. However, analysts question the sustainability of the low price point and standard of service, citing concerns over network coverage and quality. Industry experts predict that TPG's plan may not have a significant impact on the competitive mobile market, with Singtel, StarHub, and M1 likely to introduce cheaper plans or more data to narrow the gap.

images.alt_text: Australia-listed TPG posted start-up losses of A$1.8 million (S$1.6 million) in Singapore for the six months to Jan 31, and A$68.9 million of capex for mobile network build.

site_title: Private jet demand soars, but virus-induced curbs restrict take-offs
summary: Private jet demand has surged globally due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, but supply is being restricted by heightened safety measures in Singapore. Despite this, operators serving the local market have reported varying success in fulfilling demand. The article highlights other news stories, including a $10 billion upgrade at London's Heathrow, Tesla's entry into India, and FedEx's partnership with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries.

images.alt_text: Dassault Aviation's Falcon business jet range serves many customers, including government agencies, the military and non-governmental organisations.

site_title: Feb bank lending ticks up on business loans, but weaker growth ahead expected
summary: Singapore bank lending increased 0.6% in February, driven by a 5.8% year-on-year growth in business loans, primarily to financial institutions, manufacturing, and general commerce. However, analysts predict weaker growth ahead due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak and its impact on business sentiment. Total bank lending inched up 0.2% from January, with loans to financial institutions rising 0.2% and general commerce increasing 2.4%. Despite this, economists expect slower loan growth for Singapore banks in 2020, with forecasts ranging from 3-4%.

site_title: Mitigating climate change impact on businesses
summary: Singapore, a key financial hub in Asia, is vulnerable to climate change, with rising sea levels threatening its business district and infrastructure. The government has announced plans to implement protective measures and transition to a low-carbon economy, including phasing out conventional vehicles by 2040. However, a long-term low-carbon emissions strategy requires a broader range of measures, including improving materials efficiency and recycling in the manufacturing sector. Businesses must also ensure resilience in the face of physical risks such as sea water warming, land ice melting, and disturbance in the water cycle, and consider innovative insurance solutions to mitigate financial losses.

site_title: Furniture retail 2.0
summary: Castlery, a Singapore-based online furniture retailer, has expanded globally despite having no retail experience. The company prioritizes product development over marketing, allocating 90% of its budget to product development. Founded by Declan Ee and his partners, Castlery has successfully internationalized, entering the Australian and US markets. The company has shifted to a pure online model in Australia, and in the US, where it has seen success. Castlery has implemented digital solutions to support its growth, including an automated warehouse management system and an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system. The company is also exploring features to enhance the buying experience, such as an augmented reality app.

site_title: Q1 real estate deals fall sharply across Asia-Pac
summary: Real estate deal activity in the Asia-Pacific region sank 50% year-on-year in Q1 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with China experiencing an 80% plunge in investment volumes. However, mainland China and Hong Kong are expected to rebound more quickly than the rest of the world. Despite short-term slowdown, Knight Frank estimates that urbanization will remain a positive factor for the region in the long term, with capital from private equity funds ready to be deployed. Interest rate cuts and supportive monetary policy will also support pricing once the virus is contained.

site_title: STI ends disastrous quarter on positive note
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2.7% higher on Tuesday, marking a positive end to a disastrous first quarter, which saw a 23% decline - its worst quarterly performance since 2008. China's official factory data for March beat expectations, lifting sentiment in the Asia-Pacific region. However, economists expect China's Q1 GDP to contract by 3.4% year-on-year, with a recovery expected in Q2.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales plunge record 44% in February
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales plummeted by a record 44% in February due to the coronavirus outbreak, with sales valued at HK$22.7 billion (S$4.2 billion). This is the largest drop on record, surpassing economists' forecast of a 40.3% decline. The significant decline is attributed to growing travel restrictions and social-distancing measures.

site_title: Rise in China's PMI not a signal of sustained recovery: analysts
summary: China's official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) unexpectedly rebounded to 52 in March from a record low of 35.7 in February, indicating a modest improvement in economic activity. However, analysts caution that the readings do not signal a sustained recovery due to the ongoing global coronavirus crisis, which is expected to knock foreign demand and threaten a steep economic slump. Economists forecast a steep contraction in China's first quarter gross domestic product, with some expecting a year-year slump of 9% or more.

site_title: Covid-19 effects will reverberate for years
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, with severe medical, economic, and human challenges. The virus has killed or sickened hundreds of thousands and dramatically altered daily life, threatening financial security. Governments, companies, and medical professionals are struggling to respond to the crisis, with significant challenges ahead for heavily indebted businesses and vulnerable individuals. Despite the challenges, economists believe the economy will recover steadily due to central banks' swift action and governments' fiscal stimulus. A long-term view is crucial to navigating the crisis and its aftermath, with companies and investors with a strong sense of purpose and long-term approach best positioned for success.

images.alt_text: "When we exit this crisis, the world will be different. Investors' psychology will change. Business will change. Consumption will change. And we will be more deeply reliant on our families and each other to stay safe." - BlackRock chairman and chief executive officer Larry Fink.

site_title: Laws on the way to push for telecommuting amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Singapore is set to amend its regulations to enforce telecommuting measures among employers, with the goal of reducing workplace transmissions of the Covid-19 virus. The government will increase enforcement strength five-fold and enhance the Work Life Grant to support companies in implementing telecommuting. Companies that cannot implement telecommuting may be required to implement safe distancing measures, including staggering arrival and departure hours. The move aims to reduce the spread of the virus, particularly among unlinked cases, which are of particular concern.

site_title: ExxonMobil technology to create 135 new jobs in Singapore
summary: ExxonMobil's multi-billion dollar investment in new technology at its Singapore facility will create 135 new jobs, Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean announced at a virtual ceremony. The jobs will have significant spin-offs to the economy, particularly in logistics and process construction. ExxonMobil's investment boosts Singapore's energy and chemicals sector, which employs 25,000 workers and contributes to 2.3% of the country's GDP. The new technology will increase cleaner fuels production by 48,000 barrels per day and is part of ExxonMobil's efforts to decarbonize its operations.

site_title: No ERP charges at most gantries from April 6 due to 'exceptional circumstances'
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) will suspend ERP rate reviews and temporarily reduce charges at 96% of gantries, starting April 6, due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Most gantries will be free of charge, while the remaining locations will see rates reduced by up to S$2. The decision is made to address lighter traffic and is not intended to encourage more driving. The LTA will review rates more frequently, but the next scheduled review is brought forward to end-April.

site_title: SIA's massive fund raiser a call to the faithful
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is seeking a massive cash injection of up to S$15 billion to combat the financial impact of the coronavirus. The airline, majority owned by Temasek Holdings, is proposing the massive fund raiser to save itself from financial difficulties. The move comes as SIA suffers from the economic downturn caused by the pandemic.

site_title: US authorities working on plan to allow virus-hit ship to dock
summary: US authorities are finalizing a plan to allow the coronavirus-stricken cruise ship Zaandam to dock in Florida after its operator warned that more passengers may die if left out at sea. The ship, carrying over 2,600 passengers, has already seen four deaths, with more lives at risk. The Zaandam was originally meant to dock in Fort Lauderdale on April 7 but was instead left out at sea due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Authorities are working on a plan to bring the ship to shore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Russian agri and dairy firm Don Agro posted a 16.9% drop in net profit to S$5.2 million for FY2019 due to higher cost of sales and lower harvest prices. Golden Energy completed its acquisition of Ravenswood Gold Mine in Queensland, Australia. SATS issued S$200 million worth of 5-year notes with a fixed coupon rate of 2.88% per annum. Hong Leong Asia saw a 39.1% hike in net profit to S$34.4 million for FY2019.

site_title: Dubai to inject capital into grounded Emirates Airline
summary: Dubai has announced a capital injection to support Emirates Airline, its largest carrier, amid the coronavirus crisis. The government will inject equity into the company, which has been forced to ground its passenger flights. Emirates has cut staff salaries by up to 50% to reduce costs. The move is seen as a recognition of the airline's strategic importance to Dubai's economy. The UAE's economy is also expected to take a hit, with estimated revenues of Middle East airlines expected to drop by 39% this year.

site_title: US$ surges on quarter-end flows; outlook robust
summary: The US dollar surged 0.7% to 99.88 against a basket of six currencies on Tuesday, driven by Japanese firms' demand for dollars amid the end of Japan's fiscal year and quarter-end positioning changes. The dollar rose 2.5% for the quarter, making it the biggest gainer, while the Norwegian crown fell 19% and the Australian dollar weakened 1.3%. Despite a mixed outlook on the novel coronavirus front, dollar demand remained robust, with analysts forecasting further gains.

site_title: Hong Kong's Feb private home prices fall the most in 15 months as virus spreads
summary: Hong Kong private home prices fell 2.1% in February, the largest monthly decline in 15 months, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This marks the third consecutive monthly drop, following a 0.1% decline in January. The epidemic has kept the city on lockdown, affecting shoppers and office workers. Property experts expect prices to drop 10% for the full year, with transaction volumes expected to decrease by 20-30% in the next two months. Despite a recent uptick in confirmed cases, buyers and agents do not expect a collapse in prices due to strong demand and low interest rates.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower as virus cases mount
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as coronavirus cases continued to climb, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.4% each. The Federal Reserve unveiled a new vehicle to boost market liquidity. Despite this, the US stock market edged closer to fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: Businesses with 'food shop licences' not subject to virus-related ban: police
summary: Singapore police clarified that businesses with "food shop licences" can continue operations as long as safe-distancing measures are in place, despite a recent ban on bars and entertainment venues. Establishments licensed as restaurants, snack bars, and counters can operate, but public entertainment must be suspended until April 30. This decision aims to differentiate between businesses that primarily sell food and those that provide live entertainment.

site_title: Fed to allow foreign central banks to swap US Treasury debt for cash
summary: The Federal Reserve announced a new facility, the FIMA repo facility, allowing foreign central banks to swap US Treasury debt for US dollars, starting April 6. This move aims to alleviate the cash crunch and dollar demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The facility will provide overnight lending to central banks at a modest interest rate, helping to maintain the supply of credit to US households and businesses. The operation will be in place for at least six months, supporting the smooth functioning of financial markets.

site_title: US consumer confidence fell in March to lowest since 2017
summary: US consumer confidence fell to its lowest level since 2017 in March, according to the Conference Board's index, which dropped 12.6 points to 120. The decline was attributed to the intensification of the Covid-19 pandemic and increased uncertainty about the economy and jobs. Buying plans also deteriorated, with fewer respondents indicating they'll purchase major appliances in the next six months. The drop in confidence is seen as a sign of a severe economic contraction, with further declines expected.

site_title: Help with debts for those who have trouble repaying both banks and licensed moneylenders
summary: Singapore's Credit Counselling Singapore (CCS) will provide debt management assistance to individuals struggling with both bank and licensed moneylender debts, starting Wednesday. This new program, in collaboration with the Credit Association of Singapore, aims to help those who have trouble repaying debts. The move comes amid the economic impact of COVID-19, with the Singapore economy shrinking 2.2% in the first quarter. Borrowers can seek help through online learning, group talks, or one-to-one financial counselling. This is a departure from CCS' previous focus on bank and credit card debt only.

site_title: LMIRT, First Reit announce mall, retail space closures as Jakarta considers lockdown
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo announced a potential lockdown with closures of non-essential businesses, prompting mall and retail space closures. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) and First Reit will close 23 malls and 7 retail spaces from April 1-14, while essential services will remain open with limited hours. The closures come as Indonesia struggles with 1,414 confirmed Covid-19 cases and 122 deaths. Both trusts maintain they are in compliance with debt obligations and have adequate financial reserves.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic sparks race among Israeli app developers
summary: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Israel has seen a surge in tech startups developing innovative solutions to contain transmission. Over 70 companies have created apps and technologies, including Hamagen, which uses geolocation to inform users of potential exposure, and Vocalis Health, which aims to diagnose COVID-19 through voice analysis. The Israeli defense ministry has supported Vocalis Health, while the health ministry has assured that GPS data from Hamagen remains secure. These developments reflect Israel's reputation as a hub for tech innovation, with many hospitals and research centers also exploring the use of technology to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Jakarta ups budget deficit to 5%, cuts taxes amid virus
summary: Indonesia has cut corporate taxes and temporarily scrapped a budget deficit cap to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The government allocated 405.1 trillion rupiah to fight the outbreak, pushing the budget deficit to 5.07% of GDP. The corporate tax rate was lowered to 22% from 25%, and the budget deficit cap will be relaxed until 2023. This move aims to inject stimulus into the economy and support middle- and low-income households amid concerns of widespread job losses and economic downturn.

site_title: Thailand triples cash handouts to 135b baht for workers hit by virus impact
summary: Thailand's Cabinet has agreed to triple its cash handout to 9 million workers affected by the coronavirus, increasing the total amount to 135 billion baht. The original plan was to provide 45 billion baht, and the government will finance 45 billion baht through its budget, seeking additional funding sources for the rest. The move aims to ease the economic impact of the virus.

site_title: Japan lenders tapping Fed dollars for clients, bank group says
summary: Japanese banks have tapped the US Federal Reserve for over $180 billion in dollar funding, becoming one of the largest users of the central bank's programme aimed at boosting global liquidity. This is amid the coronavirus outbreak, with banks acting as intermediaries by releasing cash into the economy. The low cost of the funds, at 0.35% for three months, has eased stress in market-sourced dollar funding, and banks' dollar funding has become more robust since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Coronavirus: Employers who don't implement telecommuting risk committing offence
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry task force has announced new regulations requiring employers to implement telecommuting measures for jobs that allow it, with the goal of reducing workplace transmissions of COVID-19. Employers who fail to comply may face fines or a Stop Work Order. The government will also enhance the Work Life Grant to support companies in implementing telecommuting. Meanwhile, the government has recorded a rise in locally transmitted cases, with 47 new confirmed cases reported on Tuesday, and has introduced measures to control the spread, including stricter safe distancing measures and the extension of the Community Health Assist Scheme.

site_title: Indonesia pushes budget deficit to 5%, cuts taxes amid virus
summary: Indonesia has cut corporate taxes to 22% and temporarily relaxed a 3% budget deficit cap to combat the coronavirus outbreak. The government will allocate $24.8 billion to fight the pandemic, increasing the budget deficit to 5.07% of GDP this year. The measures aim to shield the economy from the crisis, with the government focusing on stimulus for middle- and low-income households to sustain the economy. President Joko Widodo also declared a national health emergency and issued social distancing rules to mitigate the outbreak.

site_title: Hong Kong February retail sales post record fall on coronavirus spread
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales plummeted by a record 44% in February due to coronavirus-related travel restrictions and consumer avoidance of shopping centers. The economic downturn comes after months of anti-government protests, which have already put the economy in recession. This marks a significant decline from January's revised 21.5% drop. The spending drought poses a major challenge for the already struggling economy.

site_title: Singapore must protect present vulnerabilities and future capabilities
summary: Singapore's government has announced its second "Resilience Budget" with an additional S$48 billion to support the economy amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The package aims to cushion hard-hit businesses and vulnerable sections of society. The move comes as the global pandemic threatens economies worldwide, with the government emphasizing the need to protect present vulnerabilities and future capabilities. The package's details will continue to be analyzed and implemented to help the country navigate the economic crisis.

site_title: Welcome to the post-virus world
summary: The US and the world have entered the post-virus world, where the COVID-19 pandemic has drastically changed the way societies function. The global impact of the virus makes the old view of health emergencies not central to economies and lives obsolete. The US and Europe have under-invested in preparation, leading to vulnerability, but it's not the lack of technology that's the issue. Instead, it's the interaction of the virus with social structures and healthcare provision. A long haul is expected, but a commitment to developing and deploying scientific and organizational ideas can shorten it, and eventually, the world will prevail in this new reality.

site_title: Ascendas Reit takes 25% stake in Galaxis for S$102.9m
summary: Ascendas Reit acquired a 25% stake in Galaxis for S$102.9m. Galaxis, a business park in Singapore's one-north precinct, is expected to generate a 6.2% net property income yield. The acquisition is accretive to Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit and strengthens its portfolio. The 17-storey building has a gross floor area of 68,835 sq m and is 99.6% occupied by tenants. The remaining lease tenure is around 52 years. The transaction cost is about S$2.99m, including stamp duty and professional advisory fees.

site_title: The West's steep learning curve in containing Covid-19
summary: The global response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been hindered by a lack of experience in containing public health crises, similar to the 1918-19 Spanish Flu pandemic. European and US policymakers initially delayed and disorganized their responses, leading to a delayed and violent financial market reaction. However, central banks are taking steps to mitigate the economic impact, including massive monetary programs to buy assets and prevent a financial market freeze. Governments are also stepping in with support programs for small and medium-sized enterprises to prevent mass bankruptcies. Ultimately, a coordinated effort between central bankers and governments is needed to contain the pandemic and prevent a prolonged global recession.

site_title: SATS issues S$200m 2.9% 5-year notes
summary: SATS has issued S$200 million worth of 2.9% 5-year notes, maturing in 2025. The notes, in denominations of S$250,000, will be used for refinancing existing borrowings and general corporate purposes. The Series 001 Notes are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Wednesday. The issuance is under SATS' S$500 million multi-currency debt-issuance programme, with DBS Bank and UOB as joint lead managers and bookrunners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 22.01 points to 1,350.89 on Tuesday, driven by a higher closing volume of 3.013 billion lots worth RM2.156 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 708 to 185. This marks a positive trend for the Malaysian stock market, but the article does not provide further context or explanation for the cause of the increase.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.85% to 23,603.48, following a rally on Wall Street and a strong factory activity report from China. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also edged up 0.11%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.51%. The positive momentum was seen as a sign of investors' optimism despite global market uncertainty, including US-China trade tensions.

site_title: US retail rent negotiations get messy with US$20b due
summary: US retailers are struggling to pay April rent, with major chains like Mattress Firm and Subway postponing or slashing payments. Mall operators, such as Taubman Centers, expect to be paid, while Best Buy plans to pay rent at some locations. The coronavirus outbreak has left retailers cash-strapped, with tens of thousands of workers laid off. The federal stimulus bill is expected to provide relief, but its impact is uncertain, and many retailers plan to withhold rent payments. Landlords are facing potential losses of over $20 billion in rent, with some negotiating deals on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia posts 39.1% hike in full-year net profit to S$34.4m
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a 39.1% increase in full-year net profit to S$34.4 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2019, driven by higher business volumes and better contribution margins from its Building Materials Unit. Other income rose 46.6% to S$71.5 million, while selling and distribution expenses increased 20.0% to S$296.5 million. The company attributed the rise in expenses to higher warranty and freight costs.

site_title: Businesses with 'food shop licences' not subject to ban: police
summary: Singapore police clarified that businesses with "food shop licences" can continue operations as long as safe-distancing measures are in place and public entertainment is suspended.
