The clarification follows a recent order to shut down all bars and entertainment venues, which applies to establishments without valid food shop licences and public entertainment licenses. Licensed restaurants, snack bars, and counters can continue operations, but all forms of public entertainment must be suspended until April 30.

site_title: Yanlord nets 2.8b yuan in pre-sales for Nanjing and Nantong apartments
summary: Yanlord Land Group Limited announced an estimated 2.8 billion yuan (S$572.7 million) in pre-sales for its apartment units in Nanjing and Nantong, China. The developer sold out units at its inaugural launch of 209 apartments in Nantong and 126 of 132 units in Nanjing, generating 914 million yuan and 999 million yuan in pre-sales, respectively. This marks a progressive recovery in buyer sentiments in the Chinese property sector, which has been affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company plans to capitalize on the sales momentum with additional project launches.

site_title: Indian doctors fight coronavirus with raincoats, helmets amid lack of equipment
summary: Indian doctors are using makeshift protective gear, including raincoats and motorbike helmets, due to a severe shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) to combat the coronavirus. The shortage has left over 1,000 medical personnel concerned about becoming carriers of the virus. The Indian government has pledged to procure PPE domestically and from South Korea and China, but projections indicate over 100,000 cases by mid-May, putting the underfunded health system under strain.

site_title: American Airlines to ask for US$12b in government relief: WSJ
summary: American Airlines plans to seek $12 billion in government assistance to navigate the global aviation downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. This request is nearly a quarter of the $50 billion allocated for the industry in the US economic rescue package. The airline's CEO and president, Doug Parker and Robert Isom, expressed confidence that the funds will allow them to fly through worst-case scenarios. The Trump administration is also considering taking equity shares in airlines as part of the bailout plan.

site_title: German city follows Austria and stipulates face masks for shoppers
summary: Germany's city of Jena has introduced a new measure to slow the spread of the coronavirus, requiring face masks for shoppers and public transport users. This decision comes after Austria and follows a two-week period of closed schools, restaurants, and public gatherings. With 119 cases in Jena, the town aims to protect the population. Alternative options, such as towels or scarves, will be accepted due to face mask shortages. Germany has seen 61,913 confirmed cases and 583 deaths, with officials stressing the need to maintain social distancing measures.

site_title: STI has a positive end to its worst quarter since 2008
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2.7% higher on Tuesday, ending its worst quarterly performance since 2008. Official Chinese factory data beat expectations, lifting sentiment despite the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The STI declined 23% in Q1, but analysts expect a contraction of 3.4% in China's Q1 GDP, followed by a recovery in Q2. The market saw a positive end to the quarter, with Genting Singapore, Singtel, and ComfortDelGro advancing.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end more than 2% higher; down 20.2% for the quarter
summary: South Korean shares rose more than 2% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of another US stimulus package and data showing a rebound in China factory activities. However, the year-to-date decline was 20.2%, the largest since 2008. The KOSPI index closed at 1,754.64, with a trading volume of 1,026.76 million shares.

images.alt_text: The Seoul stock market's main KOSPI closed up 37.52 points, or 2.19 per cent, at 1,754.64.

site_title: Mortgage borrowers, SMEs can seek to defer certain debt repayment till year-end: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced measures to help mortgage borrowers and small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) defer debt repayment due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Individuals can defer principal or both principal and interest payments until December 31, 2020, with interest only accruing on the deferred principal amount. SMEs can also defer principal payments and extend loan tenures. Additionally, banks and finance companies can offer low-cost funding through the MAS Singdollar Facility to support SMEs. These measures aim to provide relief to affected individuals and businesses amid the economic downturn caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Wind-power industry heads for record year
summary: The wind power industry is expected to see a 9% capacity increase to 66,422 megawatts in 2020, down from the previously anticipated 24% expansion. The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted supply chains and investment plans worldwide, leading to downward revisions in renewable energy growth forecasts. Despite this, the industry's revenue is fixed to power-purchase contracts, providing stability. Offshore wind is expected to remain unaffected, while onshore installations may be impacted by the virus. The industry is expected to recover in the long term, with increased installations forecasted for 2021 and beyond.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend gains
summary: European stock markets rose, extending gains from the previous session, driven by a sharp rebound in oil prices and data showing a surprise increase in Chinese factory orders. London jumped 2.4%, Frankfurt climbed 2.3%, and Paris advanced 1.6%. Analysts attributed the gains to China's slow return to normal life, providing Western investors with a sense of hope.

site_title: French firms request 3.8b euros in state-guaranteed loans amid virus crisis
summary: French companies have requested nearly 3.8 billion euros in state-guaranteed loans to help them cope with the novel coronavirus crisis. This is part of a larger 300 billion euros in business loans offered by the government, 15% of France's gross domestic product. As of the current time, 21,000 companies have made a request for these loans.

site_title: Golden Energy JV completes acquisition of Australia gold mine
summary: Golden Energy's joint-venture company, Ravenswood Gold Group, has completed its acquisition of the Ravenswood Gold Mine in Queensland, Australia, for up to A$300 million. The mine has significant expansion potential and Gear shares rose 12.7% following the announcement. The acquisition was made by Gear's subsidiary Golden Investments (Australia) II and EMR Capital's nominee, Raven Gold Nominee. A completion payment of A$50 million was made to the former mine owner Carpentaria Gold.

site_title: Trump, Putin discuss oil price plunge, coronavirus
summary: US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed the plunge in oil prices and the coronavirus pandemic in a phone call. Trump expressed concern over the impact on the US energy industry and called for an increase in oil prices. The Kremlin stated that the two leaders "exchanged opinions" on the oil market and discussed bilateral relations. Trump also hinted that Putin may use the call to push for an end to US sanctions on Russia, which have been in place since Moscow's annexation of Crimea in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin discussed plunging oil prices and the coronavirus pandemic Monday, the Kremlin said, as Trump said Moscow is pressing for an end to US sanctions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down in seesaw trade
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Tuesday in volatile trade, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.88% and the Topix index dropping 2.26%. Investors remained nervous about a possible lockdown in the Japanese capital, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ExxonMobil has announced plans to deploy new technology in Singapore, creating 135 new jobs. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced new guidelines for Annual General Meetings (AGMs), requiring live webcasting and limiting physical attendance to 10 people. Meanwhile, TPG Telecom has launched a commercial SIM-only plan in Singapore, while MyRepublic has increased data caps. The National Wages Council has urged employers to support staff who want to take on a second job due to the pandemic. The STI ended 2.7% higher, marking its best quarter since 2008.

images.alt_text: The investment will create 135 new jobs with significant spin-offs to the rest of the economy in areas such as logistics, process construction and maintenance, said Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean at a virtual foundation-laying ceremony for the project.

site_title: Bouncing back from a business partner's betrayal
summary: A businesswoman, Ong Shu Huai, overcame a traumatic experience with a former business partner who attempted to extort her out of her company, Glass Curtains. She sued and eventually set up another company, The Glass Scape Group of Companies, to continue the business. Around 2017, she also became the sole distributor of Ziptrak, an Australian brand of outdoor blinds, in Singapore and Malaysia, which now turns over S$6 million annually. Through her experiences, Ong has become more resilient and careful, and emphasizes the importance of people management and self-care in her management style.

site_title: Growth in Australia coronavirus cases slows
summary: Australia reported a sustained slowdown in new coronavirus infections, with the rate of growth slowing to an average of 9% over the past three days. The country has seen 4,400 cases and 19 deaths, with the death rate below 1%. Officials warned against complacency and emphasized the need for strict social distancing policies, with penalties for those flouting rules. The government has introduced measures to boost the public health system, including a wage subsidy for businesses and the delivery of additional hospital beds and ventilators.

site_title: Newlat agrees to buy Italian dairy group Centrale Latte d'Italia
summary: Italian food group Newlat agreed to buy a 46.24% stake in dairy group Centrale Latte d'Italia (CLI) for 1 euro and 0.33 Newlat shares per CLI share. The deal will create the third largest domestic operator in the sector, boosting Newlat's revenue to 500 million euros. CLI recorded revenues of 180 million euros last year, primarily from milk and dairy products. Newlat's revenue rose 5% to 320 million euros last year, driven by pasta and dairy products, following a 35% sales increase in the first two weeks of March due to coronavirus concerns.

site_title: JTC launches Gul Ave industrial site for application
summary: JTC launched a 0.58-hectare industrial site along Gul Avenue for application with a 20-year tenure, offering a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and zoning for heavy industrial use. This is the fourth of five Reserve List sites under the 2020 industrial government land sales programme, aiming to provide more industrial development choices. The site will be released for sale if it receives an acceptable offer, following the Reserve List system.

site_title: Sino Grandness back in the black with Q4 net profit of 2.6m yuan
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry reported a net profit of 2.6 million yuan (S$522,000) for Q4 2019, reversing its net loss of 188.8 million yuan in the same period the year before. Revenue fell 24.4% to 462.3 million yuan due to decreased sales of beverages and canned products in overseas and domestic markets. The company's full-year net profit was 223.4 million yuan, up 44.9% from the previous year, driven by a 14.8% decrease in cost of sales. Sino Grandness shares closed up 9.09% on the news.

site_title: France's JC Decaux to buy minority stake in Hong Kong's Clear Media
summary: JC Decaux, the world's largest outdoor advertising company, is set to buy a minority stake in Hong Kong's Clear Media as part of a consortium takeover. The consortium, led by Han Zi Jing, has offered HK$7.12 per share, valuing Clear Media at HK$3.86 billion. JCDecaux will hold a 23% stake, while Antfin and China Wealth Growth Fund III LP will also participate. Goldman Sachs and Slaughter and May are advising on the deal.

site_title: Huawei posts 5.6% rise in 2019 profit, smallest increase in 3 years
summary: Huawei reported a 5.6% increase in 2019 profit to 62.7 billion yuan, its smallest annual profit growth in three years, due to weak overseas sales amid US security concerns. The company's carrier business saw a 3.8% sales rise, while revenue overall rose 19% to 858.8 billion yuan. Huawei attributed the growth to a 34% jump in sales for its consumer business unit, mainly driven by China. The company faces ongoing restrictions from the US and prepares for further measures to restrict chip supply.

site_title: ExxonMobil's new tech deployment in Singapore to create 135 new jobs, says Teo Chee Hean
summary: ExxonMobil is investing in new technology at its Singapore facility, creating 135 new jobs with significant spin-offs to the economy. The investment, valued at multi-billion dollars, boosts Singapore's energy and chemicals sector, which employs 25,000 workers and contributes 2.3% to the country's GDP. The new technology will increase cleaner fuels production by 48,000 barrels per day and is part of ExxonMobil's efforts to decarbonize, with discussions on potential carbon-capture technologies underway with the Singapore government.

site_title: Hong Kong Feb home prices fall the most in 15 months as virus spreads
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices in February fell 2.1% from the previous month, the largest decline in 15 months, due to the spread of the coronavirus. The epidemic led to a virtual standstill in the city, impacting property transactions. Despite recent upticks in confirmed cases, experts expect the market to stabilize in the second half with a 10% drop in prices for the full year, and a 20-30% decline in transaction volumes in the next two months.

site_title: Aston Martin may need more cash even after bailout by tycoon
summary: Aston Martin may need additional funding despite a £536 million bailout from billionaire Lawrence Stroll, citing increased uncertainty from the coronavirus crisis. The company lacks sufficient working capital, according to European Securities and Markets Authority rules, and may need to tap high-interest notes. Shares fell 9.3% after the announcement. Aston Martin's directors believe the company has access to loans, including delayed draw notes with a 12% interest rate, but the liquidity warning raises concerns about the company's long-term financial stability.

site_title: SoftBank-backed car trading platform said to explore funding options
summary: Chehaoduo Group, a car trading platform backed by SoftBank Vision Fund, is exploring funding options amid a hit in auto sales due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company is considering equity fundraising, asset-backed securities issuance, and local government support. A potential funding round could come after auto sales in China gradually return to normal. Chehaoduo is seeking fresh capital to expand its car services market presence. The company has previously worked with local governments and is also considering an initial public offering in Hong Kong or the US.

site_title: Shell sees oil sales volume, margins holding up in first quarter
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc reported that the coronavirus pandemic is not expected to significantly impact demand for its oil products in the first quarter. The company expects sales volumes and margins to remain relatively unscathed, with marketing margins expected to remain strong. Oil-products sales volumes are forecasted at 6-7 million barrels per day, while upstream oil and gas production is estimated at 2.65-2.72 million barrels of oil equivalent per day. Shell cancelled its share buyback program, cut capital expenditure, and pulled out of a liquefied natural gas project due to the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Empty store shelves spur Brits to grow their own vegetables
summary: Empty store shelves in the UK have sparked a surge in people growing their own vegetables as the country's food supply chain faces disruption due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Over half of the UK's food is produced domestically, but reliance on the EU for a quarter of imports is also a concern. With travel restrictions and an aging workforce in agriculture, some Britons are taking matters into their own hands, with sales of fruit and vegetable seeds skyrocketing. This shift towards self-sufficiency may be a long-term solution to the UK's food security issues.

site_title: Australia to ease rules on raising capital amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, will temporarily relax rules to make it easier for listed companies to raise capital due to the coronavirus pandemic. The regulator will allow companies to issue "low-doc" offers, such as rights offers and placements, without meeting usual requirements. This move aims to support companies affected by the outbreak. The relaxation is a one-time measure, and the usual rules will apply once the pandemic is under control.

site_title: Australia's AAA rating under a cloud as debt, deficit blow out
summary: Australia's AAA sovereign rating is under threat due to the country's growing debt and deficit. The government's A$320 billion fiscal support package to combat the coronavirus pandemic is expected to see the debt burden almost double over the next 12-18 months. While analysts expect the rating to remain AAA for now, the surge in debt may lead to a "negative" outlook from "stable." The fiscal position is the primary source of concern, with some economists preferring a rating downgrade to a deep recession.

site_title: China stocks suffer worst quarter since 2018 as coronavirus worries deepen
summary: Chinese stocks closed 0.1% higher on Tuesday after a report of better-than-expected industrial activity, despite a deepening coronavirus pandemic. The Shanghai Composite index fell 4.5% in March and 9.8% for the first quarter, its worst since 2018. The CSI300 index dropped 6.4% month-on-month and 10% for the quarter, also its worst since 2018. Fears of an economic fallout continue to weigh on the market.

site_title: Hungry and in chains, Thailand's tourist elephants face crisis
summary: Thailand's tourism industry, severely impacted by the coronavirus, is leaving thousands of elephants in the country's tourist sector vulnerable to starvation and exploitation. Estimated 2,000 elephants are "unemployed" due to the decline in visitor numbers, with many being underfed and chained for extended periods. Campaigners warn of a crisis, with elephants at risk of being sold to zoos or used in illegal logging activities. Conservationists and elephant camps are urging the government to provide financial support to ensure the welfare of these animals.

site_title: Facebook aims US$100m at media hit by the coronavirus
summary: Facebook has pledged US$100 million to support media outlets affected by the coronavirus pandemic, in addition to its existing US$300 million investment by the end of 2021. The company will provide US$25 million in grants to local news outlets and spend US$75 million on international marketing efforts. This move aims to help the media industry recover from the economic downturn caused by the pandemic, which has led to significant advertising revenue losses and staff cutbacks.

images.alt_text: Facebook announced Monday that it would dole out US$25 million in grants to local news outlets and spend US$75 million in a marketing drive aimed at news organisations internationally in response to the coronavirus-prompted economic downturn, which has caused advertising to plummet and has threatened media industry revenues.

site_title: Asia dealmakers look to take-privates, distressed sales as M&As slump to 7-year low
summary: Asia's dealmakers are shifting focus to distressed sales and take-private deals amid a 7-year low in merger and acquisition (M&A) activity due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The region's deal value dropped 20% in Q1 2020 to $177.4 billion. To combat the slump, bankers are exploring alternative strategies, including distressed sales and take-private deals. This move aims to mitigate the impact of travel restrictions and face-to-face meetings on M&A activity.

site_title: Indonesia to suspend all foreign arrivals, barring a few exceptions
summary: Indonesia's foreign minister announced a ban on all foreign arrivals and transits to prevent the spread of coronavirus, except for foreigners with stay permits and diplomatic visits. The government aims to issue regulations by Tuesday, and will strengthen screening for Indonesian nationals returning to the country.

site_title: Five-star quarantine: struggling Australian hotels get lifeline
summary: The Australian government has quarantined over 1,600 people in hotels to slow the spread of the coronavirus, providing a lifeline to the struggling hospitality industry. Thousands more are expected to be isolated at the government's expense in hotels, serviced apartments, and backpacker hostels. The Australian Hotels Association credits this move as a "lifeline" for hotels that remain open, keeping key staff employed and maintaining a 10% occupancy rate. This measure aims to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic on the industry.

site_title: Oil prices rebound strongly from 18-year lows
summary: Oil prices rebounded strongly in Asian trade on Tuesday, rising 7.3% to US$21.50 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and 3.3% to US$23.50 a barrel for Brent crude. The rebound followed 18-year lows on Monday, amid optimism over government stimulus measures to support the global economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. Saudi Arabia's announcement to raise oil exports and a phone call between US President Trump and Russian counterpart Putin also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: UK economy stagnated at the end of 2019, before virus lockdown
summary: The UK economy stagnated in the fourth quarter of 2019, with gross domestic product remaining unchanged from the previous quarter, before being severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The economy is now expected to shrink by 10% in the first half of the year, its steepest slump in a century. Despite a narrowing current-account deficit, hopes for a steady recovery have been dashed, with the annual growth rate remaining at 1.1% and office for national statistics figures showing a lack of improvement.

site_title: Japan businessman paid US$8.2m by Tokyo Olympics bid committee lobbied IOC member
summary: A Japanese businessman, Haruyuki Takahashi, received $8.2 million from the Tokyo Olympics bid committee for lobbying International Olympic Committee members, including former powerbroker Lamine Diack. Takahashi gave Diack gifts, including a Seiko watch, and claimed they were normal for building relations. The payments were part of a larger $46,500 expenditure on luxury watches. French investigators are looking into potential bribes to secure Tokyo's bid, with Diack and others under scrutiny. The International Olympic Committee said it was unaware of the payments and would respect the confidentiality of the process.

site_title: TPG launches first commercial product in Singapore, while MyRepublic raises data caps
summary: TPG Telecom, Singapore's fourth mobile network operator, has launched its first commercial SIM-only product. The company will phase out its free trial services, while MyRepublic has raised data caps on its mobile plans and introduced two new "limited-time" contract-free plans.

site_title: Extreme isolation: world's last virus-free corners hold tight
summary: A handful of countries, including Palau, Samoa, and parts of Antarctica, remain virus-free, but residents are experiencing anxiety and fear despite strict travel restrictions. Palau's isolation from the Pacific has kept COVID-19 at bay, but a suspected death and the Northern Mariana Islands' first cases signal the virus's relentless march. The country's economy is also struggling due to reduced tourism and supply chain disruptions, with residents practicing social distancing and awaiting test kits. The global pandemic's impact is being felt even in remote corners, including the Antarctic research bases, where 90 people are isolated until November.

site_title: 14 NUS students infected with Covid-19, all imported cases
summary: 14 students from the National University of Singapore (NUS) have been confirmed to have contracted Covid-19, all of whom are imported cases. The students, who arrived in Singapore, were immediately isolated and transported to their homes or hotels for a 14-day stay-home notice. In addition, two students have breached their notices and will face disciplinary action. The university has encouraged students living in hostels to return home, with their hostel fees refunded. This marks the first reported cases of Covid-19 among NUS students since the pandemic.

site_title: Tencent-backed online education firm Yuanfudao raises US$1b in new round
summary: Yuanfudao, a Tencent-backed online education firm, has raised $1 billion in a new financing round led by Tencent Holdings and Hillhouse Capital Group. The company's valuation has increased to $7.8 billion, up from $3 billion in 2018. Yuanfudao's online courses and homework plans have seen a surge in interest as the coronavirus pandemic forces students in China to attend classes online, making it one of the few sectors to attract investor interest.

site_title: AGMs must include live webcast, limit physical attendance to 10 people: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has announced that annual general meetings (AGMs) must include a live webcast and limit physical attendance to 10 people to comply with safe-distancing regulations. Issuers must also provide shareholders with the opportunity to ask questions and allow proxy voting. This guidance supersedes an earlier version and allows companies to hold AGMs while adhering to government regulations. The move aims to facilitate shareholder engagement and ensure compliance with safe-distancing measures.

site_title: London landlords dump holiday lets on residential market, pushing down rents
summary: London landlords are shifting from short-term holiday rentals to the traditional letting market due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to a 10%+ price cut in inner London areas. This surge in traditional listings has pushed down rents, with 5.4% of Kensington and Chelsea rentals seeing significant declines. Similar trends are seen in other popular destinations, and Airbnb has reported a 40% collapse in bookings in big European cities. The pandemic's impact on the UK real estate sector is expected to continue, with potential financial stress on investors.

site_title: Covid-19: LMIRT to close all malls, retail spaces in Indonesia for 2 weeks
summary: LMIRT, Indonesia's largest mall operator, will close all 23 malls and 7 retail spaces for a minimum of two weeks starting April 1 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Essential services, including supermarkets and pharmacies, will remain open with reduced hours. Tenants can choose to continue operations for online delivery orders. This move follows the trust's previous closure of 11 malls from March 27 to April 9. Indonesia has 1,414 confirmed Covid-19 cases and 122 deaths.

site_title: Malaysian palm oil groups urge Sabah state to allow work to resume
summary: Malaysian palm oil groups have urged the Sabah state government to reconsider its order suspending palm operations due to the coronavirus. The shutdown, which affects 75% of the state's palm oil production, will disrupt operations including harvesting and milling, resulting in a potential revenue loss of US$199.86 million per month. The groups warned that the industry will face significant challenges resuming operations without the required workforce, which could lead to losses for planters and mill workers, totaling around 100,000 people.

site_title: Japan urges citizens to stay away from a third of the world
summary: Japan has issued "Level 3" travel warnings against 73 countries and regions, or about a third of all countries, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The warnings include countries like the US, Canada, China, and South Korea, and may lead to a ban on entry for non-Japanese nationals from these countries. The move aims to prevent an explosive surge in coronavirus cases.

site_title: Savage sell-off in Chinese dollar bonds lures bargain hunters
summary: Chinese dollar bonds have rebounded sharply as investors bet that a plunge in prices amid market chaos is overdone, with a 6.9% rally in an index tracking high-yield dollar bonds sold by Chinese companies. Some bonds, previously trading above 80% of face value, have fallen to less than 60% due to liquidity stress. Fund managers now see value in "good quality credit" at low valuations, with some quality Chinese developers and state-owned companies being "slaughtered by mistake" amid the rush for the exits. Beijing's stimulus packages and easing measures are underpinning the confidence.

site_title: Free cooking gas for poor during lockdown set to push up India's imports
summary: India's liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) imports are expected to surge in the June quarter due to a nationwide lockdown, which coincides with reduced crude processing by Indian refiners. The lockdown has led to a 21-day halt in industries, resulting in lower fuel demand. As a result, India may import 700,000 tonnes of LPG per month, with 70% of the 80 million beneficiaries of a free cooking gas scheme opting for refills. Saudi Arabia has assured continued supply of LPG to meet India's demand.

site_title: New Zealand extends state of emergency to stop Covid-19 spread
summary: New Zealand is extending its state of national emergency for a further seven days to combat the spread of Covid-19, following the initial seven-day declaration on March 25. Minister of Civil Defence Peeni Henare stated that the extension ensures access to necessary resources to prevent the spread of the virus in communities. The move aims to help stop the spread of Covid-19 and can be extended as many times as necessary.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.9% on Tuesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, as investors reacted to government and central bank pledges to support the global economy amid the coronavirus crisis. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,613.27, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also saw gains. The rally was driven by optimism over economic support measures.

site_title: Virus breaks the mold for telework in office-bound Japan
summary: Japan is testing its traditional "salaryman" stereotype as companies, driven by the coronavirus, start embracing telework. Despite government efforts to encourage flexible working patterns, adoption has been slow. However, the pandemic has forced employers and workers to try telework, with many experiencing benefits such as saving time and improving work-life balance. Experts say the coronavirus outbreak has changed mindsets, with companies beginning to see working from home as a feasible option, potentially leading to a shift away from the traditional office culture.

images.alt_text: That's a view familiar to Yuki Sato, 35, currently experimenting with teleworking for the first time.

site_title: Air Canada to temporarily lay off half its workforce
summary: Air Canada announced it will temporarily lay off nearly half of its workforce, affecting 15,200 employees and 1,300 managers, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline will reduce operations by 85-90% in the second quarter and implement a cost reduction program to generate at least $500 million. Senior executives will give up part of their salary, while the president and CFO will give up their entire salary. The measures are aimed at mitigating the impact of the pandemic on the airline's operations.

site_title: Coronavirus could force GM to delay its redesigned 2021 SUVs
summary: General Motors has postponed work on at least six future models to conserve cash amid the coronavirus pandemic, potentially delaying the launch of its redesigned 2021 large sport utility vehicles in late April. The company has suspended development work on the Chevrolet Equinox, GMC Terrain, Cadillac XT4, Bolt EV, Chevrolet Silverado, and GMC Sierra, pushing preproduction to 2021. GM is also delaying the launch of its Ultium battery system and new vehicles like the GMC Hummer EV and Cadillac Lyriq.

images.alt_text: General Motors told suppliers on Monday it is postponing work on at least half a dozen future models to conserve cash during the coronavirus pandemic and suggested it could delay the planned launch in late April of its highly profitable large sport utility vehicles.

site_title: Visa transaction volumes hurt as coronavirus crisis deepens
summary: Visa Inc reported a decline in transaction volumes due to the coronavirus pandemic, with domestic spending sharply declining in travel, restaurants, and entertainment. The company forecasts mid-single-digit percentage revenue growth for the second quarter. Transaction volumes fell in the second half of March, and cross-border travel-related spending has deteriorated rapidly. Mastercard and PayPal have also warned of slowing revenue growth. Analysts expect Visa's second-quarter revenue to be $5.83 billion and earnings per share to be $1.36.

site_title: EDBI, Vertex Ventures invest in US cell and gene therapy startup ElevateBio
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDBI) and Vertex Ventures have invested in US cell and gene therapy startup ElevateBio in a $170 million Series B round. Other investors include The Invus Group, Surveyor Capital, and existing investors F2 Ventures, MPM Capital, and others. The funding will support ElevateBio's centralized innovation and manufacturing hub, BaseCamp, and clinical studies for at least six cell and gene therapies. The startup plans to partner with Asian biotech companies and academic centers to develop novel therapies for cancers and rare diseases.

site_title: US grocers add plexiglass sneeze guards to protect cashiers from coronavirus
summary: US grocery chains Kroger, Walmart, and Albertsons are installing plexiglass partitions at checkout counters to protect cashiers from the coronavirus. The partitions, which also include floor decals, aim to promote physical distancing in checkout lanes. Other retailers, including Amazon's Whole Foods, are also implementing similar measures. The move is part of efforts to reduce virus exposure to front-line cashiers and provide reassurance to customers.

images.alt_text: Kroger Co, Walmart Inc, Albertsons and other grocery sellers are installing plexiglass partitions at checkout counters to protect cashiers from the highly contagious coronavirus.

site_title: US coronavirus death toll passes 3,000: Johns Hopkins University
summary: The US coronavirus death toll surpassed 3,000, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally, with over 163,000 confirmed cases. President Donald Trump has faced criticism for the federal government's slow response to the pandemic. Trump cancelled plans to re-open the country by Easter and extended social distancing guidelines until the end of April after top scientists warned of a rising death toll, with predictions ranging from 100,000 to 200,000 lives lost.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.3% or 59.98 points to 19,144.95. The rally was driven by a strong performance on Wall Street, where stocks rose over 3% on Monday. Despite concerns over the spread of coronavirus infections in Japan, investor sentiment was boosted by government interventions and central bank actions. The dollar rose to 108.10 yen, while Fujifilm gained 2.70% on expectations of its anti-flu medicine's potential approval as a coronavirus treatment.

site_title: US dollar up, but yuan sluggish as traders sceptical of China PMI bounce
summary: The US dollar rose 0.7% to 108.55 yen on Tuesday as Japanese investors rushed to cover a shortage of the currency before fiscal year-end. However, sentiment remained fragile due to the ongoing global coronavirus crisis. China's yuan remained stagnant despite a manufacturing PMI showing growth in March, with investors skeptical of the uptick due to ongoing disruptions. The pound fell 0.71% to $1.2331, weighed down by a sovereign ratings downgrade, while the euro fell 0.24% to $1.1013. A global recession is expected to favor currencies least affected by the economic downturn.

site_title: Samsung Display to stop producing LCD panels in South Korea, China by end 2020
summary: Samsung Display will stop producing LCD panels in South Korea and China by the end of 2020, following a decision to suspend one of its two LCD production lines amid falling demand and a supply glut. The company aims to supply LCD orders to customers without any issues by the end of the year. This move is part of Samsung's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions and focus on other display technologies.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.2% in Feb on business loans: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.2% in February from January, driven by higher business loans amid the virus outbreak. Loans to financial institutions, manufacturing, and other sectors increased 0.6% to S$430.91 billion. The total domestic banking unit lending stood at S$692.85 billion in February.

site_title: KFC owner Yum Brands breaks junk debt market's four-week fast
summary: Yum Brands, the owner of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell, has sold $600 million in junk-rated debt bonds, ending a four-week drought in the US market for such debt issues. The deal was more than 10 times oversubscribed and came with a 7.75% yield, significantly higher than the 4.75% yield in Yum's prior debt deal. The company plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes. Moody's has amended Yum's ratings outlook to "negative" due to increasing debt levels and uncertainty surrounding the pandemic's impact on the company's revenues and earnings.

site_title: Rio Tinto to scale back New Zealand aluminium smelter ops on Covid-19
summary: Rio Tinto to scale back operations at its New Zealand aluminium smelter due to government restrictions to contain the coronavirus. The company will close one production line and reallocate affected workers to other areas, reducing production by 340,000 tonnes per year. The move comes after the smelter made a loss of US$46 million in the last financial year. The company had previously put the smelter under review, and the decision will be made by the end of the first quarter of 2020.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto Ltd will close one of the aluminium production lines at its smelter in Tiwai, New Zealand, to comply with government restrictions to contain the coronavirus, its New Zealand's Aluminium Smelters (NZAS) venture said on Tuesday.

site_title: Telemedicine startup Doctor Anywhere bags US$27m in Series B round
summary: Doctor Anywhere, a Singapore-based telemedicine startup, has secured US$27 million in Series B funding led by Square Peg, EDBI, and IHH Healthcare. The funds will be used for regional expansion to Malaysia and the Philippines, as well as deepening its presence in Singapore. The company aims to enhance its product and expand its tech and data science teams. With a network of clinics and over a million users, Doctor Anywhere has seen a significant increase in users since the start of social distancing measures, with more than doubling since January.

site_title: Billionaire's Instagram-perfect isolation on a luxury superyacht draws outrage
summary: Billionaire David Geffen's luxury superyacht, Rising Sun, has sparked outrage due to his Instagram-perfect isolation in the Caribbean during the COVID-19 pandemic. Geffen, 77, has been sailing between Grenada and St. Vincent since February, despite the crisis affecting the world unequally. His decision has highlighted the stark contrast between the wealthy's self-seclusion and the struggles of essential workers. The yacht's presence has also affected the superyacht industry, with many charter bookings canceled and yacht sales on hold.

site_title: Singapore employers urged to support staff who need 2nd job amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore employers are advised to support staff seeking second jobs to supplement incomes amid the coronavirus outbreak. The National Wages Council and Ministry of Manpower recommend job-sharing arrangements, shorter work weeks, or temporary layoffs, allowing employees to take on part-time or temporary work for another employer. Employers should waive contractual prohibitions against second jobs and help resolve conflicts of interest. The Ministry of Manpower also advises employees to be transparent with both employers about their second job requirements to prevent disputes.

site_title: Bacon left out of surge beef and eggs are getting from lockdowns
summary: US pork belly prices have plummeted to 41 cents per pound, the lowest since 1999, due to restaurants closing and people preparing more meals at home during the coronavirus lockdowns. This is in contrast to beef and eggs, which have surged in price. The low pork belly prices are expected to last as long as restaurants remain closed, potentially leading to sales and stockpiling by traders. Experts suggest buying pork belly if storage space is available, as prices may increase when economic activity resumes.

site_title: No ERP charges at most gantries from April 6 amid fewer cars on roads
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore will suspend ERP charges at most gantries starting April 6, with rates reduced by up to S$2 at 96% of gantries islandwide. Most expressway and arterial road gantries will be free of charge, except for a few specific locations. The decision comes amid lighter traffic due to the Covid-19 outbreak and is intended to encourage safe-distancing measures and limit non-essential travel. The LTA will review ERP rates more frequently if the situation continues to decline.

site_title: G20 finance ministers to hold virtual talks on coronavirus crisis
summary: G20 finance ministers and central bankers are holding a virtual meeting to discuss the coronavirus crisis, following a pledge by G20 leaders to inject $5 trillion into the global economy to combat the pandemic. The US and Russia are expected to discuss a moratorium on sanctions during the pandemic. The meeting comes amid criticism of the G20's slow response to the crisis, which has left over 37,500 dead worldwide and triggered financial shockwaves. The US share of the $5 trillion is $344 billion, with developing nations to receive support from the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Petrobras increases liquefied petroleum gas imports
summary: Brazil's state-owned oil company Petrobras is increasing liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) imports due to soaring consumer demand in some areas amid concerns about potential coronavirus-related supply limitations. Three ships carrying 20 million kilograms of LPG each are on their way to Brazil, with the first arriving on Monday. Petrobras reduced the average price of 13kg LPG canisters by 10% to 21.85 reais (US$4.21), citing confidence in distributors and resellers to pass on the price cuts to customers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, Singapore Airlines, City Dev, FLT, FCOT
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported updates on Tuesday, March 31, 2020. DBS Group announced it will defer dividend payments until its annual general meeting, while Singtel's board volunteered a 10% fee cut. Singapore Airlines continued to cut spending despite a recent cash call. City Developments Limited appointed a new CEO for its hotel arm. Meanwhile, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust are set to merge, with FCOT expected to delist on April 29.

site_title: Trump says more than 1 million Americans have been tested for coronavirus
summary: US President Donald Trump announced federal social distancing guidelines will remain in place through the end of April, with travel restrictions to China and Europe likely to stay. Over 1 million Americans have been tested for coronavirus, with guidelines encouraging people to avoid gatherings of 10 or more and dining in restaurants. Trump urged Americans to follow the restrictions, saying "every one of us has a role to play in winning this war" and that challenging times are ahead for the next 30 days.

site_title: Ford, General Electric to produce 50,000 ventilators in 100 days
summary: Ford Motor Co and General Electric's healthcare unit will produce 50,000 ventilators over 100 days at a Michigan plant. The simplified ventilator design, cleared by the FDA, meets most Covid-19 patients' needs without electricity. Ford plans to deploy 500 UAW employees and begin production in late April, with the potential to build 30,000 per month as needed. Other manufacturers, including GM, also plan to increase ventilator production to cope with the pandemic surge.

site_title: Hyundai unveils plans for smart mobility lab in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Hyundai Motor announced plans to build a smart mobility lab in Singapore's Jurong Innovation District. The 28,000 square meter lab will focus on developing future mobility technologies, including electric vehicles, autonomous platforms, and multi-modal mobility services. Construction is expected to start in May 2020 and complete by the second half of 2022. The lab will test innovative solutions for advanced mobility services, collaborate with local partners, and review potential collaborations with Singapore's Smart Nation initiative. Hyundai aims to transform itself into a smart mobility solutions provider and expand into global markets.

site_title: Don Agro FY19 profit falls 16.9% in first results since Catalist debut
summary: Don Agro, a Russian agri and dairy firm, reported a 16.9% decline in net profit to S$5.2 million for FY19, primarily due to higher cost of sales and lower harvest prices. Revenue jumped 45.3% to S$35.4 million, driven by increased sales from crop production, livestock, and milk. A maiden final dividend of 0.693406 Singapore cents per share was recommended, totaling 20% of the group's net profit. Don Agro's shares closed up 27.3% to S$0.28 on Catalist following the release of its results.

site_title: Architect Michael Sorkin dies from Covid-19
summary: Architect Michael Sorkin, known for his outspoken views on social justice and urban planning, has died from complications related to COVID-19 at the age of 71. A polymath and influential architecture critic, Sorkin was a vocal advocate for using architecture as a tool for social change and resisted the status quo. His writings and designs promoted green zones, sustainability, and citizen participation in urban planning, and he was a natural radical who saw architecture through a political lens.

images.alt_text: Mr Sorkin's work - lectures, teaching, writings and projects - inspired audiences and students to use architecture to resist the status quo and help achieve social equity.

site_title: Virgin Australia in talks with government about support for airline industry
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings is in talks with the Australian government for a potential A$1.4 billion loan rescue package, which would involve a government ownership stake if repayment is not made in two to three years. The airline industry's support proposal includes A$5 billion in aid. The talks come as the coronavirus crisis prolongs, with the airline seeking assistance to survive.

site_title: CaterSpot eyes APAC expansion with backing from Tat Hong family office
summary: CaterSpot, a B2B food delivery startup, is expanding into Asia-Pacific markets with backing from Tat Hong family office Triplestar Holdings. The company aims to raise $6-8 million in Series A funds to fuel growth in markets such as Malaysia, Taiwan, South Korea, Australia, and the UAE. CaterSpot has already raised $1.6 million in funds and has turned a profit within 18 months, with an average order size of over $270. The startup will use the funds to preserve revenues through loyalty initiatives and cut costs.

site_title: Oil traders hustle for tankers to divert US crude to Asia
summary: Oil traders are scrambling to book supertankers to divert US crude to Asia as the US Gulf Coast faces a glut of crude due to the White House's failure to secure funding for emergency stockpiles. BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Vitol are among companies inquiring about or booking tankers for a 10-day period starting late-April, with the aim of storing surplus crude while prices rebound. The strategy involves reducing speeds during the 60-day voyage, known as slow-steam, and may involve storing oil in onshore facilities or selling to Chinese refiners.

images.alt_text: Oil majors and traders are scrambling to book supertankers to try and divert a flood of American crude to Asia, betting the region is the best place to store the surplus while the market waits for a rebound.

site_title: Airlines plan furloughs; Air New Zealand sees smaller carrier in a year
summary: Major global airlines project layoffs, furloughs, and capacity cuts due to the coronavirus pandemic. Air New Zealand expects staffing levels to be 30% lower than current levels. The aviation industry has shrunk by half since mid-January, with 40% of passenger jet fleets in storage. Airlines are rushing to shore up liquidity and reduce costs to stay afloat.

site_title: US markets watchdog head says SEC should not ban short-selling of shares
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chairman Jay Clayton stated that the agency should not ban short-selling of shares, amid concerns over the coronavirus sparking a global recession. Clayton emphasized the need for market integrity and believes the current alternative uptick rule is sufficient. Analysts argue that short-selling bans undermine free markets and limit accurate asset pricing. The SEC is monitoring trading whipsaw during extreme volatility, but experts, including the Managed Funds Association, suggest the current framework is effective and adding restrictions would worsen the issue.

site_title: Trump says coronavirus travel ban may extend to more countries
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the country may expand its travel ban to include additional countries, including those in Europe and Asia, to combat the spread of coronavirus. The existing ban affects non-US citizens traveling from China, Iran, the UK, Ireland, and 26 European countries in the Schengen Area. Trump stated that the current guidelines will be "toughened up" and have a significant impact. The travel restrictions have already been scaled back with agreements with Canada and Mexico. The federal social distancing guidelines will be extended until the end of March.

site_title: China's March official factory activity unexpectedly expands after steep contraction
summary: China's factory activity unexpectedly expanded in March, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 52 from a record low of 35.7 in February. The expansion is attributed to government measures to contain the COVID-19 pandemic, but analysts expect the economy to contract due to disruptions to business and consumer activity. The unexpected expansion suggests a possible rebound in the economy, but global pressure from the pandemic is expected to keep businesses under heavy pressure.

site_title: Australia tightens scrutiny on foreign takeovers
summary: Australia has introduced stricter regulations on foreign takeovers, requiring all investments to obtain approval from the nation's investment review board. The move aims to protect domestic firms during the coronavirus outbreak. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg described the new rules as "temporary" and "designed to protect Australia's national interest." The regulations apply to all foreign investments, regardless of size, and are intended to ensure the country's stability during this period.

site_title: Shell drops out of major US LNG project, Energy Transfer delays decision
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has withdrawn from a major US liquefied natural gas (LNG) export project in Lake Charles, Louisiana, due to the recent crash in energy prices. The project's partner, Energy Transfer LP, has also delayed its final investment decision to 2021. The decision comes as global LNG demand has hit record highs, but the collapse in oil and gas prices has led to delays in new LNG projects worldwide, with US energy firms developing over 50 billion cubic feet per day of new export capacity.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell pulled out of a major US liquefied natural gas (LNG) export plant under development following the recent crash in energy prices, quickly followed by its partner, Energy Transfer LP, delaying its final decision on whether to go ahead with the project to next year.

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs curbing bonuses at time of coronavirus: CEO
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein is considering curbing 2020 bonuses in solidarity with Switzerland's victims of the coronavirus epidemic. The bank has already paid out 1.24 billion Swiss francs in loans to 7,800 companies. Despite the Swiss financial watchdog's call to curb dividend payments, Credit Suisse plans to pay out its 2019 dividend. A decision on 2020 dividends will be made in autumn, with the bank halting a share buyback that accounted for two-thirds of payouts to shareholders.

site_title: China slashes reverse repurchase rate to counter virus impact
summary: China's central bank cut its reverse repurchase rate to 2.2% from 2.4%, the largest margin in five years, to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus. A 50 billion yuan reverse repo operation was launched to inject funds into the financial system. The move aims to lower corporate funding costs and keep market interbank rates low, but had little impact on market sentiment, with Shanghai's key stock index about one percent lower.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking US gains; STI up 2.5%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, tracking US gains and rising 2.5% to 2,477.30, after a 4.5% decline on Monday. Gainers outnumbered losers 131 to 32, with S$514.1 million worth of securities changing hands. The rally follows a strong US stock market, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Another plunge takes crude benchmarks to lowest levels since 2002
summary: Global oil benchmark Brent crude plummeted to its lowest level in nearly 18 years, falling 8.7% to $22.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude briefly dipped below $20 a barrel. The decline is attributed to the growing prospect of a prolonged coronavirus shutdown, which is expected to cause a 20% drop in fuel demand worldwide. Producers and shippers are scrambling to lock up oil in storage as demand falls, with some US shale producers formally requesting production cuts for the first time in nearly 50 years.

site_title: StanChart commits US$1b to finance firms making in-demand items
summary: Standard Chartered has committed US$1 billion to finance companies producing essential goods and services to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, including pharmaceuticals, healthcare providers, and equipment manufacturers. These firms will receive funding to support production and distribution of items such as ventilators, face masks, and sanitizers. The move aims to alleviate the financial strain caused by the outbreak.

site_title: Europe: Shares reverse course to end higher on defensive plays
summary: European stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by defensive sectors amid plummeting oil prices and coronavirus concerns. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.1% after earlier dropping 1%, with healthcare, utilities, and telecom stocks gaining. Energy stocks added 3% despite oil prices slumping, while bank stocks fell 3.1% as lenders complied with the European Central Bank's dividend freeze. The healthcare sector was the biggest boost, with Galapagos jumping 6% after a Jefferies upgrade.

site_title: Dollar snaps losing streak as investors opt for safety
summary: The US dollar snapped a week-long losing streak on Monday as investors sought safety amid prolonged coronavirus uncertainty. The dollar rallied against major currencies and riskier emerging markets, with the euro, sterling, and Aussie dollar falling 0.5-1%. China's offshore yuan fell after the central bank cut a key interest rate. This comes as governments tighten lockdowns to combat the pandemic. The dollar's recovery is attributed to investors' shift away from riskier assets.

site_title: US crude dips below US$20 as lockdowns slash demand; Brent hits 18-year low
summary: US crude oil prices dropped below $20, while Brent crude hit an 18-year low, amid heightened fears of a prolonged global coronavirus shutdown and resulting decline in fuel demand. World demand is forecast to plummet 15-20 million barrels per day, a 20% drop from last year. Analysts warn that the price of oil is becoming unprofitable for many oil firms, and higher cost producers may need to shut production. Massive production cuts will be needed beyond Opec to address the demand shock.

site_title: Survive or thrive with the unprecedented Resilience Budget
summary: Singapore's Resilience Budget, a S$48.4 billion package, aims to support businesses and individuals through the COVID-19 pandemic. The package includes measures to help companies stay afloat, such as deferment of corporate income tax payments and property tax rebates. Additionally, the government is increasing wage co-funding and extending the period of support. The objective is to help companies remain in business, saving jobs and protecting livelihoods. The government also encourages businesses to use the downtime to transform and reskill workers, setting them up for long-term success.

site_title: Disney chairman Bob Iger to forgo salary; other execs take cuts
summary: Disney Chairman Bob Iger will forgo his salary, while other executives will take 20-30% pay cuts, starting April 5, due to the coronavirus' impact on the company. The move comes as the US$2 trillion stimulus package limits executive compensation for companies seeking loans. Iger's new CEO, Bob Chapek, will also take a 50% pay cut. The company's theme-park workers are receiving pay through April 18. The actions are a response to the virus' shutdown of movie theaters, theme parks, and cruise ships.

site_title: Logistics startup Inteluck snags over US$5m from MindWorks Capital, Lalamove
summary: Singapore-based logistics startup Inteluck has secured over US$5 million in funding from MindWorks Capital and Lalamove, a Hong Kong-based logistics firm, in a pre-Series B round. Inteluck will use the funds to launch an intelligent dispatch system and expand its customer base in the Philippines and other South-east Asian markets. The company currently aggregates 17,000 trucks on its platform and has over 100 enterprise customers, including Coca-Cola and OPPO. The investment aims to help Inteluck scale to become the dominant industry leader in the region.

site_title: Europe gets no respite from lockdowns after deadly weekend
summary: Europe continues to grapple with the COVID-19 pandemic, with Spain and Italy reporting over 3,000 deaths over the weekend. EU officials warn against easing lockdowns, citing strained healthcare systems and shortages of ventilators. Germany's economy minister says it's too early to discuss easing restrictions, while Italy's public health leader suggests a gradual reopening. European countries remain divided on how to support economies and workers, with some calling for pooled financial resources and others adopting their own bailout plans.

site_title: Biolidics to launch Covid-19 rapid test kit in April
summary: Singapore-based cancer-diagnostics company Biolidics has announced the launch of a Covid-19 rapid test kit expected to be available by the end of April. The test can detect Covid-19 with an accuracy of over 95% in 10 minutes, using serum, plasma, or whole blood samples. Biolidics has received provisional authorisation from Singapore's Health Sciences Authority for use in the country. The test kit is more affordable than existing options and can facilitate decentralized screening of suspected patients, making it suitable for border entry and potential Covid-19 clusters.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Will Resilience stimulate the Singapore economy?
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses Singapore's Resilience Supplementary Budget, with Professor Sumit Agarwal sharing his views on its potential impact on the economy. He suggests that wage support could help stave off job losses and that fiscal schemes could stimulate an expected multiplier effect. However, he also questions the effectiveness of other measures, such as fiscal schemes, in helping the economy recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: NWC unveils wage cut guidelines to sustain businesses, jobs amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore has unveiled wage cut guidelines to help businesses and jobs during the Covid-19 outbreak. The guidelines recommend that employers only cut the Monthly Variable Component (MVC) of workers' wages, which is used as an emergency lever to lower the wage bill. This move aims to sustain businesses and jobs while minimizing the impact on workers.

site_title: Frozen UK home market leaves buyers stranded
summary: The UK housing market has been effectively frozen due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with transactions and mortgage offers put on hold. Buyers like Jerome Reback are facing uncertainty, as agreed sale dates are being pushed back and some sellers are reconsidering their commitment to move. Property values may decline by up to 10% this year, according to Savills, and the government is encouraging those living in homes to stay put until there is clarity on when the country will return to normal. The shutdown is expected to have a significant impact on the market, with lenders struggling to process mortgage applications and valuers unavailable.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 3.2% as stocks finish solidly higher
summary: US stocks ended Monday with a 3.2% gain, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 700 points to 22,327.48. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also advanced, with gains of 3.4% and 3.6%, respectively. Investors seemed to be accepting the dire economic outlook and were reassured by federal spending and central bank interventions. Despite rising coronavirus cases, consumer confidence remained relatively stable, and some stocks, such as Johnson & Johnson and Abbott Laboratories, rose on positive news.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks gained more than 3 per cent Monday as markets weighed a dire near-term economic outlook against unprecedented federal spending and central bank interventions.

site_title: Analysts expect volatility in USD/SGD in the near term
summary: Analysts predict volatility in the Singapore dollar (USD/SGD) in the near term due to the COVID-19 pandemic's economic impact. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) recently eased monetary policy, but a brief morning rally suggests a knee-jerk reaction. Analysts expect the SGD to remain weak until the end of 2020, with some predicting a strengthening towards the end of the year. Forecasts vary, with predictions ranging from 1.38 to 1.48 by year-end, depending on the economic recovery and interest rate adjustments.

site_title: Asti CEO withdraws resignation amid 'challenging times' for firm
summary: Asti Holdings CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee has withdrawn his resignation amid "challenging times" caused by the coronavirus pandemic and US-China trade war uncertainty. He had initially tendered his resignation in April 2020 due to personal reasons. The company, a semiconductor manufacturer, has struggled to find a replacement for Loh, citing his strong personal relationships with major suppliers and customers. Loh's resignation was set to take effect on April 7, 2020, but he will now lead the firm through these uncertain times.

site_title: Airbnb to pay out US$250m to hosts to help ease Covid-19 cancellation pain
summary: Airbnb is allocating US$250 million to help offset losses by hosts due to the coronavirus pandemic. The aid will pay hosts 25% of their normal cancellation fees for cancellations between March 14 and May 31. This move comes after Airbnb offered guests a full refund for cancellations made before March 14. The company is also creating a US$10 million relief fund for Superhosts and Experience hosts, with grants available for up to US$5,000.

images.alt_text: Airbnb said on Monday it was allocating US$250 million to help offset losses by hosts around the world whose guests have cancelled bookings in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, following its announcement earlier this month that guests could get full refunds for certain reservations.

site_title: With 735,000 jobs lost, rich Nordic nations are in shock
summary: The Nordic region, comprising Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, and Iceland, is experiencing a severe economic shock due to the COVID-19 pandemic. With 735,000 jobs lost, the region's population of 27 million faces a significant economic downturn, with many workers on temporary leave without paychecks and 105,000 fired. Generous welfare states and universal healthcare provide some support, but the economic impact is still painful, with young graduates particularly vulnerable to long-term unemployment.

site_title: Sterling drops against dollar as rating cut clouds British outlook
summary: The British pound fell against the dollar on Monday, dropping 0.4% to $1.2386, as a credit ratings downgrade by Fitch and economic uncertainty due to the coronavirus pandemic clouded the country's economic outlook. The downgrade, which cut Britain's sovereign debt rating, raised concerns about the country's public finances and trade agreement with the EU. Finance minister Rishi Sunak announced stimulus measures, including a commitment to pay 80% of temporarily laid-off workers' wages, to curb unemployment and recession.

images.alt_text: Sterling skidded against the dollar on Monday, as the US currency reasserted its safe-haven status and Britain's economic outlook was knocked further by a credit ratings downgrade.

site_title: GCB in Cluny Park being sold for S$40m
summary: A Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Cluny Park, Singapore, is being sold for S$40 million, or nearly S$1,964 per square foot, based on its freehold land area. The buyer, Han Xiaoli, a director of Lobb Heng Group, is expected to redevelop the property. The sale price is considered slightly high by market watchers, but may have been agreed upon in January before the Covid-19 outbreak. The GCB was one of 12 developed by Straits Steamship Land in the 1990s.

site_title: MAS' double-tap policy easing still an exercise in restraint
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased its exchange rate-based monetary policy, tweaking the slope and mid-point of the Singdollar nominal effective exchange rate policy band. This move aims to provide better liquidity for banks and businesses amid the economic devastation of the Covid-19 pandemic. Analysts note that the restraint suggests fiscal policy will need to pull its weight, as monetary policy is considered a blunt instrument. The MAS has guided for inflation to turn negative for the year, and the central bank is expected to stand pat on its neutral bias at its next meeting in October.

site_title: SIA cost cuts continue as S$15b from cash call must 'last as long as possible'
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will continue to implement cost-cutting measures, including salary cuts and compulsory no-pay leave, despite a recent S$15 billion cash call. The airline will operate at 4% of its original capacity and has arranged a S$4 billion bridging loan facility to meet its liquidity needs. CEO Goh Choon Phong has urged staff to be prepared for a "long and harsh Covid-19 induced winter" and will use the S$15 billion funding judiciously to last as long as possible.

site_title: Can you really sell your house on Zoom?
summary: The UK housing market has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with a significant decline in transactions expected for the next few months. Mobility restrictions and distancing measures make in-person viewings impossible, forcing estate agents to slash costs. The government has suspended property taxes and paid employee wages, but smaller outfits face a difficult year. Digital property portals like Rightmove and Zoopla are engaging in a price war, while some agents, like Foxtons Group, are loss-making and must reduce expenses. The market is expected to rebound eventually, but the timing and outlook depend on the government's success in preventing permanent economic damage.

site_title: Rent rebates not enough to save retailers as virus-related curbs slash traffic further
summary: The Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) is urging landlords to provide additional support to retailers struggling due to Covid-19-related curbs. The association is asking landlords to halve base rent or limit percentage turnover deduction to 15% or less for a six-month period. The proposal also allows businesses to exit leases without penalty, without losing security deposits or facing legal action. The SRA's appeal follows similar calls from other industry bodies, amid a significant drop in footfall and dining bookings in Singapore.

site_title: Technology the answer to Covid-19 battle
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the global transition to digitization, flattening its economic impact through technology. Remote work, online shopping, and virtual events have become the norm, with tech companies working to assess and re-route supply chains. Emerging technologies like artificial intelligence, talking robots, and drones are being introduced to combat the virus. Bitcoin is being explored as a potential solution to the economic fallout, offering protection from currency manipulations and devaluations. As the pandemic subsides, the role of technology in society is expected to be more enhanced than ever, with a shift towards distributed management and a more decentralized, globalized world.

site_title: In trying to overcome high logistics costs, DAP's Gina Toh struck gold
summary: Gina Toh, general manager of logistics firm DAP Asia Pacific, overcame the high logistics costs that almost deterred her from starting her own business. With a $100,000 initial investment, Toh and her husband created DAP in 2004, which now generates millions of dollars in turnover, employs over 50 staff, and operates 150,000 square feet of warehouse space. Toh's biggest challenges were navigating industry regulations, managing a team, and implementing efficient warehouse management systems. Her management style, described as transformational, focuses on change and growth to stay ahead in the rapidly evolving industry.

site_title: HK luxury apartment landlords slash rents to attract tenants
summary: Hong Kong luxury apartment landlords are slashing rents by up to 20% to attract tenants amid the COVID-19 pandemic and economic uncertainty. Weakened demand from international companies and the volatile stock market have put pressure on landlords' capital. In a high-end area of West Kowloon, a three-bedroom apartment was recently leased for HK$32,000 (S$5,885) per month, 20% less than the initial asking price. This decline is part of a broader trend in expensive neighborhoods, with listings in Soho and Sheung Wan also dropping by 7.3% and 6% from last year.

site_title: LuxLexicon, LNX Global, Carousell raise funds for underprivileged children
summary: LuxLexicon, LNX Global, and Carousell have partnered for a week-long online charity event to raise up to S$20,000 for underprivileged children affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The fundraiser, hosted on Carousell, features over 50 pre-owned luxury items donated by celebrities, with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The sale will run until April 5, with some items listed at a fixed price and others available via a lottery bidding method for S$1.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics to open on July 23 next year
summary: The Tokyo Olympics will open on July 23, 2021, after being postponed from its original July 24, 2020, date due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Paralympics will follow from August 24 to September 5, 2021. The decision aims to give health authorities and organisers time to prepare for the event amidst the pandemic, with minimal disruption to the international sports calendar.

site_title: Japan's ruling party plans 100t yen stimulus to fight virus hit
summary: Japan's ruling party plans a 100 trillion yen (S$1.32 trillion) stimulus package to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus, with direct spending worth 20 trillion yen. The package, which would account for 16-17% of the country's GDP, aims to support the world's third-largest economy. The government plans to sell bonds worth 16 trillion yen to fund the package, which would strain Japan's already heavy debt burden. The package will include measures such as zero-interest loans for small businesses and cash payouts to households.

site_title: Companies gear up for supply chain realignment
summary: Companies are reevaluating their supply chain strategies due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has severely impacted China's manufacturing sector. The country's contribution to global manufacturing output is estimated to be between 27-50% of global output. The pandemic has caused widespread disruptions, particularly in labor-intensive industries such as automotive, electronics, and apparel. To mitigate these risks, companies are expected to diversify their supply chains, potentially shifting production to countries like Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. This shift may also be driven by technological advancements, such as the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence, and advanced robotics, which can help negate the low labor cost advantage of countries like China.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: DBS Group Holdings has deferred dividend payments to shareholders until a new AGM date is fixed, following the original schedule of March 31. Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group posted a net loss of 5.8 million yuan for its fourth quarter, while Second Chance Properties saw a 23.1% drop in net profit. In contrast, Low Keng Huat's net profit jumped 264% to S$12.7 million for its fourth quarter. A hearing for the proposed merger of Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust is set for Friday.

site_title: Global cooperation must still drive post-pandemic recovery and growth
summary: A global pandemic is accelerating anti-globalization sentiments and nationalist tendencies worldwide, particularly in the US and EU. The crisis has exposed reliance on critical medical products, leading to Sino-American tensions and calls for de-coupling of the two economies. National governments are taking a leading role in responding to the crisis, but this approach is short-sighted, as global cooperation is necessary for long-term recovery and preventing future outbreaks. The pandemic highlights the need for continued global cooperation, rather than replacing it with economic autarkies.

site_title: Foreseeable unforeseeables
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the limitations of the concept of "black swans," events that are unforeseen and unexpected. However, experts had been warning of a viral pandemic for decades, including as recently as last year. The US government's response to the crisis has been criticized for being slow and inadequate, with President Trump claiming that the crisis was "unforeseen." Experts argue that policymakers and leaders often miss the big picture by focusing too narrowly on their own country and time period, and that political systems tend not to respond to warnings of low-probability disasters. The US government's handling of the pandemic has fallen short of other advanced economies, and the lack of preparedness and planning has resulted in significant consequences.

site_title: Qantas pilots approve pay deal covering Sydney-London flights
summary: Qantas pilots have approved a pay deal that paves the way for the airline to fly non-stop commercial flights from Sydney to London. The deal, covering flights to London and other destinations, was agreed upon with 85% of pilots voting in favour. The airline had cancelled international flights due to the coronavirus pandemic and is now planning to order up to 12 Airbus A350-1000 planes for the Sydney-London flights, with potential flights starting in the first half of 2023.

site_title: Easing of rules enables Australian brewers to make sanitiser to meet demand
summary: Australia's medicines regulator has relaxed rules to enable small brewers and distillers to produce hospital-grade hand sanitiser, citing high demand from rural hospitals and aged care homes due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The rule change allows distilleries to make sanitiser using two WHO-developed recipes without government approval. This move aims to ease supply pressures and provide opportunities for Australian businesses to diversify, while some breweries have shifted their focus to producing hand sanitiser instead of beer.

site_title: DBS takes fast lane to used-car loans, doubling its market share
summary: DBS has doubled its used-car loan market share to 20% in just a year, driven by competitive pricing, stronger partnerships with dealers, and enhanced digital capabilities. The bank plans to increase used-car loan growth by 20% this year, but is cautious due to the ongoing virus outbreak, which may impact motor vehicle sales. DBS has digitized its sign-ups and aims to have 80% of used-car loans taking place online by 2021. However, the bank may revise its growth targets if consumer sentiment becomes sluggish, and remains hopeful that Singapore will recover from the economic crisis.

site_title: The ball is now in the court of businesses
summary: Singapore businesses face a crucial two-month period amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with many entrepreneurs struggling to maintain operations due to revenue losses. Despite closures and financial struggles, the business community has come together in unity, with entrepreneurs emerging to help each other and the government. The government's Resilience Budget has been praised for its timely support, and businesses are urged to adapt to social distancing measures and prioritize public health and safety. As the situation evolves, individuals and businesses are called upon to work together to reduce risk elements and emerge from the crisis in the best possible state.

site_title: Covid-19 may prove game-changer for virtual sports
summary: Virtual sports events are gaining popularity as traditional live sports are shut down due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Organizers are streaming events on YouTube, Facebook, and Twitch, generating advertising revenue and maintaining fan engagement.
