Virtual horse racing, boxing, cycling, football, and motor racing events have taken place, with some even featuring celebrity participants. Fans are turning to live streaming and participating in video games, with millions expected to download apps for virtual racing and other sports.

site_title: Dubai property group Limitless seeks advisers for restructuring
summary: Dubai-based property developer Limitless is seeking advisers to work on a financial restructuring plan due to a liquidity crisis. The company, formerly owned by Dubai World, was one of the biggest casualties of Dubai's 2009 property crash and debt crisis. Limitless has written to creditors stating it will be unable to pay accrued profit by March 2020 and is committed to agreeing on a restructuring plan benefiting all stakeholders. A team of legal and financial advisers will assist in finding a solution to the company's financial woes.

site_title: 35 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore with 3 new clusters
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore announced 35 new Covid-19 cases, including three new clusters, on March 30, 2020. 26 of the cases were local, with no recent travel history, and 9 were imported. There are now 879 cases in Singapore, with 228 fully recovered and 420 still in hospital. Three deaths have been reported, with the latest being a 70-year-old man who died from complications. Globally, Covid-19 deaths have exceeded 34,000 and over 700,000 people have been infected in 177 countries and regions.

site_title: Wuhan businesses reopen as Beijing moves to revive virus-hit economy
summary: China ramps up efforts to revive its economy as Wuhan businesses reopen after a two-month lockdown, with smartly turned out staff greeting customers in masks and gloves. The city reported no new cases for a sixth day, while the central bank cut interest rates unexpectedly. However, the country remains wary of carriers and infected individuals returning from abroad, with international flights cut and travel curbs rolled back. The government is pushing for fiscal and monetary stimulus to spur recovery, but concerns about a second wave of infections persist.

site_title: Why does Covid-19 get the blame when Eagle Hospitality Trust's woes predate it?
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has faced a payment shortfall after its sponsor, Urban Commons (UC), reneged on a monthly fixed rent payment. UC blames the Covid-19 pandemic for reducing income productivity, but the fact that UC didn't dip into its own pockets to make up for the payment shortfall raises concerns. EHT's IPO documents showed that UC was required to provide a $43.7 million security deposit, but the sponsor has only provided $28.7 million, leaving a $15 million shortfall. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is investigating the matter, and regulators are questioning the adequacy of IPO disclosure rules.

images.alt_text: The Queen Mary, a hotel aboard a docked ocean liner in California, is one of 18 assets in Eagle Hospitality Trust's portfolio.

site_title: Foam in hole and toilet paper for prizes, US women golfers play on despite Covid-19
summary: US women's golfers continue competing on a third-level tour despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with the Cactus Tour staging its 12th 54-hole event. The Arizona-based tour has been allowed to operate by a ruling declaring golf courses as "essential businesses." Players follow safety precautions, including social distancing and limited group sizes. Winners receive prizes, including a toilet roll and US$2,800, with one winner describing the unusual prize as a "little extra" during a time of toilet paper scarcity. The tour will continue until May 14, with no assurance of a return date.

site_title: Singtel raises S$2m to support vulnerable groups, healthcare workers during Covid-19
summary: Singtel has raised S$2 million to support vulnerable groups and healthcare workers during the Covid-19 pandemic through its Touching Lives Fund. The funds will be channeled to 18 charities and social enterprises, including S$500,000 to The Courage Fund and S$600,000 to healthcare groups. The company's board of directors has also agreed to a 10% fee cut for the upcoming financial year as a show of solidarity.

site_title: CDL names veteran hotelier as group CEO of M&C Hotels
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has appointed Clarence Tan as the group CEO of Millennium & Copthorne (M&C) Hotels, effective Thursday. Tan, a veteran hotelier, joins from InterContinental Hotels Group, where he was managing director for South-east Asia and Korea. He aims to drive profitability, achieve synergies, and cost efficiencies, with a focus on navigating the hotel arm through the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the global hospitality industry.

site_title: NGOs press drug firm Gilead over potential virus treatment
summary: NGO groups, including Doctors Without Borders and Oxfam, have written to Gilead Sciences, urging the company not to enforce exclusivity over its potential Covid-19 treatment, remdesivir. The 145 organizations claim Gilead holds primary patents in over 70 countries, allowing them to block generic development until 2031. They request Gilead ensure rapid availability, affordability, and accessibility of remdesivir until clinical trials demonstrate its efficacy. The groups argue that an exclusivity-based approach would hinder access to a potentially critical treatment for Covid-19.

site_title: Saudi Aramco weighs pipeline stake sale to raise cash
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil producer, is considering selling a stake in its pipeline unit to raise cash amid a slump in crude prices and growing spending obligations. The potential sale could raise over $10 billion, with the company aiming to pay out $75 billion in dividends this year and meet its $70 billion acquisition of Saudi Basic Industries Corp. Preliminary discussions with potential advisers have begun, but the sale remains uncertain and Aramco may decide against it.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher as markets gird for volatility
summary: US stocks rose early Monday, opening higher as markets anticipated a volatile week due to the economic impact of the coronavirus and emergency government spending. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 gained 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.0%. The gains were attributed to investors weighing the economic toll of the coronavirus against government stimulus measures.

site_title: China's big banks flag asset quality pressure due to virus
summary: China's largest state banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank, and Bank of Communications, expect asset quality to be impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic due to borrowers struggling to repay loans. Despite having plush capital reserves, smaller lenders like Baoshang Bank and rural commercial banks are likely to struggle. The banks' net interest margins are expected to narrow, and there is a risk of rising soured debt and overdue loans. The impact is expected to be short-term and controllable, but Moody's has changed its view of six Chinese banks to negative due to the virus's impact on industries such as manufacturing and trade.

site_title: Digibank contender MatchMove takes stake in e-commerce enabler Shopmatic
summary: MatchMove, a digital bank licence-contender, has taken a strategic stake in Shopmatic, a Singapore-based e-commerce enabler. The deal, worth a few million dollars, will allow MatchMove to extend services to more than 435,000 small and medium enterprises and individual entrepreneurs. The investment is part of Shopmatic's Series B round, aiming to raise S$15 million to S$20 million by October 2020. MatchMove aims to increase its stake in Shopmatic and eventually offer services such as digital payments and remittance to its users, positioning itself for sustainable long-term success in the digital banking space.

site_title: US crude dips below US$20 as lockdowns hit demand
summary: Oil prices plummeted, with US crude dipping below $20 and Brent hitting its lowest level in 18 years, due to heightened fears of a prolonged coronavirus shutdown and declining fuel demand. Global oil demand is evaporating, forcing oil firms to shut production, and storage capacities are almost full. Analysts predict oil prices may need to trade lower to trigger production shut-ins, with some warning a price of $10 per barrel is no longer unimaginable.

site_title: STI resumes fall despite global support moves
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.5% to 2,416.24, with all 30 counters closing in the red, after relief from global fiscal support measures faded. The decline follows a $48.4 billion support package by the Singapore government to combat the economic fallout of Covid-19. Asia-Pacific equity benchmarks were mostly lower, tracking a 18-year-low in oil prices. In contrast, the ASX 200 in Australia surged 7% to a record high, after Canberra committed A$130 billion to supporting its economy.

site_title: Van Gogh painting stolen from Dutch museum during coronavirus shutdown
summary: A Vincent van Gogh painting, "Lentetuin" or "Spring Garden," was stolen from the Singer Laren Museum in the Netherlands during the coronavirus shutdown. The 1884 painting, which depicts a woman in a garden, was taken by thieves who forced open the museum's glass front doors. The theft occurred while the museum was closed due to the outbreak, with the director expressing shock and outrage at the loss. Police are investigating the incident.

site_title: Govt's real firepower to fight Covid-19 is fiscal stimulus: DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that fiscal stimulus is the government's real firepower to fight Covid-19, complementing monetary policy. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased its policy stance, lowering the mid-point of its exchange rate policy band, and the government has introduced a Supplementary Budget with over S$48 billion in new measures to protect jobs, support enterprises, and strengthen economic resilience. The government expects a negative impact on revenue, but remains confident in its ability to guide the economy and allocate resources efficiently.

site_title: Nature reclaims world's city streets and spaces emptied by virus outbreak
summary: With countries under coronavirus lockdown, nature is reclaiming city streets and spaces, allowing wildlife to freely roam undisturbed by human traffic. Wild animals, such as wild boar, sika deer, and turkeys, have been spotted in cities like Barcelona, Nara, and Oakland, while pumas have been seen in Santiago, Chile. The lockdown has also led to reduced noise pollution, allowing birds and other animals to sing and mate more freely, with some species benefiting from the suspension of hunting seasons.

images.alt_text: Scopoli's shearwater birds (calonectris diomedea) on the Mediterranean Sea at the Calanques National Park, off the coast of south-eastern France. Here wildlife "is reclaiming its natural habitat with surprising speed", says the park's president, Didier Reault.

A puma turned up in the centre of the Chilean capital Santiago, which is under curfew. "This is the habitat they once had and that we've taken away from them," said Marcelo Giagnoni, the head of Chile's agricultural and livestock service, that helped police capture the curious big cat.

site_title: EasyJet grounds fleet: plans to build buffer against virus blow
summary: EasyJet grounds its entire fleet for at least two months to conserve cash amid the coronavirus pandemic, grounding 4,000 UK staff for two months. The airline is in talks to build a cash cushion and will restart flights when government restrictions and demand permit. EasyJet's shares fell 7.5% as the company has a strong balance sheet but faces a US$252 billion revenue hit from the pandemic. The UK government has created a £330 billion loan program, and EasyJet may raise cash with a sale-and-leaseback transaction.

site_title: Who will be the winner in the fight for a post-Covid-19 America?
summary: The US is navigating a post-Covid-19 America with significant changes possible, as politicians propose radical alterations to society, wealth redistribution, and redefined priorities. The pandemic has given the Trump administration an excuse to shut down borders and detain people indefinitely, while progressives seek to reduce the prison population, expand workers' rights, and implement policies to improve lives. Disasters often lead to lasting change, as seen in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, which shifted the balance of power and led to regime change. The current crisis has revealed the interconnectedness of society, the importance of collective decisions, and the potential for a new order to emerge, with the possibility of a universal basic income, social safety nets, and redefined values.

site_title: Summer Olympics in Tokyo to start on July 23, 2021
summary: The Summer Olympics in Tokyo, initially postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, will now take place from July 23 to August 8, 2021. The decision was made to give organizers ample time to address the pandemic's fallout. The International Olympic Committee and Tokyo organizers have announced measures to minimize disruptions, including retaining volunteers and providing full refunds for tickets. The postponement avoids conflicting with major European and US sporting leagues, and President Thomas Bach expressed confidence in overcoming the challenge with stakeholders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 14.21 points to 1,328.88. Losers outnumbered gainers 511 to 305, with 2.821 billion lots traded worth RM1.858 billion.

site_title: Singtel raises S$2m to support vulnerable groups and healthcare workers during Covid-19
summary: Singtel has raised S$2 million to support vulnerable groups and healthcare workers during the Covid-19 outbreak. The funds, raised through staff and management contributions, will be channeled to 18 charities and social enterprises, including S$500,000 to The Courage Fund. Singtel's board of directors will also take a 10% fee cut, while the company will extend care packages of free services to the public. The initiative aims to provide relief to vulnerable individuals and families and show gratitude to healthcare workers.

site_title: Saudi to raise oil exports to record levels as price war rages
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to raise oil exports to a record 10.6 million barrels per day starting from May, despite a global supply glut, as part of a price war with Russia. The move follows a production cut agreement among top producers that failed to reach an agreement on further cuts. Saudi Arabia aims to capture greater market share by decimating high-cost rivals, including US shale producers. The price of oil has reached 17-year lows, with Brent North Sea crude tumbling to US$22.58 per barrel, and analysts warn that oil could sink further as storage tanks approach full capacity.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's new tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue and similar operating loss as H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: AstraZeneca scores win as diabetes drug shown to slow kidney disease
summary: AstraZeneca's diabetes treatment Farxiga has shown "overwhelmingly" effective results in slowing chronic kidney disease, according to an interim study analysis. Patients on Farxiga had better renal function and were less likely to die from heart or kidney disease than a control group on placebo. The trial was stopped early due to the significant results, and AstraZeneca plans to present the findings at an upcoming medical conference and discuss early market approval for the new use. Analysts expect the drug to generate $3 billion in sales in 2024.

site_title: Court hearing for FLT-FCOT merger expected on Friday
summary: A court hearing for the proposed merger of Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) is expected to take place on Friday. The merger, valued at S$1.58 billion, involves a trust scheme of arrangement and will see FLT pay the scheme consideration via cash and new FLT units to FCOT unitholders. The expected book closure date is April 14, and the effective date is April 15, pending the lodgement of the trust scheme court order with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: CDL names veteran hotelier as group CEO for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels
summary: CDL appoints Clarence Tan as group CEO for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, effective Thursday. Tan, a veteran hotelier with over two decades of global hospitality experience, joins CDL from InterContinental Hotels Group. He will oversee the performance of M&C's 150 hotels and 43,500 rooms, focusing on achieving synergies, cost efficiencies, and driving profitability. The appointment comes amid the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the global hospitality industry.

site_title: J&J, US government plan 1 billion doses of coronavirus vaccine
summary: Johnson & Johnson and the US government plan to invest $1 billion to produce over 1 billion doses of a coronavirus vaccine, with production starting by September and aiming for emergency use authorization in early 2021. The company will begin manufacturing without knowing for sure if the vaccine works, as it's the only option to meet the demand. J&J will start building a plant in the US and scouting for European and Asian manufacturing sites to meet the global demand.

images.alt_text: Johnson & Johnson said on Monday that it and the US government will invest US$1 billion to create enough manufacturing capacity to make more than 1 billion doses of a vaccine it is testing to stop the new coronavirus.

site_title: Japan to boost govt bond issuance to fund stimulus: sources
summary: Japan plans to boost government bond issuance by $149 billion from July to fund a massive stimulus package to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The additional 16 trillion yen (US$149 billion) comes on top of the government's existing plan to sell nearly 129 trillion yen of Japanese government bonds. The total amount to be sold in markets in the upcoming fiscal year would be the first increase in annual bond issuance in four years, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledging a huge stimulus plan to combat the virus fallout.

site_title: ComfortDelGro spending S$80m more on cabbie relief
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is spending S$80 million to extend daily rental relief for cabbies in Singapore until September 30, amid worsening economic conditions due to the Covid-19 outbreak. This move will push the company's Singapore taxi operations into the red for the year ending December 31, 2020, marking the first time the company posts full-year losses. The relief extension aims to support cabbies' survival, with the company also passing on savings from licence fee waivers and government handouts.

site_title: Grab senior leaders to take up to 20% pay cut during virus crisis
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing giant, has announced that its senior leaders, including co-founders, will take a pay cut of up to 20% amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company will also match voluntary donations made by employees to support its drivers, delivery staff, and merchants. Grab has launched new initiatives, including expanded financial assistance and merchant relief measures, to help its drivers and merchants during the crisis. The company will also expand its daily-essentials delivery service and reskill its drivers to create additional earning opportunities.

site_title: A Paris mortuary overwhelmed by coronavirus victims
summary: A Paris mortuary is overwhelmed by the mounting coronavirus death toll, with 50 cadavers arriving daily and no space for cold chambers. Undertakers are struggling to cope with the crisis, citing shortages of protective gear and the emotional toll of dealing with grieving relatives. The mortuary has limited visitation rooms and shortened funeral ceremonies to prevent contagion, while some families are unable to claim the bodies of their loved ones. France's death toll from Covid-19 has surpassed 2,600, with many cases going unclaimed due to lack of next of kin.

site_title: Biolidics to launch Covid-19 rapid test kit in April
summary: Biolidics has announced the launch of a Covid-19 rapid test kit in April, which can detect the virus with an accuracy of over 95% in 10 minutes. The test kit, which uses serum, plasma, or whole blood samples, has received provisional authorization from Singapore's Health Sciences Authority. Biolidics claims its test kit is more affordable than existing options and will enable decentralized screening, suitable for border entry and potential clusters. The company is working to obtain approval for use in Asia, particularly in the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Hong Kong.

site_title: STI closes 4.5% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.5% on Monday, closing at 2,416.24 points, as relief from last week's global fiscal support measures faded and uncertainty over the pandemic's duration weighed on sentiment. The MAS lowered the mid-point of the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate band, and equity benchmarks in Asia-Pacific were mostly lower, tracking oil prices. The ASX 200 in Australia advanced 7% to a record high, bucking the trend.

site_title: Anglo American cancels rough-diamond sales on coronavirus lockdowns
summary: Anglo American's diamond unit De Beers Group has cancelled its third sales event, Sights 2020, due to lockdowns in Botswana, South Africa, and India caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company will instead seek innovative ways to meet supply in the coming weeks. This decision is the latest impact of the pandemic on the diamond industry, which has seen several major events cancelled or postponed.

site_title: Second Chance Properties Q2 net profit falls 23.1% to S$1.4m
summary: Second Chance Properties, a Mainboard-listed company, reported a 23.1% drop in Q2 net profit to S$1.4 million, mainly due to a fair-value loss on financial assets. Revenue edged up 2.3% to S$7.2 million. The company expects modest economic growth in Singapore in 2020 if the US-China trade war escalates. Revenue from its gold business rose 7.0%, while rental revenue from its apparel business fell 16.6% due to competition and online shopping trends.

site_title: Saudi Arabia tells banks to support businesses to avoid job cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority (Sama), has ordered banks to provide concessional loans to businesses to prevent job cuts due to the coronavirus. The six-month lending program aims to "assist in maintaining employment levels." Banks will also offer debt repayment relief to customers who have already been laid off. The measures may put pressure on banks' revenue, but will help support businesses and prevent job losses.

site_title: Thai Airways may cut some plane types for good after grounding jets
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl may permanently reduce its aircraft types after grounding most of its fleet due to the coronavirus outbreak. The airline is currently grounded 69 of its 82 jets, resulting from a drop in passenger volume and route cancellations. Thai Airways' board and management will develop two plans by next month: one to get the carrier through the pandemic and another for business rehabilitation. The airline's future fleet composition may be significantly altered after the pandemic ends.

site_title: China's Sinopec says coronavirus outbreak has had severe impact on Q1
summary: China's Sinopec reports a severe impact on Q1 production and operations due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company will trim 2020 capital expenditure by 2.5% and make a detailed plan to reduce spending, to be reported in April. This move is part of the company's efforts to mitigate the effects of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Asia's top refiner China Petroleum & Chemical Corp, or Sinopec, said the coronavirus outbreak has had a severe impact on first quarter production and operations.

site_title: SIA to let staff take up temporary jobs outside group
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will allow staff to take temporary jobs outside the group due to significant job cuts and reduced flight operations amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline, facing negligible revenue and significant cash flow issues, has raised S$15 billion through a rights issue and mandatory convertible bonds. Staff will receive pay cuts and compulsory no-pay leave, with some employees being offered voluntary leave or temporary placements outside the group. The airline aims to use the funding judiciously to last until market recovery.

images.alt_text: Employees are also being given the option of temporary placements outside the group. Staff will return to the airline at the end of the deployment period, the memo said.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend losses in early deals
summary: European stocks declined in early trading on Monday, extending losses from the previous day's slump. The decline was driven by ongoing coronavirus-fueled volatility and plummeting oil prices. Major European markets, including London, Frankfurt, and Paris, fell 1-2.4% in early deals. Despite China's latest stimulus efforts, including a 50 billion yuan injection into its financial system, European markets were dragged down.

site_title: South Korea to pay 9.1t won cash to families, draw up 7.1t won extra budget
summary: South Korea plans to draw up a 7.1 trillion won supplementary budget to fund emergency cash payments to families affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The government aims to spend 9.1 trillion won on "emergency disaster relief payment" to support domestic demand and economic growth. To fund the budget, the government will issue deficit-covering bonds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.32% to 23,175.11, amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus. The decline was attributed to worries about the depth of the crisis, despite global stimulus and monetary easing measures. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.11%. The losses followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for US stocks despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: 35 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore; 3 new clusters
summary: Singapore reported 35 new Covid-19 cases, including three new clusters: S11 Dormitory@Punggol, Wilby Residences condominium, and Hero's nightspot. 26 local cases and 9 imported cases were confirmed, bringing the total to 879 cases. 228 cases have fully recovered, and 420 remain hospitalized, with 19 in critical condition. Three deaths have been reported, all in March, and globally, over 34,000 deaths and 700,000 infections have been reported in 177 countries.

images.alt_text: Hero's, a bar in Circular Road, was identified as one of the three new Covid-19 clusters on March 30, 2020.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn's profit down 24% in last quarter of 2019
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Foxconn reported a 23.7% fall in profit in the last quarter of 2019, with net profit of NT$47.76 billion, due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on demand from key customers like Apple. The company had previously warned of a 15% decline in revenue in the first quarter, but expects revenue to recover as production returns to normal in virus-hit China. Foxconn's shares have fallen over 12% this year.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Foxconn reported a 23.7 per cent fall in profit in the last three months of 2019 on Monday as it braces for the impact from the coronavirus pandemic that has hit demand from key customers such as Apple.

site_title: Australian brewers swap cleansing ale for sanitiser in coronavirus fight
summary: Australia's craft brewers are shifting their focus from producing beer to sanitiser due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The country's medicines regulator has changed its rules, allowing small brewers and distillers to make hospital-grade hand sanitiser without government approval. Several breweries, including One Drop and Banks and Solander, are repurposing their equipment and expertise to produce sanitiser, with some selling it for up to $10 per 200ml bottle. This move aims to meet high demand from rural hospitals and aged care homes.

site_title: Malaysia curbs to hit full-year consumer spending: report
summary: Malaysia's Movement Control Order, in place until April 14, may lead to slower household spending growth of 4.2% in the full year, down from 6.3% initially projected. The lockdown has closed borders, schools, and non-essential businesses, except for supermarkets and convenience stores. Sales are expected to increase due to stockpiling and home-cooked food, but restaurants and hotels will face significant revenue losses. The Malaysian Association of Hotels projects a 560.7 million ringgit loss, while retailers estimate a 90% loss in revenue due to difficulty transitioning to e-commerce.

site_title: Malaysia limits hours for shops, restaurants, taxis in lockdown
summary: Malaysia has imposed new restrictions in a lockdown to contain the pandemic, limiting shops, restaurants, and taxis. Stores that sell food, restaurants, and petrol stations can operate between 8am and 8pm, while taxi services can operate between 6am and 10pm. Only one person is allowed in a private vehicle at any time. The restrictions, which have been in place since March 18, have been extended until April 14 as the number of infections continues to rise. The government is enforcing compliance through police roadblocks and army deployments.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased the appreciation of the Singapore dollar to a neutral stance, lowering the mid-point of its policy band. The National Wages Council recommends adjusting the Monthly Variable Component (MVC) downwards if wage cuts are needed. Singapore Airlines will allow employees to take temporary placements outside the group amid cost-cutting efforts. ComfortDelGro Taxi extends daily rental relief for cabbies until September 30 due to worsening economic conditions. The STI closed 4.5% lower on Monday due to uncertainty over the pandemic's length.

site_title: Coffee importers stockpiling on fears over coronavirus lockdowns
summary: Coffee importers worldwide are stockpiling supplies, bringing forward orders by up to a month, due to fears of coronavirus lockdowns disrupting supply chains. Strong demand and tight supplies, even before the pandemic, have driven up coffee prices. Exporters in Brazil and Colombia are concerned about logistical challenges and potential labor shortages during the harvest season, which could impact global supply. Major roasters are accelerating deliveries from other origins to mitigate potential shortages, citing growing uncertainty and requests from major buyers.

site_title: Coronavirus fails to dampen South Korea's fever for exam success
summary: South Korea's private tuition industry, known as "hagwons," continues to operate despite the country's coronavirus outbreak, with 9 out of 10 schools remaining open. Parents are sending their children to these cram schools to ensure they don't fall behind in their studies, as the government-imposed school closures have delayed the start of the school year. The industry, worth $17 billion, is driven by the desire for high scores on the national university placement exam, which can impact job and marriage prospects.

site_title: Sabah extends palm oil plantation shutdowns
summary: Malaysia's Sabah state has extended a shutdown of palm oil plantations until April 14, affecting six districts, to curb the spread of coronavirus. The shutdown, initially set for March 31, was expanded after seven estate workers tested positive for the virus. The move is expected to significantly impact production, with the entire state except one district unable to harvest. Sabah accounts for 25% of Malaysia's palm oil production, and the country has reported 2,470 coronavirus cases, the highest in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Coronavirus may prove game changer for virtual sports
summary: Virtual sports events are gaining popularity due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with three billion people in lockdown tuning in to watch live streams of horse-racing, boxing, cycling, football, and motor-racing. Organizers are generating revenue by streaming events on YouTube, Facebook, and Twitch, and some drivers are even competing in virtual racing events. Examples include a virtual MotoGP, a boxing match featuring Muhammad Ali, and a virtual Grand National. The shift to virtual sports is expected to maintain fan engagement and revenue for sports organizations.

site_title: Nature takes back world's empty city streets
summary: Empty city streets are being reclaimed by wildlife as humans retreat indoors due to coronavirus lockdowns. Wild animals, including wild boar, sika deer, and pumas, are venturing into deserted streets and metro stations in cities like Barcelona, Nara, Japan, and Santiago, Chile. The sudden absence of human noise pollution is allowing animals to explore and interact with their environment, with some species even taking advantage of the reduced hunting season to find mates.

site_title: Money Hacks: Lessons for budding women entrepreneurs in the Covid-19 era (Ep 68)
summary: In a recent podcast episode, DBS Bank's group head of SME banking, Joyce Tee, shares actionable financial tips with budding women entrepreneurs in the Covid-19 era. The top concerns of women entrepreneurs, according to Tee, include work-life balance and managing finances. She advises women to approach business with resilience, research, and a clear understanding of their target audience. Tee also emphasizes the importance of differentiating services and avoiding gender stereotypes in business. The episode aims to inspire and support women who are considering starting a side business or becoming entrepreneurs.

site_title: Australia's top retail bank boss warns of sharp economic slowdown
summary: Australia's top retail bank boss, Matt Comyn, warns of a 10% economic contraction in the March quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a sharp decline in consumption. The country's economy has dodged a recession since the 1990s, but surging unemployment and higher loan losses are likely to cripple growth. The government has rolled out measures to mitigate the impact, including fiscal stimulus packages and interest rate reductions, but economists predict an unemployment rate above 11% by June and a 3% shrinkage in annual economic output in 2020.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close little changed amid coronavirus fears
summary: South Korean shares closed nearly unchanged on Monday, following a 9.7% gain last week, as concerns over the coronavirus outbreak outweighed stimulus measures. The KOSPI index closed 0.04% lower at 1,717.12, with large caps falling and small caps gaining. The government announced emergency cash payments and a second supplementary budget to ease the economic impact, while the central bank drew on a US$12 billion currency swap with the Federal Reserve to provide funding to local banks. The KOSPI has fallen 21.87% this year due to the outbreak.

site_title: UK public sector contractor Kier cuts pay for 6,500 employees
summary: UK public sector contractor Kier Group will cut wages for approximately 6,500 employees, including executives, by 7.5-25% for three months starting April. The company, which operates mostly government-contracted projects, maintains that 80% of its sites remain operational. Kier had £910 million in credit facilities and £395 million in average net debt as of December. This move is likely in response to the financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: EasyJet grounds 'entire fleet' over coronavirus
summary: British airline easyJet has grounded its entire fleet due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, with no certainty of when commercial flights will resume. The airline had already begun grounding a majority of its planes last week and has operated 650 rescue flights, returning over 45,000 customers. Crew members have volunteered to operate rescue flights, and the UK government has introduced an emergency scheme to pay crew 80% of their average pay for two months. EasyJet's future plans remain uncertain, but it will continue to work with governments to operate additional rescue flights as requested.

site_title: Green fuel plants are shutting down and some may never come back
summary: The US biofuel industry is facing a crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic and cheap oil, with ethanol plants shutting down and some potentially never coming back. Producers are battling chronic oversupply, trade upheaval, and slumping demand and prices. Smaller producers and those with heavy debt loads are struggling to survive. Industry leaders predict a significant shift in the industry after these "Black Swan events," with some plants likely to run out of capital.

site_title: Drop in China's new coronavirus cases; none in Wuhan for 6th day
summary: China reported a drop in new coronavirus infections for a fourth day, with 31 new cases, including one locally transmitted infection, down from 45 the previous day. The city of Wuhan, at the center of the outbreak, reported no new cases for a sixth day, as businesses reopened and residents reclaimed a more normal life. Policymakers are now focusing on revitalizing the economy, which has been nearly paralyzed by months-long curbs, with the central bank cutting interest rates and extending loans to businesses.

site_title: Australia shares post record daily gain after stimulus package
summary: Australian shares rose 7% on Monday, their largest single-day gain in history, as a stimulus package and slowdown in daily COVID-19 infections boosted buying. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 339 points higher at 5,181.40. Prime Minister Scott Morrison committed A$130 billion to save jobs, while healthcare stocks led the gain, with Ansell Ltd and CSL advancing nearly 25% and 12% respectively. The rate of daily infections has halved in recent days, sparking optimism for sectors like banks and healthcare.

site_title: Loyang industrial site up for sale at S$8.8m guide price
summary: An industrial site in Loyang, Singapore is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$8.8 million. The 45,439 sq ft site has a remaining tenure of 31 years and a plot ratio of 2.5. The site is zoned "Business 2" for heavy industrial use and has 76,697 sq ft of untapped gross floor area. The property is accessible via major expressways and has operational production spaces, warehousing, and offices. The seller is a supplier of heavy equipment and spares to the oil and gas industry.

site_title: Sanofi, Regeneron expand testing of potential coronavirus treatment
summary: Sanofi and Regeneron have expanded a clinical trial of their rheumatoid arthritis drug Kevzara as a potential coronavirus treatment to patients outside the US, including Italy, Spain, Germany, France, Canada, and Russia. The trial will enroll about 300 hospitalized patients with severe COVID-19 infection. The companies aim to suppress the immune system's overreaction, or cytokine storm, which causes organ damage. The trial follows US trials, with Regeneron leading US trials and Sanofi leading trials outside the US, amid the global COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Netanyahu aide diagnosed with coronavirus, unclear if Israeli PM affected
summary: An aide to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has tested positive for coronavirus, but it's unclear if Netanyahu was exposed. The aide, a parliamentary aide, was in good condition and had been present at a parliament session last week where Netanyahu was also present. Netanyahu had previously tested negative for coronavirus on March 15. The Health Ministry requires a 14-day self-isolation and possible testing for those in proximity to the infected aide. Netanyahu is set to convene officials to discuss a proposed lockdown to address the coronavirus crisis.

images.alt_text: An aide to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has tested positive for coronavirus, officials said on Monday, but it was not immediately clear if the 70-year-old leader had been exposed or his work affected.

site_title: Europe gets no respite from lockdowns after deadly weekend
summary: European countries face no respite from lockdowns as the COVID-19 outbreak claims over 3,000 lives in Spain and Italy, with healthcare systems stretched beyond capacity. Spain's ICU patients have surpassed 4,400 beds, and Italy's current restrictions will likely continue through Easter before authorities assess relaxation. European officials warn against easing restrictions, with Germany opposing joint euro-area financial resources. The economic cost of the pandemic continues to rise, with over 200,000 French businesses seeking assistance to keep 2.2 million workers on the payroll.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Taxi extends cabbie relief, to sink into red for fiscal 2020
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is extending its daily rental relief for cabbies in Singapore until Sept 30, 2020, due to worsening economic conditions and enhanced Covid-19 measures. The relief, valued at S$46.50 per day, will push the company's taxi operations into the red for the year ending Dec 31, 2020. The move aims to support cabbies facing a sharp drop in tourist arrivals and increased measures to restrict crowds. The company is also passing on savings from licence fee waivers and government subsidies to cabbies.

images.alt_text: Land transport company ComfortDelGro Corporation is spending S$80 million to extend its daily rental relief for cabbies until Sept 30 amid worsening economic conditions and enhanced Covid-19 measures.

site_title: 7 firms sign MOU to study hydrogen as green energy source for Singapore
summary: Seven Singapore and Japanese companies signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to study hydrogen as a low-carbon energy source. The seven firms, including PSA Corporation and Sembcorp Industries, will evaluate the technical and commercial feasibility of hydrogen import and usage in Singapore. Researchers will work alongside the companies to develop hydrogen production and distribution technologies, such as catalysis, to accelerate maritime decarbonization. The initiative aims to reduce carbon emissions and support Singapore's transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: National Wages Council recommends lower MVC or 10% of basic pay, if cuts needed
summary: The National Wages Council recommends adjusting the Monthly Variable Component (MVC) downwards or cutting basic pay by up to 10% if necessary. For firms with no MVC, a 10% cut in basic pay is suggested. The council also recommends a freeze in wages for low-wage workers earning up to S$1,400 and providing special consideration to workers who assisted the business during the challenging period. Retrenchment should be considered only as a last resort and done responsibly.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes lower on virus, profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index fell 1.57% on Monday, closing at 19,084.97, due to the spreading coronavirus and profit-taking. The broader Topix index dropped 1.64% as investors cashed in on recent gains and a stronger yen weighed on the market. Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike urged residents to stay home, warning of a possible "explosion" of the virus. Major shares, including Toyota and Sony, declined, while Fujifilm rose 5.97% on reports of government support for its anti-flu medicine research.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index lost more than 1.5 per cent on Monday, as the spreading coronavirus prompted investors to cash in on recent gains with a higher yen also weighing on the market.

site_title: Britain orders 10,000 ventilators from F1, aerospace consortium
summary: Britain has ordered over 10,000 ventilators from a consortium of aerospace, engineering, and technology companies, including Airbus and BAE Systems, to aid in the country's COVID-19 response. Production is set to begin this week, following expected regulatory approval. The group aims to provide a significant boost to the UK's ventilator supply, addressing the ongoing shortage.

site_title: Germany bets on South Korean model in coronavirus fightback
summary: Germany is adopting a South Korean model to combat the coronavirus, focusing on widespread testing and quarantining to break the infection chain. The country aims to conduct 200,000 tests a day, testing all those who suspect they have caught the virus and their contacts. Smartphone location data will be used to track down and isolate potentially infected people. Despite a low mortality rate, German health officials warn of a potential "storm" of new cases in the coming weeks, with concerns about the country's underfunded healthcare system and understaffed intensive care beds.

site_title: From sofas and kitchens, music stars hold coronavirus concert fundraiser
summary: Billie Eilish, Elton John, and other music stars held a coronavirus concert fundraiser from their homes, dubbed "IHeart Living Room Concert for America." The one-hour show, broadcast on Fox, featured performances by Mariah Carey, Camila Cabello, Alicia Keys, and more. The event aimed to lift spirits, raise money for frontline workers, and remind Americans to follow health guidelines. The concert raised over $1 million in its first 10 minutes, with donations going to Feeding America and First Responders Children's Foundation.

site_title: Vietnam's ban on rice exports still in force, govt may set limit: traders
summary: Vietnam's ban on rice exports remains in place, with traders expecting the government to lift the suspension and set a quota this week. The government has stockpiled 270,000 tonnes of rice to ensure food security, and a working group has estimated 6.5-6.7 million tonnes of rice left for exports this year. Traders anticipate an export limit of 800,000 tonnes in April and May, and the ban on new contracts may be lifted as early as this week.

site_title: Indonesia prepares to lock down 30 million people to curb virus
summary: Indonesia may soon quarantine 30 million people in the capital and surrounding areas to curb the spread of the coronavirus, which has killed over 100 people in the world's fourth-most populous nation. The plan follows a spike in confirmed cases, with Jakarta reaching 675, and is expected to be announced by the governor of West Java on Monday. Authorities are concerned about a potential new wave of infections and are ramping up rapid testing. The lockdown aims to prevent an exodus of people from the capital to their hometowns, complicating ongoing efforts to halt the spread of the virus.

site_title: Quick takes: MAS carefully nipped Singdollar strength in the bud, analysts say
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased the country's exchange rate-based monetary policy, flattening the pace of the Singapore dollar's appreciation and lowering its nominal effective exchange rate (NEER) band. Analysts say this was a "calibrated move" to maintain stability, with the MAS setting the SGD NEER to zero and reinforcing a weak growth outlook. While the move was seen as a step in the right direction, some analysts believe the MAS could have been more aggressive in its easing, and the medium-term view remains one of further upsides for the USD/SGD exchange rate.

site_title: Twitter removes 2 Bolsonaro tweets questioning virus quarantine
summary: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro's tweets questioning quarantine measures to contain the novel coronavirus were removed by Twitter. The social media platform cited its expanded global rules on managing content that contradicts public health information. Bolsonaro had posted videos flouting social distancing guidelines and urging the economy to continue, despite warnings from Health Minister Luiz Henrique Mandetta. The removals come as Brazil struggles with 3,904 confirmed cases and 114 deaths.

site_title: China's Geely 2019 net profit drops 35% amid broader market slump
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd reported a 35% drop in 2019 net profit to 8.19 billion yuan due to lower sales amid China's prolonged auto market slump. Revenue fell to 97.40 billion yuan, below estimates of 99.43 billion yuan. The company sold 1.36 million cars in 2019, aiming for 1.4 million in 2020. Despite the decline, Geely remains the country's most globally high-profile automaker, with parent Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co Ltd's investments in Volvo Car and Daimler AG.

site_title: Outrage in Germany as Adidas, H&M stop rent payments
summary: Global retailers Adidas and H&M have sparked outrage in Germany after announcing plans to stop paying rent on stores forced to close due to the coronavirus outbreak. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz urged companies to find solutions with landlords, while Justice Minister Christine Lambrecht warned against taking advantage of a government measure shielding tenants from eviction. Adidas, which made a net profit of nearly 2 billion euros in 2019, said it would continue to pay small private landlords, while H&M and other retailers plan to halt rent payments.

site_title: US Justice Department reviews stock trades by lawmakers after coronavirus briefings
summary: The US Justice Department is reviewing stock trades by lawmakers ahead of the coronavirus pandemic, in coordination with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The inquiry is focusing on lawmakers who sold off shares after being briefed on the risks of the crisis. US Republican Senator Richard Burr has been reached out to by the FBI, and he had previously stated that he relied solely on news reports to guide his decisions on stock sales. The investigation is still in its early stages.

site_title: US regulator approves limited use of malaria drugs for virus
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration has approved the limited emergency-use authorization of two antimalarial drugs, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, to treat coronavirus patients. The FDA allowed their distribution to hospitalised teen and adult patients with Covid-19, pending larger clinical trials. President Trump touted the drugs as "game-changers" despite scientists' warnings against overhyping unproven treatments. The US has over 140,000 novel coronavirus cases and 2,489 deaths, and some researchers fear Trump's endorsement could create shortages for patients with lupus and rheumatoid arthritis.

site_title: Seven steps for legacy companies to drive disruptive innovation
summary:
Legacy companies can drive disruptive innovation by adopting a separate innovation function, reframing problem questions from a customer's perspective, and designing a consistent user experience. To achieve this, they should consider the following steps: 

1. Reframe problem questions in terms of customer experience.
2. Design a consistent user experience across all channels.
3. Excite CXOs, business sponsors, and investors with a strong business case.
4. Implement simple, flexible, and adaptable frameworks.
5. Consider using a dedicated marketing and sales organisation.
6. Turn operations and maintenance into an asset for continuous innovation.
7. Foster a culture that supports innovation and accelerates change.

By following these steps, companies can successfully launch ground-breaking products in a bear market and stay competitive against volatile market forces.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on healthcare, financials; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Monday, driven by gains in the healthcare and financial sectors, after a 5.3% drop in the previous session. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 4,911.00, its largest monthly drop ever, but still up for the year. Fears of a deep recession due to the coronavirus outbreak continue to weigh on material and energy stocks.

site_title: SoftBank drops 10% after OneWeb files for bankruptcy protection
summary: SoftBank's shares fell 10% after satellite operator OneWeb filed for bankruptcy protection, citing over $1 billion in liabilities and assets. This marks a setback for SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's plan to raise $41 billion to buy back shares and slash debt. OneWeb had raised $3.3 billion in debt and equity financing, with SoftBank investing $1 billion, and was working on providing affordable high-speed access worldwide. The company had been in advanced discussions for a fresh investment but fell apart due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Base metals fall as coronavirus shutdowns widen, hit demand
summary: Global base metals prices fell as the coronavirus pandemic's shutdowns widened, impacting demand. Industrial metals, including copper, aluminium, nickel, zinc, and lead, declined in value due to concerns about prolonged global shutdowns and their potential economic impact. US President Donald Trump extended stay-at-home guidelines until the end of April, and a senior British medical official warned lockdown measures could last months, fueling market fears. Asian shares slid, and oil prices tumbled as the global shutdown's duration became increasingly uncertain.

site_title: US dollar slows slide as investors seek shelter amid pandemic crisis
summary: The US dollar slowed its decline after a week of losses, steadying against the pound, euro, and other currencies as investors sought safe-haven assets amid the pandemic crisis. The Japanese yen edged ahead, and gold rose 0.5%. The dollar's slide was attributed to a risk-averse mood, with investors favoring broader safe-haven assets. The US has over 137,000 coronavirus cases and 2,400 deaths, with President Trump extending social restrictions until April 30.

site_title: A new solar-panel plant could have capacity to meet half of global demand
summary: GCL System Integration Technology Co plans to build the world's largest solar-panel manufacturing plant, with a capacity to meet half of global demand, in eastern Hefei province, China. The $3.62 billion plant will produce 60 gigawatts of solar panels annually, exceeding China's 2019 capacity of 30 gigawatts. The facility will supply almost 51% of solar installations worldwide, boosting the company's production capacity nine-fold. The project is part of a push by Chinese solar manufacturers to grab greater market share and reduce costs, potentially leading to more pain for the industry.

site_title: SGD makes brief gains following MAS's monetary easing
summary: The Singapore dollar briefly rallied after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) eased monetary policy, with the currency strengthening to 1.426 against the US dollar at noon. The move was seen as a complement to the government's S$48 billion support package to rescue the economy, which is expected to shrink by 1-4% in 2020. Analysts believed the limited currency market reaction was expected due to the MAS's neutral approach, and the brief rally was short-lived, with the dollar weakening again by mid-afternoon.

images.alt_text: The Singapore dollar made a brief rally on Monday morning, shortly after the central bank eased monetary policy in a widely anticipated move due to expectations of a coronavirus-led slowdown.

site_title: Asian markets resume losses as stimulus joy fades
summary: Asian markets declined Monday, following a steep drop on Wall Street, as investors shifted their focus from the US stimulus package to the growing coronavirus crisis. The US stimulus package's effects have faded, and experts predict a worldwide recession. Senior US scientist Anthony Fauci warned of up to 200,000 US deaths, while analysts predict more market turmoil ahead. The uncertainty surrounding the economic impact of the pandemic continues to weigh on markets, with the global economy grinding to a halt and 40% of the world in lockdown.

site_title: StanChart sets aside US$1b to finance pharma firms, mask makers amid Covid-19
summary: Standard Chartered sets aside US$1 billion to finance companies producing goods and services to combat the Covid-19 outbreak, including pharmaceuticals, healthcare providers, and mask manufacturers. The bank will offer financing at preferential rates, including loans, import finance, and working capital facilities. Companies must receive regulatory approvals to manufacture the goods. The move aims to support companies that switch into producing anti-virus products and help existing manufacturers meet the surge in demand.

site_title: Flexible Financing Holds Massive Potential for SME Growth
summary: Flexible financing holds massive potential for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to grow, as traditional financial institutions struggle to meet their needs. According to a recent joint report, innovations in SME working capital financing and consumer lending will comprise half of the US$38 billion annual revenue in digital financial services by 2025. Fintech companies offer flexible lines of credit, which can be structured to meet the unique needs of each business, providing a better alternative to traditional loans. This can help SMEs manage cash flows, mitigate delayed payments, and plan their finances more efficiently, ultimately supporting their growth and sustainability.

site_title: Japanese comedian Ken Shimura dies from coronavirus
summary: Japanese comedian Ken Shimura, 70, died on Sunday evening after being hospitalized with the novel coronavirus in Tokyo. He was one of the country's best-known comedians with a career spanning over four decades. Shimura's death comes as Japan continues to grapple with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Two Indian refiners declare force majeure to curb Middle East oil supply
summary: Two Indian refiners declared force majeure on Middle East oil purchases due to a nationwide lockdown in India, resulting in a sharp decline in local fuel demand. The lockdown, imposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has left millions without work and shut down Asia's third-largest economy. With storage tanks full, companies have cut crude refining.

site_title: Gulf's massive migrant workforce fears virus limbo
summary: Millions of migrant workers across the Gulf, predominantly from Bangladesh, India, Nepal, and Pakistan, face uncertainty as host countries lock down, employers withhold wages, and strict coronavirus containment measures lead to deportations and confinement. Advocacy groups warn that cramped accommodation and inadequate sanitation endanger migrant workers, who may not have access to healthcare. Many fear for their health and job security, with some reporting unpaid leave and arbitrary dismissal. The situation has drawn scrutiny, particularly in Qatar, where the lockdown of a densely populated industrial area has been criticized as a "ground-zero" for the virus.

site_title: Latam Airlines cuts more flights as virus spreads
summary: Latam Airlines, Latin America's largest carrier, suspended further international routes until April 30 due to the global coronavirus pandemic, cutting international operations by 90% and domestic operations by 40%. The airline will continue limited routes between Santiago, Brazil, and Miami, New York, and Los Angeles. Affected passengers can reschedule trips until the end of the year at no extra cost, with ticket values held as credit for future journeys.

site_title: Equis buys South Korean solar, battery storage project; eyes US$2b in investments
summary: Equis Development, a Singapore-based renewable energy developer, has acquired a hybrid solar project in South Korea with a 22MW solar generation component and 70MWh battery storage system for an undisclosed amount. The project, Jara 1 Solar Project, will commence construction in April and generate over 200 jobs. Equis Development expects to invest up to US$2 billion in South Korea over the next three years, with the acquired project being a key component of this investment. The project will provide a stable income stream for the local community through a partnership with the Sinan municipality.

site_title: Rich Europeans flee virus for second homes, spreading fear and fury
summary: Rich Europeans are fleeing to their second homes in France, such as the island of Noirmoutier, amid rumors of a nationwide lockdown to combat the coronavirus outbreak. Locals on the island are expressing frustration and anger at the influx of Parisians, with some physicians labeling the behavior as "irresponsible and selfish." The situation highlights the economic and social disparities between wealthier and poorer regions during the pandemic.

site_title: Cruise company still searching for port for virus ship
summary: A Holland America Line cruise ship, Zaandam, carrying 1,800 passengers, including 42 with flu-like symptoms, has entered the Panama Canal after transferring healthy passengers to another ship and restocking supplies. The ship had been stuck in the Pacific Ocean since March 14 due to refusal from several South American ports to dock. The Panama Canal Authority allowed the ship to transit for humanitarian reasons, but Fort Lauderdale mayor Dean Trantalis rejected the ship's request to dock, citing concerns about the passengers' onward travel arrangements. The ship's passengers, including four who have died, continue to plead for help as the company searches for a port to disembark.

site_title: North Korea says tested multiple rocket launchers
summary: North Korea successfully tested "super-large multiple rocket launchers", state media reported, as part of a series of four firings this month. The test, led by vice-chairman Ri Pyong Chol, was not commanded by leader Kim Jong Un, who was not seen in the photos. Analysts say this move aims to downplay the significance of the launch and reduce the impact on stalled diplomacy with the US. The test comes as North Korea continues to refine its weapons capabilities and amid a prolonged hiatus in disarmament talks with the United States.

site_title: Amazon workers to go on strike at New York site over virus concerns
summary: About 100 Amazon employees at a New York fulfillment centre plan to go on strike over safety concerns and the spread of the coronavirus. The employees are demanding the site be closed for at least two weeks, sanitised, and workers be paid during this time. They also want retroactive compensation for those who stayed home due to health fears. The strike is in response to what the employees claim is Amazon's inaction on safety precautions, including allowing an employee to return to work while awaiting test results.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Monday on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses on Monday, falling 1.97% as the US stimulus and easing measures' euphoria gave way to ongoing coronavirus concerns. The Hang Seng Index dropped 463.43 points to 23,020.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.63% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 1.95%. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: MAS eases Singdollar appreciation to 'zero slope', lowers mid-point of policy band in one-two blow
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased its exchange rate-based monetary policy, returning the Singapore dollar to a neutral stance and lowering the mid-point of the policy band for the first time since 2009. The MAS also lowered its core inflation forecast to between -1% and 0%, reflecting a sharp downgrade due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the economy. This move is seen as a measured response to the deteriorating macroeconomic conditions, with analysts praising the MAS for not moving to the lower bound of the policy band.

site_title: Toyota says most Europe plants won't restart until April 20 at earliest
summary: Toyota has extended the suspension of its European factories until at least April 20, with the exception of its Russian factory, which will close from March 30 to April 3. This follows the suspension of production in North America and other European countries due to the coronavirus epidemic. The company's decision aims to minimize the risk of further disruptions to production.

site_title: Shanghai tops world's IPO league table despite coronavirus
summary: Shanghai has topped the global initial public offering (IPO) league table for the first time in nearly three years, raising US$7.31 billion in the first quarter, surpassing New York's Nasdaq with US$5.13 billion. Despite the coronavirus epidemic, China's markets have fared better than many Western benchmarks, with the CSI 300 down 9.4% for the year. The Chinese government's fiscal response and relaxed rules for follow-on share sales are expected to boost the prospects of companies looking to list on the mainland markets.

site_title: China's Xi says will adjust policies to protect smaller firms from virus impact: state TV
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that the government will adjust policies to protect small and medium-sized firms from the impact of the coronavirus. During a visit to a factory in Ningbo, Xi urged Chinese firms to resume operations and production despite ongoing efforts to control the virus. This move aims to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic on smaller businesses.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at open after MAS eases monetary policy; STI down 2.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.4% on Monday morning after the Monetary Authority of Singapore eased monetary policy by returning the Singapore dollar to a neutral stance and lowering the mid-point of the policy band for the first time since 2009. The MAS also eased the pace at which the currency can strengthen. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,468.51, with banking stocks and heavyweights like Singtel, Genting Singapore, and ComfortDelGro Corporation also experiencing declines.

site_title: Qantas says pilots approve pay deal covering Sydney-London flights
summary: Qantas pilots have approved a pay deal that would enable the airline to fly the world's longest non-stop commercial flights from Sydney to London. The deal, which covers flights on Airbus A350-1000 planes, has been agreed upon due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the airline. The flights could start in the first half of 2023, allowing Qantas to charge premium prices for the non-stop journeys. 85% of pilots voted in favor of the agreement, following initial reservations due to an outsourcing threat and uncertain economic climate.

site_title: Trudeau remains in isolation after wife recovers from virus
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will remain in self-imposed isolation for 14 days despite his wife Sophie Gregoire Trudeau's recovery from COVID-19. Trudeau tested positive after she returned from a trip to London, and he has no symptoms. He cited the need to follow Health Canada's protocols and recommendations. Trudeau has been working remotely and announced new financial measures to support vulnerable Canadians. As of Sunday, 6,243 Canadians had tested positive for the coronavirus, and 64 have died.

site_title: Mortgage bankers ask SEC to save them from wave of margin calls
summary: Mortgage bankers are urging the US Securities and Exchange Commission and the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority to address the issue of margin calls on hedge positions to prevent industry instability. The Mortgage Bankers Association claims that the US Federal Reserve's emergency bond purchases are triggering unsustainable margin calls, putting lenders at risk. The MBA has asked regulators to direct brokers to work constructively with lenders to resolve the issue.

site_title: Unknowns await emerging markets after wildest moves since 2008
summary: Emerging markets face uncertainty after unprecedented economic measures were taken to combat the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a brief rally, stocks, bonds, and currencies have retreated, signaling a prolonged crisis. Many countries, including South Africa, China, and the Philippines, are seeking additional stimulus measures or support from international institutions, such as the International Monetary Fund. Investors are concerned about the impact of the pandemic on developing economies, with some predicting the worst monthly performance since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall more than 3% at open
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted more than 3% at the open on Monday, driven by concerns over the spreading coronavirus and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 and Topix indexes dropped 3.26% and 3.17%, respectively. The Dow Jones ended down 4.1% on Wall Street. Traders attributed the decline to profit-taking sales following US stock falls and the yen's appreciation.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened down more than three per cent on Monday, as traders fret about the spreading coronavirus and a higher yen against the dollar also weighing on the market.

site_title: SoftBank-backed farming startup Plenty is in talks to raise cash
summary: Plenty Inc, a softbank-backed indoor farming startup, is in talks to raise $100 million or more in funding, with SoftBank's Vision Fund leading the round at or below a $1 billion valuation. The company has raised $400 million in capital over the past four years and aims to expand beyond the Bay Area with a new farm in Compton, Los Angeles. Plenty has not commented on the financing proposal, stating it is not in need of new equity financing and will evaluate any proposals opportunistically.

site_title: A death at Jefferies highlights urgency of C-suite backup plans
summary: A coronavirus crisis has highlighted the urgency of C-suite backup plans, with at least one company poised to hire a new CEO largely by video interviews. The death of Jefferies Financial Group's CFO, Peg Broadbent, from complications tied to the virus, underscores the risk of senior executives falling ill. Companies are adapting their succession plans to include more extensive isolation measures and considering roles beyond traditional CEO and CFO positions. Boards are working around the clock to react to the virus, and some are mandating down time for top executives to ensure their health and happiness.

site_title: Peak US death rate likely to hit in two weeks: Trump
summary: President Donald Trump stated that the US peak death rate from the coronavirus pandemic is likely to hit in two weeks. He extended the "social distancing" guidelines until April 30 to slow the spread. Trump also predicted the country will be on its way to recovery by June 1, shifting his previous Easter target.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said on Sunday that the peak death rate in the United States from the coronavirus pandemic was likely to hit in two weeks.

site_title: Crude oil futures slide as pandemic darkens demand outlook
summary: Crude oil futures plummeted Monday, extending last week's losses due to the worsening coronavirus pandemic and the Saudi-Russia price war. US West Texas Intermediate and Brent futures fell 5.2% and 5.6% respectively, reaching lows of $19.92 and $23.53 per barrel. Analysts predict massive production cuts will be needed to counter demand destruction, which could fill global storages in a couple of months, disrupting pricing.

site_title: Japan to expand entry ban to include US, China, most of Europe: Asahi
summary: Japan is set to expand its entry ban to include citizens from the US, China, most of Europe, South Korea, and parts of Southeast Asia and Africa due to the rapid spread of the coronavirus pandemic. The ban may also restrict travel to these countries. This move comes as Japan struggles to contain the virus.

images.alt_text: Japan will expand its entry ban to include citizens travelling from the United States, China, South Korea and most of Europe amid a rapid spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the Asahi newspaper reported on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 20.23 points or 1.51% to 1,322.86. Volume was 129.35 million lots worth RM58.50 million. The market saw a loss-gain ratio of 308 to 65.

site_title: China defends against incoming second wave of coronavirus
summary: China is defending against a potential second wave of coronavirus infections, with imported cases increasing and domestic transmissions remaining low. The country has reported 693 overseas cases, with most coming from Chinese returning home from abroad. Despite easing travel restrictions, concerns about asymptomatic cases remain, and scientists have developed a nanomaterial that can absorb and deactivate the virus. China's death toll has reached 3,300, with 81,439 reported infections, and the government is taking measures to control the spread, including cutting international flights and restarting local transportation services.

site_title: Trump ditches hopes of quick virus bounce-back for US
summary: President Donald Trump extended emergency coronavirus restrictions for another month, shifting his timeline for life returning to normal in the US. The death rate is expected to increase for two weeks, and social distancing guidelines will remain in place until at least the end of April. The US has over 140,000 confirmed Covid-19 infections and 2,467 deaths, with Spain reporting its deadliest day with 838 deaths. The global pandemic has claimed over 33,880 lives, with more than 3.38 billion people under confinement measures worldwide.

site_title: Dollar posts biggest weekly fall since 2009
summary: The US dollar experienced its biggest weekly decline since 2009, falling 3.90% to 98.41 against a basket of currencies on Friday. The decline follows a surge in the dollar in March as markets struggled with the novel coronavirus pandemic. The US House of Representatives approved a $2.2 trillion aid package, supporting a rally in other major currencies. Central bank efforts to increase dollar supply have helped temper the rout, with the dollar index now poised to rebound.

site_title: Michael Sorkin dies from coronavirus; saw architecture as vehicle for change
summary: Architectural critic, author, and urban visionary Michael Sorkin has died at 71 due to complications from the novel coronavirus. A polymath whose work promoted social justice and equality, Sorkin was known for his biting wit and intellectual scope. He was an outspoken critic of the establishment and advocated for housing, green energy, and citizen participation in urban design. Sorkin's designs, mostly unbuilt, ranged from urban planning schemes to sustainable proposals, and he was a prominent voice in the field, inspiring audiences and students to use architecture to change lives.

site_title: Vietnam PM asks major cities to prepare for lockdown to stop virus
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc has asked major cities, including Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, to prepare for possible lockdowns to combat the spread of the coronavirus, with the country nearing 200 confirmed cases. The request comes as the country reviews and updates its virus-fighting plans, with a focus on city lockdown scenarios. This move aims to slow the spread of the virus and protect public health.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's prime minister has asked major cities to prepare for possible lockdowns to stop the spread of the coronavirus as the number of confirmed cases in the South-east Asian country almost reached 200, a government statement said on Monday.

site_title: Bank of Japan says ready to relax capital, liquidity requirements for banks
summary: The Bank of Japan stated it is prepared to relax capital and liquidity requirements for banks, even if they meet necessary requirements, if they demonstrate steady progress in meeting these standards. This move comes in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The central bank's decision aims to support the financial sector and promote market operations.

site_title: World Bank, IMF urge debt relief for poorer countries hit by Covid-19
summary: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund have urged debt relief for poorer countries severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The two organizations have launched emergency programs offering grants and loans to developing countries, with a focus on debt relief from official bilateral creditors. World Bank President David Malpass stated that many countries will need debt relief to fight the pandemic and its consequences, with the bank planning to spend $160 billion over the next 15 months. A joint plan for debt relief is set to be presented at the IMF's virtual Spring Meetings in April.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FHT, Frasers Property, Prime US Reit, Suntec Reit, Riverstone
summary:

Several Singaporean companies saw developments that may impact trading on Monday, March 30, 2020. Meanwhile, Biolidics acquired a cancer diagnostics company, and Singtel's earnings forecast was raised due to a creditors' voluntary winding-up of its joint-venture firm Hooq Digital. Shares of these companies rose on Friday.

site_title: Century-old vaccine investigated as a weapon against coronavirus
summary: A 100-year-old vaccine, Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG), used to prevent tuberculosis, is being tested to see if it can protect against coronavirus. A six-month trial in Melbourne, Australia, involving 4,000 healthcare workers, will determine if the BCG vaccine can reduce disease in those infected with the coronavirus. The vaccine is expected to boost the immune system, defending against a range of infections. Similar research is underway in the Netherlands, with potential trial sites in other cities also being explored. The study aims to protect healthcare workers at high risk of infection.

images.alt_text: A vaccine that's been used to prevent tuberculosis is being given to healthcare workers in Melbourne to see if it will protect them against the coronavirus.

site_title: Gold gains as US dollar weakens, fears of economic damage mount
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,621.85 per ounce as the US dollar weakened, driven by concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The US dollar hit a two-week low, making gold cheaper for investors holding other currencies. The International Monetary Fund warned of a need for "very massive" spending to avoid economic damage. Meanwhile, Asian shares slid and oil prices tumbled as fears of a prolonged global shutdown mounted.

site_title: Scrap EPL season if it can't be finished by end of June, says Tottenham's Kane
summary: England captain Harry Kane suggests the Premier League season should be cancelled if it cannot be completed by the end of June due to the coronavirus pandemic. The current season is suspended until at least April 30, with Euro 2020 cancellation providing a window to conclude domestic seasons in the summer.
