Kane believes finishing the season by June is crucial, as delaying it would have a significant impact on the next term, potentially delaying the start of the 2020-21 season.

site_title: An online lifeline in Portugal for old ventilators amid coronavirus crisis
summary: A Portuguese online platform, Vent2Life, has been launched to repair old, unused ventilators to help combat the coronavirus crisis. The platform connects hospitals with skilled technicians to fix malfunctioning equipment, aiming to repair at least 200 ventilators. Portugal, with a reported 2,362 cases and 33 deaths, is under mounting pressure, and the government has already bought 500 ventilators from China. The platform, backed by companies and universities, hopes to bring ventilators back to life ahead of the expected peak in April, when the epidemic is expected to peak in Portugal.

site_title: Banks win extra year for Basel capital rule because of virus
summary: Global banking regulators delayed new capital requirements for banks due to the COVID-19 pandemic by one year to January 2023. The delay, worth billions of dollars, allows banks to respond to the pandemic's impact on the industry. The Basel rules, which assess risks in mortgages, equities, and derivatives, will be phased in between 2023 and 2028. Regulators aim to ensure banks can provide critical services to the real economy while maintaining financial and operational resilience. The decision was made to support the banking system during the pandemic.

site_title: US sees 518 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours
summary: The US recorded 518 new coronavirus-linked deaths in 24 hours, bringing the country's total deaths to 2,409. The number of cases increased by 21,333, with 136,880 total cases, making the US the hardest-hit region. New York state, the epicenter of the pandemic in the US, has nearly 60,000 cases and 965 deaths. Senior US scientist Anthony Fauci predicted that the novel coronavirus could claim between 100,000 and 200,000 lives in the US.

site_title: Singapore firm Vena Energy sets new bar with inaugural green bond issuance
summary: Vena Energy, a Singapore-based firm, has set a new bar with its inaugural green bond issuance, raising US$325 million in five-year bonds with a fixed coupon of 3.133% per annum. This milestone comes as Vena Energy became the first homegrown firm to offer US dollar-denominated green bonds in February. Industry observers view this as a key step in Singapore's quest to become a global green finance hub.

site_title: CCB warns of risks despite improved Q4 net profit
summary: China Construction Bank (CCB) reported a 2.1% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to 41.39 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. Despite the improvement, the bank warned of new risks and challenges brought by the coronavirus epidemic, including soured loans and global financial market turmoil. CCB chairman Tian Guoli stated the bank will closely monitor these risks, following a similar pattern set by other major Chinese state banks.

site_title: New Zealand central bank gives more liquidity to companies
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) announced it will deploy more tools to provide liquidity to the corporate sector and support market functioning due to the coronavirus. A new weekly Open Market Operation will provide up to NZ$500 million in exchange for eligible corporate and asset-backed securities, starting March 31. Additionally, the bank will offer to purchase government bonds maturing on May 15, 2021, for liquidity management purposes. These measures aim to offset the impact of the pandemic on the economy.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) said on Monday that it was deploying more tools to provide additional liquidity to the corporate sector and support market functioning to offset the impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: 'No farewells, no ceremonies': China's Hubei cremates coronavirus dead
summary: In China's Hubei province, the crematorium in Jingzhou is handling unclaimed urns due to the coronavirus outbreak, with families unable to hold funerals or retrieve the remains of their loved ones. The crematorium's staff work around the clock, wearing full protective gear, as the nation's lockdown eases. The virus has infected over half a million people and killed 25,000, with China's bereaved families unable to participate in traditional funeral rituals.

site_title: Buffett-backed BYD to supply electric-car parts to its rivals
summary: BYD Co, backed by Warren Buffett, will supply electric-car parts to rivals and aspiring vehicle manufacturers under the brand name FinDreams. The company, China's largest EV maker, will offer a full suite of EV components including batteries, powertrains, and lights to diversify revenue amid slowing car demand. Founder Wang Chuanfu announced the move in an online press conference, aiming to reduce dependence on vehicle sales and expand its business.

site_title: Australia curbs gatherings, locks down travellers, in new coronavirus measures
summary: Australia has implemented new coronavirus measures, restricting public gatherings to two people from midnight, with fines of A$1,600 for those who breach the limit. The neighboring states of New South Wales and Victoria account for most of Australia's total Covid-19 infections and death toll, now at 17. Tasmania has also imposed a two-person limit on public gatherings and banned movement between holiday homes. Travelers arriving in Australia from overseas must go into monitored quarantine for 14 days. The federal government has also paused loan repayments for six months and evictions for renters.

site_title: Dubai property group Limitless seeks advisers for restructuring
summary: Dubai-based property developer Limitless is seeking legal and financial advisers to work on a financial restructuring plan. The company, which was heavily affected by the 2009 property crash and subsequent debt crisis, is among several entities in Dubai that have been forced to restructure their debts. Limitless, formerly owned by state investment vehicle Dubai World, is looking to address its financial challenges, following a similar path to other entities in the region.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Resilience Budget - helping Singapore's businesses stay afloat
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses the Resilience Budget, a scheme to help Singaporean businesses stay afloat amidst economic uncertainty. The episode was part of The Breakfast Huddle with Elliott Danker, Manisha Tank, and finance presenter Ryan Huang. No other key events or conclusions are mentioned in the provided article.

site_title: Turkish central bank predicts strong growth despite coronavirus
summary: Turkey's central bank predicts strong growth in the first quarter despite the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, citing a strong January and February. The economy remains resilient, with no noticeable signs of weakening consumption apart from travel spending. However, ratings agencies warn that Turkey could be hit hard by the pandemic, with growth contracting by 7% in the second and third quarters. The Turkish lira has fallen 8% against the US dollar this year due to the global sell-off.

images.alt_text: Turkey's central bank expects high first-quarter growth thanks to a strong January and February, its deputy governor was quoted as saying on Sunday, as the nation battles to contain the coronavirus.

site_title: US could take equity shares in coronavirus-hit airlines: officials
summary: The US government is considering taking equity shares in coronavirus-hit airlines and other vital corporations in exchange for direct cash grants or loans. White House economics adviser Larry Kudlow and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the government could take a stake in companies receiving federal aid, with Mnuchin stating that taxpayers should be compensated. The massive $50 billion airline rescue plan includes $25 billion in direct cash payments and loan guarantees, with warrants also being considered as a form of equity participation.

site_title: ASTI CEO withdraws resignation amid 'challenging times' for company
summary: ASTI Holdings CEO Michael Loh Soon Gnee has withdrawn his resignation amid "challenging times" due to the coronavirus pandemic and US-China trade war. He had initially tendered his resignation in April 2020 due to "personal reasons" but will continue to lead the semiconductor manufacturer. The company has struggled to find a replacement for Loh, and shares rose 5% after his decision. Loh has strong relationships with major suppliers and customers, and his experience will be crucial for the company during uncertain times.

site_title: Indonesia prepares to lock down 30m people to curb spread of virus
summary: Indonesia prepares to lock down 30 million people in its capital and surrounding areas to curb the spread of the coronavirus. The lockdown, expected to be announced on Monday, follows a spike in confirmed cases in Jakarta, with the number of infections reaching 675. The plan aims to prevent an exodus of people from the capital city area to their hometowns or villages, where they may spread the virus. Authorities have already declared a state of emergency in Jakarta and are ramping up rapid testing of suspected cases.

site_title: Trump says US won't pay Harry and Meghan security
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the US will not pay security costs for Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, who have moved to live in California. The couple reportedly flew in on a private jet from Canada before the border closure due to the coronavirus outbreak. Trump's tweet confirmed the couple's decision to leave their royal duties and pursue an independent life. The couple, who have ties to Los Angeles, will now be responsible for their own security protection.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said Sunday that the United States would not pay security costs for Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, appearing to confirm that the royal couple have moved to live in California.

site_title: Egypt's banks told to limit withdrawals and deposits
summary: Egypt's central bank has instructed banks to temporarily limit daily withdrawals and deposits to control inflation and hoarding amid the coronavirus pandemic. Individuals are limited to 10,000 Egyptian pounds (S$907.10) and companies to 50,000 pounds, with exemptions for businesses using the funds to pay employees. Additionally, daily ATM withdrawals and deposits are limited to 5,000 pounds. This move aims to prevent hoarding and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Europe bonds await next supply wave amid fiscal-shock anxiety
summary: European bond markets are set to receive a significant supply of debt from top borrowers this week, despite investor concerns about a tsunami of issuance to fund stimulus plans. Germany, France, Spain, and Italy are scheduled to auction 25 billion euros in debt, while the UK will offer 5 billion pounds. The European Central Bank's emergency debt-buying program has helped drive down euro-area bond yields, and investors expect a lower policy rate by year-end. The ECB's purchases have also boosted excess liquidity, easing concerns about a supply surge.

site_title: London's iconic Ritz hotel sold for below £800m
summary: The Ritz Hotel in London has been sold to a Qatari investor for less than £800 million (S$1.42 billion), according to a statement from law firm Macfarlanes. The sale comes amid a dispute among the heirs of British billionaire Barclay twins, with Frederick Barclay's son and daughter objecting to the deal. The sale appears to have been pushed through during the coronavirus crisis to avoid contestation. The twins, who own the hotel, had previously received competing offers exceeding £1 billion and had threatened legal action if the sale price was lower.

site_title: Hong Kong to provide 2nd round of financial aid to companies
summary: Hong Kong's government will introduce a second round of financial aid to companies affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The subsidies from the Epidemic Prevention Fund aim to protect workers, following a first aid package announced last month. The government reported a surge in coronavirus cases, with the daily increase rising to over 60, and nearly quadrupling the number of infections in the past two weeks. The move is seen as a response to the economic challenges faced by the city, which may drag on for an extended period of time.

site_title: Market call difficult in generation-defining moment
summary: US stocks experienced a record-breaking correction to the fastest correction in history, driven by contrasting investor sentiments of complacency and panic due to the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 24% year-to-date before rebounding sharply in a historic "all-in" policy response. Despite a strong rally, the outlook for high stock market volatility and a still-downward trend remains uncertain, with the coronavirus's severity and duration unknown. Investors are advised to approach the market with caution, prioritizing risk-mitigation and quality over all-clear signals, and considering strategies to minimize regret, such as selling low-quality bonds and moving to higher-quality peers.

site_title: China's US$30t market promise beckons global wealth companies
summary: China's trillion-dollar asset-management market is opening wider, with foreign firms like BlackRock and Vanguard seeking to tap the market, expected to reach $30 trillion by 2023. Starting April 1, firms can apply for wholly-owned mutual fund management licenses, boosting ownership in existing joint venture partnerships, or pursuing venture private funds. Foreign players are expected to only account for 6% of revenue generated in the asset management space by 2023, but a significant opportunity nonetheless, with the potential to be worth $8 billion.

site_title: World's top glove maker sees shortage as virus fight spikes
summary: Top Glove Corporation Bhd, the world's largest glove maker, expects a product shortage due to a surge in demand from Europe and the US amid the coronavirus outbreak. The company has extended shipping times and is adjusting delivery times from 30 days to 150 days to cope with the demand. Orders are almost double the company's production capacity, with the company adding new machines every week and increasing production by up to 30%. The company is also sourcing local workers to help with the increased demand.

site_title: Australia tightens social distancing rules to combat coronavirus
summary: Australia tightened social distancing rules to combat the coronavirus, implementing fines and closing beaches in states with high case numbers. The country's death toll rose to 14, with most cases in NSW and Victoria states. Returning citizens from abroad will be put into compulsory quarantine in hotels for two weeks. The government is urging people to stay home and cancel social gatherings, with Victoria and South Australia implementing on-the-spot fines for those breaking rules.

site_title: Suntec City unveils second rent assistance package
summary: Suntec City, a major mall in Singapore, has unveiled its second rent assistance package in support of the government's Resilience Budget. The package includes a half-month rental rebate for each of the months of April, May, and June 2020, benefiting over 97% of its tenants. This addition to the earlier disbursement brings total relief to retail tenants of up to 2.75 months. The company will also suspend rents for tenants in closed leisure and entertainment venues until April 30.

site_title: 42 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with 3 cases forming new cluster in Yishun
summary: Singapore reported 42 new Covid-19 cases, including 24 imported cases from Europe, North America, and other regions, and 18 local cases with no recent travel history. A new cluster was identified at a bridal salon in Yishun, with three cases, including a 22-year-old woman hospitalised at Changi General Hospital. Fourteen cases were discharged, bringing the total to 212, and 19 remain in critical condition. Singapore also reported its third coronavirus death, a 70-year-old man with no recent travel history.

site_title: Stimulus lifts STI but not everyone is a buyer
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index gained 1.66% last week, closing at 2,528.76, driven by the government's Covid-19 relief package. However, market experts caution that the bounce may be short-lived, with the CBOE Volatility Index still high. Research by Goldman Sachs suggests that US bear markets since the 1880s averaged 29-57% declines, highlighting cyclical and structural vulnerabilities. Meanwhile, investors are betting on China's gradual recovery, with some preferring online gaming and retail stocks.

site_title: Signs indicate EURGBP at inflection point
summary: EURGBP pair is at an inflection point, poised for a rebound after piercing the upper band of its 1,000-pip range. The resistance level at 0.9307 has been validated by past rejections, and the stochastics oscillator is showing an overbought condition. The MACD indicator also suggests a reversal, with the signal line below the 0 line and MACD histogram above. The next level of support is at 0.8617, with the bottom of the range at 0.8311.

site_title: The many benefits of inclusive hiring
summary: Singaporean companies are embracing inclusive hiring, citing benefits such as increased job satisfaction, improved work environment, and enhanced company culture. Four companies, including Bernard Chan's, Soap Ministry, and Pan Pacific Hotels Group, have successfully integrated employees with disabilities into their workforce. The Enabling Employment Credit scheme launched in Budget 2020 provides support for employers of persons with disabilities. However, experts emphasize the need for education, training, and resources to overcome hurdles such as miscommunication, fixed mindsets, and bandwidth limitations. To make inclusive hiring successful, companies must be open to change, redesign job scopes, and prioritize communication and respect for employees with disabilities.

site_title: Asean continues to miss own targets for economic integration: business council
summary: Asean continues to struggle with regional economic integration, missing targets despite a record high inflow of foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2018. The EU-Asean Business Council warns that underlying concerns, including non-tariff barriers to trade and investment, are masking the true state of the region's economic integration. Intra-Asean trade remains flat, and the region risks being no more than the sum of its parts if non-tariff barriers are not removed. The council calls for more collective action to advance development and improve competitiveness.

site_title: Coronavirus prompts layoffs at e-scooter startup Bird
summary: Electric-scooter startup Bird is laying off nearly a third of its workforce, around 30% of its staff, to survive the economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company has paused shared scooter operations in many markets and drastically cut spending. Founder Travis VanderZanden cited an "unknown timeline" and economic situation as the reason for the cuts. Employees will receive severance pay and extended health plan coverage. The move comes as other transportation companies, like Lime, also adjust their operations amid the pandemic.

site_title: UK warned to expect months of virus measures
summary: The UK is expected to remain under lockdown for six months or longer due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, according to Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries. The current rules to stay at home are expected to take two to three weeks to assess their impact on the spread of Covid-19. The death toll has surpassed 1,200, but Harries expressed optimism that the current measures could "squash the top of the infection curve." The UK's economy also contracted for the second month in a row, adding to the country's economic woes.

images.alt_text: Life in locked-down Britain may not return to normal for six months or longer as it battles the coronavirus outbreak, a top health official warned on Sunday, as the death toll reached passed 1,200.

site_title: Prime US Reit seeking assets in growing job markets
summary: Prime US Reit, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (REIT), is focused on acquiring assets in growing job markets in the US. The REIT's CEO, Barbara Cambon, believes the US office supply market remains limited, with vacancy rates stable due to the growth of sectors such as technology and finance. Prime has a diversified portfolio of 11 prime and freehold office properties in nine primary US markets, with a total appraised value of US$1.25 billion. The REIT aims to grow its portfolio through organic and inorganic strategies, targeting yield-accretive assets in strategic markets where US corporations are expanding their operations.

site_title: Global oil market close to collapse due to global lockdowns
summary: The global oil market is on the brink of collapse due to unprecedented lockdowns and reduced consumption. With the world's largest economies shutting down, oil demand has plummeted by up to 20 million barrels a day, causing a catastrophic surplus. Refineries are shutting down, and storage tanks are full, forcing traders to store excess oil in idle supertankers. The collapse in commercial air travel has cut jet fuel use by up to 75%, and the shutdown of vast swathes of the economy has decimated demand for petrol and other fuels.

site_title: Gold's safe-haven status tarnished by speculators
summary: Gold's price has become increasingly volatile due to short-term investors and speculators dumping the precious metal to raise cash, despite its supposed safe-haven status. The World Gold Council and analysts are concerned about the unpredictable price moves, citing factors such as the coronavirus crisis and negative interest rates. Gold's price has fallen in tandem with the stock market and risen with equity markets, but has struggled to match its 2011 record price. The gold market is multi-faceted, with investors and speculators contributing to price gyrations, and the true value of gold lies in its monetary and industrial uses.

site_title: Taxi, private-hire car drivers allowed to deliver food and groceries to address delivery slot shortage during Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Singapore has allowed taxi and private-hire car drivers to deliver food and groceries due to a delivery slot shortage during the Covid-19 outbreak. The measure aims to supplement income for drivers and help address the issue of limited delivery slots on online grocery platforms. The government has temporarily liberalized regulations to enable drivers to participate in delivery services, with the option to continue until the end of June. This move is part of efforts to support the economy and alleviate the burden on traditional passenger services.

site_title: Flexiwork to the fore
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the shift towards flexible work arrangements, with many companies embracing large-scale work-from-home initiatives. CEOs from various organizations, including HSBC Singapore, The American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore, and AXA Insurance, express their openness to flexible work and its benefits, such as improved work-life balance, reduced real estate costs, and increased productivity. However, they also highlight the need for companies to invest in digital tools and security measures to support remote work. Many experts believe that flexible work will become the new norm, enabling companies to attract and retain talent, reduce business travel, and increase online events and meetings.

images.alt_text: Tony Cripps, Chief Executive Officer, HSBC Singapore.

site_title: Straco says Shanghai Ocean Aquarium to remain closed due to Covid-19
summary: The Shanghai Ocean Aquarium, operated by Straco Corporation, will remain closed due to the evolving Covid-19 situation in Shanghai. The aquarium initially closed in January but reopened on March 18, only to close again on March 30, 2020, as a precautionary measure. Straco will continue to monitor the financial impact of the crisis on its performance and will announce a re-opening date when the situation improves.

site_title: Australia home sales slump after public auctions banned
summary: Australia's home sales slump after public auctions were banned due to social-distancing measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic. 3,203 properties were scheduled for auction, but 40% were pulled from the market. Only 51.4% of houses sold, the lowest clearance rate since June 2019. The ban affects individual inspections and auctions, with some listings switching to private sales and others pulling properties from the market until confidence improves.

site_title: Spanish hotels are turned into medical bunkhouses
summary: Spanish hotels are being converted into medical bunkhouses to accommodate doctors and nurses fighting the Covid-19 pandemic. Many hotels in Madrid, Italy, and Spain are now idle due to lockdowns, with millions of foreign visitors cancelled. Hoteliers are donating empty rooms to healthcare workers, and some are considering closing for the year. The pandemic may lead to structural changes in the tourism industry, with travellers becoming more cautious about mass gatherings and cash-strapped airlines re-introducing services gradually.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market continues to be impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with many regions experiencing force majeure declarations and reduced cargo volumes. The Cape market saw a decline in prices, with the Cape 5TC closing out the week at $3,675, down -392. The Panamax market also saw a decrease, with rates for fronthaul trips fixed in the $8,000's. The Supramax market suffered significant losses, with the average of the timecharter routes posting losses of $1,092. The Handysize Index declined, with limited cargo support and volume thin in both East Coast South America and the US Gulf.

site_title: UK seeks to shield businesses by amending bankruptcy rules
summary: The UK government is amending bankruptcy rules to allow struggling businesses to continue trading if they can't pay debts due to the coronavirus pandemic. Changes will enable firms being reorganized to access supplies and raw materials without being placed into administration by creditors. Additionally, a clause will temporarily remove personal liability for company directors during the pandemic. The measures aim to give firms extra time to weather the crisis while ensuring creditors get the best return possible.

site_title: French chefs cook up antidote for virus confinement
summary: French celebrity chefs are using television and social networks to help the public cope with the COVID-19 pandemic confinement. Shows like "Everyone in the Kitchen" and online classes are featuring simple, easy-to-make recipes using common ingredients. Chefs such as Cyril Lignac, Amandine Chaignot, and Alexandre Mazzia are sharing recipes and cooking tips on social media, aiming to improve people's daily lives by cooking at home. The goal is to prove that cooking can be easy, good, and affordable, even with limited ingredients and equipment.

site_title: Stock market's massive rebound may not last amid dire economic slowdown, analysts warn
summary: US stocks surged into bull-market territory last week following a record-breaking $2.2 trillion fiscal stimulus and the Federal Reserve's efforts to stabilize markets. However, analysts warn that this rebound may not last due to an unpredictable economic slowdown caused by the coronavirus. Individual households may receive up to $3,400 in stimulus payments, but the effectiveness of these measures remains uncertain. The market's resilience is being tested as investors await signs of whether conventional economic measures can combat the virus's impact.

site_title: Banks should stop share buybacks and cap their dividends
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have engaged in aggressive share buybacks during the market's downturn. This move is seen as a strategic decision to preserve capital and provide timely information to investors. The banks' share prices have sunk despite the buybacks, suggesting they believe their shares have value. With a historic recession looming, the banks' actions aim to maintain financial stability and provide clarity to investors.

site_title: Emergency flights for tens of thousands stranded by virus in South Asia
summary: Foreign governments have stepped up operations to evacuate tens of thousands of tourists stranded by the coronavirus pandemic in South Asia, particularly in Nepal and Sri Lanka. Almost 17,000 tourists are stuck in Sri Lanka, while tens of thousands are in India. Charter flights have been chartered by countries such as Germany and Australia to transport stranded tourists, with the goal of evacuating around 10,000 people. The evacuations come as international flights have been cut or halted in the region to halt the spread of the deadly novel coronavirus.

site_title: Trump's ventilator demands will test carmaker supply chains
summary: US President Donald Trump is accelerating efforts to produce ventilators for Covid-19 victims, leveraging the manufacturing capabilities of carmakers like Ford and General Motors. The companies have vast supply chains, skilled engineers, and "clean rooms" in their factories, making them well-suited to build the highly intricate medical devices. Trump invoked federal authority to accelerate output, and several carmakers, including Airbus and Tesla, have offered to help produce ventilators. While questions remain about their ability to meet demand and ensure patient safety, they represent the best hope for meeting the overwhelming demand for the life-saving equipment.

site_title: SGX grants time extensions for AGMs to First Sponsor, Serrano
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Singapore property developer, has obtained a waiver from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) to postpone its annual general meeting (AGM) for its 2019 financial year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The AGM is now expected to take place by June 30, with the company issuing its annual report and notice by April 15 and June 14, respectively. This allows the company to put in place alternative arrangements for the AGM while adhering to stricter gathering size limits.

site_title: Taiwan says US media expelled from China are welcome
summary: Taiwan's foreign minister, Joseph Wu, has welcomed American journalists expelled from China, who are now free to set up shop in Taiwan. The 13 journalists, from the New York Times, Washington Post, and Wall Street Journal, were expelled by Beijing as part of a spat over media freedoms. Taiwan, which has emerged as one of Asia's freest societies, sees itself as a beacon of freedom and democracy, and is eager to attract foreign journalists. The move is seen as a victory for Taiwan, which has long been critical of China's human rights record.

site_title: Hedge funds are pouncing on companies infected by coronavirus
summary: Hedge funds are capitalizing on the coronavirus pandemic's economic downturn, betting on depressed stocks, corporate bonds, and commodities. Despite billions of dollars in losses, funds are urging clients to invest in the markets, citing the 2008 financial crisis as a comparable period of low valuations. Funds are targeting companies with high-quality bonds or loans and are positioning themselves for massive government stimulus packages to revive markets. Billionaires like Kenneth Griffin are warning of the pandemic's risks, and some economists predict a global recession.

site_title: As US virus cases exceed 100,000, doctors decry scarcity of drugs and equipment
summary: The US has surpassed 100,000 known COVID-19 cases, with over 1,600 deaths, as doctors plead for more protective gear and equipment to treat patients. Shortages of ventilators, medical supplies, and trained staff are widespread, with hospitals in New York City, New Orleans, and other virus hotspots sounding the alarm. US President Donald Trump invoked emergency powers to require General Motors to build ventilators, while Congress passed a $2.2 trillion relief package to aid hospitals and businesses.

site_title: Social distancing works against virus: Aussie PM
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced an additional A$1.1 billion to expand telemedicine care and health services amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The daily increase in cases has halved to 13-15% from 25-30% a week ago, indicating social distancing measures are working. There are 3,809 confirmed cases, with 16 deaths, and two-thirds of cases linked to contact with overseas travelers. State leaders are concerned about rising community transmission, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, and are urging consistency in containment measures.

site_title: Riverstone sees demand surge for healthcare gloves amid virus outbreak
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysia-headquartered glove manufacturer, sees a surge in orders for healthcare gloves amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The company is producing as many as it can, but orders will only reach end users in October due to production capacity constraints. Riverstone's production facilities are running at 90-93% utilisation rate, and the company is increasing its production capacity to 10.4 billion gloves per annum. Despite stiff competition, Riverstone's healthcare glove segment is growing faster than its cleanroom glove segment, which generates higher margins. The company's shares have outperformed the broader market despite a recent sell-off.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong says during the 2008 global financial crisis, Riverstone had to build up its resilience, so it decided to balance its cyclically sensitive but higher margin cleanroom segment with the more defensive but lower margin healthcare glove segment.

site_title: 'Corona criminals' prey on Europe's virus fears
summary: Criminals are exploiting the COVID-19 pandemic to profit from Europe's virus fears, selling substandard protective goods, counterfeit medicines, and running internet scams. Police agencies, including Europol, have reported a rise in online fraud, phishing, and scams targeting vulnerable individuals. Counterfeit surgical masks, cybercrime, and burglaries have seen a decrease, but cybercrime and online scams are on the rise. Authorities warn of a surge in domestic violence, anti-social behavior, and exploitation of the elderly, with some police stations seeing a 30% increase in domestic violence reports.

site_title: US lab unveils portable 5-minute Covid-19 test
summary: A US-based lab, Abbot Laboratories, has developed a portable Covid-19 test that can provide results in as little as 5 minutes. The test, which is the size of a small toaster, uses molecular technology and has been given emergency authorization by the FDA to be made available to healthcare providers. The test's small size allows for deployment outside hospitals in outbreak hotspots, and Abbott is working with the FDA to send it to virus epicenters.

site_title: Startups ride wave of digital entertainment as more stay indoors
summary: Digital entertainment startups in South-east Asia are thriving as more people stay indoors due to the Covid-19 pandemic. User activity has surged, with platforms like Viddsee seeing a 50% increase in unique users in the Philippines. Companies are developing new ways to engage consumers, such as portable home karaoke systems and e-sports firms. The rise of digital entertainment is expected to continue, driven by the growing demand for online content and entertainment options.

images.alt_text: User activity is climbing higher and higher for digital entertainment startups in South-east Asia as more people stay indoors due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies ranging from an e-sports firm to a seller of portable home karaoke systems told The Business Times that more people are seeking ways to lift their spirits while stuck at home.

site_title: Fitch downgrades UK debt to AA-, outlook negative
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded the UK's debt to AA- from AAA, citing significant weakening of public finances and damage to the economy from the coronavirus pandemic. The negative outlook reflects concerns over the economy's ability to recover and the impact of lingering Brexit uncertainty. The downgrade comes as the UK economy shrinks for a second month, adding to the pressure on policymakers to address the economic challenges.

site_title: 42 new coronavirus cases in Singapore; 3 cases form new cluster in Yishun
summary: Singapore reported 42 new confirmed Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 844. A new cluster of 3 cases was identified at The Wedding Brocade bridal salon in Yishun. 24 imported cases were linked to travel to Europe, North America, and Asia, while 18 local cases had no recent travel history. A 70-year-old man, Chung Ah Lay, died from complications due to Covid-19, marking the third coronavirus death in Singapore. Contact tracing is ongoing for new cases, and 14 more patients were discharged from hospitals or isolation facilities.

site_title: Trump invokes defence powers to order GM to produce ventilators
summary: President Donald Trump invoked the Defense Production Act to force General Motors to manufacture ventilators, as supplies of the equipment grow short amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The order requires GM to accept and prioritize federal contracts for ventilators, following delays in negotiations. Trump claimed GM was "wasting time" and that the action will help ensure the quick production of ventilators to save American lives.

site_title: NTUC suggests running upcoming public golf course jointly with SICC
summary: The Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) is considering a proposal to jointly run the Sime Public Golf Course with the National Union of Students in Singapore (NTUC) following a January 8th announcement from NTUC. The proposal aims to optimize operations, reduce costs, and improve synergy between the two courses, which share common infrastructure. SICC has set up a task force to assess the proposal's financial and operational viability, with a special task force and independent firm to be engaged. Members are expected to provide explicit approval for the collaboration, with an extraordinary general meeting to be held once the terms are known.

images.alt_text: SICC, Singapore's oldest and grandest golf and country club has four 18-hole courses - two at Bukit and two at its Island location.

site_title: European airlines resist mounting coronavirus refund claims
summary: European airlines are resisting mounting coronavirus refund claims by seeking to suspend EU rules requiring refunds for cancellations and instead issue vouchers to customers. The airlines argue that issuing immediate refunds would be a significant cash drain, but consumer groups condemn the move, saying it would force consumers to lend airlines money. The European Commission has rejected industry calls to relax refund requirements, and some airlines are disabling refunds online and offering only vouchers. Airlines are now asking authorities to waive refund requirements if vouchers are reimbursable after a year.

site_title: Wee Investments up UOL, Haw Par stakes
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 7.6% from March 20 to 26, driven by a 9.6% gain in the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index. In share buybacks, DBS Group Holdings led with 2.2 million shares purchased at an average price of S$17.31 per share. Wee Investments acquired 1,003,000 UOL Group shares for S$6,245,560, increasing Wee Cho Yaw's stake to 37.45%. Meanwhile, Wee Ee Lim's stake in UOL Group rose to 14.82%, and Wee Ee Chao's stake in Haw Par Corporation increased to 36.23%.

site_title: New date for Tokyo Olympics 'won't satisfy everybody', says Coe
summary: World Athletics president Sebastian Coe stated that settling on a new date for the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 will not satisfy every sport. Coe noted that various sports have specific challenges at particular times of the year, making it unlikely to find a solution that meets the approval of all sports.

site_title: Apple's factories are running, but suppliers wary about iPhone demand
summary: Apple's iPhone factories are operating in China, but suppliers are cautious about demand due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Orders for the quarter ending in March are expected to drop 18% compared to last year, and the production ramp-up for new 5G phones has been postponed. Suppliers, including display manufacturers, are adjusting their production targets and workforce levels, with some considering reducing their targets by over 17%. The uncertainty around demand has made it challenging for Apple suppliers to gauge the company's performance, with some predicting a "V-shaped" recovery and others anticipating a more gradual improvement.

site_title: URA urges showflat viewings by appointments amid Covid-19
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has urged developers to adopt safe-distancing measures at their sales galleries and limit group sizes to 10 persons, amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The measures include ensuring a minimum of one person per 16 square meters of usable space and implementing space markings for queues. Developers are also required to contact the URA's office before opening their show galleries to public viewing. This move aims to minimize the spread of the virus and reduce crowds at showflats.

site_title: Tokyo restricts movement to combat virus, some folk carry on as usual
summary: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike urges citizens to stay indoors until April 12 to prevent a potential state of emergency due to a surge in coronavirus infections, which have climbed to over 1,400 in Japan with 47 deaths. Despite the restrictions, some people continue to carry on as usual, with many millions more in surrounding suburbs. The city's total cases have risen to 299, with a high risk of an explosive rise in infections due to untracked contacts. The government has deployed the military to assist in virus screenings and quarantine transport.

site_title: Small businesses become endangered in virus-stricken New York
summary: New York's coronavirus outbreak has led to widespread closures of small businesses, with many forced to shut down or significantly reduce operations. Biscuits & Bath and Otto Enoteca, two dog daycare and restaurant companies, have temporarily shut down due to lack of revenue. The US$2 trillion relief bill signed into law aims to provide forgivable loans to small businesses, but experts are skeptical about the speed and availability of the funds, potentially leaving many businesses struggling to recover.

images.alt_text: As New York becomes the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States, even die-hard businesses are shutting down in the so-called "city that never sleeps."

site_title: ECB asks banks to halt dividends over virus crisis
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has asked eurozone banks to freeze dividend payments until October 2020 to preserve liquidity during the coronavirus crisis. The ECB also advises banks not to buy back shares, to support lending to households and businesses. The proposal is aimed at boosting banks' capacity to absorb losses and maintain maximum capital preservation. Compliance with the proposal is estimated to keep an extra 30 billion euros of capital in the financial system.

site_title: Instacart gig workers threaten walkoff over virus safety
summary: Instacart gig workers are threatening a walkout next week unless the company provides coronavirus hazard pay and safety supplies, including disinfectant wipes and protective gear. The group, called the Gig Workers Collective, claims Instacart is "profiting astronomically" while putting workers at risk. The company has announced new health and safety measures, including bonuses for in-store shopping and two weeks pay for hourly employees or full-time shoppers diagnosed with Covid-19 or quarantined. Instacart aims to add 300,000 more shoppers to meet surge in demand.

site_title: Stranded by virus lockdown, India migrant workers walk home
summary: Millions of migrant workers in India, who were left jobless due to the country's coronavirus lockdown, are walking long distances back to their home villages. With no way to earn money, many are forced to choose between walking home or going hungry. Thousands have already set out on foot, while authorities have organized buses and flights to take some home, with health checks in place. The government has announced a $23 billion welfare package to help the poorest citizens, including migrant workers, with direct cash transfers and food subsidies.

site_title: China dialing back virus conspiracy claims, US says
summary: China has largely abandoned its conspiracy theory claims that the US was responsible for the origin of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a US official. The State Department's Global Engagement Centre reported that Chinese government social media postings showed "mostly negative reactions" in Africa to the conspiracy theory. Instead, China is now praising its own successes in containing the virus and delivering aid abroad. The US continues to view Russia as a major concern, with thousands of Russian-linked social media accounts running a coordinated campaign to undermine official narratives.

site_title: China's Xi offers Trump help in coronavirus fight as Wuhan reopens to traffic
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping offered US President Donald Trump help in fighting the coronavirus, following a war of words between the two nations over the pandemic. Wuhan, the Chinese city where the outbreak emerged, reopened to incoming traffic on Friday. The US now has the most coronavirus cases of any country, with nearly 85,000 infections. China has sent virus data to US scientists and will send more after Trump and Xi spoke by telephone.

site_title: Customer leaves US$10,000 tip, anonymously, in Florida restaurant
summary: A customer anonymously left a US$10,000 tip to be divided among the employees of Skillets restaurant in Naples, Florida, a day before the restaurant was forced to close due to the coronavirus outbreak. The owner, Ross Edlund, expressed gratitude and said the gesture shows "truly fantastic people in the world." The US$10,000 was evenly split among the 20 employees, with each receiving US$500. The customer's identity remains unknown.

site_title: Trump signs US$2t recovery plan as US virus cases skyrocket
summary: US President Donald Trump signed the $2 trillion rescue plan to combat the coronavirus pandemic, bringing an end to a dramatic legislative saga on Capitol Hill. The package includes relief checks of up to $3,400 for families, $100 billion for hospitals, and $377 billion in grants for small businesses. The measure also expands unemployment assistance for 3.3 million jobless claims. Despite the legislative breakthrough, US stocks sank, and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin pledged a speedy distribution of checks, with direct deposits expected in three weeks.

site_title: Spain death toll hits 4,858 as 769 die in 24 hours
summary: Spain's COVID-19 death toll reached 4,858, with 769 deaths in 24 hours, a record one-day figure. The country has increased testing, ordering millions of kits worldwide, and medical staff cases have surged to 9,444, straining the healthcare system. Despite a slowdown in new infections, hospitals face continued pressure, and Spain has urged EU member states to provide financial solidarity to combat the crisis. The economic impact is being felt, with the labor ministry banning layoffs and Finance Minister Maria Jesus Montero warning that the EU's future is at stake if member states do not work together.

site_title: Philanthropy is Phillip's second name
summary: Philippine tycoon John Gokongwei, also known as "Philanthropy," has been described as the type of man he is after leaving a firm. No further information is provided about this event.

site_title: S&P cuts Airbus outlook amid concern over deliveries, advances
summary: Standard & Poors cut Airbus' outlook to negative due to concerns over aircraft deliveries and advance payments from airlines affected by the coronavirus crisis. The ratings agency estimated a 5 billion euro funding gap per month, citing a large majority of airlines' pre-delivery payments had already received financing before the crisis. Airbus has boosted liquidity to 30 billion euros and may use its Airbus Bank subsidiary to tap liquidity from the European Central Bank.

site_title: Canada pumps C$200b into virus-stricken economy
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a C$200 billion economic aid package to boost the country's virus-stricken economy. The measures include a 75% wage subsidy for small and medium businesses, as well as grants, tax deferrals, and low-interest loans. The Bank of Canada also lowered a key interest rate to 0.25% to cushion the impact of the pandemic. The package comes as a parliamentary report forecasts a 5.1% contraction of Canada's economy in 2020, the worst since 1962.

site_title: Seniors enjoy walk on golf courses
summary: Seniors in Singapore are enjoying a unique perk: walking on golf courses. The trend began during the COVID-19 pandemic, when the government lifted restrictions, allowing golf courses to reopen. This has led to a surge in golf activity among seniors, who can now enjoy the sport without the need for formal membership or lessons. The relaxed atmosphere has made golf more accessible to this age group, providing a new way for them to stay active and socialize.

site_title: SoftBank's bet on sharing economy backfires with Covid-19
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund, backed by billionaire Masayoshi Son, is facing a crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund's investments in sharing economy startups, such as WeWork, Uber, and Didi Chuxing, are struggling as people stay home, reducing demand. SoftBank's shares have tumbled 50% in a month, and the company is considering selling assets to raise $41 billion to buy back shares and slash debt. Investors fear that SoftBank's portfolio companies may not survive, threatening Son's reputation as a tech investor.

site_title: IMF chief: 'Clear we have entered recession'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief, Kristalina Georgieva, stated that the global economy has entered a recession, worse than the 2009 financial crisis, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The IMF estimates the global financial needs of emerging markets at $2.5 trillion, with over 80 countries requesting emergency aid. Georgieva warned that domestic resources are insufficient to cover the needs, but the IMF is aiming to increase its response. The US has approved a $2.2 trillion economic package, which also boosts the IMF's lending capacity to $1 trillion.

site_title: Pros Choo and Koh secure sponsorship
summary: Singaporean golfers Mardith Choo and Chia Kah Woei secured a sponsorship deal, providing a boost to their stagnant careers. The news comes as the golfers face uncertainty due to the pandemic's impact on the sport. The exact terms of the sponsorship were not disclosed.

site_title: SGD bounces slightly after fiscal blast
summary: Singapore's dollar briefly strengthened 2.7% on Friday after Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled a S$55 billion fiscal injection to support the economy. The SGD touched 1.4249 against the greenback, but experts predict a short-lived spike as the economy remains weak. The central bank is likely to loosen monetary policy, making a return to a softer SGD necessary.

site_title: France reports 299 more coronavirus deaths, total toll 1,995
summary: France reported 299 additional coronavirus deaths, bringing the total death toll to 1,995. The country's top health official, Jerome Salomon, stated that 32,964 people have tested positive for the virus, with the actual number likely higher due to limited testing. The death toll is lower than the 365 reported on Thursday. The total does not include those who died at home or in retirement homes.

images.alt_text: France on Friday reported that 299 more people had died in hospital from the coronavirus epidemic over the last 24 hours, bringing the total death toll from the epidemic in the country to 1,995.

site_title: What's in a name? Questions to ask to spot ESG washing
summary: Investors in ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) products should be cautious of "greenwashing," or exaggerated or misleading claims about ESG integration. To spot ESG washing, investors should ask their financial advisors: Are exclusions from certain sectors thoughtful? What is the fund's ESG strategy? How experienced is the team? How is ESG integrated? How are impact and active ownership activities measured? By asking these questions, investors can better evaluate the credibility of ESG funds and make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Google offers US$800m to pandemic-impacted businesses, health agencies
summary: Google is offering US$800 million in support to businesses, health agencies, and researchers affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The aid includes US$250 million in ad grants to the World Health Organization and public agencies, US$340 million in free advertising for small- and medium-sized businesses, and US$20 million in cloud credits for researchers and academic institutions. Google also plans to match employee donations of up to US$10,000 to organizations in their communities. The company is working with partners to increase production of protective gear and ventilators needed for COVID-19 sufferers.

images.alt_text: Google on Friday pledged US$800 million worth of support in response to the coronavirus pandemic for health organisations, researchers and businesses impacted by the crisis.

site_title: Oil plunges posting fifth straight weekly loss despite stimulus efforts
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% on Friday, marking a fifth consecutive weekly loss, as the coronavirus continues to devastate global demand. Despite stimulus efforts by policymakers, oil prices fell nearly two-thirds this year, with Brent crude settling at $24.93 a barrel and US crude at $21.51 a barrel. Experts warn that the market may not recover until May, when production cuts could push prices to single digits, and major producers like Saudi Arabia may struggle to stabilize the market.

site_title: Gold rallies on stimulus hopes and supply squeeze
summary: Gold prices rallied 16% this week after the US Federal Reserve announced measures to support the US economy and increase liquidity in financial markets. The global equity meltdown and low treasury yields led to investors liquidating long gold positions, while the COVID-19 pandemic and stimulus packages have supported gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset. Central banks are expected to maintain robust net gold purchases, while physical demand in India and China may weaken due to economic growth concerns.

site_title: Reits (March 28-29, 2020)
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (REITs) saw a significant drop in prices during the March 28-29, 2020 period. However, recent data shows a rebound in the market, with REITs such as New World selling China property assets after a loan deal. US mortgage rates have also seen a reversal, climbing after five straight weeks of declines. The US market is also seeing a wave of condo launches in Q3, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases expected.

site_title: Making the virtual as good as real
summary: Virtual communications can be as effective as face-to-face interactions by following simple rules, such as setting the scene and having a clear agenda. Research by Terrific Mentors International has shown that video calls are preferred over phone calls, as they allow for nonverbal cues like body language to be conveyed. This can help build trust and facilitate a more engaging conversation. By adopting this approach, individuals can effectively navigate virtual dealings and achieve similar outcomes as in-person interactions.

site_title: Biolidics to acquire Biomedics Laboratory for up to S$3.7m
summary: Biolidics has entered an agreement to acquire Biomedics Laboratory from SAM Laboratory for up to S$3.7 million. The acquisition will grant Biolidics access to resources and capabilities. Biolidics will pay S$100,000 upfront and the remaining consideration can be deferred for up to 24 months. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and a distribution-services agreement with Clearbridge Medical Group to distribute diagnostics tests.

site_title: SGA boost for junior golfers
summary: The Singapore Golf Association (SGA) has revived the "Tiger Woods phenomenon," inspiring junior golfers worldwide with Woods' phenomenal successes in the late 1990s. This move aims to promote golf among young players in Singapore, reviving the sport's popularity and legacy.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall after 3-day rally, but mark best week since 2011
summary: European shares fell 3.3% on Friday after a three-day rally, marking their best week since 2011, due to EU lawmakers' failure to agree on a coronavirus rescue package and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's announcement of a positive COVID-19 test. The decline was also attributed to concerns over a recession, high unemployment, and lack of capex. Oil and gas stocks outperformed peers, while travel and leisure stocks were severely impacted.

site_title: UOBAM launches sustainable bond fund for retail investors
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) launched the United Sustainable Credit Income Fund (USCIF) in Singapore, targeting retail investors. The fund focuses on bonds from companies making progress towards the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). With an initial minimum subscription sum of S$1,000 or US$1,000, USCIF offers stable income through monthly dividend distributions, investing in the RobecoSAM SDG Credit Income Fund. The fund assesses companies' sustainability impact, aiming to maintain high and consistent income levels.

site_title: Singapore clothing rental market a bright spot for fashion sector
summary: Singapore's clothing rental subscription market appears to be a resilient sector despite the COVID-19 outbreak. Companies offering subscription services reported stable or rising subscriber figures, with some tripling their revenues since the outbreak began. Fitch Solutions predicts that the sector's "solid" long-term fundamentals will help it weather the pandemic, driven by steady rises in consumers' clothing spend and disposable incomes. The market is valued at US$3.9 million annually and is expected to increase over the next few years as the trend catches on.

site_title: STI gains on S$48b virus relief package
summary: Singapore stocks closed 1.66% higher on Friday, driven by a S$48 billion virus relief package. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose to 2,528.76, finishing the week up 4.9%. About 1.35 billion securities worth S$1.92 billion changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 329 to 147. The relief package is expected to cushion the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: The world will be as one
summary: A novel coronavirus has brought the world together, unifying people and nations in a shared effort to combat the pandemic. As the world rebuilds, it's clear that globalism and global supply chains will continue to play a crucial role. The virus has exposed the interconnectedness of the world, highlighting the need for cooperation and collective action to address pressing issues like climate change and consumerism. A changed worldview is necessary to mend the planet, and the new generation will need to learn the value of hard work, sacrifice, and perseverance to achieve this goal.

site_title: How 'muscle memory' may help keep us fit
summary: A new study suggests that muscles may retain a "molecular memory" of past workouts, allowing individuals to regain fitness quickly once gyms reopen. This "muscle memory" is thought to be similar to the concept of retaining physical skills, such as riding a bicycle. The study's findings indicate that muscles can recall past training and adapt to new exercise routines, potentially reducing the time needed to regain strength and size. This could be beneficial for those who have been inactive due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: US: Stocks fall, snapping three-day winning streak
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, snapping a three-day winning streak, after the House of Representatives approved a $2 trillion stimulus package to address the coronavirus crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 4.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 3.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 3.8%. Despite the decline, the Dow experienced its largest weekly gain since 1931. Economists warn of a tough road ahead, predicting a recession worse than the 2009 global financial crisis, with IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva stating "it is clear that we have entered a recession".

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks sank on Friday, plunging after three positive sessions despite the House of Representatives approving a US$2 trillion package to address the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Singapore hotels 51% full in Feb, room revenues drop 40%
summary: Singapore hotels were 51% full in February, resulting in a 40% drop in room revenues, ahead of global border closures and national lockdowns. The average occupancy rate in February 2020 was lower than in January, and the revenue per available room was down 41% year-on-year. Large hotels saw the biggest decline, with occupancy rates dropping 39.5% and revenue per available room falling 42.7%. Market watchers predict further declines in March and April, with a potential boost from returnees but not enough to offset overall declines.

site_title: 49 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, 22 imported; new cluster at SingPost Centre
summary: Singapore reported 49 new coronavirus cases, with 22 imported and 27 locally transmitted. The new cluster at SingPost Centre has linked to three cases. Locally transmitted cases are linked to two pre-schools and a school. 183 have recovered, and 432 are still in hospital, with 17 in critical care. New laws penalize those not adhering to social distancing rules, and the Ministry of Education announced one day of home-based learning per week.

site_title: Infinite QE is destroying traditional bond-fund strategies
summary: Trillions of dollars in government and central bank stimulus could create an eventual inflation shock, potentially triggering losses for bondholders. Traditional bond-fund strategies are being reworked due to the uncertainty. Core tenets of safe assets and bond portfolio hedges are being reconsidered, and expectations for returns over the next decade are being questioned. The risk of inflation shock is driven by the massive monetary and fiscal stimulus, forcing investors to reassess their market convictions and adapt to a new era.

images.alt_text: Bond investors are being forced to rework their strategies. Core tenets such as what constitutes a safe asset, the value of bonds as a portfolio hedge, and expectations for returns over the next decade are all being reconsidered.

site_title: Turning leaders into winners
summary: The executive coaching business in Singapore is facing a challenge due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite its growth trajectory in recent years. The demand for coaching has been driven by succession and disruption in the business, particularly among young heirs and startup leaders. To maintain global competitiveness, companies should prioritize tracking leadership development, according to recent articles. Authentic leadership is also seen as key to thriving in uncertain times, while companies are advised to rethink their executive structures, including the role of the executive chairman.

site_title: Measures won't stave off recession but will contain damage: economists
summary: Singapore's $48.4 billion Resilience Budget, unveiled on Thursday, is expected to help contain job losses and position the country for an eventual recovery from the COVID-19 recession. However, economists believe the measure is unlikely to prevent a recession, citing the need for strong monetary action to flatten and re-center the policy slope. The package includes wage subsidies and expanded financing options to support firms and households. Economists expect the resident unemployment rate to climb to around 3.5% and job losses of 40,000 to 50,000 for the year.

site_title: Maserati Levante review: The Trofeo life
summary: Maserati's Levante Trofeo is a high-performance, limited-edition SUV featuring a 3.8L twin-turbo V8 engine producing 580hp and a 0-100km/h time of 3.9 seconds. Only 100 Launch Edition variants were produced, with three in Singapore. The car boasts advanced tech, including an all-wheel drive system and Maserati's Integrated Vehicle Control. The Levante Trofeo is priced at S$635,800, outpacing the Porsche Cayenne Turbo. With its massive power, Italian styling, and luxurious interior, it appeals to a select group of petrolheads.

site_title: Mnuchin pledges speedy delivery of cash to Americans
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin pledged to deliver cash to Americans as part of a $2.2 trillion relief package. The package includes $1,200 payments for individuals making less than $75,000 and $500 per child. Mnuchin expects direct deposits to arrive in three weeks, addressing the need for immediate financial support amid the coronavirus-battered economy.

site_title: Singtel's streaming service Hooq files for liquidation
summary: Singtel's streaming service Hooq has filed for liquidation, with a shareholder and creditor meeting set for April 13. The company cited significant structural changes in the over-the-top video market, high content costs, and increasing competition. Hooq reported a pre-tax loss of US$62.5 million in FY19, with liabilities of US$70.8 million. Singtel, which has a 76.5% stake in Hooq, expects the liquidation to have a minimal impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share. The provisional liquidators are exploring options, including a possible amalgamation with competitors.

site_title: US consumer spending increases moderately in February
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in February, matching January's gain, as households spent more on electricity and gas. Despite this, economists predict a moderate decline in consumer spending in the first quarter due to social distancing measures, which have severely curtailed discretionary spending. Consumer prices edged up 0.1% in February, with the core PCE price index rising 1.8% for the 12 months through February. The US now has over 82,000 coronavirus cases, with more than 100 million people affected.

site_title: UK urges people not to move as housing market freezes
summary: The UK government has urged people not to move house due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, bringing the country's property market to a near standstill. Banks agreed to extend mortgage offers by three months for homebuyers who have exchanged contracts, allowing them to delay moves. The government's guidance aims to help people manage their finances amid the pandemic's financial hardship. This move is expected to deter new buyers and simplify transactions, which have become increasingly difficult due to the nationwide lockdown.

site_title: New Garden is pretty and tempting
summary: New Garden, a 5,704-meter golf course, features par or double-par holes from the popular blue tees, offering a challenging and visually appealing experience for golfers.

site_title: Stand back and see the big picture
summary: A recent article from a private investor emphasizes the importance of perspective in navigating the current stock market turmoil. Despite the overwhelming red ink, the outcome of every market crash is the same: eventual recovery. Investors are advised to stand back and view the market from a broader perspective, rather than getting caught up in daily fluctuations. Central banks and governments are injecting trillions of dollars into the global economy, providing a backstop to underpin the market until a vaccine is available. Long-term investors are encouraged to sit tight and consider gradual re-investment, as every stock market crash ultimately ends in a similar outcome.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KOYO International's subsidiary Koyo Engineering secured electrical contracts worth S$116 million, boosting its order book. Huan Hsin Holdings reported a widening loss to S$11.7 million, a 29% decrease in revenue due to weaker demand for electronics. Frasers Hospitality Trust expects its second-quarter financial performance to be impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic. Biolidics acquired Biomedics Laboratory for up to S$3.7 million to gain access to resources and capabilities.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit's portfolio to 'remain resilient' amid virus pandemic: manager
summary: United Hampshire US Reit's portfolio remains resilient amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, with over 70% of its base rental income coming from essential tenants such as grocery stores and wholesalers. The Reit's tenants are open for business and have seen a rise in demand for household products, while non-essential businesses have closed. The Reit has secured over 110,000 sq ft of new leases and entered interest rate swaps to hedge its exposure. This positioning is expected to positively impact its cash flow for 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Rich Capital terminates consultancy services for Batam project
summary: Rich Capital Holdings terminated its consultancy services for a Batam project due to Oxley Karya Indo Batam (OKIB) failing to meet terms. OKIB had partnered with Rich Capital's subsidiary to form an equal joint-venture company. OKIB alleged material losses of S$5.3 million and immaterial losses of S$110 million from construction mistakes, seeking S$5.3 million compensation. Rich Capital stated the letter was sent without approval, and Aricipta is seeking a guarantee and undertaking for OKIB to assume full responsibility of risks and liability.

site_title: Shipyards' funding need to get more acute with bigger projects
summary: Singapore shipyards face increased financing challenges due to stricter banking regulations and a lack of financing options for larger projects. Banks are withdrawing from the maritime sector, leaving shipyards with a "sheer capacity gap" in financing. Clifford Capital, a major financier for the sector, has seen strong interest from Singapore-based lenders for financing projects like the Gimi Floating Liquefied Natural Gas (FLNG) project, which was the first limited recourse project financing for a FLNG vessel in the international commercial bank market. The company believes this successful deal will pave the way for future financings.

site_title: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine incorporates JV company and branch in Taiwan
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings has incorporated a joint venture (JV) company, Bridgewater Marine, in Taiwan with 49% ownership, to expand into the Taiwanese market for the Offshore Wind Farm project. The company's indirect wholly-owned subsidiary, Mazu Land & Marine Works, has also established a branch in Taiwan with an initial paid-up capital of NT$5 million. The investment was funded through internal resources, and the Offshore Wind Farm project is expected to contribute positively to the group's earnings per share and net tangible asset.

site_title: Quarantine a boon for some HK hotels as thousands return
summary: Thousands of Hong Kong citizens and expatriates are returning to the city, seeking refuge in hotels due to cramped apartments and social distancing concerns. Many are choosing hotels over apartments, fearing the risk of coronavirus transmission in densely populated flats. This trend is a boon for some hotels, providing an opportunity for occupancy and revenue amid the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia ramps up support for virus-hit economy to RM250b
summary: Malaysia has announced a RM250 billion support package for its economy, which includes RM50 billion to guarantee working capital loans and RM1 billion to ensure sufficient food supply. The measures aim to alleviate pressures on businesses and people affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a national lockdown and over 2,000 confirmed cases in the country. The government's support dwarfs the stimulus measures taken during the 2008 global financial crisis, with economists praising the move as growth-supportive and crucial for the nation's recovery.

images.alt_text: "This government may not be the government that you voted for. But I want all of you to know that this government cares for you," Mr Muhyiddin said in his speech.

site_title: Frasers Property sets aside S$45m in further rental rebates for tenants
summary: Frasers Property is setting aside S$45 million to provide further rental rebates for tenants across its retail malls. This follows the government's Resilience Budget, which announced enhanced property tax rebates. Tenants will also receive full property tax rebates and cash security deposits will be released to offset one month's worth of rental payments. Additionally, a one-month rental waiver will be granted to closed entertainment venues and centres.

site_title: Hong Kong limits gatherings to four after record virus surge
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced measures to combat the record surge in coronavirus cases, including limiting gatherings to four people, closing cinemas, gyms, and arcades, and reducing restaurant capacity by half. The measures will take effect on Sunday, with exemptions for weddings and funerals. The city has seen a 518-case surge in infections over two weeks, prompting Lam to emphasize public health and the need for business support.

site_title: Resilience package to mitigate earnings drop for STI stocks
summary: Singapore's Resilience Budget, a $48.4 billion package, is expected to lead to 4% cost savings for Straits Times Index (STI) stocks, reducing earnings contraction to 5% year-over-year. Analysts expect significant benefits for banks, Singapore Airlines, Genting Singapore, and supermarket stocks, with estimated cost savings ranging from 2% to 22%. The measures are expected to sustain the economy and build resilience, with banks as key beneficiaries, reducing the risk of provisions spiking up.

site_title: S$48b support package could be reviewed nearer year end: PM
summary: Singapore's S$48.4 billion Resilience Budget, announced to support the country's response to the coronavirus pandemic, may need to be reviewed or modified by year-end. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the government is prepared to draw on reserves if needed and could extend, raise, or reduce the support package. The budget's components are designed to last until the end of the year, but Lee warned that the situation could worsen, requiring further action.

site_title: Thailand closes more public facilities as coronavirus cases top 1,100
summary: Thailand has closed more public facilities and businesses to curb the spread of coronavirus, with the total number of cases reaching 1,136 and five deaths. The government extended existing closures until the end of April. The country reported 91 new cases and one fatality on Friday, with 97 patients recovering. A 50-year-old man in Narathiwat province died after contracting the virus at a mosque in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: The Thai government on Friday ordered the closing down of more public facilities and businesses in a bid to curb the spread of coronavirus, and extended existing closures until the end of April.

site_title: British PM Johnson tests positive for Covid-19
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has tested positive for Covid-19, announcing he will self-isolate but continue leading the government's response via video-conference. Johnson experienced mild symptoms and was tested after England's chief medical officer advised him to do so. He thanked NHS workers for their efforts in battling the spread of the virus, which has so far confirmed 11,658 cases and 578 deaths in Britain. This comes after Prince Charles also tested positive earlier in the week.

site_title: USD/CNH futures shoots past US$119b
summary: SGX's USD/CNH futures surpassed $119 billion on March 27 as investors sought to hedge against the economic fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic. Demand for risk management on currencies increased, with open interest for INR/USD futures reaching a new high. SGX's head of FX and rates, K.C. Lam, attributed the surge to clients hedging more than usual, particularly on USD/CNH and INR/USD, and building larger open interests to protect their positions. The move reflects the mounting uncertainty surrounding the virus outbreak and border lockdowns.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower, resuming sell-off after 3-day surge
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, resuming their sell-off after a three-day surge. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3.5% to 21,754.26, while the S&P 500 dropped 3.2% to 2,545.80 and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 2.9% to 7,572.60. The downturn comes amid a worsening economic outlook due to the coronavirus outbreak.

images.alt_text: About five minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 3.5 per cent or around 800 points to 21,754.26.

site_title: Vickers secures US$200m commitments for its largest fund yet; portfolio biotechs active in Covid-19 space
summary: Vickers Venture Partners has secured US$200 million in commitments for its largest fund yet, US$500 million Fund VI. The fund will invest in biotechnology, nanotechnology, and artificial intelligence, with a focus on companies active in the Covid-19 space. Fund VI will deploy US$200 million from existing investors, including pension funds from Europe and the US, and will have a net internal rate of return of 7-31% from previous funds. The firm's chairman, Finian Tan, believes the pandemic has increased the potential of deep-tech investments, and the fund is expected to perform despite the current economic downturn.

images.alt_text: "(Biotech) is our best performing sector at the moment," says Dr Tan. "We have two companies that are quite active in the coronavirus space and it has changed the potential of our portfolio because suddenly we are in the thick of things."

site_title: 49 new coronavirus cases in Singapore; new cluster at SingPost Centre linked to 3 cases
summary: Singapore reported 49 new coronavirus cases on March 27, with 22 imported and 27 locally transmitted. A new cluster linked to the SingPost Centre in Eunos has 3 cases. 183 have recovered, and 432 are still in hospital. New laws penalize individuals sitting less than 1m away from others, with fines up to $10,000 or jail for up to 6 months. The Ministry of Education also announced home-based learning for all schools.

site_title: US consumer spending held up in February before virus hit
summary: US consumer spending remained stable in February before the COVID-19 pandemic, with personal spending rising 0.2% for the second consecutive month. This was followed by a 0.6% increase in personal income, reflecting increases in employee compensation and farm proprietors' income.
