Inflation data showed a 0.2% monthly gain and a 1.8% annual rise, exceeding projections. However, economists project sharp declines in gross domestic product in the second quarter due to job losses and store closures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 15 points to 1,343.09 on Friday, driven by a gain of 711 stocks to 232 losers. Volume reached 4.190 billion lots worth RM2.721 billion.

site_title: Malaysia mulls buying coronavirus test kits from South Korea as tally rises
summary: Malaysia is considering purchasing up to 1 million coronavirus test kits from South Korea to increase its testing capacity, following a surge in infections. The country has reported 2,161 cases, with over 1,000 linked to a mosque gathering. Malaysia's diagnostic testing capacity has been increased to 7,100 cases per day, with plans to increase it further to 16,500 by mid-April. The government aims to screen more people with rapid antigen test kits, which can determine if someone has the virus faster than diagnostic tests.

site_title: Rich Capital terminates consultancy services for Batam project
summary: Rich Capital Holdings terminated its consultancy services for the Batam project after Oxley Karya Indo Batam (OKIB) failed to meet its terms of demand, including withdrawing a letter of demand and providing a guarantee. OKIB alleged material losses of S$5.3 million and immaterial losses of S$110 million due to alleged construction mistakes. Rich Capital is seeking compensation, guarantees, and costs incurred by OKIB for its time and efforts.

site_title: Assessing the suitability of complex financial instruments
summary: A client's knowledge and financial situation must be considered before an investment is recommended. The 2008 bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers highlighted the risks of complex financial instruments, such as minibonds, which can result in significant losses. This lesson remains relevant today, with thousands of retail investors in Singapore and Asia losing savings in structured products. As markets continue to rise, it is essential to prioritize individual financial situations and consider the suitability of investments to avoid potential losses. A balanced approach is crucial to unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: Britain's Next bows to staff pressure and ceases online operation
summary: British clothing retailer Next has temporarily ceased its online operations amid staff pressure due to the coronavirus emergency. The decision comes as the UK government introduced measures to support workers during the lockdown, including a 80% wage grant for those furloughed. Next had previously stated it could sustain a £1 billion hit from the pandemic, but ultimately bowed to staff pressure and stopped taking online orders.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust expects Q2 performance to be hit by Covid-19
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) expects its Q2 financial performance to be negatively impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, citing weaker operating performance across its 15 assets in Asia, Australia, and Europe. The company has temporarily closed food-and-beverage outlets and will progressively close properties in the UK due to stricter measures. FHT has implemented cost-containment measures, including temporary room closures and unpaid leave for staff, to mitigate the negative impact and preserve cash flow. The company's fixed-rent master lease structure provides minimum rent and downside protection.

site_title: My dad has coronavirus. I don't know if I should say goodbye
summary: A family is navigating the uncertainty of their father's COVID-19 diagnosis, with the 68-year-old doctor facing a high risk of complications. Despite his exhaustion, he remains optimistic but knows the risks and has made the decision to be treated at home. The writer is struggling to come to terms with the possibility of losing him, experiencing anticipatory grief and cherishing everyday moments they share. The family is preparing for the worst-case scenario, but for now, they're focusing on enjoying each other's company and holding onto memories.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government will take all necessary measures to help citizens and businesses during the Covid-19 outbreak, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Hotel occupancy rates dropped to 51.4% in February, with room revenues plummeting 40%. Singtel's video streaming service Hooq is liquidating due to financial struggles. The Ministry of Manpower will enforce safe-distancing measures, with firms flouting rules facing stop-work orders. The STI index finished the week up 4.9% at 2,528.76, while Vietnam expressed surprise over US tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Koyo unit bags electrical contracts
summary: KOYO Intl's subsidiary, Koyo Engineering (South-east Asia), has secured S$116 million worth of electrical contracts with completion dates between 2021 and 2026. The contracts, awarded by an independent third party, are expected to positively impact the group's earnings for the 2020 financial year. None of the directors or substantial shareholders have a direct interest in the contracts. Koyo shares closed flat at S$0.06 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Singapore hotels 51% full in Feb 2020, room revenues plunge 40%: STB
summary: Singapore hotels experienced a significant decline in occupancy rates in February 2020, with the standard average occupancy rate falling to 51% due to coronavirus fears. Room revenues plummeted 40% year-on-year, with revenue per available room dropping to S$117. Large hotels were the worst affected, with occupancy rates down 39.5 percentage points and revenue per available room declining 42.7%. The decline was a stark contrast to the same period in 2019, when occupancy rates were 88.5% and revenue per available room was S$230.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop more than 2% at open
summary: European stock markets dropped more than 2% at the open on Friday, following three days of gains, as traders reacted to global stimulus efforts to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus. London, Frankfurt, and Paris saw declines of 2.7%, 2.4%, and 2.2% respectively. The losses came despite gains in mining and healthcare shares, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks and the ongoing economic recovery.

site_title: STI finishes week at 2,528.76, up 4.9%
summary: Singapore stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 1.66% or 41.20 points to close at 2,528.76, finishing the week up 4.9%. The relief package announced by the government, worth S$48 billion, boosted investor sentiment. Top gainers included Jardine Matheson and Genting Singapore, while Singapore Airlines was the top loser, falling 6.46% after announcing an S$8.8 billion cash call. Regional markets also closed higher, following overnight gains in US markets.

site_title: Singtel's video streaming service Hooq in liquidation
summary: Singtel's video streaming service Hooq has commenced a creditors' voluntary liquidation, with a shareholder meeting and creditor meeting scheduled for April 13. The company, which Singtel has an indirect 76.5% effective interest in, cited significant changes in the over-the-top video market and increasing competition, as well as high content costs, as reasons for its decline. Hooq's operating revenue from Singtel's digital life segment shrunk by 15% in the third quarter of 2019, and the company's failure to grow sufficiently has led to a challenging business model, according to Fitch Ratings.

site_title: S$15b cash call gives SIA a shot at surviving Covid-19
summary: Singapore Airlines has received a massive cash call of up to S$15 billion, backed by Temasek Holdings, to help it survive the Covid-19 pandemic. The proposed exercise, involving a rights issue of new shares and convertible bonds, will boost the airline's stamina and give it a shot at restoring itself when the crisis ends. Analysts say SIA is now in a "very enviable position" to wait until the international market recovers, allowing it to recover when the crisis ends.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US slumps by most since October 2008
summary: US consumer sentiment has plummeted by 11.9 points to a three-year low of 89.1 in March, according to the University of Michigan's sentiment index. This is the largest decline since October 2008, amid mounting Covid-19 cases and business closures. The majority of consumers now expect bad financial times, with a majority anticipating an increase in national unemployment. The report also shows a drastic drop in buying conditions for durable goods and a measure of economic outlook.

images.alt_text: US consumer sentiment plummeted in March by the most since October 2008 as mounting Covid-19 cases nationwide and business closures elevated concerns about the economy.

site_title: Huan Hsin widens loss, needs more time for exit-offer proposal
summary: Huan Hsin Holdings, a Singapore-listed electronics contract manufacturer, has widened its loss to S$11.7 million in FY2019, down from a year-ago loss of S$2.4 million. The company has failed to submit a reasonable cash exit, despite being called to delist by the Singapore Exchange in 2018 due to repeated failure to meet listing requirements. Huan Hsin's shares have been suspended, and management remains committed to corporate restructuring to streamline operations and dispose of non-performing assets.

site_title: Malaysia announces RM250b stimulus package to cushion impact of coronavirus
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced a RM250 billion (S$83.02 billion) stimulus package to counter the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes direct fiscal injections, loan schemes, and public welfare measures, with a focus on supporting families, businesses, and food security. The government aims to ensure its finances remain sound over the medium term and has set aside 1 billion ringgit for a food security fund. The package is in addition to a previous RM20 billion stimulus plan and will proceed with major projects, including the east coast rail line.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, closing a healthy week on a positive note, driven by a blockbuster US stimulus plan and the Federal Reserve's pledge to ease liquidity concerns. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.56%, while the Shanghai Composite Index advanced 0.26%. The Shenzhen Composite Index, however, slipped 0.46%. The gains come as investors welcome the US stimulus and ease liquidity concerns, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine incorporates JV company and branch in Taiwan
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings has incorporated a joint venture company, Bridgewater Marine, in Taiwan with a 49% stake, and a branch of Mazu Land & Marine Works in Taiwan with a 100% stake. The JV and branch aim to expand the company's business into Taiwan to support the offshore wind farm project. The investment was funded internally, and the project is expected to positively contribute to the group's earnings per share and net tangible asset for the current financial year.

site_title: China's industrial firms post steepest fall in profits in a decade
summary: China's industrial firms saw their profits drop 38.3% in the first two months of the year, the steepest decline in a decade, due to a virus epidemic affecting the economy. This marks a worsening from a 6.3% fall in December. The decline combines January and February data, excluding Lunar New Year distortions.

site_title: South Korea reports 91 new coronavirus cases, total 9,332: KCDC
summary: South Korea reported 91 new coronavirus cases, bringing the national total to 9,332, according to the Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention. This marks a significant increase in cases, but the country's response to the outbreak remains under control.

site_title: MOM to enforce safe-distancing measures; firms which flout rules face stop-work order
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has warned companies that failing to implement safe-distancing measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19 will face enforcement action, including stop-work or remedial orders. The measures include telecommuting, staggered working hours, and adequate spacing between workstations. Companies that do not comply may be ordered to cease operations until the measures are implemented.

site_title: BlackGold extends cut off date for bond subscription agreement
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources is extending the cut-off date for a bond subscription agreement with Jinzhou Business Investment Logistics Co due to COVID-19 precautions in China. The company initially aimed to raise up to S$25 million through interest-free convertible bonds to finance new plans. The initial tranche of S$3 million was set to be subscribed by JBIL by March 30, but the company will now extend this deadline. The decision is aimed at fulfilling certain conditions hindered by the outbreak.

site_title: Singapore, South Korea affirm importance of keeping trade, supply chains open
summary: Singapore and South Korea reaffirmed the importance of maintaining open trade flows and supply chain connectivity amid the coronavirus outbreak. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and South Korean Trade Minister Yoo Myung Hee discussed the matter in a videoconference, emphasizing the need to ensure the continuity of trade and essential supplies. Singapore has also committed to maintaining open trade lines with six countries, including New Zealand, to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on global trade.

site_title: Seoul: Shares mark best weekly gain since 2008 on stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares surged to a 11-year high, gaining 1.87% to close at 1,717.73, marking their best weekly gain since 2008. The KOSPI index rose 9.68% for the week, snapping a two-week decline. The improvement in investor confidence was driven by hopes of global stimulus against the coronavirus, boosting investor confidence and snapping the two-week slump.

site_title: UOBAM rolls out sustainable bond fund for retail investors
summary: UOB Asset Management launched the United Sustainable Credit Income Fund (USCIF), a sustainable bond fund targeting retail investors in Singapore. The fund invests in bonds from companies making progress towards the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, providing stable income through monthly dividend distributions. With an initial minimum subscription of S$1,000 or US$1,000, USCIF is the first of its kind available to retail investors in Singapore, offering a unique opportunity for investors to support sustainable development while earning a stable income.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes up 3.88%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed up 3.88% at 19,389.43, following a rally on Wall Street due to a massive US economic relief package. The broader Topix index also advanced 4.30% to 1,459.49. This marks the latest in a series of gains for Asian markets, which have been driven by investor optimism despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Govt will do whatever it takes to help Singaporeans through Covid-19 outbreak: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's government, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, will take "whatever it takes" to stabilize the economy and help companies during the Covid-19 outbreak. A $48.4 billion Supplementary Budget has been introduced to support businesses, workers, and families, bringing the total support to $55 billion. The government is prepared to tap into reserves if needed, with Lee warning that the economic downturn could last a long time, particularly in industries like aviation and tourism.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit says portfolio 'remains resilient' amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: United Hampshire US Reit says its portfolio "remains resilient and well-positioned" to navigate the Covid-19 pandemic, citing that over 70% of its base rental income comes from essential businesses. The Reit's tenants include grocery-anchored and necessity-based retail properties, as well as self-storage facilities in the US, with locations in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, and other states. This exposure to essential businesses positions the portfolio for continued stability during lockdowns.

site_title: Regional automakers' supply, sales to take a hit from pandemic
summary: Regional automakers' sales and production are expected to take a hit from the Covid-19 pandemic, with passenger vehicles leading the decline. Thailand's vehicle sales are projected to contract 9.2% in 2020, while Indonesia and Malaysia are tipped to see sales shrink year on year. However, Indonesia may post a robust recovery from 2021 due to low household debt levels and looser vehicle loan requirements. The pandemic's impact on the industry is compounded by supply chain disruptions, dealership closures, and deteriorating economic outlook.

site_title: WeWork says virus will hamper ability to hit 2020 targets
summary: WeWork, a shared office space provider, says the coronavirus outbreak will hinder its ability to meet 2020 financial targets. The company, which had $4.4 billion in cash at the end of last year, cited uncertainty and volatility caused by the pandemic. Despite rising revenue 90% in 2019 to $3.5 billion, WeWork reported a net loss of $1.25 billion in the third quarter. The company's largest investor, SoftBank Group, has threatened to unravel part of its deal, and WeWork has temporarily shut down locations due to the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog steps up monitoring of fund managers amid volatility
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has stepped up monitoring of fund managers amid market volatility caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The SFC warned fund managers to ensure clients are treated fairly when selling illiquid investment products. The agency emphasized the need to check liquidity and credit quality of funds before recommending them to clients. The warning comes as the Hang Seng Index's volatility gauge reached 64.8, its highest level since 2008. The SFC also urged fund managers to manage liquidity and keep investors informed about steps taken to do so.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up more than 3% on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks surged over 3% on Friday, tracking US economic relief package rallies. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 3.42% to 19,303.64, while the Topix index rose 3.08%. The US Dow surged 6.4% after the economic relief package cleared the Senate, with the dollar reaching 109.13 yen. Investors are encouraged by the Japanese government's plans to fire additional stimulus to counter the coronavirus impact.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened more than three per cent higher on Friday, tracking rallies on Wall Street on a massive US economic relief package.

site_title: New York hotels tapped for extra beds with hospitals short
summary: New York officials are tapping hotels for extra beds as hospitals struggle to cope with the surge in COVID-19 cases. The state is seeking 10,000 rooms to house emergency responders and medical workers, with 15 hotels offering their facilities. Billionaire Ty Warner has offered his 330-room hotel near Central Park for free, and the Four Seasons is providing rooms to doctors and nurses at a cost of $6,500 per night. The state aims to increase hospital capacity by 50% and build temporary hospitals to address the overflow.

site_title: The healthcare startup that's fast-tracking drone delivery
summary: Zipline, a California healthcare startup, is expanding its drone delivery services to the US in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, which has already made hundreds of deliveries in Rwanda and Ghana, plans to launch a service in North Carolina later this year to help Novant Health deliver medicine and supplies to rural clinics. Zipline's drones can fly at 60mph, navigate by GPS, and carry up to 2 tonnes of freight over a week. The company is working with the FAA to obtain certification and is exploring ways to deploy drones at a wider scale to help the US medical supply chain.

site_title: India's coronavirus heroes come under attack
summary: Frontline workers in India, including doctors, nurses, delivery drivers, and airline staff, are facing attacks and harassment due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Panicked residents have blocked their homes, threatened them, and even forced them out of their homes. E-commerce giants have also halted deliveries due to staff harassment. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has condemned the abuse, calling it a "huge issue" and urging Indians to treat medical workers as heroes, not pariahs. The government has appealed for help to protect health workers.

site_title: Australia to quarantine international arrivals in virus fight
summary: Australian authorities have announced plans to quarantine international arrivals in airports to combat the spread of the coronavirus. The measure will be enforced by the defence force, following a meeting with the National Cabinet. The country has already taken incremental measures to slow the spread of the virus, including closing pubs, barring non-essential travel, and closing borders to non-residents. The number of infections has grown to 2,985 with 13 deaths, prompting the government's decision to introduce quarantine measures.

site_title: Oil storage buckles as virus saps demand
summary: Global oil storage capacity is under intense pressure due to booming output from Saudi Arabia and the US, while the coronavirus outbreak slams the world economy and crude demand. Oil prices have collapsed to nearly two decades low, with storage facilities around the world struggling to hold the excess crude. Industry experts predict a global surplus of 10.6 million barrels per day in the second quarter, with storage capacity potentially breached, leading to a potential oil price crash and immediate production shutdown.

site_title: 'Printing money': booming mask producers in China meet global demand
summary: Thousands of factories in China have rapidly shifted to producing face masks in response to the global demand for protective equipment during the COVID-19 pandemic. Since the outbreak in early February, over 8,950 new mask manufacturers have emerged, with many exporting to countries such as Italy, South Korea, and the European Union. The high demand has led to significant profits, with some manufacturers earning tens of thousands of dollars per day, despite rising costs for raw materials. China's daily mask production has reached 116 million, with many meeting overseas demand, and the industry is expected to continue beyond the pandemic.

site_title: Japan's Mitsui says may book up to 70b yen impairment loss
summary: Japanese trading house Mitsui & Co may book impairment losses between 50 billion yen (S$655.4 million) and 70 billion yen (S$918.7 million) due to falling commodity prices and the coronavirus outbreak. The company is likely to book losses on its stakes in the Eagle Ford shale oil and gas project in the US and the Tempa Rossa oil field in Italy. Impairment losses are attributed to plunging oil prices.

images.alt_text: Japanese trading house Mitsui & Co said on Friday it may book impairment losses between 50 billion yen (S$655.4 million) and 70 billion yen (S$918.7 million) in the year ending March 31 due to falling commodity prices and the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Tencent to develop cloud game platform with Huawei
summary: China's Tencent Holdings has launched a co-innovation lab with Huawei to develop a cloud game platform, GameMatrix, leveraging Huawei's Kunpeng processor. The collaboration aims to enhance gaming experiences through artificial intelligence and augmented reality. Tencent will tap into Huawei's computing power to build the platform, exploring further possibilities in AI and AR. This partnership marks a significant move towards Tencent's expansion into cloud gaming.

images.alt_text: China's Tencent Holdings launched a co-innovation lab with Huawei to develop a cloud game platform, the world's biggest game company said in a statement on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop, but set for best weekly gain since 2011; New Zealand higher
summary: Australian shares fell 1.6% on Friday, but are set for their best weekly gain since 2011 as policymakers launched stimulus efforts to combat the global economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The Reserve Bank of Australia made a historic foray into quantitative easing, and the US is expected to pass a $2 trillion stimulus package. Despite the decline, the benchmark index has gained 5.3% so far this week. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1.6% for its best weekly gain on record.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains, dollar sinks on stimulus pledges
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Friday, driven by government and central bank stimulus pledges to support the global economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The dollar sank as traders became optimistic about a sharp but short recession. The G-20's US$5 trillion stimulus package gave traders hope, despite the escalating number of Covid-19 cases worldwide. Markets are on course for a healthy week-end gain, with investors buoyed by monetary easing and government support.

site_title: Middle East airlines must tap handouts to survive virus crisis
summary: Middle East airlines are facing a severe crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenue expected to drop by 39% this year. Authorities have closed airports and halted passenger flights, leaving carriers with limited financial support. The Arab Air Carriers' Organization and International Air Transport Association have appealed for urgent financial aid from governments, warning that inaction will imperil the industry's future. Many airlines are forced to cut costs, cancel orders, and risk going bankrupt, with at least 800,000 jobs at risk.

site_title: South Korea investors rush back to stocks at record pace, betting on bounce
summary: South Korea sees a record surge in retail investors rushing back to the stock market, betting on a sharp bounce amid the coronavirus pandemic. As of Thursday, deposits for equity investments reached 41 trillion won (S$48.46 billion), a 53% increase since mid-January. This surge is attributed to investors seeking safer alternatives to the housing market, which has been impacted by curbs such as tighter loan restrictions and heavier taxes. The number of active stock trading accounts also reached a record high of 30.6 million, with 790,000 new accounts for equities trading opened in March.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.20 points or 1.30% to 1,345.29 at 9:08am on Friday, driven by higher trading volume. The index surpassed its previous high of 1,340.09. This follows a strong performance in the Singapore Stock Exchange, where the STI reached a new high. The rally is seen as a response to market positivity despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Hot stock: Singapore Airlines shares fall after S$8.8b cash call unveiled
summary: Singapore Airlines shares plummeted 10.1% to S$5.85 after the airline proposed issuing bonds and new shares at a discount to raise S$8.8 billion. The airline plans a renounceable 3-for-2 rights issue and a 10-year mandatory convertible bond issue to raise additional funds. Trading resumed after a trading halt, with shares later rebounding to S$6.29. The airline is facing its biggest crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with sweeping capacity cuts and salary reductions.

site_title: US cancels major Philippines war games due to virus
summary: The US has cancelled the Balikatan 2020 war games in the Philippines due to the coronavirus pandemic. The exercises, involving thousands of troops from the US and Philippines, were set to take place from May 4-15. The US has the largest number of confirmed infections, while the Philippines has reported around 700 cases. The cancellation is deemed prudent for the health and safety of both countries' forces. US troops from Japan and South Korea, which have been impacted by the virus, will not participate in the cancelled exercise.

images.alt_text: The US military has cancelled large-scale exercises involving thousands of troops in the Philippines in May due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Japan says no need now for state of emergency
summary: Japan's government has decided not to declare a state of emergency due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe described the crisis as a "national crisis" after a surge of cases in Tokyo. However, the government stated that Japan is not currently in a situation that requires an emergency declaration. A new crisis task force has been set up, seen as a preliminary step towards declaring a state of emergency.

site_title: More SGX-listed firms keep Malaysia operations shut amid extended lockdown
summary: More Singapore-listed firms in Malaysia are shutting down operations due to the extended lockdown, which now ends on April 14. The lockdown, initially set to end on March 31, was extended by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin following a rise in coronavirus cases. Companies affected include Astaka Holdings, Hatten Land, and several others, citing compliance with the lockdown to avoid potential risks and disruptions.

site_title: Singapore: Shares advance at Friday's open; STI up 2.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.6% on Friday, driven by the government's S$48.4 billion Resilience Budget to help weather the Covid-19 crisis. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,553.19. The budget includes loan capital, wage offsets, property tax rebates, and deferment of corporate income tax. Gainers outnumbered losers 154 to 26, with around 66.5 million securities worth S$153.8 million changing hands.

site_title: In the US, restaurants on the edge of failure over virus crisis
summary: The US restaurant industry is facing significant challenges due to the coronavirus crisis, with many establishments at risk of shutting down permanently. The National Restaurant Association estimates that the industry could lose at least $225 billion and 5-7 million jobs over the next three months. Restaurant owners are calling for $455 billion in government aid, including an emergency fund, unemployment benefits, and loans. A survey found that 3% of restaurants have already closed, while 11% may do so within a month. The industry's survival is seen as uncertain, with many relying on gift cards and takeout sales to stay afloat.

site_title: US dollar pulls back as panic selling eases, on course for biggest loss in decade
summary: The US dollar is on track for its biggest weekly fall in over a decade, falling 1% to 108.35 yen, due to a series of stimulus measures worldwide and easing panic selling. Despite an unprecedented rise in US jobless claims, the virus' devastating impact on the economy, shares on Wall Street have risen, raising hopes that selling in risk assets may have run its course.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars get a reprieve as US dollar falters
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw significant gains, with the Aussie up 4.4% and the kiwi up 4.6%, their best weekly performances since 2011, following dire US jobs data and the Federal Reserve's pledge of unlimited easing. The Fed's commitment boosted equities globally and eased liquidity strains, aiding risk assets. Both the Reserve Bank of Australia and New Zealand have been buying government bonds to lift liquidity and keep yields low, contributing to the currency rallies.

site_title: SoftBank's sharing economy bet backfires with coronavirus outbreak
summary: SoftBank's sharing economy investments, such as WeWork and Didi Chuxing, are struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic, which is reducing human interaction and forcing companies to cut costs. SoftBank shares have plummeted 50% in a month, and the company's Vision Fund is at risk of being depleted. SoftBank is seeking to raise an additional $10 billion to support its portfolio companies, including WeWork, Oyo, and travel startups. The company's reputation as a tech investor is under scrutiny, and investors are worried about the stability of its empire.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.78% to 23,768.41. This follows a strong rally on Wall Street, driven by government and central bank pledges to support the US economy. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 1.02% and 1.25% respectively. The rally comes ahead of US GDP data and US-EU trade talks, which traders are watching closely.

site_title: Merkel says Germany opposes 'coronabonds' in virus crisis
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed opposition to "corona bonds" that would pool eurozone countries' debt to respond to the coronavirus crisis. Merkel stated that the existing European Stability Mechanism is her preferred instrument, rejecting a proposal backed by France and Italy. The German stance aligns with other member states, indicating a unified approach to addressing the crisis.

site_title: US prepares crackdown on Huawei's global chip supply: sources
summary: The US is preparing to restrict the global supply of chips to China's Huawei Technologies, citing national security concerns over the coronavirus. Senior officials in the Trump administration agreed to new measures, including requiring foreign companies to obtain a US license before supplying certain chips to Huawei. This could deal a blow to Huawei and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), while also impacting US companies. The move is seen as part of a growing tit-for-tat with China, and could anger Beijing, which has spoken out against US efforts to exclude Huawei from 5G networks.

site_title: Fitch maintains US AAA rating despite coronavirus
summary: Fitch Ratings has reaffirmed the US's AAA credit rating despite the country's rising unemployment and looming recession due to the coronavirus pandemic. The rating is supported by the US economy's structural strengths, including its size and dynamic business environment. Fitch predicts a 3% GDP shrinkage this year, but recovery is possible in 2021 if the virus is contained. However, the country's high deficits are expected to worsen due to the stimulus package, potentially leading to a debt ratio exceeding 115% of GDP by the end of 2020.

site_title: Sponsors aim to buy back cheap debt
summary: Sponsors in Europe's leveraged loan market are seeking to buy back cheap debt, taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic and plummeting oil prices. Average prices of European leveraged loans have fallen to under 80% of face value, with some loans trading at 38.75% of face value. Sponsors like Apollo, BC Partners, and Carlyle believe the correction has gone too far and are in talks with banks to do so. This could prove lucrative for sponsors, with potential profits of up to 20% on buybacks.

site_title: European bourses defend coronavirus plans in extreme conditions
summary: Stock exchanges in Europe defended their coronavirus contingency plans despite extreme market conditions, citing successful execution and cooperation with supervisory authorities. The Federation of European Securities Exchanges stated that plans, including 'working from home' protocols, are working satisfactorily. The comments come as investors dump shares amid recession concerns, sparking speculation about potential trading suspensions.

site_title: Trump to receive new coronavirus recommendations this weekend, plans Xi call
summary: President Donald Trump is set to receive new coronavirus recommendations from his advisers this weekend, amid rising US cases. The recommendations aim to curb the spread while allowing the economy to reopen. Trump has been pushing for an early reopening, despite health experts' concerns. He plans to speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping later, casting doubt on Beijing's coronavirus case figures. The US has reported over 81,000 infections, surpassing China and Italy. Trump also announced a visit to Norfolk, Virginia, to send off a Navy hospital ship, and urged the House to pass a $2 trillion stimulus package.

site_title: A Language Of His Own
summary: National Gallery Singapore hosts the first solo exhibition of Malaysian artist Latiff Mohidin, titled "Latiff Mohidin: Pago Pago," featuring over 80 artworks and writings. The exhibition showcases Mohidin's distinctive art style, blending Western and Eastern aesthetics, and explores his experiences in various parts of Europe, Southeast Asia, and the Americas. The show, which runs until September 27, highlights Mohidin's unique language, born from his cultural exposure and influences.

images.alt_text: The exhibition features more than 80 artworks, writings and rare photos.
Pago Pago II.
Provoke.

site_title: Vickers hits US$200m first close for largest fund; portfolio biotechs tackling virus outbreak
summary: Vickers Venture Partners, a South-east Asian-based venture capital firm, has secured US$200 million in commitments for its largest fund yet, Fund VI, which will invest in biotechnology, nanotechnology, and artificial intelligence. The fund has already made 11 investments and is focused on developing novel technologies to tackle the novel coronavirus pandemic. Chairman Finian Tan expects a viable vaccine for Covid-19 within 12-18 months and is confident that the firm's portfolio will perform despite the current economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Dr Tan said the firm has "a couple" of portfolio companies that are planning to go public next year. "I think that might be delayed by six months? But there's nothing imminent that is going to affect them."

site_title: EU leaders give Eurogroup two weeks for virus response
summary: EU leaders have given the Eurogroup 2 weeks to develop a strong economic response to the coronavirus crisis. The call came after a video summit where hard-hit Italy and Spain urged their northern partners to do more. The proposals should take into account the unprecedented nature of the Covid-19 shock and be presented within the given timeframe for a comprehensive response.

site_title: Trump encourages cruise lines that want stimulus money to register in US
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that he supports American cruise lines registering domestically to access loans from a $2.2 trillion stimulus package. The US Senate approved the spending bill, which requires companies to be "created or organised in the United States" to receive funding. Major US-headquartered cruise lines are currently registered in countries with lenient laws, and Trump stated that registering domestically would make it easier to make loans to these companies. This move comes after extensive outbreaks of Covid-19 on cruise ships and subsequent quarantines and repatriations of American passengers.

site_title: Dogs being trained to sniff out Covid-19: charity
summary: A British charity, Medical Detection Dogs, has teamed up with the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Durham University to train dogs to detect Covid-19 through their sense of smell. The charity has previously trained dogs to detect diseases like cancer and malaria, and believes each disease triggers a distinct odor. The goal is to have dogs screen anyone, including asymptomatic individuals, to determine if they need to be tested. The training process is set to begin in six weeks, with the aim of deploying detection dogs at airports to rapidly identify people carrying the virus.

site_title: Spain virus toll passes 4,000 but death rate slows
summary: Spain's coronavirus death toll surpassed 4,000, with 655 new fatalities reported, a 19% increase. However, the death rate slowed from a 27% rise the previous day. The country's total cases rose to 56,188, also showing a 18% increase. Health Minister Salvador Illa expressed cautious optimism, stating that the numbers indicate a possible phase of stabilization. Despite the ongoing pandemic, the government aims to step up testing to 50,000 per day and has set up field hospitals to treat less severe cases.

site_title: Baring All With Sapphire
summary: Swiss watchmakers are producing fully-transparent sapphire cases on a larger scale, potentially making them the next coveted feature of luxury timepieces. Brands like Hublot, Richard Mille, Greubel Forsey, and others have released limited-edition sapphire case watches, with prices ranging from $294,000 to $2.4 million. The mass production of sapphire cases, however, remains a challenge due to the material's difficulty in machining, requiring 40 days of continuous machining. As a result, sapphire case watches remain exclusive and out of reach for most buyers.

site_title: China reports one local coronavirus case, 54 imported, cuts international flights
summary: China reported 55 new coronavirus cases, including 54 imported cases, with 5 new deaths. The total confirmed cases in mainland China stand at 81,340. Shanghai reported the most new imported cases with 17, followed by 12 in Guangdong. China has ordered airlines to cut international flights, limiting routes to one per country and flights to one per week, starting March 29. Foreigners with valid Chinese visas will also be temporarily suspended from entry starting March 28.

images.alt_text: Mainland China reported its first locally transmitted coronavirus case in three days and 54 new imported cases, as Beijing ordered airlines to sharply cut international flights fearing travellers could reignite the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Coronavirus pushes Zimbabwe to re-introduce use of US dollar
summary: Zimbabwe has re-introduced the use of foreign currency, including the US dollar, for domestic transactions amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The central bank governor cited measures to mitigate the impact of the virus on the economy and society. The move reverses a ban on the use of foreign currency implemented in June 2019, which led to a spike in inflation. The government claims the move will make it easier for businesses to operate, but a labour economist believes it's an attempt to stabilize the economy and that the measure may stay in place long-term.

site_title: US Space Force launches first mission despite coronavirus
summary: The US Space Force successfully launched its first national security mission, sending a Lockheed Martin Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) satellite into orbit despite the coronavirus pandemic. The AEHF-6 satellite, the sixth and final in the constellation, was launched on March 27, 2020, aboard an Atlas V551 rocket from Cape Canaveral in Florida. The satellite provides global, survivable communications capabilities for military forces, featuring encryption, low probability of interception, and jammer-resistance. The launch marked a significant milestone for the newly created Space Force, which aims to become a warfighting domain.

site_title: Venezuela blasts US Maduro indictment as 'coup'
summary: Venezuela's foreign minister, Jorge Arreaza, accused the US of a coup attempt after President Nicolas Maduro was indicted by the Justice Department for "narco-terrorism." Maduro is accused of leading a cocaine trafficking group called "The Cartel of the Suns." Arreaza called the indictment "miserable, vulgar, and unfounded accusations" targeting the Venezuelan people and democratic institutions. The indictment is an extremely rare case against a foreign head of state, raising tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Australians trial TB vaccine to fight coronavirus
summary: Australian researchers are conducting a large-scale human trial to test the BCG vaccine, used to prevent tuberculosis, as a potential Covid-19 prevention measure for health workers. The trial, involving 4,000 healthcare workers in Australia, aims to determine if the vaccine reduces Covid-19 symptoms. Similar trials are being conducted in several countries, including the Netherlands, Germany, and the UK, with the hope that the vaccine's effectiveness against Covid-19 symptoms can buy time to develop a specific vaccine. The trial is expected to begin within weeks.

site_title: US has world's most confirmed coronavirus cases: trackers
summary: The US has surpassed China and Italy with the highest number of confirmed coronavirus cases, with 82,404 cases reported, according to Johns Hopkins University and The New York Times. At least 1,178 people have died of Covid-19 in the US, with 40% of Americans under lockdown orders. Experts warn that the true number of cases could be much higher due to test kit shortages. The CDC listed 68,440 cases, lagging behind outside tallies, as the country continues to struggle with the pandemic's impact.

site_title: Fox News slammed for talking hair, nails during pandemic
summary: Fox News host Ainsley Earhardt faced backlash for expressing concern over how women will get their hair and nails done during the pandemic, labeling it a "trivial everyday worry." Critics described her comments as "vapid" and "vain," sparking a social media pile-on. Despite the criticism, Earhardt's comments were seen as a distraction from the pandemic's more pressing issues. The incident highlighted the perceived disconnect between Fox News' coverage of the pandemic and the concerns of its viewers.

site_title: Resilience Budget: More support for firms to upgrade capabilities
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced enhancements to the Enterprise Development Grant, Productivity Solutions Grant, and SME Go Digital Programme in Singapore's Resilience Budget. These enhancements aim to support businesses in digitalizing, restructuring, and upgrading capabilities. The support will last until the end of the year, providing more resources for businesses preparing for recovery.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close third straight day higher; emergency fund vote eyed
summary: European stocks rose for the third consecutive day, driven by gains on Wall Street. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 2.6% higher, adding nearly 15% over the past three sessions. The increase follows a record reading in US weekly jobless claims, fueling calls for more stimulus measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. EU lawmakers are set to vote on emergency funds to cushion the blow from the outbreak.

images.alt_text: European stocks reversed course to end higher on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street, while investors awaited a vote by EU lawmakers on emergency funds to cushion the blow from the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: More help for aviation industry, plus tourism, hotel, convention sectors
summary: Singapore's government has unveiled an enhanced support package worth S$450 million to help the aviation, tourism, hotel, and convention sectors recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. The package includes a 75% wage offset for local workers, rebates on landing and parking charges, and rental relief for airlines and cargo agents. The government also aims to maintain minimum connectivity levels, allowing Singaporeans to return home and essential goods to be brought in. The measures are expected to help address immediate challenges and preserve jobs in the affected industries.

site_title: Virus restrictions ground most of Africa's airlines: association
summary: Most of Africa's airlines are grounded due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 95% of planes grounded, excluding cargo flights. The African Airlines Association warned that several airlines could go bankrupt. The pandemic has led to airport and border closures in many African states, forcing carriers to cancel inter-African and inter-continental flights. The situation poses significant challenges for the aviation industry in Africa, with potentially severe financial consequences for affected airlines.

site_title: An action plan for companies to combat Covid-19
summary: IBM has released an "Action Guide" to help companies navigate the Covid-19 pandemic, focusing on four key components: employees, customers and partners, finance and operations, and the community. The guide advises companies to prioritize calmness, patience, and planning to protect themselves, prepare for the future, and improve their positioning. Key areas include facilitating remote work, enhancing customer experience, optimizing finance processes, and building community support. By taking proactive steps, organizations can improve their competitive positioning and operational efficiency in the new normal.

site_title: Battle On The Dining Front
summary: Fine dining chefs in Singapore are banding together to support healthcare workers during the Covid-19 pandemic. Chef Han Li Guang's charity drive, which aims to raise funds and send meals to healthcare workers, has raised over S$6000 and delivered S$5000 worth of packed meals. Industry partners, including restaurants and cafes, are pooling their proceeds to buy food from suppliers and send it to nurses and staff at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. Direct donations have also poured in, with non-customer individuals contacting Chef Han to express their desire to help.

site_title: Famous chefs, NY restaurants to push landlords for rent breaks amid Covid-19
summary: Renowned chefs and New York restaurants, including Cipriani and Smith & Wollensky, have formed a group called The Restaurant Network to seek rent breaks and capital assistance from landlords amid the COVID-19 crisis. The group, led by chefs Bobby Flay and Stephen Starr, aims to propose terms to landlords for rent relief and capital assistance to help small businesses survive. With many restaurants facing closure, the group is seeking help until health officials signal the all clear, which is unlikely soon.

site_title: Deskbound

site_title: The Art (Or Crime) Of Seduction

Knox argues that seduction was once seen as a harmless game involving individuals with full agency, but has become increasingly associated with unequal power dynamics and a lack of consent. site_title: Set an end date for Covid-19 economy shutdowns
summary: The US and global economies are facing exponential increases in costs due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists warn that lengthy shutdowns could lead to a second Great Depression. To mitigate this, policymakers must set a well-defined end date for shutdowns and encourage normal economic activity to resume. Mass antibody tests could help identify the healthy and newly immune population, allowing for a safer reopening. Other policy pillars, such as bolstering nursing home defense and protecting vulnerable populations, are also crucial.

site_title: The Design Ethos of Kengo Kuma
summary: Japanese architect Kengo Kuma, 65, has come a long way from his humble beginnings with a modest public bathhouse in Japan. He is now a renowned architect with over 300 staff, 600 built works, and high-profile commissions worldwide, including the Founders' Memorial in Singapore. Kuma's design ethos emphasizes simplicity, sustainability, and harmony with the environment. He has rejected traditional Japanese Modernism and postmodern influences, instead incorporating native materials, simple techniques, and traditional craftsmanship into his designs. His work often features wood, stone, and other natural materials, and he seeks to create a conversation between architecture and humanity. Kuma's approach has earned him respect from younger architects, who admire his rigorous pedagogy and exploration of materiality.

site_title: Malls ordered to stop large group activities, implement crowd control

Failure to comply may result in fines of up to S$10,000 and six-month jail terms. The measures aim to reduce the risk of Covid-19 transmission.

site_title: Italy's dead overwhelm morgues as virus toll tops 8,000

As the crisis continues, Italy is struggling to cope with the surge in deaths, with more bodies being sent to nearby towns for cremation. The country's healthcare system is severely strained.

site_title: SIA seeks S$8.8b in rights issue of shares and bonds

site_title: Big tech will save us after the pandemic is over

However, some smaller competitors, such as Airbnb and Uber, are vulnerable to the crisis and may struggle to recover. Governments are likely to turn to big tech companies to help foot the bill for stimulus packages and healthcare costs, which could further concentrate their power and influence.

summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to raise S$8.8 billion via a rights issue and convertible bonds to address the financial impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The airline will issue up to 1.77 billion new shares at S$3 each and up to S$3.5 billion of mandatory convertible bonds at S$1 each. SIA's largest shareholder, Temasek Holdings, will subscribe to its full entitlement and commit to additional funding. The airline aims to use the proceeds for operating cashflow, aircraft purchases, and debt servicing.

site_title: Satisfying izakaya cooking at Mobomoga
summary: Mobomoga, a quirky izakaya-sake bar in Singapore, offers an authentic Japanese dining experience despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The restaurant, hidden behind a plain door, features a cramped and eclectic space with counter-only seating and an open kitchen. Chef Tanaka-san, a Niigata native, serves simple yet comforting food, including sashimi, kushiage, and sukiyaki, at reasonable prices. The restaurant's sake selection is also highly enjoyable and reasonably priced. With a rating of 7, Mobomoga is a good option for those looking for a genuine Japanese dining experience in Singapore.

site_title: 2020 deficit to rise to record S$39.2b, but Singapore's fiscal position remains robust
summary: Singapore's budget deficit for 2020 is expected to rise to a record S$39.2 billion, or 7.9% of GDP, as the government rolls out a massive support package to save the economy. Despite the record deficit, analysts say the country's fiscal position remains robust due to its strong reserves, lack of external debt, and triple-A rating. The government has tapped into its past reserves, with President Halimah Yacob giving in-principle support for S$17 billion of reserves to be used. The unprecedented deficit is expected to have a minimal impact on the country's finances due to its prudent reserve management and fiscal discipline.

site_title: Italian scientists investigate possible earlier emergence of coronavirus
summary: Italian researchers are investigating whether the new coronavirus may have emerged in Italy earlier than previously thought, with a higher-than-usual number of severe pneumonia and flu cases in Lombardy in the last quarter of 2019. Researchers are reviewing hospital records to determine if the virus was present in Italy at the end of 2019, with some experts casting doubt on the hypothesis, citing the virus's infectiousness and the lack of reported cases before January.

site_title: Tenants sceptical that landlords will pass on rebates in Resilience Budget
summary: Singapore's government has announced expanded property tax rebates to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 crisis. Commercial properties will pay zero property tax for 2020, while non-residential properties will receive a 30% rebate. Landlords have committed to passing on the rebates, but tenants remain skeptical due to previous experiences with delayed or inadequate support. Tenants' groups and some retailers expressed concerns that the rebates may not translate to lower rentals. The government's measures aim to support businesses and workers, with wage offsets and liquidity support also provided.

site_title: Santak extends closure of Johor factory
summary: Santak Holdings has extended the closure of its Johor factory to April 14 due to Malaysia's movement control order. This will impact the production of precision machined parts and negatively affect the company's financial performance, earnings per share, and net asset value per share for the current financial year. The closure will also affect Malaysian employees working at the Singapore factory due to commuting restrictions.

site_title: Behind-the-scenes look at President's nod to draw on reserves
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob has given in-principle approval for the government to draw up to S$17b from past reserves to fund a second stimulus package aimed at rescuing the economy from the novel coronavirus. The decision comes after the government faces a significant economic challenge, with President Yacob stating that the situation resembles a thunderstorm rather than a drizzle. The reserves were built up over the years for such purposes, and the government plans to use them to support the economy.

site_title: Malls to suspend all large group activities, implement crowd and queue control until April 30
summary: Malls and standalone stores in Singapore will suspend large group activities and implement crowd and queue control measures until April 30. They must limit group sizes to 10 or fewer, and adhere to safe-distancing measures such as one person per 16 square meters of usable space. Bars, entertainment venues, and communal facilities like playgrounds will be closed, while fitness studios can remain open. Failure to comply may result in fines up to S$10,000 and six months in jail.

site_title: India outlines US$23b stimulus to help poor hit by lockdown
summary: India has announced a US$22.6 billion economic stimulus plan to provide relief to millions of poor people affected by the nationwide lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes direct cash transfers and food security measures, aiming to support the country's 1.3 billion people. The lockdown, ordered by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has led to supply constraints and panic buying, leaving the poor and daily laborers most vulnerable. The stimulus plan is part of the government's efforts to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Public sector to create 10,000 new jobs over the next year
summary: The Singapore government plans to create 10,000 new jobs in the public sector over the next year, with 8,000 trainee places available for first-time young job seekers. The initiative, called the SGUnited Jobs Initiative, aims to provide meaningful employment opportunities in emerging areas such as social services, early childhood education, and information and communications technology. The government will also offer short-term, temporary jobs to handle the increase in Covid-19 related operations.

images.alt_text: Anticipating more job losses from the Covid-19 fallout, DPM Heng said the government will dish out S$145 million in the next six months to offer financial help to the jobless and families in need of money.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.59 points to 1,328.09 on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume reached 3.504 billion lots worth RM2.259 billion, with 540 gainers and 295 losers.

site_title: Covid-19 pushes US jobless claims last week to record 3.3 million
summary: The US experienced a record 3.3 million jobless claims last week, surpassing the previous record of 695,000 in October 1982, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's economic shutdown. The surge in unemployment benefits was largely attributed to the pandemic's impact on food services, accommodation, entertainment, and healthcare. The US Senate approved a $2.2 trillion economic rescue package to cushion the blow. Economists had predicted a higher number, with some warning of a "horrific" result, as New York state alone received 1.7 million calls about benefits.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Govt may propose further draws on reserves amid Covid-19 storm
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a new Resilience Budget to combat the coronavirus pandemic, with potential further draws on past reserves up to S$17 billion. The government has prepared for such a scenario, having accumulated reserves for "rainy days." Measures include enhancements to job support schemes, a temporary bridging loan program, and an aviation support package. The President has given in-principle support for the government's plan, cautioning against overusing reserves. The government will continue to monitor the situation closely and take further action as needed.

site_title: SPH directors, senior management take pay cuts
summary: SPH directors and senior management will take a 10% pay cut in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. The move aims to show solidarity with fellow Singaporeans and better position the company for the challenging time. The cuts, starting next month, will be reviewed at the end of the year. Additionally, SPH Foundation will donate S$100,000 to The Courage Fund to support those affected by the pandemic.

site_title: The world is on the brink of running out of places to put oil
summary: The world is facing a severe oil storage crisis, with inventories expected to increase by 1.8 billion barrels in the first half of 2020, surpassing available storage capacity of 1.6 billion barrels. This shortage is driven by falling demand due to the coronavirus outbreak and Saudi Arabia's decision to flood the market with crude at deep discounts. As a result, oil producers will be forced to cut output by June, leaving no places to store unwanted crude, according to an industry consultant.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Enhancements for digitalisation and skills upgrading programmes
summary: Singapore's government is enhancing digitalisation and skills upgrading programs to support businesses during the novel coronavirus pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Resilience Budget, which includes raising the maximum support levels for the Productivity Solutions Grant to 80% and the Enterprise Development Grant to 90%. The government will also extend training support to more sectors and increase absentee payroll rates to 90% for all employers starting May 1. These enhancements will last until December 2020 and aim to help workers and businesses adapt to the pandemic.

site_title: US jobless claims surged to record 3.28 million last week
summary: US jobless claims surged to a record 3.28 million in the week ended March 21, more than quadrupling the previous record high of 695,000 in 1982. This comes as businesses shuttered and laid off workers in efforts to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Economists' projections for the figure ranged as high as 4.4 million, with the data dating back to 1967.

site_title: Coronavirus: Singapore reports 52 new cases, 28 from overseas
summary: Singapore reported 52 new COVID-19 cases on March 26, with 28 from overseas. All except two were returning residents or long-term pass holders who traveled to Europe, North America, or Asia. Locally transmitted cases were linked to existing clusters, with 20 cases connected to a pre-school cluster in Fengshan. The country has 404 active cases, with 18 in critical care, and 172 recovered. Two patients have died from complications due to the virus. Contact tracing is ongoing for 14 unlinked cases.

images.alt_text: All except two of the 28 were returning residents or long-term pass holders who had travelled to Europe, North America, Middle East or other parts of Asia.

site_title: Mapletree commits S$18m rental relief for its tenants, offers payment deferment
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) is committing an additional S$18 million in rental relief and offering payment deferment for its retail tenants due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This assistance package aims to offset about two months of rent and follows the government's announcement of property tax rebates. MCT has also implemented safe-distancing measures across its properties. The move is expected to ease cash flow for its tenants and cushion the impact of the pandemic on the retail sector.

site_title: Bank of England keeps interest rate at record-low 0.1%
summary: The Bank of England maintained its main interest rate at a record-low 0.1% to combat the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made after a week of emergency meetings, and policymakers also kept its quantitative easing stimulus at £645 billion. The bank warned that the global economy will shrink sharply in the first half of 2020, with the British economy likely to suffer a "very sharp" drop in economic activity.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England kept its main interest rate at 0.1 per cent Thursday, a week after cutting the borrowing cost to the record-low level to combat economic fallout from the coronavirus.

site_title: S$48.4b Resilience Budget for Singapore to tackle Covid-19 crisis
summary: Singapore has unveiled a record S$48.4 billion Resilience Budget to tackle the Covid-19 crisis, with in-principle support up to S$17 billion from past reserves. The budget includes measures to save jobs, support workers, and strengthen longer-term resilience, such as wage offsets, property tax rebates, and deferment of corporate income tax payments. The government has also committed S$1.9 billion for longer-term resilience and has frozen government fees and charges for a year. The overall budget deficit for FY2020 has risen to S$39.2 billion, but the government remains fiscally sustainable due to disciplined use of past reserves.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has unveiled a $48.4 billion resilience budget to tackle the Covid-19 crisis, with potential support from past reserves. The country's 2020 growth forecast has been downgraded to between -4% and -1%. Singapore Airlines is considering corporate action with Temasek's support. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) ended 0.7% lower.

site_title: Spanish doctors forced to choose who should get intensive care
summary: In Spain, medical staff are struggling to cope with the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to difficult decisions about who receives intensive care. Older patients are often denied treatment in favor of younger patients with a better chance of survival. Dr. Daniel Bernabeu described a situation where he signed a death certificate for one patient while helping another who was choking, highlighting the dire situation in emergency rooms. With overflowing intensive-care wards and morgues reaching capacity, the crisis is taking a devastating toll on the country's healthcare system.

site_title: Governments give more help to airlines hit by Covid-19
summary: Governments worldwide have stepped up aid for airlines severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The US has offered $58 billion in assistance, with Singapore promising to support its carrier, Singapore Airlines. Australia has also eased competition rules to help airlines. Airlines have been forced to drastically cut schedules and turn planes into cargo-only transporters, leading to a sharp reduction in cargo capacity and affecting global trade. The International Air Transport Association estimates the pandemic will cost the industry $252 billion in lost revenues this year.

site_title: Geo Energy may scrap acquisition, buys back 8% senior notes
summary: Geo Energy Resources may scrap its acquisition of PT Titan Global Energy due to unmet conditions. The proposed acquisition, announced in September, has been amended and the completion date extended to March 31. If conditions are not fulfilled, Geo Energy can immediately terminate the agreement.

site_title: Hedge fund manager to lead Norway sovereign fund after US$124b loss
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, has named Nicolai Tangen, a London-based hedge fund manager, as its new chief executive. Tangen will succeed Yngve Slyngstad in September after the fund lost US$124 billion this year due to the coronavirus pandemic. Tangen has built up one of Europe's leading investment firms, delivering good financial results as an international investment manager, according to Norwegian central bank Governor Oeystein Olsen.

site_title: Battle between high- and low-sulphur fuels shaping up
summary: The International Marine Organization's (IMO) 2020 global sulphur specifications for bunker fuel have largely gone as expected, with low-sulphur fuels pricing higher than high-sulphur ones. Despite initial concerns, bunker fuel sales in Singapore rose 7.5% in January, driven by a surge in marine gas oil demand. The share of very low-sulphur fuel oil (VLSFO) increased to 70%, while high-sulphur fuel oil (HSFO) prices dropped to 17%. Scrubbers, which allow ships to use cheaper high-sulphur fuel, are becoming more widespread, but their carbon-dioxide emissions and wastewater issues remain. The IMO 2020 mandate is expected to have a lasting impact on the shipping industry's greenhouse gas emissions, with alternative fuels and energy-saving technologies likely to play a key role.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit bags S$433m contract
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) has awarded a S$433 million contract to Sembcorp Design and Construction, a subsidiary of Chip Eng Seng, for the Tuas Water Reclamation Plant project. The contract includes building works for biosolids building and digesters, treatment and biogas handling equipment, and testing and commissioning. Construction is expected to be completed by 2025, and the contract will contribute positively to Chip Eng Seng's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Indonesia has no plan for capital controls, to ramp up fiscal stimulus
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated the country has no plan to implement capital controls due to the coronavirus fears. The rupiah has lost 14% this year, but a 1.1% gain on Thursday was attributed to US and European fiscal stimulus. The central bank has bilateral swap arrangements, including a $30 billion deal with China's central bank, to support the rupiah. The government is preparing to expand fiscal stimulus, including easing taxes and increasing government spending, to cushion the economy from the virus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Indonesian central bank governor Perry Warjiyo on Thursday said the country has no plan to implement capital control measures to stop outflows due to coronavirus fears, saying that its foreign exchange reserve is more than enough to prop up the currency.

site_title: UOB employee tests positive for Covid-19
summary: A United Overseas Bank (UOB) employee has tested positive for COVID-19, according to the bank's statement on Thursday. The employee, who is not customer-facing, is receiving medical care and has been placed under isolation. Colleagues who had close contact with the infected employee are on leave of absence until next week, and others on the affected floor are working from home. The bank is conducting deep cleaning and disinfection of the affected area, and has increased temperature screening, hand sanitizer availability, and enhanced cleaning protocols at its premises.

site_title: SMRT gives taxi partners $5.8 million in rental rebates
summary: SMRT is providing an additional S$5.8 million in rental rebates to taxi partners due to reduced demand caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. From March 27 to April 30, daily total rent reductions will be S$60, and for April, S$55. This support, combined with the Special Relief Fund (SRF), totals around S$10.6 million over 7.5 months.

site_title: CAAS lets aviation companies defer fee payments by a year
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has announced that Singapore carriers and the airport operator can defer payment of certain fees by up to a year for fees due between April 1, 2020 and March 31, 2021. This deferral applies to about $140 million worth of fees, including Certificates of Airworthiness and air services agreements. The move is part of the government's support package to help the aviation sector recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: SPH Reit commits to fully pass on property tax rebate to tenants
summary: SPH Reit has committed to fully passing on its 2020 property tax rebate to tenants, in line with Singapore's government announcement. The rebate is part of efforts to alleviate the impact of COVID-19 on businesses. The company's manager will also take a 10% cut in directors' fees and pay cuts for senior staff. SPH Reit aims to finalize the details of its enhanced tenants rebate scheme by April and may consider further rental rebates for affected retail and F&B businesses.

site_title: Singapore's current account surplus to tumble in 2020 due to Covid-19: Fitch Solutions
summary: Fitch Solutions has forecasted Singapore's 2020 current account balance to shrink to 12.9% of GDP, down from 17.3% in 2019, due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The goods trade surplus is expected to decline, mainly due to severe global economic disruptions. Exports are forecasted to contract 10% and imports to contract 8.5%, with the service sector expected to post a small surplus. The overall income deficit is likely to remain steady. The weakening Singapore dollar is expected to limit the deterioration of the trade balance.

site_title: SIA considering corporate action with Temasek's support
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is considering a corporate action with Temasek Holdings' support to navigate the COVID-19 outbreak. The airline had previously announced significant capacity cuts and pay cuts for staff. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Temasek will provide support, ensuring SIA can "emerge stronger" from the crisis. The government's aviation sector support and possible direct measures will aid in preserving the country's air hub status.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall over 2% at open
summary: European stock markets fell over 2% at the open on Thursday, as investors took profits after two sessions of gains fueled by global economic stimulus measures. London, Frankfurt, Paris, Milan, and Madrid all declined, with London losing 2.5% and Madrid falling 2.4%. The decline was attributed to investors locking in gains and uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Britain turns to Dyson for 10,000 ventilators to ramp up the coronavirus fight
summary: Britain has ordered 10,000 ventilators from Dyson to help combat the coronavirus outbreak, following an urgent appeal from Prime Minister Boris Johnson to manufacturers. Dyson designed the ventilator, called The CoVent, in a short space of time, utilizing its expertise in air movement and manufacturing. The device requires approval from the British medical regulator before production can begin, expected to start early next month. Britain currently has around 8,000 ventilators and is racing to boost production as the country prepares for an expected surge in cases.

site_title: Resilience Budget: S$20b allocation for loan capital to support companies
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$20 billion of loan capital in the Resilience Budget to support companies affected by the novel coronavirus pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that this will help strong companies and catalyse private sector loan capital, providing assistance where credit needs are more acute. The move aims to support the private sector and mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: STI's rally loses steam, ends 0.7% lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore's stock market ended 0.7% lower on Thursday, as the recent rally fizzled out amid the harsh reality of the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on the local economy. The Ministry of Trade and Industry lowered its 2020 growth forecast to -4 to -1%, and the city-state is likely to experience its first full-year recession since 2001. A record S$48.4 billion will be committed to help the economy weather the storm, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announcing measures to support key sectors such as aviation and telcos.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Government freezes all fees and charges for a year till March 2021
summary: Singapore's government has frozen all fees and charges for one year, starting from April 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021, to offer flexibility amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. This includes suspending loan repayment and interest charges for graduates, as well as late payment charges on Housing Board mortgages for three months. The measures aim to support individuals struggling with payments during this difficult period.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Aviation, tourism-related firms to get 75% wage offsets
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a Resilience Budget to support the country's aviation and tourism sectors during the coronavirus pandemic. The enhanced Jobs Support Scheme will provide 75% wage offsets for local workers in these industries, with businesses in aviation getting up to S$4,600 per month. The aviation support package includes measures such as rebates and rental relief for airlines and ground handlers. The government also aims to retain connectivity to the world and keep supply lines open, and will set aside S$90 million to help the tourism industry rebound.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Singaporeans on Workfare to get S$3,000 in cash
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Singaporeans on the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme will receive a one-time cash payout of S$3,000 under the Resilience Budget to address the coronavirus outbreak. This is a significant enhancement over the previously announced Workfare Special Payment, which would have provided a minimum payout of S$100 and a maximum of S$720. Eligible employees and self-employed persons will receive two equal payments of S$1,500 each in 2020.

site_title: Jetstar crew offered temporary jobs amid suspension of flights
summary: Jetstar Asia has offered temporary jobs to more than a third of its crew amid the suspension of flights due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Crew members have been hired as safe-distancing ambassadors, healthcare assistants, and "SG Clean" ambassadors, primarily working at coffee shops, hawker centers, and airports. The move aims to support the crew financially and contribute to the community during the challenging time. Jetstar Asia appreciates the government's wage-support package for the aviation industry.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Singapore's overall budget deficit almost quadruples to S$39.2b
summary: Singapore's overall budget deficit for financial year 2020 is expected to reach a record S$39.2 billion, nearly four times the initial estimate of S$10.9 billion, due to a substantial support package to rescue the coronavirus-battered economy. The government has tapped into past reserves, using S$17 billion, to fund the support package, which was announced in the Resilience Budget. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the government's fiscal sustainability and preparedness to address the economic uncertainty.

site_title: Resilience Budget: S$95m more for taxi and private-hire drivers, S$55m for arts sector
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced additional support for taxi and private-hire drivers, with an additional S$95 million, and the arts sector, with an additional S$55 million, as part of the Point-to-Point Support Package and Resilience Budget.
