Eligible drivers will receive S$300 monthly payments until end-September, while private bus owners will receive a one-year road tax rebate and six-month waiver of parking charges. The arts sector will receive support through major companies, the National Arts Council's Capability Development scheme, and digitalisation efforts.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Income tax payments for companies and self-employed deferred for 3 months
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a 3-month deferment of income tax payments for companies and self-employed persons due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. Companies will not have to pay income tax from April to June 2020, while self-employed persons will not have to pay from May to July 2020. The move aims to ease cash flow worries for businesses.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall after two sessions of sharp gains; won weakens
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.09% to 1,686.24 after two sessions of sharp gains, with investors booking profits ahead of US jobless claims data. The won weakened, and foreigners sold 593.31 million won worth of shares. The central bank launched quantitative easing, while the government plans to loosen foreign exchange liquidity rules. The US Senate passed a $2 trillion stimulus bill, and US jobless claims are expected to surge, prompting investors' caution.

site_title: Russia to ground all international flights from midnight on Friday
summary: Russia will ground all international flights from midnight on Friday, as part of new measures against the coronavirus outbreak. The decree, published by the government, orders aviation authorities to halt regular and charter flights, except for special flights evacuating Russian citizens. The grounding will start at 2100 GMT on Thursday, affecting flights from Russian airports to foreign airports and back.

images.alt_text: Russia will halt all international flights from midnight on Friday under a government decree listing new measures against the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Firms can get trade loans of up to S$10m, bridging loans of up to S$5m
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Resilience Budget to support businesses amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Enterprise Financing Scheme (EFS) will receive a boost, with the maximum loan quantum increased to S$10 million and the government's risk-share increasing to 80 per cent. Businesses will also receive higher subsidies for loan insurance premiums and a one-year temporary bridging loan programme will be expanded to all enterprises, with a maximum supported loan of S$5 million.

site_title: PM, ministers to take three-month pay cut in solidarity with Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister and Cabinet ministers will take a three-month pay cut in solidarity with Singaporeans amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This move, announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, also includes the President and other political office-holders. The pay cut is in addition to a one-month cut previously announced. The move aims to demonstrate the government's commitment to supporting the public during this challenging time.

images.alt_text: The Prime Minister, Cabinet ministers and other political office-holders - as well as the President - will take a three-month pay cut to stand in solidarity with Singaporeans in this difficult time, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said on Thursday.

site_title: OUE to rebrand Mandarin Orchard as largest Hilton hotel in Asia-Pacific
summary: OUE will invest approximately S$90 million to rebrand Mandarin Orchard Singapore as Hilton Singapore Orchard, the largest Hilton hotel in the Asia-Pacific. This rebranding marks a significant expansion for Hilton in Singapore and solidifies the hotel's position as a flagship property. The rebranding is part of a partnership between OUE, the master lessee, and OUE Commercial Reit, which owns the hotel under its portfolio. The investment aims to enhance the hotel's offerings and attract more customers to the property.

site_title: Covid-19: Singapore casinos restrict access, implement safe distancing measures
summary: Singapore casinos Resorts World Sentosa and Marina Bay Sands are restricting access to certain members only and implementing safe distancing measures due to government regulations to contain the spread of Covid-19. The restrictions started at 11:59pm on Thursday, limiting RWS casino access to existing Genting Rewards card members and annual levy holders, while MBS's casino access is restricted to Sands Rewards Club members with Gold status or higher, or existing annual levy holders. These measures aim to reduce the risk of transmission and comply with government guidelines.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with losses on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.74% to 23,352.34, following a healthy rally. Investors took profits and awaited US jobless claims data, which may impact global markets. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index down 0.60% to 2,764.91.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index slipped 0.74 per cent, or 174.85 points, to close at 23,352.34.

site_title: Australia tells cruise ships to depart as coronavirus cases rise
summary: Australia orders two cruise ships to depart as coronavirus cases rise to nearly 2,800, with 12 deaths. The Ruby Princess, where 147 infected passengers disembarked, is a primary source of infection. State authorities clash with the federal government over oversight, leading to calls for tougher restrictions on social activities. Western Australia prepares to quarantine passengers on a third cruise ship, the Vasco de Gama, after seven tested positive for Covid-19.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Singapore President gives in-principle support for 'substantial' support package
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob has given in-principle support for a "substantial" second support package to rescue the coronavirus-battered economy, allowing the government to draw on past reserves. This comes as the country reported a 2.2% contraction in its first-quarter GDP and lowered its growth forecast to between -4 and -1%. The package's details and size will be revealed by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat in his Resilience Budget speech. President Halimah's support is seen as a significant step forward in addressing the economic crisis, which she described as "unparalleled in modern history".

site_title: Resilience Budget: Jobless can get S$800 monthly; new fund to give families urgent help
summary: Singapore has introduced a Covid-19 Support Grant, providing S$800 monthly to low and middle-income workers who lost jobs due to the pandemic. The grant will be available from May to September 2020. Additionally, a temporary relief fund will be set up for families in April, offering immediate financial assistance. The Resilience Budget, which allocates S$145 million, aims to help Singaporeans through the pandemic. The government has also increased flexibilities for the ComCare scheme to provide assistance to affected individuals and families.

site_title: Resilience Budget: S$48.4b in support measures; govt may draw up to S$17b from reserves
summary: Singapore will roll out S$48.4 billion in support measures under a supplementary budget, focusing on saving jobs, supporting workers, and strengthening economic resilience amid the coronavirus outbreak. The government has obtained President's in-principle support to draw up to S$17 billion from reserves, alongside S$6.4 billion from Budget 2020. The measures amount to 11% of Singapore's GDP, with the economy forecast to contract between -4% and -1%.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down 4.5% as Japan virus fears grow
summary: Japanese stocks plummeted 4.5% on Thursday as investors sold off amid growing fears of a coronavirus expansion in Tokyo. The Nikkei 225 index fell 882.03 points to 18,664.60, while the Topix index dropped 1.78% to 1,399.32. The three-day rally came to an end, with traders spooked by Tokyo's governor warning of possible virus expansion.

site_title: High Court dismisses honestbee's restructuring bid; creditors may wind up firm
summary: The High Court has dismissed honestbee's restructuring bid, effectively allowing creditors to wind up the company. The startup, which had sought to restructure US$230 million of debt, had requested a two-week adjournment due to concerns from key investor Brian Koo's affiliated entities. With the court's decision, honestbee is no longer under court protection, and its sole secured creditor, Formation Group, is now able to retake its office space. The outcome may mark the end of the road for the distressed startup, which had been seeking alternative investors.

site_title: Resilience Budget: S$3b allocated for cash distribution to all families amid pandemic
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$3 billion for the Resilience Budget to provide cash distribution to all families amid the pandemic. The enhanced Care and Support Package includes a tripled cash payout for adult Singaporeans (S$300 to S$900), tripled payouts for families with young children (S$300), and increased grocery vouchers and Workfare Special Payments for lower-wage workers. The package now costs around S$4.6 billion, with a one-off PAssion Card top-up in cash for Singaporeans aged 50 and above.

site_title: Resilience Budget: No property tax for landlords hit by coronavirus, others to get 30% rebate
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a revised Resilience Budget, exempting commercial properties severely affected by the coronavirus pandemic from paying property tax in 2020. Hotels, serviced apartments, tourist attractions, shops, and restaurants qualify for this exemption. For other non-residential properties, landlords will receive a 30% rebate, while tenants of offices and industrial properties will also receive a 30% rebate. The government will also provide rental waivers to tenants, including enhanced support for those in hawker centres and social service agencies.

site_title: Resilience Budget: S$15.1b Jobs Support Scheme to help companies
summary: Singapore's government will allocate S$15.1 billion to the Jobs Support Scheme, a 10-fold increase from the initial S$1.3 billion, to co-fund wages and support 1.9 million local employees. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat urged employers to hold on to their workers with this government support, which is more than twice the level of support provided during the Global Financial Crisis.

site_title: Urgency for Asean to realise the vision of the AEC and trade more with itself is greater than ever: EU-ABC
summary: Asean's foreign direct investment (FDI) numbers have risen to an all-time high, but underlying concerns remain. The region has missed its targets for regional economic integration and intra-Asean trade continues to lag. The EU-Asean Business Council attributes this to non-tariff barriers to trade and investment, which must be removed to achieve sustainable economic development. Asean's credibility rests on its leadership's efforts to identify and eliminate these barriers, and the implementation of initiatives like the Asean Single Window and Single Self-Certification Programme is crucial to advancing intra-Asean trade.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Aim to create 10,000 jobs in public and private sector over the year
summary: Singapore's Resilience Budget aims to create 10,000 jobs in both public and private sectors by the end of the year. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to recruit for long-term roles and short-term temporary jobs, including health declaration assistants and transport ambassadors. The government will also launch an SGUnited Jobs virtual career fair with over 2,200 job vacancies and an SGUnited Traineeships programme to support young people and local first-time jobseekers.

site_title: Majority of Australian businesses expect hit from coronavirus: ABS
summary: Majority of Australian businesses expect a hit from coronavirus-related restrictions, with approximately half experiencing adverse impacts during the mid-March data collection period. A further 86% expect to be affected in future months, citing a fall in demand as the most common impact. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) conducted the survey to gauge the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares set for third day of gains ahead of US stimulus vote
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, driven by technology and healthcare stocks, ahead of a US stimulus package vote. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level in over a week, with healthcare stocks advancing nearly 3.3% and oil prices boosting the energy index. Despite gains, sentiment remains uncertain due to the pandemic's impact on businesses and jobs. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 3.8%, with software and tourism stocks leading the gains.

site_title: Gold declines a second day as investors weigh squeeze, stimulus
summary: Gold prices dropped for a second day, falling 0.8% to $1,604.14 an ounce, as investors weighed concerns over a trading squeeze and digest the US stimulus bill. The US stimulus bill, which includes unlimited quantitative easing, has sparked optimism among investors, with Goldman Sachs predicting a buying opportunity. Meanwhile, logistical disruptions caused by the pandemic have eased, reducing the divergence of prices in New York and London.

site_title: MAS to hold auctions for USD from Fed swap facility starting Friday, March 27
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will hold auctions to lend USD obtained from the US Federal Reserve's swap facility to Singaporean banks starting Friday, March 27. The first auction will offer $10 billion in 7-day funds to cater to increased demand for USD at the end of the quarter. This move aims to support stable USD funding conditions in Singapore and facilitate USD lending to businesses in the region, as part of global efforts to maintain financial market stability.

site_title: Small banks are struggling just as the world needs them most
summary: Regional banks, which should support community businesses during the coronavirus pandemic, are struggling due to low margins, bad debt, and the threat of ratings cuts. Moody's Investors Service downgraded four South Korean regional banks and US small banks called for delayed loan-loss accounting rules to prevent curtailed lending. Analysts warn of rising loan losses and weakening revenues as the pandemic slows economic activity globally, with the US$2 trillion stimulus bill providing aid for small businesses.

site_title: Singapore Airlines calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: Singapore Airlines has called for a trading halt pending an announcement. The airline's shares closed 10.4% higher on Wednesday at S$6.50, following a report that pilots will be placed on compulsory no-pay leave starting April 1 to save jobs. The airline is also exploring ways to increase liquidity, reduce capital expenditure, and operating costs amid the COVID-19 outbreak.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) on Thursday morning called for a halt in the trading of its shares pending the release of an announcement. The halt was called at 8.14am before the market opened for trading.

site_title: Resilience Budget will save jobs, support firms, help households: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Resilience Budget, a supplementary budget to support jobs, companies, and households affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The budget aims to save jobs and provide additional help to those hardest hit, with measures including cash payouts to workers and support for front-line agencies. The economy is expected to shrink 2.2% in the first quarter and face a full-year recession, with a forecast of -4 to -1% growth in 2020. The budget will be presented in Parliament on March 26, 2020.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on US stimulus; NZ hits 2-week high
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive session, with the S&P/ASX 200 index climbing 2.3% to a one-week high, driven by the US Senate's passage of a $2 trillion stimulus package to combat the coronavirus epidemic. The healthcare sector and miners led the gains, while the Reserve Bank of Australia proposed buying A$3 billion in sovereign bonds as part of its quantitative easing program. In New Zealand, the benchmark index hit a two-week high, driven by a one-month lockdown and a stronger-than-expected finance minister's forecast of the epidemic's impact on jobs.

site_title: LMIRT closes 11 Indonesia malls to curb coronavirus spread
summary: LMIRT, a mall trust in Indonesia, is temporarily closing 11 malls from March 27 to April 9 due to the coronavirus outbreak. The closures are voluntary and not ordered by local authorities. Essential services, such as supermarkets and pharmacies, will remain open with shorter hours. Tenants of the closed malls will be exempt from rental fees during the closure period. The trust's manager expects distributable income to be negatively affected in the second quarter. This move is part of a broader trend of malls closing or announcing temporary closures across Indonesia.

site_title: China, US to set aside differences in G20 coronavirus summit: media
summary: China and the US are expected to put aside their differences in a G20 coronavirus summit, agreeing that the outbreak is a global threat and setting up a mechanism to share information and experiences in fighting the disease. The leaders are expected to convene via video conference to unite efforts towards a global response, following criticism of the G20 group's slow response to the crisis. This comes after preparatory talks between the two countries agreed to set aside their differences, amid tensions over the origin of the virus and accusations of misinformation.

site_title: Singapore's 2020 growth forecast hits negative territory, Q1 GDP contracts 2.2%
summary: Singapore's official 2020 growth forecast has been downgraded to -4% to -1%, entering negative territory due to the COVID-19 outbreak. This marks the first time since 2001 the country's GDP has contracted. The first quarter's 2.2% contraction and 10.6% quarter-on-quarter decline indicate a recession is inevitable, with economists slashing their forecasts. The services sector, accounting for two-thirds of GDP employment, is expected to lead the decline, making a full-year recession unavoidable.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US lawmakers debate stimulus
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday amid a US stimulus package debate, despite a surge in global equities. The $2 trillion plan, which includes a "wartime level of investment," helped stocks recover from a recent downturn. However, four Republican senators opposed the bipartisan deal with the White House, dampening the advance. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by positive investor sentiment despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Saudi Arabia chairs G-20 crisis talks as virus threatens recession
summary: Saudi Arabia chairs an emergency online G-20 summit as the coronavirus threatens a recession. US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin will participate, amid criticism of the group's slow response. The talks come as the global Covid-19 death toll nears 21,000 and over 3 billion people are locked down. The summit also addresses an oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which has disrupted energy markets. The outcome of the talks is uncertain, with King Salman under pressure to address the crisis.

site_title: Resilience Budget: Self-employed persons to get S$1,000 cash each month, more training allowance
summary: The Singapore government will provide S$1,000 monthly cash assistance to eligible self-employed persons for nine months under the Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme (SIRS). The scheme, part of the Resilience Budget, aims to support self-employed individuals during the Covid-19 pandemic. The government is allocating S$1.2 billion for this initiative, with details to be announced by the Ministry of Manpower. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the plan in Parliament, aiming to help self-employed persons "ride out the Covid-19 storm".

site_title: Singapore factory output posts 1.1% drop in February: EDB
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 1.1% in February, driven by a contraction in the electronics cluster, according to the Economic Development Board. Manufacturing output excluding biomedical manufacturing fell 2.5% due to growth in medical technology and pharmaceuticals segments. Despite this, biomedical manufacturing saw a 9.1% increase, driven by higher export demand for medical devices and increased production of biological products.

site_title: US$2t rescue package passes US Senate, heads to House
summary: The US Senate passed a $2 trillion rescue package to alleviate the economic and healthcare impacts of the coronavirus crisis. The measure includes cash payments to taxpayers, grants and loans for small businesses and hospitals, and expanded unemployment benefits. The package is headed to the House of Representatives for approval before being sent to President Donald Trump for signature. The deal was reached between Republicans, Democrats, and the White House, providing a significant economic lifeline to Americans and battered industries.

images.alt_text: The measure cleared the Senate by an overwhelming majority and was headed next to the House of Representatives, which must also pass it before it goes to President Donald Trump for his signature.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, extending a healthy rally fueled by the US stimulus deal. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.33% to 23,604.83, while Singapore's STI increased 0.4%. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.71% and 0.73% respectively. The rally comes despite US President Trump's new threats, with investors continuing to stay positive about the market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.73 points or 0.36% to 1,319.77 on Thursday, opening lower. The index saw a trading volume of 70.42 million lots worth RM36.04 million. Gainers outpaced losers 163 to 52.

site_title: New Zealand mosque shooter pleads guilty to all charges: police
summary: An Australian, Brenton Tarrant, a self-avowed white supremacist, pleaded guilty to all 51 charges related to the 2019 mosque shootings in New Zealand that killed 51 people. The guilty pleas were taken via an audio-visual link from Auckland Prison. The shootings, which targeted Muslims at Friday prayers, were the worst mass shootings in modern New Zealand history.

site_title: Airbnb holds meeting with bankers to extend US$1b debt facility: source
summary: Airbnb held a meeting with bankers to discuss extending its existing US$1 billion debt facility, which was agreed in 2016 and has never been used. The company is seeking to extend the period to be prudent amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a slowdown in bookings. Despite having US$3 billion in cash, Airbnb is looking to boost its cash coffers. The company expects its bookings to recover, reaching 2019 levels by early 2021, and has received inquiries from potential investors.

site_title: US should refrain from export controls in pandemic response: Chamber of Commerce
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce urges the US to refrain from adopting export controls on essential goods needed to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The chamber welcomes a joint pledge by Australia, Canada, and other countries to keep supply chains open and avoid export controls. US President Donald Trump downplays the likelihood of an executive order banning exports of medical supplies, saying the US produces the best medical equipment in the world. The issue will be addressed by G-20 leaders in a virtual summit.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as GDP forecasts weigh; STI down 0.7% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 2,487.05, following the Ministry of Trade and Industry's downgrade of the country's 2020 GDP forecast to -4 to -1%. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, were down, while Jardine Matheson Holdings rose 3.9%. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of the GDP data release.

site_title: FY21 earnings for Singtel, StarHub to fall 9-10% if Covid-19 persists: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has cut FY2021 earnings forecasts for Singapore telcos Singtel and StarHub by 10% and 9% respectively, citing the persistence of the Covid-19 pandemic. Singtel is expected to be impacted by translation losses and Optus's roaming revenues, while StarHub may benefit from its joint 5G bid. DBS analysts suggest dividend yields for both telcos remain attractive, but warn of potential share price declines if earnings fall by 10-15%.

images.alt_text: If the fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic persists through 2020, DBS Group Research could cut FY2021 earnings forecasts for Singapore telcos Singtel and StarHub by 10 and 9 per cent, respectively.

site_title: Gold sparkles in Covid-19 shadow
summary: Gold prices surge as investors seek shelter from the COVID-19 pandemic and rising inflation, with demand from both commodity traders and retail buyers experiencing a seven-year peak. The precious metal has risen to a December 2012 peak of $1,703.39 per ounce, with some companies encountering logistical issues meeting the rapid growth in demand due to flight cancellations and lockdowns. Industry experts argue there is no shortage of gold, but the situation is becoming more complex, with refineries temporarily halted in Switzerland and South Africa imposing a lockdown.

site_title: DBS postpones AGM
summary: DBS Group has postponed its annual general meeting (AGM) due to the novel coronavirus outbreak, deferring it from March 31 to an unspecified date. The government has imposed stricter measures to enforce safe-distancing in social settings, and legislative amendments are being proposed to allow listed companies to hold meetings solely by virtual means. DBS apologizes to shareholders for the inconvenience and will update them on the new date and procedures after the amendments are passed and necessary arrangements are made.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens down more than 3%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 3.13% or 611.27 points to 18,935.36, while the Topix index dropped 2.64% or 37.61 points. The decline occurred amid profit-taking following recent surges, despite US stimulus plans offsetting concerns over the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened down more than three per cent on Thursday on profit-taking after surging in recent sessions although US stimulus plans offset worries over the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Japan to set up coronavirus headquarters, possible step to emergency declaration: media
summary: The Japanese government is preparing to set up a coronavirus headquarters, potentially leading to a state of emergency declaration due to the rapid spread of the virus in Tokyo. Under a revised law, the prime minister can declare a state of emergency if the virus poses a "grave danger" to lives and the economy. If declared, governors in affected regions would need to take measures such as lockdowns and event cancellations to slow the spread. This move comes as Japan's recession risk increases due to the outbreak.

site_title: Fake cures, risky rumours: coronavirus misinformation hits home
summary: Misinformation about the coronavirus has led to devastating real-world impacts, including people taking poisonous "cures" and avoiding life-saving medication. Fake cures such as volcanic ash, UV lamps, and colloidal silver have been debunked by health authorities, while others, like cocaine and bleach-like solutions, have also been touted online. The rapid spread of misinformation has also led to confusion over heart medication and has prompted health authorities to advise patients to continue taking their prescribed drugs. The effects of misinformation have been particularly severe in Iran, where over 210 people died from drinking toxic alcohol after false claims circulated online.

site_title: ARA to grow property credit platform with majority stake in Europe's Venn Partners
summary: ARA Asset Management has acquired a majority stake in Venn Partners, a European real estate private debt investment manager. The acquisition, via a joint venture, will provide ARA with a presence in European real estate credit markets. ARA will provide cornerstone capital and working capital to drive the joint venture's expansion. Founded in 2009, Venn Partners has over £5 billion in assets under management and will expand its investment management business in the UK, Europe, and other geographies.

site_title: US joblessness set to spike as virus takes toll on businesses
summary: US joblessness is expected to surge amid the coronavirus pandemic, with economists warning of a record explosion of Americans filing for unemployment benefits. The Labor Department's weekly data for the week ending March 21 is set to show a significant increase, with predictions ranging from 1.5 to 3.5 million claims. The US economy is projected to contract by 14% due to the shutdown, with unemployment potentially rising to 15% later this year. A massive $2 trillion rescue package has been passed to mitigate the economic impact, including a $600 weekly expansion of unemployment insurance.

images.alt_text: With streets in major cities barren, and shops and restaurants forced to close due to the coronavirus pandemic, economists warn of a record explosion of Americans filing for unemployment benefits.

site_title: Coronavirus could become seasonal: top US scientist
summary: A US scientist, Anthony Fauci, suggests the new coronavirus could return in seasonal cycles, citing cases appearing in southern Africa and the southern hemisphere as winter approaches. This underscores the need for a vaccine and effective treatments. Currently, two vaccines are in human trials, with deployment possible within a year to a year-and-a-half. Treatments, including antimalarial drugs, are also being investigated. Fauci emphasizes the need to be prepared for another cycle, following a recent Chinese research paper that reached similar conclusions, citing colder weather allowing respiratory droplets to remain airborne and weakening immunity.

site_title: Airbnb says US coronavirus stimulus bill could offer its hosts some relief
summary: Airbnb announced that US hosts could receive relief from the $2 trillion coronavirus stimulus bill, which includes temporary unemployment benefits for self-employed and gig workers. The bill aims to alleviate the economic impact of the pandemic on the travel industry, which has been severely affected by government restrictions. With over 450,000 infected and 21,000 deaths worldwide, the stimulus bill is a crucial measure to support the US economy.

site_title: SoftBank's big bet on sharing economy backfires with coronavirus
summary: SoftBank's big bet on the sharing economy is backfiring due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Japanese conglomerate's portfolio companies, including WeWork, Uber, and Didi Chuxing, are struggling with declining revenues and reduced demand for shared services. SoftBank's Vision Fund, which has invested $100 billion, is under pressure, and investors are concerned about the company's debt and the potential for massive writedowns. SoftBank's CEO, Masayoshi Son, may be forced to step in to support his startups, which could tarnish his reputation as a tech investor.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, SATS, ComfortDelGro, OUE, OUE C-Reit, Bonvests
summary: Wilmar International established four new subsidiaries and acquired one in China, with shares closing up 7.9% to S$3.26. SATS offered S$200 million in 5-year notes with a 2.88% coupon rate, shares closing up 13.2% to S$3.09.

site_title: Amazon pauses sellers' loan repayments amid coronavirus
summary: Amazon has temporarily paused loan repayments for its sellers, allowing them to avoid repaying sums between $1,000 and $750,000. The pause, which began on March 26 and will last until April 30, includes interest, and repayments will resume on May 1. This move aims to provide relief to sellers struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has led to declining sales and reduced fulfillment services.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc on Wednesday said it temporarily would not require sellers in its marketplace to repay loans it had made to them, as merchants confront the prospect of declining sales during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Airlines turn to cargo for revenue as US Senate nears industry aid vote
summary: Airlines are turning to cargo services to boost revenue amid the coronavirus pandemic. Delta Air Lines and Air New Zealand plan to offer cargo charter services on passenger planes. The US Senate is set to vote on a $58 billion industry aid bill, which includes payroll support. The passenger travel industry has been severely impacted, with Flight Centre Travel Group announcing 6,000 job cuts and Singapore Airlines grounding its entire fleet. Airlines are exploring alternative revenue streams to mitigate losses.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia proposes to buy A$3b in govt bonds as part of QE
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia proposed buying A$3 billion in government bonds as part of its quantitative easing program to keep short-term yields around 0.25%. The purchase will be made between May 2021 and April 2024. This is part of the central bank's A$15 billion government securities purchase program launched on March 20.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) on Thursday proposed to buy A$3 billion (S$2.6 billion) in sovereign government bonds as part of its quantitative easing programme to keep short-term yields around the cash rate of 0.25 per cent.

site_title: US warship sails through Taiwan Strait amid heightened China tensions
summary: A US warship, the USS McCampbell, sailed through the Taiwan Strait on March 25, amid heightened tensions between China and Taiwan. The ship's transit was described as an "ordinary mission" by the US and Taiwan militaries, with no cause for alarm. The move comes after China's air force carried out exercises close to Taiwan, prompting Taiwan to scramble fighters. The US has no official relations with Taiwan but is its main international supporter and arms supplier, and has committed to a free and open Indo-Pacific.

site_title: Tales from the crypt: Washington cathedral digs up 5,000 respirator masks
summary: The Washington National Cathedral unearthed 5,000 respirator masks in its crypt, purchased over a decade ago for clergy use during health scares. The masks were meant to prevent clergy from contracting illnesses while providing pastoral care. After verifying their safety, 3,000 masks were donated to Georgetown University Hospital and 2,000 to Children's National Hospital, with a few reserved for cathedral clergy.

site_title: IOC working toward July-August Olympics in 2021: Yomiuri
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is working with sports bodies to arrange a July-August window for the postponed Tokyo Olympics in 2021. IOC chief John Coates hopes to confirm the schedule within a month. The Games would avoid clashes with the world championships for swimming and athletics, and follow the same arrangements planned for 2020, including holding the marathon in Sapporo. This decision comes after intense pressure from athletes and sporting bodies due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the IOC agreeing to push back the Games by up to a year.

site_title: France withdraws troops from Iraq over coronavirus
summary: France has withdrawn its 200 military personnel from Iraq due to the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made in coordination with the Iraqi government and involves a provisional suspension of training activities. This move follows a broader adjustment of coalition deployments in Iraq.

site_title: Moody's forecasts recession for G-20 countries in 2020
summary: Moody's forecasts a recession for G-20 countries in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, predicting a 0.5% contraction in global GDP. The US economy is expected to shrink by 2%, while the eurozone is forecast to contract by 2.2%. China, however, is expected to see an economic expansion of 3.3% despite its initial outbreak.

site_title: Spain overtakes China with 3,434 virus deaths
summary: Spain's coronavirus death toll surpassed China's, reaching 3,434, with 738 new fatalities reported. The country is struggling with a lack of medical supplies, and the government has secured a €432 million deal with China to cover 550 million masks, 5.5 million rapid test kits, and other essential items. Despite a national lockdown, deaths and infections continue to rise, with officials warning that the peak may be approaching.

site_title: UK Parliament shuts early over coronavirus
summary: The UK Parliament shut down early due to the coronavirus outbreak, with MPs sent home a week early for their Easter break. The decision was made to align with the nationwide shutdown of non-essential shops and services, and the government's order for people to stay at home. The House of Commons will reconvene on April 21, 2020.

site_title: Detected coronavirus cases top 450,000 worldwide: AFP tally
summary: More than 450,000 new coronavirus cases have been reported worldwide, with at least 20,647 deaths, according to a tally by AFP. Cases are concentrated in China and Italy, with 81,218 and 74,386 reported respectively. The US has surpassed China as the country with the most reported cases.

site_title: Oil prices slip as US stimulus vote delayed
summary: US oil prices slipped 1.5% and 0.4% for West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude, respectively, in Asian trade on Thursday, following a delayed Senate vote on a $2 trillion stimulus package to combat the coronavirus-ravaged US economy. The earlier rally in oil prices was due to the agreement on the massive stimulus package, which would be the largest ever rescue in the US. The delay in the vote led to a bearish outlook on US oil prices.

site_title: Britons answer call for volunteer coronavirus force
summary: The British government's call for volunteers to help those stuck at home due to the coronavirus outbreak has been met with a response of over 405,000 people, exceeding the initial target of 250,000. This effort aims to support the most vulnerable individuals, including those with underlying health conditions, by delivering groceries and medicines. The initiative, part of the NHS Volunteers scheme, is larger than Britain's armed forces and will provide a vital lifeline to those in need.

site_title: Apocalypse delayed? 'Walking Dead' finale postponed by virus
summary: The Walking Dead series finale has been postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic. The show's Season 10 finale, originally set to air on April 5, will now end with its 15th episode on the same date. The planned finale will appear as a special episode later in the year, as production was unable to complete post-production. The show's delay is seen as ironic, given its post-apocalyptic theme and the current global lockdowns caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Three billion under lockdown as UN warns virus threatens humanity
summary: The UN warned that Covid-19 is threatening humanity, with over 3 billion people under lockdown to stem its spread. The global death toll surpassed 20,000, with Spain and Italy reporting a surge in fatalities. The UN Secretary General launched an appeal for $2 billion to help the world's poor, emphasizing the need for global action and solidarity. Markets rebounded after the US pledged $2 trillion in stimulus, while India, Russia, and other countries imposed strict measures to contain the virus, with over 130 million Americans under lockdown.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks rally for second straight day
summary: Brazil's Sao Paulo stock exchange surged 7.5% on Wednesday, marking the second straight day of gains, as stimulus package plans boosted world markets. The Ibovespa index has been pummeled by the coronavirus pandemic, but recent gains are the first back-to-back increases this month.

site_title: Canada makes 14-day self-isolation mandatory for travellers
summary: Canada has implemented a 14-day mandatory self-isolation period for travellers returning home to curb the spread of COVID-19. The measure, enforced under the Quarantine Act, carries fines of up to C$1 million or up to three years in jail for non-compliance. The new guideline comes after reports of travellers ignoring previous self-isolation recommendations. The first person in Canada to be arrested for violating the order was a 53-year-old woman in Newfoundland, who faces a possible fine and up to six months in prison.

site_title: Massive US economic rescue plan is only the start, experts say
summary: The US Congress is set to pass a massive $2 trillion economic rescue plan to combat the coronavirus pandemic's economic damage. The bill includes cash payments to most Americans, expanded unemployment insurance, and loans to small businesses. However, experts warn that this is only the first step, and more measures may be needed to get the economy running again, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell acknowledging the potential limitations of the plan.

site_title: Bangladesh seeks Singapore investments
summary: Bangladesh is seeking investments from Singapore, citing the country's growing middle class and improving economic conditions. A business delegation from Singapore visited Bangladesh last August to explore investment opportunities, with potential areas including infrastructure development, electronics, and real estate. High Commissioner Md Mustafizur Rahman sees growth potential in the manpower sector, particularly in education and healthcare, where Singapore's high standard of education could attract Bangladeshi students. Despite a trade imbalance, Rahman believes the two countries can find ways to narrow it, and Bangladesh is eager to learn from Singapore's development model and strengthen bilateral ties.

site_title: Kosovo government toppled by no-confidence vote
summary: Kosovo's government was toppled by a no-confidence vote in the 120-member assembly, with 82 MPs voting in favor of the motion. The parliament speaker, Vjosa Osmani, confirmed the result after nearly 12 hours of debate. The vote occurred as the country tries to halt the spread of coronavirus, plunging Kosovo into political uncertainty. The outcome leaves the country without a clear leader as it faces the ongoing health crisis and economic challenges.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 close higher on stimulus hopes, Nasdaq down
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.4% to 21,200.55, and the S&P 500 gaining 1.2% to 2,475.56, amid expectations of government stimulus to combat the coronavirus outbreak. The Nasdaq slipped 0.5% to 7,384.30. A US$2 trillion economic rescue package was announced, but lawmakers still had not voted on the proposal. Key tech stocks fell, but Boeing rallied 24.3% after reports of US$17 billion loans.

site_title: BOS urges leveraged clients to sell in rallies
summary: Bank of Singapore CEO Bahren Shaari advises leveraged clients to sell during market rallies due to the ongoing coronavirus-fuelled crisis, which he believes has yet to peak. Clients should offload unwanted investments during rebounds, as the crisis is only beginning to show its effects. Despite a 15% increase in assets under management to $117 billion last year, hiring is not a priority, with a focus on protecting jobs.

site_title: New York governor says social distancing slowing coronavirus
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo reported that social distancing measures are slowing the spread of the coronavirus in the state. Hospitalizations are increasing at a slower rate, with projections suggesting a doubling time of 4.7 days, down from 2 days previously. Despite still being on the "way up the mountain" with peak cases expected in 21 days, Cuomo assured residents that medical supplies will last more than a fortnight. He called on President Trump to deploy equipment to New York and other affected states.

images.alt_text: Social distancing appears to be slowing the spread of the coronavirus in New York, the epicentre of America's pandemic, Governor Andrew Cuomo said on Wednesday.

site_title: IMF sees a recession at least as bad as global financial crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) expects a global recession this year, with a contraction of at least 1.5% and advanced economies shrinking 3.3%, comparable to the severity of the 2008 financial crisis. Nearly 80 countries have requested emergency finance, and the IMF supports extraordinary fiscal actions and easing moves by central banks to mitigate the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The fund emphasizes the need for containment and strengthening of health systems to facilitate a stronger recovery next year.

site_title: Covid-19 fight at 'critical phase'; suspension of all schools may be next
summary: Singapore is at a critical phase in its fight against COVID-19, with National Development Minister Lawrence Wong signaling the possibility of introducing more drastic measures, including the closure of schools and some workplaces if the number of infected cases continues to rise. Wong emphasized the need to prioritize public health, save lives, and slow the virus before managing economic consequences. The country's task force will assess the situation and take necessary actions to mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Election cannot be delayed unless state of emergency is called: Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean stated that delaying the Singapore General Election beyond April 2021 would be unconstitutional and only possible if a state of emergency is declared. He also emphasized that calling a state of emergency is not a light decision and that a caretaker government would not have the mandate to mobilize resources. The government is weighing the option of holding the election early or later to give the new government a clear and fresh mandate to address the Covid-19 crisis.

images.alt_text: It would be unconstitutional to delay holding the General Election beyond the April 2021 deadline as such a delay can only take place if a state of emergency is called, Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean said in Parliament on Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares end whipsaw session higher as stimulus hopes persist
summary: European stocks ended a tumultuous session higher, closing up 3.1% as investors bet on further stimulus measures to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Despite a 28% decline from its February record high, the Stoxx 600 index gained ground due to cheap valuations in the energy and travel sectors. However, concerns about the economic situation, including high coronavirus death tolls in Italy and Spain, and lockdowns in major economies, persist. Anticipation of a US$2 trillion fiscal stimulus package and regional governments' measures to dull the economic shock also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Stocks jump as US settles on US$2t in aid
summary: US lawmakers agree on a stimulus package worth up to $2 trillion, boosting global markets, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) registering its first three-week gains. The STI rose 6.1% to 2,505.47, with Asian equity benchmarks also experiencing strong gains. Despite optimism, strategists remain cautious due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and rising cases.

site_title: US new home sales fall in Feb - could decline further on Covid-19
summary: US new home sales dropped 4.4% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 765,000 units, following a surge in January. The decline is attributed to the novel coronavirus pandemic, which is boosting unemployment and disrupting economic activity. Economists predict further decline, with a nearly 10% drop in the second quarter, due to severe job losses and damage to household confidence.

site_title: Insurers get reprieve as Olympics gets delayed, not canned
summary: The Tokyo Olympics have been postponed to 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, providing insurers with a reprieve from potential losses. Insured costs are estimated at US$2 billion, including TV rights and sponsorship, and US$600 million for hospitality. Insurance industry sources suggest that insurers may only need to pay out a fraction of this amount, as some policies may cover postponement and companies can still make money from the Olympics when it takes place. The International Olympic Committee and local organisers may look to recoup some money from insurers for the delay.

site_title: Pompeo attacks Chinese virus campaign at G-7 as Europeans seek cooperation
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic during a G-7 videoconference, labeling it a "disinformation campaign" aimed at deflecting blame. Pompeo claimed China has spread conspiracy theories about US involvement, but European allies emphasized cooperation to combat the global pandemic. France and Germany issued statements calling for global unity, while Pompeo acknowledged the need for cooperation, including with China, ahead of a virtual summit with the Group of 20.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday that the Group of Seven powers were united in opposing China's coronavirus "disinformation," but European allies emphasised cooperation to fight the global pandemic.

site_title: Companies scramble to rework AGM plans on 10-person limit
summary: Companies in Singapore are scrambling to rework their annual general meeting (AGM) plans due to the government's limit of 10 persons per gathering amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. DBS Group Holdings, Centurion Corp, and United Overseas Bank have adjusted their arrangements, with some opting for live webcasts instead of in-person meetings. Regulatory bodies, including the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), are working to propose legislative amendments to abide by safe distancing rules. Companies are urged to provide remote participation options and follow safe distancing guidelines.

images.alt_text: Companies have been caught flat-footed by the government's latest limit on gathering size, in particular those that have already arranged for physical annual general meetings (AGMs) in the near future.

site_title: Oil prices settle higher on stimulus package, fuel demand sinks
summary: US crude oil prices rose 2% to $24.49 a barrel, bolstered by a potential $2 trillion stimulus package, despite a sharp decline in fuel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. Demand for oil products fell 2.1 million barrels per day last week, with the US weekly petrol product supplied dropping 859,000 barrels per day. The outlook for the energy sector has turned "extremely pessimistic," with capital expenditures expected to drop by at least 30% and oil inventories expected to keep growing.

site_title: Farewell parties: Club operators told to ensure safe distancing measures
summary: Singapore authorities are cracking down on nightlife venues planning "farewell" parties despite the government's ban on all bars and entertainment venues until April 30 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Singapore Police Force, Singapore Tourism Board, and Enterprise Singapore will deploy enforcement operations over the next two days. The measures aim to reduce the risk of seeding new local coronavirus clusters. Operators are reminded to ensure safe distancing measures to avoid fines.

site_title: Singapore, partners pledge to keep essential trade moving
summary: Singapore and six other regional economies have pledged to maintain air, sea, and other trade flows during the Covid-19 pandemic, ensuring the supply of essential goods like food and medical supplies. The pact aims to avoid export controls and restrictions on shipments of essential goods, with Singapore working with partners to facilitate the flow of these goods. The move aims to support the global economy and prevent disruptions to global supplies of essential goods.

site_title: Covid-19 aid: Banks should put moratoriums on table
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is urging banks to implement moratoriums on loan repayments to ease financial burdens on customers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Banks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB have already introduced relief measures, but MAS suggests more prescriptive guidelines would help alleviate anxiety and free up resources for banks to provide support. Automatic moratoriums on loans and payments could provide relief, but banks must also ensure sound credit decisions and provide workout plans for customers to repay loans after the moratorium period.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Interview with Josephine Teo, Minister for Manpower
summary: Singapore's Minister for Manpower, Josephine Teo, discussed measures in the 2020 budget to support companies affected by COVID-19. The interview on Money FM's Prime Time podcast touched on the government's efforts to mitigate the economic impact. Teo emphasized the importance of adaptability and innovation in the workforce. She also highlighted the need for companies to upskill their employees to stay competitive. The conversation aimed to provide insights into how the government's initiatives can help businesses navigate the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Chinese students pay thousands of yuan for seats on private jet to flee virus-hit US
summary: Chinese students from wealthy families are paying tens of thousands of dollars for seats on private jets to return home to China due to the US coronavirus outbreak, with some flights costing up to 2.3 million yuan. The alternative, 60-hour flights with multiple transit hops, is not feasible. Private charter companies are filling the demand, but prices are rising due to limited availability. The US has banned chartered flights from overseas, and China is expected to follow suit, further increasing costs.

site_title: Bonvests revokes proposed dividends, implements pay cut to sustain operations
summary: Bonvests Holdings has revoked its proposed dividend of one Singapore cent per share due to the negative impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its business. The company has also implemented pay cuts of 10-50% for staff and a 10% reduction in directors' fees to conserve cash resources. These measures aim to sustain business operations and ensure the viability of the group until the pandemic improves. The company expects rental division, financial results, and cash resources to be affected by the prolonged virus outbreak.

site_title: Digital robo-adviser Smartly throws in towel
summary: Smartly, a Singapore-based digital robo-adviser, will cease operations after fewer than three years in business due to intense competition. The firm cited "challenging" conditions and a decision not aligned with its parent company's strategic objectives. Smartly will return client funds within 3-6 business days and offer clients 50% off management fees for six months if they transition to rival StashAway. The move follows market volatility and the launch of new robo-advisory services by major banks.

site_title: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square takes off Covid-19 hedges
summary: Veteran investor Bill Ackman has removed credit market hedges and reinvested $2.6 billion in his fund, Pershing Square Holdings, as he becomes increasingly positive on the stock and credit markets. Ackman initially took out the hedges in March due to the novel coronavirus, but market falls and government support have made him more optimistic. He has redeployed the funds in existing holdings and new acquisitions, maintaining a 17% cash position. Ackman warns that markets will remain volatile, potentially leading to portfolio turnover and re-establishing hedges.

images.alt_text: Mr Ackman, in a note of caution, says he expects markets and the firm's performance to remain volatile.

site_title: NTUC to support freelancers with S$4m training allowance fund
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has set aside S$4 million to support freelancers with higher training allowances during the coronavirus outbreak. The fund will enable union members to claim higher training allowances to defray the opportunity cost of going for courses. Eligible courses include SkillsFuture Series programmes and sector-specific courses, with no cap on the number of courses freelancers can attend. The training allowance will be given out after completion of the programmes, and freelancers who joined the union before March 2020 will receive S$8.50 per hour, while those who joined after will receive S$8 per hour.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Procurri Corporation's US subsidiary rejected a demand for indemnification of US$474,317 from the sellers of a stake in its US joint-venture, Rockland Congruity. Fortress Minerals and UMS Holdings in Malaysia suspended operations due to Malaysia's movement control order. ARA US Hospitality Trust initiated cost controls, and Geo Energy Resources' ratings were downgraded by Fitch due to weak operating profile and liquidity issues. Chaswood Resources Holdings and Aspen (Group) Holdings also implemented measures to cope with the order, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed.

site_title: Hubei eases coronavirus curbs; new imported cases decline
summary: China's Hubei province has eased coronavirus curbs, lifting traffic controls and resuming construction work, after two months of lockdown. The province reported no locally transmitted infections, while mainland China saw a decline in new cases, with 47 reported on Tuesday, all from travelers returning home. The lockdown in Wuhan will be lifted on April 8, and China is strengthening quarantine and screening rules for international arrivals to prevent a surge in imported cases.

site_title: US$ slips on stimulus plan, riskier currencies' gain
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% against a basket of currencies after the US Senate agreed on a $2 trillion stimulus package to shield the US economy from the pandemic. Riskier currencies, such as the Australian dollar and Norwegian crown, rallied, while the British pound also gained around 1%. The euro rose 0.3% against the dollar, and sterling was up from recent lows. Investors, fearful of the pandemic, had previously liquidated dollars for safer currencies. The stimulus package steadied money market nerves and prompted investors to buy back into riskier currencies.

site_title: Softbank's Son still betting on himself
summary: Japanese billionaire Masayoshi Son, founder of SoftBank, is continuing to bet on himself despite considering a leveraged buyout. His stake in the company has risen to 26.9% and he has pledged 216.9 million shares worth $7.4 billion to lenders. Son has also loaned 30 million shares to his holding company, GungHo Online Entertainment, whose shares have dropped 35% this year. The move is rare due to the stock market rout and high-risk loans.

site_title: Playwright Terrence McNally dies from Covid-19 complications
summary: Playwright Terrence McNally, a four-time Tony Award winner, died on Tuesday in Sarasota, Florida, at 81 due to complications from COVID-19. Born on November 3, 1938, McNally was a prolific dramatist with over three dozen plays to his credit, including works like "Love! Valour! Compassion!" and "Master Class." His career spanned five decades, with notable successes on Broadway and off-Broadway, and he was known for introducing mainstream audiences to gay characters and situations. McNally received a Tony Award for lifetime achievement in 2019.

images.alt_text: The cause of his death was complications of the coronavirus. McNally, 81, had chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder and had overcome lung cancer.

site_title: How to monitor a US$2 trillion rescue package
summary: The US government is on the verge of issuing a $2 trillion rescue package, equivalent to $5,500 per American. To ensure transparency and accountability, the use of blockchain technology can be integrated into the process. A blockchain-based system can track transactions, provide tamper-resistant records, and enable anyone to see where the funds are being disbursed. This system would allow for real-time monitoring and oversight, potentially saving millions in wasted expenditure and restoring confidence in government. The use of blockchain technology could also serve as a model for future government expenditure, ensuring the best use of funds in responding to the COVID-19 crisis.

site_title: What's a bar? New containment measures spark confusion among operators
summary: Singapore's authorities have announced tightened safe-distancing measures, mandating the closure of bars and entertainment venues with high risk of transmission until April 30. However, confusion has arisen among food and beverage establishments, with some unclear whether they are bars or not, given their multi-concept venues. Many operators have expressed uncertainty, with some claiming they can remain open due to restaurant licenses. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will study the matter to clarify the affected establishments.

site_title: White House, senators strike deal on stimulus package of over US$2 trillion
summary: The US Senate has agreed on a historic $2 trillion stimulus package with the Trump administration, Senate Democrats, and Republicans to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The package includes $500 billion for loans and assistance to companies, $350 billion for small businesses, $150 billion for hospitals, and direct payments to lower- and middle-income Americans of $1,200 per adult and $500 per child. The legislation also includes restrictions on corporate loans and executive bonuses, and bars businesses owned by President Trump or his family from receiving loans. The Senate is set to vote on the bill on Wednesday, with the House to follow.

site_title: Only multilateralism can help world overcome global crisis
summary: The global economy was already vulnerable to a recession before the coronavirus pandemic, and the stock market's crash has made a recession nearly inevitable. Unlike past crises, the international community's rapid multilateral response has been hindered by US President Donald Trump's disdain for cooperation, which has led to a global response to the Covid-19 crisis failing to materialize.

site_title: Icelanders skip hot springs for ice baths
summary: In south-western Iceland, a group of 15 participants, mostly from Reykjavik, take part in an unusual ice bath therapy, inspired by the Wim Hof Method. The cold water, at -6°C, is said to melt away stress and fatigue. Participants, equipped with breathing exercises and meditation, immerse themselves in the icy waters for two minutes, followed by a challenging walk back to dry land. While some scientists question the effectiveness of cold therapy, participants swear by its benefits, with one saying it "completely changed" his life.

site_title: Thai central bank cuts GDP forecast, holds rates
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) cut its 2020 GDP forecast to minus 5.3% due to the severe impact of the coronavirus pandemic on Thailand's economy. The central bank kept its one-day repurchase rate steady at 0.75%, despite cutting it last week. Economists predict further policy rate cuts and a deflation spiral, with some forecasting a rate of 0.25% by end-2020. The BOT also slashed its export forecast to an 8.8% drop and predicted a 60% decline in foreign tourist numbers to 15 million this year.

site_title: The G-20 will have its pandemic moment
summary: G20 leaders will convene virtually to discuss the Covid-19 crisis, with a focus on creating a collective response to the global pandemic. The meeting may also address the looming bacterial threat, as the crisis has accelerated the use of disinfectants. Policymakers are urged to create a market incentive reward programme for pharmaceutical companies to develop new drugs, and to invest around $10 billion in diagnostics, treatments, and vaccine development. A similar approach to the 2009 London summit, which created a framework for a coordinated multilateral response to the global financial crisis, is needed to prevent a deeper economic crisis and social strife.

site_title: China buys record volume of Russian oil as European demand dives
summary: China is purchasing a record 1.6 million tonnes of Russian oil for loading at sea over the next four weeks, taking advantage of low prices due to a collapse in European demand. This marks a new monthly record for Urals supply to China, providing a lifeline to Russian firms struggling to sell oil in Europe. The deliveries could indicate China is using the collapse in oil prices to fill its strategic reserves, which are expected to reach 1.15 billion barrels in 2020.

site_title: Brian Koo may withdraw lifeline for honestbee
summary: honestbee, a Singaporean startup, may lose its white knight, LG scion Brian Koo, due to delayed funds from his venture firm Formation Group and FLK Holdings. Honestbee is seeking a court adjournment to clarify the position and potentially seek new investors amid the worsening Covid-19 pandemic. The startup is also investigating allegations of breached fiduciary duties against former directors Jeffrey Wong and Joel Sng, who deny the claims. Honestbee's proposed scheme of arrangement to repay creditors could be impacted by FLK's potential withdrawal.

site_title: Meet the architect behind the Founders' Memorial
summary: Kengo Kuma, a renowned Japanese architect, is featured in a Weekend magazine issue. Born as a 10-year-old, he was inspired by Kenzo Tange's Yoyogi National Gymnasium design. Kuma's career spans over 30 years, with notable projects including the Founders' Memorial in Singapore, emphasizing natural materials and sustainability. He currently leads a team of 300 staff and has over 600 built works worldwide, including the New National Stadium for the postponed Tokyo Olympics 2020. Kuma continues to think outside the box with innovative designs.

site_title: Looking to the supplementary budget for a lifeline in the storm
summary: Singapore's supplementary budget, introduced amid the global Covid-19 crisis, aims to provide a lifeline to the economy. The budget, announced by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, may include more sweeping measures to support industries and households, despite the government's prudence. The uncertainty surrounding the virus's spread and the economy's future recovery pose challenges, with the possibility of a fundamental shift in support provision. The government may opt for a series of lifeboats, introducing new measures as needed, but the duration of the crisis remains uncertain.

site_title: UBS reviewing 'buy' call on EHT default event; stock suspended
summary: UBS has placed its "buy" rating on Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) under review due to the US-based hotel trust's loan default. EHT was served with a notice of default after its master lessees failed to pay rent, despite the trust meeting its debt obligations. The default triggered a voluntary trading suspension and may impact the trust's ability to realize asset value, with UBS estimating a 61.5% decline could wipe out unit holders' equity. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the decline of the hospitality market, with US hotel occupancy falling 24.4 percentage points year-on-year.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit completes purchase of German properties, sells 12 other assets
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has completed two deals: acquiring three German light industrial/logistics properties for about 40.9 million euros and selling 12 European assets to The Blackstone Group for 65.7 million euros. The German portfolio will be leased to Felss Group for 15 years, while the sold assets include properties in France, Denmark, and the Netherlands. The Reit's portfolio now comprises 94 properties valued at 2.08 billion euros, with its debt position unchanged and gearing ratio below 45%.

site_title: Tourism goes virtual in coronavirus-confined California
summary: California's tourism sector is severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic, with many businesses forced to shut down or adapt to virtual tours. Guided tours, such as those offered by Adam Duford in Santa Monica, have transitioned to live broadcasts on social networks, allowing for revenue despite the physical closures. The state's tourism industry, worth over $145 billion last year, is forecast to decline, with many businesses laying off employees and struggling to survive the lockdown. Virtual tours are becoming a lifeline for businesses, providing a way to reach customers while social distancing measures remain in place.

site_title: Chaswood Resources continues to run Malaysian restaurant business
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings, a CATALIST-listed food and beverage operator, will continue to operate its Malaysian restaurant business through takeaway and delivery services under Malaysia's movement control order. The limited operations may impact its financials for the 2020 financial year and earnings per share. The company will monitor the situation and make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Singapore's strategy can help preserve healthcare capacity: Gan
summary: Singapore's strategy to flatten the curve of COVID-19 cases may prolong the pandemic, but it will help preserve healthcare capacity to care for more severe cases, said Health Minister Gan Kim Yong. Two possible scenarios have been established: one with a sharp peak and the other with a long tail. This approach prioritizes reducing hospitalizations and intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, allowing for better management of severe cases. The strategy aims to balance the risk of prolonged transmission with the need to protect healthcare capacity.

site_title: All travellers arriving in Singapore to receive Stay-Home Notice requirements in advance
summary: Singapore requires all travellers, including citizens, permanent residents, and Long-Term Pass holders, to submit a health declaration before immigration clearance. Starting March 27, travellers will receive an electronic notification via email regarding a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) on arrival. They must present the acknowledgement email to ICA officers upon arrival. Failure to comply may result in fines of up to S$10,000 or six months imprisonment, and pass holders may risk having their passes revoked.

site_title: Olympics delay leaves Athletes' Village in limbo
summary: The Tokyo Olympics' postponement has left the Athletes' Village in limbo, with hundreds of luxury apartments sold and developers facing a double whammy of falling prices and buyers pulling out of contracts. The apartments, originally intended for competitors, were to be converted into over 4,000 condos with city views, priced at 170 million yen (S$2.2 million). This has caused headaches for developers, who are now struggling to find buyers and manage the financial risks associated with the delayed project.

site_title: Saudi seals off three cities after second virus death
summary: Saudi Arabia has sealed off its capital Riyadh and two holiest cities, Mecca and Medina, after reporting its second death from the coronavirus. The kingdom has extended curfew hours to 3 pm, restricting movement between provinces. Authorities have barred entry and exit from these cities and plan to implement a 21-day curfew. The health ministry reported 900 infections, with a resident of Mecca confirmed as the second fatality. The kingdom has also closed cinemas, malls, and restaurants, and suspended the umrah pilgrimage, amid efforts to contain the virus.

site_title: SATS to issue S$200m in notes due 2025
summary: SATS announced plans to issue S$200 million in five-year notes with a fixed coupon rate of 2.88% per annum, maturing in 2025. The notes will be used for refinancing existing borrowings and general corporate purposes. DBS Bank and UOB have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners. The issuance is under SATS' S$500 million multi-currency debt-issuance program. The company's shares closed up 13.2% to S$3.09 on the news.

site_title: Thousands stuck on cruise ships off Australia over virus fears
summary: Thousands of passengers on three cruise ships were stranded off Australia's west coast due to COVID-19 fears, with officials refusing to let them land to avoid a repeat of a previous surge. The Artania and Magnifica were anchored off Fremantle with over 1,700 passengers on board, while the Vasco de Gama was en route with 800 passengers, including 150 international travelers. Passengers would face quarantine restrictions, with some being allowed to disembark under strict supervision to the airport or for urgent medical attention.

site_title: Telework is not business as usual for telcos
summary: Singapore's telcos, M1, StarHub, and Singtel, have seen a surge in demand for business continuity products, including virtual meeting tools, as companies adopt remote work arrangements to combat the spread of Covid-19. However, analysts expect no significant impact on telcos' financials in the near term. To attract SMEs, telcos are offering discounted or free services, such as call-forwarding app subscriptions and virtual meeting software subscriptions. Despite pockets of growth, the overall enterprise market is unlikely to benefit, with a slowdown in IT projects and deteriorating business sentiment potentially affecting enterprise revenues.

site_title: Competition, tough times beginning to separate MVNO winners from losers
summary: Competition among Singapore's mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) is intensifying, with several struggling financially. Circles.Life, a loss-making MVNO, has laid off staff, mainly in its international markets. Zero Mobile, which suspended services in 2019, was recently blacklisted by the regulator for possible consumer protection breaches. The struggles highlight the challenges faced by MVNOs in the competitive Singaporean market, where major players like M1, Singtel, and StarHub dominate.

site_title: Coronavirus: 73 new coronavirus cases in Singapore; 18 cases from new cluster
summary: Singapore reported 73 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 631, with 38 imported and 27 linked to clusters or previous cases. Two new clusters were identified, including a pre-school cluster with 14 staff and four family members. The government has announced strict measures, including closing entertainment outlets, limiting gatherings, and suspending tuition classes, to combat the spread of the virus.

site_title: Aspen's business operations in Malaysia remain closed
summary: Aspen Group Holdings in Malaysia has closed its headquarters, offices, and sales galleries until April 14 due to the movement control order. Construction works for ongoing projects have also been halted. Employees will continue to work from home, and operations will resume once the order is lifted, subject to government directives. The pandemic is expected to impair the group's earnings capacity for the next 12 months, but it does not anticipate a material financial impact on its earnings per share and net asset value.

site_title: Bangladesh honours its founding father
summary: Bangladesh is celebrating the 100th birth anniversary of its founding father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, also known as Bangabandhu, on the occasion of the 49th anniversary of independence and national day. Bangabandhu led the country's independence movement and was its first Prime Minister. He is widely regarded as the greatest Bengali of all time, known for his courage, charisma, and commitment to justice and human rights. His legacy continues to shape the country's development, and he is remembered for his remarkable political career, which included a non-violent non-cooperation movement and the formulation of national policies.

site_title: Economic stimulus is the wrong solution for now
summary: The US Senate and White House have agreed to infuse $2 trillion into the economy to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. However, economists argue that stimulating the economy is the wrong approach, as it may exacerbate the spread of the virus. Instead, the government should provide liquidity to allow businesses and individuals to survive the economic shock, slowing down the economy to prevent further spread. This approach prioritizes worker and business survival over immediate economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Fed should be prepared to make loans readily available to efficient businesses that, because of the crisis, may close their doors permanently.

site_title: Delayed Olympics risks turning into colossal advertising bust
summary: The 2020 Tokyo Olympics have been delayed by up to a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, causing uncertainty for hundreds of companies worldwide that rely on the event for massive advertising and promotional opportunities. Local Japanese sponsors, including major brands like Asahi beer and Asics sneakers, are facing significant financial risks, with some potentially pulling out or no longer operating. Global Olympic partners, such as Coca-Cola and Visa, are also affected, with long-term deals spanning multiple Olympic cycles. The delay may impact hospitality, product launches, and sponsorship deals, but could also provide a better return on advertising investments due to reduced global lockdowns.

site_title: US durable goods orders increase solidly before coronavirus
summary: US durable goods orders rose 1.2% in February, beating expectations of a 0.8% decline, but are expected to decline as the coronavirus pandemic continues to impact the economy. The sector, which accounts for 11% of the US economy, has been showing signs of stabilizing before the outbreak of the virus. However, the highly contagious coronavirus has brought the economy to a sudden halt, with governors ordering residents to stay indoors and non-essential businesses closed, leading to massive unemployment and a rush to apply for jobless benefits.

site_title: Sim Leisure incorporates subsidiary in Singapore
summary: Sim Leisure Group announced the incorporation of its 60%-owned subsidiary, Sim Leisure Creative, in Singapore with a S$10 million issued and fully paid-up share capital. The subsidiary will lease non-financial intangible assets and provide management consultancy services. The remaining 40% is held by minority shareholders not related to the company's directors or substantial shareholders.

site_title: US cybersecurity experts see recent spike in Chinese digital espionage
summary: US cybersecurity firm FireEye detected a surge in new cyberspying by a suspected Chinese group, dubbed "APT41", starting January 20, targeting over 75 customers worldwide.
