The hacking group exploited recently disclosed flaws in software developed by Cisco and Citrix to break into networks in the US, Canada, Britain, and other countries. FireEye assessed with moderate confidence that APT41 was composed of Chinese government contractors, marking a broad departure from typical Chinese hacking activity.

site_title: iPhone makers suspend India production due to lockdown
summary: Foxconn and Wistron Corp have suspended all production at their Indian plants due to a nationwide lockdown ordered by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The lockdown, which started on March 25, 2020, affects the output of Apple iPhones and other gadgets. The companies, key manufacturing partners to major electronics names, will resume production once further government announcements are made. The lockdown impacts the Indian market, where Apple has a limited presence due to high prices and tariffs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 33.36 points to 1,324.50 on Wednesday, closing higher. The index saw 641 gainers and 267 losers, with a trading volume of RM4.329 billion.

site_title: STI jumps 6.1% as US policymakers agree to US$2t fiscal stimulus package
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 6.1% to 2,505.47, driven by US policymakers agreeing to a US$2 trillion fiscal stimulus package. The news boosted global equity markets, with Asia-Pacific benchmarks registering strong gains. However, strategists remain cautious due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and rising cases. The market is expected to remain volatile until conclusive evidence of infection curves flattening and lockdowns ending.

site_title: M'sia extends movement curbs, prepares economic stimulus
summary: Malaysia extends its two-week movement curbs and prepares a second economic stimulus package as the country reports 172 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 1,796, the highest in South-east Asia. The curbs will be extended until April 14, and a new stimulus package will be unveiled, focusing on supporting the most vulnerable populations. The government also plans to carry out mass testing in high-risk areas and has linked nearly two-thirds of its infections to a religious gathering.

site_title: Rex unit signs agreement for 15% stake in 2 Norwegian Sea drilling licences
summary: Rex International's unit, Lime Petroleum AS, has signed an agreement with INEOS E&P Norge AS for a 15% stake in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences. The farm-in deal is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to begin exploration drilling early next year. The move fits into Lime's technology-led and near-field exploration strategy, with plans to drill in Fat Canyon located in a Jurassic reservoir.

site_title: Bonvests Holdings revokes proposed dividends, implements pay cut to sustain operations
summary: Bonvests Holdings has revoked its proposed dividend of 1 Singapore cent per share due to the negative impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its business. The company has also implemented pay cuts of 10-50% for staff and a 10% reduction in non-executive directors' fees. These measures aim to conserve cash resources and sustain business operations until the pandemic improves. The company expects its financial results and cash resources to be negatively impacted, with results for FY2020 likely to be adversely affected.

site_title: Sias issues guidance to shareholders for AGMs amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Sias) in Singapore has issued guidance to shareholders for attending annual general meetings (AGMs) amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Shareholders are encouraged to avoid attending meetings due to the 10-person attendee limit set by the Ministry of Health. However, shareholders are advised to continue monitoring their investments and reviewing the annual report. This guidance aims to ensure compliance with health advisory notices while allowing shareholders to stay informed about their investments.

site_title: Time to review Project Completion Period deadlines
summary: The Singapore construction and real estate industries are facing significant challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including labor and material shortages, lockdowns in Malaysia, and disruptions to global supply chains. The five-year Project Completion Period (PCP) deadline for residential projects is becoming a concern, with many developers at risk of missing the deadline. The government has explored options to provide relief to businesses, including waiving levies for employers with foreign workers serving quarantine notices. However, the prolonged pandemic and lockdowns are expected to lead to significant delays in construction progress, impacting the industry's ability to meet deadlines and deliver completed properties to homebuyers.

site_title: Maybank offers free remittance services for Malaysians in Singapore
summary: Maybank offers complimentary remittance services for Malaysians in Singapore until April 14, 2020, allowing them to transfer funds without fees to individual Malaysian bank accounts at attractive exchange rates. The initiative aims to provide relief to those affected by Malaysia's movement control order due to the COVID-19 outbreak. This move follows Maybank's previous introduction of relief measures, including Home Loan Repayment Relief and complimentary insurance coverage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks boosted by US stimulus deal
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 3.81% on Wednesday after the US agreed on a massive stimulus package to support its economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,527.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased by 2.17% and 2.92%, respectively. The rally was driven by positive market sentiment and the expectation of economic recovery.

site_title: Tokyo begins Olympic task of reorganising Games
summary: Japan has postponed the Tokyo 2020 Olympics to 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic, a move unprecedented in peacetime. The Games, initially set for July 2020, will be reorganized, affecting venues, security, ticketing, and accommodation. International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach has left the door open for the rescheduled Games to take place in the spring or summer of 2021. The delay has sparked disappointment and relief among athletes, with the Japanese government framing the event as the "Recovery Games" to show the world's resilience.

images.alt_text: Japan set about the unprecedented task of reorganising the Tokyo 2020 Olympics Wednesday after making the tough decision to postpone the Games by a year as the coronavirus pandemic locks down one third of the planet.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend recovery at open
summary: European stock markets continued their recovery, with London up 1.5% and Frankfurt, Paris, Milan, and Madrid gaining 2.4%, 2.7%, 2.7%, and 3.6% respectively at the open on Wednesday. The gains follow Tuesday's huge 7.5% rise. The recovery is attributed to governments and central banks supporting the global economy amid the coronavirus fallout.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Geo Energy Resources
summary: Fitch has downgraded Geo Energy Resources' long-term issuer default rating and senior unsecured guaranteed notes from B- to CC, citing a probable default within the next 12 months due to weak operating profile and deteriorating liquidity. The company faces significant refinancing challenges, declining reserves, and reduced profitability amid weak coal prices. Its acquisition plans have also been impacted, with a 51% stake in Indonesian coal mines now unlikely due to execution uncertainty. A material cash shortfall is expected, with US dollar notes maturing in October 2022.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher ahead of Senate vote on stimulus bill
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.4% at 20,992.28, and the S&P 500 gaining 0.2% to 2,452.14. This follows a 11.4% surge on Tuesday, the largest one-day gain since 1933. The positive trend comes ahead of a Senate vote on a $2 trillion stimulus package to boost the US economy affected by the coronavirus outbreak.

images.alt_text: A couple of minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.4 per cent at 20,992.28.

site_title: UnUsUaL Limited implements pay cut and other moves to conserve cash reserves amid virus crisis
summary: UnUsUaL Limited, a concert promoter, has implemented a 10-20% pay cut across its group to conserve cash reserves amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has postponed concerts and events, but expects to resume them when the virus is contained due to its relationships with partners and artists. UnUsUaL will also cut discretionary expenses and renegotiate payment terms on existing commitments.

site_title: Brian Koo may withdraw lifeline for honestbee; ex-director denies startup's allegations
summary: Honestbee, a Singapore-based startup, may lose support from its white knight, LG scion Brian Koo, due to a delay in funding from his venture firm Formation Group and FLK Holdings. Honestbee is seeking an adjournment of its hearing to clarify the position of FLK and Formation, and potentially seek new investors. The startup has also accused former directors, including Jeffrey Wong and Joel Sng, of breaching fiduciary duties, with Wong denying the allegations. Honestbee is investigating irregularities in transactions involving the former directors and is seeking clarification on the status of its restructuring plan.

site_title: Sustainability lessons from the Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought sustainability fundamentals of ESG (environment, social, and governance) to the forefront, showcasing the potential for countries to collaborate and achieve significant positive outcomes. In China, the closure of factories and quarantine orders led to cleaner air and reduced carbon dioxide emissions, with satellite images showing a 21.5% increase in "good-quality-air days" in Hubei province. Similarly, the halt of gondola activities in Venice brought back dolphins into the city's canals. The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of social cohesion, corporate governance, and inclusive decision-making, with countries like China and Italy making courageous decisions that come with significant costs but ultimately benefit the long-term.

images.alt_text: From the Lombardy region in Italy to Hubei province in China, the virus has greatly challenged the inhabitants, but it has, strangely, also strengthened the social fabric of these communities, uniting them in overcoming a common deadly foe.

site_title: UMS Holdings extends suspension of Penang factory operations
summary: UMS Holdings has extended the suspension of its Penang factory operations until April 14, in compliance with Malaysia's extended movement control order. The factory in California, USA remains closed due to a state stay-home executive order, while production facilities in Singapore will continue to operate. The company will assess the impact of government directives on its business and provide updates on the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: France to implement 4b euro liquidity support plan for startups
summary: France is implementing a 4 billion euro liquidity support plan for startups, aiming to aid the country's growing startup ecosystem. The plan, announced by digital junior minister Cédric O, follows years of tax cuts and business-friendly measures by President Emmanuel Macron. This move seeks to support the liquidity of early-stage digital companies, helping France turn into a startup nation.

site_title: Some India ports declare force majeure, could delay oil discharges: documents, sources
summary: Some Indian ports, including those owned by Adani Ports & SEZ Ltd, have declared force majeure due to the 21-day lockdown to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, according to documents and sources. This could delay oil discharges and impact crude oil imports, with some operations continuing despite the declaration. No government-owned ports have declared force majeure yet, but have been given the liberty to do so.

site_title: ARA H-Trust launches cost-cutting measures amid virus outbreak
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) has implemented cost-cutting measures amid the COVID-19 outbreak, including cutting labor cost hours and staffing, closing facilities, and reviewing operating contracts. The move comes as the company faces declining room occupancies due to increased booking cancellations and fewer new reservations. ARA H-Trust may also consider temporary hotel closures and consolidating operations in the same geographic area to mitigate losses. The company's cost mitigation and capital preservation measures aim to preserve capital and navigate the challenging hotel market.

site_title: Malaysia extends movement curbs to April 14 as virus cases surge
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin extended the country's movement curbs until April 14, citing a surge in coronavirus cases with 172 new infections and a total of 1,796 cases, and 17 deaths. The original restrictions were set to expire on March 31. A comprehensive economic stimulus package is expected to be announced on Friday.

site_title: Fortress Minerals mining activities remain suspended as Malaysia extends movement control order
summary: Malaysia has extended its movement control order, suspending Fortress Minerals' mining activities in Bukit Besi, Terengganu. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.21 on Wednesday. Fortress Minerals is unable to quantify the financial impact of the control order on its earnings per share and net asset value per share for the financial year ending Feb 28, 2021. The company will continue to monitor the situation and make announcements as necessary.

site_title: Wilmar sets up 4 new subsidiaries and acquires 1 firm
summary: Wilmar International has established four new subsidiaries in the Solomon Islands, China, Myanmar, and Sri Lanka, and acquired one firm in China. The new subsidiaries will engage in food product sales and distribution, rice and flour milling, edible oils refining, and ship crew recruitment and placement. Wilmar also acquired a 69.50% stake in Shenzhen Delion Food Co for RMB72.6 million. The company's shares closed up 7.9% to S$3.26 following the announcement.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Taxi extends and increases the daily rental relief for cabbies
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has increased its daily rental relief for cabbies by S$10, making it a total reduction of S$46.50 per day until the end of April. The company aims to support cabbies affected by the Covid-19 outbreak amid stricter measures to contain the virus. The enhanced relief is part of ComfortDelGro's efforts to mitigate the drop in income, following the government's announcement of a second stimulus package.

site_title: Thailand warns economy to contract in 2020, but holds fire on rates
summary: Thailand's central bank kept interest rates steady at 0.75% despite a severe economic outlook forecast for 2020, citing the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The Bank of Thailand cut its GDP forecast to minus 5.3%, the first contraction since the 2009 global financial crisis. Tourism, a key driver of the economy, is heavily reliant on Chinese tourists and trade, making Thailand vulnerable to the virus. With 934 reported cases and 4 deaths, Thailand's economy faces significant challenges due to widespread disruptions to travel and factory supply chains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has reached a critical phase in its fight against COVID-19, with National Development Minister Lawrence Wong signaling the possibility of closing schools and workplaces if the number of infected cases continues to rise. Singapore-based robo-advisor Smartly has folded its business due to intense competition. UBS has placed its "buy" rating on Eagle Hospitality Trust under review after the US-based hotel trust called for a voluntary trading suspension. The STI jumped 6.1% as US policymakers agreed to a $2 trillion fiscal stimulus package, while Vietnam was surprised by Trump's tariff announcement and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Negotiators reach agreement on massive US coronavirus response bill: Trump aide
summary: US senators and Trump administration officials have reached an agreement on a $2 trillion economic stimulus bill to alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The deal was announced by White House official Eric Ueland, stating "We have a deal." The massive stimulus package aims to provide relief to individuals and businesses affected by the pandemic, marking a significant development in the US response to the crisis.

site_title: White House not considering 3-month tariff deferral: Navarro
summary: US Trade Advisor Peter Navarro denied the Trump administration is considering a 3-month tariff deferral on imported goods to ease economic pain from the coronavirus pandemic. Industry groups, including Americans for a Prosperous America, are seeking the deferral, arguing it would harm US producers. Navarro stated the tariffs have been an important defense against China's economic aggression, enriching China at the expense of American workers. The US Trade Representative's office has not commented on the proposal.

site_title: Malaysia's Feb CPI up 1.3% on year, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's February consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.3% from a year earlier, below the forecasted 1.4% pace. This marked a slowdown from the 1.6% increase in January, the fastest since May 2018. Inflation was driven by increases in miscellaneous goods and services and transport, but declined in the clothing and footwear sector. The central bank expects headline inflation to remain modest in 2020, though higher than the previous year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares surge nearly 6% on global stimulus efforts
summary: South Korean shares surged nearly 6% on Wednesday, extending gains into a second day, as global stimulus efforts eased pressure on non-dollar assets. The KOSPI index rose 5.87% to 1,704.40, with foreigners net selling $194.64 million worth of shares. The US stimulus bill nearing passage and South Korea's central bank plans to inject dollars into local markets via a currency swap with the US Federal Reserve also contributed to the gains. Despite the surge, the index has still fallen 22.45% this year.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 strategy may stretch outbreak but will preserve healthcare capacity: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong said the country's strategy to flatten the curve of the Covid-19 outbreak may stretch the pandemic over a longer period, but will preserve healthcare capacity to care for severe cases. The strategy involves building herd immunity, which carries two risks: an uncontrolled spike in cases overwhelming the healthcare system or the immunity not being effective or sustained. To mitigate this, the government is strengthening early detection and contact tracing efforts, expanding its contact tracing capacity to 4,000 contacts per day.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up 8.04% after US stimulus deal
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 8.04% on Wednesday, driven by a $2 trillion US coronavirus rescue package and relief over the Tokyo Olympics postponement rather than cancellation. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,546.63, while the broader Topix rose 6.87%. The rally follows a 7% gain on Tuesday.

site_title: 'Unconstitutional' to delay election without state of emergency: Teo Chee Hean
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean stated in Parliament that delaying the Singapore General Election beyond April 2021 is unconstitutional without a state of emergency. A state of emergency can only be declared in such circumstances, and it's not a decision to be taken lightly. The government must choose between holding elections soon or settling them early to give the new government a full mandate to make tough decisions amidst the COVID-19 crisis.

site_title: Closure of schools and workplaces possible if number of Covid-19 cases continues rising: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore is reaching a critical phase in its fight against COVID-19, with National Development Minister Lawrence Wong signaling the possibility of introducing drastic measures, including school and workplace closures, if case numbers continue to rise. Wong emphasized the need to prioritize public health, save lives, and slow down the virus before addressing economic consequences. He urged Singaporeans to take the latest measures seriously, as the fight against the virus requires collective effort. The government has already announced measures to close bars, cinemas, and other public spaces, and is focusing on isolating returnees.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise after US govt agrees to massive stimulus package
summary: Australian shares surged 5% on Wednesday, reaching a 5,000 mark, following the US government's agreement on a massive stimulus package to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 5.5% higher, its largest percentage gain in over a week. The news of the stimulus package was released during market close, prompting a late surge in buying.

site_title: Hubei residents rush to leave China virus epicentre as lockdown lifts
summary: Huge crowds in Hubei province, China, flooded train and bus stations on Wednesday as lockdown restrictions were lifted, allowing healthy residents to travel after two months. People with a "green" health code were allowed to move in or out of the province. Thousands of people, including children in masks, were seen queuing for trains and coaches, with some returning to work after being separated for over two months. The easing of rules comes as China's coronavirus death toll surpasses 3,200.

site_title: Credit Suisse spying scandal hits ex-CEO Thiam's bonus
summary: Credit Suisse's former CEO Tidjane Thiam had part of his 2019 bonus cut due to the bank's surveillance scandal, which cost him 15% of his overall compensation. The scandal led to Thiam's resignation in February. The bank's annual report stated that Thiam's non-financial assessment score was reduced due to the scandal's impact. Chairman Urs Rohner is also stepping down, and a search for his successor is underway.

site_title: Singapore authorities remind nightlife operators of safe distancing at 'farewell' parties
summary: Singapore authorities are reminding nightlife operators to adhere to safe distancing measures at "farewell" parties, following the government's decision to close all entertainment venues until April 30. The measures include a distance of at least 1 meter between participants and suspending events with over 250 people. Authorities will deploy enforcement operations over the next two days, and officers will monitor the situation and take action against those who fail to comply. The move aims to reduce the risk of seeding new local coronavirus clusters amid over 550 reported cases in Singapore.

site_title: CDL New Zealand unit to halt development works, close office due to lockdown
summary: CDL New Zealand's unit will halt development works and close its corporate office due to New Zealand's imminent lockdown. Sales activity will continue, with land agents working remotely. The company is confident unconditional agreements for land sales will be settled this year, but delays in regulatory site inspections and title issuance are expected. CDL has sufficient financial resources to maintain its business.

site_title: Bank of Singapore urging leveraged clients to sell in rally
summary: Bank of Singapore's CEO, Bahren Shaari, advises leveraged clients to sell investments during market rallies due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. He believes the crisis is not yet at its peak and that many countries are not well-prepared. Shaari suggests using rebounds to offload unwanted investments, citing the best time to do so.

site_title: UBS reviewing 'buy' call on Eagle Hospitality Trust after event of default
summary: UBS has placed its "buy" rating on Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) under review due to the US-based hotel trust's voluntary trading suspension amid a loan default triggered by rent payment shortfalls. EHT plans to sell assets and undertake a strategic review, but UBS analysts warn that distressed selling could pose significant risks to its book value, potentially wiping out all unitholders' equity. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the decline in the hospitality market, with US hotel occupancy falling 24.4 percentage points year-on-year.

site_title: Gold faces historic squeeze with coronavirus threatening NY shortage
summary: The global gold market is facing a historic squeeze due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has halted physical trading routes and led to a surge in demand as investors seek a safe haven. The Comex exchange in New York is experiencing a shortage, with open interest in the April gold contract at 195,604 contracts and total deliverable stocks at 8.7 million ounces. This has driven up gold futures prices to a record premium over spot gold in London, with the spread reaching $67.57 an ounce. Efforts are being made to facilitate physical delivery and ensure the efficient running of the global gold market.

site_title: DBS links F&B players to services to set up online take-out orders
summary: DBS is partnering with homegrown tech startups Oddle and FirstCom to offer digital services to food and beverage businesses, enabling them to set up their own online food-ordering sites in just three days. This service aims to help F&B firms raise their online presence and create new income streams amid the virus outbreak. DBS will absorb set-up costs and waive merchant discount rates for six months for FirstCom customers adopting the digital merchant collections solution.

site_title: One fifth of US companies in China back to normal operations: poll
summary: A survey by the American Chamber of Commerce in China found that nearly one-fifth of US companies in China have returned to normal operations after disruptions caused by the coronavirus epidemic. Nearly a quarter of respondents expect to return to normal operations by the end of April, while another fifth expect delays throughout the summer. The survey also highlighted the reliance of US companies on China's small and medium-sized businesses, which have been slow to recover, and called for direct support to these suppliers and customers.

site_title: Ackman's Pershing Square takes off coronavirus hedges: letter
summary: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management has lifted its coronavirus hedges and reinvested the proceeds in existing and new stock holdings. The hedge fund, which initially took out credit market hedges in March, completed the exit on March 23 and generated $2.6 billion. Ackman became increasingly positive on the outlook due to market falls and government support. The fund maintained a 17% cash position and made new investments in companies like Starbucks and Agilent, with a focus on those built to withstand the crisis and flourish long-term.

site_title: Singapore, 6 other Pacific countries pledge to keep trade, supply chains going during Covid-19 crisis
summary: Singapore and seven other Pacific Rim countries have pledged to maintain open trade and supply chains during the COVID-19 pandemic, avoiding export controls and tariffs on essential goods. The statement, signed by trade ministers from Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Myanmar, New Zealand, and Singapore, aims to ensure the flow of goods, including medical supplies, despite global disruptions. The move seeks to maintain critical infrastructure, such as air and seaports, and facilitate trade flows.

site_title: In coronavirus-hit world, sponsors to stand by delayed Olympics
summary: Major corporate sponsors of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, including Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble, and Intel, are standing by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) despite the Games being postponed to 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic. The companies have committed close to $4 billion to multi-year contracts, and while some may seek creative solutions or termination, most consider themselves long-term partners of the IOC. The IOC's non-profit status and reliance on broadcast rights and sponsor revenue make it unlikely that sponsors will seek refunds, and the organization is likely to work with sponsors to ensure a successful event.

site_title: New Zealand PM Ardern declares national emergency to tackle Covid-19
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern declared a national emergency to combat the coronavirus outbreak, citing the need to preserve the country's way of life. The move comes as the number of Covid-19 cases rose to 205, prompting a complete lockdown at midnight. This is the highest level of alert, and authorities are taking drastic measures to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: Work pass holders to obtain MOM approval before entering Singapore from Malaysia
summary: Singapore requires Ministry of Manpower (MOM) approval for all work pass holders, including dependents, before entering the country from Malaysia. Existing work pass holders and those awaiting in-principle approval must obtain approval and serve a 14-day Stay Home Notice (SHN). Essential services workers, such as lorry drivers and supply truckers, are exempt from these requirements. Employers must declare housing and food arrangements and inform affected staff and dependents not to travel to Singapore until approval is granted. This measure follows Malaysia's extension of its movement control order due to rising COVID-19 cases.

site_title: Australia warns of looming health system crisis as coronavirus cases jump
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced stricter social distancing measures due to the accelerating number of coronavirus infections, which could overwhelm intensive care units. New restrictions limit wedding guests to five and funerals to 10, pushing the country closer to lockdown measures. The surge in cases poses a significant threat to the country's health system, with officials warning of a looming crisis.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Dairy Farm to 'buy', strong sales expected amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Dairy Farm to a "buy" rating, citing its attractive valuation and expected robust earnings amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The analysts lowered the target price to US$4.70 from US$5.20, citing a 22% correction in the share price. Dairy Farm's core grocery retail business is valued at under 10 times its earnings, and the analysts expect brisk sales during the outbreak, with limited downside for the stock. The company has also implemented measures to ensure access to food and essentials for vulnerable groups.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades mm2 Asia to 'fully valued' following closure of Singapore cinemas
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded mm2 Asia to "fully valued" from "hold" due to the Republic's cinema closure amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The downgrade lowered the target price to 10.7 Singapore cents from 30 cents. Shares rose 0.6 cents or 4.8% to 13 cents. A "fully valued" call implies a negative total return of over 10% over the next 12 months.

site_title: One third of humanity under virus lockdown
summary: A third of the world's population, approximately 2.6 billion people, are under lockdown orders due to the COVID-19 pandemic. India's 1.3 billion population is under a three-week lockdown, while China has relaxed restrictions in its epicenter province of Hubei. The US Congress is set to pass a $2 trillion stimulus bill, and global markets have surged, with the Dow Jones Industrial Index surging 11.3% on Tuesday. The pandemic has claimed over 18,200 deaths and 405,000 infections worldwide, with Europe being the hardest-hit region.

site_title: Coronavirus: ACRA, MAS to propose legislative amendments on conduct of shareholder meetings
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are proposing legislative amendments to allow listed companies to conduct shareholder meetings while complying with safe-distancing rules amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. The amendments will permit issuers to limit attendees in physical meetings and allow virtual participation. The changes will be introduced in April, with issuers expected to comply with the Ministry of Health's safe-distancing measures. The proposed amendments will provide flexibility for companies to adapt to the new situation and enable investors to participate in meetings through virtual means.

site_title: China Sunsine clarifies cheaper raw materials led to lower cost of sales
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings reported a 11.1% decrease in cost of sales to 1.91 billion yuan in 2019, despite a 10.5% increase in sales volume. The decrease was mainly attributed to a 30% decline in raw material costs due to oversupply in the market. Other costs of sales increased, while interest income from bank deposits and foreign exchange gains contributed to a 20% increase in other operating income.

site_title: Oyo sees signs of recovery in China after coronavirus outbreak
summary: Oyo Hotels and Homes, a hospitality startup, reports a recovery in bookings in China, its second-largest market, as the coronavirus outbreak eases. CEO Ritesh Agarwal stated that results have started to come back up in China, despite the company cutting thousands of jobs this year. Oyo is also offering free accommodation to medical first responders helping with the outbreak. The company's efforts come as China faces a rise in imported cases and potential restrictions, raising concerns about a second wave of infections.

site_title: Singapore robo-adviser Smartly folds business
summary: Singapore-based robo-adviser Smartly has ceased operations after fewer than three years due to intense competition in the digital advisory space. The firm cited "challenging" service standards and strategic corporate considerations by its parent company, VinaCapital Group, as the reasons for its decision. Smartly aims to return customer funds within 3-6 business days, and customers can contact the firm for inquiries about their accounts. The exact size of Smartly's assets under management and customer base remain unclear.

site_title: South Korea reports 100 new coronavirus cases, total 9,137: KCDC
summary: South Korea reported 100 new coronavirus cases, bringing its total to 9,137, according to the Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention. This marks a significant increase in cases since the beginning of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: South Korea reported 100 new coronavirus cases on Wednesday, bringing its total infections to 9,137, the Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention said.

site_title: Apple may start reopening stores in first half of April
summary: Apple may reopen some retail stores in the first half of April, with stores outside of Greater China reopening on a staggered basis. The company has extended remote work for many employees through April 5, with flexible arrangements to be re-evaluated weekly. Apple closed 458 stores in March to mitigate the spread of coronavirus, but those in China have since reopened. The company prioritizes the health and safety of its teams, customers, and communities.

site_title: Coronavirus closures may hit Singapore Reits harder than the global financial crisis
summary: Singapore Reits may face a harder hit from the coronavirus outbreak than the global financial crisis. The government's strict measures, including venue closures, could impact investor appetite. Reits' unit prices have plummeted, with a 26% quarterly drop, and the impact on net operating income might be bigger than during the 2008 crisis. The closure of public venues, particularly leisure and entertainment sectors, could last longer and affect Reits' distribution per unit. Current valuations are not close to the 2008 trough, making the potential impact even more significant.

site_title: Coronavirus calls into question PSA-Fiat Chrysler merger
summary: The coronavirus pandemic has cast doubt over the pending merger between PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler (FCA), creating the world's fourth-largest automaker. The tie-up, announced in October, is set to be finalized in early 2021, but preparations are being hindered by the economic damage and regulatory uncertainty. Legal teams continue to work on getting the green light from antitrust authorities, but the pandemic's impact on the deal's feasibility is now a major concern.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged at the start of trade on Wednesday, driven by a massive rally on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.61% to 23,255.91, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.67% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 2.30%. The rally followed hopes that US lawmakers would agree a stimulus package to protect the world's top economy against the virus crisis.

site_title: Online gaming booms as Covid-19 lockdowns keep millions at home
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in online gaming, with millions of people worldwide turning to digital entertainment as a distraction from lockdowns and social isolation. Record numbers are flocking to online servers, with internet providers scrambling to meet the surge in demand. Gaming companies are also adapting to the new reality, with some promising to keep their online servers running smoothly and introducing new in-game activities to keep players engaged. Experts predict a significant transformation in gaming habits, with younger kids likely to spend more time playing games at home as parents struggle with economic uncertainty.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares climb on hopes of massive US stimulus
summary: Australian shares rose 6.1% on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains, as US lawmakers moved closer to passing a massive stimulus package to curb the coronavirus outbreak's economic impact. The S&P/ASX 200 index jumped, with mining stocks and the "Big Four" banks also rising. Qantas Airways secured extra funds to support it amid global travel curbs. New Zealand's benchmark index climbed 3.6%, with SKY Network Television Ltd and Oceania Healthcare also experiencing significant gains.

site_title: With economy sinking, Trump's own business is in peril
summary: President Donald Trump's business empire, including the Trump Organization's hotels, golf courses, and real estate, is struggling due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with many properties facing empty rooms and potential shutdowns. The Trump Organization has reported a $435 million revenue loss in 2018, and it is unclear how severe the impact will be this year. Trump's response to the crisis has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing his own business interests, with some speculating that part of the economic rescue plan could be used to prop up his hotel and resort businesses.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street surge as US targets blockbuster bill
summary: Asian markets surged on Wednesday, following a strong day on Wall Street and Europe as US lawmakers edge towards a massive stimulus package worth up to $2 trillion to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The Dow saw its biggest percentage-point rise since 1933, while the S&P 500 enjoyed its best day in over a decade. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul, rallied, with gains ranging from 2% to 5.7%. The G-7 pledged to take necessary measures, and the Fed promised to print more cash, lifting risk assets and sending the dollar lower.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars back from the brink, hope for calm spell
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have experienced a relative calm spell after the Federal Reserve's promise to print unlimited US dollars eased liquidity constraints and boosted risk assets. The Aussie dollar rallied 2% to US$0.5967, while the kiwi dollar rose to US$0.5823. Central banks in Australia and New Zealand have also stepped up with bond-buying programs to keep borrowing costs low and credit flowing. Despite concerns about a deep recession and sharp unemployment rate in Australia, the market has been sanguine about the heavy new issuance of government debt.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Jumbo to 'hold' on Covid-19 impact to earnings
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Jumbo Group to "hold" from "buy" due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on its earnings. Analysts expect a severe beating in the share price and a significant decline in earnings forecast for FY2020-2021, with a 31-58% reduction in revenue. However, Jumbo's strong balance sheet and net cash of seven Singapore cents provide a cushion against the pandemic. The research house lowered its target price to S$0.18 from S$0.38.

site_title: Qantas shares soar on financing deal as rivals cut more capacity
summary: Qantas secured A$1.05 billion in financing against its aircraft fleet, sending shares up 30%, as the airline industry faces the coronavirus crisis. Qantas has cut international flights and staff, maintaining its investment grade credit rating. Rival Virgin Australia Holdings has stopped 90% of domestic flying and put 80% of employees on leave, with plans to close bases and adjust operations. Other Asian carriers, such as Thai Airways and Japan Airlines, have also cut capacity. The global industry is estimated to lose US$250 billion in revenue in 2020, with low-cost funding available to airlines with strong fundamentals.

site_title: Hong Kong booze ban may wipe out thousands of bars and restaurants
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced a plan to ban alcohol sales in an effort to curb the spread of COVID-19, potentially leading to the closure of thousands of bars and restaurants. The ban, proposed by Chief Executive Carrie Lam, aims to discourage residents from gathering in large groups. The move has sparked concerns about the financial impact on the city's nightlife and dining scene, with some establishments estimating losses of up to 90% of their business. The government has pledged to consider measures to help affected businesses, but the ban is set to take effect despite criticism from the industry.

site_title: UK offers millions of companies extension on filing accounts due to coronavirus
summary: The UK government has announced that over 4 million companies can apply for a 3-month extension to file their accounts due to the coronavirus outbreak, allowing businesses to prioritize managing its impact. This move aims to support companies affected by the pandemic.

site_title: US economy forecast to contract by 1% in 2020: Fitch Solutions
summary: US economy forecast to contract by 1% in 2020, according to Fitch Solutions. The revised forecast downgrades the previous growth prediction of 0.9% due to the novel coronavirus' impact, leading to a "negative wealth effect" and sharp contractions in private consumption and investment. Restrictions are expected to continue, causing uncertainty and potentially limiting the positive impact of stimulus measures, which will see the US Federal Reserve's balance sheet swell. A more meaningful recovery is anticipated in the fourth quarter as containment efforts flatten the curve of new Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Singapore: Shares advance at Wednesday's open; STI up 3.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.5% to 2,443.60 on Wednesday, driven by investor optimism over recent stimulus measures to combat the novel coronavirus pandemic. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank, gained 3-4% in early morning trade. The gains followed a record-setting US rally and investor relief over the Tokyo Olympics being postponed. In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 11.4% and the Nasdaq gained 8.1%, with lawmakers expected to agree on a massive stimulus package soon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.67% to 1,325.59 points, with 374 gainers outpacing 22 losers. Volume was 129.15 million lots worth RM48.93 million. The increase came as traders brushed off new US threats to extend the stock rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens up more than 3% after strong US rally
summary: Tokyo stocks surged more than 3% on Wednesday after a record US rally and relief over the Tokyo Olympics being postponed. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 3.45% to 18,716.44, while the Topix gained 3.08%. The US market also reached new records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging past previous highs despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. The Tokyo Olympics postponement added to the market's optimism.

site_title: Some in Bank of Japan warned of economic slump as they eased in March
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers warned of a prolonged economic slump despite easing stimulus in an emergency meeting. They expressed flexibility in monetary policy, citing the need to respond to economic and price developments. The warning comes amid global economic uncertainty, with China's GDP growth expected to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. The BOJ's actions aim to mitigate these risks and stabilize the economy. Policymakers' concerns highlight the challenges facing the global economy amidst ongoing trade tensions and the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: China reports drop in new confirmed cases of coronavirus
summary: China reported a drop in new confirmed cases of coronavirus, with 47 cases on Tuesday, down from 78 the previous day. The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China is 81,218, and the death toll has reached 3,163.

images.alt_text: Mainland China reported a drop in new confirmed coronavirus cases, all of which involved travellers arriving from abroad, the National Health Commission said on Wednesday.

site_title: Boeing plans 737 MAX production restart by May: sources
summary: Boeing plans to restart 737 MAX production by May, ending a months-long halt triggered by a safety ban on its best-selling jet after fatal crashes. The company's production restart hinges on the scale of disruptions from the coronavirus and US regulators clearing the 737 MAX to return to service. Boeing has asked some suppliers to prepare 737 parts for April shipment.

site_title: UK should widen coronavirus wage guarantee to self-employed: think tank
summary: A UK think tank recommends widening a coronavirus wage guarantee to cover self-employed and sacked workers, rather than just those temporarily laid off by their employers. The current plan, announced last week, covers 80% of wage bills for temporarily laid-off staff. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak is exploring ways to support the self-employed, but faces challenges in identifying those who will lose income. The think tank's proposal aims to provide broader financial assistance to those affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Procurri in dispute with JV stake seller over alleged discrepancies
summary: Procurri Corporation's US subsidiary rejected a demand for indemnification of US$474,317 from the sellers of a stake in its joint-venture Rockland Congruity, citing alleged discrepancies. The dispute arose from adjustments made by Procurri US that were taken into consideration for a post-closing date payment. The group expects no material impact on its earnings per share for the current financial year. Procurri Corp is working with the sellers to resolve the matter.

site_title: Banks, regulators move to protect customers from wave of coronavirus scams in UK, US
summary: UK and US banks are stepping up fraud prevention measures to protect customers from coronavirus-related scams, including fake medical supply sales and bogus government relief schemes. British banks have launched social media campaigns to flag suspicious activities, while US regulators have warned about investment and data theft scams. Scammers are using phishing emails, authorised bank transfers, and fake government schemes to target vulnerable individuals, with some victims losing significant amounts of money. Banks and regulators are urging customers to be cautious and to verify the authenticity of requests before handing over sensitive information or making payments.

site_title: China's hidden symptom-free virus cases mean epidemic not over
summary: China's exclusion of symptom-free virus cases from its official count has raised concerns over whether the outbreak has truly come under control. Despite reporting four domestic cases, local authorities in Wuhan continue to find asymptomatic cases daily. This practice is uncommon among countries like South Korea, Japan, and Singapore, which count all positive tests, regardless of symptoms. The exclusion of asymptomatic cases may be due to limited testing capacity, leaving policymakers to consider the true extent of the outbreak.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Manulife Reit, Prudential, UOB, OCBC, Olam, Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Singapore stocks are watching several developments on Wednesday. Singapore Airlines' monthly salary for cabin crew may fall by 60-70% due to reduced flying hours. Manulife Reit's management assured that leases are secure despite temporary changes in tenants. Prudential is evaluating alternative options amid market turmoil. Several lenders, including UOB and OCBC, are revising home loan offerings. Olam sold its 50% stake in an Indonesian sugar joint venture for US$82.5 million. Cromwell E-Reit completed the sale of 12 European assets and acquired three.

site_title: Pompeo says China still withholding coronavirus information
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, saying the country is still withholding crucial information. He accused China of creating risks to people worldwide and putting thousands of lives at risk. Pompeo also criticized Iran and Russia for disinformation campaigns about the virus. The US is preparing an executive order to relocate medical supply chains from China to the US, amid concerns about supply-chain challenges and the US-China relationship.

site_title: Facebook revenue slips as usage leaps during pandemic
summary: Facebook's revenue has slipped despite a surge in users due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Online voice and video calls on Messenger and WhatsApp have more than doubled, but ad revenue has weakened in countries taking aggressive measures to slow the spread of the virus. The company's free messaging services, which don't generate ad revenue, have seen increased engagement. Facebook's ad business is expected to be affected, with other companies like Twitter also dialing back earnings expectations due to the pandemic's impact on advertising revenue.

site_title: Smelling a rat: How rodents sniff out fake beggars
summary: Researchers found that Norway rats use scent cues to determine a fellow rat's hunger level, rather than relying on begging gestures. When hungry rats' air was pumped into a separate chamber, focal rats provided help faster than when well-fed rats' air was used. The scent signals included organic compounds from recently ingested food and metabolic processes, forming a "smell of hunger" that reliably indicates a rat's need. This ability helps rats identify "cheaters" and promotes a more cooperative society.

site_title: Another 'turnaround Tuesday' for STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 5.8% to 2,362.05, its best session since April 2009, after the US Federal Reserve's move to adopt unlimited quantitative easing and further lending to SMEs. The index was boosted by a weaker US dollar and news that Chinese authorities will lift travel restrictions for Hubei province residents. Other Asian-Pacific markets also registered gains. Despite some concerns about the fiscal front, analysts welcomed the Fed's move, with AxiCorp's Stephen Innes saying it's a "most welcomed" development.

site_title: Boost from e-commerce blunts coronavirus hit on Nike's China sales
summary: Nike reported a 23% drop in net income to $847 million due to a 5% decline in China sales, which fell to $1.5 billion, despite a 30% jump in digital sales. The company's sales were offset by higher revenue in North America, Europe, and Asia Pacific. With the virus waning in China, nearly 80% of Nike's stores are now open, and the company has shuttered stores outside China, Japan, and Korea due to the pandemic.

site_title: As governments tout virus aid, companies struggle to tap it
summary: Governments worldwide have pledged over $3 trillion in aid to offset the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, but companies are struggling to access it due to confusion over application processes, loan availability, and delivery timelines. Small businesses face uncertainty over government support, with some reporting difficulties in accessing loans, rebates, and other forms of assistance. Delays in aid distribution are putting businesses at risk of bankruptcy, exacerbating a global recession. Governments are responding to criticism by increasing the scope of their aid packages and improving communication with businesses.

site_title: Euro zone mulls 2% of GDP credit from bailout fund to fight coronavirus
summary: Euro zone finance ministers support a 2% of GDP credit line from the ESM bailout fund to help combat the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic. The Enhanced Conditions Credit Line (ECCL) would allow governments to access potentially unlimited European Central Bank bond buying if needed. EU leaders will decide on the use of the money at their tele-summit on Thursday, amid concerns that financial markets could demand high prices for lending to governments, particularly for highly indebted countries like Italy.

site_title: In Japan, disappointment but understanding over postponed Olympics
summary: Japanese citizens reacted with disappointment but understanding to the postponement of the Olympics due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Games, initially set to start on July 24, will now take place "not later than summer 2021". Many acknowledged the need to prioritize athlete health, citing the rapidly spreading virus globally. Despite initial enthusiasm, opinion polls showed people increasingly believed the Games could not be held, leading to widespread disappointment among locals and volunteers.

site_title: 64 Ethiopians found dead in cargo container in Mozambique
summary: Sixty-four Ethiopian migrants were found dead in a cargo container in the Mozambican province of Tete, with only 14 survivors. The victims were believed to be smuggled from Malawi and suspected to be Ethiopians. The cause of death is presumed to be asphyxiation due to being crammed inside the container. Authorities have arrested the truck driver and his assistant, and a manhunt is underway for the intermediary who facilitated the smuggling. The Ethiopian government has launched an investigation and expressed sadness over the tragedy.

site_title: SoftBank plans to sell US$14b in Alibaba shares
summary: SoftBank plans to sell around $14 billion of its Alibaba shares, part of a $41 billion fundraising effort to shore up its battered businesses. The sale could range from $12 billion to $15 billion and is aimed at raising funds to pay down debt and pay shareholder returns. The move comes as SoftBank's founder, Masayoshi Son, seeks to alleviate investor concerns about the company's enormous debt load and ties to unprofitable startups.

site_title: First known child death in US from coronavirus
summary: The US has reported its first known child death from the novel coronavirus, a "youth under 18" from Lancaster, California, according to Los Angeles County health officials. Despite the disease typically not being severe in juveniles, the death was confirmed, contradicting previous studies showing Covid-19's impact on older patients and those with underlying conditions. This case is the first reported child death in the US, and only two known cases of minors dying from the disease have been recorded in China.

site_title: Italy's new virus infections drop to lowest point in crisis
summary: Italy has reported its lowest number of new virus infections since the start of the coronavirus crisis, with health officials attributing the decline to a two-week lockdown. The restrictions, set to expire on Wednesday, are likely to be extended for weeks or months. Italy's government is closely monitoring the data, with officials hopeful that the measures are slowing the spread of the virus. The country's economic cost is mounting, but the decline in infections provides a glimmer of hope in the fight against the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore general insurance posts S$28m hit in 2019
summary: Singapore's general insurance market posted an underwriting loss of S$28 million in 2019, with five largest segments - motor, health, property, employer's liability, and travel - recording a combined underwriting loss of S$43.4 million. The loss was largely due to a 12.2% increase in total insurance claims paid out, despite a 7.6% growth in gross written premiums to S$4.1 billion.

site_title: Airlines beg for rescue as coronavirus hit soars to US$250b
summary: Global airlines urge governments to provide massive bailouts to rescue the air transport industry, citing a projected $250 billion in revenue losses due to the coronavirus crisis. The industry is contemplating months without flying, with up to half of airlines facing possible bankruptcy. IATA chief Alexandre de Juniac emphasizes the need for urgent government support, brushing aside concerns about strings attached to relief. The crisis has already led to widespread job losses and potential delays in a recovery, with some analysts warning of a "U-shaped" rebound.

images.alt_text: Global airlines urged governments on Tuesday to speed up bailouts to rescue the air transport industry as they doubled their estimate of 2020 revenue losses from the coronavirus crisis to more than US$250 billion.

site_title: French coronavirus lockdown should last 'at least six weeks': government advisors
summary: France's coronavirus lockdown, imposed last week, is expected to last at least six weeks, according to a committee of scientific experts advising the government. The lockdown, which began on March 17, orders all French citizens to stay inside except for essential trips, as the country's death toll from the pandemic rises to 1,100. The experts believe that the confinement will last at least six weeks to effectively combat the virus, with Health Minister Olivier Veran stating that the duration will depend on the virus's progression.

images.alt_text: The lockdown imposed last week in France to battle the coronavirus should last at least six weeks in total, a committee of scientific experts advising the government on the outbreak said on Tuesday.

site_title: Share buybacks not for all companies
summary: In the first three weeks of March, 53 Singapore-listed companies spent a record S$448 million on share buybacks, with the Straits Times Index declining 20% since the start of the month. This surge in share repurchases is partly driven by the market sell-off, allowing companies to accumulate shares at lower costs for employee incentives. However, experts warn that companies with strong balance sheets and cash reserves may be better off seeking cheap assets to improve their prospects when the global economy recovers, rather than engaging in share buybacks.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit sells 12 assets, buys 3 in Europe
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) sold 12 light industrial/logistics assets in France, Denmark, and the Netherlands for 65.7 million euros, and acquired three freehold assets in Germany for 40.9 million euros. The manager stated that the Covid-19 outbreak has had minimal impact on income from European properties. Following the transactions, Cromwell E-Reit's portfolio now comprises 94 properties valued at about 2.08 billion euros.

site_title: India to halt domestic passenger flights in ramp-up of virus fight
summary: India will ground all domestic passenger flights from Wednesday to combat the spread of the novel coronavirus, citing a sharp increase in cases and the need to prevent an explosion of cases that could overwhelm the public health system. More than 700 million people in 30 states and territories have been ordered into complete lockdowns, with incoming international flights banned for a week and many states sealing their land borders.

site_title: Airlines, airports seek storage space as pandemic idles planes
summary: Airlines and airports worldwide are facing a crisis as thousands of idle planes are taking up valuable space, with over 5,000 planes stored since the start of the year. Major airports like Frankfurt, Hong Kong, and Seoul have converted runways, taxiways, and maintenance hangars into giant parking lots. Smaller airports, such as Avalon Airport in Australia, are also being used for storage. Airlines like Qantas and Singapore Airlines have cut flight schedules, and some have even parked planes at military airports or traditional desert storage facilities. The industry is struggling to find space as demand returns.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark best day since 2008 on hopes of calmer markets
summary: European shares surged 8.4% on Tuesday, their strongest session since 2008, as investors regained confidence in the market due to recent stimulus measures. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index jumped despite still being 30% down from its record peak in February. Low valuations and bargain hunting contributed to the rebound, with nearly all index constituents trading positive.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks close up nearly 10%
summary: Brazil's Sao Paulo stock exchange closed up 9.69% on Tuesday, following global markets higher on optimism about the coronavirus pandemic. Oil and airline stocks led the rebound, with Petrobras and airlines Gol and Azul closing up 16%, 17%, and 13% respectively. The Brazilian real strengthened 1.1% to 5.08 to the dollar. Despite this, the Sao Paulo exchange has lost over 40% since its all-time high in January due to the pandemic.

site_title: Oil little changed as falling demand offsets hopes of US aid package
summary: Oil prices rose modestly on Tuesday, settling at $27.15 a barrel for Brent futures and $24.01 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. Despite a 12-cent gain, prices fell off the day's highs as the pandemic's toll on demand offset hopes for a US$2 trillion economic relief package. India's lockdown of 1.3 billion residents has destroyed fuel demand worldwide, and the oil market faces twin shocks from the price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia and the pandemic's impact on fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose modestly on Tuesday, but settled off the day's highs as the coronavirus pandemic's heavy toll on demand offset hopes for a forthcoming US$2 trillion US economic relief package.

site_title: Spain seeks Nato help as virus death toll touches 2,700
summary: Spain has asked Nato for humanitarian assistance to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, as the country's death toll reached 2,700 and infections surged towards 40,000. Despite a lockdown, deaths and infections continue to rise, with the Spanish army joining efforts to curb the spread. The country has been severely affected by the pandemic, logging the third-highest number of deaths globally.

site_title: G-20 video talks on coronavirus set for Thursday: Moscow
summary: World leaders, including President Vladimir Putin, will hold an emergency G-20 online summit on March 26 to discuss the global coronavirus response. The summit, which will take place in a videoconference format, aims to battle the pandemic and its impact on the global economy. The move comes as the global toll from Covid-19 surges, with over 16,000 reported cases and 1.7 billion people confined to their homes. The summit is also supported by France and China, who have called for a virtual meeting.

site_title: South Africa orders mines to close in 21-day virus lockdown
summary: South Africa has ordered mines to close for 21 days as part of a nationwide lockdown to contain the coronavirus. The move affects the nation's significant gold, platinum, and palladium industries, which account for 75% and 38% of global supply respectively. The lockdown will start from midnight on Thursday and will be enforced by the army, with some essential services allowed to operate. The closure is expected to negatively impact gold and platinum production targets, with major producers such as Harmony Gold and Sibanye Stillwater weighing the directive.

site_title: Money FM podcast: A game changer in the fight against COVID-19
summary: Singaporean scientists successfully cultured COVID-19 from an infected patient's clinical sample, according to Professor Wang Linfa, director of the Emerging Infectious Disease Programme at Duke-NUS Medical School. This breakthrough could be a game-changer in the fight against the deadly pandemic.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic savages global economy; US PMI at record low
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted the global economy, with business activity surveys from Australia, Japan, and the euro zone showing record falls. The US March PMI plummeted to 40.5, its lowest level on record. Analysts predict a significant contraction in the euro zone economy, with a potential 2% quarter-on-quarter shrinkage. The US economy is also in recession, with economists citing the ongoing lockdowns and supply chain disruptions as major external shocks.

site_title: S Korea doubles coronavirus rescue package to 100t won
summary: South Korea has doubled its coronavirus rescue package to 100 trillion won ($116 billion) to support companies hit by the pandemic, aiming to prevent bankruptcies and stabilize the stock market. The package includes loans to small and medium-sized companies and corporate bond purchases. The move follows similar measures by global governments and central banks to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Hmlet co-founder Zenos Schmickrath leaves startup to pursue next challenge
summary: Zenos Schmickrath, co-founder of Singapore-based co-living operator Hmlet, has left the startup to pursue his next challenge. He remains a shareholder and the company is valued at over US$154 million. Hmlet recently cut around 10% of its employees, and the startup is shifting towards an asset-light model to improve its bottom line. Despite recording a US$246,000 loss in 2018, the company has raised over US$40 million in funding and is on track to serve 5,000 members across Asia-Pacific by the end of 2020.

site_title: Trump's labels amid virus battle fan anti-Asian racism
summary: US President Donald Trump is rebranding the COVID-19 pandemic as a Chinese threat, labeling it the "Chinese virus" and "Wuhan virus", despite acknowledging the virus originated in China. This shift in narrative has sparked concerns of anti-Asian racism, with reports of rising racist incidents against Chinese and ethnically Asian Americans. Trump's aides aim to frame the pandemic as a foreign threat to justify his re-election campaign, tapping into nationalist sentiment and blaming China for the US's economic woes.

site_title: How to fail at timing the market and still win big
summary: A writer reflects on their experience of investing in two stocks, Chipotle Mexican Grill and American Oriental Bioengineering, during the 2008 financial crisis. Despite failing to time their purchases, Chipotle's stock grew over 700% since 2007 due to the company's underlying growth, while American Oriental Bioengineering's stock plummeted to zero. The writer concludes that timing a buy is not as crucial as the quality of the company, and investing in high-quality companies at low valuations can still lead to significant gains.

site_title: Delhi's rebel gym goers risk virus to pump iron
summary: In defiance of India's lockdown, gyms in New Delhi continue to operate, with owners citing the need to support their livelihoods. Despite police action, gym-goers claim they can fight the virus with strong immunity, with some even taking extreme measures to stay active. Authorities have filed cases against gyms, but owners argue that shutting down would be disastrous for their businesses. India's booming bodybuilding culture has contributed to the gyms' determination to stay open, with some even believing that the country's hot climate can help combat the virus.

site_title: Trump calls for quick end to US coronavirus lockdown
summary: President Donald Trump called for a quick end to US coronavirus lockdowns, aiming to restart the economy within three weeks. He expressed frustration with social distancing measures, saying they're too disruptive and likened the US to a country that can't be shut down. Trump's proposal includes a 15-day observation period, which he believes will be sufficient to prevent the spread of the virus. Despite health experts' warnings, Trump's push for a rapid reopening carries risks of prioritizing economic interests over the survival of vulnerable individuals.

site_title: DBS to suspend registrations for in-person attendance at next week's AGM
summary: DBS has suspended registrations for in-person attendance at its annual general meeting (AGM) on March 31 due to stricter measures to contain the Covid-19 outbreak, deferring or cancelling all events and mass gatherings. The bank will continue to accept registrations for the live webcast option. DBS plans to update its shareholders on revised meeting plans by March 26.

site_title: US: Dow has biggest rally since 1933, surging 11.4% on stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks surged 11.4% on Tuesday, the largest one-day gain since 1933, driven by hopes of a massive stimulus package to combat the coronavirus' economic impact. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose to 20,704.91, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained 8.1% and 9.4%, respectively. Investors expect a US$2 trillion or higher package, which could include checks for individuals and small businesses, and loans to corporations. The package aims to cushion the economy's downside and boost spending.

site_title: SGX will not ban bearish bets, priority is to keep markets accessible
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ruled out banning bearish bets, prioritizing market accessibility over restrictions. Despite high market volatility, SGX continues to use circuit breakers to pause large price movements, rather than halting trading altogether. This approach aims to minimize disruptions while maintaining market liquidity.

site_title: India to go under total virus lockdown, says PM Modi
summary: India has implemented a 21-day total lockdown nationwide to combat the spread of the coronavirus, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi announcing the measure in a national address. The lockdown will begin at midnight on March 24 and will restrict all non-essential movements, including social gatherings, transport services, and shopping. Those who flout the rules may face up to two years in jail and a financial penalty. The move aims to slow the spread of the virus, which has seen a sharp increase in recent days, with 519 infections reported, including 10 deaths.

images.alt_text: India's 1.3 billion people will go under "total lockdown" for 21 days to combat the spread of the coronavirus, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Tuesday, sparking panic buying.

site_title: Blackstone's acquisition of Soho China is a win-win deal
summary: Blackstone is set to acquire Chinese property developer Soho China in a $4 billion deal, privatizing the company and taking on its $4.7 billion debt. The offer per share is double Soho's current share price, with Blackstone aiming to deter potential investors. The deal, if finalized, would be a win-win for both parties, showcasing Blackstone's market insights and business acumen. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the coming weeks, with Blackstone likely to succeed in its bid for the company founded by prominent couple Pan Shiyi and Zhang Xin.

site_title: Asian markets up on Fed's massive bond-buying programme
summary: The US Federal Reserve's massive bond-buying programme has boosted Asian markets, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising 4.8% as of Tuesday. South Korea and Japan also saw significant gains, with stocks jumping 8.6% and 7.1%, respectively. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 4.5% following the programme's announcement, easing concerns over capital flight from the region and fueling risk appetite. The dollar's reversal was seen as a key factor in the market's rally, with investors seeking higher returns in the face of economic uncertainty.

site_title: Coronavirus forces New York City schools into daunting experiment
summary: New York City's 1.1 million public school students began remote learning due to the coronavirus outbreak, with teachers and parents reporting promising early results despite technical issues. The city's largest school system is conducting a grand experiment, with some students enjoying the distraction of virtual assignments and learning activities. Teachers used digital platforms like Google Classroom and Zoom to deliver live classes, with some students accessing assignments from makeshift desks at home. Despite challenges, many students and parents found the remote learning experience to be a welcome distraction from the worrying acceleration of the virus.

site_title: MAS to flatten S$NEER slope, could re-centre: economists
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to flatten the slope of the foreign exchange policy band on March 30, potentially re-centring it at a lower level. Economists agree on the likelihood of re-centring, which would imply further monetary easing, but the actual size depends on the S$NEER's performance. The move aims to stabilize the Singapore dollar's value and boost the economy amid uncertainty.

site_title: US congress homes in on US$2t rescue for virus-hit economy
summary: US lawmakers are on the verge of a deal to provide a $2 trillion rescue package to combat the economic strain caused by the coronavirus pandemic. After days of intense negotiations, top Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer expressed optimism that the deal can be reached in the next few hours, citing "no outstanding issues" that can't be overcome. The package would include relief for hospitals, businesses, and ordinary Americans, with potential checks of up to $3,000 for a family of four. The deal needs to pass the Senate and then the Democratic-led House before being sent to President Donald Trump for approval.

site_title: Singapore shuts entertainment spots including bars, cinemas in virus fight
summary: Singapore authorities have shut down bars, entertainment venues, and tuition centers, and canceled events to minimize the spread of the novel coronavirus. The measures, effective from March 26 to April 30, include reducing operating capacity at public venues, limiting gatherings to 10 people, and enforcing safe distancing measures. The government aims to take a risk-based approach, scaling back measures if effective, and stepping up to a lockdown if necessary. The move follows a surge in imported cases, with 49 new confirmed cases reported on Tuesday, bringing the total to 558.

site_title: Sibor dive triggers fresh battle in mortgage rate cuts
summary: Singapore's inter-bank offered rate (Sibor) has plunged to new lows following the US Federal Reserve's two off-cycle rate cuts in March, prompting banks to adjust their mortgage rates. Banks are revising their home loan offerings, increasing spreads in floating rate packages and lowering fixed rates. Key banks such as Citibank, HSBC, and UOB have made changes, with some lowering fixed rates to 1.72% and increasing floating rate spreads to 0.23-0.53%. Experts warn that housing loans are expected to remain soft this year due to the global economic slowdown, and advise customers to set aside funds for unexpected situations.

site_title: US dollar continues slide as Fed stimulus calms markets
summary: The US dollar fell 1% against a basket of its rivals, marking its second consecutive day of decline, as the Federal Reserve increased measures to shield the economy from the novel coronavirus. The Fed announced programs including corporate bond purchases and guarantees for direct loans to companies. Despite this, the global economy is expected to remain constrained, and markets could quickly turn risk-off mode. The euro surged 1.5% against the US dollar, while the euro zone's PMI plummeted to a record low of 31.4 in March.

site_title: Using trading tools to beat market volatility caused by Covid-19
summary: Sophisticated traders and hedge funds have used various market tools to generate handsome returns despite the extreme stock market sell-off caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Short-selling has also been effective for less-sophisticated investors. The Singapore stock market has seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while US stocks continue to edge towards fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Tan Chong's full-year profit falls 65% on lower vehicle sales
summary: Tan Chong International, a Singapore-based car company, reported a 65% decline in full-year net profit to HK$212.93 million due to lower vehicle sales in key markets. Revenue fell 7.6% to HK$14.53 billion, primarily due to a 16% decline in motor vehicle sales. The company expects further impact from global trade and health issues, as well as changing automotive industry safety standards and ride-hailing trends.

site_title: People still putting their US mansions on the market
summary: Despite the US economic downturn and COVID-19 pandemic, some homeowners are choosing to list their luxury mansions on the market, often at reduced prices. According to real estate brokers, historically low interest rates and a perception of unique market positioning are driving sellers to list their properties. Contracts are being signed, particularly for homes below $1.5 million, with first-time buyers seemingly less affected by the market collapse. However, uncertainty remains, and sellers acknowledge that the market may fluctuate in the coming months.

site_title: Governments pull out stops to mitigate fallout from Covid-19
summary: Governments worldwide have implemented drastic measures to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, including monetary and fiscal stimulus packages, emergency rate cuts, and loan programs for businesses. The US Federal Reserve announced open-ended asset purchases, while the European Union and other countries have unveiled massive rescue packages to soften the blow of an unprecedented health crisis. Despite these efforts, economists warn that a prolonged recession could result in significant job losses and business failures, highlighting the need for governments to balance economic and humanitarian concerns.

site_title: IOC, Japan agree to push back Tokyo Olympic Games to 2021
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) and Japan have agreed to postpone the Tokyo Olympic Games to 2021 due to the coronavirus crisis, making it the first time in the Olympics' 124-year history that the event has been postponed. The decision was made after a call with IOC president Thomas Bach, with Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stating that the event will be rescheduled for the summer of 2021 at the latest.
