The postponement is expected to further impact Japan's economy, with economists predicting a significant decline in GDP and a worsening of consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told reporters that the Games were delayed to ensure that it would be a safe and secure event for athletes and spectators.

site_title: Covid-19: Call for bold measures in Singapore's second support package
summary: Singapore's second support package for SMEs is expected to be sizeable, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat considering tapping past reserves to fund it. Associations and consultants are calling for bold measures, including a six-month moratorium on loans, wage support, and increased subsidies for hiring mature local workers. The government is also urged to waive employers' 17% CPF contribution and landlords to stop dragging their feet on rental rebates. The support package aims to mitigate severe fallout from the pandemic within the next few months, with a broad-based, multi-faceted approach needed to support businesses at all levels.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International sold its 50% stake in Indonesian sugar joint venture Far East Agri for US$82.5 million, with US$2.5 million contingent on a sale-and-purchase agreement. Thakral Corporation raised S$5.8 million from the sale of a retail building in Japan. Haetec Jietong Holdings secured two S$7 million contracts for heat exchangers and pressure vessels. SIIC Environment Holdings appointed Tang Congliang as its new CFO, while Metech International appointed Clement Tay as executive director and CEO. Santak Holdings closed its Johor factory due to the Malaysian government's Movement Control Order.

site_title: Gold investors betting it's 2008 all over again
summary: Gold prices have tumbled amid a market rout, but some analysts see parallels with the 2008 global financial crisis, which led to a strong rally for the metal. If the price trajectory follows 2008, gold could bounce back strongly as market stress continues. Despite a 7.5% drop from its peak, gold's relative purchasing power has risen due to declines in other commodities. Central banks have pledged billions of dollars in stimulus, and investors are waiting for a policy response to inflation fears.

site_title: Why we like Chinese equities in the face of the global Covid-19 challenge
summary: Morgan Stanley forecasts a year-on-year contraction in global economic growth in H1 2020, with full-year growth ending at 0.9% due to the Covid-19 pandemic and oil price decline. However, China is expected to outperform the broad EM equities, with a 4% upside from the March 20 market close, driven by the government's stimulus measures and online-focused New Economy stocks. China's fiscal deficit is forecast to widen to 2.3% in 2020, and Morgan Stanley recommends overweighting media and entertainment, e-commerce, capital goods, and materials, as well as Singapore due to its defensive nature and intact household balance sheet.

site_title: Ford joins GE, 3M in speeding up ventilator, respirator production
summary: Ford Motor has joined General Electric's healthcare unit and 3M in a partnership to accelerate ventilator and respirator production under "Project Apollo." The effort comes as the US government calls on major automakers to support the pandemic response. With the rapid spread of the coronavirus, a global shortage of ventilators has strained healthcare systems, and Ford's involvement is seen as a step to address this issue.

site_title: Fallout for listed firms includes pay cuts, closures
summary: Singapore-listed companies are feeling the impact of the coronavirus pandemic with pay cuts, closures, and cancellations. BreadTalk is cutting salaries by 30-50% and closing hotels, while Singapore Press Holdings scrapped its $233.1 million Canadian aged care acquisition. mm2 Asia is reducing fixed costs and accelerating Asian programming to mitigate the short-term impact. Hospitality Group GL will progressively close its hotels due to the virus spreading to Europe and the UK.

site_title: US could become global epicentre of Covid-19 pandemic: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that the US could become the global epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak, citing a "very large acceleration" in cases in the country. Over 85% of new cases in the past 24 hours were from Europe and the US, with 40% from the US. As of Monday, the US had over 42,000 cases and 559 deaths. Britain has entered lockdown, and China's Hubei province will lift travel restrictions on people leaving the area, while other regions will tighten controls.

site_title: Big tech could emerge from coronavirus crisis stronger than ever
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated trends that have been benefiting big tech companies, with many experiencing steady growth despite the global economic downturn. Amazon is hiring 100,000 warehouse workers, and Facebook and Microsoft are seeing increased demand for video calling and online collaboration services. Streaming services like Netflix and YouTube are gaining new audiences, and companies are shifting to cloud computing to meet the surge in remote work. The pandemic has deepened reliance on tech services, and experts predict that big tech companies will emerge from the crisis stronger than ever.

site_title: Manulife US Reit blames price fall on fund sell-off, private bank margin calls
summary: Manulife US Reit's units have fallen 30% year-to-date, largely due to mass selling by index funds and exchange-traded funds, margin calls from private banks, and increased fund redemption and switching amid rising US Covid-19 volatility. This is in line with the FTSE ST Reit Index's 27% retreat, but steeper than the Straits Times Index's decline. Reits in the US are down about 40% year-to-date. The Reit's manager attributes the decline to these factors, which have "wiped out four years of work".

images.alt_text: Jill Smith, CEO of the Reit manager, says the sponsor is limited in its ability to buy back units to bolster prices, given the regulation which disallows any unitholder from holding more than a 9.8 per cent stake in the Reit. The sponsor already owns 8.6 per cent of the Reit.

site_title: MOM unveils more measures to help firms cope with Covid-19
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower announced measures to help companies cope with the Covid-19 outbreak, including a three-month extension of levy payment timelines for SMEs, a levy waiver for foreign workers on overseas leave, and a refund for construction firms affected by disruptions. Firms with excess manpower are urged to retain locals and consider transferring foreign workers to other employers facing labor shortages. These measures aim to cushion the impact of the pandemic on businesses.

site_title: WHO needs to take on bigger role in global fight against Covid-19
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is urged to take a more significant role in the global fight against COVID-19 due to the fragmented and politicized efforts to combat the pandemic. The WHO's lack of centralized leadership has hindered effective communication and hindered international cooperation, resulting in suboptimal responses. A multilateral strategy, detached from national and political interests, is deemed crucial to combat COVID-19. The WHO's establishment of a Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) Vaccine Deployment Initiative in 2009 set a positive precedent for global cooperation, but its current response is deemed inadequate, with a need for a more comprehensive and timely global response.

site_title: iFly Singapore's tenants get 6-month rental reduction
summary: iFly Singapore has announced a 20% rental reduction for six months for its food and beverage tenants at Sentosa, amid the challenging business climate due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Visitor numbers have fallen over 50% since the outbreak, impacting F&B operators who rely heavily on tourist visits. The rental reduction is part of a package that includes passing on over 230% of the property tax rebate to tenants, aiming to help them stay in business and protect jobs. This move is seen as a relief measure to support the affected tenants and partners.

site_title: On the trail of the education holy grail
summary: Ednovation, a Singapore-based education company, aims to personalize its curriculum using AI to cater to individual students' needs. The company, founded in 1991, operates a preschool and infant-care chain with over 90 centers across Singapore, China, and ASEAN. Ednovation's AI-powered program will use machine learning to adapt to students' learning pace and style, helping them master technology and develop essential skills. The company's goal is to become a one-to-one learning experience, making education more accessible and effective. Ednovation's expansion plans include exploring markets in Indonesia, Vietnam, and India, with Enterprise Singapore supporting their efforts.

images.alt_text: "If you can have such a model of different ways of learning math, the different topics and different methods, you can imagine having an intelligent system that can actually help children navigate and learn at their own pace, in their own way. I believe that is the holy grail for AI in education." - Richard Yen, founder of Ednovation.
Students from ChildFIrst are required to show off their coding chops, in the form of a robot dance before they graduate.

site_title: US new home sales slower but strong in February before virus
summary: US new home sales decreased 4.4% to an annual rate of 765,000 in February, seasonally adjusted, despite low mortgage costs and a tight supply. The median sales price rose to $345,900. Economists warn that the damage from the coronavirus pandemic will become evident in March and April sales figures. Experts predict a significant slowdown in activity, with the ground lost now unlikely to be recovered quickly, according to Ian Shepherdson of Pantheon Macroeconomics.

site_title: Nudging students to rebut privacy violations
summary: Singapore aims to build a viable AI ecosystem by engaging students in both the opportunities and risks of AI. The country's Personal Data Protection Act and AI governance framework provide guidelines for organizations to deploy AI responsibly. However, more needs to be done to build trust in AI technology, as seen in cases like Cambridge Analytica. Educators can use historical context and scholars like Max Weber and Emile Durkheim to make students aware of the importance of digital surveillance and its impact on society. The long-term consequences of new AI technologies are unforeseeable, and industry dominance in AI governance regulation is a concern.

site_title: SIA cabin crew to see average pay shrink by up to 70%
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will implement measures to cut costs amid the COVID-19 pandemic, including a 70% pay cut for cabin crew and a 55-50-15% pay cut for pilots. The airline will also ground 138 planes and suspend most of its network. SIA staff will be allowed to work for other companies during their no-pay leave or furlough periods. The measures, agreed upon with unions, aim to save jobs and reduce costs, with the airline's CEO taking a 30% salary cut.

site_title: Thailand imposes state of emergency to tackle virus
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha has declared a state of emergency for a month, starting March 26, to combat the novel coronavirus outbreak. The decree grants him broad powers to impose curbs on everyday life, including social distancing measures, to reduce the spread of the virus. Confirmed cases have surged to over 800, with four fatalities reported. The government has announced a package of initiatives worth 117 billion baht to help mitigate the impact of the crisis, including cash handouts and soft loans for workers and small firms.

site_title: US screenwriter donates medical supplies from Netflix series to healthcare workers
summary: Award-winning US screenwriter Ryan Murphy has donated medical supplies from the set of his Netflix series "Pose" to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The supplies, which include elastic bandages, were used in hospital scenes and are valued but not disclosed. Murphy's donation follows a week of similar efforts by other industry professionals, including Shonda Rhimes and Greg Berlanti, to support healthcare workers.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality gets notice of default on US$341m loan; delays payout
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has received a notice of default and acceleration on a US$341 million loan from Bank of America, citing non-payment of rent by master lessees due to the coronavirus pandemic. As a result, the lenders have accelerated the loan, and the trust's distribution to stapled security holders has been delayed. EHT's issue managers are seeking professional advice and engaging with lenders to negotiate a consensual strategy for operating the trust amid the pandemic. The trust's portfolio comprises 18 hotels across the US, which are experiencing reduced occupancy levels.

site_title: Remembering the seafarers during Covid-19
summary: Singapore has implemented measures to restrict crew and passenger changes for vessels arriving from countries with high Covid-19 cases, but the global maritime transport industry is calling for governments to facilitate crew changes to keep trade moving. Industry leaders emphasize that 90% of global trade relies on commercial shipping, and that seafarers need exemptions to travel to and from their ships to maintain supply chains. The industry representatives urge governments to treat seafarers as key workers and provide necessary exemptions to prevent disruptions to global trade.

site_title: Shipping industry urges G20 to keep freight flowing as virus hits supply chains
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping and International Association of Ports and Harbors urged the G20 to allow merchant shipping to flow freely, despite the coronavirus shutdown, to prevent supply chain disruptions. Ships and crews face quarantine restrictions, lockdowns, and minimal port access, affecting the delivery of food, medicine, and key commodities. G20 leaders will convene a video conference to discuss the crisis, while finance ministers and central bankers agreed to develop an action plan to respond to the outbreak, which is expected to trigger a global recession.

site_title: Hmlet co-founder Zenos Schmickrath leaves company
summary: Zenos Schmickrath, co-founder of Singapore-based co-living operator Hmlet, has left the company to pursue his next entrepreneurship opportunity. Although Schmickrath remains a shareholder, Hmlet CEO Yoan Kamalski confirmed his departure in a statement. The departure comes as the company is shifting towards an "asset-light model" to improve its bottom line, having recently raised over $40 million in funding.

site_title: Prudential continues to 'actively evaluate' options for listing of US unit amid Covid-19
summary: Prudential is 'actively evaluating' listing options for its US unit Jackson National Life amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The move comes after billionaire activist Daniel Loeb called for separation of Prudential's Asian and US businesses. The company aims to diversify its business mix and strengthen its standalone capital position while retaining its strong credit rating. Prudential shares closed flat at US$18.70, despite the announcement. The company's CEO, Mike Wells, cited pursuing an independent Jackson as a strategic priority.

site_title: Budget 2.0: Economists favour job-saving aid over direct cash handouts
summary: Economists in Singapore favor job-saving measures over direct cash handouts to households during the COVID-19 recession. The government's second support package, set to be unveiled on Thursday, may focus on business support and targeted relief for at-risk segments. Analysts warn that a blanket handout could be ineffective, and instead, a targeted approach to companies with severe cash flow problems or gig workers would be more effective. Some economists also propose a clawback mechanism to avoid passing the burden to future generations.

site_title: India shuts down for 21 days as coronavirus spreads across south Asia
summary: India has implemented a 21-day nationwide lockdown due to the rapid spread of the coronavirus, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi ordering citizens to stay at home from March 25. The lockdown, aimed at halting the spread of the virus, affects all air and train travel, businesses, and schools. With over 482 cases reported, India is bracing for a potential surge in infections, with health officials warning that over a million people could be infected by mid-May. The lockdown is part of a growing response across South Asia to combat the pandemic.

site_title: New York Philharmonic cancels rest of season
summary: The New York Philharmonic has cancelled the remainder of its season due to the coronavirus pandemic, anticipating a US$10 million loss in revenue. The orchestra's endowment has declined by 14% since the crisis began. Musicians' pay will be reduced in stages, affecting the organization's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Jaap van Zweden leads the New York Philharmonic in New York on Dec 5, 2019. Deborah Borda, the Philharmonic's president and chief executive, said patrons would be encouraged not to seek refunds for their tickets to cancelled performances, which add up to about US$1 million in revenue.

site_title: Odette keeps top spot at Asia's 50 Best Restaurants awards
summary: Odette, a three-Michelin-starred Singapore restaurant, retained its top spot at the 2020 Asia's 50 Best Restaurants list for the second consecutive year. The ceremony was cancelled due to the COVID-19 outbreak and announced via a low-key video stream. Singapore restaurants also performed well, with Burnt Ends rising to fifth place and Les Amis shooting up to 11th. The awards come as the restaurant industry worldwide struggles due to the pandemic, with many restaurants forced to close temporarily or permanently.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 31.26 points to 1,291.14. The market saw a significant increase in volume, with 3.2 billion lots worth RM2.2 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 756 to 155.

site_title: Coronavirus sinks US business activity to record low
summary: US business activity contracted to a record low in March due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the manufacturing and services sectors experiencing significant declines. The IHS Markit US Composite Output Index fell to 40.5, an all-time low, and economists predict further economic contraction. The number of Americans filing unemployment claims surged to a two-and-a-half year high, and the Federal Reserve rolled out new programs to support the economy. Economists believe the US is likely already in a recession that will deepen further.

site_title: Instagram steps up effort to curb Covid-19 disinformation
summary: Instagram is ramping up efforts to combat Covid-19 misinformation, with plans to display educational messages connecting users to World Health Organisation and local health resources. Verified coronavirus information will be marked with stickers, and non-credible health claims will be removed. The platform will also offer links to donations for nonprofit organisations and provide tips for social distancing. This initiative follows similar efforts by Facebook on its core platforms and other social media services, aiming to deliver verified information and stop the spread of misinformation.

images.alt_text: Instagram said Tuesday it was ramping up efforts to promote reliable content about the coronavirus pandemic and stop the spread of misinformation on the image-centric social network.

site_title: Singapore lends assistance to Philippines to fight Covid-19
summary: Singapore has donated 3,000 diagnostic tests and one PCR machine to the Philippines to aid in the fight against Covid-19. The donation was made following a phone call between Singapore's Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong and the Philippine Secretary of Health Francisco Duque III. The handover was made by Singapore Ambassador Gerard Ho to the Philippine Secretary of Foreign Affairs Teodoro L Locsin Jr. This move aims to support the Philippines in containing the pandemic and reflects Singapore's commitment to regional cooperation in the face of the crisis.

images.alt_text: Singapore Ambassador to the Philippines Gerard Ho handed over the supplies to Philippine Secretary of Foreign Affairs Teodoro L Locsin Jr on Tuesday at the Department of Foreign Affairs in Manila.

site_title: Six-month rental reduction for iFly Singapore's tenants amid challenging business climate
summary: iFly Singapore has announced a 20% rental reduction for six months for its F&B tenants at Sentosa, amid a challenging business climate due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The reduction applies to tenants like Bistro At iFly, Marrybrown, McDonald's, and Toast and Curry. The move aims to help tenants stay in business and protect jobs, with iFly passing on 230% of property tax rebates to provide substantial relief.

site_title: STI has another 'Turnaround Tuesday', closes 5.8% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 5.8% higher on "Turnaround Tuesday", its best session since April 2009. The rebound was driven by the US Federal Reserve's move to unlimited quantitative easing and further lending to US SMEs. A weaker US dollar and news of Chinese authorities lifting travel restrictions also contributed to the gains. Asian equities, including South Korea's Kospi Index, which rose 8.6%, and Japan's Nikkei 225, which jumped 7.1%, also performed well.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 to be rescheduled to no later than summer 2021
summary: The Tokyo 2020 Olympics have been postponed to no later than summer 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. This marks the first time in the Olympics' 124-year history that the Games have been postponed, with the event still retaining its name "Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games". The IOC and Japanese officials agreed to reschedule the event to safeguard athlete and public health, with the Olympic flame to remain in Japan.

site_title: GYP Properties shutters New Zealand retail centre, halts development activities
summary: GYP Properties, a New Zealand retail centre owner, shutters Pakuranga Plaza for four weeks due to the COVID-19 alert level being raised to 4. The company also halted development activities for two projects, Remarkables Residences in Queenstown and Bellfield project in Papakura. This decision comes as the government announced non-essential businesses will close for four weeks. GYP Properties will tap into government economic response package measures and comply with measures rolled out. The company's shares closed flat, and the extent of financial impact is not possible to ascertain at the moment.

site_title: Singapore shuts all bars and entertainment venues as authorities step up measures against Covid-19
summary: Singapore authorities have shut down all bars and entertainment venues, and cancelled events until April 30, as part of tightened measures to combat the spread of Covid-19. The closures will be effective from March 26. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the world is facing a "different reality" with workplaces and shops closed, and people asked to stay at home. The move aims to minimize further spread of the virus.

site_title: Full-year profit falls 65% at Tan Chong International due to poor vehicle sales
summary: Tan Chong International, a car company, reported a 65% decline in net profit to HK$212.93 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2019, due to lower vehicle sales in key markets. Revenue decreased 7.6% to HK$14.53 billion, mainly due to a 16% reduction in motor vehicle sales. The company expects vehicle sales to be further impacted by global issues, but will invest in its motor and commercial vehicle businesses.

site_title: British supermarkets limit customers to enforce social distancing
summary: British supermarkets, including Waitrose and Morrisons, are limiting customer numbers to enforce social distancing during the coronavirus outbreak. The move follows Prime Minister Boris Johnson's order for Britons to stay at home to halt the spread of the virus. Supermarkets will use a "one in, one out" policy and install screens at checkouts to shield customers and staff. All supermarkets are also asking customers to pay with card instead of cash to help contain the spread of the virus, which has killed 336 people in Britain and infected over 6,600.

site_title: Will Boris Johnson win high-stakes coronavirus gamble?
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is under pressure to deliver on his high-stakes gamble to contain the coronavirus outbreak, with a series of "lockdown" restrictions imposed on citizens. Despite growing concerns, public opinion appears to still support Johnson, with 49% believing the government is tackling the crisis well. However, experts warn that Johnson's strategy, designed to spread the outbreak over a longer period, could backfire, overwhelming the National Health Service. Johnson's leadership is also at risk due to his history of high-risk, outlier approaches, including his Brexit strategy. A successful containment of the outbreak could have a displacement effect on his wider political agenda, including his "infrastructure revolution" and Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Puma sets short-time work for 1,400 staff
summary: German sportswear company Puma has announced that 1,400 staff will switch to shorter work hours until April 13 due to the coronavirus pandemic. Employees will work half their usual hours but will still receive their full salary. The company's top executives, including CEO Bjorn Gulden and finance chief Michael Laemmermann, will waive their April salaries. This move comes as sales slump due to the crisis, and Puma has abandoned its 2020 guidance.

site_title: Thakral Corp raises S$5.8 million from sale of retail building in Japan
summary: Thakral Corp raised S$5.8 million from the sale of its 6,588 square foot retail building in Osaka, Japan. The sale of the Nambanaka Thakral Building, redeveloped into a three-storey retail building, yielded a net profit of about S$6.1 million. The funds will be used to pay debt taken up by Thakral Japan Properties to invest in Thakral Umeda Properties. The disposal is in line with the group's strategy to unlock value from investment properties in Japan, with a cap rate of 3.6%.

site_title: UK's Heathrow Airport says weekly cargo movements surge
summary: Heathrow Airport in the UK expects a 53% surge in weekly cargo movements next week, driven by increased imports of medical supplies and equipment to combat the coronavirus. As passenger flights are grounded, the airport is scaling up its cargo operation to meet the demand. The cargo rise is compared to the usual weekly average and is expected to include imports of medicines, vaccines, sanitizers, syringes, and respirators.

site_title: Japan central bank loses billions on ETFs, may face annual loss
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has acknowledged unrealised losses of 2-3 trillion yen (S$26.36 billion to S$39.54 billion) on its exchange-traded fund (ETF) holdings due to a rout in Japanese stock prices. This could be the first annual loss in nearly 40 years, constraining the BOJ's attempts to prop up market sentiment. The central bank's financial health is tied to Japanese stock prices, and analysts warn that further market falls could lead to the BOJ running out of reserves and becoming insolvent.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) on Tuesday acknowledged unrealised losses of 2 to 3 trillion yen (S$26.36 billion to S$39.54 billion) on its holdings of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) after a rout in Japanese stock prices, raising the prospect it could post an annual loss this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 4.46% on Tuesday, following the Federal Reserve's massive bond-buying package to support the US economy. The Hang Seng Index closed at 22,663.49, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The rally was driven by Asia-wide advances and traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: 49 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, of which 32 are from overseas
summary: Singapore confirmed 49 new coronavirus cases on March 24, with 32 cases imported by travelers returning from abroad. The majority were Singaporean citizens or residents (25), while five were long-term visitor pass holders. The cases originated from Britain (14), the US (5), Malaysia, France, Indonesia, and Australia. This brings the total number of cases in Singapore to an undisclosed amount.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps on hopes of US$2t stimulus
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday as investors welcomed news of a potential $2 trillion economic rescue package. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 6.08%, the S&P 500 gained 4.78%, and the Nasdaq Composite climbed 4.89%. The optimism followed signs that Washington was nearing a deal, lifting market hopes and reversing the biggest selloff since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on Fed's QE boost; NZ posts record daily gain
summary: Australian shares jumped 4.2% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 5.6% drop the previous day, following the US Federal Reserve's massive support measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The Reserve Bank of Australia also pumped A$6.88 billion into the financial system. In New Zealand, the benchmark index surged 7.2%, its biggest daily percentage gain ever, as retail banks offered a six-month principal and interest payment holiday for affected customers.

site_title: MOM introduces further measures to help companies cope with Covid-19
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has introduced new measures to help companies cope with the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. These measures include a three-month extension of the levy payment timeline for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), a levy waiver for foreign workers on overseas leave, and a Man-Year Entitlement (MYE) refund for construction firms. Firms with excess manpower are also urged to prioritize locals and consider transferring foreign workers to other employers facing labor shortages.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump at open
summary: European stocks surged at the open, driven by the US Federal Reserve's bond-buying program to support the US economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. Key indices rose: London's FTSE 100 (3.8%), Frankfurt's DAX (5.4%), Paris CAC 40 (4.2%), Madrid IBEX 35 (3.8%), and Milan FTSE MIB (5.0%). The gains came as Britain imposed a lockdown to combat Covid-19. The rally followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and despite US President Trump's new trade threats.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index rose 3.8 per cent to 5,183.12 points.

site_title: GL Limited to 'progressively' close hotels as Covid-19 hits bookings
summary: GL Limited announced that its hospitality subsidiary GLH hotels will progressively close temporarily due to the Covid-19 outbreak, except for a few to accommodate guests. The closures were prompted by a significant reduction in bookings and cancellations in Europe and the UK, as well as the UK government's call for social distancing.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 7% on weak yen, BOJ buying
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei stock index surged over 7% on Tuesday, driven by a weak yen and the Bank of Japan's aggressive asset-buying. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,092.35, while the broader Topix index rose 3.18%. A cheaper yen makes Japanese exporters more competitive abroad, boosting profits. However, market sentiment remains cautious, with investors awaiting a sign of the end to the outbreak.

site_title: Qantas probed over allegedly using crisis to try to sink rival
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog is investigating Qantas for allegedly engaging in anti-competitive behavior, after its CEO, Alan Joyce, suggested the government should not bail out struggling airlines. Joyce's comments were deemed "very unhelpful" by ACCC chair Rod Sims, who emphasized the importance of maintaining competition in the sector. If the allegations are substantiated, Qantas could face hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties, and the investigation is expected to proceed "very soon".

site_title: Seoul: Shares mark steepest daily gain since 2008
summary: South Korean shares surged 8.6% to their highest level since 2008, driven by the US Fed's plans on dollar funding and a 100 trillion won rescue package. The KOSPI index closed at 1,609.97, with foreigners buying 12.2 billion won worth of shares. The rally eased liquidity concerns in emerging markets.

site_title: Most of India under lockdown as coronavirus appears in small towns
summary: India has enforced lockdowns across large parts of the country, with curfews in some areas, as the coronavirus spreads from big cities to small towns. Health officials warn that over 1 million people in India could be infected by mid-May. The country has severed international flight links and domestic air services are set to stop. India has reported 485 cases and nine deaths, and concerns are growing about the spread to impoverished communities and the ability of public health sectors to cope.

site_title: First of Hong Kong's new online-only banks starts operating
summary: Hong Kong's first online-only bank, ZA Bank, a unit of China's ZhongAn Online P&C Insurance, began operating on Tuesday, marking a significant shake-up in the city's retail banking sector. Issued in March-April last year, the virtual banking licences were delayed due to anti-government protests and operational difficulties. ZA Bank offers lending and deposit services with an annual interest rate of 1% for Hong Kong dollar savings deposits, surpassing traditional players like HSBC. Other Asian markets have also issued or plan to issue new online banking licences amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Thailand to declare 1-month emergency on March 26
summary: Thailand will declare a one-month emergency on March 26 to deal with the coronavirus outbreak, giving Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha executive power to implement measures to contain the virus. The country reported 106 new cases and three deaths, bringing the total to 827 cases and four fatalities. Details of the emergency decree will be announced later, including the possibility of setting up checkpoints and granting officials extra authority.

site_title: Brewers and distilleries are hit hard by the pandemic
summary: Breweries and distilleries are heavily impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with companies like Anheuser-Busch InBev and Pernod Ricard withdrawing earnings forecasts due to bar closures and social distancing measures. Pernod predicts a 20% drop in profit, citing a quarter of its revenue comes from bars and restaurants. The industry is unlikely to see a boost from alcohol hoarding, and some companies are shifting focus to producing hand sanitizer and disinfectants. The pandemic has also led to delays in major deals, including the sale of Carlton & United Breweries to Asahi Group Holdings.

site_title: Sim Leisure enters into agreement to place out shares
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a Singapore-listed theme park developer, has entered into a subscription agreement with Tropika Kiara to issue over 13.4 million new shares. The deal is valued at S$2.92 million, with Tropika Kiara holding 17.5% of the enlarged share capital. The funds will be used for growth, expansion, and working capital. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.22, following the announcement.

site_title: Olam completes sale of remaining 50% stake in Indonesian sugar JV for US$82.5 million
summary: Olam International has completed the sale of its remaining 50% stake in Indonesian sugar joint venture Far East Agri for US$82.5 million. The sale was part of an initial consideration of between US$82.5 million and US$85 million, with US$2.5 million contingent on satisfaction of a sale-and-purchase agreement. The sale marks the end of Far East Agri's association with Olam, with the buyer, Mitr Phol Sugar, retaining a 50% stake in the venture.

site_title: US dollar slips as Fed's money bazooka raises hopes of easier cash supply
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.5% to 101.64 against the dollar index, as the US Federal Reserve announced unlimited quantitative easing and credit market support measures to ease tight funding conditions amid the coronavirus pandemic. The euro and British pound also rose, while the Australian dollar, Mexican peso, and South African rand gained more than 1%. Market players await business sentiment surveys in Europe for a glimpse of the virus's impact on the real economy.

site_title: Australia's Viva Energy sees up to 90% plunge in jet fuel demand on travel curbs
summary: Australia's Viva Energy expects a 80-90% plunge in jet fuel demand due to travel restrictions and flight cancellations. The company anticipates significant declines in aviation volumes, impacting refining intake and margins. Crude oil prices have crashed, but Viva Energy's margins may be supported by a weaker Australian dollar. The company is reviewing capital spending plans and operating costs to optimize refining operations.

site_title: Vulnerable groups get priority shopping hour at Singapore supermarkets
summary: Singapore supermarkets are introducing dedicated shopping hours for senior citizens and vulnerable groups, including those with disabilities and pregnant women, to ensure access to food and essentials during the Covid-19 outbreak. The priority hours will be held every Tuesday and Wednesday from 8am to 9am, with designated checkout queues and social distancing measures implemented across stores. Supermarkets Dairy Farm and FairPrice have announced similar initiatives, prioritizing the well-being and safety of their customers and staff.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore Airlines pilots will take seven days of compulsory no-pay leave per month due to the coronavirus pandemic. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to flatten the S$NEER slope in its upcoming review. The Singapore general insurance sector reported a S$28m underwriting loss, mainly due to increased claims. SGX waived the shareholder approval requirement for Golden Energy's A$70m JV investment. The STI index closed 5.8% higher, its best session since 2009. Internationally, Vietnam was surprised by the US tariff announcement, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Wells Fargo to pay special compensation to front-line staff amid virus outbreak
summary: Wells Fargo is paying special compensation to front-line employees amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Domestic full-time employees making less than $100,000 will receive a $600 pre-tax payment, while part-time employees will get a $300 bonus. Front-line employees will also receive an additional $200 per pay period for up to five paychecks starting April 17. The move comes as other large US banks, including Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase, have also announced similar measures to support their employees during the pandemic.

site_title: Vietnam says up to half of seafood export contracts cancelled, delayed due to coronavirus
summary: Vietnam's seafood exporters face significant challenges due to the coronavirus outbreak, with up to 50% of export contracts cancelled or delayed. This has led to a 10% decline in aquatic product exports in the first two months of 2020, resulting in a $989 million loss. The country's seafood exports, valued at $8.54 billion last year, account for 3.2% of total export earnings. With no deaths reported from the virus, Vietnam's health ministry has taken measures to mitigate the impact on the seafood industry.

site_title: Temasek's biggest shareholdings fall US$23.5b in 3 months
summary: Temasek Holdings' largest equity shareholdings have declined by approximately US$24 billion in 3 months due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Singaporean state investor's top 12 holdings and controlled companies have seen a market value drop of around one-third. This decline is concerning for Singapore, which relies on Temasek's performance to fund its budget. The expected long-term returns of Temasek and other key entities will be reassessed to determine the net investment return contribution.

site_title: Singapore bankruptcies started surging even before coronavirus hit
summary: Singapore is bracing for a surge in bankruptcies as cases rose 47% to 434 individuals in January, the highest since 2004. Companies in liquidation also increased to 287, the highest since records began in 2005. The COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the economic slowdown, with economists predicting a 0.3% shrinkage in Singapore's economy this year. The government has allocated $6.4 billion in stimulus measures, but experts warn that bad-loan costs and lending may contract due to the virus.

site_title: Italy sees second successive drop in virus deaths
summary: Italy has reported its second consecutive drop in daily COVID-19 deaths, with fatalities decreasing from 793 on Saturday to 601 on Monday. New infections also declined, falling from 6,557 on Saturday to 4,789 on Monday. Despite these drops, the country has still seen over 6,000 deaths in a month.

site_title: Jewellers in India brace for lowest sales in 25 years on virus fears
summary: India's jewellery sales are expected to plummet 30% in 2020, the lowest in 25 years, due to the coronavirus lockdown. The industry, already hit by record-high domestic prices, will see a significant decline in demand, with many stores shut until further notice. The All India Gem and Jewellery Domestic Council estimates 690 tons of jewellery sales last year, a 40% cut expected in the coming weeks. The industry is seeking relief measures, including loan extensions and reduced import tax, to mitigate the impact on thousands of small workers.

site_title: Product standards glut could pose non-tariff trade barrier: Researcher
summary: A researcher warns that Southeast Asia's non-tariff measures (NTMs) involving product standards could pose a trade barrier, increasing costs of doing business. University of Malaya professor Evelyn S. Devadason notes that NTMs, such as sanitary and phytosanitary measures, can cause delays, informal payments, and lack of proper testing and storage sites. The measures, used by countries like Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia, could hinder regional economic integration. To address the issue, policymakers should prioritize NTMs on the planning agenda to create a coherent regulatory framework and reduce conflicting standards.

site_title: Delhi's rebel gym goers risk virus to pump iron
summary: Delhi's gyms, defying government orders, continue to operate despite the coronavirus pandemic, with owners facing police action. Thousands of workout enthusiasts, prioritizing their fitness needs, risk exposure to the virus. The situation is particularly dire in crowded backstreets, with gyms packed with over 20 people waiting for a turn on 10 machines. The owners' decision to stay open has sparked concerns about public health.

site_title: China health commission says virus transmission risks remain
summary: China's National Health Commission says the country still faces risks from sporadic and overseas coronavirus infections, despite efforts to combat the virus. The commission relaxed restrictions on passengers leaving Hubei province starting from Wednesday, with Wuhan to follow in April. New infections on the Chinese mainland doubled on Monday, driven by cases from overseas. Experts note that asymptomatic patients, not included in the overall case list, may pose a risk of new outbreaks once travel restrictions ease, but are being isolated.

images.alt_text: China cannot afford to let its guard down when it comes to combating the coronavirus, with the country still at risk from sporadic infections as well as those from overseas, a health official said on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong bans non-residents amid Covid-19 outbreak, says bars can't serve alcohol
summary: Hong Kong bans non-residents for 14 days to curb a second wave of imported coronavirus cases, with bars also prohibited from serving alcohol. The city's Chief Executive Carrie Lam imposed the travel measure, halting airport transit services and increasing penalties for quarantine violators. The move comes after a surge in cases linked to social gatherings, including a wedding banquet. Lam expressed hope for voluntary compliance, but warned of legislative measures if necessary, citing the need to protect the city from the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will ban non-residents from visiting for 14 days and wants to prevent bars from serving alcohol as the city sees a second wave of imported coronavirus cases.

site_title: At Alibaba's Lazada, coronavirus measures become the latest culture conflict
summary: Lazada, the South-east Asian arm of Alibaba Group, is facing a culture conflict with its staff over coronavirus measures. Employees are upset about daily health reports and other measures seen as invasive, with some reporting frequent calls from HR even on weekends. The company has also asked staff to wear masks at work despite local guidance, and considered restricting social activities. The conflict highlights Alibaba's struggles to manage Lazada, with rapid declining morale and key executives departing. The company has made some changes, including adding a privacy protection paragraph to its health check-in program, but tensions remain.

images.alt_text: At Lazada, the South-east Asian arm of Alibaba Group, staff are furious over demands they submit health reports daily and other coronavirus-prevention steps seen as too invasive, highlighting a long-running culture clash with management from China.

site_title: South Africa orders mines to close in 21-day virus lockdown
summary: South Africa has ordered mines to close for 21 days as part of a nationwide lockdown to contain the coronavirus. The move affects the country's significant mining industry, which accounts for 75% of the world's platinum supply and 38% of palladium. Mines will be closed from midnight Thursday, with grocers, pharmacies, and banks allowed to remain open. Essential services, including the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, will continue to operate. The closure will impact mining companies' output targets and earnings, with Harmony Gold Mining Co predicting a negative impact on its production.

site_title: Parking pain: Airlines, airports hunt for storage space as pandemic idles planes
summary: Airlines and airports worldwide are facing an unprecedented parking problem as the pandemic idles thousands of aircraft. Over 5,000 planes are in storage, with many airports converting taxiways, maintenance hangars, and runways into giant parking lots. Major airlines like Qantas, Singapore Airlines, and Lufthansa are parking planes at airports and military facilities, while smaller airports are also being used for storage. The issue is expected to worsen as carriers cut flight schedules and more planes are grounded.

site_title: Hormel, Maple Leaf pay worker bonuses to keep plants going
summary: Food giants Hormel and Maple Leaf are offering cash bonuses to their plant staff in the US and Canada amid the coronavirus crisis. Cargill Inc is paying an additional $2/hour for employees completing shifts and a $500 bonus. Hormel will spend over $4 million on bonuses, with full-time workers receiving $300 and part-time workers $150. Maple Leaf is providing an additional $80/week for hourly staff. These measures aim to keep production running despite worker shortages and concerns over immigrant visas.

site_title: mm2 reports positive cash flow amid coronavirus disruptions
summary: Mainboard-listed film production company mm2 Asia reported positive cash flow despite the coronavirus disruptions affecting its core content production operations and cinema business. The company refinanced its loan facility and remains confident of meeting fiscal responsibilities. It attributes its strong core business order book to pent-up demand from China and expects a backlog of Hollywood movies to be released once the virus is contained, maintaining demand for quality content.

site_title: South Korea doubles rescue package to 100t won amid coronavirus woes
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in announced a doubling of the country's rescue package to 100 trillion won (S$115.89 billion) to combat the economic and financial impact of the coronavirus. The expanded package includes policy financing loans for small to medium-sized companies, job preservation measures, and corporate bond purchases to inject liquidity into financial markets. This move aims to mitigate the economic fallout and support the country's struggling economy amidst the pandemic.

site_title: SoftBank plans to sell US$14b in Alibaba shares: sources
summary: SoftBank plans to sell around $14 billion in Alibaba shares as part of a $41 billion fundraising effort to address business losses from the coronavirus pandemic. The sale could be part of a larger stake sale in SoftBank's telecommunications arm and Sprint. SoftBank's shares surged 21% in Tokyo, marking the largest intraday gain since listing. Founder Masayoshi Son is using Alibaba shares for shareholder returns and debt repayment, a move investors have urged for years.

site_title: DBS suspends in-person registrations for AGM amid virus outbreak
summary: DBS has suspended in-person registrations for its annual general meeting (AGM) amid the Covid-19 outbreak, following stricter measures to contain the virus. The meeting, originally scheduled for March 31, will now be held via a live webcast only. DBS had previously limited in-person attendance to 249, but the new measures have led to the cancellation of in-person registrations. The bank plans to update shareholders on revised meeting plans by Thursday.

site_title: Royal Caribbean directors step in to help with new bank loan
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises secured a US$2.2 billion one-year loan, backed by a US$100 million investment by two board members, Eyal Ofer and Arne Alexander Wilhelmsen. The loan helps the company maintain liquidity amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has severely impacted the cruise industry. With the new secured term loan facility, Royal Caribbean now has over US$3.6 billion in liquidity, enabling it to focus on its long-term plans. The company has also raised its credit capacity by US$550 million and plans to cut expenses to improve liquidity.

site_title: New York Philharmonic cancels season because of coronavirus
summary: The New York Philharmonic cancelled its remainder of the season due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a loss of $10 million in revenue and a 14% decline in its endowment. The orchestra's musicians will maintain their health benefits, but pay will be reduced in stages, with full salaries paid through March and then a base pay of $3,000 per week in April and 75% of that in May. The Philharmonic is working to reduce operating costs and preserve sales for the next season, which is expected to be strong.

site_title: US airlines draft plans for passenger flights shutdown: report
summary: US airlines are drafting plans for a potential voluntary shutdown of virtually all passenger flights due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. Industry officials and federal agencies are considering the move, which could violate some labor contracts. The White House and airlines have not made final decisions, but the shutdown would likely favor a government order due to the large number of mail and cargo shipments carried by passenger jets. No official announcement has been made yet.

site_title: Singapore general insurance sector falls into red with S$28m underwriting loss
summary: The Singapore general insurance sector recorded an underwriting loss of S$28 million in 2019, down from a profit of S$36.3 million in 2018. The main contributor to the loss was motor insurance, which incurred a 7.6% increase in claims and a S$17.4 million underwriting loss. The sector's gross written premiums grew 7.6% to S$4.1 billion, with the health insurance segment showing an upward trend in claims. The General Insurance Association of Singapore has appointed a new management committee to address the sector's challenges, including the impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Economists expect MAS to flatten S$NEER slope in upcoming review
summary: Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to flatten the slope of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band in its upcoming review, with some predicting a re-centring of the policy band to boost the economy. Analysts from major banks, including OCBC, UOB, HSBC, and Standard Chartered, expect a softer S$NEER, while others anticipate a downward re-centring of the band by up to 2%. MAS will release its six-monthly monetary policy statement on March 30, which is earlier than expected.

site_title: Trump considers reopening US economy over health experts' objections
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering reopening the economy despite health experts' objections, citing the economic pain caused by shutdowns. The US has already seen stay-at-home orders for over 100 million Americans, with Britain and several US states locking down their economies. Trump's move is seen as a departure from the consensus among government leaders and health officials that the best way to defeat the virus is through restrictions.

images.alt_text: As the United States entered week two of trying to contain the spread of the coronavirus by shuttering large swaths of the economy, President Donald Trump, Wall Street executives and many conservative economists began questioning whether the government had gone too far and should instead lift restrictions that are already inflicting deep pain on workers and businesses.

site_title: China to lift travel curbs on Hubei province, including Wuhan
summary: China has lifted lockdown restrictions on over 50 million people in central Hubei province, including Wuhan, after two months of curbs. Residents can leave the province starting Tuesday if healthy, while Wuhan will end restrictions on April 8. However, people with a "green" health code are required to travel in or out of the region. The number of imported cases has surged, with 74 new cases reported nationwide, fueling concerns about a second wave of infections.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as Federal Reserve unveils 'game changer' support measures
summary: The Federal Reserve unveiled a massive bond-buying program to support the US economy, marking an unprecedented monetary experiment. Asian markets surged, with Tokyo up 6.7%, Seoul 6%, Hong Kong and Singapore 4%, and Wellington and Taipei 5%. The greenback sank against major peers, lifting crude prices. The US dollar's weakness also lifted equities in Asia, despite the US Congress' gridlock on a $2 trillion rescue package. Analysts described the Fed's move as a "game changer" and "unprecedented monetary experiment in the history of financial markets."

site_title: California governor says state needs 50,000 more hospital beds
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom announced the state needs 50,000 additional hospital beds to accommodate a surge in coronavirus patients predicted by computer modeling. The governor ordered the closure of all state parking lots due to gatherings despite a stay-at-home order. Newsom also sought to purchase 200 million pieces of protective gear for healthcare workers.

site_title: Spanish soldiers find bodies in retirement homes
summary: Spanish soldiers have found elderly patients abandoned and sometimes dead at retirement homes amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Dozens of deaths have been recorded at facilities across the country, with the army deployed to help disinfect them. An investigation has been launched, and officials have vowed to take action, with the Defence Minister stating that those found to be abandoning the elderly will be held accountable. The temporary morgue at a Madrid shopping mall has been set up to cope with the surge in cases, and a nearby field hospital has been converted to treat coronavirus patients.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.21% to 1,275.07, with 175 gainers beating 46 losers. Volume reached 67.26 million lots worth RM25.49 million.

site_title: Macau announces new restrictions on Hong Kong, China visitors
summary: Macau's leader Ho Iat Seng announced new restrictions on visitors from the Chinese mainland, Hong Kong, and Taiwan who have traveled overseas in the past 14 days. Those who have not traveled abroad will still face a 14-day quarantine. The former Portuguese colony has 25 confirmed coronavirus cases and has previously banned foreign visitors and non-resident workers. The restrictions aim to curb the spread of the virus, which has affected Macau's tourism industry heavily.

site_title: Tipping goes virtual as coronavirus decimates US restaurant jobs
summary: The US restaurant industry is shifting to virtual tipping as the coronavirus pandemic decimates jobs. Former employees are using Google spreadsheets to collect tips for out-of-work waiters and bartenders via payment apps. Organizers are also using online platforms like GoFundMe to raise money for restaurants and venues. While some see it as a heartwarming gesture, others view it as a necessity for survival, as government bailouts are delayed. The reliance on virtual tipping highlights the financial struggles faced by US service workers, who rely heavily on tips for income.

site_title: China's factories work 24/7 to build ventilators for Milan, New York
summary: China's factories, including Aeonmed Co, are working around the clock to build ventilators for countries hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. With over 40,000 orders waiting, the factories have reached maximum capacity and are expected to continue producing until May. The global demand for ventilators is skyrocketing, with the US needing 30,000 and Italy facing a severe shortage, with doctors having to triage patients. Chinese companies are capitalizing on the demand, with the country's main manufacturers delivering over 14,000 ventilators to Hubei, the region where the outbreak originated.

site_title: Bank of Thailand may cut policy rate again as virus risks mount
summary: The Bank of Thailand may cut its benchmark interest rate again by 25 basis points to 0.50% on Wednesday, following a surprise rate cut last week to mitigate the coronavirus outbreak's economic impact. A Reuters poll shows a slim majority of economists expect this move, with some forecasting two more rate cuts in Q2 and Q3. The rate cut comes as Thailand's economy faces challenges, including a heavy reliance on Chinese tourists and trade, and a drought that has already hit growth last year.

site_title: South Korea: Shares bounce back from plunge, triggering sidecar limits
summary: South Korean shares surged more than 6% on Tuesday, triggered by US Federal Reserve's new support measures. The benchmark KOSPI index rose 93.79 points to 1,576.25, while the won strengthened and bond yields fell. This rebound follows a 5.11% decline on Monday. The extraordinary support measures bolstered investor sentiment, leading to a sharp bounce in the market.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as stimulus bill stalls in Senate
summary: US stocks plummeted 3.0% on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average sinking 600 points to 18,591.93, amid stalled stimulus package discussions in the Senate. The Federal Reserve announced emergency measures, including unlimited Treasury debt purchases and direct lending to small businesses. Despite the Fed's efforts, analysts expect markets to remain volatile until the US economy stabilizes amidst the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Hand-washing: a luxury millions of Yemenis can't afford
summary: Millions in war-ravaged Yemen lack access to clean water and hand-washing facilities, making them vulnerable to the spread of COVID-19. The country's healthcare system, already strained by five years of conflict, is at risk of collapse. Nearly 18 million people, including 9.2 million children, lack regular access to safe water, and only one-third of the population has piped water. The UN warns that the introduction of COVID-19 in Yemen could overwhelm hospitals and health facilities, exacerbating the humanitarian crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 3% at the start of trade on Tuesday, following the Federal Reserve's pledge to increase bond-buying to support the US economy during the virus crisis. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.44%, while China's Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.83%. The rally was seen as a positive response to the Fed's efforts to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Australian coronavirus cases leap as lockdown broadens
summary: Australia reported its highest daily rise in coronavirus cases, with 149 new cases in New South Wales, bringing the state total to 818 and the national toll to 1,886. The national death toll remains at seven. The country is on the verge of a full lockdown, with schools remaining open but parents advised to keep their children home. Authorities are enforcing self-isolation requirements with harsh penalties, and the economy is expected to suffer, with unemployment rates predicted to exceed 11%.

site_title: New-wave home flippers halt purchases with market in turmoil
summary: Companies specializing in "iBuying" home flipping, such as Zillow and Opendoor, are halting purchases due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on the real estate market. Zillow has stopped buying homes to preserve capital and protect employees, while Opendoor and Redfin Corp have also reduced their operations. The companies' high-tech model, which involves buying and selling homes quickly, is now facing challenges as the market becomes increasingly volatile. The halt in purchases could test the companies' ability to sell their existing inventories of homes.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust gets notice of default on US$341m loan, delays distribution
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has received a notice of default on a $341 million loan, accelerating the loan's principal amount, due to non-payment of rent by master lessees. The managers have delayed distribution to stapled security holders and will not draw on security deposits as planned. The distribution, scheduled for March 30, has been deferred pending discussions with lenders and assessment of financial implications. The managers are seeking professional advice and aim to develop a consensual strategy to protect the interests of stapled security holders.

site_title: People are still putting their mansions on the market
summary: Despite the US economic downturn and COVID-19 restrictions, some homeowners are listing their properties for sale, often with prices corresponding to a booming luxury market. Sellers cite historically low interest rates and a belief in unique market positioning as reasons for listing. Contracts are being signed, particularly for homes below $1.5 million, with first-time buyers and those seeking a home being less affected by the stock market collapse. Experts predict ongoing demand for real estate, with some sellers confident that the market will recover in the future.

site_title: Nomura invests US$25m in Singapore waste management firm Blue Planet
summary: Japanese brokerage and investment bank Nomura has invested US$25 million in Singapore waste management firm Blue Planet Environmental Solutions. Founded in 2017, Blue Planet provides waste collection, transportation, and treatment services in Asia. The funds will be used to expand its products and services in the region. This investment is part of Nomura's focus on supporting startups in the waste management sector, highlighting the growing importance of sustainable waste management in Asia.

images.alt_text: Other key investors of Blue Planet include the Neev Fund, a private equity fund created as a partnership between the State Bank of India and the UK government's Department for International Development.

site_title: Santak closes Johor factory, warns of negative impact on financials
summary: Santak Holdings has closed its Johor factory in Malaysia from March 18 to March 31 due to the movement control order, impacting the production of precision machined parts and affecting several Malaysian employees commuting to work in Singapore. The company expects a negative impact on its financial performance for the financial year ending June 30, 2020. Shares were trading flat at 8.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Compulsory no-pay leave for SIA pilots starts April amid coronavirus hit
summary: Singapore Airlines' pilots will start a compulsory no-pay leave (CNPL) of 4-7 days per month starting April 1 to save jobs amid the coronavirus crisis. Captains will take 7 days, First Officers 5 days, and Second Officers 4 days. The move, along with no flying, will result in up to 55% salary cuts for Captains and 50% for First Officers. The airline has also implemented sweeping capacity cuts of 96% and taken other cost-cutting measures to conserve cash and shore up liquidity.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) pilots will be placed on compulsory no-pay leave (CNPL) of between four and seven days a month starting Apr 1 as the airline and its unions work together to save jobs in what has been described as an unprecedented crisis for global aviation.

site_title: Gold rises over 1% as Federal Reserve ramps up support measures
summary: Gold prices rose over 1% on Tuesday, following a near 4% jump in the previous session, as the US Federal Reserve announced unprecedented measures to support the economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. Spot gold climbed 1.7% to $1,578.83 per ounce, with US gold futures rising 1.6% to $1,592.20 per ounce. The Fed will back purchases of corporate bonds, backstop direct loans to companies, and roll out a program to get credit to small and medium-sized businesses, boosting Asian shares.

site_title: Fast food closures sweep UK, as even drive-thrus deemed unsafe
summary: The UK has shut down all fast food restaurants, including McDonald's, KFC, Starbucks, and Subway, due to the coronavirus pandemic. Prime Minister Boris Johnson ordered the closures, citing rising global urgency to stop the virus. The move reflects the severity of the situation and the need for drastic measures to slow the spread of the virus.

site_title: BreadTalk cuts employee salaries amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: BreadTalk Group has implemented temporary salary cuts of 10-50% for employees amid the coronavirus outbreak. Senior management executives will take a 30-50% pay cut, while middle management executives in Asean countries will receive a 10-15% cut. The measures will impact approximately 1,840 employees in China and Hong Kong, saving the company about S$1.4 million per month. The pay cuts were implemented after other cost-saving measures, including no-pay leave and reduced operating hours, were taken.

site_title: Japan to strengthen monitoring against improper trading activity: Aso
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) plans to strengthen monitoring against improper trading activity amid market volatility. Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the FSA will work with the securities watchdog and stock exchanges to monitor and strictly deal with fraudulent activities, such as short selling. This move aims to prevent and address improper trading practices.

images.alt_text: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) will strengthen monitoring against improper trading activity given heightened market volatility, Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open after Wall Street rout; STI up 3.7%
summary: Singapore shares rose 3.7% at Tuesday's open, rebounding from the largest single-day fall since 2008. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 83.64 points to 2,317.12, with gains outnumbering losses 150 to 40. Banking stocks led the recovery, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank up 3.1%, 2.8%, and 4.1% respectively. The rebound follows a weak Wall Street close on Monday, where the Dow Jones fell 3% amid partisan bickering over a stimulus package.

site_title: China's imported virus cases spike as fears grow of second wave
summary: China reported 78 new COVID-19 cases, with 74 being imported from overseas, sparking fears of a second wave. Seven more people died, all in Wuhan, bringing the total death toll to 3,277. The imported cases are the highest since March and nearly double those reported on Monday. Cities are imposing quarantine measures on new arrivals, and Beijing-bound flights are being diverted for screening. The National Health Commission warned of a second wave of infections, citing "inadequate quarantine measures" as a major concern.

site_title: SPH scraps purchase of Canada aged-care assets on Covid-19 'instabilities'
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) will not proceed with its $244.5 million acquisition of six senior housing properties in Canada due to global market instabilities caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The deal, announced last month, was expected to complete by May. The termination of the agreement will not impact SPH's consolidated net tangible assets or earnings per share for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2020. This decision follows SPH's earlier plan to purchase five aged-care assets in Japan, with three completed and two expected to finish in April.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia pumps liquidity, proposes bond buys to ease financial conditions
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia injected A$6.9 billion into the financial system and announced plans to buy A$4 billion in government bonds to ease economic conditions amid the coronavirus pandemic. The bank has since March 12 flooded the system with nearly A$65 billion cash, aiming to keep short-term yields around 0.25%. A recession is still inevitable, with economists forecasting a 3.5% contraction in the June quarter and an unemployment rate of 11.1% by then.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank injected A$6.9 billion (S$5.92 billion) into the financial system on Tuesday and said it would buy A$4 billion in government bonds as it looks to blunt the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Pharma firm Anges and Osaka University to begin testing coronavirus vaccine on animals
summary: Japanese biopharmaceutical firm Anges Inc and Osaka University have completed development of a COVID-19 prophylactic DNA vaccine. The vaccine will be tested in animals soon, following over 350,000 global coronavirus infections and 15,000 deaths. This development comes as the world struggles to combat the pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on Federal Reserve support; New Zealand jumps
summary: Australian shares rose 2.6% to 4,657.7 on Tuesday, regaining some losses from the previous session, following the US Federal Reserve's pledge to stabilize the financial system with unlimited quantitative easing. The Reserve Bank of Australia also pumped A$6.88 billion into the financial system. New Zealand shares rose 4% to 8,838.1, driven by a 21.1% gain in SKY Network Television. The World Health Organization reported over 300,000 coronavirus cases worldwide, with Australia's cases topping 1,600.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Tuesday, regaining some of the sharp losses from the previous session, as a pledge by the US Federal Reserve to spend whatever it took to stabilise the financial system lifted sentiment even though the boost may be short-lived.

site_title: SGX waives shareholder approval requirement for Golden Energy's A$70m JV investment
summary: Golden Energy and Resources will not require shareholder approval for its A$70 million investment in a joint venture to acquire the Ravenswood gold mine in Australia, following a waiver from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The waiver granted Golden Energy the flexibility to consult SGX on investments beyond the initial A$70 million. The investment is supported by Golden Energy's 86.9% majority shareholder PT Dian Swastatika Sentosa.

site_title: Facebook lowers video quality in Latin America, following Europe
summary: Facebook is lowering video streaming quality in Latin America to alleviate network congestion amid the coronavirus outbreak, following similar measures in Europe. The company will temporarily reduce bit rates for videos on Facebook and Instagram in the region. This move is part of efforts by social media platforms and internet service providers to manage bandwidth constraints. Other affected platforms include Netflix, YouTube, and Amazon, which have also lowered video quality in Europe. The goal is to ensure internet access remains available to those working from home.

site_title: SIIC Environment, Metech make C-suite appointments
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings appointed Tang Congliang as its new CFO, replacing Xu Zhan, effective March 23. Meanwhile, Metech International appointed Clement Tay as executive director and CEO, replacing Simon Eng, who stepped down on March 3 due to a new business direction. The appointments were announced in regulatory updates on Monday. SIIC Environment shares closed down 4.9% to 19.5 cents, while Metech shares fell 3.7% to 13 cents.

site_title: 'Help us fight this': New Zealand PM Ardern appeals ahead of coronavirus lockdown
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has appealed to citizens to help fight the coronavirus pandemic ahead of a nationwide lockdown. The country has 102 confirmed cases, with two local transmission cases, and is implementing self-isolation for everyone, shutting all non-essential services and schools for a month. Ardern believes the lockdown gives New Zealand a chance to beat the virus, but emphasizes that individual actions are crucial to its success.

site_title: Trump praises Federal Reserve's Powell for 'really good job'
summary: US President Donald Trump praised Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell for his "really good job" in addressing the coronavirus pandemic's economic impact. Trump previously criticized Powell, but now commended the Fed's measures, including slashing interest rates to zero and buying unlimited government debt. Trump also acknowledged the strong US dollar, which he noted makes trade "much tougher," but praised its value. The shift in tone marks a significant change in Trump's stance on the Fed and its policies.

site_title: World's back office scrambles to stay online as India locks down
summary: India's lockdown has disrupted the country's $181 billion outsourcing industry, with companies such as UBS, Deutsche Bank, and Infosys scrambling to ensure their Indian staff can continue working remotely. Industry group Nasscom is working with clients to classify back office work as essential services, allowing staff to work from offices if needed. However, concerns over data security and privacy are hindering progress, with many firms requesting clients to relax non-disclosure agreements. The situation poses significant challenges for banks and finance firms, which rely on India's data centers for operations.

images.alt_text: Companies in India are scrambling to ensure that the millions who staff the back offices of Wall Street banks and take on work outsourced by firms from airlines to insurers can keep going as the nation mandates increased work from home amid a spike in coronavirus cases.

site_title: China's Jan-Feb pork imports surge 158% on pre-holiday stocking
summary: China's pork imports surged 158% in January-February to 560,000 tonnes, driven by pre-holiday stocking ahead of the Lunar New Year. This comes despite a sharp slowdown in frozen goods clearing at ports due to the coronavirus epidemic. China faces a severe pork shortage due to the African swine fever, which devastated its hog herd in 2019, reducing sow inventory by up to 60%. The surge in imports may alleviate the shortage but highlights the challenges China faces in meeting its pork demand.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks close down 5%
summary: Brazil's Sao Paulo stock exchange closed down 5.2% on Monday, extending recent losses amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Ibovespa index plummeted over 7% in midday trading before recovering some ground. This marks a 47% loss since its all-time high on January 23, when China placed Wuhan under quarantine.

site_title: US prosecutors charge PDVSA contractor with money laundering
summary: US prosecutors have charged Leonardo Santilli, a Venezuelan oilfield contractor, with money laundering for bribing PDVSA officials to win overpriced contracts. Santilli allegedly received nearly $150 million from PDVSA-controlled joint ventures between 2014 and 2017, then sought to hide the proceeds in US bank accounts. Authorities seized $44.7 million of his funds in 2018. The charges are part of a US investigation into corruption at PDVSA, which has contributed to Venezuela's humanitarian crisis.

site_title: Cyber security startup Horangi snags US$20m led by Provident Growth
summary: Cybersecurity startup Horangi has secured US$20 million in a Series B round led by Provident Growth, a South-east Asia-focused private equity firm. Existing investors Monk's Hill Ventures, Right Click Capital, and Genesis Alternative Ventures also participated. The funding will be used to expand in South-east Asia and enhance its cloud-security product, Warden, by integrating AI and machine-learning technologies to combat advanced threats. This brings Horangi's total funds raised to US$23.1 million.

site_title: Canada, Australia quit Tokyo 2020 Olympics
summary: Canada and Australia have quit the Tokyo 2020 Olympics due to the coronavirus crisis, citing concerns for athlete health. The decision comes as the International Olympic Committee and Japanese government consider postponing the Games for the first time in history. The Olympics were initially set for July 24-Aug 9, with over $12 billion invested by host Japan and significant sponsorship and broadcasting stakes at risk.

site_title: Japan government appoints ex-Norinchukin exec Miyazono as GPIF head
summary: Japan has appointed Masataka Miyazono, a former Norinchukin Bank executive, as the new head of its $1.5 trillion Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest pension fund. This move aims to enhance the GPIF's investment strategy and manage its massive size.

site_title: Grocery delivery service Instacart to add 300,000 'shoppers'
summary: Grocery delivery service Instacart plans to add 300,000 'shoppers' in the next three months to meet soaring demand for grocery delivery amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company aims to double its ranks of full-service shoppers, following similar announcements by Amazon and Walmart.
