Instacart's order volume in North America has surged by over 150% compared to last year, with customers placing larger orders. The move is seen as an opportunity for those looking for flexible earnings during the crisis, with some benefits offered to Instacart shoppers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, DBS, SPH, SIIC, Golden Energy
summary: Singapore Airlines shares fell 11% after announcing a raft of cost-cutting measures to increase liquidity. DBS shares dropped 7% as the bank appointed new board members. Singapore Press Holdings canceled a $244.5 million Canadian property acquisition due to Covid-19 market instability. BreadTalk Group temporarily reduced executive pay amid the pandemic. SIIC Environment Holdings appointed a new CFO, while Metech International appointed a new executive director and CEO. Golden Energy and Resources secured a waiver to invest in an Australian gold mine without shareholder approval. UMS Holdings closed its Malaysian factory due to movement control orders, while Frencken Group received approval to continue operations.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on weak yen, Bank of Japan buying
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index surged 4.91% to 17,716.55 in early trade, boosted by a weak yen and the Bank of Japan's aggressive asset-buying. The dollar was trading at 110.91 yen, down from 111.26 yen in New York, making Japanese exporters more competitive abroad. The Bank of Japan's buying of ETFs also supported investor sentiment, according to senior market analyst Seiichi Suzuki. The move comes as global equity markets tumbled Monday despite fresh stimulus announcements due to the ongoing coronavirus economic toll.

site_title: Crude edges higher, US petrol slumps over 30% on sinking demand
summary: US petrol prices plummeted over 30% to a record low, reaching 41.18 cents a gallon, as global travel restrictions due to the coronavirus destroyed fuel demand. Brent crude futures rose 5 cents to $27.03 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 73 cents to $23.36 a barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to the US Senate's failure to pass an economic stimulus package and the collapse of an OPEC deal to cut oil production.

site_title: Emergency legislation 'would help builders deal with delays'
summary: Singapore's construction industry is seeking emergency legislation to help deal with delays caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The common standard form contracts in use do not specifically address pandemics as a "force majeure" event, leaving builders without grounds to modify or relax performance. Partner Derek Loh of TSMP Law Corp suggests enacting legislation to provide a legal right for contractors to adapt to unforeseen circumstances, alleviating the industry's financial burden.

site_title: South Africa orders lockdown as continent moves to stop virus spread
summary: South Africa has ordered a nationwide lockdown for 21 days, starting from midnight Thursday, to combat the spread of coronavirus, with the number of cases and deaths increasing significantly in the country. The lockdown will be enforced by soldiers and police, and is seen as a decisive measure to save millions of South Africans from infection. Other African countries, including Senegal, Ivory Coast, and DR Congo, have also declared states of emergency and implemented curfews and confinement measures to slow the spread of the virus.

site_title: Trump calls to protect Asian Americans after virus uproar
summary: US President Donald Trump called for protection of Asian Americans after facing backlash over his use of the term "Chinese virus" to describe the Covid-19 pandemic. He tweeted that Asian Americans are "amazing people" and not responsible for the virus. This tone contrasts with his previous anger over accusations of racism. The World Health Organization discourages the term due to its potential to stigmatize communities and falsely indicate that they cannot be infected.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump called on Monday for protection of Asian Americans after charges that his use of the term "Chinese virus" had aggravated a backlash.

site_title: Coronavirus dims Twitter earnings expectations
summary: Twitter has lowered its earnings expectations for the current quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on online advertising. The company now expects an operating loss and declining revenues, citing a 23% increase in daily users but a significant downturn in ad targeting. Despite the challenges, Twitter remains committed to serving the public conversation, with a 164 million daily user base and the pandemic being a main topic of conversation on the platform.

site_title: India to halt domestic passenger flights in ramp-up of virus action
summary: India will ground all domestic passenger flights starting Wednesday to combat the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. The move comes as more states order lockdowns, with over 700 million people in 30 states and territories affected. Incoming international flights are also banned for a week, and sea and river ports have been shut. Indian Railways has cancelled all services except for suburban and goods trains, and intra-state and metro services have been halted. The World Health Organisation welcomed the measures, which could help slow down virus transmission.

images.alt_text: India will ground all domestic passenger flights from Wednesday to combat the spread of the deadly new coronavirus, the government said, as more states ordered lockdowns in the world's second most populous nation.

site_title: UK government orders three-week lockdown to tackle virus
summary: The UK government has ordered a three-week lockdown to tackle the spread of coronavirus, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson urging citizens to "stay at home" to protect the National Health Service (NHS) and save lives. Non-essential shops, services, and gatherings of more than two people are banned, while essential services like shopping and exercise are allowed. The lockdown will be reviewed in three weeks, with the government seeking to "turn the tide" of the outbreak within 12 weeks.

site_title: Netherlands extends bans on public gatherings to June 1
summary: The Netherlands has extended its ban on public gatherings from April 6 to June 1 in an effort to curb the spread of COVID-19. The ban, initially set to last until April 6, was deemed necessary after large crowds were spotted at Dutch beaches. If the ban does not work, the country is preparing for a full lockdown. The decision was made by Justice Minister Ferd Grapperhaus, who acknowledged that the ban would have a significant impact on some individuals.

site_title: Flexibility without compromising on productivity
summary: The world's largest remote working experiment has been underway since the COVID-19 pandemic, with organisations that implemented the right policies and empowered workforce experiencing relatively seamless transitions. However, underprepared companies faced productivity loss due to digital file and platform inaccessibility, ineffective management approaches, and inadequate technology. The experiment has highlighted the importance of having the right technology and management strategies to support remote working. Key takeaways include the need for flexible policies, empowered workforces, and technology to maintain business continuity and productivity.

site_title: Japan government to offer bleakest economic assessment in nearly 7 years: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government is expected to issue its bleakest economic assessment in nearly 7 years in March due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on private consumption and business sentiment. The government will likely drop language describing the economy as "recovering" for the first time in six years and nine months. This assessment marks a significant downgrade, indicating a worsening economic outlook. The decision is a result of the cooling economy, which is expected to continue due to the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: Japan's government is expected to offer its bleakest economic assessment in nearly seven years in March as the coronavirus outbreak cools private consumption and business sentiment, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore, Australia deepen ties with raft of new agreements
summary: Singapore and Australia signed 10 agreements to deepen bilateral cooperation, including data innovation and the digital economy, during a virtual meeting between Prime Ministers Lee Hsien Loong and Scott Morrison. The agreements cover areas such as military training, cybersecurity, and scientific research, with the goal of expanding bilateral ties despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The partnership, established in 2015, aims to advance cooperation in all areas, including defense, trade, and technology.

site_title: Europe: Stocks back in red as virus spread feeds recession fears
summary: European shares fell 4.3% on Monday as the spread of the coronavirus fueled recession fears, with a 4.5% economic shrinkage predicted by UBS economists this year. Travel and leisure stocks underperformed, while industrials and oil and gas heavyweights saw some gains. Despite a 750 billion euro stimulus package, major car makers face production curbs and flatlining demand, and Airbus withdrew its 2020 financial forecast. The European economy appears likely to enter recession due to the lockdowns and economic disruption caused by the outbreak.

site_title: Core inflation negative in Feb; MAS to release policy decision on March 30
summary: Singapore's core inflation turned negative in February for the first time in a decade, falling to -0.1% year-on-year, below economists' predictions of 0.1%. The main drag was falling services costs, chiefly airfares and holiday expenses, amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will release its policy decision on March 30, with economists expecting significant monetary easing.

site_title: Gold falls as cash dash, strong US dollar override stimulus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,488.00 per ounce, as investors stockpiled cash amid the coronavirus pandemic and rising national lockdowns. The US dollar reached a 3-year high, overshadowing stimulus measures from global central banks. Investors are winding up their positions, citing panic and capital outflow, with the US Federal Reserve continuing to roll out emergency support.

site_title: Olympic postponement inevitable, says IOC official
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is considering a postponement of the Tokyo Olympics due to the coronavirus pandemic. Senior IOC official Dick Pound says a postponement is now inevitable and likely to be a one-year delay to 2021. The IOC will wait four weeks to announce its decision, during which time it will explore options with the Japanese government and stakeholders. A one-year postponement is seen as the most feasible option, allowing for better organization and minimizing disruption to athletes and the global sports community.

site_title: US economic rescue plan blocked again in Senate, talks continue
summary: The US Senate blocked a nearly $2 trillion economic rescue package, falling short of the 60 votes needed to advance. Democrats argued the Republican-led legislation prioritizes big corporations over workers and under-equipped healthcare systems. Despite intense negotiations, a deal remains elusive, and the Senate may take until the end of the week to pass a rescue package. The Dow Jones plummeted 2.85% and the Nasdaq fell 0.68% after the vote, amid concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported that over 80% of its employees in China have resumed work, despite a temporary production drop. UMS Holdings' factory in Penang remains closed until March 31 due to Malaysia's Movement Control Order. Frencken Group received approval to continue its manufacturing operations in Bangi, Selangor, with reduced employee numbers. Zico Holdings closed its Malaysian premises from March 18 to 31 and implemented a business continuity plan.

site_title: Italian cruise ship isolates passengers after virus infection
summary: An Italian cruise ship, Victoria, has isolated over 700 passengers after a 63-year-old Argentine woman tested positive for Covid-19. The woman, who is in stable condition, was taken off the ship in Crete on Sunday. The company is taking precautions to prevent the spread of the virus among the remaining passengers. This move comes as Italy has been one of the countries most affected by the pandemic. The ship will remain in Crete until further notice to ensure the health and safety of all on board.

site_title: HAO Mart branches out with niche offerings, halal concepts
summary: HAO Mart, a Singaporean grocery chain, has achieved 50% year-over-year growth since its founding in 2016, expanding to 44 outlets across four formats. The company aims to reach S$100 million in revenue this year, surpassing its aerospace industry revenue. HAO Mart's success is attributed to its focus on niche offerings, such as Halal Hub outlets catering to the Muslim community. The company is investing in technology and automation to improve efficiency, including a new warehouse and delivery system. HAO Mart plans to continue expanding in Singapore, with a focus on stabilizing its business before potentially entering the overseas market.

site_title: Bear market of today different; how it ends is anyone's guess
summary: The current bear market of 2020 is distinct from previous ones due to the combination of health, business, and financial worries caused by the global health pandemic. Volatility has led to losses of 20-30% on major exchanges, with oversold markets attempting to rally but feared to be followed by another downward wave. Economists predict stagflation, which could lead to rising interest rates and pressure on corporations and individuals with excessive debt, further weakening the stock market. The surge in the US dollar also poses a significant burden on emerging nations' foreign debt.

site_title: US, Singapore roll out more measures to ease pandemic hit
summary: The US Federal Reserve and Singapore have rolled out additional measures to ease the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The US will buy bonds to keep borrowing costs low and provide up to $300 billion in new financing to support businesses and consumers. In Singapore, a supplementary budget will be announced on Thursday, offering support measures for workers, businesses, and households. The government aims to cushion the economic fallout and promote a swift recovery.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Featuring author Jung Chang
summary: Michelle Martin interviews author Jung Chang on her books about Sun Yat Sen and other stories. Chang discusses her writing process and shares insights into her subjects. The conversation explores the intersection of history, politics, and culture. Chang's books offer a unique perspective on significant figures and events, providing readers with a deeper understanding of the past. The podcast provides a platform for Chang to share her knowledge and experiences with listeners.

site_title: Beyond burgers: Asia puts twist on alternative meats
summary: In Asia, the growing demand for sustainable meat alternatives is driving the development of creative products, such as lab-grown "seafood" and dumplings made with tropical fruit instead of pork. This trend is expected to fuel a surge in meat and seafood consumption, but environmental groups warn of potential damage.

images.alt_text: Karana chef-in-residence Sowmiya Venkatesan displaying plant-based "pork" and chive dumplings made from jackfruit.

site_title: How to hold a successful annual general meeting
summary: Companies should prioritize engaging shareholders beyond financial discussions at their annual general meetings (AGMs), using technology to hold virtual AGMs if necessary. They should provide more clarity on financial fundamentals, management performance, and corporate strategy, demystifying goodwill and intangibles. Companies should also discuss future plans, including corporate strategic direction, business segments, and market disruptions. Additionally, they should articulate long-term value creation, non-financial data, and supply chain integrity. Effective listening and responding to shareholder concerns are crucial, and staying true to the AGM's purpose can lead to a positive outcome for the company.

site_title: STI sees largest single-day fall since 2008
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 7.4% to 2,233.48, its largest single-day fall since 2008, amid rising virus-induced recession fears and little effect from policymakers' stimulus measures. The benchmark is now 34.6% down from its 52-week high. Sell-offs persisted as investors liquidated assets, with Singapore Airlines and real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) experiencing significant declines. Experts expect the market to remain "largely externally influenced" until investors believe the pandemic is over.

site_title: ECB ready to do more for coronavirus emergency if needed: official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to take additional measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, according to ECB official Ignazio Visco. The bank has already implemented stimulus measures, including ultra-cheap loans and asset buys worth €1.1 trillion, and is ready to increase the size of its emergency bond purchase program if necessary. Visco emphasized the importance of a coordinated effort by EU member states to mitigate the effects of the pandemic and ensure a swift recovery.

site_title: Swedbank investigation unearths 36.7b euros of 'high risk' payments
summary: Swedbank AB has been found to have handled 36.7 billion euros (S$57.4 billion) in potentially suspicious transactions, raising concerns of money laundering. An investigation commissioned by Swedbank, led by Clifford Chance, found that the bank's senior management failed to establish clear lines of AML-related responsibilities. The Swedish financial regulator has fined Swedbank a record 4 billion kronor (S$561.5 million). The bank's CEO, Jens Henriksson, has acknowledged that there were "cultures in the bank that are not acceptable."

site_title: Joy of spring: Japan fetes cherry blossoms despite coronavirus
summary: In Japan, despite COVID-19 warnings, crowds gathered to admire cherry blossoms in Tokyo, with many not wearing face masks. Traditional blossom hotspots were still visited, with officials urging caution against large gatherings. Despite restrictions, many people celebrated the event, with some picnicking and drinking under the trees. The cherry blossom season, a significant national event, has seen a decline in tourism and business earnings due to the pandemic, with forecasters predicting a 40% loss in earnings.

images.alt_text: Over a warm long weekend in Tokyo, people packed into traditional blossom hotspots like Ueno Park (above), many not even wearing face masks, to admire the fluffy white and pink flowers hanging from delicate stems.

site_title: US seeks to repatriate 13,500 stranded in pandemic
summary: The US State Department is trying to repatriate approximately 13,500 stranded Americans overseas due to the coronavirus pandemic, with 5,700 already brought back. Despite efforts, the department is hesitant to guarantee the safe return of all individuals, citing remote locations and suspended commercial services. The department is working to arrange transportation for Americans in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burkina Faso at their own expense. A reserve program has been activated to enlist commercial airliners on behalf of the Defence Department, but it is unclear if this will be sufficient to reach all stranded Americans.

images.alt_text: Some 5,700 people have already been brought back - including more than 800 out of the Chinese virus epicenter of Wuhan and 1,200 last week from Morocco as well as 300 from the Diamond Princess cruise in Japan, the official said.

site_title: Indonesia in a state of denial over Covid-19
summary: Indonesia's government is under fire for its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with critics accusing them of denial and poor leadership. Despite the country's poor healthcare facilities and low hospital bed capacity, the government has failed to enforce lockdowns and take necessary measures to protect citizens. The administration's stimulus package included funds for boosting tourism, and a recent decision to cancel a soft lockdown in Jakarta was later reversed. The government's inaction is expected to result in a significant loss of lives and a severe economic downturn, potentially affecting the country's economic growth to as low as 2% or even zero.

site_title: Online Filipino tutors turn lockdowns into opportunities
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has created a surge in demand for online Filipino tutors, particularly in China, Japan, and other countries with English language classes. Thousands of Filipino teachers are now working from home, taking advantage of the situation to teach English and earn a living. Online platforms like 51Talk and RareJob have seen a significant increase in demand and usage, with some firms experiencing a 154% surge in shares. Filipino tutors are using creative methods to engage their students, such as using props and candy to keep them entertained.

site_title: Tiong Seng bags S$227.5m contract for Tan Quee Lan Street condo
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings has secured a S$227.5 million contract to build a luxury condominium project on Tan Quee Lan Street in Singapore. The project, which will include two 30-storey blocks and commercial space, is expected to be completed in March this year. Tiong Seng will use its prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology to build the project. The contract is the group's third win this year, increasing its construction order book size to approximately S$1.2 billion.

site_title: PwC flags Best World's sales proceeds going into other bank accounts
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-listed premium skincare products seller, has been flagged by its independent accountant PwC for potentially understating sales proceeds in 2018, with 20% of sales value going into other bank accounts. The 20% mainly represents trade rebates to franchisees under an "oral arrangement" and has been used for commissions, staff payments, and transfers to Vicstar Lifestyle, owned by the spouses of two top Singapore distributors. PwC has recommended the board review financial statements and seek a formal legal opinion on the potential understatement.

site_title: Emaar closes bookings at three more Dubai hotels
summary: EMAAR Properties has closed bookings at three Dubai hotels, Address Dubai Mall, Address Sky View, and Palace Downtown, for 10 weeks due to weak demand caused by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The hotels will be closed from March 22 to May 31. The decision is part of a consolidation effort to maximize guest experience and carry out essential maintenance and renovation works. The move comes as the United Arab Emirates has temporarily banned foreigners from entering the country to stop the spread of the deadly virus.

site_title: Crude oil hits 17-year low, further slide expected
summary: Crude oil prices have plummeted to a 17-year low, with Brent crude falling to US$28.14 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude slipping to US$22.47 per barrel. The price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, combined with the COVID-19 pandemic and a crude supply glut, has led to a 60% loss in oil prices this year. Analysts expect further downward pressure on prices, with some predicting Brent could average US$10 per barrel or lower in the second quarter.

site_title: Future-focused HR policy means valuing older workers too
summary: OCBC Bank's head of human resources, Jason Ho, emphasizes the importance of valuing older workers in a future-focused approach to manpower. Measures such as the Job Security Council, which matches retrenched workers with new jobs, demonstrate this approach. Ho advocates for a skills-based approach, using artificial intelligence and big data to facilitate matching, and recognizes the value of older workers' soft skills and experience. He suggests that firms should view older workers as an asset, rather than a cost, and provide training opportunities to upskill them. This approach can help firms adapt to the changing workforce and survive in a world with technological advancements and an ageing population.

site_title: Covid-19 outbreak tests materiality threshold for continuous disclosure
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is testing the materiality threshold for continuous disclosure, with businesses and governments worldwide grappling with its impact. As governments impose measures to contain the virus, companies are facing issues ranging from corporate governance to employment, and investors are seeking more information on the pandemic's effects on operations and bottom lines. Issuers are advised to provide transparency on the actual and potential impacts of COVID-19, and to share assessments on disruptions to business activities, balance sheets, and liquidity.

site_title: Home work triggers demand jump for chips, laptops, network goods
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in demand for laptops, network peripherals, and components, including chips, as companies shift to virtual offices. South Korea reported a 20% jump in semiconductor exports, while the US saw nearly one in three Americans ordered to stay home. Cloud computing has boosted sales of server chips, and analysts expect demand to continue, with UBS forecasting a 10% rise in DRAM chip prices in the second quarter.

site_title: Singapore artists grapple with virus fallout
summary: The Singapore arts industry is severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with the cancellation of major events such as the Singapore International Festival of Arts and a significant decline in museum attendance. Thousands of artists are losing their gigs and income, with many relying on ticket sales and sponsorship to survive. The National Arts Council has announced a S$1.6 million support package, including a 30% subsidy for venue rental and a one-time capability-development grant for individuals and arts organisations. The industry is calling for public support, with some artists advocating for ticket donations instead of refunds to help mitigate the losses.

site_title: SoftBank unveils dramatic 4.5t yen asset sale plan
summary: SoftBank has unveiled a plan to raise up to 4.5 trillion yen ($59.5 billion) by selling or monetizing assets over the next four quarters to buy back stock and slash debt. The move aims to reassure investors amid the COVID-19 fallout, with shares surging 19% - the most in over 11 years. The plan includes a new share buyback program of up to 2 trillion yen, on top of previously announced repurchases. SoftBank's assets, including stakes in Alibaba and WeWork, are being considered for sale.

site_title: Covid-19 stress brings out latent muscle in SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is experiencing record trading amid the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by heightened uncertainties. The market is seen as a safe haven for investors, with many Singaporeans taking advantage of undemanding valuations to invest in SGX/Singapore dollar assets. According to Michael Syn, head of equities at SGX, the exchange has seen a surge in account openings, as investors look to the potential rebound at the end of the pandemic. This is an extraordinary run for the market, which is often considered less exciting than its neighbors.

site_title: Why SMEs should embrace machine learning
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from embracing machine learning (ML) to improve profitability and revenue. By using mathematical algorithms to analyze large amounts of data, ML can help identify patterns, predict customer behavior, and optimize marketing spends. SMEs can start by identifying relevant data, such as website visitor information, purchase orders, and employee claims, and applying ML algorithms to unlock concealed information and knowledge. A mindset shift is necessary, starting with small-scale projects and focusing on specific problems to solve.

site_title: Sengkang EC OLÁ sells 30% of units on first weekend
summary: Anchorvale, a joint venture between Evia Real Estate and Gamuda Land, sold 167 of 548 units in its Sengkang EC OLÁ development, with 30% of all units sold within the first weekend. Units were sold at an average price of S$1,135 psf, with 40% on a deferred payment scheme. Despite lower-than-expected turnout, the developer remains optimistic, citing the project's affordable pricing and unique features.

site_title: Malaysia suspends short-selling amid coronavirus volatility
summary: Malaysia's market regulator and stock exchange suspended short-selling until April 30 due to the coronavirus pandemic's volatility. This decision aims to support an orderly market amid exceptional global and market conditions. The Securities Commission Malaysia will assess the situation and consider additional precautionary measures as necessary.

site_title: British companies mothball full-year results after regulators call for delay
summary: British companies, including Kingfisher, have delayed full-year results for at least two weeks due to the Financial Conduct Authority's request to assess the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on their businesses. The FCA advised companies to hold off on reporting to better understand the situation. Several companies, including AG Barr, Mears Group, and Lamprell, have also taken similar actions. The Financial Reporting Council supports the FCA's decision, encouraging listed companies to consider delaying other corporate reports for the next two weeks.

site_title: Airbus lifts liquidity to 30b euros to ride out pandemic
summary: Airbus has increased its liquidity to 30 billion euros to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on its airline customers, who have halted flights and plane deliveries. The company has also suspended earnings guidance, terminated its dividend, and extended credit lines. Airbus plans to continue production, but notes that the wide-body market will be depressed and may activate "operational scenarios" depending on the virus's spread. The company's CEO stated that the extra funding is aimed at safeguarding the business and ensuring its return to efficient operations once the situation recovers.

site_title: Virus outbreak puts regional startups through their first stress test
summary: Singapore's startups face their first test as the COVID-19 pandemic dampens consumer demand, disrupts supply chains, and reduces workforce operations. Companies with strong cash flow and positive unit economics are better positioned to survive, but those with weak business models or balance sheets are likely to fail. To extend their cash runway, companies should re-evaluate their business plans, cut costs, and maintain staff morale. Investors are also tightening their belts, and startups may face reduced opportunities for funding. Agility and adaptability will be key for startups to thrive once the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Covid-19: Disruptions in global supply chains may be worse than for Sars
summary: Global supply chains may face larger disruptions from the novel coronavirus outbreak than the Sars epidemic in 2003, according to OCBC Bank CEO Samuel Tsien. The recovery from the crisis is expected to be slow, with consumer confidence flagging and companies delaying investment and expansion plans. Tsien warned that the current volatile market environment and significant uncertainties will slow down recovery, which is expected to accelerate by 2021.

images.alt_text: Mr Tsien cautions that amid volatile markets and significant uncertainties, recovery from the crisis will be slow.

site_title: Citi slashes Asean GDP growth forecast to 2.9%, down from 4.3%
summary: Citi Research has slashed its 2020 economic growth forecast for ASEAN to 2.9%, down from 4.3% due to the Covid-19 outbreak reaching an "inflection point" in South-east Asia. The forecast reflects extended drag on tourism, weaker domestic demand, and transitory supply shocks. A recovery is expected to be U-shaped, with a potential GDP contraction and technical recession in Thailand, near-stagnation in Singapore, and growth almost half of potential in Malaysia.

site_title: Should America return to big government?
summary: The US government is implementing a massive fiscal stimulus plan, estimated to cost over $1 trillion, to combat the economic impact of the novel coronavirus. This move marks a significant shift from the Republican Party's previous stance on limited government intervention in the economy. President Trump's plan includes $300 billion for small businesses, $50 billion for the airline industry, and $150 billion for other struggling sectors. The plan also includes a promise of $1,000 to every American adult. Critics argue that the plan could be more cost-effective to isolate the elderly and weak, and invest in treatment while encouraging social distancing, rather than shocking the entire economy.

site_title: 54 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore in highest single-day spike; 48 cases imported
summary: Singapore has confirmed 54 new Covid-19 cases, the highest single-day spike, with 48 cases imported. This is the first time the country has seen a daily increase above 50 cases.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic to cost Asia-Pac economies US$620b: S&P
summary: S&P Global Ratings forecasts the Covid-19 pandemic to cost Asia-Pacific economies approximately US$620 billion in total and permanent income loss from 2020 to 2021. The region's average growth rate is expected to be 2.7%, with economic contractions in Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Japan. China's GDP growth rate is expected to slow to 2.9% in 2020, with a real GDP forecast of -0.8% for Singapore. The agency attributes the losses to measures to contain the pandemic, which could cause a surge of defaults among non-financial corporate borrowers.

site_title: Contractors seeking legal advice over project delays
summary: Contractors in Singapore are seeking legal advice due to increasing concerns over project delays and penalties related to the COVID-19 pandemic. Many construction projects are ongoing, but materials and workers from China and Malaysia are in short supply, causing delays. The government and industry associations have advised sympathetic views on project delays, but many contractors are still facing penalties. One radical suggestion is for Parliament to enact emergency legislation to declare COVID-19 grounds for excuse performance and provide relief to the S$30 billion construction industry.

site_title: Real estate billionaire Barrack says commercial mortgages on brink of collapse
summary: US real estate billionaire Tom Barrack warned that the commercial-mortgage market is on the brink of collapse due to the COVID-19 pandemic. He predicts a "domino effect" of borrower defaults, mass foreclosures, and potentially bank failures if banks and the government don't take prompt action. Barrack's paper highlights the fragility of mortgage Reits and credit funds, and he argues for a coordinated rescue plan to prevent a catastrophic economic impact, which he believes could surpass that of the Great Depression.

site_title: Old restaurant chains get a second look from quarantined America
summary: Decades-old US restaurant chains such as Papa John's, Domino's Pizza, and Wingstop are experiencing a resurgence in popularity due to the coronavirus pandemic. Confined consumers are turning to these chains for delivery and takeout, leading to a surge in hiring. Domino's Pizza has outperformed peers, with its stock gaining 8% this year, while Papa John's and Wingstop have also seen significant gains. Little Caesars Enterprises is also staffing up, offering free delivery through April 5, to meet the increased demand.

site_title: US: Wall St slides as Fed boost fails to assuage virus worries
summary: US stocks slid lower on Monday as a brief surge in optimism from the Federal Reserve's aggressive credit boost was overshadowed by concerns over the rapidly spreading coronavirus pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.76%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.62%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.47%. Despite the Fed's efforts, investors remained cautious, with the pandemic's impact on the economy and market uncertainty lingering.

site_title: UMS Holdings Penang factory to remain closed till March 31
summary: UMS Holdings, a precision engineering firm, has announced that its Penang factory will remain closed until March 31 due to Malaysia's movement control order. The factory in Singapore will operate normally, while the California facility will be closed due to the state's stay-at-home order. The temporary halt is expected to have minimal financial impact, and the company will monitor the COVID-19 situation and keep shareholders informed.

site_title: Frencken Group's operations in Bangi to continue operations
summary: Frencken Group has received approval from Malaysian authorities to continue its mechatronics manufacturing operations in Bangi, Selangor, despite the ongoing movement control order. The company will adhere to reduced employee numbers and conditions set by the authorities. This decision is not expected to impact its operations outside of Malaysia, with other factories in Asia, Europe, and the US serving customers. Frencken shares closed at $0.52, down 1.9%.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei jumps 2% on weak yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 2.02% to close at 16,887.78, driven by a weak yen. Investors remained unfazed by speculation of potential Tokyo Olympics postponement due to virus concerns. The broader Topix index also gained 0.68%. The strong yen move was seen as a positive factor for Japanese stocks.

site_title: Mnuchin says G20 prepared to coordinate globally as needed
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said G20 countries are prepared to coordinate globally as needed to address the worsening coronavirus pandemic. Finance ministers and central bankers from the 20 largest economies agreed on a video call to support economies and coordinate actions. The G20 summit, scheduled for later this week, will focus on addressing the crisis, with economic relief and global recession fears on the agenda. The summit comes as countries impose lockdown measures, with over 14,600 deaths reported worldwide.

site_title: Dollar erases losses as stocks plunge again
summary: The US dollar erased early losses and rose 0.2% to 102.82 against a basket of currencies, driven by a global stock market collapse and concerns about the banking system's ability to lend dollars. The dollar's safe-haven appeal increased as investors sought to hold cash and avoid riskier assets. Despite this, the dollar's gains were tempered by losses against the yen and Swiss franc, which rose due to increased foreign currency interventions. The dollar's rally was also attributed to short covering by hedge funds.

site_title: Fed announces second wave of stimulus to support economy
summary: The Federal Reserve announced a second wave of stimulus to support the US economy, including buying an unlimited amount of bonds to keep borrowing costs low. The Fed will also establish programs to ensure credit flows to corporations, state and local governments, and households, with a total of up to $300 billion in new financing. The measures aim to aid employers, businesses, and cities affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve will take on a slew of efforts, many aimed at directly aiding employers and households, as well as cities and states.

site_title: Downturn a reset button for lofty startup valuations
summary: The COVID-19 economic downturn may reset lofty startup valuations in South-east Asia, presenting an opportunity for venture capitalists to invest in fundamentally sound companies at a cheaper price. Investors expect a softening in valuations, with some venture capitalists and funds already raising larger funds. Despite a slowdown in funding activity, investors are still seeking good deals, particularly in well-managed tech enterprises. High-valuation deals may still occur, but late-stage companies may face challenges in securing funding, and investors must balance their desire for a good price with fairness to entrepreneurs.

site_title: Covid-19 will be the technology test for businesses
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for businesses to be resilient and prepared for unexpected events. Companies that have invested in technology and flexible working arrangements are better equipped to handle staff absences and maintain operations. Investment management companies like Schroders have seen success with remote work, enabling staff to work from anywhere, at any time, with full access to systems and tools. This approach has allowed them to maintain service levels, protect staff, and control the spread of the virus. As the pandemic continues, it is clear that technology and a strong social contract with employees are critical for business resilience.

site_title: Hong Kong bars non-residents, limits alcohol over virus
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, announced a series of measures to combat the coronavirus, including banning non-residents from entering the city from March 25, and restricting the sale of alcohol in bars and restaurants for at least two weeks. The measures aim to halt the rapid spread of the virus, which has more than doubled to 356 cases in the last two weeks. Non-residents flying in from overseas will be barred, but those from the Chinese mainland, Macau, and Taiwan will still be allowed entry.

site_title: Dubai's vast malls to close under UAE plan to curb virus
summary: Dubai's famous malls will shut down for two weeks to curb the coronavirus, with shopping centers, fresh food markets, and restaurants limited to home deliveries. The decision, part of the UAE's plan to contain the spread of COVID-19, also includes suspending passenger and transit flights for two weeks, with cargo and emergency flights exempt. The UAE has reported over 150 cases and two deaths from the disease, and Gulf countries have imposed various restrictions to combat the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Dubai's famous malls will shut down for a fortnight under the United Arab Emirates' plan to curb coronavirus, which will also see its airports closed to passenger and transit flights.

site_title: 'Joy of spring': Japan fetes cherry blossoms despite virus
summary: Despite Japan's coronavirus warnings, crowds flocked to traditional cherry blossom hotspots, with many not wearing face masks. Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike urged people to avoid large gatherings, but many continued to celebrate, citing the importance of the event. Researchers predict a 40% loss in business earnings due to the outbreak, while officials in South Korea are taking measures to limit access to popular blossom spots.

site_title: Next MAS decision to be released March 30, instead of April
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that its next monetary policy decision will be released on March 30, earlier than the usual April date. Economists expect significant monetary easing due to the ongoing economic toll of the Covid-19 outbreak. The MAS may also adjust the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate policy band, potentially lowering it.

site_title: Singapore government to unveil additional Covid-19 support measures on Thursday
summary: The Singapore government plans to unveil additional Covid-19 support measures on Thursday, five weeks after the Budget 2020 announcement. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver the ministerial statement, which will include live television and radio coverage. The measures aim to help workers, businesses, and households cope with the pandemic's impact, reflecting the rapidly evolving situation.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls for H2 2025. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Germany approves 750b euro package to cushion virus blow
summary: Germany has approved a 750 billion euro package to cushion the economic blow from the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes 156 billion euros in new debt for social spending and company aid, as well as a 600 billion-euro rescue fund to provide loans and guarantees to virus-hit businesses. The fund includes 400 billion euros in guarantees, 100 billion euros for bailouts, and 100 billion euros for state-backed loans.

site_title: 54 new coronavirus cases in S'pore; 48 cases imported
summary: Singapore has confirmed 54 new COVID-19 cases, with 48 being imported, marking the highest daily number of new cases. All but one imported case were returning residents or long-term pass holders, who had traveled to Europe, North America, and Southeast Asia. The total number of infected patients is 509, with 15 in critical condition. Eight more cases have been discharged, bringing the total of discharged and fully recovered cases to 152.

images.alt_text: Singapore has confirmed 54 new Covid-19 cases, including 48 that are imported, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Monday.

site_title: GE cuts US aviation jobs by 10% in US$1b savings plan
summary: General Electric's aviation division plans to cut 10% of its US workforce, affecting approximately 2,600 jobs, in an effort to save $500 million to $1 billion this year. The company will also reduce executive compensation and furlough half of its domestic maintenance employees for 90 days. The move is a response to the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, which has sapped demand for commercial air travel. CEO Larry Culp will forgo his remaining salary for 2020, while David Joyce, GE Aviation boss, will give up half of his salary.

site_title: SIA slashes capacity by 96%; group's cost cuts to affect 10,000 staff
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has drastically cut its capacity by 96% due to the Covid-19 pandemic, grounding 138 planes and leaving only 9 operational passenger aircraft. The airline group is also introducing salary cuts of 10-30% for staff, with CEO Goh Choon Phong taking a 30% cut. The move is expected to affect around 10,000 staff, with some taking voluntary no-pay leave or furlough. The airline's revenue is projected to decline by at least S$1 billion in the fourth quarter, with some analysts forecasting a full-year loss for FY21.

site_title: 31 French tourists test positive in Cambodia virus cluster
summary: Thirty-one French tourists from a tour group in Cambodia have tested positive for the coronavirus, prompting a quarantine in a hotel. The patients, aged 40s to 80, received treatment in isolation in Sihanoukville, while two local guides and five remaining tourists tested negative. This cluster brings Cambodia's total cases to 87. Authorities have implemented restrictions, including shuttering entertainment venues and schools, but no official stay-at-home order has been issued. The outbreak comes as Cambodia receives aid and investment from China, with which the country has a close relationship.

site_title: Asian stocks resume plunge as more countries turn to self-isolation
summary: Asian stocks plummeted as governments intensified lockdowns to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with many countries turning to self-isolation. The Singapore Straits Times Index fell 7.4% and other key benchmarks in Asia tumbled, with some markets closing with substantial losses. The US Senate blocked a coronavirus economic response rescue package, leaving investors disappointed. Global recessionary fears continue to rise, with crude oil hitting 17-year lows amid a global supply glut. Analysts expect large declines in earnings performances by Asian corporates, with some forecasting a 14% earnings per share fall in 2020.

site_title: More than 1 billion told to stay home worldwide over virus outbreak
summary: More than 1 billion people worldwide have been advised to stay home due to the coronavirus pandemic, with at least 659 million under mandatory lockdown measures in over 50 countries. Governments are taking drastic measures to stem the spread of the virus, with stay-at-home recommendations and lockdowns in place to protect public health.

site_title: Malaysia coronavirus cases up by 212 in biggest daily jump
summary: Malaysia reported 212 new coronavirus cases, the largest daily jump, bringing the total to 1,518. About 970 cases are linked to a religious gathering near Kuala Lumpur. The death toll rose to 14. The health ministry attributed the surge to the gathering.

site_title: STI closes 7.4% lower -- its largest single-day decline since October 2008
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 7.4% to its largest single-day decline since 2008, closing at 2,233.48 points. Investors continued to liquidate assets, seeking cash, amid global recessionary fears due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The benchmark index is now firmly in bear territory, down 34.6% from its 52-week high. Policymaker stimulus measures have had little effect, and the US Senate's rejection of a coronavirus economic response package further worsened sentiment.

site_title: MAS issues Covid-19 advisory to financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued an advisory to all financial institutions in Singapore to implement "safe distancing measures" amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The advisory aims to reduce the risk of further local transmission and safeguard customers' health. The move is in line with the latest guidance from the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Manpower. This will also help ensure the financial sector's operational resilience during the virus outbreak.

site_title: US-China enmity turning Covid-19 pandemic into a new battleground
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has turned into a new battleground between the US and China, as countries increasingly isolate themselves from the world. Australia, New Zealand, India, and the EU have imposed travel curbs, lockdowns, and state of emergency declarations. This uncoordinated response undermines multilateralism and global institutions like the IMF and World Bank. The tensions are a result of the US-China enmity, with China's handling of the pandemic being a major point of contention. The situation is likely to escalate further ahead of the EU-China summit later this month.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dive more than 4% at open
summary: European stocks plummeted over 4% at the opening of trading Monday, amid rising coronavirus deaths and a US lawmakers' failure to agree on a trillion-dollar emergency package. The FTSE 100, DAX, and CAC 40 indices dropped 4.8%, 4.6%, and 4.4% respectively.

site_title: Bigger salary cuts for SIA's management, compulsory no-pay leave to be rolled out for staff
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is implementing deeper pay cuts for its management team amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Chief executive Goh Choon Phong will take a 30% salary cut, while executive vice-presidents and senior vice-presidents will take 25% and 20% cuts respectively. The airline is also introducing compulsory no-pay leave for pilots, executives, and associates, with about 10,000 staff affected. These measures aim to reduce costs and increase productivity in the face of uncertainty over the pandemic's impact on the airline industry.

images.alt_text: With the airline industry flying into heavy turbulence, Singapore Airlines (SIA) is initiating deeper pay cuts for its management team, while introducing compulsory no pay leave (CNPL) on certain days each month for pilots, executives and associates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 43.40 points to 1,259.88. The index saw a loss of 2.34% in volume worth RM2.312 billion, with 771 losers outnumbering 161 gainers.

site_title: Australia's central bank buys A$4b of government bonds
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) bought A$4 billion in local government bonds as part of its quantitative easing programme to keep short-term yields around 0.25%. The purchases included bonds with maturities from 2021 to 2027, and were made to ensure credit was cheap and freely available across the economy amid the coronavirus impact. This is the second day of the RBA's bond-buying programme, following a A$5 billion purchase on Friday.

site_title: Ex-GIC and PepsiCo veterans appointed to DBS' board of directors
summary: DBS Group has appointed Anthony Lim, a former GIC veteran, and Punita Lal, a former PepsiCo India marketing head, to its board of directors, effective April 1. Lim will serve on DBS' main boards and join the Board Risk-Management Committee and Executive Committee, while Lal will be a member of the Compensation and Management Development Committee and, subject to approval, the Nominating Committee. The appointments are part of DBS' board renewal process, which also includes the retirements of Nihal Kaviratne and Danny Teoh on March 31.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 Games delay looms as Canada, Australia quit
summary: Major sporting nations Australia and Canada have quit the Tokyo 2020 Olympics due to the coronavirus crisis, marking the first time in 124 years that the Olympics have been postponed. Host Japan has invested over $12 billion in the event, and a delay would be a significant blow to sponsors and broadcasters. The decision comes as global pressure mounts to postpone the Games.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 4.86% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 21,696.13, amid concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 3.11%. Despite global emergency stimulus measures, investors remained cautious, leading to a sharp decline.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index plummeted 4.86 per cent, or 1,108.94 points, to close at 21,696.13.

site_title: Home work triggers demand jump for chips, laptops and network goods
summary: Demand for laptops, network peripherals, and chips has surged as more employees work from home due to the coronavirus pandemic, with South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co Ltd reporting a 20% jump in semiconductor exports. Cloud computing has boosted server chip sales, and companies are rushing to build virtual offices. China is leading chip demand, with cloud service providers offering free resources to help maintain operations. Analysts expect demand to continue, with UBS forecasting a 10% rise in DRAM chip prices and a 31% increase in server chip demand in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's core inflation turned negative in February for the first time in over a decade due to a decline in services amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The government is set to unveil additional support measures to help workers, businesses, and households cope with the pandemic. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) closed 7.4% lower, its largest single-day decline since 2008. SIA's management will take a 30% salary cut, while a compulsory no pay leave will be rolled out for staff.

images.alt_text: With the airline industry flying into heavy turbulence, Singapore Airlines (SIA) is initiating deeper pay cuts for its management team, while introducing compulsory no pay leave (CNPL) on certain days each month for pilots, executives and associates.

site_title: Shell cuts costs, slashes spending on virus turmoil
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has cut costs and reduced spending by billions of dollars due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has led to an oil price collapse. The company will slash operating costs by $3-4 billion and reduce annual spending to $20 billion from $25 billion. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that Shell is taking decisive action to ensure its financial strength and resilience, with staff maintaining focus on safe operations while prioritizing their health and welfare.

site_title: Sengkang EC OLÁ sells 30% of units on 1st weekend at S$1,135 psf on average
summary: In Singapore, a third of units in the Sengkang EC OLÁ were sold within the first weekend, with 167 out of 548 units sold at an average price of S$1,135 psf. 30% of units sold were to first-time buyers, while 40% opted for deferred payment schemes. The developer attributed the lower-than-expected turnout to economic uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close over 5% lower as virus-driven shutdowns rise
summary: South Korean shares plummeted over 5% on Monday as a rise in coronavirus-driven shutdowns worldwide fueled recession fears, overshadowing policy efforts to stabilize markets. The benchmark KOSPI index fell 80.10 points, or 5.11%, to 1,486.05, marking a 32.38% loss for the year. The South Korean central bank announced repo operations to ensure financial institutions have access to short-term credit, while the government vowed to prevent market volatility from turning into a credit crunch.

site_title: Gold falls as cash dash, strong US dollar override stimulus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,488.35 per ounce as investors stockpiled cash amid the coronavirus pandemic and rising national lockdowns. The US dollar strengthened, overriding stimulus measures from global central banks, and threatening to overwhelm policymakers' efforts to cushion a deep global recession. Market participants await further policy easing, with the US Senate considering a $1 trillion package.

site_title: Robot designed in China could help save lives on medical frontline
summary: Chinese researchers at Tsinghua University have designed a robot to help save lives on the medical frontline during the coronavirus outbreak. The robot, equipped with a robotic arm, cameras, and medical tools, can perform tasks such as ultrasounds, mouth swabs, and organ sound detection without requiring doctors to be in the same room as patients. The robot, which costs RMB 500,000, has been trialled by doctors in Beijing and is set to be used in Wuhan starting Sunday, with a nurse or staff member accompanying it on ward rounds.

site_title: South Korea to help car industry ride out coronavirus
summary: South Korea is providing logistical and financial support to its car industry to help it navigate the coronavirus crisis. The government will speed up customs clearance, arrange freight transportation, and offer liquidity support to the industry, which employs 12% of South Korea's workforce. The move aims to mitigate disruptions to supply chains from Europe and the US, where car factories and dealerships have been shut down due to the pandemic, affecting South Korean carmakers like Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp.

site_title: Making waves: Barcelona turns shipping containers into affordable homes
summary: In Barcelona, a dozen flats made from disused shipping containers have been completed as part of the city's effort to address its social housing crisis. Rising rents and a shortage of public housing are affecting vulnerable citizens, with experts citing Spain's outdated housing policy as a major issue. The city is exploring alternative solutions, including community land trusts and non-profit affordable housing providers, and has approved €400 million in funding for social housing projects. While the shipping container flats are a step in the right direction, experts say more needs to be done to address the crisis.

site_title: Biden to start considering running mates, consulted Obama
summary: US Democratic presidential front-runner Joe Biden plans to start vetting possible running mates in a matter of weeks, with at least six or seven women under consideration. Biden discussed potential running mates with former President Barack Obama, emphasizing the need for someone who shares his fundamental views on policies and can serve as president immediately. Despite concerns over the coronavirus, Biden believes the election should proceed as scheduled in November.

site_title: US diesel cash prices latest to slump from coronavirus fallout
summary: US ultra-low sulfur diesel prices have plummeted due to the coronavirus fallout, falling to their lowest seasonally since 2011. Refiners boosted production to escape poor margins for gasoline and jet fuel, causing an oversupply in some regions. Cash prices for diesel in Chicago and the Midwest have reached their lowest seasonally since 2016, potentially leading to declines in refining margins. The decline in demand for transportation fuels has also led to lower refining margins for gasoline, which have not been this low since 2005.

site_title: PwC sheds some light on Best World's financial affairs in interim update
summary: Best World International's independent accountant, PricewaterhouseCoopers Advisory Services, has released an interim update on the company's financial affairs. The review, initiated after concerns over sales practices, suggests that 20% of sales proceeds from the China franchise business in 2018 may have been diverted into other bank accounts. The review is nearing completion, but still requires access to outstanding information and documents. The findings raise questions about Best World's financial practices and the accuracy of its previous financial reports.

site_title: Singapore core inflation negative in February as services are hit by Covid-19
summary: Singapore's core inflation turned negative in February for the first time in over a decade, largely due to a decline in services costs amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Core inflation fell to -0.1% year-on-year, while headline inflation was 0.3% year-on-year. Economists predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will lower its inflation forecasts and implement monetary easing measures. The MAS and Ministry of Trade and Industry will release updated forecast ranges in its March 30 Monetary Policy Statement.

site_title: Valuetronics resumes China operations after Covid-19 shutdown
summary: Valuetronics Holdings has resumed operations and production at its factories in China, with over 80% of its employees returning to work following a Covid-19 shutdown. The electronics manufacturer expects a decrease in revenue for the six months ending March 31, 2020, due to reduced production days and capacity. Business sentiment remains uncertain in major markets, including the US, Europe, and China, and the company's shares are trading down 6.1% due to the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Airbus signs credit facility for 15b euros, withdraws 2020 guidance
summary: Airbus signs a 15 billion euro credit facility to bolster its financial position amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has crippled the travel industry. The company withdraws its 2020 financial guidance and suspends funding for staff pension schemes. Airbus has around 30 billion euros of available liquidity and plans to resume partial aircraft production when its factories reopen. The move comes as its US rival Boeing seeks a $60 billion lifeline for the US aerospace industry. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury remains optimistic about the company's ability to overcome the crisis.

site_title: Divisions among Hong Kong expats over virus response
summary: Hong Kong expats are divided over the city's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with some criticizing the well-heeled community for not taking the outbreak seriously enough. Despite the city's early adoption of face masks and social distancing, the number of cases has more than doubled to 318 in the last two weeks, largely due to the return of locals and foreign residents. The expat community is at odds over the severity of the situation, with some calling for more drastic measures. The city's ability to manage the outbreak has been attributed to the public's compliance with health measures.

site_title: Philips to ramp up production of ventilators in coronavirus fight
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips plans to double its production of hospital ventilators to 2,000 per week within eight weeks to help combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The company aims to increase production of other critical equipment, such as vital signs monitors and diagnostic imaging systems, and expects to hire extra staff to meet demand. Despite the increased production, Philips expects the pandemic to harm its first-half results due to waning demand for consumer products and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: DBS provides A$212m sustainability-linked loan to Hong Kong's Link Reit
summary: DBS Bank has provided a A$212 million five-year sustainability-linked term loan to Hong Kong-listed Link Real Estate Investment Trust (Link Reit) to support general corporate funding and sustainability initiatives. The loan's interest savings will be tied to Link Reit's performance in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) and its listing on global sustainability indices. This is DBS's first sustainability-linked loan for a Reit in Asia and follows Link Reit's issuance of green bonds in 2016 and 2019.

site_title: China's mobile carriers lose 15 million users as virus bites
summary: China's mobile carriers, including China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom, reported a decline in subscribers due to the coronavirus crisis. China Mobile lost over 8 million users in January and February, while China Telecom lost 5.6 million and China Unicom lost 1.2 million. The decline shows the pandemic's impact on business activity, even for essential services. This is the first industrywide slump in subscribers since China Mobile started reporting monthly data in 2000.

site_title: SoftBank to sell up to 4.5t yen in assets to expand share buyback, cut debt
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to sell up to 4.5 trillion yen (S$59.52 billion) in assets to buy back 2 trillion yen of shares and reduce debt. The move aims to improve shareholder returns amid pressure from activist hedge fund Elliott Management. SoftBank's share price jumped 19% following the announcement, as the company seeks to address investor skepticism over its startup bets. The asset sales will be executed over the next four quarters, and the company did not specify what assets would be sold.

site_title: China iron ore tumbles as global coronavirus-related curbs intensify
summary: China's iron ore prices plummeted over 5% on Monday, with the Dalian iron ore contract dropping to 632 yuan (S$129.50) a tonne, the lowest since March 9. Global coronavirus-related curbs further darkened the economic outlook, with Moody's Investors Service predicting a permanent hit to global economic activity this year. Despite signs of increased demand locally, Chinese steel futures also fell, with domestic steel products down 4.8% on a weekly basis.

site_title: Singapore and Australia ink digital-economy pact, renew cybersecurity tie-up
summary: Singapore and Australia finalized a digital-economy pact on March 23, 2020, creating a framework for deeper cooperation in the digital economy. The agreement establishes interoperability between digital systems, addresses emerging technologies, and facilitates data flow. It also covers areas such as electronic payments, source-code protection, and small and medium enterprise cooperation. The pact complements Singapore's efforts to develop multilateral rules for e-commerce. The two countries also signed seven memoranda of understanding to identify pilot projects for collaboration in areas like artificial intelligence and digital identities.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at over 7-year low on recession fears; NZ slumps
summary: Australian shares plummeted to a 7-year low on Monday, closing 5.6% lower at 4,546.00, amid recession fears fueled by widespread travel and public life curbs. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell as much as 8.6% earlier in the session. Heavyweight financials stocks, including banks and retailers, suffered significant losses, while biotech firm CSL Ltd rose 4.2%. New Zealand's benchmark index also slumped 7.6% to its lowest close since May 2018, following the country's decision to move to its highest alert level and impose self-isolation measures.

site_title: South Korea reports fewest new coronavirus cases since Feb 29 peak
summary: South Korea reported 64 new coronavirus cases on Monday, the lowest number since February 29, with a total of 8,961 cases and 110 deaths. For the 12th consecutive day, new infections were under 100, with 257 patients released from hospitals. This marks the first time since January 20 that the country has seen more recoveries than new infections. The extended downward trend in daily infections has boosted hopes that the outbreak may be abating.

site_title: US jobless rate may soar to 30%, Fed's Bullard says
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President James Bullard predicts the US unemployment rate may reach 30% in the second quarter due to coronavirus shutdowns, with a 50% drop in gross domestic product. He calls for a powerful fiscal response to replace $2.5 trillion in lost income and suggests the Fed is poised to take additional measures to ensure market stability. Bullard emphasizes the need for Congress to act quickly to support American workers and businesses, and he urges 100% coverage of lost income for unemployment insurance.

site_title: China online retail giants Alibaba, JD emerge from coronavirus deadlock
summary: China's e-commerce sector is emerging from a coronavirus-induced logistics deadlock, with delivery volumes approaching pre-outbreak levels. Alibaba, JD.com, and Pinduoduo are seeing shipping activity return to normal, with Cainiao's logistics arm operating at full capacity. However, a full e-commerce recovery depends on consumers resuming buying non-essential items, as middle-class consumers are tightening spending due to the pandemic's long-term impact. The industry is expected to see growth approach normality in the second quarter, with online physical product sales showing 3% year-on-year growth in January and February.

images.alt_text: China's e-commerce sector is beginning to emerge from a months-long logistics ordeal brought on by the coronavirus outbreak, judging by the latest data on delivery volumes. But a longer-term rebound hinges on a recovery in demand for goods beyond the essentials.

site_title: Coronavirus and ecosystem integration: Hope for the best, prepare for the worst
summary: A global pandemic, declared by the World Health Organization, has disrupted global trade, with China, a major manufacturing hub, experiencing a downturn in business due to the outbreak. This has forced companies to prepare for the worst and develop business continuity plans to mitigate potential losses. The lack of Industry 4.0 capabilities in Chinese manufacturers has made them vulnerable to disruptions, and companies must now find alternative suppliers and integrate their supply chains more efficiently to adapt to the new reality. Ecosystem integration technology can provide the necessary insights to quickly identify and respond to disruptions, enabling businesses to "hope for the best but prepare for the worst."

images.alt_text: Most of China is now considered low risk and should return to normal work and life, Premier Li Keqiang said at a government meeting on the coronavirus but lessons on supply chain can and should be gleaned from the experience of the supply chain shut down.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI down 7.5% at Monday afternoon reopen
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 7.5% at the Monday afternoon reopen, its largest single-day fall since October 2008, amid global recessionary fears and the spread of the Covid-19 pandemic. Policymaker efforts to combat the pandemic have shown little effect, with US Senate Democrats blocking a coronavirus economic response rescue package. Key decliners included Singapore Airlines, DBS, OCBC Bank, and Ascendas Reit, with shares falling 9.1%, 6.6%, 5.9%, and 8.4%, respectively.

site_title: Beyond burgers: Asia puts twist on alternative meats
summary: Asia is introducing creative meat alternatives to cater to growing demand for sustainable options, with lab-grown "seafood" and tropical fruit-based products being developed. Despite environmental concerns, the region's meat consumption is projected to increase, fueled by rising middle classes. Plant-based meat alternatives are gaining popularity, with a 30% annual growth rate in developed markets such as South Korea, Hong Kong, and Singapore. This trend is expected to continue as consumers seek sustainable options, despite the environmental impact.

site_title: Echoes of Great Depression as Australian jobless queue for help
summary: Jobless Australians flooded unemployment offices nationwide as the coronavirus pandemic threatens to plunge the country into recession, similar to the Great Depression. Despite a A$189 billion government relief package, queues stretched around the block at unemployment offices and online portals crashed as people rushed to register for income support payments. Prime Minister Scott Morrison warned of an economic crisis, saying "they are lining up at Centrelink offices as we speak" and that 2020 would be the "toughest year of our lives".

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic to cost Asia-Pacific economies US$620b: S&P
summary: S&P Global Ratings forecasts the Covid-19 pandemic to cost Asia-Pacific economies US$620 billion in total and permanent income loss from Q1 2020 to mid-2021. The loss will be distributed across sovereign, bank, corporate, and household balance sheets. This estimate covers the period when major economies return to trend, and is based on the agency's baseline scenario.

site_title: Some tips on how to stay sane in a world that isn't
summary: Therapists and experts recommend simple ways to cope with debilitating anxiety in a world affected by COVID-19. Daily goals, finding joy, and connecting with others can help create resilience. Practicing mindfulness, taking mental inventory of well-being, and limiting media intake can also reduce anxiety. Additionally, channeling anxiety into helping others can provide a sense of agency and reduce feelings of helplessness, allowing individuals to focus on the present moment and find a sense of calm.

site_title: In trying to overcome high logistics costs, she struck gold
summary: Gina Toh, general manager of logistics firm DAP Asia Pacific, overcame high logistics costs by investing in warehouse space and equipment through economies of scale, despite facing numerous challenges, including regulations, industry terminology, and employee management issues. Toh's company started with a $100,000 investment in 2004 and has since grown to make millions in turnover, employing over 50 full-time staff and operating over 150,000 square feet of warehouse space. Toh attributes her success to developing key skills, such as people management and communication, and believes investing in the right people is her best bet for the company's future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge 5% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 5% at the open on Monday, March 23, 2020, amid concerns over the rising global coronavirus death toll and the failed US senate emergency economic proposal. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1,145.52 points to 21,659.55. Investors were spooked by the worsening pandemic and the economic uncertainty, leading to a significant decline in market sentiment.

site_title: Sunright allowed to operate at minimal level during Malaysia lockdown
summary: Sunright, a Malaysian semiconductor testing and burn-in service provider, can operate at a minimal level during the country's lockdown due to its exemption as an essential goods supplier. The company will adhere to health ministry measures despite Malaysia's nationwide lockdown from March 18 to March 31. Sunright's shares rose 8.3% on Friday.

site_title: Chinese companies delay fundraising plans after watchdog tightens rules
summary: Chinese companies are delaying or changing fundraising plans due to the China Securities Regulatory Commission's (CSRC) tightened rules on private share sales. The CSRC recently loosened rules to help companies affected by the coronavirus, but closed a loophole that allowed key executives and unrelated fund managers to take advantage of the relaxed rules. At least 10 Chinese firms have said they may delay or change their plans, citing uncertainty over their investor classifications. This move is likely to put pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: Yum China moves to cooking kits to survive virus
summary: Yum China Holdings, the parent company of KFC and Pizza Hut in China, is adapting to the coronavirus pandemic by introducing new business lines such as catering and delivering raw food for home-cooking. The company is customizing menus for corporate clients and delivering raw steaks to home cooks with recipe details. Despite a challenging quarter ahead, CEO Joey Wat remains optimistic, citing opportunities for innovation and the ability to open new outlets this year.

site_title: Amazon's focus on essentials sows panic, confusion among merchants
summary: Amazon's delivery delays of non-essential goods will extend for at least another month, causing panic among online merchants who rely on the retailer for business. The delays stem from the company's focus on essential products, which is performed by algorithms with little human oversight, leading to confusion over what constitutes an essential item. Tens of millions of products will be unavailable until late April, resulting in lost sales for merchants who derive 90% or more of their revenue from the platform.

site_title: New Zealand announces move to enter lockdown over next 48 hours
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced a 48-hour lockdown, moving the country to its highest alert level, effective immediately. All non-essential services, schools, and offices will be shut, while supermarkets and pharmacies remain open. Bars, cafes, restaurants, and cinemas will also be closed. This move aims to slow the spread of COVID-19, with Ardern stating New Zealand is "now preparing to go into self isolation."

site_title: Emaar closes bookings at three more Dubai hotels as virus impact worsens
summary: Emaar Properties in Dubai will close bookings at three hotels for 10 weeks due to the coronavirus outbreak. The affected hotels, Address Dubai Mall, Address Sky View, and Palace Downtown, will not accept new bookings from March 22 to May 31. The decision is attributed to weak demand caused by the virus. The United Arab Emirates has temporarily banned foreigners from entering the country.

site_title: Asia: Stocks take further hit amid more lockdowns to fight Covid-19; STI down 7.4%
