summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) falling 7.4% to its lowest since October 2008, amid increased lockdowns to combat the spread of Covid-19. The global death toll surpassed 14,000, and confirmed cases exceeded 330,000. Investors liquidated assets, contributing to tightened liquidity conditions and a flight to cash, particularly the US Dollar. The downturn is attributed to ineffective stimulus measures and rising recession fears.

site_title: Singapore shares slide on heightened virus jitters; STI down 7.9% at open
summary: Singapore's stocks plummeted 7.9% at the start of the week after the country reported its first two COVID-19 deaths and shut its borders to all short-term visitors. The benchmark Strait Times Index fell to 2,219.98, with banking stocks and most index constituents declining. Other heavily traded securities, such as Rex International and ESR-Reit, also tumbled. The move follows Singapore's decision to close its borders to reduce the importation of COVID-19 cases, which economists say will further squeeze the aviation and tourism industries.

site_title: Real estate billionaire Barrack says commercial mortgages on brink of collapse
summary: Real estate billionaire Tom Barrack warns that the US commercial-mortgage market is on the brink of collapse due to the coronavirus pandemic. He predicts a "domino effect" of catastrophic economic consequences if banks and government don't intervene, including margin calls, mass foreclosures, and bank failures. Barrack calls for a $500 billion rescue plan with taxpayer funds, temporary accounting suspensions, and loan forbearance. He believes the impact could be worse than the Great Depression, and most of his investments are at risk.

site_title: Harvey Weinstein tests positive for coronavirus in prison: union official
summary: Former movie producer Harvey Weinstein, 68, has tested positive for coronavirus while serving a 23-year prison sentence for sexual assault and rape. He has been placed in isolation at Wende Correctional Facility in New York, where several corrections officers have also been quarantined due to lack of protective equipment. This comes after Weinstein's conviction was hailed as a victory for the #MeToo movement, with over 100 women accusing him of sexual misconduct.

images.alt_text: Former movie producer Harvey Weinstein, who is serving a prison sentence for sexual assault and rape, has tested positive for the coronavirus, according to the head of the state corrections officers union.

site_title: Japan PM Abe says postponing Tokyo Olympics may become an option
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Monday that postponing the Tokyo Olympic Games may become an option if holding the event in its "complete form" becomes impossible due to the coronavirus pandemic. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is stepping up scenario planning, including a possible postponement. This decision aligns with the view that the Tokyo Games should be held in its complete form.

site_title: Leadership in crisis: How corporate chiefs across the globe are responding to Covid-19
summary: Global corporate leaders are implementing drastic measures to combat the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including cost-cutting measures such as layoffs, salary reductions, and dividend suspensions. Marriott International, Keppel Corp, Singapore Airlines, and OCBC Bank are among the companies taking severe actions to stay afloat. CEOs, including Arne Sorenson and Goh Choon Phong, are voluntarily forgoing their salaries to support their employees and shareholders. Companies are also focusing on retaining customers and prioritizing staff safety, with some offering voluntary no-pay leave schemes and increasing overtime pay for essential workers.

images.alt_text: Arne Sorenson, CEO of Marriott International, listens during a White House meeting with hotel and tourism executives about the effect of the coronavirus.

site_title: UK scientists to track mutations in coronavirus to map spread
summary: UK scientists will track the spread of the new coronavirus by analyzing gene sequences from infected patients in England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. The project, called Covid-19 Genomics UK Consortium, aims to map out and understand the genetic codes of the virus, helping to identify emerging mutations and guide treatments. The 20 million-pound project is co-led by the Wellcome Sanger Institute and Public Health England, and will help the UK better understand the role of international importations of the virus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 57.25 points lower, or 4.39%, at 1,246.03, with 509 losers beating 38 gainers. Volume was 199.17 million lots worth RM84.19 million.

site_title: Tiong Seng unit wins S$227.5m construction contract for residential project
summary: Tiong Seng Holdings has secured a S$227.5 million contract to construct a private residential development on Tan Quee Lan Street, featuring two 30-storey apartment blocks and commercial space. Site possession is expected in March this year. The project will include retail space, a public plaza, car park, and communal facilities. None of Tiong Seng's directors or controlling shareholder has any interest in the contract, and the company's shares were unaffected by the announcement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, UOB, Singapore Airlines, NetLink, Tiong Seng
summary: Singapore stocks saw new developments on Monday, with key companies experiencing share price movements. DBS, OCBC, and UOB surged with share buybacks, while Singapore Airlines' shares fell due to reduced travel demand. NetLink NBN Trust and Tiong Seng Holdings reported positive developments, including redevelopment plans and a construction contract. OUE C-Reit announced a new debt issuance program, and UMS Holdings and Frencken Group stated they can continue operations amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: UAE to suspend all passenger flights: state media
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has announced a two-week suspension of all passenger and transit flights, effective in 48 hours, to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus outbreak. The decision, subject to review in two weeks, will exempt cargo and emergency evacuation flights. The UAE reported its first two deaths from Covid-19 and has imposed various restrictions, including stopping visa on arrival and prohibiting foreign residents from returning.

site_title: Canada coronavirus death toll jumps, officials could punish those ignoring precautions
summary: Canada's coronavirus death toll has jumped by over 50% to 20, with 1,430 confirmed cases, as the country closes its borders to all but essential travel and announces a $27 billion aid package. Officials threaten to punish those ignoring precautions, including Health Minister Patty Hajdu, who could use the federal Quarantine Act to sanction non-compliant individuals. Nova Scotia has declared a state of emergency, banning gatherings of more than five people, and Quebec has closed shopping malls, with schools shut until May 1.

site_title: WeWork board's special committee prepares for fight against SoftBank
summary: WeWork's board special committee is preparing for a fight against SoftBank, which is refusing to complete its $3 billion tender offer. The committee claims SoftBank's excuses are "inappropriate and dishonest" and that the company is obligated to complete the offer. SoftBank maintains its ability to walk away if material liabilities are discovered, and that the offer does not impact its commitment to WeWork or the company's financial strength. The dispute raises concerns about the future of the deal.

site_title: Covid-19 could cause worse disruptions to global supply chains than Sars: OCBC chief
summary: OCBC Bank CEO Samuel Tsien warns that the current COVID-19 outbreak could cause larger disruptions to global supply chains than the 2003 Sars epidemic. Volatile markets and uncertainties will lead to a slow recovery through 2021, with consumer confidence and investment plans delayed. The financial market has become more defensive, and the stresses to global supply chains could be significant.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher supported by cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, supported by a relatively cheaper yen, as investors monitored the spread of the coronavirus. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.57% to 16,813.43, while the Topix index gained 0.61% to 1,290.99. The cheaper yen, which made the US dollar more expensive, boosted the market. Despite concerns over the coronavirus, investors appeared to be cautiously optimistic, with Tokyo stocks opening higher.

site_title: Domestic travel, airline hubs the latest hit as coronavirus restrictions tighten
summary: Airlines worldwide cancelled more flights as coronavirus restrictions tightened, with Australia and New Zealand advising against non-essential domestic travel. The UAE halted flights for two weeks, Singapore and Taiwan banned foreign transit passengers, and Emirates and Etihad Airways suspended all inbound and outbound passenger flights. Cargo and emergency evacuation flights were exempt, and the decision was subject to reassessment.

site_title: McDonald's to temporarily close all UK, Ireland restaurants amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: McDonald's temporarily closed all UK and Ireland restaurants by 7pm on March 23, 2020, due to the coronavirus outbreak. This decision follows global efforts to curb the spread of the virus, with 95% of McDonald's restaurants in China having reopened. The company has suspended share buybacks to navigate the crisis but maintained its dividend policy.

site_title: Partisan battles block US Senate coronavirus bill but talks continue
summary: US Senate coronavirus bill stalls due to partisan battles, failing to reach 60 votes for procedural clearance. The measure, which would provide financial aid for Americans, small businesses, and critically affected industries, was blocked by Democrats' objections to its provisions benefiting corporate interests. Despite ongoing negotiations, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell urges Democrats to stop their "obstruction," while President Donald Trump maintains hope for a swift passage of a massive aid package.

site_title: China sees drop in new coronavirus cases; all new cases imported
summary: Mainland China reported 39 new confirmed coronavirus cases, a drop from the previous day's 46, all of which involved travelers arriving from abroad. The city of Beijing expanded virus screening measures, diverting international flights and requiring all arriving passengers to undergo tests. The total accumulated number of confirmed cases in mainland China stands at 81,093, with a death toll of 3,270. No new locally transmitted infections were reported.

site_title: France toughens lockdown penalties as coronavirus kills medic
summary: French lawmakers approved tougher penalties for defying a nationwide confinement order as the coronavirus death toll rose, with a doctor being the first medical victim. The death toll increased by 112 to 674, and confirmed cases rose by 11% to 16,018. Those caught defying the order will face harsher penalties, including fines and prison terms. The government is considering a tax-free "attendance bonus" for essential workers and is testing an anti-malaria drug hydroxychloroquine to combat the pandemic.

site_title: South Korea's March 1-20 exports rise, but virus-led demand slump seen weighing
summary: South Korea's exports rose 10.0% in the first 20 days of March, driven by a 20.3% increase in semiconductor shipments. However, the growth is expected to be overshadowed by a deepening slump in overseas demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. Exports to China, South Korea's largest trading partner, rose 4.9% during the period, with average exports per working day falling 0.4%. The pandemic's impact on the country's exports is likely to weigh on the full-month data.

site_title: French fashion labels Saint Laurent, Balenciaga to make coronavirus face masks
summary: High-end fashion labels Saint Laurent and Balenciaga, owned by French parent group Kering, will start manufacturing face masks to ease shortages during the coronavirus crisis. The move comes as protective gear stocks dwindle across France, prompting complaints from doctors and police unions. Kering plans to produce 3 million surgical masks for the French health service and donate 1.1 million masks and medical overalls to Italy.

site_title: SIA confirms 96% capacity cuts, grounding 138 planes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has confirmed a 96% capacity cut, grounding 138 planes, due to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak and tightened border controls. The airline is exploring ways to increase liquidity, reduce capital expenditure, and operating costs. SIA's low-cost unit, Scoot, will also suspend most of its network. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, emphasized protecting jobs and getting passengers safely back home. SIA is pursuing cost-cutting measures, including salary and fee cuts, and has drawn on credit lines to meet cash flow requirements.

site_title: Olympics-IOC to start discussions on possible Tokyo 2020 postponement
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has begun discussing possible postponement of the Tokyo 2020 Games due to the coronavirus pandemic. The IOC will consider modifying the start date or moving the Games by a year or more, but has ruled out cancellation. The organization will hold detailed discussions within the next four weeks to assess the global health situation and its impact on the Olympics. Several major stakeholders, including World Athletics and the International Paralympic Committee, have expressed support for a postponement, citing concerns for athlete safety and preparation.

site_title: Fed could provide massive support for US business, states in bill
summary: The US Treasury may receive at least $425 billion to support business and municipal borrowers, potentially backed by the Federal Reserve, as part of an economic aid package. The bill, currently being finalized by the Trump administration and congressional leaders, would provide liquidity through broad-based lending programs operated by the Fed. Analysts see this as a positive step, but note that the $4 trillion in liquidity proposed by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin may not be enough to address the economic crisis.

images.alt_text: Congress could hand the US Treasury at least US$425 billion to backstop potentially much larger support by the Federal Reserve (Fed) for business and municipal borrowers as part of an economic aid package being hammered out by the Trump administration and congressional leaders.

site_title: Emirates to halt almost all flights; cuts salaries on Covid-19 impact
summary: Emirates, the world's largest long-haul airline, will suspend nearly all of its passenger operations starting March 25 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Cargo services and routes to 13 countries, including the US, UK, and Singapore, will continue. The airline plans to ground 230 planes, or 85% of its fleet, and cut salaries for most employees by 25-50% for three months. Chairman and CEO Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum cited a lack of travel confidence and government requests to support repatriation as the reasons for the drastic measures.

site_title: Businesses looking for larger second stimulus package, SBF poll finds
summary: A poll by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) found that 73% of businesses believe the second stimulus package should be as large or larger than the S$4 billion announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. Over half of the 188 respondents hope the new package can be rolled out immediately or in a month's time, citing a need for urgency. The poll highlights businesses' concerns over wage costs, cash flow, and manpower challenges, with 69% of respondents being SMEs.

site_title: Oil falls more than US$1 as coronavirus spreads
summary: Oil prices plummeted more than $1 a barrel as the global coronavirus pandemic continues to disrupt demand. Brent crude futures fell 6.8% to $25.14 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 5.6% to $21.37 a barrel. The current production cut deal expires on March 31, with analysts predicting demand will fall by 10% due to the pandemic. Goldman Sachs estimates a 8 million barrel-per-day demand loss, while Vitol expects a 10 million barrel-per-day decline. Oil prices have fallen 60% since the start of the year.

site_title: New Zealand central bank to inject NZ$30b into economy
summary: New Zealand's central bank, Reserve Bank of New Zealand, announced plans to inject NZ$30 billion into the economy through government bonds to stimulate the virus-hit economy. The move comes after slashing its base rate to 0.25% and a government spending package of NZ$12.1 billion. The bank cited negative economic implications of the coronavirus outbreak and agreed that further monetary stimulus is needed to meet inflation and employment objectives. The economy, heavily reliant on tourism and farm exports, is worth about NZ$310 billion a year.

site_title: Italy bans internal travel as a further 651 die from coronavirus
summary: Italy has banned internal travel and frozen non-essential business activities in an effort to slow the spread of coronavirus. The move comes as the country's death toll reaches 5,476, with 651 new fatalities reported. The government has also ordered companies to shut down until April 3, affecting sectors such as the car, clothing, and furniture industries. Despite a slight drop in new cases, health officials warn that the situation remains dire, with Italy's health system at breaking point.

site_title: Investors will emerge from 'fog of war' in unfamiliar terrain
summary: Investors are emerging from the "fog of war" in the midst of the fastest stock market correction in history, driven by the coronavirus. The current environment is characterized by a lack of liquidity, increased risk, and a shift in investor risk assessment, with equity and credit risk turning from green to red. Investors face unfamiliar territory, with a growing component of risk residing in asset classes beyond their natural habitat and lacking inherent liquidity. The industry's capacity to absorb risk has been curtailed by regulation, consolidation, and tighter risk management, exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Swedish PM tells Swedes to take responsibility in national address on coronavirus
summary: Sweden's Prime Minister Stefan Lofven urged citizens to take responsibility in a national address on coronavirus, with 1,906 confirmed cases and 21 deaths. He emphasized the need for individual sacrifices to prevent the spread of the disease, especially for vulnerable groups. Sweden has closed high schools and universities, banned public gatherings, and recommended social distancing for those above 70. The move comes as the country faces staff shortages and a risk of protective gear shortages.

images.alt_text: Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lofven in a rare live television address to the nation on Sunday evening called on all Swedes to play their part in stopping the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: World Bank moving forward on US$1.7b in pandemic aid projects
summary: The World Bank's executive board is set to consider $1.7 billion in pandemic aid projects for Afghanistan and Ethiopia, funded through the $14 billion Fast Track Facility approved last week. The projects aim to help countries respond to the coronavirus pandemic's health and economic impact. World Bank teams are preparing projects in 40 countries, with work advancing on projects in 14 other countries. The Bank is also working to free up $1.5 billion in Covid-19 funding in 24 countries and extend trade finance and working capital lines to clients.

images.alt_text: The World Bank's executive board is expected to consider later this week the first fast-track funds to help Afghanistan and Ethiopia respond to the coronavirus pandemic, the Bank's president said on Sunday.

site_title: Gilead puts emergency access to experimental coronavirus drug on hold amid surging demand
summary: Gilead Sciences has temporarily halted emergency access to its experimental coronavirus drug remdesivir due to overwhelming demand, citing an exponential increase in compassionate-use requests. The company plans to shift to expanded access programs, prioritizing enrollment in clinical trials to generate data on the treatment's safety and effectiveness. Exceptions will be made for pregnant women and children under 18 with severe Covid-19. The move comes as the US and Europe struggle with the rapid spread of the virus, with no approved treatments or vaccines available.

site_title: Lush landscapes, historic sites, engaging festivals
summary: Pakistan welcomes travelers with top ratings from Conde Nast Traveller and Forbes, boasting diverse landscapes, historic sites, and engaging festivals. The country offers great value to Singaporeans, with their money multiplying 100 times when converted to the Pakistani rupee. The new government is promoting tourism, and the improving security situation has helped increase tourism figures. Pakistan's earnings from tourism are expected to nearly double from $22 billion in 2017 to $40 billion by 2028. The country has introduced a liberal visa regime, and Singapore nationals can apply for visas online.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit sets up S$2b debt issuance programme
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) has set up a S$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The programme, managed by DBS Trustee and OUE CT Treasury, will issue unsubordinated notes and unsecured perpetual securities. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings, fund corporate activities, and finance working capital purposes. Units of OUE C-Reit gained 3.5 cents or 12.1% to 32.5 cents at Friday's close.

site_title: Singapore banks show voracious appetite in buying back shares
summary: Singapore banks have aggressively bought back shares since March, with DBS leading the tally at S$368 million, exceeding its 2019 total. UOB and OCBC also participated, spending S$16.2 million and S$19.2 million respectively. The surge in share buybacks comes as the banks' shares have fallen 25-30% due to the virus outbreak, trading below book value. Analysts attribute the move to the banks' belief that their shares are undervalued, with some seeing it as a signal that the companies' shares are priced below intrinsic value.

site_title: Private, online and hi-tech: the coronavirus economy
summary: The coronavirus pandemic has accelerated the shift towards private, online, and tech-based living, with certain sectors thriving while others struggle. Online retailers like Walmart and Amazon have seen a surge in demand, while small businesses and traditional cinema chains face significant challenges. The airline industry is also severely impacted, with private jet charter companies experiencing a surge in demand as wealthy customers opt for safer alternatives. Meanwhile, technology that enables online group meetings and collaborations has spiked, with companies like Zoom experiencing a significant increase in stock value.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Singapore SME retailers come together to help one another
summary: Singapore SME retailers have formed a COVID-19 Pledge to provide support and relief to workers during the pandemic. The initiative, led by Pure Senses, offers a cash allowance to participating businesses. Other SMEs can sign up to join the initiative, aiming to help each other navigate the challenges posed by the outbreak.

site_title: US says website offered phony coronavirus vaccines
summary: The US Justice Department cracked down on a website offering phony coronavirus vaccines, marking its first action against coronavirus-related fraud. The website, which has since been shut down, was selling vaccines for a fee, despite the US having no approved vaccines available at the time. The move comes as the coronavirus has killed over 400 Americans and disrupted millions of lives. The case highlights the growing concern of coronavirus-related scams and the government's efforts to combat them.

site_title: Goldman injects US$1b into own money-market funds
summary: Goldman Sachs injected over $1 billion into its prime money-market portfolios amid heavy investor withdrawals due to coronavirus-related stress. The bank purchased $722.4 million from the GS Financial Square Money Market Fund and $301.2 million from the GS Fund Square Prime Obligations Fund. This move aims to boost liquidity and mitigate the impact of investor outflows.

site_title: Buybacks and director acquisitions continue surge
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 13.3% from March 13 to 19, with the FTSE All World Index dropping 22.9% for the year. Share buybacks surged with 49 stocks repurchasing shares for S$208.3 million. Director acquisitions also increased, with 130 director changes and 39 substantial shareholder acquisitions. Key director acquisitions included Wee Investments acquiring 3.97 million shares of UOL Group, and executive chairman Loo Choon Yong acquiring 4.03 million shares of Raffles Medical Group.

site_title: Stocks, corporate bond recovery only when cash scramble ends
summary: The US economy has ground to a halt due to the Covid-19 pandemic, causing a historic stock-market crash and credit crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 13% last week, its biggest loss since 1987, and fell to its lowest level in over a decade. The Federal Reserve and US government have launched massive stimulus efforts, but it remains unclear if these efforts can prevent a catastrophic collapse. The crisis has also affected major industries such as car production and retail sales, with unemployment claims expected to rise to over 2 million.

site_title: Weathering a tornado of change
summary: Business leaders discuss how to prepare for a prolonged Covid-19 pandemic, with a focus on innovation, resilience, and adaptability. They emphasize the need to re-imagine offerings, services, and strategies to address changing needs and constraints. Key takeaways include: leveraging technology to enhance remote work, prioritizing business continuity and client service excellence, and fostering a culture of empathy and resilience. Many organizations are also exploring new opportunities, such as local sourcing, teleworking, and circular thinking, to emerge stronger and more relevant in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: US home sales race to 13-year high, but virus disruption looms
summary: US home sales reached a 13-year high in February with existing home sales increasing 6.5% to 5.77 million units, the highest level since 2007. However, the housing market recovery is likely to be derailed by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has disrupted economic activity and led to a surge in job losses. Economists predict a recession by the second quarter, with jobless claims reaching a 21/2-year high and potentially exceeding 2 million next week.

site_title: SIA looking to store some planes as travel demand evaporates
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is considering storing some of its planes, including the double-decker Airbus A380, due to reduced travel demand amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline is assessing its network and will make any announcements when necessary. SIA's budget unit Scoot is also cutting 99% of its flights for two weeks. Analyst Brendan Sobie expects the global A380 fleet to be grounded by the end of March due to inefficiency and low passenger demand. SIA may accelerate the retirement of older model aircraft and use some passenger planes for cargo to meet demand.

site_title: Asia steps up virus efforts as 2nd wave of infections strikes
summary: Asia steps up virus efforts as a second wave of COVID-19 infections strikes the region. The number of cases in Asia has surpassed 95,000, with South Korea being the hardest-hit country with over 8,500 cases. Authorities have imposed tighter travel restrictions, closed businesses, and implemented lockdowns in several countries, including Australia, India, and Pakistan. The World Health Organization has called for "aggressive" action in the region, fearing a major outbreak could cripple healthcare systems.

site_title: Commercial property market on ice as virus wreaks havoc
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought the commercial property market to a standstill, with hotels, offices, and retail spaces lying empty. The lack of clarity on the crisis's duration and impact on the economy is causing widespread panic among investors, leading to a 45% decline in investment activity this year. Deals are collapsing, and credit is shrinking, with up to 15% of commercial property loans potentially defaulting in the next two years if a recession hits. Experts predict long-lasting changes in the industry, with shopping malls and office space demand expected to decline, and telecommuting becoming the new norm.

site_title: Social capital and trust help government respond to virus crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong attributes the country's effective response to the Covid-19 outbreak to its high social capital and trust. He emphasizes the importance of transparency and communication during the crisis. Lee notes that the government has worked closely with the public and media to provide updates and reassure citizens. Despite acknowledging that the crisis is far from over, Lee highlights the need for Singapore to diversify and secure its food supplies, while also maintaining connections with the global community.

site_title: Stimulus, rate cuts offer reprieve but STI still at risk
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index gained 99.74 points or 4.3% to close at 2,410.74 last Friday, ending its losing streak. Despite government and central bank measures, market watchers warn the risks of a pandemic-induced recession remain high. Economists have lowered global GDP growth forecast for 2020 to 1.6%, citing the potential for credit shocks and ongoing virus outbreaks. Job vacancies are expected to fall further due to the virus outbreak, while some companies may benefit from China's recovery in manufacturing activity.

site_title: US market sell-off brings short sellers US$344b profit
summary: US investors made a significant profit of $344 billion from short-selling in the last month as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq declined. Short sellers, who bet on stock declines, pocketed the difference between the borrowed shares and their resale price. This profit surge is attributed to the ongoing global spread of the novel coronavirus and the darkening economic prospects. The data from S3 Partners indicates no turnaround in bearish sentiment, with short sellers continuing to bet against US stocks.

site_title: Airlines appear to come up short in bid to win cash grants in rescue package
summary: Major US airlines' last-ditch effort to secure $29 billion in cash grants from the US government to weather the coronavirus crisis appears unsuccessful. The airlines offered to avoid job cuts through August 31 and restrictions on executive pay in exchange for the grants. Without direct cash assistance, airlines may need to implement "draconian measures" such as furloughs. Airlines are expected to apply for collateralized loans and will face terms that could include demanding stock, warrants, or options as part of any loans.

site_title: Covid-19 hits the ST Index
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has plunged 24% since March due to the economic impact of Covid-19, with China's retail sales and industrial output declining significantly. The US Federal Reserve's drastic rate cut and quantitative easing measures have failed to calm markets, instead highlighting the severity of the situation. The oil price war and disruptions to global supply chains have also weighed down business sentiments. Investors are watching for potential support levels at 2,200 and 2,528, but a rebound may not be a recovery, and negative catalysts such as further Covid-19 escalation could lead to further declines.

site_title: Dollar eases after ferocious rally
summary: The US dollar eased on Friday after a ferocious rally last week, losing 0.3% to 1.2000 against the euro. The dollar's surge was driven by investors seeking safe-haven assets amid market volatility. Six major central banks announced a coordinated action to enhance liquidity in the greenback, increasing daily currency swap operations. However, the dollar still faces challenges, with some funding indicators showing strains in the market. Analysts warn that the situation remains stressed, despite lower FX volatility.

site_title: Coronavirus: 23 new cases in Singapore including 18 imported; 4 recovered
summary: Singapore reported 23 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 455, with 18 imported cases and 5 locally transmitted cases. Four more have recovered, totaling 144 cases discharged from hospital. The government has tightened border controls, suspending short-term visitor entry and restricting gatherings. The country has also implemented safe distancing measures. To date, over 260,000 COVID-19 cases have been reported globally, with 11,200 deaths.

site_title: UK government to pay workers' wages to stem coronavirus layoffs
summary: The UK government will pay a significant share of private sector wage bills to prevent layoffs as the country struggles with the coronavirus shutdown. The plan, announced by Finance Minister Rishi Sunak, will cover 80% of workers' salaries, up to £2,500 per month, for firms that keep staff on. The measure, funded by increased debt, aims to mitigate the economic impact of the shutdown and is part of a broader £100 billion economic response package.

site_title: Hotelier grandson of Asia's sugar king turns venture capitalist
summary: Kuok Meng Xiong, the 38-year-old grandson of Asia's "Sugar King" Robert Kuok, has launched K3 Ventures, a venture capital firm with a focus on supporting startups in Singapore and beyond. The firm has backed 38 companies, including China's Bytedance and Singapore's Grab Holdings, with investments ranging from $1 million to $3 million, yielding a 43% return to date. Kuok aims to help companies "disrupt" the traditional industries dominated by his family's conglomerate, while maintaining the firm's minimalistic approach and hands-on involvement.

site_title: Amazon raises overtime pay for warehouse workers
summary: Amazon raises overtime pay for US warehouse workers to double pay after 40 hours, up from 1.5 times the regular rate, from March 15 to May 9, amid the COVID-19 outbreak. This is the second pay increase for Amazon workers in a week, following a hike in the minimum hourly rate to $17 from $15. The company also offers unlimited unpaid time off and has implemented measures to reduce contact among employees. Despite this, four Democratic US senators expressed concern over the lack of hazard pay for warehouse staff, with one senator applauding the wage increase but calling for further action.

site_title: Malaysian army helping to enforce two-week travel curb
summary: Malaysia has deployed its army to enforce a two-week travel curb amid the country's high number of coronavirus cases, with over 3,460 infected and 86 deaths. The restrictions follow a mass Islamic gathering in February that linked to the majority of cases. Troops join police in roadblocks and patrols to ensure compliance, with 90% of the population adhering but 10% still not cooperating. The government aims to track and test remaining attendees, isolate, and treat infected individuals.

site_title: Tokyo organisers planning for potential Olympics delay: sources
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics organisers are drafting alternative plans in case of a postponement due to the coronavirus outbreak, with possible scenarios including delays of one or two years. Despite the Japanese government's stance that postponement is not an option, officials are exploring options to mitigate potential losses of over $25 billion. The International Olympic Committee has also expressed willingness to consider different scenarios, but athletes and sponsors are growing increasingly concerned about the health risks associated with holding the Games as planned.

site_title: Homes, offices, the great outdoors - NetLink wants to hook up wherever
summary: NetLink NBN Trust, a Singapore-based fibre broadband business trust, is seen as resilient in the face of the pandemic due to its steady revenue and growth potential in non-residential markets. The trust aims to expand its services to small businesses, non-broadband users, and 5G developments. Despite facing challenges, NetLink's CEO, Tong Yew Heng, remains positive about the outlook, citing the trust's business model as "resilient" and its ability to adapt to new technologies. The trust plans to invest in fibre-to-anywhere infrastructure and expects higher capital expenditure this year.

site_title: Thailand announces market steps to ease coronavirus impact
summary: Thailand's Bank of Thailand has introduced measures to ease the impact of the coronavirus, including a facility to provide liquidity for mutual funds and a corporate bond stabilisation fund. The measures aim to provide liquidity and build investors' confidence in the financial market. The bank's preliminary estimate of eligible bond mutual funds is approximately 1 trillion baht. Thailand reported 599 coronavirus cases, with one death, and has implemented various restrictions, including mall closures and school and bar closures. The bank's interest rate was cut unexpectedly on Friday, and economists predict the economy will contract this year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) has set up a facility to provide liquidity for mutual funds through commercial banks.

site_title: Ackman, Cohodes warn of private equity pain in virus shakeout
summary: Short-seller Marc Cohodes and investor Bill Ackman warn of potential losses for private equity funds due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing high debt levels and a near freeze in leveraged lending. Cohodes predicts the industry's "game is in the process of ending" and that firms will be exposed as having overpaid for assets with excessive leverage. Ackman warns that if the crisis persists, private equity firms, including Blackstone and KKR, could also go bankrupt. The outcome depends on the course of the virus outbreak and the availability of liquidity.

site_title: China to divert Beijing-bound international flights to other airports
summary: China's aviation regulator has announced that all international flights due to arrive in Beijing will be diverted to 12 other designated airports starting Monday. Passengers will undergo screening before being allowed to reboard their planes and travel to Beijing. This measure is part of China's efforts to combat the coronavirus.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the week's tanker and dry bulk market. Key highlights include:

- The Capesize market made gains, with the Cape 5TC settling at $4,067, a +$1,270 increase from the previous week.
- The Atlantic Basin saw a decline in bunker prices, lifting timecharter rates in relation to marked voyage rates.
- The Panamax market experienced a thin week, with owners locking in for longer duration business due to the bleak macro-outlook.
- The Supramax/Ultramax market was volatile, with rates fluctuating due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
- The Handysize market had a positive week, with rates in the Continent to Mediterranean trade broadly remaining firm.
- The tanker market saw a decline in rates, particularly for VLCCs, with charterers waiting for sentiment-driven rises.
- The Suezmax market experienced a crash in rates, while the Aframax market saw a modest rise in rates.

site_title: Singapore shuts borders to short-term visitors
summary: Singapore has closed its borders to all short-term visitors, effective March 23, as part of its efforts to reduce the importation of COVID-19 cases. Only essential workers, including healthcare, transport, and logistics personnel, will be allowed entry or return. This move aims to conserve resources and limit new cases, while also affecting the aviation and tourism industries, which are expected to suffer further economic losses. Economists warn that this will have a significant impact on the economy, with potential contractions and investment slowdowns.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China looks headed for worst economic performance in 50 years
summary: China's economy is projected to experience its worst performance in 50 years, with the latest data showing a double-digit contraction in January and February. Estimates suggest a negative quarter-on-quarter growth of 10-20%. This grim outlook raises pressure on policymakers, who are expected to take action to stabilize the economy. The contraction is worse than analysts' initial expectations, highlighting the severity of the economic standstill.

site_title: Virus chaos leaves English football clubs fearing for their future
summary: English football clubs outside the Premier League face financial uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with Championship, League One, and League Two matches delayed until April 30 at the earliest. A £50 million relief package has been agreed upon, but it may only be enough to tide clubs over for four weeks, prompting fears of layoffs and potential team closures. Some teams, like Hearts in Scotland, have already implemented 50% wage cuts, and non-league clubs may need government aid to survive, with estimates suggesting £15-20 million in bailout funds are required.

images.alt_text: Championship, League One and League Two matches will not resume until April 30 at the earliest and even that date looks optimistic given the chaos caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Aussie government to spend A$66.4b on second stimulus package
summary: The Australian government plans to spend A$66.4 billion on its second stimulus package, aiming to support individuals in need and small to medium-sized businesses that produce a third of the country's annual economic output and employ over 40% of the workforce. This move comes as states impose major lockdowns due to the coronavirus. The stimulus package will help shelter the economy from the financial impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Is overcoming Covid-19 a war that can be won?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is likened to a war, with investors seeking companies that benefit from a prolonged fight. US President Donald Trump has referred to the pandemic as a "wartime president" and invoked the Defense Production Act to accelerate medical supply production. Private companies, such as Ford and Tesla, have also pledged to produce medical equipment. However, economists warn that the pandemic's economic impact will be severe and widespread, and that governments must contain the spread of the virus to protect vulnerable populations and economies.

site_title: Doing their bit in the war against Covid-19
summary: GrabCare drivers, led by Grab driver Michael Lee, are part of an initiative to enable healthcare professionals to travel to and from hospitals. Lee, who has been driving since February, says he never intended to back away from the fight against Covid-19. His family helps him manage his mask and hand sanitizer supplies, and his 8-year-old daughter reminds him to wear a mask when passengers are unwell. The GrabCare program aims to support healthcare workers during the pandemic.

site_title: New York's millennial homeowners and where to find them
summary: Millennials in New York face significant challenges in buying homes due to high prices, restrictive lending rules, and lingering student debt. Despite this, some are making progress through government programs and innovative financing options. The median household income of millennials in New York is around $108,000, but 91,585 of them own homes, representing just 9% of all homeowners. To overcome these obstacles, young buyers are exploring co-ops, income-restricted apartments, and negotiating with developers to secure affordable deals.

site_title: Singapore businesses seek larger second stimulus package urgently as global economy worsens
summary: Singapore businesses are urging the government to consider a larger second stimulus package due to the worsening global economy amid the Covid-19 outbreak. A poll by the Singapore Business Federation found 73% of businesses believe the package should be as large or larger than the S$4 billion announced in Budget 2020. The poll also revealed businesses need support for wage costs, tax rebates, and manpower challenges. Despite this, 86% of respondents said their businesses are ready to ride out the situation for at least six months.

site_title: Crude reality: price crash means oil firms must slash spending
summary: Oil firms face a significant challenge as the COVID-19 pandemic and price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia lead to a record drop in oil prices. Investment spending is expected to decline by half a trillion US dollars, with companies like Saudi Aramco and Exxon Mobil Corporation cutting their investments. The industry is struggling, with smaller companies potentially facing restructurings and shutdowns. Environmental activists see this as an opportunity to reduce fossil fuel reliance, but some positive outcomes, such as increased investment in renewables, may also emerge.

site_title: Amazon raises overtime pay for warehouse workers
summary: Amazon is raising overtime pay for US warehouse workers to double pay after 40 hours, up from 1.5 times, from March 15 to May 9, as the company tries to meet growing demand during the coronavirus outbreak. The move comes as CEO Jeff Bezos focuses on COVID-19 efforts. The change affects hourly workers at Amazon's US warehouses, providing a temporary boost to their pay.

site_title: Taiwan might be rolling out its new stock trading system at the wrong time
summary: Taiwan is set to roll out a new stock trading system, allowing continuous trading, rather than a five-second matched call auction. The change, which began on Monday, is the only major capital market to use auctions throughout regular trading. However, the timing may be problematic, as it coincides with a period of market uncertainty due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: US airlines appear to come up short in bid to win cash grants in coronavirus rescue package
summary: US airlines' last-ditch effort to secure cash grants from the coronavirus rescue package appears unsuccessful. In a letter to congressional aides, the CEOs of 10 major US airlines requested $29 billion of the $58 billion sought, offering not to make job cuts through August 31 if granted. Without direct cash assistance, airlines warned they may need to implement "draconian measures" like furloughs. Despite this, the airlines' plea seems to have fallen short, leaving them to consider other options to weather the crisis.

site_title: Tokyo organisers quietly plan for potential Olympic delay, sources say
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympic organisers have started drafting alternative plans in case of a potential delay due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the Japanese government's stance that postponement is not an option, organisers have been exploring different scenarios, including scaling back the Games or holding them without spectators. A final decision on postponement will be made by the International Olympic Committee, but Japan's stance also plays a significant role in the decision. Organisers are concerned about the financial implications of a delay, with over $15 billion at stake.

site_title: Covid-19: MOM revokes 89 work passes for breach of entry approval, SHN requirements
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has revoked 89 work passes for breaching entry approval and stay-home notice (SHN) requirements due to COVID-19. 73 of these breaches involved work-pass holders with travel history to affected countries who entered Singapore without approval, while 16 were caught violating leave of absence or SHN requirements. Those found guilty have been permanently banned from working in Singapore, and their employers have been suspended from issuing work passes for one to three years.

site_title: EU to suspend budget rules to help face virus crisis
summary: The European Commission has decided to suspend EU budget rules to help countries respond to the coronavirus pandemic. EU chief Ursula von der Leyen triggered the "general escape clause," allowing governments to freely inject spending into the economy as needed. This move aims to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia adds A$66.4b in stimulus, considers 'draconian' steps to curb coronavirus
summary: Australia's government has announced a second stimulus package worth A$66.4 billion to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus, with measures including underwriting loans for small businesses and boosting unemployment benefits. The country has recorded 7 Covid-19 deaths and 1,098 confirmed cases. To curb the spread of the virus, the government is considering "draconian" social distancing measures, including closing public spaces, and has already enforced restrictions on gatherings. The stimulus package dwarfs the initial A$17.6 billion measures, with Australia now committing about 10% of its annual GDP to support.

site_title: Malaysia deploys army as coronavirus curbs spread across Southeast Asia
summary: Malaysia has deployed the army to enforce a two-week travel curb amid a surge in coronavirus cases, with over 3,460 infected and 86 deaths. The majority of cases, 63%, are linked to an Islamic gathering in Kuala Lumpur. Singapore and Vietnam have also banned foreigners entering their countries. Indonesia, with the highest number of cases in Southeast Asia, has turned an emergency hospital into a COVID-19 treatment center. The region's rapid spread of cases has prompted widespread restrictions and measures to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Water is an under-used weapon in climate change fight, UN says
summary: The UN says water is an under-used weapon in the fight against climate change, with efficient use of water in daily life, agriculture, and industry helping reduce emissions and curb climate change. Global warming threatens the right to water and sanitation for billions of people, and policymakers and businesses should manage water resources better to conserve electricity and fuel needed for water pumping, cleaning, and delivery.

site_title: Stay home for three months, UK tells 1.5 million people most at risk
summary: The UK government advises 1.5 million vulnerable individuals to stay at home for at least 12 weeks due to the coronavirus epidemic. Those with underlying health conditions, such as cancer or organ transplants, are at high risk. The government will contact individuals through their GP practice and offer support, including a dedicated phone line and grocery delivery arrangements. This measure aims to protect the National Health Service and save lives.

site_title: Air quality picking up in quarantined countries
summary: Air quality in quarantined countries is improving, with a significant drop in nitrogen dioxide (NO2) emissions in Wuhan, China, and northern Italy, according to NASA and European Space Agency images. However, recent data shows a resurgence in NO2 emissions in China, and the trend is still unclear. Experts note that NO2 is a short-lived pollutant, but long-term exposure to air pollution can cause serious health issues, including respiratory problems and premature deaths. The confinement measures are expected to reduce pollution, but the long-term impact on health is still unknown.

site_title: Wuhan recovery gives hope to rest of world: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reported that Wuhan, China, has not recorded any new cases of Covid-19 in 24 hours, marking the first time since the outbreak began. This development gives hope to the rest of the world battling the pandemic, with WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stating that the situation can be turned around with caution and solidarity between generations. Young people are also not spared, with Tedros warning that they can be hospitalized for weeks or even die from the disease.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization said Friday that the Chinese epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak at last reporting no new cases gave hope to the rest of the world battling the pandemic.

site_title: Virus-hit UK companies told to halt financial statements
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in the UK has advised listed companies to halt the publication of preliminary financial statements for at least two weeks to assess the impact of the novel coronavirus epidemic on their businesses. This decision follows the government's shutdown of shops, restaurants, and other public places and advises people to avoid non-essential travel. The FCA aims to ensure companies can provide more accurate financial information amid the pandemic.

site_title: EasyJet to ground majority of planes from Tuesday
summary: British airline easyJet will ground the majority of its planes starting from March 24 due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline will complete repatriation flights by Monday. This move mirrors actions by other carriers worldwide, citing country lockdowns, travel restrictions, and changes in travel advice.

site_title: Chinese economy normalising but stark risks remain: IMF
summary: China's economy is showing signs of normalisation after the COVID-19 pandemic, but stark risks remain. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) notes that most larger Chinese firms have reopened, but infections could rise again as travel resumes. Outbreaks in other countries and financial market volatility may also affect consumer and firm confidence in Chinese goods. China's economy is expected to slow significantly in the first quarter, with the IMF citing weak industrial production and retail sales data. The IMF advises policymakers to continue supporting growth and financial stability, and to coordinate internationally.

site_title: How the coronavirus has affected New York real estate
summary: The novel coronavirus has significantly impacted the New York real estate market, with brokers, buyers, and sellers struggling to adapt to new norms. Open houses have been limited or banned, and FaceTime tours have become the norm. Brokers are now required to sanitize surfaces, conduct pre-showings to assess buyers' health, and limit the number of attendees. Some buildings have even shut down amenities like gyms and playrooms. As the city moves towards a near-total shutdown, some buyers are opting for short-term rentals in the suburbs, while others are considering leaving the city for good.

images.alt_text: As the city moves toward a near total shutdown, some New Yorkers are looking for ways to leave its confines. Those who have second homes are heading to them, and others with the means are seeking short-term rentals in the more sparsely populated suburbs.

site_title: Crowdsourced virtual supercomputer revs up virus research
summary: A crowdsourced virtual supercomputer, "Folding@Home", has been created to accelerate research for a coronavirus treatment. The project, led by computational biologists, harnesses idle computing power from over 400,000 users worldwide to handle trillions of calculations needed to understand the structure of the virus. The virtual supercomputer has a capacity of 400 petaflops, three times more powerful than the world's top supercomputers, and is working in parallel with other supercomputers to identify potential drug therapies. The project aims to find "pockets" or holes in the virus where a drug can be squeezed in, and has already made significant progress, including identifying 77 potential compounds that could bind to the main "spike" protein of the coronavirus.

site_title: Singapore to shut borders to short term visitors from Monday, 11.59pm
summary: Singapore will close its borders to short-term visitors starting Monday at 11:59pm, limiting entry to those providing essential services like healthcare and transport. Short-term visitors who arrived in Singapore over the weekend will be required to serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) before leaving the country. Returning Singapore citizens and long-term pass holders will also be issued a two-week SHN upon entry. The move aims to conserve resources and limit the importation of Covid-19 cases, following a surge in global cases.

site_title: Malaysia growth seen as low as 2% on 'triple whammy' of troubles
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace since the 2009 financial crisis, with analysts predicting a 2% growth rate for 2020 due to a "triple whammy" of troubles: the coronavirus, oil-price crash, and political upheaval. The country is grappling with the most cases of Covid-19 in South-east Asia, prompting a lockdown and government measures to bolster the economy. Analysts from various firms, including Fitch Ratings, United Overseas Bank, and Kenanga Research, have revised their forecasts to reflect the challenges facing Malaysia's economy.

site_title: UAE reports first two deaths from coronavirus
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) reported its first two deaths from coronavirus, with 140 infections confirmed in Abu Dhabi, where 31 have recovered. This marks a significant development in the country's response to the pandemic.

site_title: Italy shuts factories as daily toll nears 800
summary: Italy shut all non-essential factories after recording 4,825 coronavirus fatalities, surpassing a third of the world's total, and overtook China as the global epicenter of Covid-19. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte emphasized the need for essential goods and services to remain operational, while urging the elderly to stay indoors due to the average age of victims being 78.5. The country's infection rate rose by 6,557 to 53,578, with Lombardy reporting 3,251 new cases, as the situation continues to worsen.

site_title: Europe: Shares crawl into second day of gains, but lose for week
summary: European shares rose 1.8% on Friday, their second consecutive day of gains, but closed the week down for the fifth time. Initial optimism from emergency measures by the Bank of England and European Central Bank was short-lived, as fears over the economic impact of the coronavirus persisted. The outbreak showed no signs of slowing, with the death toll in Italy surpassing China's. Defensive sectors such as telecom and healthcare performed well, while the travel and leisure sector surged 10% after a 19-year low.

site_title: US senators question Amazon on coronavirus safety at warehouses
summary: US senators Cory Booker, Bernie Sanders, Robert Menendez, and Sherrod Brown expressed concern over Amazon's coronavirus safety measures, citing low supply of disinfectant wipes and concerns about worker safety. Amazon disputed the allegations, stating it has taken measures to keep employees safe, including staggering work times and requiring hand-washing. The senators requested answers on covering Covid-19 test costs and offering paid sick leave. Amazon has announced benefits, including unlimited unpaid time off, to employees fearful of contagion.

site_title: United Airlines slashes international schedule by 95% for April
summary: United Airlines slashes its international schedule by 95% for April due to government restrictions on travel to curb the coronavirus spread. All flights to Canada will be suspended starting April 1, while trans-Atlantic, trans-Pacific, and Mexico operations will also be significantly reduced. This move follows an initial 60% schedule reduction announced earlier.

site_title: Elon Musk, Medtronic discuss ventilators amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla CEO, discussed ventilators with medical device maker Medtronic amid the US coronavirus shortage. Musk tweeted about a "long engineering discussion" with Medtronic, but neither party elaborated on the topic or potential outcomes. This comes as governments worldwide, including the US, appeal to automakers and manufacturers to ramp up ventilator production. Musk previously offered to make ventilators for coronavirus sufferers, following the US appeal for respirator mask donations.

site_title: To release or not to release? Music's dilemma over virus
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has raised questions about releasing new music, with some artists choosing to wait, while others have decided to proceed with their planned albums. The Weeknd released his 14-track album "After Hours" despite the timing being considered terrible. Other artists, including Baxter Dury and Thomas Dutronc, have also released their albums, while some have postponed their releases. Some musicians, like Bob Geldof, have expressed concerns about the timing, but many hope their music can bring comfort to fans during this challenging time.

site_title: US senators launch negotiations on US$1t stimulus
summary: US senators began negotiations on a $1 trillion emergency stimulus package to aid Americans affected by the coronavirus, with Republicans seeking rapid passage and Democrats pushing for stronger worker protections. The proposed package includes one-time "recovery rebates" of up to $1,200 for adults earning under $99,000 annually and loan guarantees for industries hit by the crisis. Senate leaders aim to reach a compromise by the end of the day, with a vote on final passage planned for Monday.

site_title: Netflix commits US$100m to help actors, crews thrown out of work
summary: Netflix has launched a $100 million fund to support actors and production crews affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The majority of the funds will go to financially troubled workers on Netflix productions worldwide. The move aims to provide economic support to the "creative community" during this challenging time, with Netflix chief content officer Ted Sarandos stating that the company wants to help those who have supported it through good times.

site_title: US senators defend selling shares before coronavirus crash
summary: US Senators Richard Burr and Kelly Loeffler faced criticism for selling large amounts of stock before the coronavirus-induced market meltdown. Burr sold up to $1.7 million in February after public assurances the government was ready to battle the virus, while Loeffler sold up to $3.1 million in January after participating in a private coronavirus briefing. Both senators denied wrongdoing and claimed they followed proper procedures. President Donald Trump called for an investigation, but some critics, including Democratic Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, called for the senators to resign or face prosecution for insider trading.

site_title: Saudi to hike borrowing to stimulate virus-hit economy
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to raise borrowing by 20 percentage points to 50% of GDP to stabilize its economy affected by plunging oil prices and the COVID-19 pandemic. Finance Minister Mohammed al-Jadaan announced a 120 billion riyal ($32 billion) stimulus package to support the economy, which will be partly funded through increased borrowing. The country's public debt burden is expected to reach 50% of GDP by 2022, with a projected deficit of 7-9% of GDP for the current year.

site_title: Airbnb board meets to consider raising funds or buying assets
summary: Airbnb's board met to consider options due to the economic crisis, including acquiring distressed assets, raising funds, or revising plans for a stock market debut. The company has been approached by a dozen potential investors with offers ranging from $100 million to $1 billion. Airbnb is also exploring acquiring short-term rental providers, such as Sonder Inc, which may be a potential target. The company's valuation is expected to decline from its previous $31 billion due to the pandemic's impact on the home-rental market.

site_title: Singapore reports first two Covid-19 deaths
summary: Singapore reports its first two COVID-19 deaths, with a 75-year-old woman and a 64-year-old Indonesian national passing away due to complications. Both patients had been in the intensive care unit for 26 and 9 days, respectively. The country has confirmed 385 cases, with 131 discharged and most patients improving. The government urges citizens to follow safe distancing measures to slow the spread of the virus.

site_title: Belgian borders shut to non-essential travel
summary: Belgium closed its borders to non-essential travel on March 20, 2020, to contain the coronavirus. The decision was made after talks with neighboring countries, allowing only freight and essential travelers, such as those for national security, healthcare, or EU work, to pass through. Belgians abroad were allowed to return home with an official document.

site_title: North Korea fires two 'ballistic missiles' into sea
summary: North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast, sparking international condemnation as the world struggles with the coronavirus pandemic. The launches, which Japan's defence ministry also confirmed, come despite speculation that the virus has reached the isolated nation. Analysts believe Pyongyang may be trying to normalize its missile tests and that the country is likely struggling with a coronavirus crisis on a national scale. The UN Security Council has made humanitarian exemptions to sanctions on North Korea to help it fight the virus.

site_title: No need to rush Tokyo Olympic decision say US as splits emerge
summary: US Olympic chiefs say more time is needed to determine the fate of the Tokyo Olympics due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a need for expert advice and information. In contrast, the US sports federation USA Swimming calls for the Games to be postponed, citing disruptions to training and competition schedules. The International Olympic Committee is under pressure to make a decision, with athletes and sports leaders expressing concerns about athlete safety and the impact of the pandemic on their preparations.

site_title: ECB says banks now have extra 1.8t euros to lend in virus fight
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has eased rules on capital buffers, allowing banks to issue up to 1.8 trillion euros (US$1.9 trillion) to households and corporate customers in need of extra liquidity during the coronavirus pandemic. The move aims to keep cash flowing and prevent a credit crunch. The ECB has also updated its oversight of banks' lending operations to take into account massive crisis-fighting support from eurozone governments, and will consider government moratoriums on loan repayments when evaluating lenders' stock of outstanding credit.

site_title: UK government orders closures to fight virus
summary: The UK government has ordered the closure of cafes, pubs, bars, restaurants, nightclubs, theatres, and leisure centers to combat the coronavirus outbreak. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said these establishments should shut "as soon as they reasonably can" from Friday night, but takeout services will still be allowed. This move aims to slow the spread of the virus and is part of the government's efforts to fight the pandemic.

site_title: AirAsia says review cleared Airbus sponsorships; Tony Fernandes reinstated to CEO
summary: AirAsia has cleared Airbus sponsorships after an independent probe found the procurement process to be robust and justifiable. The airline's procurement with Airbus was found to have demonstrated benefits to the group and was properly disclosed to the board of directors. CEO Tony Fernandes and chairman Kamarudin Meranun, co-owners of a Formula One racing team, have been reinstated following the review. The allegations, which included claims of bribery, were part of a $4 billion settlement between Airbus and regulators.

site_title: Goldman Sachs CEO pay boosted to US$27.5m
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon's pay package increased to $27.5 million in 2019, a 20% jump, as the company continues to operate amidst the coronavirus pandemic. The pay raise is similar to that of other top executives from major financial institutions. Solomon's compensation reflects his efforts in building new consumer-oriented products, including a credit card with Apple. The move has sparked criticism, particularly given the timing and the economic downturn affecting many industries.

site_title: Gold poised for back-to-back weekly slump with dollar rampant
summary: Gold is poised for a back-to-back weekly loss, its first since September, due to the coronavirus crisis and the dollar's surge to an all-time high. Despite emergency rate cuts and asset-purchase programs, gold remains lower this year. The metal's decline is attributed to investors selling gold to raise cash amid extreme market volatility, with some fearing the economic downturn will last longer. Central banks' efforts to mitigate the damage have not calmed stressed markets, with gold taking a backseat to the dollar as the preferred haven.

site_title: Covid-19: Stricter measures like ban on events with over 250 people; new contact tracing app
summary: Singapore introduces stricter "safe distancing measures" to reduce Covid-19 local transmissions, including bans on events with over 250 people and public venues. The Ministry of Health also launches a new contact tracing app that will inform users if they have been in close contact with a Covid-19 case. These measures aim to minimize further transmissions and protect public health.

site_title: Delta Air Lines says coronavirus to cut Q2 revenue by 80%
summary: Delta Air Lines warned that the coronavirus outbreak cut earnings by US$10 billion in the second quarter, an 80% drop from a year ago. The airline's chief executive Ed Bastian projected a 80% reduction in June quarter revenues, citing "drastic shutdowns" in the travel industry. Bastian warned that recovery will take an extended period once the virus is contained, with no clear end to the economic impact.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines on Friday warned that plunging travel amid the coronavirus outbreak cut earnings by US$10 billion in the second quarter, an 80 per cent drop from a year ago.

site_title: Malaysians with work permits can continue working in Singapore: MFA
summary: Malaysian workers with Singapore work permits can continue working in Singapore with health screenings and accommodations. Food and products will still be transported across the border smoothly despite Malaysia's two-week lockdown. This decision was made after a phone call between Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean and Malaysian Senior Minister Sri Ismail Sabri Yaakob. The move aims to minimize disruptions to the labor market and supply chain.

site_title: Singapore and New Zealand commit to maintaining supply chains amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: Singapore and New Zealand have committed to maintaining supply chains amid the coronavirus outbreak by removing existing trade restrictive measures on essential goods, particularly medical supplies. The two countries will work closely to identify and address trade disruptions, ensuring that air and sea freight lines remain open to facilitate the flow of goods. This cooperation aims to minimize the impact of the outbreak on trade and maintain open and connected supply chains.

site_title: Australia's Bondi Beach closed after crowds defy coronavirus rules
summary: Australia's iconic Bondi Beach was closed on Saturday after thousands of people defied social distancing orders to visit the beach, despite the country's coronavirus outbreak. The beach closure was announced by New South Wales state police minister David Elliott, citing the need to prevent the spread of the virus. The closure comes amid a rise in infections and deaths across Australia, with the death toll remaining unchanged at seven. The move is part of a broader effort to enforce social distancing rules and prevent large gatherings.

images.alt_text: Australian officials closed Sydney's iconic Bondi Beach on Saturday after thousands of people flocked there in recent days, defying social distancing orders to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, amid an unusually warm autumn spell.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Getaround looks for a buyer as demand evaporates
summary: Getaround, a car-sharing company backed by SoftBank's $100 billion Vision Fund, is seeking a buyer due to a sharp decline in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The startup, which had valued at over $1 billion, has 5 million users and operates in over 300 cities. If unable to find a buyer or secure additional funding, Getaround may consider bankruptcy protection. The company's financial struggles have raised concerns over SoftBank's creditworthiness and the value of its investments.

site_title: Liverpool should not be denied EPL trophy
summary: Liverpool is on track to win its first English Premier League (EPL) title in 30 years, with a 25-point lead over Manchester City. However, the COVID-19 pandemic may disrupt the league's completion, prompting discussions on how to award the title if play is suspended or cancelled. Some suggest freezing the league standings, promoting the top two teams from the second-tier English Championship, and expanding the league to 22 teams for the next season. Fans and officials believe it would be unfair to deny Liverpool the title, given their dominant performance this season.

site_title: Job vacancies to fall further, so focus will be on saving jobs, reskilling workers: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's job vacancies fell 21% in 2019, with 42% of openings being newly-created positions, according to the Ministry of Manpower's report. Despite economic uncertainties, such as the US-China trade war, employers continued to create new jobs. The government is focusing on saving jobs and reskilling workers amid the coronavirus outbreak, with job-matching support for those who need it most. The top industries with new positions were construction, ICT, and security and investigation, with skilled workers in high demand, particularly software developers and teaching professionals.

site_title: Fiat, Toyota, Renault latest to halt Brazil auto production due to virus
summary: Fiat Chrysler, Toyota Motor Corp, and Renault have temporarily halted auto production in Brazil due to the coronavirus pandemic, joining General Motors Co and Mercedes Benz. Volkswagen and Volvo have also announced production halts. The closures follow similar measures in the US and European Union. Auto production in South America is expected to fall by 98,000 units in March and April, according to IHS Markit. Brazil, the continent's largest auto producer, has been significantly impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Lim Jui joins SGInnovate as new CEO
summary: SGInnovate, a Singapore government-owned company, has appointed Lim Jui as its new CEO, effective May 1. Lim joins from NTUitive, bringing over 20 years of experience in innovation, research commercialization, and investment. He aims to support entrepreneurial scientists in building and scaling deep-tech startups, addressing the sector's underfunding issue. The company, which was founded in 2016, will continue to provide equity-based investments, talent access, and business-building advice under Lim's leadership.

site_title: UOB, OCBC unveil relief measures for Malaysia customers as coronavirus outbreak worsens
summary: Singaporean banks UOB and OCBC unveiled relief measures for their Malaysian customers amid the worsening coronavirus outbreak. UOB's measures include a one-year loan repayment moratorium, interest-only repayments, and restructuring options for corporate clients, while retail customers receive a six-month moratorium on personal loans, mortgages, and credit cards. OCBC offers a six-month principal repayment moratorium on housing loans and bridging loans, as well as a special relief fund for SMEs. The banks aim to ease financial burdens and provide support to affected customers.

site_title: Trust is integral to keep wheels of financial markets turning
summary: Trust is crucial in the financial markets, and investment professionals can build credibility and professionalism to earn and maintain client trust. Understanding clients' goals and fears is key, and a trust equation can be used to assess credibility and professionalism. Key components include credibility, professionalism, brand, reputation, and values. Investment firms can demonstrate trustworthiness by maintaining a strong brand, adopting a code of conduct, and showcasing ongoing professional development. By addressing these components, investment professionals can increase client trust and build a more professional industry.

site_title: Search for coronavirus vaccine becomes a global race
summary: A global arms race for a coronavirus vaccine has begun, with China, Europe, and the US competing to develop and produce a vaccine first. The competition has taken on a nationalistic approach, with governments seeking to ensure their own populations receive priority access to the vaccine. This could lead to shortages and unequal distribution of the vaccine. Executives from major pharmaceutical companies are working together to increase production and ensure equitable access, but governments' nationalistic approaches pose a challenge to this goal. A vaccine is at least 12 months away from development.

site_title: US: Dow falls again to end Wall Street's worst week since 2008
summary: Wall Street stocks plummeted, marking the worst week since 2008, as the coronavirus pandemic worsens. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 4.6% to 19,173.98, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 4.3% and 3.8%, respectively. Economists forecast a 13% contraction in the second quarter and warn of a prolonged economic impact, with some predicting an L-shaped recession. The Federal Reserve announced measures to boost liquidity, citing an unprecedented surge in layoffs and revenue decline in many industries.

site_title: 'Supernormal' H2 earnings expected from Top Glove on virus-related demand: analyst
summary: Top Glove Corp's earnings for the second half of 2020 are expected to be "substantially stronger" due to solid demand, a stronger US dollar, and lower rubber costs. The company's weekly sales orders have more than doubled, and sales lead times have jumped to four months, with analyst Lee Yen Ling expecting 8-10% higher sales volume in H2. Despite capacity growth, the company's plant utilization rate has risen to 90%, but may be limited by worker shortages. Maybank IB Research maintains its "buy" call on Top Glove, but lowers its target price to RM6.32.

site_title: Gucci owner Kering warns of fall in Q1 sales
summary: Kering, the French luxury goods group behind Gucci, Saint Laurent, and Balenciaga, expects a 15% decline in comparable sales in the first quarter due to the coronavirus outbreak. The health crisis has forced store closures and sapped demand in major markets like China, the US, and Europe. Operating margins are expected to decline, and the company has implemented cost-cutting measures. Despite this, analysts say Kering's forecast is better than feared, and the company remains well-positioned due to its strong brand portfolio and cash-rich status.
