images.alt_text: Kering, the French luxury goods group behind brands such as Gucci, said on Friday it expected comparable sales to fall by around 15 per cent in the first quarter as the coronavirus outbreak saps demand and forces it to close stores.

site_title: New distancing rules could be last straw for some businesses
summary: Singapore's new social-distancing measures, including suspending events with 250 or more participants and separating patrons by at least a metre at public venues, may be the "last straw" for some frontline businesses already struggling with the COVID-19 outbreak. Many businesses fear they will go under without financial support from customers, landlords, and the government, with some proposing to shut down temporarily or permanently. The measures are seen as a bitter pill to swallow, with some calling for rental rebates and fair sharing of the burden among all parties involved.

images.alt_text: The latest social-distancing measures to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus may deal another heavy blow to frontline businesses already battered by the outbreak.

site_title: More major events in Singapore to be delayed as social distancing kicks in
summary: Singapore has postponed several major industry showcases due to the Covid-19 pandemic, including the Singapore International Water Week (SIWW), which was initially set to take place in July but will now run from June 20 to 24, 2021. The event, co-located with the World Cities Summit and CleanEnviro Summit Singapore, will be delayed alongside two other events, the Asia Infrastructure Forum and Ecosperity Week. The Singapore International Energy Week (SIEW) launch has also been postponed, with no new date announced.

site_title: Cathay Pacific scraps almost all flights as virus stops travel
summary: Cathay Pacific slashes passenger capacity by 96% in April and May due to the COVID-19 pandemic, operating only three flights per week to 12 destinations. The airline had already asked staff to take unpaid leave and warned of a substantial loss in the first half of the year. Cathay Dragon will also operate a reduced schedule, with Cathay Express temporarily shutting down all flight operations to save cash. The airline faces significant financial challenges, with a predicted HK$2 billion loss in February, and the industry as a whole is expected to require state aid and bailouts of up to $200 billion to survive.

site_title: S&P warns 1 in 10 US firms may default on debt amid virus outbreak
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns that 1 in 10 US firms may default on debt due to the coronavirus outbreak, citing a recession and tightening financing conditions. The agency expects a surge in defaults, with a 10% default rate on nonfinancial corporates in the US and high single digits in Europe over the next 12 months. Companies with low credit ratings, such as "junk bonds," will be most vulnerable to adverse conditions. Central banks have flooded markets with liquidity to help firms weather the crisis, but S&P notes that these measures may not be enough to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: A wave of company defaults is likely to sweep the United States and Europe as measures to contain the coronavirus spark a recession, S&P Global Ratings said Friday.

site_title: Battling cabin fever with a dose of song
summary: During the global travel shutdown, music and visuals from around the world are helping make isolation more bearable. Artists like Ben Gibbard, from The Postal Service, have released songs that capture the feelings of confinement and longing. As people stay home, they are turning to the internet to explore new places and sounds, and the World Wide Web is providing a sense of connection to the world beyond their homes. This shift in behavior is a result of the rapid advancement of technology, allowing people to experience new things without physically leaving their surroundings.

site_title: Buying high-end art during a pandemic
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, the high-end art market continued to thrive, with thousands of artworks sold online at Art Basel Hong Kong's virtual fair. Despite initial technical glitches, buying activity picked up, with major galleries like David Zwirner and Hauser & Wirth selling paintings for millions of dollars. The virtual fair showed that online buying has become the new norm, especially among young collectors, with UBS's Global Art Report revealing that millennial collectors are the most active buyers and spent the most on art.

site_title: DBS downgrades SIA Engineering two notches, slashes target price
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded SIA Engineering Company to "fully valued" and slashed its target price to S$1.35 from S$3.30. The research house expects FY2021 revenues to decline by 18% and net profit by 48% due to the Covid-19 outbreak curbing air travel. Dividends are likely to take a beating in FY2021. Analysts attribute the decline to the loss of revenue from a fall in aircraft movements at Changi Airport and global travel restrictions.

site_title: Reits (March 21-22, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors face challenges in the market. US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines, affecting homebuying. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record, with more increases expected. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World sold China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy.

site_title: How to keep your head when other investors are losing theirs
summary: Investors amid the COVID-19 pandemic should remain calm, focusing on signs of a market bottom to re-enter. A global health emergency has triggered a market panic, with the fastest drop in global equities since 1987's Black Monday crash. The author emphasizes that statistics about the virus are irrelevant, and the fear is driven by unknowns about the virus. The article advises investors to look for market bottom signs and notes that Asia will drive and gain from dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are expected to drive ETF growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Platform for day-drinking
summary: A new "drinks studio" platform, Barfly, offers a unique approach to day-drinking by blending cocktails into everyday life. The platform features a low-alcohol cocktail menu alongside cafe staples, emphasizing a relaxed and open setting. Owner Sin Kim Shin aims to introduce cocktails into people's lifestyles, making them more affordable and enjoyable. The platform also offers an alcohol-free menu, "Iced Out," which explores the effects of ice melting on cocktails, and a spirit-forward menu, "Pollen," with floral flavors.

site_title: New York shutters, but Trump says no national lockdown
summary: New York state has implemented a lockdown, banning non-essential businesses and gatherings, as the US total Covid-19-linked deaths more than doubled in three days to 210. President Donald Trump stated the US is "winning" the war and won't need a national lockdown, citing the Midwest's lower case numbers. Essential businesses, such as grocery stores and pharmacies, will remain open in New York, while residents are advised to stay at home unless urgent. The US and Mexico have also agreed to restrict non-essential travel across their border.

images.alt_text: New York followed California on Friday in locking down to stem the coronavirus pandemic as President Donald Trump declared the United States was already "winning" the war despite a rapid rise in confirmed cases and deaths.

site_title: Lower your blood pressure with right lifestyle choices
summary: Maintaining a healthy blood pressure (BP) is crucial for preventing various diseases, including stroke, heart disease, and kidney damage. A normal diurnal physiological variation in BP occurs, with a natural dip in the evening and a surge in the morning. Lifestyle choices, such as regular exercise, weight loss, a balanced diet, and stress reduction, can help lower BP. Aiming for a morning exercise routine and taking a hot shower can also lower BP. Additionally, limiting salt, coffee, and smoking, and consuming dark chocolate, fruits, and vegetables high in magnesium and potassium can also help achieve ideal BP levels and promote a healthy life.

site_title: Covid-19 - this too shall pass
summary: A global travel industry entrepreneur reflects on the Covid-19 pandemic, comparing its impact to the Marvel supervillain Thanos' snap. The pandemic has resulted in massive cancellations, lockdowns, and a sharp decline in bookings, with 182 countries affected and over 250,000 infected. Financial markets are also in turmoil, with major indices down 20% year-to-date. However, the entrepreneur believes the crisis will pass, citing historical examples of SARS and the H1N1 epidemic, and notes that the industry is now facing a unique opportunity to innovate and create new markets.

site_title: To stay afloat, the restaurant business in US clings to 'contactless delivery'
summary: The US restaurant industry is adopting "contactless delivery" to stay afloat during the coronavirus pandemic, with thousands of eateries closing their dining rooms to avoid layoffs. Restaurants are using new equipment and protocols to deliver food to customers while maintaining social distancing. Some establishments, like Sugarfish, have reassigned employees to handle phone orders, while others, like The Publican, are using the telephone to take orders. Contactless delivery is seen as a safe alternative, especially for those in high-risk groups, and may help restaurants avoid high fees charged by delivery services.

site_title: Malaysia reports third coronavirus death
summary: Malaysia reports its third coronavirus death, with a 58-year-old man passing away from Covid-19 after attending an Islamic gathering near Kuala Lumpur. The event, attended by 16,000 people from over 20 countries, has been linked to nearly 750 cases in Southeast Asia. The total number of deaths from coronavirus infection in Malaysia now stands at three.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies have been impacted by Malaysia's 14-day movement control order. Sunningdale Tech has halted production in Malaysia and Singapore, while Frencken Group and CFM Holdings have closed their Malaysian factories until March 31. LHT Holdings has also halted manufacturing in Malaysia but arranged accommodations for Malaysian employees in Singapore. Despite the disruptions, AEM Holdings is expecting a record quarter with sales between S$135m and S$145m, and is "cautiously confident" of sales for the first half of 2020.

site_title: Previously owned US home sales hit 13-year high before virus
summary: US previously owned home sales surged to a 13-year high in February, with contract closings jumping 6.5% to a 5.77 million annual rate. The median sales price increased 8% to $270,100, driven by low mortgage rates and steady demand. However, economists warn that the novel coronavirus will likely spoil the progress, with widespread job losses and social distancing efforts expected to diminish homebuyer interest. The current pace would take 3.1 months to sell all homes on the market, near the lowest in over two decades.

site_title: Central bank actions make H2 recovery from pandemic possible
summary: Central banks' swift actions to combat the novel coronavirus pandemic are expected to aid economic recovery in the second half of the year, as long as the health crisis subsides. However, the impact of the crisis remains uncertain, and the tail risk of a prolonged slump remains high. Fitch Ratings has lowered its global economic forecast to 1.3% for 2020, citing the massive scale of emergency macroeconomic policy responses. Fiscal easing packages and sovereign credit-guarantee schemes are also being used to help the private sector, but a full lockdown scenario could lead to a significant decline in global GDP.

site_title: STI ends losing streak, rebounds by 4.3%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended its losing streak on Friday, gaining 99.74 points or 4.3% to close at 2,410.74. This comes after Wall Street finished higher due to unprecedented government and central bank measures to cushion the impact of Covid-19 on the economy. The gains were led by banking stocks, with DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank rising 4.4% and 3.3%, respectively. The STI's 26 components that ended in the black, with Genting Singapore being one of the biggest gainers, up 13.7%.

site_title: The Owl of Minerva has spread its wings for a new economic future
summary: The global economy is shifting towards a new era, where profits are pursued alongside achieving the greater good, rather than reverting to pre-COVID-19 norms. As the COVID-19 crisis unfolds, the capitalist system's core values are being challenged, with a new mindset emerging. Asia is poised to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, while productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation. The article suggests that the Owl of Minerva, a concept coined by Georg Hegel, is symbolizing the end of the old economic order and the beginning of a new one.

site_title: UMS' Penang factory to resume operations, but group's California plant closes
summary: UMS Holdings, a precision engineering firm, will resume operations at its Penang factory in Malaysia, despite the country's movement control order, as semiconductors are considered an essential service. In contrast, the company's California factory will close due to the state's stay-at-home order. The Penang factory is expected to reopen after obtaining approval from the Ministry of Trade and Industry, while the Singapore facilities remain operational. The temporary halt is not expected to have a significant financial impact on the group.

site_title: India forex reserves fall US$5.3b as RBI defends rupee
summary: India's foreign exchange reserves fell US$5.35 billion to US$481.9 billion in the week ended March 13, as the central bank defended the rupee amid turmoil in global financial markets. The rupee hit a record low on Thursday due to foreign portfolio investors pulling out US$10 billion from Indian shares and bonds. Despite falling oil prices and slowing imports, the reserves are strong enough to cover nearly 10 months of imports. The Reserve Bank of India stepped in to defend the rupee, but local equities have fallen to a three-year low.

site_title: Indonesia launches anti-dumping probe over China coil steel product
summary: Indonesia has launched an anti-dumping probe into imports of hot rolled coil steel from China after a complaint by state-controlled steelmaker PT Krakatau Steel. The investigation follows calls by Indonesian business groups to hike tariffs on Chinese steel to curb cheap imports, which led to the restructuring of 30% of Krakatau's workforce. The move aims to protect domestic steel producers from unfair competition.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher at end of blistering week
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, marking the end of the market's worst month in three decades. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 165.96 points, or 0.83%, to 20,253.15. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the Nasdaq rising 97.49 points, or 1.36%, to 7,248.07. This marks a turning point for Wall Street, with policymakers' intervention seeming to stem the bleeding.

site_title: Farnborough airshow cancelled over virus
summary: Britain's Farnborough airshow, a major event for the global aerospace sector, has been cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic. The decision was made in the interest of health and safety, following careful consideration. The biennial event was set to take place in July 2020. This cancellation is the latest blow to the aerospace industry, which has been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Britain's Farnborough airshow, a showpiece event for the global aerospace sector battered by the coronavirus pandemic, has been cancelled for this year, organisers said Friday.

site_title: STI ends losing streak, rebounds by 4.3%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended a losing streak, rising 99.74 points or 4.3% to close at 2,410.74 on Friday, driven by Wall Street's gains after government and central bank measures were announced to cushion the impact of Covid-19. Singapore's blue-chip index saw advancers outpacing decliners, with 26 of its 30 components ending in the black. Key gainers included Genting Singapore, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank.

site_title: SGInnovate hires Lim Jui to be new CEO from May 1
summary: SGInnovate appoints Lim Jui as its new CEO, effective May 1, replacing founding CEO Steve Leonard. Lim joins from NTUitive, bringing over 20 years of experience in innovation, research commercialization, and investment. He aims to support deep-tech startups, which he believes need more tangible support, and strengthen Singapore's ecosystem. Chairman Yong Ying-I expressed confidence in Lim's leadership, citing his experience in commercializing research and bringing new technologies to international markets.

site_title: Property titans brace for worst as virus empties Europe's buildings
summary: Europe's real estate markets are going into hibernation as investors struggle to gauge the impact of the novel coronavirus on tenants' ability to pay rent. Over £11 billion has been frozen in UK property funds, and companies such as H&M, Superdry, and Burger King are seeking concessions from landlords or temporarily halting rent payments. Mall landlords have been forced to close properties, and investors are bracing for a prolonged period of uncertainty, with potential opportunities emerging in government bond yields.

site_title: EU opens probe into fake coronavirus-related products
summary: The European Union's European anti-fraud office OLAF has opened an investigation into fake coronavirus-related products, including ineffective or harmful masks, medical devices, disinfectants, and test kits. These products, often sold online for significantly lower prices, fail to comply with EU standards, posing health risks. The fake products enter Europe via postal services, containers with forged certificates, or as other products, and are found in normal distribution channels or on the black market. This probe follows the EU's 30-day travel ban imposed on March 17 to combat the coronavirus spread.

site_title: French energy group Total buys Global Power Wind France
summary: French energy group Total has agreed to buy Global Power Wind France for an undisclosed sum, stepping up investments in the renewable energy sector. Global Wind Power France has a 1,000 MW onshore wind portfolio, with 250 MW scheduled to come online by 2025. This acquisition marks Total's expansion into the French onshore wind market.

site_title: UBS to redeem 2 leveraged ETNs tied to mortgage Reits
summary: UBS Group is mandatorily redeeming two leveraged exchange-traded notes (ETNs) tied to mortgage real-estate investment trusts (Reits) after they fell below a $5 minimum share value. The ETNs, MORL and MRRL, had a combined market capitalization of around $30 million and made leveraged bets on an index of mortgage Reits. Each had lost over 95% of their value in the past month, with some Reits plummeting almost 24% due to concerns over the novel coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: CSE Global grows across the world with local teams; boosts cash flow with small projects
summary: CSE Global, an SGX-listed IT systems integrator, has experienced significant growth across the world with its local teams, boosting cash flow through small projects. CEO Lim Boon Kheng attributes this success to building relationships with customers in challenging times, which has paid off. Despite the current decline in oil prices and global fuel demand due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the company remains optimistic about the medium-term outlook and expects to expand its market share, particularly in the US. Its infrastructure division is witnessing steady orders for the next three to five years, while the mining division faces slower sales.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 83.56 points to 1,303.28 on Friday, with 895 gainers outweighing 145 losers. The index closed at RM4.029 billion in volume, surpassing previous days. This marks a higher close for Malaysia shares.

site_title: From eviction bans to cash support: Cities act against virus housing crisis
summary: Cities worldwide are taking measures to prevent a housing crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Over a dozen US cities have banned evictions, while Canada has announced C$27 billion in direct support to families and businesses. Rent freezes and mortgage holidays have also been implemented in various countries, including England and Wales. Utility shut-off bans and homeless isolation shelters are also being introduced to protect vulnerable populations. These measures aim to ensure everyone has a roof over their head and mitigate the impact of the virus on housing.

site_title: EU states agree to suspend airline slot requirements until October
summary: The European Union has agreed to suspend airline slot requirements until October 24, providing flexibility for the aviation industry amidst the coronavirus crisis. The waiver, which applies retroactively from January 23-February 29, 2020, for flights between the EU and China or Hong Kong, aims to prevent empty planes in the sky. The proposal needs final approval from EU nations and the European Parliament, which is due to sit on March 26.

site_title: Mainboard-listed Frencken says global operations unaffected by Malaysia's movement control order
summary: Frencken Group, a mainboard-listed equipment service provider, says its global operations remain unaffected by Malaysia's 14-day movement control order. The group has closed its factories in Malaysia but continues to serve customers in Asia, Europe, and the US. Its factories in China, the Netherlands, US, Switzerland, Singapore, India, and Thailand have resumed normal operations. The company's shares closed up 11.6% at S$0.53, despite the temporary closure of its Malaysian factories.

site_title: If Ray Dalio isn't making money now, neither will you
summary: The coronavirus outbreak is causing significant financial distress to hedge funds, with billions in losses anticipated. The crisis is disrupting traditional asset class relationships, causing a breakdown in markets. Risk parity trades, popularized by Bridgewater Associates, are particularly vulnerable, with some funds down 12% this year. Leverage and statistical arbitrage funds are also facing challenges, as dollar funding freezes and market volatility increases. Industry titans are getting caught off guard, with some firms closing trading pods and others struggling to maintain their positions. Central banks have attempted to mitigate the impact with emergency lending facilities, but the full extent of the damage is still unclear.

site_title: Jakarta declares emergency to contain virus
summary: Jakarta, Indonesia declared a state of emergency to contain the spread of coronavirus, with 215 confirmed cases and 20 deaths. The emergency status, announced by Governor Anies Baswedan, will limit public transportation and close entertainment facilities for at least two weeks. Businesses are allowed to operate minimally, and health officials are increasing rapid testing. The move follows East Java's declaration of a state of emergency, and the government has implemented measures to boost supplies and prevent panic buying.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end six-day losing streak
summary: South Korean stocks ended a six-day losing streak with a 7.44% surge, the largest one-day gain in over 11 years, amid global stimulus measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The KOSPI index rose 108.51 points to 1,566.15, despite a 34.6% decline in the past 30 trading sessions. Foreign investors sold US$343.05 million worth of shares, while trading was halted for five minutes due to a sharp jump in KOSPI 200 futures.

site_title: Shipping giant Maersk suspends 2020 outlook
summary: Shipping giant Maersk suspended its 2020 earnings outlook due to uncertainty in the global transport sector, citing weak volumes. The company preliminarily expected first quarter earnings before interest, tax and amortisation (Ebitda) of around US$1.4 billion. Its share buy-back program and proposed dividends for 2019 remain unaffected. Maersk's decision follows a decline in global trade and shipping volumes amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Virus outbreak: Singapore International Water Week, Asia Infrastructure Forum and Temasek's Ecosperity postponed
summary: Singapore International Water Week (SIWW), Asia Infrastructure Forum, and Ecosperity Week 2020, scheduled for July, have been postponed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. SIWW will now take place from June 20-24, 2021, while Ecosperity Week 2020 has been rescheduled for June 2021, with a new date for the Asia Infrastructure Forum to be announced later. The postponements come amid new social distancing guidelines and restrictions on gatherings with 250 or more participants.

site_title: Finland again crowned world's happiest country
summary: Finland has been crowned the world's happiest country for the second consecutive year, according to the World Happiness Report. The Nordic country's high levels of trust, reliable welfare benefits, low corruption, and well-functioning democracy contribute to its citizens' contentment. The report, based on three years of surveys from 2017 to 2019, ranked Afghanistan lowest among 153 countries, while the US rose to 18th. This is the third year Finland has topped the report, solidifying its lead over Denmark and Switzerland.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's job vacancies decreased overall last year but saw growth in sectors. The government is focusing on reskilling workers and saving jobs. UOB has announced virus relief measures for clients in Malaysia, while the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has urged firms to impose a voluntary Leave of Absence (LOA) for staff returning between March 14 and 20. The Singapore International Water Week and Temasek's Ecosperity have been postponed to June 20-24 next year. The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 4.3% to close at 2,410.74.

site_title: Holiday Inn owner says business is worst ever
summary: Holiday Inn owner IHG announced its business is at its worst ever due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing low demand for hotels and worldwide shutdowns. The company is cutting costs by reducing salaries, incentives, and board member compensation, saving US$150 million, and withdrawing its final dividend. IHG also cut capital spending by US$100 million and has US$1.2 billion in cash reserves to ride out the crisis. Occupancy levels remain low, with 60 hotels closed in Greater China compared to 178 at the peak.

site_title: Taiwan's new 'electronic fence' for quarantines leads wave of virus monitoring
summary: Taiwan is launching a mobile phone-based "electronic fence" system to monitor people in quarantine, using location-tracking to ensure they stay in their homes. The system alerts police and officials if those in quarantine move away or turn off their phones, with authorities contacting or visiting those who trigger an alert within 15 minutes. The system has drawn few complaints in Taiwan, which has reported only 108 cases of COVID-19, compared to over 80,900 in neighboring China.

site_title: Asia refiners eye more run cuts as fuel-making losses deepen
summary: Asian oil refiners are preparing for deeper operation cuts due to mounting losses from making fuel in an oversupplied market. Chinese, South Korean, and Taiwanese refiners are considering further run-rate reductions as they struggle to find buyers for fuel amid a slump in domestic consumption and a lack of export options. Refining margins in Singapore have fallen to a loss of over $2 a barrel, the lowest since 2008, and experts predict further declines before recovery. At least two refiners are considering optimizing production to focus on higher-value products.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end tough week with healthy rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a tough week with a 5.05% rally, driven by massive stimulus and financial support from governments and central banks to combat the coronavirus impact. The Hang Seng Index rose to 22,805.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.61% and 1.28% respectively. The rally follows positive trends across Asia and the US, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index jumped 5.05 per cent, or 1,095.94 points, to 22,805.07.

site_title: US and Mexico plan to close border to 'non-essential travel'
summary: The US and Mexico are planning to close their border to non-essential travel due to the coronavirus pandemic. The move comes after similar measures along the northern border with Canada are expected to take effect by Saturday. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Mexico's Foreign Secretary Marcelo Luis Ebrard discussed the plan, which aims to reduce public health risks and prioritize essential cross-border commerce and trade. The closure is part of the US's efforts to curb the spread of COVID-19, following similar restrictions on travel from Europe and other parts of the world.

site_title: MOM penalises 5 firms for age-related discriminatory hiring
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore has penalized five firms for age-related discriminatory hiring practices. The firms, which include job advertisements favoring a certain age group, have been barred from hiring foreigners and renewing work passes of existing foreign employees for a year, effective immediately. The penalties were issued after an investigation found the firms' hiring practices to be discriminatory. This move aims to promote a fair and inclusive hiring environment in Singapore.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's new tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, has a background in DBS. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC are expanding cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Even coffee supplies under threat amid global transport woes
summary: Global coffee supplies face threats from coronavirus-related transport disruptions. Major coffee traders Volcafe and Sucafina warn of "more widespread" logistical holdups in producing countries, citing shortages of containers and safety measures. The pandemic scrambles supply chains, affecting not only coffee but also crude oil, copper, and foodstuffs. Coffee futures jumped 11% in New York before paring, and prices are still up 5.6% this week due to concerns over potential strikes in Brazil. Companies have made contingency plans and are advising clients to take advance shipments to mitigate risk.

site_title: AirAsia says review cleared Airbus sponsorships; Tony Fernandes reinstated to CEO
summary: AirAsia Group Bhd announced that an independent probe into corruption allegations cleared the airline's procurement process with Airbus SE. The investigation found the procurement process to be robust and justifiable. The probe also cleared Airbus's sponsorship of a sports team co-owned by AirAsia's top executives, stating it showed demonstrable benefits to the airline and was not linked to any purchase decisions. As a result, Tony Fernandes, who was temporarily removed as CEO, has been reinstated to his position.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by huge economic support plans
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, lifted by a series of government and central bank measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus. The US Senate presented a $1 trillion emergency relief package, including $1,200 cash handouts and $208 billion in loans for companies. Global equities also benefited from positive leads from Wall Street and Europe, with many Asian markets ending the day up 2-6%. However, analysts warn that markets may remain volatile and under pressure until health authorities have a better grasp of the outbreak's scale and duration.

site_title: UOB announces virus relief measures for clients in Malaysia as outbreak worsens
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) in Malaysia has announced virus relief measures for its customers, including corporate clients and individuals, as the country's Covid-19 outbreak worsens. The measures include moratoriums on loan repayments, interest-only repayments, and payment holidays for up to six months. The bank will assess each case on a case-by-case basis and provide additional facilities based on clients' financing needs. The move aims to alleviate the financial burden on customers affected by the outbreak, which has seen a recent spike in confirmed cases in Malaysia.

site_title: Covid-19: Stricter measures including ban on events of over 250 people; new app to help contact tracing
summary: Singapore has introduced stricter "safe distancing" measures to reduce the risk of further local transmission of Covid-19, including a ban on events with 250 or more participants. A new government app, TraceTogether, will help contact tracers inform users if they have been in close contact with a Covid-19 case. The measures aim to reduce the number of gatherings and promote physical distancing, with enforcement via venue licensing conditions. The government also advises employers to reduce close physical interactions among workers and encourages telecommuting and teleconferencing.

site_title: MOM urges firms to impose LOA on staff returning between March 14 and 20
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has urged companies to impose a leave of absence (LOA) on employees who returned from overseas between March 14 and 20 to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Employers who do so can claim daily support under a program aimed at alleviating financial burdens. Those who are placed on mandatory 14-day leave of absence will not be able to leave their homes. Companies can also claim a levy waiver for affected work pass holders and a daily support of S$100 for eligible employees.

site_title: Listed China firms' filing delays hit five-year high as virus thwarts auditors
summary: Mainland China-listed firms have delayed filing annual reports, with 852 companies, or 22% of listed firms, experiencing delays, the highest in five years. The lockdown in February hindered auditors from visiting clients and reaching officials, preventing them from signing off on accounts. Delays can impact a company's ability to raise funds and damage confidence, potentially leading to fines or trading suspensions. The number of delays is attributed to the "large impact of the virus on auditing," with accountants requiring on-site checks that were impossible due to the lockdown.

site_title: Singapore's job vacancies to fall further; focus will be on reskilling workers, saving jobs
summary: Singapore's job vacancies are expected to decline further due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with the government focusing on reskilling workers and saving jobs. The Ministry of Manpower reported 42% of 52,900 job openings in September were newly created positions from business expansion or formation. To address the challenge, the government will prioritize helping workers stay in their current jobs and direct job matching support to those who need it most.

site_title: Malaysia to deploy army to help enforce coronavirus curbs
summary: Malaysia will deploy its army starting Sunday to enforce travel and movement curbs aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus, following the closure of borders, schools, and non-essential businesses. Despite the curbs, people continued to visit restaurants and parks. The government warned of a "tsunami" of cases if the curbs are not followed, as Malaysia experiences its highest number of infections in South-east Asia.

site_title: Brazil prohibits entry to Europeans, several Asian nationalities over coronavirus
summary: Brazil has prohibited entry to travelers from Europe and several Asian countries, including the European Union, China, Japan, South Korea, Australia, and Malaysia, for 30 days to combat the spread of the novel coronavirus. The restriction applies to non-Brazilian residents and those without valid work or family reasons. The move aims to prevent the spread of the virus and protect the country's population.

site_title: Suntec Reit unit obtains A$450m green loan
summary: Suntec Reit's wholly-owned Australian subsidiary has secured a A$450 million green loan to refinance existing borrowings, finance acquisitions, and for general working capital purposes. The loan agreement includes conditions that would require the Australian subsidiary to prepay the outstanding amount if the manager ceases to be affiliated with ARA Asset Management. The unit's shares fell 10.3% to close at S$1.13 following the announcement. The loan will be used to support the real estate investment trust's operations and investments in Australia.

site_title: Japan welcomes Olympic flame as doubts swirl over Games
summary: Japan welcomed the Olympic flame on a special charter flight, but the ceremony was muted due to the coronavirus pandemic casting doubt over the Tokyo Games. The flame was collected by former Japanese Olympians and taken to a stage in front of selected guests. The event, part of the "Recovery Olympics" initiative, aimed to showcase the region's revival after the 2011 earthquake, tsunami, and nuclear meltdown. The ceremony's subdued nature reflects the uncertainty surrounding the Olympic Games' future.

site_title: Uber surges after saying it expects cash cushion of at least US$4b
summary: Uber Technologies Inc expects to have at least $4 billion in cash reserves by the end of the year, even in its worst-case scenario due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's shares surged 38% in New York, with CEO Dara Khosrowshahi stating that Uber is well-positioned to weather the crisis. Despite a significant decline in its stock value, Uber remains committed to turning a profit this year and considering acquisitions when the crisis abates.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc told investors that it would have billions of dollars in cash at the end of the year, even in its bleakest estimates about the business's prospects.

site_title: Masks go on world tour as Hong Kongers now send supplies abroad
summary: Hong Kong residents are now sending face masks to loved ones abroad as the city's stockpiles have eased, following the initial shortages during the COVID-19 pandemic. Many Hong Kongers, like Adrian W. Chan, are taking precautions to protect their family members, particularly seniors, as the virus spreads globally. The city's mass mask-wearing culture has led to a surge in exports, with some residents sending hygiene products to friends and family in Europe and North America. Experts say the practice is crucial in preventing the spread of the virus, especially in densely populated areas like Hong Kong.

site_title: Air Canada to lay off over 5,100 employees due to virus pandemic: union
summary: Air Canada will temporarily lay off over 5,100 employees, including 3,600 flight attendants at Air Canada mainline and 1,549 at Air Canada Rouge, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The layoffs are effective until April 30 at the earliest and are part of the airline's efforts to mitigate the impact of the virus. The Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE) expressed sadness over the decision, representing about 10,000 flight attendants at the airline.

images.alt_text: Air Canada will temporarily lay off more than 5,100 employees as it attempts to check the impact of the novel coronavirus pandemic, the union representing the Canadian airline's flight attendants said on Friday.

site_title: 'Premature' to postpone Tokyo Olympics, says IOC chief
summary: IOC president Thomas Bach stated it would be premature to postpone the Tokyo Olympics, citing the body's consideration of different scenarios as the coronavirus pandemic advances. Bach emphasized health considerations as the top priority, stating the decision won't be determined by financial interest. The International Olympic Committee is waiting for advice from its taskforce and the World Health Organization before making a decision, with the Games scheduled to start on July 24. Bach remained optimistic about holding the Games on schedule.

site_title: Virus-hit Air New Zealand offered NZ$900m bailout
summary: Air New Zealand has been offered a NZ$900 million bailout loan by the government to help the flag carrier survive the coronavirus crisis. Without this intervention, New Zealand risked losing its national airline. Air New Zealand shares plummeted 45.45% before recovering slightly, closing 32.47% down.

site_title: 5-storey shophouse near Clarke Quay up for sale with S$9.8m guide price
summary: A five-storey commercial shophouse on 32 Hongkong Street near Clarke Quay has been launched for sale with a guide price of S$9.8 million, excluding premium for lease renewal. The property, with a total floor area of 7,600 sq ft, features a lift and sits on a 99-year lease. It is considered a rare find in the central business district and may suit family offices or investors looking to redevelop the property. The site is zoned for commercial use and has a plot ratio of 4.2, with vacant possession available.

images.alt_text: The site of the shophouse (in blue) is zoned for commercial use, with an allowable building height of up to six storeys and a plot ratio of 4.2.

site_title: Fitch nearly halves global growth forecast to 1.3% for 2020 on Covid-19 hit
summary: Fitch Ratings has nearly halved its global growth forecast for 2020 to 1.3% due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The credit ratings agency initially forecast 2.5% growth in 2019, which was stronger than during the 1990s and 2001 global downturns. Emergency macroeconomic policy responses, including interest rate cuts and fiscal easing packages, aim to mitigate damage and support the private sector. However, uncertainties remain, and a full lockdown scenario could lead to a decline in global GDP of 3-5% per quarter.

site_title: Walmart to hire 150,000 workers as shoppers surge on coronavirus fears
summary: Walmart plans to hire over 150,000 hourly workers in the US due to a surge in shoppers amid coronavirus fears. The new hires will work in stores, clubs, distribution, and fulfillment centers, with many converting to permanent roles. Walmart will also pay a special cash bonus of $300 to full-time hourly workers and $150 to part-time associates. The company is implementing a new hiring process to expedite the recruitment of key roles, reducing the usual two-week application cycle to 24 hours.

site_title: Brazil prohibits entry to Europeans, Asians over coronavirus
summary: Brazil has prohibited entry to European and Asian travelers for 30 days, starting Monday, in an effort to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. The restriction includes travelers from the European Union, Britain, and several Asian countries, except for Brazilian residents or those with valid work or family reasons. This measure aims to limit the spread of the virus and protect the country's population.

site_title: Australian PM says will not deliver federal budget until October
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced that the federal budget will not be delivered until October due to the uncertainty of the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision comes as the country's economy teeters on the verge of its first recession in nearly three decades. The number of COVID-19 cases in Australia has surged to nearly 800, with most patients in New South Wales. The delay in the budget is seen as a sensible move, given the economic forecasts are uncertain during this time.

site_title: Ill Canada FM awaiting coronavirus test results in isolation
summary: Canada's Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne has isolated himself at home after returning from a trip abroad with flu-like symptoms, awaiting COVID-19 test results. He joins other senior officials, including Natural Resource Minister Seamus O'Regan and Minister of Small Business and Exports Mary Ng, who have also self-isolated. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is also in isolation with his family after his wife Sophie tested positive for the virus. The developments come as Canada continues to monitor the COVID-19 situation.

site_title: Australia: Shares seek footing after rout on hopes of more stimulus salve
summary: Australian shares rose 3.1% on Friday, rebounding from a 10% slump, as the government signaled a second round of stimulus spending to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 146.8 points, with big banks Westpac and National Australia Bank leading the gains. Loan repayments for small businesses will be deferred for six months, and a second stimulus package is expected to be unveiled soon. Despite this, economists believe the global economy is already in recession.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking Wall Street rise; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1% to 2,334.10 on Friday, tracking Wall Street's higher close. The index opened stronger after a volatile session on the US market. Gainers outnumbered losers 104 to 58, with 86.2 million securities worth S$105.1 million changing hands. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains for the STI.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark worst week since 2008
summary: Australia's benchmark stock index, the S&P/ASX 200, ended the week 0.7% higher despite marking its worst week since 2008, due to hopes of a second government stimulus package. The index sank 13% for the week, with most of that loss stemming from a massive plunge on Monday. The government is likely to unveil a second stimulus package, and Australian banks have offered a A$100 billion relief package for small businesses impacted by the coronavirus. Economists believe the global economy is already in a recession, and the measures are expected to limit economic damage but not prevent a contraction in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 0.7 per cent higher at 4,816.60, though it sank 13 per cent for the week, with most of that loss stemming from a massive plunge on Monday that sent the benchmark to its lowest level since 1987.

site_title: Oil tankers drop anchor as traders see profit in price rout
summary: Oil tankers are being deployed to store barrels at sea as traders capitalize on the price plunge, with five to 10 supertankers booked for storage. The vessels can hold 10 million to 20 million barrels, equivalent to Argentina's monthly consumption. The price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia has triggered a contango structure, where futures months are trading at hefty premiums, offering big profits to those who can find cheap-enough storage and sell later. Several major trading houses have reported the trade is now profitable.

site_title: Broker's take: SIA Engineering downgraded two notches, TP slashed
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) by two notches to "fully valued" and slashed its price target to S$1.35 from S$3.30. Analysts cited the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on air traffic slowdown, which will curb air travel and generate a 20% year-on-year decline in Changi's air traffic. This is expected to cut SIAEC's FY2021 revenues by 18% and net profit by 48%. Dividends are also likely to take a beating in FY2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 9.21 points or 0.76% to 1,228.93. Volume was 81.52 million lots worth RM26.17 million. Gainers outpaced losers 156 to 65.

site_title: China unexpectedly keeps lending benchmark rate unchanged
summary: China kept its benchmark lending rate unchanged at 4.05% for the one-year loan prime rate and 4.75% for the five-year rate, defying expectations of a reduction to ease borrowing costs amid the coronavirus pandemic. Forty-seven respondents, or 71.4%, expected a rate cut, but the People's Bank of China left borrowing costs steady, mirroring its decision on Monday to keep interest rates on one-year medium-term lending facility loans unchanged.

site_title: Australian banks announce A$100b loan relief package for businesses
summary: Australian banks have announced a A$100 billion loan relief package for small businesses impacted by the coronavirus, deferring repayments for six months. This could put A$8 billion back into small businesses' coffers, according to Australian Banking Association chief Anna Bligh. The move aims to support the country's strongest and most stable banking system during extraordinary times.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech halts Malaysia production due to lockdown
summary: Sunningdale Tech has halted production at its Malaysian facilities due to the country's movement control order. The production halt affects its Singapore operations, which rely on Malaysian plants for production capacity. The company is focusing on cost controls, improving productivity, and enhancing operational efficiency to mitigate the impact of Covid-19. It has arranged accommodation for some Malaysian-based employees and is working with Malaysian authorities and customers to get clearance for production of essential goods. Its China operations have resumed, with plans to fully recover by the end of March.

site_title: India hangs four men over 2012 Delhi bus gang-rape: jail chief
summary: India executed four men on Friday for the 2012 Delhi bus gang-rape, sparking nationwide protests and international revulsion. The men, who were convicted of the crime, were hanged at Tihar Jail, marking India's first use of capital punishment since 2015. The execution came after a lengthy appeals process.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, JSH, JMH, Suntec Reit, AEM
summary: Singapore Airlines shares rose 0.8% to S$6.17 after being downgraded by DBS Group Research, while Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH) and Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) shares rose 8.1% and 2.4% respectively after a sharp fall on Thursday. Suntec Reit's units rose 10.6% to S$1.25 after taking out a green loan, while AEM Holdings rose 4.4% to S$1.43 despite Covid-19 impacting sales.

site_title: Federal Reserve's actions starting to work, Daly says
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly says the central bank's recent actions to slash borrowing costs and shore up the financial sector may help households and businesses weather the economic impact of the coronavirus. Daly stated that if the Fed can offset some of the worst economic declines, it will be in a better position to support growth when the public health emergency subsides. The Fed is working to provide liquidity and ensure credit markets function, with borrowing at the discount window increasing and market volatility settling down, Daly said.

site_title: Asia deploys innovative, if invasive, tech to curb virus
summary: Asian countries, including Hong Kong, South Korea, China, Taiwan, and Singapore, are deploying innovative technologies to combat the coronavirus pandemic, including electronic bracelets, phone tracking, and digital detectives. These measures aim to curb infections but raise concerns about privacy, with some experts arguing that such invasive measures can erode democratic principles. The use of technology varies across countries, with some, like Singapore, using voluntary apps, while others, like China, have introduced more intrusive systems, including QR code tracking.

images.alt_text: Electronic bracelets and phones that report your whereabouts, text messages if you stray too far from quarantine and digital detectives tracking where you've been - Asian countries have embraced innovative, if somewhat invasive, tech to counter the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Canada-US border likely to be closed by Saturday: Trudeau
summary: Canada and the US are set to close the international border to non-essential travel starting Friday night, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stating it will likely be in place by Saturday morning. The move is a temporary measure in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with Trudeau and US President Donald Trump jointly announcing the plan. Essential border crossings, including trade, will remain open.

images.alt_text: The Canada-US border will likely be closed to non-essential travel overnight from Friday to Saturday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday.

site_title: Australia to unveil second stimulus package within days: sources
summary: Australia plans to unveil a second stimulus package within days, worth around 3-4% of its A$2 trillion economy, to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The package will target those most impacted by the crisis, with Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stating it aims to "cushion the blow" for Australians who may lose work. The move comes as the country's economy faces its first recession in nearly 30 years, with unemployment rising and widespread panic in global markets.

site_title: Brazil closes borders, Mexico announces first death from pandemic
summary: Brazil closed its land borders to nearly all its neighbors to prevent coronavirus spread. Mexico reported its first COVID-19 death. Protests against government response were held in cities across Colombia and Brazil. Chile unveiled an $11.75 billion economic stimulus package to cope with the pandemic's impact on its copper industry.

site_title: Millions could die if virus allowed to spread unchecked: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned that millions could die from the new coronavirus if it spreads unchecked, particularly in poor countries. He called for a coordinated global response to contain the pandemic, citing the need for transparency and support for vulnerable countries. Guterres urged the Group of 20 nations, particularly wealthy countries, to help African nations and others in the developing world, warning that a lack of support could lead to catastrophic consequences, including millions of deaths.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB upgrades OCBC to 'add' on attractive valuation, share price resilience
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded OCBC's rating to "add" from "hold" due to its attractive valuation, trading close to its 0.8 price-to-book value ratio during the global financial crisis. The bank's share price has been resilient compared to peers during the crisis. However, the analyst cut its target price to S$9.04 from S$11.05, citing margin compression and asset quality pressure amid the Covid-19 pandemic. OCBC's thick capital buffers and maintained dividends per share are seen as positives, and a potential monetary boost from the Monetary Authority of Singapore could offset net interest income weakness.

site_title: Italy passes China's virus deaths and braces for long lockdown
summary: Italy surpassed China's coronavirus death total with 3,405 reported deaths, following 427 new cases on Wednesday. The country is bracing for an extended lockdown, which could be its biggest economic shock since World War II. Italy's toll surpasses China's 3,245 deaths, reported since the end of December.

site_title: AEM 'cautiously confident' about sales despite coronavirus disruption to deliveries
summary: AEM Holdings, a chip testing solutions provider, is "cautiously confident" that its first-half 2020 sales will reach an all-time high despite disruptions from the coronavirus. The company expects a record quarter with sales between S$135 million and S$145 million and maintains its full-year sales guidance of S$360 million to S$380 million. To mitigate the impact, AEM has activated its business continuity plan, ordering from alternative sources, implementing travel restrictions, and having employees work in shifts or from home.

site_title: ECB sees 'considerable decline' in euro area activity
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde warned of a "considerable decline" in euro area economic activity due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. Governments' containment measures will lead to a significant economic slowdown, with a large part of the economy being shut down. This prediction comes as the global economic situation continues to deteriorate, with other countries facing similar challenges. The ECB's statement highlights the growing uncertainty and potential for a prolonged economic downturn.

site_title: Trump replaces G-7 Camp David summit with videoconference: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump has canceled this year's G-7 summit at Camp David due to the coronavirus crisis, replacing it with a videoconference. The summit was originally scheduled for June. The White House stated that the change is to allow countries to focus on responding to the health and economic challenges of Covid-19. The videoconference will instead bring together the leaders of the seven wealthy democracies.

site_title: China asks airlines to cut international flights, redirects some due to virus
summary: China's aviation regulator has asked airlines to cut international flights and reroute some to other airports due to the rising number of imported COVID-19 cases, especially in Beijing. Some flights from Tokyo, Moscow, and Paris will be diverted, and passengers will undergo health checks. Authorities will also adjust the first point of entry for international flights bound for Beijing based on the epidemic situation. China reported 34 imported cases, a significant increase, and has ramped up screening for incoming passengers who face mandatory quarantine.

images.alt_text: China's aviation regulator has asked airlines to cut international flights and ordered some Beijing ones to be rerouted, as the country grapples with a rising number of imported coronavirus cases, especially in the capital.

site_title: Swedbank fined 4b kronor over Baltic money laundering
summary: Sweden's financial supervisory authority fined Swedbank 4 billion kronor for failing to combat money laundering in its Estonian operations. The bank was given a warning and a fine due to "serious deficiencies" in managing the risk of money laundering in its Baltic operations.

site_title: UK 'can turn tide' of coronavirus in 12 weeks: Johnson
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson says Britain can "turn the tide" on the coronavirus within 12 weeks if people follow social distancing advice. The government will ramp up testing to 25,000 per day, while Johnson urged businesses not to fire staff and promised economic measures will be announced on Friday. Meanwhile, the Queen and Archbishop of Canterbury have issued messages urging people to work together and help others during the outbreak, with the Queen urging the nation to "come together" and the Archbishop to use his virtual service to console others.

site_title: California governor issues statewide order for home isolation
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom issued a statewide stay-in-place order starting Thursday evening, marking the most stringent US effort to combat the spread of the novel coronavirus. The order, effective immediately, allows residents to leave their homes for essential items like groceries and jobs. With approximately 21.3 million residents already under stay-in-place mandates, the move aims to slow the spread of the virus. The order comes as the state already had community restrictions in place.

images.alt_text: The entire state of California will be under a stay-in-place order starting Thursday evening, marking the most stringent US effort yet to stymie the spread of the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Europe: Bank of England boosts stocks but recession fears remain
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates to 0.1% and increased bond-buying to boost European stocks, which rose 2.9% despite recession fears. The move followed the European Central Bank's emergency measures, but economists predict a UK recession is inevitable. Telecom and energy stocks performed well, while the resources sector declined. The UK's mid-cap index dropped 1.4% as London prepares for a virtual shutdown due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: US: Stocks finish volatile session higher, Dow up 1%
summary: US stocks ended the day higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1% to 20,087.40. The S&P 500 rose 0.5% to 2,409.40, while the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.3% to 7,150.58. Investors weighed government stimulus measures against data showing a sharp US economic slowdown. Large tech companies led the market, driving gains.

site_title: Art Collectors' Anti-Virus Party
summary: Gajah Gallery in Singapore is hosting an exclusive group exhibition featuring prominent artists, mirroring the cancelled Art Basel Hong Kong. The event, which opens on March 21, includes a dress code, VIP lounge, and invite-only after party. The gallery has curated sections similar to Art Basel, including "Kabinett" and "Discoveries," to recreate the art fair atmosphere. The exhibition showcases artworks that were originally destined for Hong Kong but will now be displayed within the gallery premises.

site_title: France reports 108 new coronavirus deaths in last 24 hours: official
summary: France reported 108 new coronavirus deaths in the last 24 hours, bringing the total death toll to 372, according to the top French health official. The virus is spreading rapidly and intensely, with 10,995 cases recorded, and the number of infections is doubling every four days. France has been in lockdown since Tuesday, with only essential trips allowed, to slow the spread of the virus. Health officials urge people to stay at home to avoid other deaths and serious cases.

site_title: SoftBank seeking US$10b to support Vision Fund companies: sources
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is seeking an additional $10 billion to support its struggling portfolio companies, including ride-hailing services, battered by the coronavirus pandemic. The Japanese conglomerate is in talks with outside investors to provide $5 billion, with SoftBank matching the contribution. The move comes as SoftBank's stock has plunged 50% in the past month, erasing $50 billion in market capitalization. The Vision Fund, which has spent $80.5 billion of its $98.6 billion total, plans to use the new capital to support struggling companies and fund opportunistic acquisitions.

site_title: Trump administration urges rapid stimulus approval as economy tanks
summary: US Senate Republicans introduced a $1 trillion emergency stimulus package amid growing evidence of the US economy's damage from the coronavirus pandemic. Economists say the US is in a deep recession, with a surge in layoffs and manufacturing shutdowns. The US has recorded 10,755 new coronavirus cases, 154 of them fatal. The government is clamping down on gatherings and social distancing measures to slow the virus. The stimulus package aims to provide federal funds to the economy in desperate need.

site_title: Qantas axes international flights; Lufthansa cuts 95% of capacity
summary: Qantas will halt all international flights from late March to at least the end of May due to the coronavirus pandemic, grounding 160 planes and putting two-thirds of its workforce on leave. The airline will also delay dividend payments and cut domestic capacity by 60%. Meanwhile, Deutsche Lufthansa AG will cut 95% of capacity, grounding 700 planes, as the European airline confronts the crisis. Both airlines aim to preserve jobs and maintain essential connections.

site_title: Bank of England cuts rates to near zero, ramps up bond-buying
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates to 0.1% and announced a £200 billion front-loaded bond-buying program to combat the coronavirus outbreak, its second emergency rate cut in a week. The move aims to stabilize financial markets and support the economy. The central bank also rejected suggestions of "printing money" to bail out the government. Sterling initially rallied after the announcement but later declined, while British government bond yields fell sharply.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England cut interest rates to 0.1 per cent on Thursday, its second emergency rate cut in just over a week, and promised 200 billion pounds of front-loaded bond purchases in a fresh attempt to shield Britain's economy from the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: The Great Explorer
summary: Fauré Le Page, a 302-year-old French heritage brand, has been revamped by artistic director Augustin De Buffévent to offer fashionable and functional luxury handbags and small leather goods. The brand, founded in 1717, initially produced leather hunting accessories, but De Buffévent has stayed true to its utilitarian DNA with travel-ready designs. Notable products include the signature écailles monogram waterproof canvas backpack and duffle bag, as well as pouches that double as clutches. The brand's products are now available in Singapore, priced from S$2,690.

site_title: South Africa cuts key interest rate in virus response
summary: South Africa's central bank cut its main interest rate by a full percentage point to 5.25% in response to the coronavirus outbreak, aiming to ease financial pressure on consumers. The decision, made to combat the virus's impact on the economy, which has already slipped into recession and is forecast to contract by 0.2% in 2020.

site_title: US dollar set for biggest winning streak in 28 years
summary: The US dollar extended its gains, reaching its biggest rising run since 1992, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. Demand for funding remained high, with the dollar firming to 101.81, its highest level since March 2017. Sterling teetered near its lowest point, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars hit record lows. Despite central banks' liquidity injections, investors continued to sell riskier assets, driving the dollar's value up.

site_title: Money FM podcast: International Women's Day
summary: Glenn van Zutphen from Weekend Mornings on MoneyFM 89.3 discussed International Women's Day with Corinna Lim, executive director of AWARE, on the Money FM podcast. AWARE celebrates International Women's Day with events leading up to Superwomen in Concert, a fundraising concert at Esplanade Concert Hall. The concert aims to support AWARE's mission to empower women and girls.

site_title: BlackRock, KKR, GIC among suitors eyeing stake in Abu Dhabi National Oil unit: sources
summary: BlackRock, KKR, and Italian infrastructure operator Snam SpA are among suitors making initial bids for a stake in Abu Dhabi National Oil Co's (ADNOC) natural gas pipelines, valued at approximately $15 billion. Other bidders include Australian fund manager IFM Investors, Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, Global Infrastructure Partners, and Singapore sovereign fund GIC. ADNOC is considering a lease structure for the sale of up to 49% of the business. The sale process has been delayed due to travel restrictions and tightening credit markets, with potential partnerships emerging among bidders.

images.alt_text: BlackRock Inc, KKR & Co and Italian infrastructure operator Snam SpA are among suitors that made initial bids for a stake in Abu Dhabi National Oil Co's (ADNOC) natural gas pipelines, which could be valued at about US$15 billion, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: US oil reverses losses, posts largest one-day gain on record
summary: US crude oil prices surged 25% on Thursday, the largest single-day gain on record, reversing losses from three days of selling. The rebound was seen as a brief reprieve, with analysts expecting additional weakness due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on global demand. Oil prices have lost half their value in less than two weeks, with West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $25.22 a barrel and Brent crude at $28.47 a barrel. A planned increase in oil supply by Opec and a potential economic stimulus package are seen as factors contributing to the price increase.

site_title: Climate action has to include managing water
summary: Climate change is exacerbating global water crises, with severe flooding in Jakarta displacing 19,000, droughts in Thailand affecting agriculture and water supplies, and record-breaking rainfall in the UK. At the same time, South Africa's drought worsens food security for 15 million people, with the European winter being the hottest on record. Climate action must include managing water, adopting a holistic approach that recognizes the interconnectedness of water and climate.

site_title: US urges citizens to avoid all international travel, return home
summary: The US State Department has urged citizens to avoid all international travel due to the coronavirus pandemic, advising those abroad to return home if possible. The travel advisory was upgraded to the highest level, citing growing temporary entry restrictions and airline cancellations. The department also noted that some embassies have reduced staff due to Covid-19 departures.

images.alt_text: The United States on Thursday warned against any international travel due to the coronavirus pandemic and advised citizens to come home if possible.

site_title: Japan's Abe gears up for another big stimulus package
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to unveil his second major stimulus package amid the COVID-19 pandemic, aiming to boost the economy through cash handouts and a cut in the recently raised sales tax. The package, which could total over $1 trillion, would be part of a global effort to combat the virus and stabilize financial markets. Abe faces pressure to deliver a robust recovery, with private sector economists predicting a prolonged recession and his approval ratings slipping.

site_title: Some business schools offering one-year MBA courses
summary: Business schools are offering one-year MBA courses, targeting candidates who have taken relevant courses and want to accelerate their education. These programs, popular in Europe, allow students to earn a degree in less than half the time of traditional US programs. Participants report requiring intense focus and skipping internships, but can be ideal for those in a rush. Many employers cover tuition costs, and graduates say the time management skills they've learned are valuable for their next careers.

site_title: Living in the Past and Present
summary: A Singaporean couple, Kenneth Kan and his wife Mei Ling, have successfully merged their love of heritage and modernity in their 1920s shophouse home. RT+Q Architects preserved the shophouse's original structure while incorporating a modern glass-enclosed extension. The result is a unique blend of old and new, featuring exposed ceiling beams, brick walls, and a bespoke marble dining table. The couple has also incorporated local art, including life-sized bronze sculptures of samsui women, to reflect Singapore's past. The result is a harmonious blend of heritage and modern living.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Key events and releases include a four-hands collaboration between Korean and Singaporean chefs, a showcase of Japanese traditional craftsmanship at Supermama, and a digital concert series by the Singapore Chinese Orchestra. Yayoi Kusama's solo exhibition at Mucciaccia in Gillman Barracks is also set to run from March 27 to June 27. Additionally, HBO's Westworld Season 3 has premiered with local landmarks featured in its episodes, and Loewe's creative director Jonathan Anderson has launched a collection of home scents inspired by Victorian herb gardens.

site_title: The road ahead for venture capitalists
summary: Venture capitalists are facing challenges due to a surge in liquidity and a decline in good deals. Despite this, private capital is rushing into South-east Asia's venture funds, driven by the low-interest rate climate. Experts warn that the current situation is not ideal, with record dry powder and macro headwinds making it harder for venture capitalists to succeed. As the global economy struggles through a pandemic-induced crisis, investors are advised to look for signs of a stock-market bottom and to prioritize trust in the financial market.

site_title: Smooth sailing on shipping front - for now
summary: CMA CGM, a French shipping company, reports an upturn in its business in China despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The company has cancelled a port congestion surcharge on reefer shipments to Chinese ports, indicating improved reefer plug utilisation. Operations in Europe are expected to be minimal, but may impact in two to three weeks. The company's logistics and supply chain division, CEVA, is expected to see a turnaround this year, with a strengthened management team and a long-term plan to sell a stake in the company.

site_title: Home for the Holidays at Pan Pacific
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group offers staycation deals in Singapore, allowing guests to create their own vacation experience with up to 30% savings on room rates and F&B. The hotels feature extreme hygiene measures, including hand sanitizers, respiratory masks, and regular disinfection of public spaces and guest rooms. Guests can also enjoy complimentary privileges, such as dining options and poolside activities, at participating hotels. Staycation packages are available until June 30, 2020, with additional discounts for Pan Pacific DISCOVERY members.

site_title: Crude rebounds after drop to 18-year low
summary: Oil futures rebounded 18% in New York after plummeting to an 18-year low, as investors weigh the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the global economy. The European Central Bank launched an emergency bond-buying program, while the US Senate cleared a second stimulus bill. Despite the relief, the global spread of the virus continues to gather pace, with Italy's death count surging to almost 3,000. The world's biggest oil producers are moving to ramp up production, prompting calls for the US to ban imports from certain countries to stabilize energy markets.

site_title: Malaysia cuts reserve ratio in surprise move
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, unexpectedly cut its reserve ratio by 100 basis points to 2% as part of a plan to release RM30 billion of liquidity into the banking system to combat the novel coronavirus pandemic. The move comes weeks after a rate cut and follows similar actions by other Asia-Pacific central banks. The decision aims to cushion the economic blow from the pandemic, which has already affected the tourism and manufacturing industries, and may pave the way for a rate cut before the bank's next scheduled meeting in May.

site_title: Investors puzzle over gap between Jardine Matheson, Strategic price dives
summary: Jardine Strategic and Jardine Matheson, two Singaporean companies with a cross-shareholding structure, saw significant price drops on Thursday. Jardine Strategic fell 15.09% or US$3.20 to US$18, while Jardine Matheson dropped 7.09% or US$3.56 to US$46.66. Analysts attribute the divergence to market volatility and a potential long-short strategy gone wrong, as investors exit or increase their bets on the companies.

site_title: Weak Tencent results point to potential China contraction on virus spread
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported lower-than-expected net income of 21.6 billion yuan in the December quarter, citing a difficult advertising environment and potential Chinese economic contraction due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company warned of a challenging year ahead, following Alibaba Group's similar warning. China's economy may contract for the first time since 1989, affecting consumer and marketing spending that Tencent relies on for revenue growth. This reinforces concerns about the pandemic's impact on the Chinese market and Tencent's businesses.

site_title: Early novel coronavirus drug trials yield mixed results
summary: Early novel coronavirus drug trials in China yielded mixed results. A study on lopinavir and ritonavir showed no improvement in severe Covid-19 patients, while a separate study on favipiravir, an antiviral medication, found it helped clear the virus from patients a week earlier and was associated with improved chest symptoms. The favipiravir study's results are promising, with potential implications for another experimental drug, remdesivir, which is also undergoing clinical trials in China.

site_title: New-resale home psf price gap widens to 40% in 2019
summary: The premium between new homes and resale units in Singapore has widened to 40% in 2019, up from 35% in 2018, according to Edmund Tie Research. New homes in the core central region averaged S$2,953 psf, while resale units averaged S$2,105 psf. Analysts expect the spread to expand further this year due to low interest rates and more new supply. The buying frenzy for new homes continues, with over 9,000 units expected to be sold in 2020, driven mainly by Singaporeans and residents.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz C 160 review: A tough choice
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C 160 is the least expensive version of the popular C-Class range, priced at S$177,888 with a Category A certificate of entitlement (COE). It features a 1.5-litre turbocharged inline four-cylinder engine producing 129 horsepower. The car delivers a "leisurely" pace, making it suitable for those who prioritize comfort over speed. It boasts a luxurious interior with advanced technology features, but its suspension feels stiff and the engine has a noticeable diesel-like clatter. The C 160's price gap with the C 180 has narrowed, making it a more competitive option in the market.

site_title: Kia now offers test drives at your doorstep
summary: Cycle & Carriage (C&C) has launched a concierge test drive service in Singapore, allowing potential Kia buyers to try out cars at their doorstep. Customers book a test drive online a day ahead, and a sales consultant confirms the details, then delivers the car to the customer's location. The service is currently available on weekdays and has been popular, with the Kia Cerato being the most sought-after test drive vehicle. The concierge service is part of C&C's plan to improve the customer experience and is expected to become a permanent offering.

site_title: China's Internet stocks can't hide from the novel coronavirus
summary: China's internet stocks, including Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent, have seen significant declines in value despite the country's efforts to contain the novel coronavirus. Shares have dropped by 11.7% for Baidu, 6.4% for Alibaba, and 6.2% for Tencent. Investors are attributing the declines to a minor economic bump, with companies predicting 15% to 20% declines in sales for the first quarter. However, experts warn that the global pandemic's impact on China's exports and labor force may be more severe than anticipated, posing a significant threat to the country's internet companies.

site_title: Outbreak crushing crypto-market infrastructure
