The move comes ahead of a three-week break to combat the coronavirus. Canada's Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland praised legislators from all parties for their cooperation. The USMCA replaces the North American Free Trade Agreement, designed to boost trade among the three countries. The pact's entry-into-force date is set for June 1, but groups representing US automakers have expressed concerns over the new rules of origin.

site_title: Muslims still feel unsafe a year after New Zealand massacre
summary: A year after the Christchurch mosque attacks that killed 51 Muslims, the Muslim community in New Zealand still feels unsafe due to rising harassment and threats. Community leaders say the support shown immediately after the attacks has made fringe supremacist movements more defensive and vitriolic. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern acknowledged that more needs to be done to tackle white supremacists. Muslim women, in particular, are targeted due to their headscarves, and online hate speech is a significant concern, affecting not just the Muslim community but also other groups.

site_title: Colombia to turn away visitors who have stayed in Asia, Europe in last two weeks
summary: Colombia is closing its border with Venezuela and restricting visitors from Europe and Asia due to the coronavirus pandemic. Starting Monday, non-residents and non-nationals who have stayed in Europe or Asia in the last two weeks will not be allowed to enter. Colombian nationals and residents who have traveled abroad in the last 14 days will be required to isolate themselves for two weeks. The country has reported 16 cases of coronavirus, and a health emergency has been declared, suspending public gatherings and blocking cruise ships from docking.

site_title: Mexico frets about US coronavirus spread, could tighten border
summary: Mexico is considering tightening its northern border to slow the spread of coronavirus, with the US outbreak infecting over 1,800 people. Despite having only 26 confirmed cases, Mexican Deputy Health Minister Hugo Lopez-Gatell warns of a threat, citing the risk of infection in frontier cities. The government may recommend suspending non-essential services to curb mass gatherings, but aims to avoid severe economic impact. US President Donald Trump links the virus to the need for a border wall, while the US ambassador to Mexico calls for cooperation on border controls.

site_title: Disney halts production on some live-action movies
summary: Walt Disney has halted production on some live-action films due to concerns over the rapidly spreading coronavirus, with no confirmed cases at its productions. The company will reassess the situation and resume production as soon as feasible. Similar shutdowns have been reported by Netflix and Warner Bros Television Group, with Netflix shutting down US and Canadian production for two weeks and Warner Bros halting production on some series and pilots.

site_title: New Zealand cancels mosque massacre remembrance over virus fears
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has cancelled a national remembrance service for the Christchurch mosque attacks due to coronavirus fears. The service, which would have drawn several thousand people, was expected to commemorate the one-year anniversary of the mass shooting that killed 51. Ardern cited concerns about the risk of further harm from travel and contact tracing, following six reported cases of the new coronavirus in the country. Instead, the government encourages New Zealanders to reflect on the tragedy in their own way.

site_title: Australia steps up lockdown to combat coronavirus spread
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has stepped up lockdown measures to combat the coronavirus spread, canceling a rugby game and urging people to reconsider overseas trips. The nation's treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, called a crisis meeting with financial regulators to address the rapidly growing economic threat. With 197 confirmed cases and three deaths, Australia has implemented a ban on non-essential gatherings of over 500 people, including sporting and cultural events, and ordered 70% of Telstra staff to work from home until March.

site_title: US FDA approves Thermo Fischer's coronavirus test: official
summary: The US FDA has approved Thermo Fisher Scientific's coronavirus test, allowing the company to produce up to 1.4 million tests per week. This move aims to increase testing capacity amid the Trump administration's struggles to meet demand. The FDA has also previously approved a faster test made by Roche. President Trump has partnered with the private sector to ramp up test kit production, with 5 million kits expected to be available soon.

site_title: Worker at California's largest oil refinery tests positive for coronavirus
summary: A worker at Marathon Petroleum's Los Angeles Refinery in California tested positive for coronavirus and is in self-quarantine. The refinery, the state's largest producer of gasoline, continues to operate with reduced staffing. The incident is the first reported case of a worker with Covid-19 at a US refinery. The plant employs around 850 people, and management has identified a handful of people in contact with the infected worker. California has seen nearly 250 reported coronavirus cases, with the state's largest refineries playing a crucial role in fuel supply.

site_title: Electoral boundaries report: more MPs, smaller GRCs
summary: Singapore's Electoral Boundaries Review Committee has submitted its report, recommending 93 elected Members of Parliament, 31 electoral divisions, and changes to Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs). The government has accepted the report, which includes creating smaller GRCs and new Single Member Constituencies. The next General Election could be held sooner rather than later due to the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with some observers predicting it could be as early as April 2021, rather than the previously set April 2021 deadline.

site_title: Hong Kong "Umbrella" movement leader freed from prison, says 'no regret'
summary: Hong Kong democracy activist Chan Kin-man, leader of the 2014 "Umbrella" civil disobedience movement, was released from prison on Saturday. Chan, 61, was found guilty of conspiracy to commit public nuisance for his role in planning the 79-day protest. He has no regrets about his actions, saying they were necessary to fight for democracy and universal suffrage. Chan plans to visit young protesters arrested during recent unrest and share his experience. The Umbrella movement, which used peaceful sit-ins to block roads, failed to achieve concessions from Beijing, but its legacy is seen as preparing Hong Kong for further democracy fights.

site_title: US, European airlines in government talks over coronavirus support
summary: Major US and European airlines are in talks with governments to secure financial assistance due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on global travel. The US' three largest airlines - Delta, American, and United - are raising concerns about potentially furloughing tens of thousands of employees, while European carriers such as Norwegian Air, KLM, and Lufthansa are considering job cuts and government aid. The US President has stated that the US government will help the airline industry, and France and Germany have also offered support.

site_title: Air France-KLM Dutch subsidiary to cut up to 2,000 jobs
summary: KLM, the Dutch subsidiary of Air France-KLM, plans to cut up to 2,000 jobs and reduce flights by 30% in the second quarter of 2020 due to the global coronavirus outbreak. CEO Pieter Elbers stated that the company will also cut working hours by one-third for its entire staff. The move comes as the airline faces government-imposed restrictions on flying to certain countries. The company is seeking government support amid estimated global costs of the coronavirus outbreak exceeding $100 billion.

site_title: Asia-Pacific policymakers turn protectors amid Covid-19 spread
summary: Asia-Pacific policymakers are implementing measures to reduce the strain of the Covid-19 outbreak, prioritizing public health and safety while acknowledging the economic impact. Economic policies are expected to be limited until the situation is contained, with a focus on supporting industries impacted by travel curtailments, supply chain disruptions, and tourism sectors. Accommodative fiscal policies, including rate cuts and tax rebates, are being utilized to cushion against economic impact, with real estate markets likely to be affected over a longer period.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government has taken significant steps to cushion the impact on the hotel and hospitality sectors to help them through these challenging times.

site_title: Some US short-seller bets looked surprising in coronavirus crash
summary: US short-sellers increased bets on companies like 3M, Facebook, and Alphabet despite the US stock market's nosedive due to coronavirus fears. Short sellers borrowed millions of dollars' worth of shares from these companies, with 3M seeing its shares sold short surge by $245.8 million and Facebook's shares borrowed increasing by $244.9 million. This counter-intuitive move may be due to the high demand for products and services from these companies during the pandemic, such as mask-making and online services.

site_title: IMF, World Bank staff to work from home after coronavirus case at IMF headquarters
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Group have advised their staff to work from home due to a coronavirus case at the IMF headquarters in Washington. About 2,000 IMF staff and 16,000 World Bank and International Finance Corp employees are affected. The IMF remains operational, with only essential travel allowed to high-risk areas. No World Bank Group staff have tested positive for the virus, and the institutions are taking precautions to identify close contacts and prevent further spread.

site_title: Teladoc Health says daily patient visits rose 50% in past week
summary: Teladoc Health reported a 50% increase in daily patient visits over the prior week, with a peak of 15,000 visits per day, amid the global coronavirus outbreak. The company attributed the surge to increased demand for virtual care services, with several health insurers waiving consumer costs and public health officials encouraging the use of telemedicine. This marks an unprecedented daily visit volume in the US, with over half of patient visits this month coming from first-time users.

site_title: US: Stocks stage furious rally late after national emergency declared
summary: US stocks staged a furious rally late Friday after President Donald Trump declared a national emergency to combat the coronavirus, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 9.36% to 23,185.62 and the S&P 500 gaining 9.29% to 2,711.02. Despite suffering sharp losses for the week, the market responded positively to the announcement of $50 billion in federal aid. The rally was the biggest one-day percentage gain for the S&P 500 since 2008, and the Dow and Nasdaq Composite also saw significant gains.

site_title: Crude posts biggest weekly losses since 2008, hit by coronavirus and Saudi price war
summary: Oil prices experienced their largest weekly losses since 2008 due to the coronavirus outbreak and a price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia. The coronavirus has infected over 138,000 people and killed over 5,000, disrupting business and markets. Saudi Arabia has increased oil exports to target Russian refiners, leading to a global oil surplus of six million barrels per day by April, according to Goldman Sachs. Oil prices rebounded on Friday after the US and other nations signaled plans to support weakening economies.

site_title: Bill Gates steps down from Microsoft board
summary: Bill Gates stepped down from Microsoft's board to focus on philanthropic works, citing his role as chairman of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which addresses global health, education, and climate change. This departure marks the end of his involvement with Microsoft, where he previously served as chairman from 2014. Gates also stepped down from Berkshire Hathaway's board, which he had been a part of since 2004. His departure leaves Microsoft's board with 12 members.

site_title: US should "think twice" before returning 1MDB funds to Malaysia, says ex-PM Mahathir
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad advised the US to "think twice" before returning $4.5 billion in 1MDB funds to Malaysia, citing the party accused of graft, UMNO, is now in power. Mahathir resigned last month after being replaced by Muhyiddin Yassin, whose coalition includes UMNO despite voters rejecting the party in 2018. Najib Razak, former UMNO prime minister, is on trial for allegedly receiving stolen 1MDB funds.

site_title: A small hospital in the fight of its life against the deadly coronavirus
summary: EvergreenHealth, a suburban hospital in Washington, is on the front lines of the US response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Since late February, the hospital has seen a rapid increase in cases, with 65 patients testing positive and 15 deaths, half of the nation's total. Staff have been working at the edge of their capabilities, facing a highly contagious virus that has overwhelmed the hospital's resources. Despite shortages of supplies, including masks and sanitizer, the hospital has maintained operations, with caregivers being called back to work and new patients being isolated.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: City Developments Limited is in preliminary discussions with banks and parties to establish a real estate investment trust (Reit) in the UK, to be listed on the Singapore Exchange. Vibrant Group posted a net loss of S$764,000 for the third quarter due to a fair value loss on an investment property. Oneapex Limited acquired a capital markets licence to conduct fund management activities. ST Engineering's dormant subsidiary SPTel was placed under members' voluntary liquidation as part of a review to streamline its legal entity structure.

site_title: Updated voter rolls open for inspection
summary: The updated Registers of Electors for Singapore's 2020 general election are open for public inspection from March 14 to March 27. Citizens can check their particulars online or at community centers, clubs, or the Elections Department. Overseas Singaporeans can register as overseas electors to vote at designated polling stations. Individuals can submit claims to have their name included or update their particulars, as well as objections to remove a name from the register. Those whose names were removed due to not voting in a past election can apply to have their names restored.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close slightly up but mark worst week since 2008
summary: European stocks closed 1% higher on Friday, snapping a six-day losing streak, but marked their worst week since 2008. The Stoxx 600 index fell 18% for the week, weighed down by the coronavirus outbreak and its economic impact. Despite some sectors, such as mining and healthcare, showing resilience, the overall market was hit by state of emergency declarations in Spain and US travel restrictions. The week's losses were the worst since the 2008 financial crisis, with some stocks experiencing their worst weekly performances, including oil and gas, travel, and leisure.

site_title: Citigroup, JPMorgan report New York cases of coronavirus
summary: New York-based banks Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase & Co reported that they have employees who have tested positive for the coronavirus, with Citigroup confirming one case and JPMorgan confirming two. The announcements follow similar news from other banks as the virus continues to spread in the US and worldwide.

site_title: Trump declares coronavirus US national emergency, says he will most likely be tested
summary: US President Donald Trump declared a national emergency over the coronavirus, freeing up $50 billion in federal aid. He also announced plans to accelerate testing and said he would "most likely" be tested for the virus himself after possible exposure. Trump urged Americans to make sacrifices and change daily practices, contrasting his previous statements. The declaration aims to "unleash the full power of the federal government" to combat the virus, which has infected over 138,000 people worldwide and led to 47 US deaths.

site_title: Asia's private banks continue to report strong trading volumes
summary: Asia's private banks continue to report strong trading volumes despite market routs and concerns over the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Wealthy Asians appear not to be overly spooked, with trading activity remaining "orderly" and no "undue panic" yet. Private banks expect the pandemic to subside by mid-2020, and most hold a positive medium-term outlook, with DBS and Standard Chartered reporting upticks in private banking trading volumes.

site_title: Yoma JV finishes building solar-hybrid power plants for rural Myanmar
summary: Yoma JV, a joint venture of Myanmar-focused Yoma Strategic Holdings, has completed building 250 micro solar-hybrid power plants in rural Myanmar, set to power 250 off-grid telecom towers previously reliant on diesel. The plants will offset over 5,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions annually, equivalent to planting 75,000 trees. The move aims to bridge Myanmar's rural electrification gap and spur sustainable economic growth.

images.alt_text: "With about 60% of Myanmar's people having no access to the grid, the lack of a reliable supply of electricity is one of the biggest bottlenecks for economic development in the country," says Yoma Strategic's Melvyn Pun.

site_title: Virus, oil and a slowing global economy: Time to buy or take cover?
summary: A global pandemic, oil price crash, and economic slowdown have created market uncertainty. However, experts believe the coronavirus is a fleeting event, and economies will eventually recover with supportive policies and resurgent demand. Buying risk assets, such as blue-chip stocks, and investing with large, multi-philosophy asset managers can be beneficial. The author suggests the worst may be yet to come, but the current environment is the best time to buy, as the markets tend to follow economies and are swayed by fads. A contained virus will likely lead to a return to long-term economic trajectories.

site_title: Singapore's financial markets are functioning normally despite volatility: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial markets are operating normally despite global volatility, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The central bank has maintained a higher level of liquidity in the banking system and eased Singapore dollar interest rates, aligning with global trends. The nominal effective exchange rate of the Singapore dollar has also eased within the MAS policy band. The MAS stands ready to ensure the stability of the financial system and next reviews its policies in April 2020.

site_title: Indonesia unveils more emergency stimulus to fight virus fallout
summary: Indonesia has unveiled an emergency fiscal stimulus plan worth 22.92 trillion rupiah ($2.2 billion) to combat the economic fallout from the novel coronavirus crisis. The package includes tax breaks and aims to push the budget deficit to 2.5% of gross domestic product. This follows a previous stimulus announcement of $745 million and comes amid a deteriorating economic outlook, with Indonesia's stock index in bear territory and currency down 7.5% in the past month. The move is part of efforts by governments worldwide to protect their economies amid the virus crisis.

site_title: Google is developing a virus testing website for the US
summary: Google is developing a virus testing website for the US, in partnership with the government, to help people determine if they need testing and direct them to the closest location. Alphabet's Verily health-care division is also working on a website to coordinate virus testing efforts. The website, which is expected to include drive-through testing centers at Walmart and Target parking lots, aims to aid in the COVID-19 testing effort and limit the spread of misinformation. Google has approximately 1,700 engineers working on the project.

site_title: SIA suspending New York route via Frankfurt from March to April
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will suspend flights between Singapore and New York with a stopover in Frankfurt from March to April due to the US travel ban. This is part of the airline's efforts to reduce capacity and evaluate the impact of travel restrictions. The cancellations affect 15.6% of SIA's network, with some flights to Rome and China lasting until May and those to Christchurch and San Francisco in June. Customers will be re-accommodated on other flights and notified via phone or email.

site_title: Virus has 'minimal impact' on Europe income: Cromwell E-Reit
summary: The manager of Cromwell E-Reit stated the novel coronavirus outbreak has had a "minimal impact" on income from European properties, particularly in Italy. The distribution per unit (DPU) for FY2020 is expected to remain at the FY2019 level of 4.08 euro cents, despite the current circumstances. This decision was made after implementing risk-mitigation measures.

site_title: Gold hurt by other falling markets
summary: Gold prices declined by over $60 an ounce in the past week, closing lower for three consecutive days, amid concerns over large hedge funds needing cash due to the global equity meltdown and low treasury yields. The US dollar's strength also contributed to the decline. However, gold remains well-positioned for a bullish trend, with central banks expected to maintain robust net gold purchases. The Bank of England's monetary policy easing and European Central Bank's proposed measures may also support gold prices in the longer term.

site_title: China's Feb home sales plunge as Covid-19 outbreak deepened
summary: China's home sales plummeted 33% in February compared to the same period in 2019, with key developers experiencing the largest declines. The contraction, the steepest in six years, was attributed to the novel coronavirus outbreak. Despite efforts to migrate sales online, China Evergrande Group saw a 108% increase in sales, likely due to its aggressive marketing campaign. The outbreak has led to government controls, reduced consumer spending, and construction delays, causing concerns about the pace of residential sales in the coming months.

site_title: Have football fees and wages gone out of control?
summary: Football transfer fees and wages have skyrocketed, with top players commanding record-breaking sums. The current record for a goalkeeper is £80 million, while Brazilian forward Neymar earns an estimated 550,000 euros per week. The Bank of England attributes the high pay-outs to supply and demand, stating that clubs must compete for talented players to win titles. Average top annual salaries in the English Premier League range from £5 million to £8.7 million, with agents taking around 5% commission. This has led to financial pressure on less-profitable clubs, with total player expenditure exceeding 60% of revenue for top clubs.

site_title: Japan vows 'bold' steps to beat Covid-19 fallout
summary: Japan's economy minister, Yasutoshi Nishimura, has vowed to take "bold and unprecedented" steps to combat the economic fallout from the novel coronavirus. The government is reportedly working on a new spending package of up to 20 trillion yen, including cash payouts and subsidies for tourism companies, in conjunction with the Bank of Japan's planned monetary easing. This move aims to cushion the blow from the recession and shore up business confidence, with the government and central bank standing united in their efforts to address the crisis.

site_title: Thematic funds a challenge for retail investors
summary: Morningstar research found thematic funds underperform, with a low survivorship rate and high fees. Between 2010 and 2020, only 45% of thematic funds survived, and just 1 in 4 outperformed the MSCI World Index. The study suggests investors should carefully evaluate the theme, strategy, and fund manager before investing, and consider exit criteria to mitigate risks. Many experts, including DBS Private Bank's head of funds selection, are wary of thematic funds due to their high fees and potential for unsustainable investment ideas.

site_title: Dow jumps 4.9% as US stocks bounce back after rout
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, bouncing back from a rout on Thursday as Washington policymakers reported progress on stimulus to address the economic impact of the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 4.9% to 22,247.57, while the S&P 500 climbed 5.4% to 2,613.59. Despite the gains, global equities are heading for their worst week since 2008, with investors doubting the efficacy of policy responses amid growing cases and restrictions.

site_title: How to steady yourself in the face of a market meltdown
summary: A global market meltdown has occurred, ending the longest bull run in US markets, with the S&P 500 down 23% and Asian markets down 18% year-to-date. The crash is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, oil price war, and heightened valuations. Investors are advised not to sell during a crash, as prices tend to fall more than justified, and instead, focus on steady, long-term strategies, including knowing investment values, diversifying portfolios, and avoiding short-term investments. The market's volatility is a natural occurrence, and with emotional fortitude, investors can navigate the storm and reap benefits in the long run.

site_title: Why 'buy the dip' is a fallacy: stocks are more expensive than they seem
summary: Stock prices may be undervalued, but current price-to-earnings ratios are a "logical fallacy" due to delayed profit forecasts. Historically, during economic crises, analysts have reduced EPS estimates by 14.3% to 39% in the past. Assuming a similar reduction, the S&P 500's price-to-estimated earnings ratio could imply a 12% lower target price, while the MSCI Emerging Markets Index could see a 23% slump. This method suggests waiting for the market to hit its average valuation before buying, but it's not a foolproof method and should be used as a proxy for evaluating true worth.

site_title: STI falls 11% in worst weekly performance since 2008
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 11% this week, its worst performance since 2008, amidst global market volatility. The index fell 326.98 points, or 11%, from March 6's close, with 25 of its 30 constituents closing in the red. However, the STI recovered slightly after mid-day, ending 44.64 points lower, or 1.7%, at 2,634. Markets are expected to remain jittery, with analysts warning of a potential downturn.

site_title: EU's draft new deal envisages close ties with Britain
summary: The European Union has released a draft new deal with Brexit Britain, outlining a tight trade and security relationship despite London's desire for looser ties. The draft includes "level playing field" provisions to ensure fair competition, which London rejects. Britain left the EU in January and is negotiating a new partnership to take effect after a transition period ends at the end of the year. The EU's executive Commission prepared the draft ahead of second-round talks next week.

site_title: Airlines slashing prices amid pandemic because it's 'better than doing nothing'
summary: Airlines worldwide are offering discounted fares and free flight changes in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with promotions including "book now, fly later" and discounts of up to 55%. Analysts predict that industry consolidation is likely, with weaker airlines potentially going under, while healthier players may emerge ahead. The International Air Transport Association estimates a $113 billion loss in global passenger receipts this year, and operating margins are expected to narrow to under 5%. Airlines are also seeking government aid, including deferred tax payments and lower airport fees, to help mitigate losses.

site_title: Reits (March 14-15, 2020)
summary: Realtors report mixed trends in the global real estate market. In Singapore, the Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed for the first time in five weeks. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Manhattan rents have reached a record, with more increases expected. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. Goldman Sachs has also acquired a significant hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul.

site_title: Changi Airport's Feb passenger traffic falls 32.8% as virus hits travel demand
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore experienced a 32.8% decline in passenger traffic in February 2020, with 3.5 million movements, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The World Health Organization declared the outbreak a pandemic, leading to travel bans and flight cancellations. Air travel demand declined across all regions, with South-east Asia and North-east Asia impacted the most. Aircraft movements dropped 12.3% to 26,200, while airfreight throughput rose 7.6% to 147,000 tonnes. Overall, passenger traffic fell 12.9% to 9.4 million for the first two months of 2020.

site_title: Lamborghini Huracan Evo Spyder: Rocking in a winter wonderland
summary: Lamborghini's driving academy, Lamborghini Esperienza Accademia Neve, offers a 2-day intensive training course in Livigno, Italy, where participants learn to master the art of drifting a sports car on a closed-off ice track. The course, priced at €7,500, features a fleet of Lamborghini Huracan Evos and is designed to improve car control in various driving conditions. The program focuses on honing skills, building muscle memory, and providing a safe and controlled environment for drivers to push their limits.

site_title: Nordic Group wins S$30.4m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group, a Singapore-listed systems integration solutions provider, won S$30.4 million in contracts with multinational companies in various industries, including marine, oil and gas, and petrochemicals. The contracts, valued at S$11 million, S$6.5 million, and S$12.9 million, are expected to be completed in FY2020 and FY2021, with minimal impact on earnings per share. The company also reported a surge in fourth-quarter net profit to S$1.3 million, a 6-fold increase from the previous year, with revenue growing 8% to S$23.2 million.

site_title: Singapore bourse suffers wild swings, more pain in store
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced wild price swings on Friday, with the Straits Times Index falling 1.7% to 2,634.00, following Wall Street's worst plunge in three decades. Analysts expect extended volatility as the Covid-19 pandemic has yet to peak, with conditions for stability not fully in place. The market may be technically oversold, but the prognosis remains unchanged, with bear markets expected to see short-term spikes. Experts warn of more pain in store, citing the oil price war and lack of faith in monetary policy's effectiveness.

site_title: SIA cancels flights on US travel ban, says will re-accommodate customers
summary: Singapore Airlines cancels US flights due to travel ban, reducing capacity by 15.6% until May. The cancellations affect flights to and from New York, Rome, and China, with some flights to Christchurch and San Francisco impacted in June. The airline will re-accommodate customers on affected routes.

site_title: British Airways to cut jobs over coronavirus: CEO
summary: British Airways will cut jobs due to the coronavirus pandemic's devastating impact on global air travel demand. CEO Alex Cruz stated that jobs may be lost "for a short period, perhaps longer term" amid severe cash-flow pressures. The airline industry is struggling with the crisis, which has infected over 134,300 people and killed over 5,000 globally. The US-imposed travel ban from mainland Europe is expected to further hurt the industry, with the International Air Transport Association warning of "enormous cash-flow pressures" for airlines.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps after worst day since 1987
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 773.20 points, or 3.65%, to 21,973.82, following their worst daily selloff in over three decades. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, gaining 89.35 and 408.59 points, respectively. Investors were optimistic about potential fiscal easing to prevent a global recession.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 773.20 points, or 3.65 per cent, at the open to 21,973.82.

site_title: RedDoorz cuts close to 50 employees in 'appraisal' exercise
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based budget hotel operator, has cut nearly 50 employees, around 8% of its Indonesian team, as part of a "periodic staff appraisal exercise" in February. Globally, the layoffs account for less than 5% of the startup's total workforce. CEO Amit Saberwal attributed the cuts to the dedicated and strong team, stating that every employee is a valuable asset. The move comes as other startups in the region, such as OYO and CXA Group, have also cut staff in recent months.

site_title: A folding phone that's a dud
summary: Samsung's Galaxy Z Flip, a $1,380 foldable smartphone, has received negative reviews due to its impractical design and numerous flaws. The device's foldable screen is prone to scratches, and its mechanical hinge can be finicky, making it tedious to use. The phone's biometric scanner often fails to work, and the screen's crease is visible when unfolded. The device's pocketability is compromised due to its bulkiness when folded, and its camera is not as good as high-end phones. Overall, the Galaxy Z Flip is deemed impractical and not worth the high price tag.

site_title: US consumer sentiment drops in early February, coronavirus blamed
summary: US consumer sentiment fell 5.0% to 95.9 in early March, slightly higher than expected, due to the coronavirus pandemic and declining stock market prices. Despite initial concerns, the response to the virus has not triggered economic panic, but further declines in confidence are likely as the virus continues to spread.

site_title: My lockdown diary, from a small, old town in Italy
summary: In Italy, a small town near Milan, a lockdown has been implemented due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the town's main square, Piazza del Duomo, eerily empty. Residents are forced to stay at home, with only essential services and food stores allowed to operate. The town's hospital has been overwhelmed with COVID-19 patients, and healthcare staff are exhausted. Despite the challenges, life continues, with residents finding ways to cope, including writing newsletters and going for solitary walks in the countryside. The town's economy is also struggling, with restaurants and businesses forced to shut down.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 74.68 points to 1,344.75. Losers outnumbered gainers 819 to 223, and volume was 5.7 billion lots worth RM4.9 billion.

site_title: 13 new Covid-19 cases, including nine who caught it overseas
summary: Singapore has confirmed 13 new Covid-19 cases, including nine imported, bringing the total infections to 200. The imported cases include two Singaporeans who attended a mass religious event near Kuala Lumpur, linked to four local cases. 97 cases have fully recovered, with 103 remaining in hospital, most stable or improving, and 11 in critical condition.

images.alt_text: A member of a healthcare team takes a traveller's temperature at Changi Airport. Singapore has confirmed 13 new Covid-19 cases, including nine that are imported.

site_title: Singapore financial markets functioning normally despite volatility: MAS
summary: Singapore's financial markets are operating normally despite global market volatility, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The central bank has maintained a higher level of liquidity in the banking system and eased Singapore dollar interest rates, allowing the nominal effective exchange rate to ease within its policy band. The Straits Times Index closed 1.67% lower on Friday, extending Thursday's losses to a four-year low. The MAS stands ready to ensure the stability of the financial system, with its next policy review scheduled for April 2020.

site_title: CDL in preliminary discussions about Singapore Reit for UK commercial assets
summary: CDL is in preliminary discussions with banks and parties to establish a Reit with UK commercial assets, which will be listed on the Singapore Exchange. The properties and terms of the potential Reit are currently under review. If successful, this would be CDL's first foray into the UK market.

site_title: Xerox pauses HP hostile takeover, proxy fight amid outbreak
summary: Xerox has paused its hostile takeover bid for HP amid the coronavirus outbreak, prioritizing employee health and safety. CEO John Visentin stated that the company will continue its pursuit of HP when the pandemic stabilizes. The pause comes as Xerox's shares have fallen 33% over the past month, while HP's shares have declined 18%. The deal, valued at $35 billion, was met with resistance from HP, which argued the takeover price undervalues the company. Xerox will focus on protecting its stakeholders during the pandemic before resuming its efforts.

site_title: Covid-19: New border restrictions, event advisories
summary: Singapore introduces new border restrictions for travellers from Italy, France, Spain, and Germany due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Symptomatic travellers will receive stay-home notices, and all cruise vessel port calls will cease. The country also issues advisories for large events, workplaces, and public venues. These measures aim to control the spread of the virus.

site_title: Berlin court finds rent freeze law unconstitutional
summary: A Berlin district court ruled the city's rent freeze law unconstitutional, referring it to Germany's Federal Constitutional Court for a definitive ruling. The court found the city legislature lacked the power to pass the legislation, which froze rents in Berlin for five years. The Federal Constitutional Court previously rejected an application for an injunction against the rent freeze law. The outcome remains uncertain, pending further review by the Federal Constitutional Court.

site_title: Getting ahead of ourselves, and our crimes
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) advancements have made pre-crime, the ability to predict future threats or non-compliance events, a possibility. However, the use of AI in pre-crime raises concerns about privacy and choice. To mitigate these risks, it's essential to establish a clear agenda on how AI-derived insights will be used. AI can aid in investigation and audit processes by analyzing data and identifying patterns, but it's crucial to address the challenges of reviewing all available information and selecting relevant data. Pre-crime can be used as a deterrent, encouraging self-regulation and nudging individuals to make desired choices, rather than a systematic erosion of choice.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound; London up 3%
summary: European stock markets rebounded, with London up 3.4%, Frankfurt 2.1%, Paris 2.4%, and Milan 4.5% at the start of trading. This follows Thursday's plunge due to recession fears triggered by the coronavirus pandemic, with Paris experiencing its worst one-day loss ever. London and Frankfurt suffered losses of around 10-12% since the late 1980s.

site_title: Active funds beat passive 'marginally' in recent sell-off: iFast
summary: Active funds have outperformed passive 'marginally' in the recent sell-off, according to iFast Corp senior unit trust analyst Shawn Teow. Over the last month, the SPDR Straits Times Index ETF was the worst performer compared to a peer group of 11 unique Singapore equity active strategies. Trading volume and turnover for ETFs have nearly doubled, driven by retail investor euphoria and high expectations for the Sino-US trade deal. However, Teow warns of a growing risk of portfolio concentration as market leaders dominate the market, increasing concentration and company-specific risks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end more than 1% down, well off early lows
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.14% down, or 276.16 points, to 24,032.91, following a tumultuous week of losses due to fears of a global recession caused by the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell 9% over the past five days, while China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined, with losses of almost 5% and 6%, respectively.

site_title: RedDoorz cuts close to 50 staff in 'appraisal' exercise
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based budget hotel operator, has cut nearly 50 staff, or around 8% of its Indonesian team, as part of a "periodic staff appraisal exercise" in February. The move affects 600-strong Indonesian team, with the remaining staff cuts being less than 5% of the startup's global workforce. CEO Amit Saberwal attributed the move to the startup's growth, stating that every employee is a valuable asset. The move follows similar staff cuts by competitors OYO and CXA Group, amid regional reorganisation exercises.

images.alt_text: The breach of 5.9 million customer records at RedDoorz was the largest data breach incident since Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act came into force.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee submitted its report, recommending changes to electoral boundaries, including more MPs and a new Sengkang GRC. The government accepted the recommendations. Singapore introduced new border restrictions for travelers from four European countries, ceased port calls for cruises, and issued advisories for large events due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The healthcare market in Singapore is expected to grow to $29.8 billion this year. Changi Airport's February passenger traffic fell 32.8% due to the virus. The STI ended 1.7% lower at 2,634.00.

site_title: China cuts reserve ratios for some banks to spur lending amid epidemic
summary: China's central bank has cut reserve ratios for some banks by 50-100 basis points to release 550 billion yuan in liquidity, supporting the economy amid a coronavirus outbreak. The move, the ninth since 2018, aims to spur lending and ease monetary policy. The reserve requirement ratio for qualified joint-stock banks will be reduced by an additional 100 bps, effective March 16. Analysts expect China's economic growth to fall to 3.5% in the first quarter.

site_title: Japan's economic policymakers now factoring in Olympics cancellation, sources say
summary: Japan's economic policymakers are considering the risk of Olympics cancellation due to the coronavirus outbreak, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's repeated assurances that the Games will proceed as planned. The Bank of Japan may loosen monetary policy next week to ease market volatility, but officials fear an Olympic cancellation could upend even the most pessimistic economic projections. A cancellation could lead to a huge blow to household and corporate sentiment, potentially freezing consumption and causing the economy to crumble. Policymakers are preparing for the worst-case scenario in the government's April economic package.

site_title: influence.co raises US$3m in seed funding led by Bonfire Ventures
summary: INFLUENCE.CO, a platform for influencers and creators, has secured US$3 million in seed funding led by Bonfire Ventures. The investment will be used to scale the community and launch a media division focused on the influencer lifestyle. The company, which has raised US$4.4 million to date, has over 175,000 members, including 35,000 businesses. Founded in 2016, influence.co aims to connect the influencer economy through inspiring content and collaborative commerce.

site_title: World travel may shrink 25% on coronavirus in 2020, shed 50m jobs
summary: The World Travel and Tourism Council projects international travel to slump by a quarter in 2020 due to the coronavirus epidemic, potentially affecting up to 50 million jobs in the global travel and tourism sector. This would result in a 12-14% job reduction, equivalent to three months of global travel. The council urges governments to simplify visas, cut travel taxes, and introduce incentives once the epidemic is under control. The tourism industry accounts for 10% of the world's GDP and jobs.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus epidemic is putting up to 50 million jobs in the global travel and tourism sector at risk, with international travel likely to slump by a quarter this year, the World Travel and Tourism Council projected on Friday.

site_title: Registers of Electors open for public inspection from March 14 to 27
summary: The lists of Singaporean eligible voters for the next general election are open for public inspection from March 14 to 27. The voter rolls contain the names of all qualified electors as of March 1. Singapore citizens can check their particulars online or in person at community centres, clubs, or the Elections Department. Those who did not vote in a past election can apply to have their names restored. Overseas Singaporeans who have lived in Singapore for at least 30 days between 2017 and 2020 can register as overseas electors to vote at overseas polling stations.

site_title: Mainland China reports 8 new confirmed cases of coronavirus
summary: Mainland China reported 8 new confirmed cases of coronavirus, bringing the total to 80,813. The death toll rose to 3,176, with 6 new fatalities in the central province of Hubei, all in the provincial capital of Wuhan.

site_title: Australia urges against gatherings of more than 500 people to contain coronavirus
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison urged people not to gather in groups of more than 500 to contain the spread of coronavirus, as health officials warned millions of residents will contract the disease within months. The ban applies to non-essential gatherings, excluding schools, airports, and public transport. The country has recorded 156 infections and three deaths, with authorities expecting a rapid increase in cases due to the southern hemisphere winter. The move comes as the global virus toll surpasses 135,000 and 4,900 deaths.

site_title: Sasseur Reit to resume full ops; reopen 2 China malls after outbreak closure
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, will resume full operations after reopening two China outlet malls, Chongqing and Bishan, on March 15. The malls had been closed for about seven weeks due to the novel coronavirus outbreak in China. The Reit's financial impact from the closure is expected to be minimal, with stable income from fixed and variable components. Sasseur Reit units fell 1.5% to 66.5 cents after the announcement, but the Reit's full-year financial impact is not significant. The Reit had previously reopened its Kunming and Hefei outlet malls on March 11 and 13, respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI pares steep losses at Friday afternoon reopen
summary: Singapore stocks pared losses on Friday, recovering from early-session declines amid growing optimism over a potential COVID-19 cure, a US stimulus deal, and the Bank of Japan's bond-buying plan. The STI index closed with slight gains, following a 5-day rally. Market sentiment improved despite ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Australian home minister Peter Dutton tests positive for coronavirus
summary: Australian Home Minister Peter Dutton tested positive for coronavirus and was admitted to hospital in Queensland, Australia, on Friday. He had attended a meeting with Prime Minister Scott Morrison and other Cabinet members the previous Tuesday. Authorities expect a rapid increase in infections as the southern hemisphere winter approaches, with Australia having recorded 156 cases and three deaths. Dutton stated he feels fine and will provide an update in due course.

site_title: Rich universities scramble with virus forcing student refunds
summary: US universities, including Harvard, Princeton, and MIT, are scrambling to refund students due to the coronavirus forcing them to send students home. Schools plan to prorate room and board costs, with Brown University offering a pro-rated credit or refund of about $16,000. Harvard will pro-rate its $18,000 room and board cost as of March 15. Smaller colleges and public universities may struggle to offer refunds, relying on student revenue to fund fixed costs.

images.alt_text: Harvard College, Princeton University (top) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are among schools that plan to prorate room and board costs as the coronavirus has forced them to send students home.

site_title: Oyo entices virus-stricken hotels in Japan with cash
summary: Oyo Hotels, a startup in SoftBank Group Corp's portfolio, is offering cash to virus-stricken hotels in Japan to join its platform. The company will pay a lump sum equal to a proportion of their past year's revenue to new members. This move aims to expand its reach and improve relations with hotels, which have been hampered by technical problems and public backlash. The offer is available immediately and will run indefinitely, as Oyo seeks to contribute to Japan's lodging industry during the crisis.

site_title: Nordic Group wins S$30.4m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group secured about S$30.4 million in contracts, set to be completed over the next fiscal year. The contracts are with new and repeat customers in various industries, including marine, oil and gas, and semiconductor. The deals include S$12.9 million in renewed maintenance contracts, a S$6 million overhaul contract, and S$6.5 million in ad hoc projects. The contracts are not expected to significantly impact the company's earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: SoftBank unveils US$4.8b buyback after stock tumble, pressure from activist fund
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is buying back up to $4.8 billion of its shares, partially meeting the demand of activist fund Elliott, after its shares tumbled by about a quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic. The plan comes after Elliott pressed SoftBank for $20 billion in stock buybacks. SoftBank shares are trading 50% below fair value, making the buyback a good idea, according to analyst Kirk Boodry. The buyback will begin on Monday and will take place over a year, with no fresh financing planned.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post biggest weekly drop since 2008
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 3.5% on Friday, posting their biggest weekly drop since the 2008 financial crisis, amid panic over the coronavirus outbreak. The benchmark KOSPI fell 13.2% for the week, the sharpest since October 2008. Foreigners sold $1.02 billion worth of shares, while the country's president held a meeting with top economic officials to discuss the outbreak's impact. The Bank of Korea is considering a rate cut, its first since 2008, to tackle the economic crisis.

site_title: South Korea reports 110 new novel coronavirus cases, total at 7,979
summary: South Korea reported 110 new novel coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 7,979, according to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. This marks a downward trend in new cases, slightly down from the 114 recorded on Thursday.

site_title: Australia: US stimulus hopes help shares bounce back from 8% fall
summary: Australian shares rebounded 4.4% to 5,539 points, their largest daily gain in over 11 years, as US stimulus hopes boosted markets. The S&P/ASX 200 index recovered from an 8% fall earlier in the session, with healthcare, financial, and energy stocks leading the rally. The Reserve Bank of Australia injected an unusually large amount of cash into the financial system amid global panic selling. A US economic aid package was nearing agreement, according to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, and expectations of US stimulus supported sentiment.

site_title: Australia tells citizens to reconsider all foreign travel amid virus pandemic
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison advised citizens to reconsider all foreign travel amid the novel coronavirus pandemic, citing the widespread nature of the disease. The government also moved to halt events of more than 500 people to slow the spread. This decision comes as the pandemic continues to spread globally, with no end in sight. The Australian government's measures are aimed at protecting its citizens from the virus.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down 6%, paring losses after virus rout
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 6.08% or 1,128.58 points to 17,431.05, trimming losses after a global rout on fears of a recession linked to the coronavirus outbreak. The broader Topix index dropped 4.98% or 66.18 points. The decline follows a global market downturn amid concerns over the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: One Championship moves to closed-door, audience-free events amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: One Championship has suspended all live audience events until May 29, 2020, due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The organization will instead host closed-door, audience-free events, starting with a global broadcast show in Singapore on April 17. Other events, such as Dota 2 e-sports competitions, will also be held in a studio-only format. One Championship's martial arts event, One Infinity 1, is still scheduled for May 29 in Manila, but its status is subject to change if the virus situation deteriorates.

site_title: Covid-19: Border restrictions on 4 European countries, no port calls for cruises, advisories for large events
summary: Singapore introduces new border restrictions for travelers from Italy, France, Spain, and Germany, effective March 15, with a 14-day stay-home notice for those entering with symptoms. The country also ceases port calls for all cruise vessels and advises against large events, workplaces, and public venues. The move aims to curb the spread of the Covid-19 virus, with 47 imported cases reported as of March 12, and the government warns of potential spikes in cases due to the global outbreak.

site_title: English Premier League in doubt as Arteta, Hudson-Odoi get coronavirus
summary: The English Premier League is facing uncertainty after Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta and Chelsea winger Callum Hudson-Odoi both tested positive for the new coronavirus, prompting at least one game to be postponed. The Premier League will hold emergency talks on Friday regarding future fixtures, with the league's schedule in doubt. Other top-flight clubs, including Leicester and Manchester City, have also been affected by the virus, leading to self-isolation and potential fixture postponements.

site_title: Thailand sees its first pro-democracy march since 2014 coup
summary: Thailand witnessed its first pro-democracy march since the 2014 coup, with hundreds of protesters marching on parliament in Bangkok, calling for the government to quit. The march, dubbed "Black Friday," was held in response to the government's handling of the Covid-19 crisis, economic faltering, and the disbanding of the progressive Future Forward Party. Protesters, including students, expressed their discontent with the government of ex-army chief Prayut Chan-O-Cha, who was voted into power a year ago, and vowed to continue mobilizing for democratic reforms.

site_title: Electoral boundaries report: More MPs, new Sengkang GRC, smaller GRCs
summary: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee has submitted its report, recommending 93 elected Members of Parliament, up from 89, across 31 electoral divisions. This includes 14 Single Member Constituencies and 17 Group Representation Constituencies, with changes such as a new four-member Sengkang GRC and smaller GRCs. The next General Election must be held by April 2021, with four new Single Member Constituencies created. The report's recommendations were accepted by the government, marking the first major step towards the next General Election.

site_title: Over 95% of larger Chinese firms outside Hubei resume work: official
summary: China's vice-industry minister Xin Guobin reported that over 95% of larger Chinese firms outside Hubei province have resumed work, with 60% of small and medium-sized firms also returning to work. China aims to coordinate with other countries to promote business resumption despite pandemic uncertainty. The country is working to gradually return to normalcy after imposing strict restrictions on transport and people to slow the spread of infections.

site_title: 'Minimal impact' from coronavirus on Europe income: Cromwell E-Reit
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) reports minimal impact from the coronavirus outbreak on its income from European properties, particularly in Italy. The manager expects distribution per unit to remain at FY2019 levels. With 23% of its portfolio in Italy and significant government tenants, the Reit is well-diversified and resilient against short-term economic shocks. Cromwell E-Reit's CEO believes the outbreak's impact on the Reit's Italian properties will be limited due to long leases.

site_title: Indonesia to ban face mask exports to ensure domestic supply
summary: Indonesia's Trade Minister Agus Suparmanto announced a temporary ban on the export of face masks to ensure domestic supply amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. The ban aims to meet demand from domestic industries and consumers, who have seen prices jump due to stockpiling. The measure will remain in place until the government is satisfied with local supply.

site_title: Singapore healthcare market set to grow to S$29.8b this year: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's healthcare market is expected to grow to S$29.8 billion in 2020, a 9% increase from last year, and reach S$68.7 billion by 2029. The market's proportion of GDP is forecast to rise to 9% by 2029, driven by rising government spending and increased use of healthcare services due to an ageing population. Government healthcare spend is expected to nearly triple to S$50 billion by 2029, while private healthcare expenditure is forecast to rise to S$18.8 billion.

site_title: Changi Airport February passenger traffic falls 32.8% as virus hits travel demand
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore reported a 32.8% drop in February passenger traffic, handling 3.5 million movements, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The World Health Organization has declared the virus a pandemic. Available seat capacity fell by 30% for March 2020, and travel demand declined across all regions except Africa. Major destinations, such as China, Hong Kong, and South Korea, saw significant declines, while airfreight throughput rose 7.6% due to urgent fulfilment of backlogs in China.

site_title: Canada PM's wife tests positive for novel coronavirus: statement
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's wife, Sophie Gregoire Trudeau, has tested positive for the novel coronavirus, according to the Prime Minister's Office. The statement did not provide further details on her condition or when she was tested. This comes as Canada and the world grapple with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Yoma JV builds 250 micro solar-hybrid power plants for rural Myanmar
summary: Yoma JV, a joint venture of Myanmar-focused Yoma Strategic Holdings, has completed building 250 micro solar-hybrid power plants in rural Myanmar, aiming to power 250 off-grid telecom towers previously reliant on diesel power. The power plants will offset over 5,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions annually, equivalent to 75,000 trees. The move is part of YMP's business model, which connects mobile network operators to nearby communities through mini-grid distribution networks, providing affordable electricity.

site_title: Disney to shut Florida and Paris theme parks, cruise line over virus
summary: Disney to shut its Florida and Paris theme parks, and cruise line due to the novel coronavirus, with closures lasting at least until the end of March. The company cited an abundance of caution and a desire to protect guests and employees. Disney's California resort will also shut, with Disney Cruise Line suspending departures through the end of the month.

site_title: Malaysia's Jan factory output rises 0.6% y-o-y, slows from Dec
summary: Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.6% in January, marking the second consecutive month of slower expansion, according to government data. This decline was attributed to a decrease in the mining and electricity sectors. The January growth was lower than the forecasted 0.7% expansion. The output index had risen 1.3% in December, down from the 2% pace in the previous month.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.6 per cent in January from a year earlier, the second straight month of slower expansion on a decline in the mining and electricity sectors, government data showed on Friday.

site_title: Philippines' finance minister tasks state pension funds to support stock market
summary: Philippines' Finance Minister Carlos Dominguez ordered state pension funds to increase daily investments in the stock market to support the market amid a global downturn triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. The broader index has fallen nearly 30% year-to-date. Dominguez instructed the Government Service Insurance System and Social Security System to "double their daily average purchase volumes" to support the market. The announcement led to a 4.53% trimming of morning losses, with the index plummeting 11% in early trade. The move aims to take advantage of low stock prices and stabilize the market.

site_title: Indonesia to support economy with 120t rupiah stimulus to counter virus impact
summary: Indonesia's finance minister announced a 120 trillion rupiah (S$11.4 billion) stimulus package to counter the impact of the coronavirus on its economy, with measures including tax exemptions and corporate tax discounts for manufacturing companies. The stimulus represents 0.8% of the country's GDP and aims to widen the budget deficit to 2.5% of GDP this year. The package is expected to take effect starting April and will run for six months.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks plunge, triggering Kospi circuit breakers for first time since 2001
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted to a near 10-year low, triggering circuit breakers on the main Kospi index for the first time in nearly two decades, amid panic over the coronavirus. The benchmark Kospi fell 7% to 1,705.65, with the won sliding to a four-year low. Foreigners sold 570.6 billion won worth of shares, and the Bank of Korea is discussing a potential interest rate cut.

site_title: Japanese government, Bank of Japan remain cautious over coronavirus impact
summary: The Japanese government and the Bank of Japan are sharing information on the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on markets and the economy. Japanese Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated that both institutions are sharing a "strong sense of crisis" and are closely monitoring market developments daily. The cautious stance reflects the potential economic risks posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Washington excludes some Chinese medical products from tariffs
summary: The US Trade Representative's office granted exclusions from import tariffs for some medical products imported from China, including face masks, stethoscope covers, and blood pressure cuff sleeves. The exclusions were granted amid the novel coronavirus outbreak to alleviate strain on the US healthcare system. This move comes after earlier exclusions were granted for hand-sanitising wipes and examination gloves. The tariff rate on medical products was initially set at 15% but was lowered to 7.5% as part of the Phase 1 US-China trade agreement.

site_title: Formula One in turmoil as season-opening Australian Grand Prix cancelled
summary: The Australian Grand Prix, the season-opening Formula One event, has been cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision was made after McLaren pulled out of the event after a team member tested positive for the virus, and 14 other staff were placed in quarantine. The cancellation follows the postponement of the Chinese Grand Prix and the decision to hold the Bahrain event without spectators. Formula One chief Chase Carey stated that the focus will shift to the upcoming Bahrain and Vietnam races, and further announcements will be made on the schedule.

site_title: China ramps up efforts to boost consumption as virus hurts economy
summary: China's state planner has announced guidelines to boost residents' property income and improve consumer market supply, aiming to promote consumption amid the coronavirus crisis. The National Development and Reform Commission will reduce import tariffs on consumer goods and encourage regions with car plate quota restrictions to increase quotas. This effort follows China's GDP growth slowing, putting pressure on policymakers to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Australia's central bank boosts liquidity as virus panic hits markets
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), injected A$8.8 billion into the financial system on Friday to combat panic selling and rising borrowing costs amid the coronavirus pandemic. This move, exceeding the estimated requirement of A$3.4 billion, aims to offset the strain on markets. The US Federal Reserve has also taken similar action, injecting US$500 billion into the banking system. Australia's main stock index fell 7% on Friday, with losses for the week now at 20%. The RBA's move aims to add extra liquidity to the market.

site_title: Airbnb Q4 loss deepens even before travel disruption from virus
summary: Airbnb reported a Q4 loss of $276.4 million, excluding interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, a significant increase from $143.7 million the previous year. Revenue rose 32% to $1.1 billion, with over $2 billion in cash reserves. The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted the travel industry, with Airbnb projecting a 25% revenue increase in the first quarter, which may underestimate the full effect of the pandemic. The company's business has been devastated in China, with planned bookings down 90% from last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open sharply lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened sharply lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 71.63 points or 5.05% to 1,347.80. Volume was 245.24 million lots worth RM91.14 million. The market saw 576 losers compared to 25 gainers.

site_title: Canada PM Trudeau working from home as wife tested for Covid-19
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his wife, Sophie Gregoire-Trudeau, have self-isolated at home after she returned from a speaking engagement in Britain with mild flu-like symptoms. Trudeau will work from home and skip a meeting with provincial leaders due to caution. Several provinces have implemented stricter measures, including Quebec's ban on indoor gatherings of over 250 people and Ontario's closure of public schools. The cancellation of sporting events and entertainment galas has been reported, with the Canadian Screen Awards and Juno music awards also scrapped.

site_title: G-7 vows continued cooperation on coronavirus; opts for virtual finmin meeting
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) nations reaffirmed their commitment to international cooperation in addressing the COVID-19 pandemic, following a virtual meeting of finance ministers. The US Treasury stated that the G-7 is in regular contact and committed to continued cooperation on global health and economic impacts. The meeting comes as the virus has killed 4,750 globally, triggering panic and heavy losses in world financial markets.

site_title: Didi Chuxing sets US$10m fund for drivers who test positive for coronavirus
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has set a US$10 million fund to support drivers and couriers diagnosed with coronavirus in several countries, including Australia, Brazil, and Japan. The fund aims to provide support to drivers and couriers who typically lack sick leave and other benefits. Didi's move comes as companies worldwide grapple with how to respond to the pandemic. This initiative follows similar steps taken by Didi in its home market of China, where the company has offered daily allowances to hospitalized drivers and provided free transportation for medical workers.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei down more than 7% amid global rout over coronavirus
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 7.12% or 1,322.15 points to 17,237.48, following a global rout amid recession fears due to the coronavirus outbreak. US President Donald Trump's comments on delaying the Tokyo Olympics weighed on the market. Analysts predict a potential dip to the 17,000 level. The broader Topix index also fell 6.31%. The global downturn was sparked by the US ban on travel from Europe.

site_title: Coronavirus-hit Princess Cruises to suspend operations
summary: Princess Cruises, operator of 18 ocean liners, suspends voyages for two months due to coronavirus concerns. The decision, made after one of its ships was denied entry to San Francisco Bay and multiple crew and passenger infections were reported. The suspension affects all Princess Cruises ships, including those currently underway, and comes after Finland's Viking Line temporarily paused operations. The move is expected to impact Carnival Corp, which has already seen a significant decline in shares, and is seen as a major blow to the cruise industry already struggling with cancellations.

site_title: Asia buyers lose out as Saudis prioritise oil sales to Europe
summary: Saudi Arabia is prioritizing oil sales to Europe over Asia, according to refiners who were unable to secure additional volumes of high-quality crude. Two north Asian refiners declined extra supplies due to quality mismatches, while Indian processors received their requested oil. Major European buyers, including Shell, BP, and Total, received significantly above normal volumes, highlighting Saudi Arabia's shift in focus. This move comes as Saudi Aramco slashes official selling prices and ramps up output to record levels in response to Russia's price war.

site_title: Virgin Australia cuts more capacity, suspends guidance amid Covid-19 blow
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings cut more capacity, suspended financial guidance, and froze hiring amid the coronavirus outbreak, joining Qantas Airways in reducing capacity. The airline also offered unpaid leave to staff and reduced its second-half capacity by 6%, citing weak demand. Virgin has over $1 billion in cash and flexibility to manage liquidity pressures, with its next major debt maturity not until October 2021. The airline's shares have plummeted to record lows, and industry estimates suggest passenger revenue could drop by up to $113 billion this year.

site_title: Qantas Airways to backpay underpaid staff
summary: Qantas Airways has agreed to backpay its underpaid staff, totaling A$7.1 million to 638 employees, after self-reporting non-compliance with employment contracts. The airline made a court-enforceable undertaking to make the payments, which will be verified by an independent expert. Three further pay audits will also be conducted to benefit current and future employees. This move comes amid underpayments scandals affecting several major Australian companies, with the federal government planning to introduce laws to criminalize "wage theft".

images.alt_text: An Australian industrial regulator on Friday said the country's biggest airline Qantas Airways had agreed to backpay its staff millions of dollars after self-reporting non-compliance with employment contracts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Keppel, Khong Guan, Guocoland, Lendlease Reit
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: SIA shares fell S$0.34 to close at S$7.34 after announcing flight cuts due to tepid travel demand. Keppel Corporation remains on track for a voluntary pre-conditional partial offer. Khong Guan reported a widening net loss of S$636,000 for the half year. Guocoland established a new subsidiary in China with no expected financial impact. Lendlease Reit offered a 0.2 month rent rental waiver amid the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Khong Guan posts H1 loss of S$636,000
summary: Khong Guan, a Singaporean biscuit maker, reported a net loss of S$636,000 for the half year ended Jan 31, 2020, with revenue slipping 8.7% to S$29,078. The loss per share remained unchanged at 2.46 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to lower sales and higher costs due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Directors expect another challenging environment for the second half of the year.

site_title: Big money trying to flee small markets crushes Asian stocks
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Thursday as foreign investors withdrew $4 billion from South-east Asian markets, with Thailand's benchmark SET Index dropping 12% and reaching its worst level since 2006. The selloff was exacerbated by US President Trump's travel ban from Europe and the rapid spread of the coronavirus. Investors are now trading near their lowest in 14 years relative to global developed peers, with the MSCI Asean Index's valuation below two-standard deviations of its 10-year average.

site_title: US dollar wins out as pandemic drives rush for liquid assets
summary: The US dollar strengthened against most currencies amid the coronavirus pandemic, with investors seeking the world's most liquid currency. The euro declined 0.72% against the dollar, while the pound and Swiss franc also fell. The European Central Bank's failure to cut interest rates disappointed investors, who had expected a stimulus package. The Federal Reserve provided $1.5 trillion in short-term liquidity to calm financial markets, but investors expect further action. The dollar shortage, indicated by blowout swap spreads, has led to a surge in the greenback's value.

site_title: Sasseur Reit to resume full operations on Sunday with reopening of last 2 China malls
summary: Sasseur Reit, a real estate investment trust, will resume full operations on March 15 after its two remaining China outlet malls reopen. The malls had closed on January 26 due to the novel coronavirus outbreak and were initially expected to be closed for several months. However, the Reit's manager stated that the financial impact of the closure should be minimal, with the Reit continuing to receive a stable income component. This comes after the Reit's units closed down 5.6% on Thursday following the reopening of its previous two malls.

site_title: Stock plunge in Asia continues after Wall Street's worst session since 1987; STI down 5.1%
summary: Asian stocks plummeted further on Friday, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) down 5.1% after Wall Street's worst session since 1987. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 10%, the S&P 500 fell 9.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 9.4%. The MSCI All-Country World Index is now down over 25% this year, with safe-havens like gold trading lower. Economists expect a larger support package in Singapore to combat the economic strain from the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Apple says reopening all its branded stores in China
summary: Apple is reopening all 42 of its branded stores in China, more than a month after they were closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. The stores will reopen on Friday with varying opening times. This decision comes after the company initially announced the closure in early February.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc is reopening all 42 of its branded stores in China on Friday, a company spokesman said, more than a month after they were shut in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: KPMG audit finds no manipulation in Wirecard's financial statements
summary: KPMG's audit of Wirecard AG found no discrepancies in its financial statements for 2016-2018, dismissing allegations of account manipulation. The German payments company had hired KPMG to address claims made by the Financial Times. The audit's results do not require any corrections to Wirecard's annual financial statements, according to the company's statement.

site_title: Hang Seng: Index plunges into bear market
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted into a bear market, falling 7.4% on Friday and dropping below 23,339.94 points, a 20% decline from its January high of 29,174.92 points. The global rout triggered by the coronavirus pandemic led to the market's downturn. This marks the first time the Hang Seng Index has entered a bear market since 2016.

site_title: France closes schools, urges elderly to stay home over coronavirus
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron announced the indefinite closure of schools, creches, and universities to combat the coronavirus, which has killed 61 people and infected nearly 2,900 in France. Macron urged people over 70 and those with chronic diseases to stay home, while local elections scheduled for Sunday will proceed as planned. The government will provide compensation to affected employees and delay tax payments. Macron emphasized the need for Europe to "react fast and strongly" to the economic impact of the crisis.

site_title: France to allow some Huawei gear in its 5G network: sources
summary: France is set to allow some Huawei equipment in its 5G network, despite US calls to exclude the Chinese telecoms giant. The French cybersecurity agency, ANSSI, has decided to approve the use of non-core Huawei gear, citing lower surveillance risks. This decision is seen as a compromise, as French authorities aim to balance security concerns with economic interests. France is following Britain's lead, and its decision may influence neighboring Germany's approach to Huawei.

site_title: Top French chef heads to Asia without telling customers
summary: Michelin-star chef Thierry Drapeau unexpectedly closed his Logis de La Chabotterie restaurant in France without warning prepaid customers and left for Asia. Drapeau cited a desire to be with his family in Vietnam to see his son grow up, but failed to reimburse customers or notify regional authorities. The closure left customers, including one woman who had paid months in advance to celebrate her 50th birthday, feeling "betrayed" and forced to find alternative dining options. Drapeau plans to open new restaurants in Bangkok and Cambodia.

site_title: STI plummets 6.2% in early Friday trade, tracking global rout
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 6.2% in early Friday trade, reaching a new 52-week low, amid a global rout. The benchmark index fell 132.56 points to 2,546.08, with major banks like DBS, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank also experiencing significant declines. The global sell-off was attributed to a lack of a strong US fiscal response and the latest travel ban for arrivals from Europe to the US, with market strategist Pan Jingyi warning of sustained volatility for the next month.

site_title: Temasek's plans for Keppel still intact
summary: Temasek's planned acquisition of an additional 30.55% stake in Keppel Corp remains intact despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on global economies and stock markets. The offer price of S$7.35 per share, representing a 26% premium over the last traded price, remains unchanged.
