The Australian government's economic stimulus plan provided little relief, and energy and mining stocks were hit hard, with some stocks losing up to 4.9%.

site_title: Oil prices fall more than 3% after Trump's coronavirus address
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a 30-day travel ban from Europe to the US over the coronavirus pandemic, causing oil prices to plummet over 3% with West Texas Intermediate slipping to under $32 a barrel and Brent crude falling to $34 a barrel. The ban, set to take effect Friday, follows a week of turmoil in crude markets due to a price war between Saudi Arabia and the UAE. The move was seen as a potential solution to the crisis, but its effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: Asian stocks roiled after Covid-19 fears hit fever pitch, STI down 3.7%
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index in Singapore falling 3.7% to its lowest level since 2016, amid fears of a Covid-19 pandemic and a US travel ban from Europe. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 5.9% on Wall Street, while the Nikkei 225 in Japan and the Kospi index in South Korea also fell sharply. Analysts expect a volatile session with Treasury yields rising, and the market may not yet be pricing in a worst-case scenario from the double whammy of economic and oil price shocks.

images.alt_text: The sharp selloffs in Asian equities resumed on Thursday, after the World Health Organization labelled Covid-19 a pandemic and the US temporarily halted travel from Europe for 30 days.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades Uni-Asia to 'neutral', halves target price to S$0.62
summary: KGI Securities downgraded Uni-Asia Group to "neutral" and reduced its target price to S$0.62 due to the COVID-19 outbreak and weaker macroenvironment, which will impact the group's business segments in bulk shipping, Hong Kong property investments, and Japan hotels. Despite a stronger balance sheet and proactive asset recycling, the brokerage expects significant challenges in 2020, citing a negative impact on all business segments, including a 7.1% decline in Japan's economy and potential delays in the Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Nearly US$640b coal investments undercut by cheap renewables: research
summary: Research by the Carbon Tracker Initiative found nearly $640 billion of coal investment worldwide is at risk due to cheaper renewables. Institutional investors are withdrawing from fossil fuel companies as emissions targets discourage coal use. The report analyzed 95% of coal plants worldwide, highlighting the economics of operating, under construction, or planned plants. This trend suggests that coal investments may become stranded as renewable energy becomes more cost-competitive.

site_title: Singapore stocks sink amid global rout; STI opens 1.4% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% to 2,744.53 in early trading on Thursday, tracking a global market rout. The benchmark index lost 79.3 points as banking stocks, including OCBC, DBS, and United Overseas Bank, declined. OCBC confirmed a staff member had contracted the novel coronavirus. The US Dow plunged 5.9% overnight, pushing it into a bear market, as the World Health Organization declared the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Shares tumble at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.01% at Thursday's open due to US President Donald Trump's ban on travel from Europe to the US, sparking concerns over the spread of the novel coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index dropped 759.11 points to 24,472.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.19% to 2,933.31. The decline was attributed to the escalating global pandemic and its impact on the financial markets.

site_title: Rio Tinto to pay ex-CEO's deferred bonus with interest
summary: Rio Tinto will pay former CEO Sam Walsh A$6.8 million in deferred bonus payments, including interest, after a dispute resolution process found that the payments should not be delayed. The payments were originally deferred in 2018 while a UK investigation into payments to a consultant on a Rio iron ore project in Guinea was ongoing. The dispute resolution process determined that Walsh's payments should be made, with two more payments due in 2020 and 2021. The payments relate to a portion of Walsh's long- and short-term incentive awards.

images.alt_text: Rio Tinto will pay out part of a delayed bonus to former chief executive Sam Walsh after a dispute resolution process found that the payments should not be held up, both parties said on Thursday.

site_title: CME to close Chicago trading floor on coronavirus concerns
summary: CME Group Inc announced it will close its Chicago trading floor after business hours on Friday to reduce large gatherings amid the coronavirus outbreak. The closure, which will be evaluated as more medical guidance becomes available, will allow for electronic trading to continue. No coronavirus cases have been reported on the trading floor or in the building. The move comes as markets experience unusual volatility, with some traders expressing concerns about the impact of the outbreak on the open-outcry market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 17.13 points or 1.19% to 1,426.70. Volume reached 156.53 million lots worth RM55.34 million. The market saw a loss of 305 to 51 gainers.

site_title: AIA Group's new business value growth slows to 6% in 2019 on Hong Kong protests
summary: AIA Group reported a 6% increase in new business value in 2019, slower than expected, due to Hong Kong protests. The company's new business value rose to $4.15 billion, down from $3.96 billion in 2018. This marks a significant slowdown from the 20% annual growth in new business value seen in recent years. The Hong Kong-based insurer attributed the decline to the prolonged protests, which impacted sales.

site_title: Australia unveils stimulus to offset coronavirus impact
summary: Australia's government has unveiled a $17.6 billion economic stimulus package to combat the coronavirus outbreak, which is expected to prevent the country from entering its first recession in nearly 30 years. The package includes funding for the health system, small businesses, and casual workers, and is valued at 1.2% of GDP. Ratings agency S&P had previously predicted a recession in the first half of 2020, but the government's strong fiscal position has allowed for stimulus without threatening its 'AAA' credit rating.

site_title: AIA Singapore operating profit rises 6% to US$583m in 2019
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 6% rise in operating profit after tax to US$583 million in 2019, driven by underlying premium growth and an increase in active agents. The company's value of new business (VONB) was marginally lower due to competition in the pricing of single-premium high net worth products. Globally, AIA's VONB was up 6% in 2019, but growth slowed in Hong Kong due to anti-government protests.

site_title: OCBC says one of its staff diagnosed with novel coronavirus
summary: OCBC Bank confirmed one of its staff members, working at OCBC Centre, was diagnosed with the novel coronavirus on Tuesday. The staff member had last been in the office on February 28 and has been working from home since falling ill. Employees who had close contact with the colleague are also working remotely, and the office has been thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. OCBC is providing support to the affected staff and their family, wishing for a speedy recovery.

site_title: Saudi Arabia provisionally charters 19 supertankers, six to US as global oil price war heats up
summary: Saudi Arabia has provisionally chartered 19 supertankers, with six set to transport 12 million barrels of Saudi crude to the US, amid a global oil price war. The shipments, driven by Saudi state oil giant Aramco's plan to boost oil supplies to 12.3 million barrels per day, are expected to increase from recent years. This move comes after Saudi Arabia slashed prices for its crude to customers worldwide following Opec's failure to reach an agreement with Russia to deepen production cuts.

site_title: Tom Hanks, wife announce positive test for coronavirus
summary: Tom Hanks and his wife Rita Wilson have both tested positive for coronavirus, according to a statement posted by Hanks on social media. The couple, 63 and 59 respectively, came down with a fever while in Australia and will now be isolated and monitored. They announced the positive test in an effort to raise awareness about the virus and encourage others to take precautions.

site_title: Coronavirus leads Warren Buffett to mull changes to Berkshire Hathaway shareholder weekend
summary: Warren Buffett, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, plans to wait until around April 1 to decide if the coronavirus pandemic will disrupt the company's annual shareholder weekend in Omaha, Nebraska, scheduled for May 1-3. Buffett's "preference" is to evaluate the situation and recommendations of health officials before making a decision. The weekend, which includes Berkshire's annual meeting, typically attracts 40,000 or more people, but the pandemic has raised concerns about public safety, with elderly people considered most at risk.

site_title: China's virus cases fall, but more imported from abroad
summary: China's coronavirus cases have dropped to a new low, with 8 new cases reported in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak. The country's death toll has risen to 3,169, with 11 new fatalities. Despite this, China imported more cases from abroad, further complicating the situation. The decline in domestic cases is a positive sign, but the ongoing global pandemic remains a concern.

site_title: Banks urge EU to ease capital rules to fight coronavirus fallout
summary: Europe's banks have called on EU authorities to ease capital rules to help businesses struggling due to the coronavirus epidemic. The European Banking Federation proposed a three-stage plan, including a "moratorium tool" to keep cash flowing to sound borrowers, easing counter cyclical buffers, and allowing banks to divert excess liquidity to non-financial businesses. The plan aims to help banks work constructively with borrowers and avoid a liquidity crisis. EU regulators are under pressure to take action, following the ECB's meeting on Thursday and the Bank of England's emergency interest rate cut.

site_title: Airbnb refuses scores of guest refunds amid coronavirus cancellation
summary: Airbnb is refusing scores of guest refunds amid the coronavirus outbreak, despite travel warnings in several countries. The company's "extenuating circumstances" policy only applies to China, Italy, and South Korea, and hosts are responsible for setting their own refund policies. Guests who have canceled bookings due to the virus are being left with significant financial losses, with one family losing over $1,000. Airbnb has updated its policies to offer hosts more tools to grant refunds, but critics argue the changes do not go far enough to support travelers.

site_title: Asia's wealthy shrug off taboos, invest in end of life services
summary: Wealthy Asian families are breaking taboos and investing in end-of-life services, aiming to improve and destigmatize the industry. Ang Ziqian, a 38-year-old Singaporean, recalls being shamed for wanting to be friends with a funeral director as a child. However, a growing number of affluent individuals are now supporting the industry through investments and educational campaigns. This shift challenges traditional Asian social norms surrounding death and dying, and could lead to improved services and greater acceptance of the sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open more than 2% down on coronavirus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 2% on March 12, 2020, amid fears of the new coronavirus pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.24% to 18,980.22, while the Topix index fell 2.42%. The World Health Organization's pandemic declaration heightened concerns, contributing to the sharp decline.

site_title: Del Monte Q3 net profit more than doubles to US$6.7m on higher sales
summary: Del Monte Pacific more than doubled its net profit to US$6.7 million for the third quarter ended January 31, 2020, driven by higher retail sales and market share improvements in canned and carton juices, packaged fruit, and other key markets. Revenue rose 5% to US$555.3 million, while earnings per share improved to 0.09 US cent from a loss of 0.12 US cent a year ago. The company attributed the strong performance to its flexibility in allocating products to other markets and expanding e-commerce sales, despite experiencing softer demand in China.

site_title: OEL in non-binding pact to buy 51% stake in China healthcare firm
summary: OEL Holdings, a Catalist-listed firm, has signed a non-binding MOU to acquire a 51% stake in Shanghai Longjian Hospital Management Co. The acquisition is part of OEL's plans to diversify into the healthcare industry. The final deal amount will be disclosed upon entry of a definitive agreement. This comes after OEL's controlling shareholder Zhang Jian led a share placement to diversify into early childhood childcare and health education in Singapore. The acquisition is subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLT, FCOT, Q&M Dental, OCBC, StarHub, SPH, Prudential
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) and Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) have seen their merger approved by unitholders, with FLT rising 2.5% and FCOT 1.9% after the announcement. Q&M Dental Group partnered with two Chinese companies to set up a surgical mask manufacturing company, resulting in a 4.6% increase. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: UN chief urges all governments to immediately 'scale up' virus fight
summary: UN chief Antonio Guterres urged governments to immediately 'scale up' their response to the novel coronavirus pandemic, calling it a "call to action - for everyone, everywhere." He emphasized that governments must address inaction to change the course of the pandemic. Guterres' statement came as the world declared the pandemic, with the UN secretary general warning that inaction could lead to devastating consequences. He urged governments to increase their efforts now to stem the disease's spread.

site_title: Oil slumps as stock markets sink, while Saudi, UAE plan to boost capacity
summary: Oil prices plummeted 4% on Wednesday, falling to $35.79 per barrel, amid renewed weakness in the stock market and the World Health Organization's declaration of the global coronavirus outbreak as a pandemic. Major oil producers, including Saudi Arabia and the UAE, announced plans to boost production capacity to mitigate the price war. Brent crude fell 3.8% and US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 4%, with both organizations slashing oil demand forecasts due to the outbreak.

site_title: New York Fed boosts daily cash injections to US$175b daily
summary: The New York Federal Reserve Bank announced a daily cash injection increase to US$175 billion to guard against the coronavirus, boosting daily injections by US$25 billion. This move aims to support the functioning of funding markets as financial institutions implement business resiliency plans. The central bank also made an emergency cut in the benchmark borrowing rate to 1.0-1.25% to boost confidence. Economists predict a potential even larger rate cut on March 18, citing the ongoing spread of Covid-19.

images.alt_text: The New York Federal Reserve Bank announced on Wednesday it will increase daily injections of cash into financial markets by US$25 billion to at least US$175 billion to guard against the coronavirus.

site_title: Banks, trade associations can help SMEs understand risk-based approach to loans
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat suggested that banks and trade associations can help small businesses understand the risk-based approach to loans, enabling them to qualify for more favorable interest rates. He proposed online training for SMEs on this approach, which can help them lower their risks and benefit both lenders and borrowers. This comes as interest rates are still high compared to those given to bigger companies, and the government has enhanced the Enterprise Financing Scheme with a maximum loan quantum doubled to S$600,000.

site_title: Latin America steps up measures against coronavirus spread
summary: Latin American countries have implemented measures to slow the spread of the coronavirus, including isolating travelers from China, Italy, Spain, and France, and shutting down major sports events. Argentina, Colombia, and Peru have restricted travelers from these countries, with Argentina also considering barring travelers from Italy due to its close historical ties with the country. The region has only reported around 150 cases and two deaths, but the measures reflect growing concerns about the virus's spread.

site_title: Europe: Shares lose for fifth day as BoE stimulus fails to entice buyers
summary: European shares fell for a fifth day, closing at a 14-month low, after initial gains from the Bank of England's stimulus measures were reversed. The benchmark Stoxx 600 dropped 0.7% due to uncertainty over the coronavirus' economic impact, with US futures pointing to losses on Wall Street. The Bank of England's rate cut and massive budget boost failed to entice buyers, and regional stocks had briefly rallied before turning red.

site_title: Trump to make primetime address on US coronavirus response
summary: President Donald Trump will deliver a primetime address on the US coronavirus response, expected to announce short-term tax breaks and a stimulus package to help the economy. The address, scheduled for 9pm ET, comes as the US sees over 1,100 confirmed cases and 32 deaths, with experts warning that the virus could spread rapidly and cause significant economic damage. Trump has faced criticism for his response to the pandemic, and the address is seen as an attempt to counter criticism and steady market jitters.

site_title: Boeing reins in spending amid 737 MAX, coronavirus crises
summary: Boeing has suspended most hiring and overtime pay as it works to conserve cash amid the 737 MAX crisis and COVID-19 pandemic. The company has also canceled 43 MAX plane orders for 2020 and experienced a significant drop in plane deliveries. Boeing has already drawn down its $13 billion loan package and plans to limit travel and bar overtime except in critical cases. The company expects the MAX to receive regulatory approval to return to service at mid-year, but this comes at a highly uncertain time for airlines.

site_title: Tiger Woods elected to World Golf Hall of Fame
summary: Tiger Woods, a 15-time major champion, has been elected to the World Golf Hall of Fame as part of the 2021 class. The induction comes after a remarkable year, including his record-tying 82 US PGA Tour titles and his 15th major title at the Masters last April. Woods, 44, is the first golfer since Bobby Jones to hold all four major championship titles simultaneously. The 2021 class was chosen by the Hall's 20-member selection committee, and additional inductees will be announced in the coming days.

site_title: US considering ban on travellers from Europe over virus: top official
summary: The US is considering a ban on travelers from Europe to slow the spread of the coronavirus, according to a senior US official. Acting Deputy Secretary of Homeland Security Ken Cuccinelli said the idea is being weighed but not yet implemented. Italy, the worst-hit European country, is already pre-screening passengers on direct flights to the US, but Cuccinelli noted the country lacks resources to screen indirect flights. The largest threat to the US, according to a top health expert, is transmission from Europe, where cases are coming from.

site_title: India suspends tourist visas over coronavirus
summary: India suspended all tourist visas until April 15 as the country attempts to contain the spread of the new coronavirus. The move comes after the World Health Organization declared the outbreak a pandemic. India will quarantine travelers arriving from seven virus-hit countries starting March 13 at the port of departure. The suspension begins at 1200 GMT.

site_title: Virus outbreak to push Cathay Pacific into H1 loss, prompt more capacity cuts
summary: Cathay Pacific has warned of a substantial loss in the first half of the year due to the coronavirus outbreak, which has forced the airline to ground over half its fleet and slash capacity. The carrier has already implemented a two-thirds reduction in capacity for March and April and expects to incur a substantial loss for the first half of 2020. Cathay chairman Patrick Healy has also hinted at potential job cuts as the situation unfolds, citing a 80% agreement from employees to take unpaid leave.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks take new plunge on virus fears
summary: Brazilian stocks plummeted 7.64% on Wednesday, with the Sao Paulo stock exchange suspending trading for the second time this week due to fears about the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The Ibovespa index dropped 10.1% earlier, triggering automatic circuit breakers, and oil and airline stocks were hit hard, with Petrobras and airlines Azul and Gol closing down nearly 10-15%. The Brazilian real fell over 7% to the dollar, and the country cut its 2020 economic growth forecast to 2.1% due to the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore employers commit to hiring disabled
summary: Over 100 Singapore employers signed the President's Challenge Enabling Employment Pledge, committing to hire, train, and retain workers with disabilities. The pledge aims to create a more inclusive workforce and follows President Halimah Yacob's call to shift workplace culture. Employers will receive support in employing, retaining, and training employees with disabilities. This year's President's Challenge will raise funds for initiatives that help persons with disabilities gain employment, including a programme that trains students from special-education schools to gain work experience.

site_title: Oil prices fall after Saudi Aramco told to raise output capacity
summary: Oil prices fell to US$36.81 a barrel for Brent crude and US$33.94 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate after Saudi Aramco was directed to raise its production capacity by 1 million barrels per day to 13 million barrels per day. The move aimed to boost output and counter losses from the previous day. Despite hopes for reduced North American production, worries about the economic impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak continued to pressure oil prices, with some predicting prices could drop to US$30.

site_title: China considers boosting state oil reserves
summary: China is considering boosting its state oil reserves amid the historic price crash, with top planning officials consulting with government agencies and energy companies about purchasing cheap oil. The decision is still confidential and Beijing has yet to decide whether to proceed. This move comes as the global oil market is heavily influenced by US President Trump's tariff policies.

site_title: Malaysia aims to resolve palm oil spat with India soon
summary: Malaysia aims to resolve its palm oil trade dispute with India within a month, following the swearing-in of a new Malaysian cabinet. The dispute began after India imposed curbs on palm oil imports in January, in retaliation for Malaysia's criticism of India's policy on Kashmir and a new citizenship law. Malaysia's exports to India dropped 54% last month. The Malaysian Commodities Minister plans to send a delegation to India as soon as possible to resolve the issue.

site_title: Amazon rainforest could collapse in 50 years
summary: Scientists warn that the Amazon rainforest could collapse in 50 years if 35% of its surface is cleared, leading to irreversible aridification, while Caribbean coral reefs may die off in 15 years due to global warming and pollution. Both ecosystems' tipping points are linked to climate change, with the Amazon's demise potentially affecting 10 million people and the coral reefs' loss threatening 90% of shallow-water species. Urgent action is needed to prevent these catastrophic changes, according to researchers.

site_title: Oil tanker costs double on Middle-East to Asia route
summary: The cost to transport oil from the Middle East to North-east Asia has nearly doubled since last week, with charter rates for supertankers surging to 95 points. This increase is attributed to the disintegration of the Opec+ alliance, leading to a flood of crude exports. The Middle East to China route, typically priced at a small premium, has seen a significant jump, with rates expected to rise to 100 points. This surge is driven by increased demand from Saudi Arabia and interest in floating storage, prompting tanker inquiries and bookings for vessels.

site_title: Prudential announces plans to list US unit Jackson National Life
summary: Prudential has announced plans to list its US unit Jackson National Life, following a call from billionaire activist hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb to separate the company's Asian and US businesses. The listing is part of Prudential's efforts to capitalize on the strong growth potential of its Asia business, with adjusted operating profit from the region increasing 14% to $2.993 billion. The Hong Kong business reported a 24% increase in operating profit, while excluding Hong Kong, the insurer's Asian business saw a 17% increase in annual premium equivalent sales.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' subsidiary UK Property Investment sold a London office building for £54.8 million, repaying a loan and recognizing an estimated net gain of £500,000. United Hampshire US Reit's Singapore IPO saw a 1.4 times subscription rate, while Lendlease Global Commercial Reit's tenant activated a business contingency plan amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Q&M Dental Group is joining forces with two Chinese companies to manufacture surgical masks.

site_title: Covid-19: Impetus to shake things up, try something new
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the need for businesses to be more agile and responsive to external shocks. Despite rapid technological advancements, many established firms struggle to keep up with changing demand and customer expectations. To address this, organizations should build a dual clock-speed approach, combining internal decision-making with real-time organizational intelligence. This involves giving decision-makers time to pause and reflect, as well as providing rapid access to relevant information. Companies like Anheuser Busch Inbev and Bridgewater Capital have successfully implemented this approach, but it remains a rare exception.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Misconceptions businesses have with regard to how cybersecurity is implemented
summary: A Money FM podcast discussed misconceptions businesses have about cybersecurity implementation. Common misconceptions include assuming cybersecurity is solely the responsibility of IT, believing that encryption is enough to secure data, and thinking that cybersecurity is a one-time fix. The podcast emphasized that cybersecurity is an ongoing process requiring continuous monitoring and employee education. Experts highlighted the need for a multi-layered approach to security, including network segmentation, employee training, and regular security audits. Effective cybersecurity requires a proactive and collaborative effort from all levels of the organization.

site_title: Italy shuts stores across country to fight virus
summary: Italy has shut all non-essential stores, except pharmacies and food shops, to combat the spread of COVID-19, which has claimed 827 lives in the country in two weeks. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte announced the drastic measure in a national address, urging Italians to make sacrifices to halt the pandemic. The country, with 60 million residents, is facing its biggest crisis in generations. The move is part of Italy's efforts to slow the virus's spread and protect its citizens.

images.alt_text: Italy on Wednesday shut all stores except for pharmacies and food shops in a desperate bid to halt the spread of a coronavirus that has killed 827 in the the country in just over two weeks.

site_title: Emergency rate cuts loom for Asia as novel coronavirus slams economies
summary: Central banks in Asia are considering emergency rate cuts amid the novel coronavirus outbreak and oil-price plunge. The Federal Reserve set an emergency 50 basis-point interest rate cut last week, prompting some Asian central banks to add liquidity. Analysts expect countries like India, South Korea, and Malaysia to deliver off-schedule rate decisions, with the outcome of the upcoming Fed meeting influencing their decisions. Several countries, including Thailand, New Zealand, and Vietnam, have scheduled rate decisions in the coming weeks, with some potentially making unscheduled moves to respond to global market pressures.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics set to break gender equality record
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced that the Tokyo 2020 Olympics is expected to have a nearly equal number of female and male athletes for the first time, with a projected 49% female participation rate, up from 34% in 1996. The IOC aims to reach full gender parity for the 2024 Paris Olympics. The announcement comes as the world struggles with the COVID-19 pandemic, with the Tokyo Games' participation rates potentially impacted by the virus.

site_title: Some economists looking at full-year Singapore recession as outbreak worsens
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have downgraded the country's full-year growth forecast to 0.6% due to the worsening Covid-19 outbreak and oil price war. Some now predict a recession, with a 30% chance of economic contraction. Analysts warn that industries like manufacturing, wholesale trade, and accommodation and food services may fare poorly, leading to a downward revision of forecasts. However, some economists believe the government's upcoming fiscal stimulus may have a positive impact, with 70% of respondents citing global financial easing as a driver of growth.

site_title: Singapore not ruling out using reserves for second support package
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said the government is considering using past reserves to fund a second support package amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The numbers are being crunched, and targeted and broad-based measures will be implemented to help firms. The support package comes as the global economy worsens, and the outbreak takes a turn for the worse since Heng's Budget speech.

site_title: Japanese firms dole out smaller pay hikes as coronavirus outbreak squeezes profits
summary: Japanese major firms have agreed to smaller pay hikes amid the coronavirus outbreak, with Toyota Motor Corp offering an 8,600 yen (S$114.28) monthly increase, down from 10,700 yen last year. This marks the first time in seven years that base pay won't rise, and steelmakers have also agreed to no base wage increases for two years. The move is seen as a response to the looming global economic slowdown and the impact of the virus on profits.

site_title: US: Dow ends 5.9% lower, enters 'bear market' on virus fears
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, entering a "bear market" as the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.9% to 23,553.22. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the Dow down over 20% from its peak. The World Health Organization declared the new coronavirus outbreak a pandemic, citing "alarming levels of inaction." The Dow's slide was fueled by event cancellations, company warnings, and travel-linked stocks.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks suffered another brutal rout on Wednesday, pushing the Dow into a "bear market" after the latest series of event cancelations and company warnings rattled investors.

site_title: US dollar resumes decline; sterling rebounds after rate cut
summary: The US dollar declined against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc due to investor fears over the novel coronavirus. The British pound rebounded after the Bank of England unexpectedly cut interest rates to combat the economic damage. Global central banks are scrambling to limit the economic impact of the virus, pushing investors into safe havens such as government bonds.

site_title: 'Precision education' can take off in Singapore
summary: Singapore is poised to adopt "precision education" to prepare future-ready workers in a rapidly changing job market. The government's SkillsFuture initiative has already seen nearly half the workforce undergoing training, and institutions like the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) are pioneering applied-learning pedagogy. With the rise of micro-credentials, SIT is introducing the work-learn continuum to its students, combining classroom learning with industry exposure. To ensure success, SIT and the government must strengthen workplace learning and create a safe space for innovative shifts in higher education.

site_title: Indonesia's Omnibus Bill: Focusing on a cure for economic ills
summary: Indonesia's government is pushing for the Omnibus Bill, a 1,000-page economic reform package, to revive the manufacturing sector and create jobs. The bill aims to simplify regulations, eliminate the negative investment list, and improve human resources. Despite public opposition from labor unions and environmental groups, the government believes the bill is crucial for attracting foreign direct investments (FDIs) and improving competitiveness. The bill's passage through parliament will be challenging, but the government hopes to find a balance between economic growth and worker and environmental protection.

site_title: Workplace deaths reach record low, but firms must not let guard down
summary: Singapore has achieved a record low workplace fatalities, with 39 deaths in 2019, a rate of 1.1 per 100,000 workers. However, the number of injuries, mainly from trips, falls, and slips, rose to a five-year high, with 629 major injuries. The government aims to reduce the injury rate to below 1 per 100,000 workers by 2028. To achieve this, companies must invest in training and reskilling for workers, particularly in the construction industry, and prioritize retaining experienced employees to maintain a strong safety culture.

site_title: Pimco to run Allianz Real Estate, forming US$100 billion unit
summary: Pimco, a US-based fixed-income manager, is taking over the management of Allianz Real Estate, forming a combined unit with US$100 billion in assets. The move aims to expand Pimco's real estate capabilities and strengthen its position in alternatives. Pimco, acquired by Allianz in 2000, will oversee the combined unit under its private strategies platform, which includes hedge funds, distressed debt, and real estate debt. This partnership is seen as a strategic move to provide customers a more comprehensive solution in real estate capabilities.

site_title: China netizens get creative in sharing censored article online
summary: China's censored article on a whistleblowing doctor, who warned of Covid-19 early, has been shared online through creative means, including screenshots, typos, and Morse code. The article, which featured an interview with a doctor in Wuhan, was removed from WeChat after disciplinary action. Despite censorship, the article has been widely shared among Chinese netizens, who are using various methods to circumvent the ban. This highlights the ongoing struggle for online freedom in China.

site_title: Why didn't Saturn eat Titan, its biggest moon?
summary: Saturn, the planet, did not eat its largest moon Titan as it did in classical mythology. In planetary science, simulations show that large planets like Saturn either consume their orbital retinue or multiple sizeable moons survive into adulthood. Unlike Jupiter's four Galilean moons, which were able to survive Saturn's gravitational pull, Titan is the largest and most massive moon of Saturn, and its survival is attributed to its unique composition and orbit.

site_title: Match Group backs US bill seen as privacy threat
summary: Match Group, the parent company of dating apps such as Tinder, has publicly endorsed a US bill aimed at curbing child abuse images online. The bill, known as the Eliminating Abusive and Rampant Neglect of Interactive Technologies Act (EARN IT), would force tech platforms to cooperate with law enforcement on encryption or risk losing immunity. Digital rights activists argue the bill weakens online encryption and erodes online privacy and speech. Match Group CEO Shar Dubey expressed support for the legislation, calling for a balance between safety and privacy concerns.

site_title: UK launches £30 billion stimulus plan after interest rate slash
summary: The UK has launched a £30 billion economic stimulus plan in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, with measures including a year-long suspension of a property tax, deferral of tax payments, and an extra £5 billion for public services. The Bank of England has also cut interest rates by half a percentage point to 0.25%, and introduced a new programme for cheap credit. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's new finance minister, Rishi Sunak, said the economy faces a "significant impact" from the virus, but expects a jump in public investment over the next five years.

site_title: Covid-19 now a non-event in Nordic countries
summary: The Nordic countries, including Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden, have been spared significant Covid-19 deaths, with no reported fatalities despite over 1,000 cases. The region's generally healthy population, universal healthcare, and low industrial pollution may contribute to its lower susceptibility to the virus. Most infected Scandinavians are young and relatively healthy, and the epidemic is still in its early stages, limiting the spread of the disease. However, experts warn that once the virus spreads to the general population, hospital wards and intensive-care units may be overwhelmed, leading to an alarming death toll.

site_title: European govts face uphill task to boost faltering economies
summary: European governments face a challenging task to boost faltering economies amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The European Central Bank and Bank of England have taken measures to provide liquidity and encourage cheap loans for small businesses. However, the region's GDP growth is already at a low 0.9% in the euro area, and there is limited room for maneuver. Analysts warn that a prolonged epidemic could have a disproportionate negative impact on the economy, and investors are uncertain about the market's recovery.

site_title: On the food trail
summary: Bangkok-based chef Supaksorn "Ice" Jongsiri's restaurant Sorn earned two Michelin stars, showcasing the evolution of Thai cuisine as young chefs redefine traditional dishes. Meanwhile, German-born Thomas Frebel's Nordic-inspired Inua in Tokyo earned two Michelin stars, introducing unique Japanese ingredients to local diners. Veteran restaurateur Martin Bem discusses the challenges of the F&B industry during the coronavirus outbreak. The article also highlights various food-related topics, including Japanese sake brewing and celebrity chef David Chang's food travelogues.

site_title: Gold rises as concerns over US stimulus dent risk appetite
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Wednesday, reaching $1,661.21 per ounce, due to concerns over the US stimulus package proposed by President Trump to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic. The White House and Congress negotiated measures, but there was no immediate sign of a deal, leading to a decline in risk sentiment. Lower interest rates and safe-haven demand also contributed to the gold price increase.

site_title: JPMorgan analysts say work-from-home may hit funding markets
summary: JPMorgan analysts warn that the COVID-19 outbreak may worsen trading conditions for US Treasuries, potentially flooding dealer-banks with $200 billion in government debt and challenging the repurchase market. This could lead to extreme moves in reaction to unexpected developments and worsen market volatility. The analysts point to signs of strain in the US Treasury market, including wider bid-ask spreads and higher transaction costs. Smaller operators in the repo market may be more vulnerable to disruption, potentially leading to higher liquidity-transaction costs.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents, volumes up in February: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental market saw a 0.1% month-on-month increase in February, with condo rents up 3.3% year-on-year. HDB rents rose 0.4% from January and 2.4% year-on-year. Volumes rebounded, with condo rentals increasing 20.6% and HDB volumes rising 11.5% from January. The rise in rental volumes may be attributed to tenants returning after the Chinese New Year and foreign students renting accommodation for the new school term. The tight supply of private housing allowed landlords to raise or maintain rents.

site_title: Microsoft leads operation to take down botnet
summary: Microsoft led a coordinated effort with 35 nations to take down the Necurs botnet, a global malware network infecting 9 million computers. The operation, eight years in the making, targeted the group's domain names and disrupted its ability to send spam emails and conduct stock market scams. Microsoft's Digital Crimes Unit worked with authorities to identify and neutralize the botnet, but it's unclear if anyone will be indicted or face trial. The operation marked the 18th time Microsoft has taken down a digital criminal operation in 10 years.

site_title: Black-and-white houses exude character, but are not for faint-hearted
summary: Singapore's 500 colonial black-and-white bungalows, built between the early 1900s and before World War Two, offer a unique facet of the city-state's efficiency and luxury. However, these historic homes come with high maintenance costs, including termite treatment and roof repairs. Rentals for these properties can be steep, with some reaching S$22,000 per month. Despite the challenges, the homes remain sought after by expats and locals alike, who value their character and historic charm. The occupancy rate remains around 85%, with the Singapore Land Authority maintaining the properties through regular repairs and upkeep.

site_title: MOM's focus is to prevent large-scale job losses: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower, led by Minister Josephine Teo, aims to prevent large-scale job losses amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Employers with 10 or more employees must notify the Ministry if they implement cost-saving measures affecting employee salaries, starting Thursday. The measure encourages responsible implementation and allows for monitoring. Additionally, the ministry promotes flexible work schedules, time-banking, and training and upskilling to support businesses and employees. The government has also set aside S$4 billion for job support and wage credits.

site_title: How Europe should manage the virus-induced crisis
summary: A sharp financial-market correction has been triggered by the Covid-19 coronavirus spread across Europe and the US, prompting calls for active monetary and fiscal policy. However, a closer look suggests that such an approach might not be effective in preventing a recession. The epidemic's long-lasting impact is uncertain and will be shaped by its evolution, unlike previous pandemics. As the situation continues to unfold, policymakers must navigate the complexities of managing the crisis and its economic consequences.

site_title: IRAS clears air on tax rebate; most landlords to pass on rebates
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has clarified that all types of shops, including those in mixed-use developments, will qualify for a 15% property tax rebate for landlords. However, landlords have been slow to pass on the savings to tenants, with some citing that the rebate does not translate to significant savings, such as 18% on a month's rent. Some landlords, including Lendlease and Perennial, have committed to passing on the rebate, while others have offered flexible-payment schemes, rental rebates, or converting security deposits to banker's guarantees.

site_title: US consumer prices rise due to Covid-19
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in February, matching January's gain, due to rising food and accommodation costs. However, the increase is expected to decline in the months ahead as the novel coronavirus outbreak depresses demand for some goods and services. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, rose 0.2% in February, and underlying inflation was boosted by rising prices for apparel, personal care, and used cars. Despite the increase, financial market expectations suggest the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again at its policy meeting next week.

site_title: Adidas warns of Covid-19 hit to Q1 sales in China
summary: Adidas warns of a potential 1 billion euro (S$1.57 billion) drop in Q1 sales in China due to the Covid-19 pandemic, impacting 20% of its sales. Although business is picking up in other countries like Japan and South Korea, the company is also experiencing disruptions. China is a significant producer of Adidas' shoes and apparel, with nearly a fifth of its products made in the country.

images.alt_text: Adidas says it is "fully confident" about its growth prospects, and that the virus outbreak is but a temporary challenge.

site_title: WHO labels Covid-19 as a pandemic
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has labeled the COVID-19 outbreak as a pandemic, citing over 120,000 worldwide infections and 4,300 deaths. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that all countries can change the course of the pandemic by striking a balance between protecting health, minimizing disruption, and respecting human life. The declaration marks a significant escalation in the global response to the outbreak.

site_title: All hands on deck as Singapore tackles Covid-19 and economic challenges
summary: Singapore is facing significant economic challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with DPM Heng Swee Keat stating that the situation is worse than three weeks ago. The global economy is expected to slow down, with sectors like aviation, tourism, and manufacturing being heavily impacted. The government is exploring a second package to stabilize the economy, with a focus on supporting workers, small and medium enterprises, and the self-employed. Measures include wage support, tax support, rebates, and training programs to help businesses prepare for the upturn. The government is also working with banks to provide more flexible financing options and explore structural solutions to address the uncertainty.

images.alt_text: From left, the panellists at yesterday's roundtable: moderator, ST's Vikram Khanna; the Institute of Policy Studies' Faizal Yahya; Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat; OCBC's Linus Goh; and Ademco's Toby Koh.

"We're very happy with the announcement of the enhanced working capital financing loans. The outreach to our SME customers has so far come back with quite positive reaction to those schemes, so the uptake I think will start to grow quite quickly over the next few weeks." - OCBC's Linus Goh.

"There are a lot of SMEs who are still very healthy, who would actually still like to hire but they are holding back. Perhaps maybe in the enhanced Budget to have wage sharing or wage support for any new headcount that these companies are going to bring on board, that will encourage strong, healthy SMEs to start hiring right now, because there's going to be talent out in the market." - Ademco's Toby Koh.

"We just had a roundtable with small companies. From their point of view, they were already badly hit because of trade tensions before Covid-19. So the message would be: whatever you're doing now, just like the rental waivers, wage support, tax support, rebates, please do more." - Institute of Policy Studies' Faizal Yahya.

site_title: Economics and taxation in the digital economy
summary: Countries struggle to tax foreign corporations due to the shift in global trade, with technological advancements making it increasingly difficult to apply existing international tax frameworks. In response, countries are adapting tax laws to include digitalization strategies, affecting both online and brick-and-mortar businesses. This change aims to address the issue of taxing income earned by foreign corporations in their territories, which has become a pressing concern for governments worldwide.

site_title: STI fails to build on Tuesday's rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore closed 48.82 points lower at 2,783.72 on Wednesday, reversing gains from the previous day. Despite a strong Wall Street session, the STI failed to build on Tuesday's rebound, with 24 of its 30 components ending in the red. Oil prices also failed to rally, and the government's announcement of a second stimulus package had little impact on markets. Key stocks like Keppel Corp, DBS, and OCBC Bank also declined, with dividend yields at levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

site_title: SPH commences £10.6m asset enhancement initiative on UK student accommodation
summary: SPH has initiated a £10.6m (S$18.9m) asset enhancement project to refurbish nine UK student accommodation properties, including Capitol Students assets in cities like Plymouth, Huddersfield, and Sheffield. The project aims to meet changing accommodation preferences and maintain competitiveness. The refurbishments will focus on converting non-en-suite rooms to studios and upgrading rooms and common areas. The initiative is expected to strengthen SPH's presence in key locations with close relationships with local universities.

site_title: FLT and FCOT unitholders approve merger
summary: Reits FLT and FCOT unitholders have approved a proposed merger, creating one of the largest S-Reits listed in Singapore with a portfolio value of S$5.9 billion. The merger, first proposed in December, will be carried out through a trust scheme, with FCOT unitholders receiving S$1.68 per unit held. The deal is expected to be sanctioned at a court hearing, with the last day of trading for FCOT units set for March 31. Moody's has changed its outlook on FCOT's ratings to negative due to uncertainty over the funding structure of the acquisition.

site_title: Dow drops 4% as US equities sell-off deepens
summary: US stocks plummeted 4% in mid-morning trading on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1,000 points to 24,013.13. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 3.6% and 3.3%, respectively, amid rising concerns the coronavirus outbreak could slow the US economy, posing significant recession risk.

site_title: GIC-backed Trax buys Boston-based firm Survey.com
summary: TRAX, backed by GIC and Warburg Pincus, acquired Boston-based Survey.com for an undisclosed amount. Survey.com provides on-demand workers for retail tasks and offers app-based tech platform for merchandising insights. This is TRAX's fifth acquisition in less than a year, strengthening its merchandising services. The acquisition aims to enhance TRAX's capabilities in retail analytics and sales improvement.

site_title: Jefferies raises OCBC to 'buy', sees resilient earnings for banking trio
summary: Jefferies has upgraded OCBC to a "buy" rating, citing the bank's resilient earnings and dividend cushion, despite recent sell-downs in Singapore banks. The analyst expects lower margins and cut 2020 earnings forecasts for DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Dividend yields for the trio have hit levels not seen since the 2009 global financial crisis, with Jefferies estimating a 6.24% dividend yield for 2020. The analyst believes the valuation of OCBC discounts risks of mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore, including 3 RSAF servicemen
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases, including 3 RSAF servicemen in France for training. 8 of the cases are imported, the largest number in a single day, linked to a private dinner function at Safra Jurong. The total cases now stand at 178, with 96 recovered and 4 servicemen infected.

site_title: Weinstein gets 23 years in prison for sexual assault
summary: Harvey Weinstein, the former film producer and emblem of the #MeToo movement, was sentenced to 23 years in prison for sexual assault. Convicted of forcing oral sex on a production assistant and raping an actress, Weinstein's sentence was within the maximum total penalty of 29 years. He has asked for a reduced sentence due to his age and health, but his lawyers argued that he is a "sick man" with a good reputation who built careers and supported his family. Weinstein will serve his sentence in a maximum-security prison.

site_title: UK announces emergency rate cut, budget boost in two-pronged stimulus programme
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates by half a percentage point, the first since 2016, to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. This move comes ahead of the UK's first budget, which is expected to include more healthcare funding and further economic stimulus. The decision is part of a two-pronged stimulus program, also announced by the Bank of England, which includes measures to support bank lending and small businesses. The rate cut aims to prevent a recession and has been coordinated with the government to maximize its impact.

site_title: US: Wall Street slumps at open as investors doubt US response to virus
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Wednesday as investors doubted President Trump's stimulus plan for the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.65%, the S&P 500 dropped 1.96%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 2.49%. The decline followed concerns over the US response to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 413.53 points, or 1.65 per cent, at the open to 24,604.63.

site_title: Apac's PE AUM hit US$1.2t in 2019, accounting for one-third of world total: Bain
summary: Apac's private equity assets under management (AUM) reached a record US$1.2 trillion in 2019, accounting for one-third of the global total, according to a Bain & Company report. Despite this, dealmaking in China has slowed, dragging down total deal value in the region.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases include 3 RSAF servicemen
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases, including three RSAF servicemen who were in France for training. Eight of the new cases are imported, the largest number seen in a day. The cases are linked to various locations, including a private dinner function at a restaurant and two hospital staff who recently traveled to the Philippines. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 178, with 96 having recovered and three servicemen hospitalized.

images.alt_text: A total of 12 new Covid-19 cases have been confirmed in Singapore, including three Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) servicemen who were in France for training.

site_title: Asia markets end lower as risk aversion returns
summary: Asian markets ended lower on Wednesday as risk aversion returned, driven by concerns over the US economy's slowdown due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Straits Times Index fell 1.7% to 2,783.72, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 4% to 24,013.13. The decline was attributed to the oil price war and doubts over US fiscal measures.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde warns of 2008-style crisis unless Europe acts against Covid-19
summary: Eurpoean Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that a 2008-style economic crisis is possible unless Europe acts swiftly against the Covid-19 pandemic. She urged EU leaders to take urgent action, stating that a coordinated response could prevent a temporary shock. Lagarde indicated that the European Central Bank will take steps as soon as this week to mitigate the crisis.

site_title: Mnuchin says IMF, World Bank funds won't repay debts to China
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank will not use their funds to repay debts to China from countries participating in the Belt and Road Initiative. Mnuchin emphasized the need for transparency in countries' debts from the initiative, following concerns that some countries, like Pakistan, have taken on significant debt. The US is working with the IMF and World Bank to ensure transparency and prevent China from using these funds to repay its debts.

site_title: Indonesia records first death from coronavirus
summary: Indonesia reported its first death from coronavirus, a 53-year-old foreign national who died in critical condition at a hospital. The woman's home country's embassy will arrange to repatriate her body. Indonesia has 26 confirmed coronavirus patients.

site_title: Biden calls for party unity after big primary wins
summary: US President Joe Biden secured decisive primary victories in Michigan and three other states, narrowing the path for rival Bernie Sanders' fading White House bid. Biden's wins, powered by a broad coalition of supporters, put him on a path to face Republican Donald Trump in the November election. Biden called for party unity and appealed to Sanders' supporters, saying "we share a common goal, and together we are going to defeat Donald Trump." With 91% of Michigan precincts reporting, Biden led Sanders 53-37 in the state, and had a 762-619 delegate lead in the overall primary contest.

images.alt_text: The sweeping wins put Mr Biden on a path to face current president Donald Trump in the Nov 3 election. He now has the support of former presidential candidates Andrew Yang and Kamala Harris.

site_title: Vietnam is preparing for a revival of the 2018 golden period of IPOs
summary: Vietnam is preparing for a revival of its 2018 golden period of initial public offerings (IPOs) of state-owned banks. The country's commercial banks are expected to list on domestic stock exchanges by the end of this year, with the goal of raising US$26.3 billion over the next two years. Despite market challenges and liquidity crises, the Vietnamese government is optimistic about the IPO process, citing the success of Techcombank's 2018 IPO. The government aims to capitalize on the country's robust economic growth and low valuations of stocks to attract foreign capital and revive the IPO market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, up 13.36 points to 1,443.83. The index saw 4.5 billion lots traded worth RM2.9 billion, with 510 gainers and 397 losers.

site_title: Pint-sized bird may be smallest dinosaur yet: study
summary: Scientists have discovered a 100-million-year-old flying dinosaur encased in amber, potentially the smallest dinosaur yet found. The preserved skull of Oculudentavis khaungraae is 7.1 millimeters long, smaller than the bee hummingbird, a modern bird species. The discovery suggests that birds may have evolved miniature body sizes earlier than thought, with some researchers believing it to be a bird or a dinosaur, while others consider it a distinct species. The amber specimen retains its original color and morphology, providing a unique view of its features.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit's Singapore IPO 1.4 times subscribed
summary: United Hampshire US Reit's initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore was oversubscribed 1.4 times, with 848 valid applications for 10.3 million units. The international placement attracted 80.3 million units, drawing interest from sovereign wealth funds, institutional investors, and family offices, with some investors subscribing for over 5% of the units. Trading is expected to commence on Thursday.

site_title: StarHub unit buys 88% of Strateq's shares for S$82.1m
summary: StarHub has acquired 88% of Strateq's shares for S$82.1 million, strengthening its enterprise digital services capabilities in the region. Strateq, a Malaysian IT company, focuses on healthcare information systems, IT infrastructure projects, and data analytics. The acquisition aims to capitalize on digital transformation trends, following StarHub's creation of cyber security firm Ensign InfoSecurity. CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos sees growth opportunities in systems integration, cyber security, and data analytics.

site_title: Q&M joins 2 Chinese companies to establish mask-making company amid shortage due to Covid-19
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Q&M Dental Group joins forces with two Chinese companies, Hubei Asihubao Living Supplies and Guangzhou Pharmasen, to establish a surgical mask-manufacturing company amid a global shortage due to Covid-19. The joint venture will see the three companies contribute funds, with Hubei Asihubao holding 70%, Pharmasen 10%, and Q&M 20%. This move aims to reduce reliance on external manufacturers and safeguard against future supply shocks, despite having a "healthy stockpile" of masks for staff and employees.

site_title: More than 100 builders go bust in China as virus strains deepen
summary: China's property sector is experiencing a significant shakeout due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 100 builders going bankrupt in the first two months of 2020, according to data from Bloomberg. Smaller home builders are particularly hard hit as they struggle to secure funding from pre-sales of apartments. The sector's liquidity crisis is expected to worsen, with new home sales projected to drop by 15% or more this year, and mergers and acquisitions among real estate companies to ramp up in 2020. Policymakers have refrained from monetary stimulus measures, instead offering marginal support from local governments.

site_title: Citi Singapore increases paternity leave to 4 weeks
summary: Citi Singapore has increased its paternity leave policy to 4 weeks, doubling the previous two-week government-mandated leave, allowing fathers to spend more time with their newborns. The move is part of a global review of parental leave policies, aiming to drive greater gender equality and create a more inclusive workplace. The new policy applies to 74 markets worldwide, including Singapore, where mothers will continue to receive the statutory 16 weeks of leave.

site_title: Thailand files complaint against Lazada for overpriced masks
summary: Thailand's Commerce Ministry filed a complaint against Lazada for selling surgical masks at excessively high prices, with prices averaging 22-26 baht per mask, exceeding the control price of 2.5 baht. The ministry will take legal action against Lazada and its three online shops, with owners potentially facing up to 7 years in prison and fines of up to 140,000 baht. The complaint was filed after the ministry classified surgical masks and hand sanitizer as controlled goods to set price ceilings and control distribution.

site_title: Uber may temporarily suspend accounts of riders, drivers with coronavirus: report
summary: Uber may temporarily suspend the accounts of riders and drivers who have tested positive for coronavirus or been exposed to it, according to a report. The company has already offered compensation to drivers and delivery personnel diagnosed with the virus or quarantined for 14 days. Uber did not immediately comment on the report.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies Inc is considering temporarily suspending the accounts of riders and drivers who have tested positive for the coronavirus or have been exposed to it, CNN reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower as rally stalls
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Wednesday as a rally fueled by US economic support stalled due to ongoing concerns about the coronavirus outbreak's economic impact. The Hang Seng Index lost 0.63%, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.94%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index shed 1.48%.

site_title: SPH commences £10.6m asset enhancement initiative for UK student accommodation
summary: SPH has launched a £10.6m (£18.9m) asset enhancement initiative to refurbish nine UK student accommodation properties. The initiative aims to meet changing student accommodation preferences and maintain competitiveness. The refurbishments will focus on converting non-en-suite rooms to studios and upgrading rooms and common areas in eight assets across Huddersfield, Plymouth, Sheffield, Bristol, and Birmingham. The move is expected to strengthen SPH's presence in key locations with strong university ties.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open firmer
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, driven by strong Wall Street performance, despite the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The FTSE 100 index rose 1.98%, the DAX added 1.78%, and the CAC 40 jumped 1.72%. Dealers attributed the gains to apparent progress in curbing the outbreak in China, but warned that alarm at rapidly increasing cases in Europe and the US is a concern.

site_title: US consumer prices unexpectedly rise in February
summary: US consumer prices unexpectedly rose 0.1% in February, matching January's gain, despite the coronavirus outbreak depressing demand for some goods and services. The increase was driven by rising food and accommodation costs, while cheaper gasoline and lower airline fares offset these gains. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates again at its next policy meeting, despite the inflation data. The core consumer price index, which excludes volatile food and energy components, rose 0.2% in February, and underlying inflation increased by 0.2229%.

site_title: WTO says services trade growth slowing as coronavirus strikes
summary: The World Trade Organisation (WTO) reported a slowdown in global services trade growth at the start of 2020, with its indicator falling to 96.8 from 98.4 in September. The decline was driven by weakened air travel and container shipping, with financial and IT services also below trend. The WTO warned that the economic impact of the coronavirus could further decline the figure in the coming months, with global merchandise trade falling by 0.2% year-on-year in the third quarter.

site_title: Asia-Pac's PE AUM reaches US$1.2t in 2019, but China drags regional deal volume down: Bain report
summary: Asia-Pacific's private equity assets under management (AUM) reached a record $1.2 trillion in 2019, but deal value declined 16% to $150 billion due to macro challenges in China, including a trade war, social unrest, and yuan fundraising regulations. China's deal value dropped 38% in the same period, while exits fell 43% to $85 billion, resulting in negative cash flow for limited partners. The region's PE market is shifting towards more cautious and quality-focused funds, with larger and experienced firms benefiting from a "winner-take-all" dynamic.

site_title: Genting's RWS launches offers as tourism numbers expected to dip
summary: Genting's Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) is offering promotions to boost visitor footfall amid expected tourism numbers to fall 25-30% this year due to the novel coronavirus. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran warned Singapore is bracing for a "hard hit" to tourism. The Singapore Tourism Board forecasted the decline earlier, with RWS launching offers to counter the expected decline.

site_title: STI fails to build on its rebound, down 1.7% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.7% on Wednesday, reversing gains from a strong opening session. The benchmark index closed at 2,783.72 points, with 24 of its 30 components ending in the red. Despite a rebound on Tuesday, the STI failed to build on its momentum. The decline comes as investors weigh tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore tourism may be worse hit than expected by coronavirus
summary: Singapore is bracing for a potentially harder hit to tourism than expected due to the global spread of the novel coronavirus. The city-state is losing around 18,000 to 20,000 tourists daily, with tourist arrivals and spending forecast to drop 25-30% this year. The government has pledged S$6.4 billion in dedicated support, including a S$4 billion stabilisation package, and is considering an additional support package if necessary. With the economic fallout expected to grow, Singapore is preparing for a potentially severe impact on its tourism industry.

site_title: Hospital group IHH Healthcare offering on-demand coronavirus test
summary: Asia's largest hospital group, IHH Healthcare, is offering on-demand coronavirus tests in Malaysia, while also assisting Singapore's authorities in diagnosing cases. The tests are being performed at IHH's Gleneagles and Pantai hospitals in Kuala Lumpur and Melaka, which have been endorsed by Malaysia's health authority. This service aims to free up public hospitals to focus on treating infected patients. IHH's ParkwayHealth Laboratory in Singapore is also accredited to help test suspected cases, with the goal of providing a convenient and efficient testing option.

site_title: China to allow some companies to return to work in Wuhan
summary: China has allowed some companies in Wuhan to return to work, with businesses providing daily necessities and those crucial to global industrial chains permitted to resume immediately after approval. This move comes as the city continues to recover from the novel coronavirus outbreak. The Hubei provincial government has given the green light for these companies to resume work and production.

site_title: Three F1 team members tested for virus at Australian GP
summary: Three staff members from Formula One teams, including two from Haas F1 and one from McLaren, have been isolated at the Australian Grand Prix while tests are conducted for coronavirus. The team members showed symptoms, prompting self-isolation, and results are expected overnight. The event, scheduled to begin on Sunday, may be affected if the tests are positive, but the teams are operating as per normal schedules.

site_title: Biden opens an all-but-insurmountable lead over Sanders
summary: Joe Biden has opened a significant lead over Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential nomination, sweeping victories in Missouri, Mississippi, Idaho, and Michigan. Biden's campaign is gaining momentum, and he is now neck and neck with Sanders in the mail-in vote in Washington state. The two will face off in a debate Sunday, but the primary contest is likely to end soon, with Biden potentially clinching the nomination by April 28.

site_title: Giving support amid Covid-19 includes considering use of reserves "if necessary": President Halimah
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob said the government may consider using past reserves if necessary to support the public health and welfare amid worsening global Covid-19 conditions. This comes as the government works on a second stimulus package to address the economic impact of the pandemic. The worsening global situation, including rapidly spreading virus and crashing oil prices, has affected Singapore's economy, with many firms experiencing disrupted supply chains and tight cash flows.

site_title: Britain pledges £30b package to combat coronavirus
summary: Britain has pledged a £30 billion stimulus package to combat the coronavirus epidemic's economic impact. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak announced the comprehensive response in the country's first post-Brexit budget, citing a "significant impact" from the virus on the economy. Despite concerns, the government believes the economy is robust and public finances are sound. Sunak vowed to take further action if needed to support British people, jobs, and businesses through the crisis. The package aims to support British people, jobs, and businesses through this moment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government is working on a second stimulus package amid the Covid-19 outbreak, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement and seeks a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup predicts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index and Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter's suspension will be cleared in an ethics case.

site_title: Haji Lane, Arab Street shophouses up for sale with S$8.5m reserve price
summary: Two adjoining conservation shophouses on Haji Lane and Arab Street are up for sale via tender at a reserve price of S$8.5 million (S$3,864 per square foot) on a 2,200 sq ft built-up area. The properties, which are fully tenanted to retail tenants, have a land area of 1,078 sq ft and are located a three-minute walk from Bugis MRT station. Suitable alternative uses include takeaway food and beverage, serviced apartments, and students' hostels, subject to approval from authorities. The tender closes on April 7.

site_title: Tokyo Disneyland to stay closed through early April due to virus
summary: Tokyo Disneyland will remain closed through early April due to the spread of coronavirus infections. The park initially closed from February 29 to March 15, but will now stay closed until early April, citing government concerns about big gatherings and sports events. The closure affects thousands of visitors and staff, and the company has not set a reopening date yet.

site_title: Bank of England cuts rates to 0.25% to counter Covid-19 impact
summary: The Bank of England cut interest rates to 0.25% to counter the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on the British economy, the first rate cut since August 2016. The decision aims to bolster the economy and maintain its target for government bond purchases at £435 billion. Additionally, the central bank introduced a new term funding scheme for small businesses, offering four-year funding over the next 12 months.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down 2.3% on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 2.27% or 451.06 points to close at 19,416.06 on Wednesday, amid profit-taking and volatile trading. The decline followed investors' nervousness over the novel coronavirus.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit over 4-yr low as virus cases jump, US stimulus disappoints
summary: South Korean shares plummeted to a four-year low due to a surge in new coronavirus cases and investor skepticism over the US stimulus package. The benchmark KOSPI fell 2.78% to 1,908.27, its lowest close since February 2016. Foreign investors sold $582.81 million worth of shares, while the Seoul government's tightened rules on short-selling failed to curb market volatility. The country reported 242 new virus cases, bringing the national tally to 7,755 and the death toll to 60.

images.alt_text: The benchmark KOSPI ended down 54.66 points, or 2.78 per cent, at 1,908.27, the lowest close since Feb 17, 2016.

site_title: Govt 'not ruling out' use of past reserves for 2nd Covid-19 support package: Heng
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has hinted that the government is considering using past Covid-19 reserves to fund a second stimulus package. This option requires approval from the President and the Council of Presidential Advisers. Heng also mentioned that there is a "sizeable amount of current reserves" available within the current term of government.

site_title: Business travel sector to lose US$820b revenue on coronavirus hit: industry group
summary: The global business travel sector is expected to lose around US$820 billion in revenue due to the novel coronavirus epidemic, with China accounting for nearly half of the losses. Business travel to Asia has been severely impacted, with companies canceling or suspending trips to China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and other countries. The industry group estimates a US$560 billion hit in February, but the revised estimate is sharply higher. The virus has killed over 4,000 people, mostly in China, and disrupted businesses globally, with the airline and hotel industries also taking a significant hit.

site_title: JPMorgan analysts say work-from-home may hit funding markets
summary: JPMorgan analysts warn that the coronavirus outbreak could worsen trading conditions in US Treasuries, potentially flooding dealer-banks with $200 billion in extra debt as market participants rush for financing. This could disrupt the repurchase market, a vital part of the financial system, and contribute to extreme market moves. Liquidity may suffer, with transaction costs in benchmark Treasuries already higher than previous episodes of stress. The analysts note that smaller operators may be more vulnerable to disruption, particularly in overnight repo funding, which has been severely disrupted in recent weeks.

site_title: FTSE Value-Stocks Asean Index at its cheapest since Nov 2013
summary: The FTSE Value-Stocks Asean Index has reached its cheapest point since November 2013, with a 18.1% decline this year and a low price-to-book ratio of 1.06 times. This is due to stringent quality and valuation screenings, which have resulted in an average 13.3% decline for Singapore-listed companies in the index. Despite this, the index remains a contrarian investment option, with its 50 stocks selected based on fundamental factors such as return on equity and operating profit margin.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall 3.6% on Wednesday, slide into bear market
summary: Australian stocks fell 3.6% on Wednesday, entering a bear market after previously flirting with the threshold. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 20% below its Feb 20 record, driven by investor uncertainty over US stimulus measures for the novel coronavirus. The benchmark retreated after the Trump administration failed to unveil its plans as promised. The decline was led by banks, with the index previously rising on promises of fiscal packages in the US and Australia.

images.alt_text: Australian stocks have entered a bear market after toying with the threshold earlier this week.

site_title: Private equity giant KKR names Asia head of global impact
summary: KKR appoints Wong Chee-Wei as head of global impact for Asia, expanding the firm's focus on investing in companies aligned with the UN's sustainable development goals. Wong, a former managing director at Tailwind Capital and EQT, will source investment opportunities and support impact-related portfolio companies across the Asia-Pacific region. This move comes after KKR closed its first global impact fund at US$1.3 billion, which has executed six investments since its inception.

site_title: FLT unitholders approve proposed S$1.58b merger with FCOT
summary: FLT unitholders approved the proposed S$1.58 billion merger with Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) at an extraordinary general meeting, with 99.85% voting in favor and 99.78% approving the issuance of new units. The merger was first proposed in December 2019 and will be conducted through a trust scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Gold rises as concerns over US stimulus dent risk appetite
summary: Gold prices rose 0.8% to $1,661.40 per ounce as concerns over a US stimulus package to combat the coronavirus epidemic dampened risk appetite.
