The White House and Congress negotiated measures to bolster the US economy, but a deal was not imminent. Asian shares and US futures fell, while US 10-year Treasury yields drifted lower and the US dollar index fell. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are expected to cut interest rates to combat the economic fallout.

site_title: Adidas warns of big coronavirus hit to China sales
summary: German sportswear maker Adidas expects its first-quarter sales in China to drop by up to 1 billion euros due to the novel coronavirus. The company had seen a 85% year-on-year decline in business in the greater China area since Chinese New Year. However, it now sees a "slight improvement" in business activity, while shopper traffic is deteriorating in Japan and South Korea. Adidas forecasts a 6-8% increase in currency-neutral sales for the full year and a 10.5-11.8% rise in operating margin.

site_title: Cathay Pacific 2019 profits plunge, predicts losses from Covid-19
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a significant drop in profits for 2019, plummeting to HK$1.7 billion due to the impact of the Hong Kong protests and the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline warned of potential losses in the first half of 2020, citing the travel disruptions caused by the virus. This marks a reversal for the airline, which had previously recovered from losses in 2018 with a major overhaul. The financial performance and liquidity position of the airline are expected to be adversely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Recession odds spike as economists slash Singapore growth forecast to 0.6%: survey
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a recession with forecasted growth of 0.6% in 2020, down from 1.5% previously, according to a quarterly poll of 21 economists. The odds of an economic contraction are nearly 30%. Private consumption and non-oil domestic export growth are also expected to decline, with inflation outlook trimmed. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is set to review monetary policy in April, with analysts predicting a "zero-slope" neutral stance for the Singdollar's pace of appreciation.

site_title: Malaysia aims to resolve palm oil spat with India within a month
summary: Malaysia aims to resolve its trade dispute with India over palm oil within a month, said Commodities Minister Mohd Khairuddin Aman Razali. The dispute began after India imposed curbs on Malaysian palm oil imports in January, in response to criticism from former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad over India's policy on Kashmir and a new citizenship law. Malaysia's exports to India dropped 54% in February, and the country plans to expand exports to new markets such as Russia and the Middle East.

site_title: China approves 10.5b yuan airport expansion project in Qinghai province
summary: China's state planner has approved a 10.51 billion yuan airport expansion project in Qinghai province, with the airport expected to handle 21 million passengers and 120,000 tonnes of cargo annually. The project will be funded by a total investment of 10.51 billion yuan, with the expansion expected to boost the region's economic growth. The project's completion is expected to improve air connectivity in the region, supporting tourism and trade development.

site_title: Malaysia forms panel to combat economic impact from virus, oil price crash
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, has formed an economic action council to tackle the economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic and a global oil price crash. The council, comprising senior ministers and experts, will review the country's finances to decide whether to recalibrate the government's budget. A RM20 billion stimulus package will be re-tabled after a review, with the goal of ensuring targeted groups receive benefits and restoring investors' confidence. The government will also consider all options, including reintroducing the goods and services tax.

site_title: Novocall raises S$700,000 in seed funding round led by 500 Startups
summary: Novocall, a sales automation startup, has raised S$700,000 in a seed funding round led by 500 Startups' South-east Asia focused fund 500 Durians. The funds will be used to accelerate product and customer development. Novocall's conversational sales automation software is used by over 2,000 businesses in 42 countries, primarily in the education and travel sectors. Founded in 2018 by three Singapore University of Technology and Design alumni, the startup plans to expand in Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: Nissan plans to resume production at Hubei plant sometime this week
summary: Nissan plans to partially resume production at its Xiangyang and Zhengzhou plants in China, with the Hubei plant expected to resume production sometime this week. The decision comes after a halt due to the coronavirus epidemic, which has killed over 3,100 people in China. Production will resume based on supply chain and worker situations.

site_title: Australia's 'AAA' rating not under immediate threat from coronavirus: S&P
summary: Australia's AAA credit rating is not under immediate threat from a likely technical recession, according to ratings agency S&P. The agency believes the country's strong fiscal position will allow it to weather the economic shock. A widely expected fiscal stimulus package is unlikely to strain the country's credit worthiness, and the rating remains stable. S&P notes that Australia can maneuver at the current rating, indicating a high level of confidence in the country's economic resilience.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars tense with jury out on stimulus success
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced wild sessions, with the Aussie reaching an 11-year low of US$0.6312 and the kiwi hitting a low of US$0.6008, before rebounding to US$0.6686 and US$0.6448 respectively. Despite a rebound in stocks, investors are second-guessing the effectiveness of global policy stimulus, citing a political roadblock in Washington. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates, with a 25 basis point cut anticipated in April, and quantitative easing to follow.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as virus uncertainty casts a pall
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with some indices rising and others falling, as investors weighed the uncertainty of the coronavirus outbreak. The US market ended 5% higher on Tuesday, but struggled to sustain the rally, while safe-haven assets like the yen retreated. Crude oil prices jumped for a second day on hopes of policy responses to the outbreak. The US government has pledged "major" economic measures, with other governments also unveiling packages to combat the impact of the virus, which has killed over 4,000 people and infected over 118,000 globally.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents, volumes up in February: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents rose in February, with non-landed private homes and HDB flats experiencing month-on-month increases. Condo rents rose 0.1% from January and 3.3% year-on-year, with core central region rents increasing 0.9% and rest of central region rents decreasing 0.4%. The outside central region saw rents remain steady.

site_title: Olympic flame lighting ceremony to be held under virus lockdown
summary: The Olympic flame lighting ceremony for the 2020 Tokyo Games will be held without spectators due to coronavirus fears and a local outbreak in Greece. Only 100 accredited guests will attend the event in Olympia, down from 700 originally planned. The Greek health ministry has suspended all mass gatherings in the affected regions until Friday, amid a critical case of the virus in western Greece.

site_title: Brokers' take: Jefferies raises OCBC to 'buy', sees earnings, dividend cushion for trio
summary: Jefferies upgraded OCBC to "buy" due to its historically resilient earnings and dividend cushion, amid a recent sell-down of Singapore banks. The local trio's dividend yields reached levels not seen since the 2009 global financial crisis. Meanwhile, Singapore banks fell, with DBS down 48 cents to S$21.01, OCBC 22 cents to S$9.50, and UOB 57 cents to S$21.37.

images.alt_text: Jefferies Research on Wednesday upgraded OCBC to "buy" amid the recent sell-down on Singapore banks, arguing as well that the local trio have historically resilient earnings and dividend cushion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.88 points lower, or 0.13%, at 1,428.59 on Wednesday. The index had 112.88 million lots traded, with losers beating gainers 205 to 42. This comes as global markets react to new Trump threats.

site_title: Government working on 2nd stimulus package in face of Covid-19: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Singapore government is working on a second stimulus package due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The package will mainly aid businesses affected by the virus, with a focus on supporting workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and self-employed workers. The government aims to preserve jobs, provide training, and offer help for retrenched workers. The package will also include targeted and broad-based approaches to support specific sectors and boost consumer confidence. The economy's inter-linkage will be considered in the package's design.

site_title: Huawei granted another 45 days to do business with US companies
summary: The US granted Huawei a provisional licence for 45 more days to continue doing business with American companies. The licence, set to expire on May 15, was initially due to expire on April 1. This extension is aimed at preventing disruptions to rural areas in the US that rely on Huawei's equipment. The decision comes after the US expressed concerns that Huawei equipment may contain security loopholes that allow China to spy on global communications traffic, a claim Huawei has denied.

images.alt_text: The United States on Tuesday granted Chinese telecom giant Huawei another 45 days to continue doing business with American companies.

site_title: Bank Indonesia likely to revise down 2020 GDP growth
summary: Bank Indonesia is expected to lower its 2020 GDP growth forecast due to the global spread of the coronavirus. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the initial V-shaped effect on domestic economic growth is now uncertain, with the next policy meeting on March 18-19 likely to result in a lower figure. The central bank aims to stabilize financial markets, which have seen significant capital outflows of 40.16 trillion rupiah (S$3.89 billion) in the year to date.

site_title: Will oat become the king of plant-based milks?
summary: Oat milk is experiencing unprecedented growth, with revenues from its sale increasing 222% in the 12 months to April 2019, according to The Good Food Institute. The market is gaining popularity due to its nutritional and environmental benefits, including being low in calories, high in fibre, and requiring less water to produce than other plant-based milks. Companies like Oatly, Elmhurst, and Nesquik are entering the market, with oat milk expected to catch up to almond milk sales in the US, with some predicting it could become the leading plant-based milk option.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday following Wall Street gains; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday, driven by a Wall Street bounce, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,858.39 points. The gains followed a volatile US trade session, where stocks finished sharply higher. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 82, with 96.9 million securities worth S$167 million changing hands.

site_title: Lippo Group invests in payments startup MoolahGo in pre-Series A round
summary: Lippo Group has invested in payments startup MoolahGo in a pre-Series A funding round, providing an undisclosed sum to expand its services and enter new markets. MoolahGo will use the funds to introduce digital mobile payments and bring other services to market. This investment follows Lippo's previous investments in fintech OVO eWallet and other companies, showcasing its interest in the Southeast Asian payments industry.

site_title: Lum Chang sells freehold London office building for £54.8m
summary: Lum Chang Holdings sold a freehold London office building for £54.8 million, a gain of about £500,000 after tax. The company repaid an existing loan of £29.9 million secured against the property. The sale was part of the company's ordinary business operations, allowing it to unlock capital for reinvestment. Lum Chang shares declined 1.5 Singapore cents or 4.3% following the announcement.

site_title: China's new coronavirus cases rise on infections from abroad
summary: China reported 24 new confirmed cases of coronavirus infections on Tuesday, reversing a four-day decline, driven by imported cases from abroad. The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China is 80,778, with a death toll of 3,158. All new deaths were reported in the central province of Hubei, including 19 in the provincial capital of Wuhan.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB keeps 'buy' on Keppel but lowers target price to S$7.60
summary: RHB Research has maintained its "buy" recommendation on Keppel Corp, lowering its target price to S$7.60 from S$7.80 due to lower expected earnings from the conglomerate's offshore and marine unit. The current price represents a 26% discount to the target price. RHB analyst Leng Seng Choon noted the O&M unit's orderbook remains strong, and the property arm should support the conglomerate's share price and dividends.

site_title: South Korea reports 242 new novel coronavirus cases, total at 7,755
summary: South Korea reported 242 new novel coronavirus cases on March 11, 2020, bringing the country's total infections to 7,755. This marks the lowest rate of new infections in 11 days.

site_title: 60% of Asia's HNW not planning for succession
summary: More than half of Asia's high net worth individuals (HNWI) are not actively planning for succession, with 60% citing different priorities or "no perceived need" for it. Only 40% of HNWIs have enacted a succession plan or are planning for succession. The top challenges in succession planning include variety of solutions, competitive pricing, and training for relationship managers. External risks such as the coronavirus outbreak, trade tensions, and geopolitical risks are major influencers on succession planning.

site_title: Australia unveils A$2.4b health package to combat coronavirus
summary: Australia has announced a A$2.4 billion health package to combat the coronavirus, including A$1.2 billion spent this year, to set up fever clinics and offer free video consultations. The package aims to prevent and treat the virus in the coming weeks. The country has also extended its travel ban for Italy and has recorded 106 cases of the virus, with three deaths. The funding package is in addition to a multi-billion-dollar economic stimulus package the government is preparing.

site_title: City in Hubei province reverses relaxation policy, to continue transport ban
summary: Qianjiang city in China's Hubei province has reversed its decision to lift strict transportation bans, instead choosing to continue with strict traffic and personnel control measures to combat the Covid-19 epidemic. The city had previously announced plans to remove traffic checkpoints, restart public transportation, and resume work for firms. The reversal was made in an announcement on WeChat, citing the need to "win the epidemic." The decision aims to maintain control and prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Taiwan readies plans to stabilise stock market
summary: Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission has prepared plans to stabilize the island's stock market amid concerns about a coronavirus outbreak. Despite a 0.4% advance on Wednesday, Taiwan stocks have declined 8% this year. Foreign investors sold NT$54.6 billion of Taiwan stocks on Monday, the largest single-day outflow since the 2008 financial crisis. The commission's head, Wellington Koo, has not yet seen the need to implement the plans, but is monitoring the market's volatility.

site_title: Flawed coronavirus test strategy contributed to US spread: experts
summary: US health experts blame a flawed coronavirus test strategy and faulty test kits for allowing the disease to spread beyond the country's ability to detect it. The initial CDC test, which was the only one authorized, returned inconclusive results due to a manufacturing fault. It wasn't until February 29 that the FDA lifted a ban on state laboratories developing their own kits. Experts argue that adopting broader testing criteria and using a wider range of tests would have helped identify the first US cases and contained the spread.

site_title: More passengers leave virus-hit ship as Trump praises operation
summary: US President Donald Trump praised the operation to evacuate passengers from the coronavirus-hit cruise ship Grand Princess, stating it's "going along incredibly well". The ship, carrying 3,500 passengers and crew, docked in Oakland, California, with 21 confirmed coronavirus infections. Critically ill passengers were taken for medical care, while others, including tourists from Canada, disembarked. The operation is ongoing, with no further updates provided.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, extending the previous day's rebound, as traders await a US policy response to the coronavirus outbreak. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.27% to 25,459.96, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.17% to 3,001.76.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday morning, extending the previous day's rebound as traders await a US policy response to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: US mayor not on registry, can't vote in primary
summary: US Mayor Quinton Lucas, who has been in office since 2019, was unable to vote in the Missouri Democratic primary due to being unlisted on voter registration records. The mayor stated that this incident highlights the issue of voter suppression, particularly in Republican-led states. Lucas expressed frustration with the situation, citing that he has voted in person for himself multiple times in the past. The incident has sparked concerns about voter accessibility and the potential for similar issues affecting other voters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, BHG Retail Reit, Nam Cheong, Chasen, Dyna-Mac
summary: Keppel DC Reit's target price was raised to S$2.19 by KGI Securities, downgrading its call to "neutral" due to a fair valuation. BHG Retail Reit reopened two malls in China after temporary store closures. Other stocks to watch include Nam Cheong, Chasen, Dyna-Mac, and others, but the article does not provide specific updates on these companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as investors worry over stimulus
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.6% on Wednesday, falling to 5,843.70, amid concerns over the government's stimulus package, which investors believe won't be enough to lift the economy. The impending measures were expected to be worth around A$10 billion. The S&P/ASX 200 index rebounded 3.1% on Tuesday, its largest daily gain since the global financial crisis. The decline in Australian shares followed similar falls in US and Singapore markets.

site_title: UK to ramp up coronavirus fight in first budget of Johnson government
summary: The UK's new finance minister, Rishi Sunak, will deliver his first budget, pledging billions to fight the impact of coronavirus, with a focus on supporting the National Health Service and companies affected by the pandemic. The government will likely issue the highest amount of public debt in almost a decade, and the Bank of England may add its firepower to the stimulus efforts. The budget aims to direct investment towards poorer regions and relax the government's self-imposed borrowing rules to cope with the expected jump in coronavirus cases.

site_title: Moody's changes FCOT outlook to negative on funding mix for FLT merger; confirms FCOT's issuer rating
summary: Moody's downgraded Frasers Commercial Trust's (FCOT) outlook to negative due to uncertainty over its funding mix for the proposed merger with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT). The credit rating agency expects FCOT's leverage to increase to 8.8 times by September 2020 if the merger is funded by a shareholder loan. The negative outlook also considers the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on FCOT's earnings and cash flows. FCOT's issuer rating and other ratings remain unchanged.

site_title: Putin lays out path to staying in power
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin outlined a path to staying in power beyond 2024, as lawmakers approved sweeping reforms to the constitution. The reforms, which include a presidential "reset" allowing Putin to run again after his current term expires, were approved in the lower house State Duma. The proposed changes would annul previous presidential terms, potentially allowing Putin to stay in power until 2036. The reforms have been met with opposition, but Putin's approval ratings have been slipping due to economic struggles and living standards falling.

site_title: Air freight rates skyrocket amid passenger flight cuts, Chinese factory restarts
summary: Air freight rates have skyrocketed due to the grounding of passenger flights in Asia, leaving shippers scrambling for limited cargo plane capacity. China's air cargo capacity dropped 39% in February, with prices on China-to-US routes tripling to over $3.50 per kilogram. This surge benefits freight haulers and offsetting revenue losses for cargo-heavy airlines, while middlemen like logistics companies bear the costs. With Chinese factories resuming production, freighter arrivals have increased, and air charter requests have surged, particularly for moving goods from China to the US.

images.alt_text: Air freight rates are skyrocketing after the grounding of many passenger flights in Asia has left shippers scrambling to book limited spots on cargo planes as Chinese industrial production restarts, according to industry insiders.

site_title: SGX queries Nam Cheong about its ability to operate as going concern
summary: Nam Cheong, an offshore support vessel builder, has assured the Singapore Exchange (SGX) that it has sufficient working capital and financial resources to meet its obligations for at least 12 months from December 31, 2019. The company's board cited sufficient cash inflows from its chartering segment, proceeds from vessel sales, and no material claims from creditors. As a result, the use of the going concern assumption is deemed appropriate for its financial statement preparation. Trading in the company's shares should not be suspended, according to the board.

site_title: Japan's live music clubs emerge as new coronavirus transmission sites
summary: Japan's live music clubs in Osaka have emerged as a major transmission site for the coronavirus, despite the government's efforts to limit large gatherings. Four small music venues have been linked to 58 cases, with many of the infected showing minimal or no symptoms. The Osaka prefectural government has asked people who attended concerts at the venues to get tested, and several other cases have been reported outside the city. Experts warn that reducing person-to-person contact is key to preventing rapid transmission, and social distancing measures are necessary to mitigate the outbreak.

site_title: Australia High Court dismisses BHP appeal against tax office payment order
summary: The Australian High Court dismissed BHP Group's appeal against a tax office payment order of US$87 million. The ruling, made on Wednesday, stated that commodities acquired from Australian subsidiaries of BHP Group plc are subject to "top up tax" in Australia under controlled foreign company rules. The court's decision was made with costs, following a dispute over BHP's marketing arm's profits from the Mt Arthur mine in Australia. The ruling upheld the Australian Taxation Office's ruling in 2019, which BHP estimated was the total primary tax subject to dispute for the 2006-2018 income years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower despite Wall Street bounce
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, despite a bounce on Wall Street, due to investor focus on the new coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.86% to 19,696.07, and the Topix index fell 0.47% to 1,400.08. This follows a rebound in the previous session from recent sell-offs.

site_title: Japan, South Korea agree to continue dialogue on export controls
summary: Japan and South Korea agreed to continue dialogue on export controls, a day after their second round of senior-level talks. Japan imposed curbs on exports to South Korea of three materials used to make semiconductors in July last year, affecting the South Korean economy and global chip supply chain. The two countries will hold their next round of talks in South Korea, aiming to resolve pending issues, including Japan's export curbs.

site_title: Argentina: Exchange rebounds 8% after Monday's crash
summary: Argentina's stock exchange rebounded 8% on Tuesday, reversing a 14% drop on Monday, amid market concerns over the new coronavirus and oil prices. The Merval index rose to 32,832.26 points, following the country's first reported coronavirus death in Latin America on Saturday.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades Keppel DC Reit to 'neutral'
summary: KGI Securities has downgraded Keppel DC Reit to 'neutral' from 'buy', citing a fair valuation with a 3.66% dividend yield, and raised its target price to S$2.19. The brokerage expects better opportunities in the market and believes the Reit is fully valued, with contributions from a proposed acquisition in Germany. Despite concerns over supply chain disruptions and coronavirus fears, KGI remains confident in data centre trends and expects a rebound in 2020.

site_title: Japan's Ministry of Finance official warns on yen volatility amid virus fears
summary: A senior official from Japan's Ministry of Finance warned of high yen volatility amid fears of the coronavirus outbreak, citing the need for stability in currencies and the stock market. The yen surged 2.7% against the US dollar on Tuesday, prompting concerns of a rapid yen appreciation that could harm Japan's export-led economy. Japan announced a second package of measures worth $4 billion to cope with the economic fallout, while the US stock market rebounded positively to President Trump's economic measures. The official emphasized monitoring both upward and downward yen swings.

site_title: Close to tipping point, Amazon could collapse in 50 years
summary: Scientists warn that the Amazon rainforest is nearing a tipping point, potentially collapsing into an arid savannah within 50 years due to climate change and deforestation. The Caribbean coral reefs could die off in 15 years if global warming exceeds 1.5°C above preindustrial levels. These ecosystem changes would have dire consequences for humanity and other species, emphasizing the need for urgent action to prevent irreversible damage.

site_title: Spain steps up coronavirus measures to 'avoid Italian scenario'
summary: Spain has taken drastic measures to combat the rising COVID-19 cases, shutting down schools, suspending flights from Italy, and advising against non-essential travel. The government has banned indoor gatherings of over 1,000 people and closed down parliament for a week after a lawmaker tested positive. To support affected businesses, the government plans to guarantee medicines and provide credit lines. The measures aim to avoid the "Italian scenario" of widespread lockdowns, with the country reporting 36 deaths and 1,639 cases.

site_title: Air Canada halts flights to Italy over coronavirus
summary: Air Canada suspended daily flights to Italy due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision came after Italy banned public gatherings and restricted travel to combat the spread of the disease, which infected over 9,000 people in just two weeks. The last flight from Rome to Montreal was scheduled for May 1. Air Canada cited "health and safety" measures as the reason for the suspension.

site_title: UK health minister tests positive for coronavirus
summary: UK Health Minister Nadine Dorries has tested positive for coronavirus, citing self-isolation at home. She is the first British politician to be diagnosed with Covid-19 and has been in contact with hundreds of people, including Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Health officials are tracing her contacts to prevent further spread. The news raises concerns about the virus's impact on senior government figures, with calls to suspend parliament likely to increase. Finance minister Rishi Sunak is set to unveil emergency measures to ease economic pain from the outbreak in the government's first post-Brexit budget.

site_title: More cleaning, few visitors at Chicago trading pits due to coronavirus
summary: Chicago's trading pits see increased cleaning and reduced visitor numbers due to the coronavirus outbreak. The CME Group has restricted large tour groups and non-essential visitors, while also advising customers who recently visited Asia or Italy to avoid the trading floor. Exchanges aim to prevent disruptions and maintain market stability amidst the global spread of the virus.

site_title: Trump says no need for him to get coronavirus test
summary: US President Donald Trump said he would be happy to get a coronavirus test, but was told there's no need due to no symptoms. Despite having contact with lawmakers who self-quarantined, Trump feels "extremely good" and has no reason to test.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll soars in locked-down Italy as pace slows in China
summary: Italy recorded its deadliest day of the novel coronavirus outbreak, with 168 new deaths, as neighboring countries clamped down on borders. In contrast, China declared the spread in Wuhan and Hubei province "basically curbed" after a visit by leader Xi Jinping. Global markets rebounded on hopes of US economic stimulus, reversing their largest one-day losses in over a decade.

site_title: Experts urge low-risk virus patients not to overwhelm hospitals
summary: Experts warn that people at low risk of falling seriously ill with Covid-19 must avoid overwhelming hospitals by following social media campaign #FlattenTheCurve. The virus has already overwhelmed hospitals in Wuhan, China, with patients dying due to lack of beds and health workers exhaustion. Experts say 80% of infections are benign, and fatalities are mostly among the elderly with underlying health issues. To slow down the epidemic, hospitals must prepare for cases and the public must adapt their behavior to minimize the virus's spread, such as washing hands and self-isolating when infected.

site_title: Oil jumps 8% on stimulus hopes, spending cuts by US producers
summary: US oil prices surged 8% on Tuesday, reversing a 30-year low set the previous day, as investors anticipated economic stimulus measures. US producers, including Occidental Petroleum, cut spending, potentially reducing output. The news followed US President Donald Trump's pledge of "major" economic support and Japan's plan to spend over $4 billion on virus-related measures. The rebound in oil prices also came as investors awaited potential changes in US trade policies.

site_title: Coronavirus disrupts White House race as Sanders, Biden cancel rallies
summary: Democratic presidential hopefuls Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden have cancelled their election night rallies in Cleveland, Ohio due to concerns over the coronavirus, which has infected over 800 Americans and killed 28. The cancellations mark the first major US political events called off due to the virus. The decision was made after Ohio governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency and public health officials warned against holding large, indoor events. The primary battle between Sanders and Biden has nearly three months to run.

site_title: Europe: Shares end red as virus uncertainty dashes initial gains
summary: European shares ended the day down 1.1% on Tuesday, slipping further into bear territory, as the coronavirus outbreak continued to cast a shadow over the market. The pan-European Stoxx 600 marked its worst day since the 2008 financial crisis on Monday. Oil prices plummeted, exacerbating recession worries and pushing oil and gas stocks into their worst drop ever. Investors are increasingly cautious, with widespread disruptions from the virus appearing likely, and are now betting on an interest rate cut by the ECB later this week.

site_title: Singapore's condo resale prices and sales drop in Feb
summary: Singapore's condo resale prices and sales dropped in February, with prices falling 0.8% and sales volume decreasing 13.1% compared to January. The decline is attributed to the novel coronavirus, Chinese New Year seasonal slowdown, and supply of new units from recent launches. Year-on-year, private resale prices rose 0.8%, while sales volume was 10.9% higher than in February last year, but 7.7% lower than the five-year average.

site_title: UN Security Council endorses US-Taleban deal
summary: The UN Security Council unanimously approved a US resolution endorsing the deal between the US and the Afghan Taleban, allowing the US military to begin withdrawing troops. The agreement, signed in February, requires all foreign forces to quit Afghanistan within 14 months if the Taleban adhere to security commitments. The UN resolution also urges the Afghan government to advance the peace process through inclusive negotiations. However, some diplomats expressed concerns over secret appendices on terrorism that were approved without knowledge of their contents, amid a political crisis in Afghanistan with the double swearing-in of President Ashraf Ghani and his rival.

site_title: Trump economic stimulus measures face coronavirus reality
summary: US President Donald Trump is seeking agreement with Republican leaders on economic stimulus measures to counter the coronavirus threat to the faltering US economy. The proposed measures include tax relief for hourly employees and small businesses, as well as aid for workers in the gig economy. Trump has also unveiled steps to help airlines and the cruise industry, and waived copay charges for virus tests. However, economists and Democrats have criticized the potential payroll tax cut, with some arguing it benefits those who need it least.

site_title: Twitter, Elliott reach deal for Dorsey to stay on as CEO
summary: Twitter has reached a deal with Elliott Management, a hedge fund that owns a $1 billion stake in the company, allowing CEO Jack Dorsey to remain in his position. Elliott will add three new directors to the board and invest $1 billion in Twitter. The agreement sidesteps a potential proxy contest and gives the company more time to formulate long-term plans. Twitter also plans to use the investment to fund a $2 billion share repurchase program and grow daily users by 20% or more.

site_title: US: Dow up 4.9% as stocks end volatile session much higher
summary: US stocks surged 4.9% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 25,016.38, driven by anticipation of US stimulus measures and rising oil prices. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 4.9% and 5.0% respectively, closing at fresh records. The rally follows a day of volatility, with the Dow Jones experiencing its worst decline in over 11 years.

site_title: Japan's live music clubs emerge as new virus transmission sites
summary: Japan's live music clubs have emerged as a new transmission site for the coronavirus, despite the government's efforts to curb large gatherings. In Osaka, 55 cases of the virus have been linked to four small music venues, with 34 cases concentrated at one venue and 18 at another. The cases, mostly in their 30s and 40s, showed minimal symptoms. Authorities have disinfected the clubs and are urging people who attended concerts on specific dates to get tested. Experts say reducing person-to-person contact is key to preventing rapid transmission.

site_title: Financial firms step up fight against spread of coronavirus
summary: Financial firms worldwide ramped up emergency measures to combat the spread of coronavirus, with Barclays and BlackRock confirming one case each in their New York offices. Barclays advised staff who worked near the affected employee or had meetings with them to self-quarantine for 14 days. This move follows similar actions by other major financial companies. The spread of the virus poses significant challenges to the industry, highlighting the need for swift and decisive action to mitigate its impact.

site_title: Covid-19: A stress test for public health systems
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis that has exposed weaknesses in public health systems worldwide. The World Health Organization (WHO) and international institutions, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), have been criticized for their lack of preparedness and response. China, which was initially hit hard by the outbreak, has made significant progress in controlling the spread of the virus. However, other countries, including the US, Italy, and South Korea, are struggling with higher death rates and economic disruption. The pandemic highlights the need for increased investment in national health systems and a more coordinated global response to prevent future crises.

site_title: Hyflux saga: Judge's bid for escrow funds to pay retail investors' advisers finds no takers
summary: A Singaporean judge rejected a proposal to create an escrow fund to pay advisers of 34,000 retail investors in Hyflux's debt, citing a lack of creditors willing to contribute. The judge criticized the current structure for providing advice to retail investors in the event of a liquidation, stating it is "wholly inappropriate." The Securities Investors Association Singapore's advisers, including PricewaterhouseCoopers and Drew & Napier, expressed opposition to the escrow suggestion. Hyflux will proceed with a scheme meeting on April 22 to address its debt issues, which may impact its cash flow situation.

site_title: BHP in 'good shape' to seize any M&A opportunities: chairman
summary: BHP Group Chairman Ken MacKenzie stated that the company is in "very good shape" to seize M&A opportunities due to the global coronavirus epidemic. Despite potential supply chain disruption, BHP is prepared to act if acquisition opportunities arise. The company's global demand forecast may be impacted by the epidemic, but MacKenzie remains optimistic about its financial position.

site_title: Three warning signs that your stock could go bust
summary: A seasoned investor shares three warning signs that a stock may go bust, citing personal experience and industry trends. These signs include excessive, crippling debt, absence of free cash flow, and persistent deterioration in financial performance. Investors should scrutinize these red flags to protect themselves from heavy losses and avoid sinking ships. By monitoring their portfolios and accounting for both risks and rewards, investors can make informed decisions and potentially avoid costly mistakes.

site_title: Want to make a Gulf dealmaker laugh? Ask when's the next IPO
summary: Dealmakers in the Gulf region are bracing for uncertainty amid a market rout caused by the collapse of the Opec+ alliance and a decline in oil prices. Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has faced criticism for his handling of the crisis, with some warning that the region's troubles could undermine economic-liberalisation efforts that depend on foreign capital. The fallout from the oil-price war and coronavirus shocks risk setting off a vicious circle, with investment banking fees likely to be collateral damage.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Eco-friendly hotels for the future
summary: Claressa Monteiro discusses eco-friendly hotels for the future on Money FM podcast. She speaks with Marcus Hanna, general manager at Fairmont Singapore, about the hotel's aquaponics project and the Accor Group's plan to eliminate plastic use within their hotels. The Accor Group aims to work towards a sustainable future, reducing plastic waste and promoting environmentally-friendly practices in their operations. This initiative is part of their commitment to corporate purpose and a zero-waste future.

site_title: Veteran businessmen venturing into startup space
summary: Veteran businessmen, typically in their 50s and 60s, are venturing into the startup space, breaking the stereotype of young entrepreneurs. A study found that 37.5% of startup founders in Singapore are in the 26-35 age bracket, with 12.1% in the 46-55 age range. Industry veterans cite their experience and industry connections as advantages, allowing them to bring a deep understanding of the industry and attract investors. This trend is seen as beneficial, as mature founders have a higher likelihood of success and can bring credibility to their startups.

site_title: BHG Retail Reit reopens 2 malls in China earlier closed due to Covid-19 situation
summary: BHG Retail Reit reopened two malls in Anhui, China, Hefei Mengchenglu Mall and Hefei Changjiangxilu Mall, after temporarily closing certain stores due to the coronavirus outbreak. The malls reopened on Tuesday with approval from local authorities, while other properties remain open on shortened hours. The company is offering relief arrangements to tenants and taking proactive measures to prevent the spread of the virus. Despite the "near-term headwind," BHG Retail Reit's long-term strategy is well-positioned to benefit from China's rising income.

site_title: Heineken to expand brewing plant in Brazil, to boost production by 75 per cent
summary: Heineken to invest 865 million reais (S$254.7 million) in its Ponta Grossa brewing plant in Brazil, a 75% increase in production capacity. The expansion will focus on Heineken and Amstel brands, solidifying its position as the third-largest brewing facility in Parana state, its most important market worldwide. The investment will be made this year and next, with the goal of boosting production and competitiveness in the Brazilian market.

site_title: ComfortDelGro buys Liverpool taxi operator for £7m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, a Singapore-based taxi operator, has acquired Liverpool City region's third-largest taxi and private-hire operator, AST, for £7m (S$12.5m). This is ComfortDelGro's first acquisition since April 2019, and it brings the company's total UK investment to S$446.6m. The deal is expected to have a minimal impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share. Analysts see this as a small but strategic move to grow ComfortDelGro's overseas presence, with debt headroom to fund further acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: US dollar rebounds as traders cling to stimulus hopes
summary: The US dollar rebounded on Tuesday after huge losses against the yen and the euro, driven by hopes of coordinated stimulus to combat the economic impact of Covid-19. The dollar regained some of Monday's losses, but the Japanese yen remained below 105 yen per dollar. Investors are optimistic about policymakers' response to the economic downturn, with the US dollar rising against other major currencies. The rebound comes ahead of GDP data and other economic indicators, which may provide further insight into the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Covid-19 forces Qantas to cut capacity, delay A350 order as CEO gives up pay for this year
summary: Qantas, Australia's largest airline, has cut its international capacity by nearly 25% and delayed an order for Airbus A350 planes due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline is also cancelling a planned A$150m share buyback and reducing staff pay. Qantas CEO Alan Joyce will forgo his salary for the year, and the management team will not receive bonuses. The airline is trying to avoid redundancies and has asked Airbus for a delay in the A350 order decision.

site_title: China's Xi says Wuhan has 'turned the tide' againt virus epidemic
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping said Wuhan has "turned the tide" against the novel coronavirus outbreak, citing a dramatic drop in new infections. His visit to the city, which was sealed off in late January, came as Hubei province announced easing travel restrictions. Xi stated that the spread of the virus has been "basically curbed" in the province and its capital city. However, the measure did not indicate if people could leave the province, and state media has been playing up Xi's role in the fight against the outbreak.

site_title: After 32 years, Aman spins off second hotel brand Janu
summary: Aman, a luxury hotel company, is spinning off its second brand, Janu, 32 years after establishing itself as a standard-setter. Janu aims to offer a more affordable, yet equally high-end experience, with properties set to open in 2022 in Tokyo, Sveti Stefan, Montenegro, and Al Ula, Saudi Arabia. Janu will cater to a younger, tech-savvy audience seeking nightlife and wellness activities, with a staff-to-guest ratio of 3 to 1 and rates around $1,000 per night. The move is seen as a way for Aman to expand its market and target a new demographic.

site_title: Singapore 2020 property auction listings may rise 10%
summary: Singapore property auction listings may rise 10% in 2020 due to an uncertain economic environment, according to Colliers International. This follows a strong 2019, where auction listings increased 34% year-on-year to 1,458. Mortgagee sales in retail, industrial, and residential sectors could increase in the second half of 2020, with the price gap between buyers and sellers narrowing, potentially improving sales and success rates.

site_title: The US has never recognised China as a developing country
summary: The US has never recognized China as a developing country, contrary to recent media reports. The US Trade Representative's Office issued a notice in February stating some trade partners, including China, would no longer be considered developing countries under the Countervailing Duty Law. However, this is a misinterpretation, as the US has never officially recognized China as a developing country. China joined the WTO as a developing country in 2001, but this does not change the fact that the US has not recognized China's developing country status.

site_title: What to expect after market rout
summary: Global markets plunged 7.2% on Monday, with the US S&P 500 experiencing its steepest single-day decline since the Great Financial Crisis. Oil prices dropped 20-30% due to a price war between major producers, and gold rallied to a six-year high. Investors are advised to remain cautious and focus on long-term goals, avoiding sectors directly impacted by the virus outbreak and sectors sensitive to falling oil prices. The Fed may cut rates further to counteract the virus hit, and global central banks are expected to follow suit with easing measures.

site_title: Oil and stock markets show some bounce after Monday's flooring
summary: Global oil and stock markets rebounded on Tuesday after a day of significant losses, driven by coordinated economic stimulus efforts and hopes for a recovery from the novel coronavirus. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields rose, while European stocks recovered 3% of their losses from Monday. Oil regained its footing after a 25% drop, and benchmark Brent crude futures rose around 5%. Investors are now expecting a temporary setback followed by a recovery, with some major banks predicting a potential cut to zero US interest rates.

site_title: Bank of Russia to sell foreign currency after plunge in oil prices
summary: The Bank of Russia announced it will sell foreign currency ahead of schedule to reduce market volatility amid a decline in oil prices, making the rouble the worst-performing currency. This move aims to increase predictability and stability in financial markets. The decision follows significant changes in the global oil market.

images.alt_text: Russia's policy makers are preparing for a period of protracted low oil prices after the Kremlin embarked on a price war with Saudi Arabia to avoid cutting production.

site_title: UK is test case for joint economic action on virus
summary: The UK is poised to unveil a budget that will likely include short-term stimulus measures to combat the novel coronavirus, with the government and Bank of England working together to craft a response. Investors are expecting a Bank of England interest-rate cut of up to half a point, which could be announced alongside the budget. The move aims to calm market panic and support struggling businesses and households. The UK's economic slump may serve as a model for joint economic action on the virus, with policymakers emphasizing the need for coordinated policy action.

site_title: Govt agencies to halt seniors' events for 14 days amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: The Singapore government has suspended all senior-centric activities by government agencies for 14 days from March 11 to March 24 to reduce the risk of Covid-19 transmission among older residents. Care services for seniors, including nursing homes and home-based care, will continue. The multi-ministry taskforce is considering broader social distancing measures, including public events, community activities, school closures, and workplace social distancing, but is mindful of their potential impact on the lives of Singaporeans.

site_title: STI bounces back from 'Black Monday'
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 1.8% on Tuesday, ending 50.17 points higher, after a "Black Monday" slump. Oil prices also recovered, with WTI crude rising above $30 a barrel. The recovery was largely driven by US stimulus measures and recovering oil prices, which prompted US President Donald Trump and Vice-President Mike Pence to consider fiscal stimulus. Several Singaporean stocks, including Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries, also bounced back from their losses, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank advancing.

site_title: Purchases of adjoining units keeping luxe condo market abuzz
summary: Singapore's luxe condo market saw several big-ticket deals sealed by local buyers in the first two months of 2020, despite the Covid-19 outbreak deterring mainland Chinese buyers. The recent purchases indicate a strong demand for luxury properties in the city-state.

site_title: Chasen asks to lift trading halt after providing update on fire at its warehouse in Jurong
summary: Chasen Holdings, a Singapore-listed investment holding company, confirmed a fire at its warehouse in Jurong on Monday night, prompting a trading halt on Tuesday. Firefighters responded promptly and extinguished the blaze by 4am the next day. No injuries were reported, with over 50 occupants self-evacuating prior to SCDF's arrival. The cause of the fire is under investigation. Chasen stated that the incident is not expected to have a significant financial impact, as the warehouse and its contents are adequately insured.

site_title: Alipay squares off with WeChat in fight for more merchants
summary: Alipay, owned by billionaire Jack Ma, is expanding its services to compete with WeChat, a super app owned by rival billionaire Pony Ma. Alipay aims to target 40 million merchants and services providers to use its mini programs, which offer quick access to services such as real estate purchases and restaurant bookings. The company has seen initial success in helping merchants cope with the economic impact of the COVID-19 virus shutdown in China, with over 1,200 developers creating new mini programs. Alipay's goal is to drive merchants to the mini programs, enabling them to manage customer data and conduct promotions.

site_title: China inflation hits 5.2% in Feb on surge in pork prices
summary: China's consumer price index (CPI) rose 5.2% in February due to a surge in pork prices, with the African swine flu decimating pig farms last year. Factory prices dropped 0.4% year-on-year, and core inflation fell to a nine-year low. The COVID-19 outbreak disrupted supply chains, leading to hoarding and price spikes for food and hygiene products. However, overall food prices jumped 21.9% and disinfectant prices increased by 14.8%. Deflationary pressures are expected to continue, with factory gate prices and exports expected to drop further.

site_title: ByteDance plans to roll out Google-like office tools as Covid-19 boosts demand
summary: ByteDance, the maker of TikTok, plans to roll out a Google-like suite of office collaboration tools, called Lark (Feishu in China), as soon as this month. The app will offer cloud-based file management, document, and spreadsheet editing, targeting China's growing demand for remote work tools amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The rollout will begin in China, with the goal of expanding beyond consumer tech and diversifying revenue sources. ByteDance has seen a surge in downloads for its existing remote-work app, Lark, and is poised to capture the latent demand in China.

site_title: Q2 business sentiment plunges to new low on Covid-19 fallout
summary: Singapore's business sentiment has plummeted to an all-time low in Q2 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak, with the construction, services, and manufacturing sectors worst-hit. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index fell to -7.88 percentage points, down from 5.31 percentage points in Q1 2020 and a record low since 2010. Companies are exercising caution, with many expecting significant impact on sales and inventory levels. The construction sector expects sales to fall 20-30% in Q2, while the services sector is expected to face direct negative effects from consumer spending.

site_title: B2B offers volume, big growth potential in e-commerce
summary: Singapore's e-commerce sector is expected to grow due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with business-to-business (B2B) transactions also holding significant potential for growth. B2B sales account for 87% of e-commerce receipts in Singapore, with a compound annual growth rate of 19% from 2016 to 2018. However, B2C sales have outpaced B2B growth, with a 29% compound annual growth rate. The government's initiatives, such as the Grow Digital scheme, aim to encourage SMEs to go online, with the potential to boost B2B e-commerce.

site_title: Auto industry's fears shifting from supply to demand
summary: The auto industry is shifting its concerns from supply chain disruptions to demand, as the COVID-19 pandemic threatens to impact consumer spending. Auto industry experts, including LMC Automotive, have cut their forecasts for 2020 sales, citing a potential demand crunch in the US. The global pandemic, with over 100,000 cases worldwide, has raised concerns about consumer psychology and confidence, with some analysts predicting a potential recession. Automotive stocks, such as O'Reilly Automotive and AutoZone, may see growth in demand if car owners delay purchases, but the "real test" will be in March, as uncertainty about the virus impacts vehicle sales.

site_title: IPOs including Reits grind to halt as Covid-19 jitters hit markets
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted initial public offerings (IPOs) and real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore, with many companies putting their plans on hold due to market volatility. Despite some companies pushing ahead with listings, concerns over the economic impact of the virus have led to a cautious approach. Industry leaders and lawyers say that company valuations are being squeezed, making it challenging to price deals in an uncertain environment. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is taking steps to stay relevant, but faces challenges including a small pool of retail and institutional investors.

site_title: Jack Ma is Asia's richest man after Mukesh Ambani's US$5.8b rout
summary: Jack Ma has regained the title of Asia's richest person after Indian energy tycoon Mukesh Ambani's net worth dropped by $5.8 billion due to the collapse of oil prices and global stocks. Ma's fortune rose to $44.5 billion, surpassing Ambani's $42 billion. The decline in oil prices, exacerbated by the spread of the novel coronavirus, erased billions from Ambani's net worth. Ambani's Reliance Industries faces challenges in cutting its net debt to zero by early 2021, with a proposed stake sale to Saudi Arabia's Aramco uncertain amid a court petition to halt the deal.

site_title: Airlines strive to stave off calamity as coronavirus locks down Italy
summary: Airlines worldwide face crisis as the coronavirus epidemic worsens, with Italy's lockdown significantly impacting passenger numbers. Thousands of flights were cancelled, and plane orders were delayed. Korean Air Lines scrapped 80% of its international capacity, grounding 100 aircraft, citing uncertainty about the virus's duration. The industry's future is uncertain, with the president of Korean Air Lines warning that the situation can deteriorate at any time. Airlines such as Delta Air Lines, however, remain optimistic about travel demand.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nam Cheong's direct subsidiary acquired a 49% equity interest in Malaysian oil and gas company SK Hull for RM49,000 (S$16,060). The acquisition was made by Nam Cheong Dockyard, a subsidiary of Nam Cheong. This move marks a significant expansion into the Malaysian market for the South Korean-based offshore support vessel builder.

site_title: Swedish actor Max von Sydow, 90, dies
summary: Swedish actor Max von Sydow, 90, has died. Born Carl Adolf von Sydow in 1929, he was known for his iconic roles in films such as "The Exorcist," "Minority Report," and "Game of Thrones." Von Sydow was widely acclaimed for his work with director Ingmar Bergman, and earned two Academy Award nominations. He passed away on Sunday in Provence, France, with no cause given, leaving behind his wife, Catherine, and their combined family.

site_title: The president who did not rise to the occasion
summary: US President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus epidemic has been marred by inconsistent messages and misinformation, creating a perception of a bewildered leader. Trump has downplayed the severity of the outbreak, suggesting that the virus would "miraculously" go away and that many cases would be mild. His administration's response has been muddled, failing to plan ahead for a global pandemic. The president's actions have exacerbated the already divided public debate, with some arguing for a more pragmatic response to the crisis.

site_title: No money in hat as Hyflux judge attempts to order funds into escrow
summary: A Hyflux judge, Justice Aedit Abdullah, attempted to order an escrow fund to pay advisers of 34,000 retail investors in the event of a liquidation, but was met with no volunteers. The proposed escrow was aimed at addressing the advisers' fees, which would be unpaid if the Utico deal falls through. Justice Abdullah ultimately decided not to order the escrow, citing the company's inability to meet the request and the need for a more suitable structure to handle advice provision. The unsecured working group also expressed its lack of confidence in resolving Hyflux's issues with Utico and expressed concerns over unequal fee payments to its advisers.

site_title: Darco explains why it is writing off debts worth S$2.46m
summary: Darco Water Technologies is writing off S$2.46 million in debts deemed "low recoverability" after three years. The impairment loss stems from three projects and a former subsidiary, including a nearly S$1.05 million loss on a wastewater project in China due to a settlement that fell short of the original contract price. The company has made full provision for impairment and expects the funds to be unrecoverable.

site_title: EU to overhaul competition rules and tackle foreign subsidies
summary: The European Union plans to overhaul its competition rules and address foreign subsidies to help European companies compete globally against US tech giants and Chinese-aided rivals. The new industrial strategy aims to tackle issues such as digital and green transitions, breaking down barriers in the single market, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2050. The EU executive will adopt a discussion paper by mid-2020 and plan legislation for next year, following calls from Germany and France for easier rules to promote European industrial champions.

site_title: Japan unveils additional US$4b of support measures
summary: Japan has unveiled a second package of COVID-19 support measures worth approximately US$4 billion, focusing on small and mid-sized firms, amid concerns about the fragile economy. The package includes funding for medical facilities, subsidies for working parents, and special financing for small and mid-size firms hit by the virus. The government will tap its budget reserve to fund the package, which is expected to affect the Bank of Japan's policy review on March 18-19.

site_title: Ikea to sell through third party for first time on China's Tmall
summary: IKEA has started selling its products on Alibaba's Chinese e-commerce platform Tmall, marking the world's biggest furniture retailer's first time selling through a third party. The move aims to reach more Chinese shoppers, who prefer multi-brand online platforms. This comes as IKEA temporarily shut its 30 stores in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Vote of no-confidence a wake-up call for old boys' club in boardrooms
summary: State Street Global Advisors, the world's third-largest asset manager, has announced a policy to promote gender diversity on corporate boards. The firm will vote against one director or the full nominating committee of companies without female board directors, starting this year. A third of the world's 30 largest asset managers have similar policies, with more extending them to Singapore and Hong Kong. This move aims to address the lack of women in boardrooms, where advocates argue that it can lead to better risk-adjusted returns and more diverse decision-making.

site_title: Oil rebounds on stimulus hopes but still under price war cloud
summary: Oil prices jumped 4% on Tuesday, rebounding from the biggest one-day rout in nearly 30 years, as investors eyed economic stimulus and potential US output cuts. Brent crude futures rose to $35.80 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate gained 5% to $32.65 a barrel. Despite a looming price war, the rebound was lifted by news of US President Donald Trump's stimulus plans and Japan's government spending package to cope with the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Cruise passengers checked for virus, all found well
summary: The Costa Fortuna, a cruise ship with 600 passengers, docked in Singapore on March 10, 2020, after a 14-day voyage. All passengers were checked for COVID-19 and found to be well. Those with recent travel history to northern Italy were individually screened and certified fit to travel. Passengers were then taken to the airport or hotels for onward flights. The ship had submitted a maritime declaration of health prior to departure, and authorities took precautions, including enhanced screenings and swab tests, to ensure public safety.

site_title: Europe set to engage emerging-market giants
summary: The European Commission is focusing on emerging markets, particularly Africa, in its foreign policy efforts. After its first 100 days in office, the new commission is promoting a relationship based on investment rather than aid, aiming to be a counterweight to other world powers. Brussels has scheduled summits with India and China, and has launched a new Africa strategy to strengthen ties with the continent. The EU sees Africa as a key partner, with significant economic growth potential, and is playing catch-up with China and Russia, as well as Western allies.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps on stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks rose 2-3% on Tuesday as investors regained confidence in coordinated policy easing to prevent a global recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 601.98 points, the S&P 500 gained 66.92 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 269.09 points. The market rally comes after a day of the biggest market rout since the financial crisis. The gains were attributed to hopes for policy easing and a potential end to the global recession.

site_title: Promoting Singapore as a hub for sustainable finance
summary: Singapore has a unique opportunity to become a regional hub and centre of excellence in sustainable finance, driven by the growing green movement and government ambitions. The country has already made strides, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's focus on climate change and the goal to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040. Singapore can capitalize on its existing efforts by taking further steps to solidify its position in sustainable finance, leveraging its unique position to drive and shape the rapidly evolving field.

site_title: Covid-19 crisis seen adding US$100 billion to Asian bank credit costs
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak is projected to add US$100 billion in credit losses to Asian banks this year, primarily affecting Chinese lenders, with a total estimated income loss of US$211 billion. This will strain balance sheets across the region, with Chinese banks facing sharp pressure due to regulatory responses. Authorities have delayed recognizing bad loans and relaxed loan recognition to mitigate the impact, but property transactions and construction are largely paused, potentially leading to long-term credit profile damage.

site_title: Amid Saudi-Russian oil price war, other Opec states sound alarm
summary: OPEC states sound the alarm over plunging oil prices amid a Saudi-Russian oil price war. After OPEC's de facto leader Saudi Arabia scrapped production cuts, other OPEC countries like Iraq and Algeria warned that flooding the market won't help producers. Oil prices lost a third of their value this week, with Iraq's Oil Minister stating that the move would worsen the situation. Fitch ratings agency predicts sustained low oil prices will negatively impact sovereign ratings of crude-exporting countries with weaker finances.

site_title: STI gains 1.8% in session after its biggest rout since October 2008
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 1.8% on Tuesday after its largest single-day fall since October 2008 due to improved sentiment following potential fiscal stimulus measures from US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Wuhan. Oil prices also recovered from multi-year lows. The STI's 30 components saw five end the day in the red, while media and property group Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) was the biggest gainer in percentage terms, jumping 7.5%.

site_title: Trading of Winas Limited securities to be suspended on April 9
summary: Winas Limited, a Mainboard-listed company, will have its securities trading suspended on April 9, 2020, after failing to secure approval for an extension to meet new listing requirements. Trading will continue until 5:16 pm on April 8, 2020, before being halted until completion of a cash exit offer.

site_title: London man second patient to be cured of HIV
summary: A London man, Adam Castillejo, 40, has become the second person to be cured of HIV after undergoing stem cell transplant treatment. The treatment, similar to that used on the "Berlin Patient" in 2011, involved receiving stem cells from donors with a genetic mutation that prevents HIV from taking hold. Thirty months after stopping traditional treatment, Castillejo's viral tests showed no active infection, with only "fossils" of the virus remaining. This breakthrough is a significant step towards a potential cure, but researchers caution that it is not a generalised cure and would require careful consideration for future patients, particularly those with drug-resistant forms of HIV.

site_title: Oracle closes Singapore office after employee diagnosed with Covid-19
summary: Oracle has closed its Singapore office after an employee tested positive for Covid-19. The employee was last seen at the Galaxis office on Friday and developed symptoms on Sunday. The office was closed for disinfection and deep cleaning, with all employees told to work from home for the next three days. Other employees who came into contact with the infected employee have been advised to take a 14-day leave of absence. This move follows similar steps taken by other large corporations in Singapore, including Grab and Facebook, which have also closed offices due to Covid-19 cases.

site_title: French Connection posts FY loss as UK high-street competition weighs
summary: French Connection, a UK-based clothing retailer, reported a full-year loss due to high-street competition from rivals like Inditex's Zara and online shopping. The retailer cited subdued consumer demand and political uncertainty related to Britain's exit from the EU as contributing factors. French Connection plans to continue holding back dividend payments this year, amidst a challenging retail environment.

site_title: Putin endorses legislation enabling him to run for president again
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has endorsed legislation that would allow him to run for a fifth term as president in 2024, potentially extending his rule until 2036. The proposal, floated by a lawmaker, would reset the two-term limit for Putin if he were to run again. Putin, 67, believes he should remain in power for Russia's stability, despite a two-term limit. The proposal must be approved by Russia's Constitutional Court, and Putin did not confirm whether he plans to run again.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.31 points to 1,430.47 on Tuesday, with 491 gainers outnumbering 477 losers. The index closed at RM3.204 billion in volume.

site_title: Darco Water Tech explains why it's writing off S$2.46m
summary: Darco Water Technologies is writing off S$2.46 million in debts deemed "low recoverability" due to three projects and a former subsidiary. The largest impairment comes from a Chinese wastewater project, where the settlement sum fell short of the original contract price. The company also wrote off S$704,000 from an Indonesian project and S$97,000 from a stalled Chinese project. Darco's former Taiwan subsidiary went into liquidation in 2019, resulting in another impairment.

site_title: BHG Retail REIT reopens two malls in Hefei city temporarily shuttered by coronavirus
summary: BHG Retail REIT has reopened two malls in Hefei, China, temporarily closed due to the coronavirus outbreak. Hefei Mengchenglu Mall and Hefei Changjiangxilu Mall reopened on March 10, after certain stores were closed from February 7 for coronavirus containment requirements. The malls had only allowed food and beverage outlets and supermarkets to operate during the closure. The reopenings were made possible with approval from local authorities.

site_title: Chasen calls for trading halt following news of Jurong warehouse fire
summary: Chasen Holdings, a Singapore-listed investment holding company, called for a trading halt on March 10, 2020, following news of a warehouse fire at its address in Jurong. The Singapore Civil Defence Force responded to the blaze, with 31 emergency vehicles and 80 firefighters deployed. No injuries were reported, but the zinc roof collapsed due to intense heat, hindering firefighters' access. The cause of the fire is under investigation. Prior to the halt, Chasen shares closed 12.3% down on Monday.

site_title: Virus to boost Asian bank credit costs by US$100b: S&P
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to add $100 billion in credit losses to banks in the Asia-Pacific region this year, primarily affecting Chinese lenders, according to S&P Global. The ratings firm estimates a total income loss of $211 billion, with Chinese property sector ratings under pressure. This will exert sharp, short-term pressure on Chinese banks and lower Asia-Pacific growth forecast to 4% for 2020.

site_title: DP World slashes fees at key Dubai business park
summary: DP World has slashed fees at the Jebel Ali Free Zone (Jafza) in Dubai by 50-70%, benefiting 7,500 companies. The move aims to boost business productivity amid the global coronavirus outbreak's impact on consumer confidence. Jafza, a specialized free zone, allows 100% foreign ownership and offers tax exemptions. The fee cuts are part of DP World's efforts to support businesses in the region and promote economic growth.

site_title: Tiny homes seen as big solution to New Zealand housing crisis
summary: A petition in New Zealand calls for eased regulations on tiny homes and mobile homes to address the country's housing crisis, which has the highest rate of homelessness among OECD nations. The petition, signed by over 4,000 people, suggests these small dwellings can provide affordable, immediate, and dignified housing for families. Despite the government's efforts to increase affordable housing, the country still faces a shortage, with thousands waiting for state housing and living in emergency accommodations.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rebound on move to tighten short-selling rules, global stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rebounded on Tuesday as the government pledged to tighten short-selling rules and as hopes of global policy stimulus supported sentiment. The Kospi index rose 0.42% to 1,962.93, reversing early losses. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners net sold around 938.7 billion won worth of shares on Monday. The US Federal Reserve increased its repo operations, and the European Central Bank is set to meet on Thursday to discuss a potential interest rate cut.

site_title: Private equity firms with energy holdings hit hard in selloff
summary: Private equity firms with energy holdings suffered significant losses on Monday due to the collapse of oil prices. Shares of firms like Blackstone Group Inc, Apollo Global Management Inc, and Carlyle Group Inc dropped 13-16% as US stocks plummeted. Energy investments, which account for 15% of Blackstone's credit portfolio and 10% of Apollo's private equity portfolio, were particularly affected. The impact on private equity firms could spread beyond energy investments, with analysts predicting more deal opportunities in a dislocation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce after rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.41% following a previous day's rout. Energy firms and companies linked to Hubei province, where President Xi Jinping visited, saw significant gains. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also increased, driven by optimism over the economic outlook.

site_title: Questions raised over how Tokyo mayor secured hot property
summary: Tokyo Mayor Masami Ishikawa faces questions over his purchase of a 100 million yen apartment in a district he governs. The apartment was reserved for landowners or loyal customers, and the developer received special dispensation to build higher than regulations permit. Ishikawa claims his son was offered the property after failing to win a lottery for an ordinary apartment, and he denies any wrongdoing. An investigation by Tokyo's Chiyoda Ward local assembly is planned, with Governor Yuriko Koike backing Ishikawa's fifth term as mayor.

site_title: Voting begins in six states as Biden-Sanders showdown heats up
summary: Voting began in six states, including Michigan, as the Democratic primary heats up between Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders. Michigan, with its large delegate haul, is a crucial prize, and a strong showing for Sanders is needed to remain viable. Biden has won several recent states, including South Carolina and Super Tuesday, narrowing the gap in the delegate race. Sanders and Biden have campaigned in Michigan, with voters expressing concerns about defeating President Trump in the general election.

images.alt_text: People vote in the Michigan primary election at Chrysler Elementary School in Detroit, Michigan, on March 10, 2020.

site_title: Covid-19: Senior-centric activities suspended for 14 days; 6 new cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore has suspended senior-centric activities for 14 days due to the COVID-19 pandemic, from March 11 to March 24. The number of cases in Singapore has risen to 166, with 93 fully recovered and 73 remaining in hospital. The government is considering broader social-distancing measures, including public events, school closures, and workplace social-distancing. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for a balanced approach, avoiding measures that could lead to fatigue or economic disruption.

site_title: The emotional wreckage of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302
summary: Families of victims of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302, which crashed in 2019, continue to push for changes in aviation safety a year after the tragedy. The crash, which killed 157 people, was the second malfunction of the Boeing 737 Max in five months. Families are seeking more scrutiny of the plane, an overhaul of aviation laws, and accountability from Boeing executives. While some demands have been met, including the grounding of the Max and increased transparency, many issues remain unresolved, and the families' efforts continue to be met with bureaucratic hurdles and resistance.

images.alt_text: Chris and Clariss Moore of Toronto, whose 24-year-old daughter Danielle died in the crash on March 10, 2019.
Kenyan Paul Njoroge, a businessman living in Toronto, lost his wife, three children and mother-in-law.

site_title: Japan unveils US$4b coronavirus package, not yet eyeing extra budget
summary: Japan has unveiled a second package worth about $4 billion to cope with the coronavirus outbreak, focusing on supporting small and mid-sized firms. The 430.8 billion yen package includes funds for medical facilities, subsidies for working parents, and special financing for small- and mid-size firms hit by the virus. The government will tap its budget reserve to fund the package, and the Bank of Japan will aim to prevent companies from facing financial squeezes before the end of the fiscal year in March.

site_title: Singapore logistics firm fined S$18,000 for lying about fair hiring
summary: Singapore logistics firm Ti2 Logistics has been fined S$18,000 for lying about fair hiring considerations in its work pass application. The company's sole director pleaded guilty to a charge under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act after it was found to have pre-selected a foreigner for a job and failed to consider local candidates. The company has been barred from hiring foreigners for 24 months and its work pass will be revoked immediately. This is the first company in Singapore to be prosecuted for making false declarations on fair hiring under the enhanced Fair Consideration Framework.

site_title: Bank of Japan will respond to impact of yen moves on economy: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank will respond to any adverse impact of recent yen rises on the economy and prices. The yen's ascent was driven by demand for a safe-haven currency amid uncertainty over the novel coronavirus outbreak.
