Kuroda emphasized the BOJ's monetary policy doesn't directly target currency moves, but the central bank will take a comprehensive look at developments and take action as needed to mitigate any economic effects.

site_title: Boss of multimillion-dollar firm was once doubted for her youth and gender
summary: Nichol Ng, CEO of FoodXervices, a multimillion-dollar firm, was once doubted due to her youth and gender. Since taking over the business in 2007, she has grown its turnover five times to surpass S$60 million. Ng credits her success to humility, resilience, creativity, and compassion, as well as her ability to inspire and empower her team. Under her leadership, FoodXervices has expanded its services, now employing 190 people and working with 5,000 customers, including major brands. Ng plans to further expand the company, including opening an overseas office and redesigning employee job scopes to ensure flexibility.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore business sentiment dropped to an all-time low in Q2 2020 due to coronavirus health risks and potential economic impact, according to the SCCB Business Optimism Index. Temasek's ST Telemedia acquired a majority stake in an Indian cloud services firm, while ComfortDelGro expanded its UK presence with a £7 million acquisition. The STI gained 1.8% after its biggest rout since 2008, despite a 10% potential rise in Singapore property auction listings due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: StanChart bet on cash management paying off
summary: Standard Chartered's cash management business in Asia and South Asia has seen double-digit year-on-year growth over the last three years, driven by its digitalisation efforts. The bank's underlying operating income from cash management rose 6% globally to $2.4 billion in 2019. StanChart has collaborated with various corporates and tech firms to adopt digital payments and collections, and has launched initiatives such as EasyPay, an e-wallet for the travel industry. The bank expects a spillover effect from its B2C services to B2B, and is redefining its advisory services to remain relevant in the rapidly digitalising transaction banking landscape.

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce back on bargain-hunting, stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares surged 3.1% to a 3-year high, rebounding from 14-month lows, as investors sought bargains and hopes for global stimulus eased concerns about the coronavirus outbreak. The S&P/ASX 200 index settled at 5,939.60, with financials and energy sectors leading the gains. The Australian government's planned stimulus package, estimated at A$10 billion, and US President Trump's plans to counter the virus outbreak also boosted investor sentiment.

site_title: Singapore property auction listings could rise 10% in 2020 due to coronavirus outbreak: report
summary: Singapore property auction listings could rise 10% in 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to Colliers International. This is expected to be driven by increased mortgagee sales in the retail, industrial, and residential sectors. The predicted rise follows a strong 2019, with 34% year-on-year growth in auction listings. The success rate of auctions declined to 1.4% in 2019, indicating a price gap between buyers and sellers. Colliers attributes the decline to cautious buyers and sellers holding onto prices, with only 8 out of 21 properties sold above their opening prices.

site_title: Spain to extend ban on evicting vulnerable homeowners, protect tenants
summary: Spain's left-wing government will extend a ban protecting vulnerable homeowners from eviction and restrict evictions of tenants who cannot pay rent for 2-4 years. The moratorium, initially set to expire on May 15, will also cover more cases of vulnerability and include single-parent families. The government plans to relax income thresholds and introduce measures to restrict evictions in high-tension rental markets, particularly in Madrid and Barcelona. These steps aim to guarantee the right to decent housing, amid a 54% increase in rental prices in the last six years.

site_title: Apple's iPhone shipments to China plunge 60% in February
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments to China plummeted 60% in February due to the coronavirus outbreak, with 494,600 units shipped compared to 1.2 million units in the same period last year. Mobile phone shipments in China slid 56% to 6.4 million units. The decline is attributed to store closures and manufacturing disruptions, with factories gradually restarting but facing lingering production bottlenecks. The impact on global iPhone revenue is expected to be short-lived, but a persistent outbreak could delay the launch of 5G iPhones.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc's iPhone shipments in China plunged more than 60 per cent in February, when the coronavirus outbreak shut down scores of its stores and hampered key manufacturing partners across its largest international market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open 1% higher
summary: Europe's main stocks indices opened 1% higher on Tuesday, one day after suffering their biggest losses in over a decade due to crashing oil prices and coronavirus fears. The FTSE 100 index rose 1.8% to 6,073.61 points, while the DAX 30 added 1.2% to 10,750.58 points and the CAC 40 gained 1.7% to 4,787.17 points. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Saudi bourse leads Gulf rally as oil prices recover
summary: Stock markets in Gulf states made a strong rebound on Tuesday, led by the Saudi bourse, which jumped 5.6% as oil prices recovered from heavy losses. Energy giant Aramco gained 5.5% after a series of sessions in the red. Other Gulf markets, including Dubai, Abu Dhabi, and Qatar, also saw significant gains, while Boursa Kuwait rallied 6.6%. The rebound comes after oil producers failed to reach an agreement on output cuts, leading to a 7.0% increase in Brent crude to around $37 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Stock markets in the energy-rich Gulf states made a strong rebound in opening trade Tuesday, led by the Saudi bourse which jumped 5.6 per cent, as oil prices bounced after heavy losses.

site_title: A McKinsey exec built a 1,000-piece art collection. Now he's selling
summary: Kito de Boer, a former McKinsey executive, is selling his 1,000-piece modern Indian art collection, which he and his wife Jane built over 28 years. The collection, valued at $4.9 million, includes works by artists like Vasudeo Santu Gaitonde and Sayed Haider Raza. The sale, featuring 83 works at Christie's in New York and an online auction, aims to boost the market, which has seen significant growth in recent years. De Boer, who retired from McKinsey in 2014, believes the sale will help demonstrate the value of Indian art and encourage collectors.

site_title: Air France-KLM warns of worse to come after virus hits passenger numbers
summary: Air France-KLM has warned that the coronavirus outbreak will further impact its business in coming months, citing a 0.5% decline in February passenger numbers due to flight cancellations in China. The airline has suspended flights to several destinations and reduced services to others, with a projected cost of 150-200 million euros up to April. As the virus spreads to other regions, Air France-KLM anticipates a more significant decline in the coming months, with flights to Italy and European services also being cut.

images.alt_text: Air-France KLM warned Tuesday the coronavirus outbreak will hit its business harder in coming months after February passenger numbers fell 0.5 per cent overall as flights to China were cut.

site_title: Korean Air president says coronavirus a threat to its survival
summary: Korean Air Lines president Woo Kee-hong warned that the coronavirus outbreak could threaten the airline's survival due to over 80% of its international capacity being cut. The airline grounded 100 of its 145 passenger aircraft as a result of travel restrictions globally. Korean Air is taking self-help measures, including deferring investments and cutting operational expenses, but may not be able to guarantee its survival if the situation persists. The airline remains "strong and resilient," with a focus on minimizing employee sacrifices.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to take developer SOHO China private in US$4b deal: sources
summary: Blackstone Group Inc is in exclusive talks to take Hong Kong-listed developer SOHO China Ltd private in a US$4 billion deal. The US private equity firm offered HK$6 (S$1.07) per share, a 100% premium to SOHO China's average January price. This deal represents one of Blackstone's biggest bets on the Chinese market and sent the target's shares to a 21-month high. The talks were initiated in early February, with SOHO China's shares experiencing significant gains following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading, up 1.8% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.8% to 2,830.97 points in Tuesday's afternoon trading session, reversing losses at the open. The recovery was attributed to potential US fiscal stimulus measures and investors buying counters on dips after 18 of the STI's 30 components hit 52-week lows. Key gainers included Singtel, DBS, OCBC Bank, and Singapore Press Holdings, with volume and turnover exceeding 2019 averages. The rally follows a bloodbath on Monday, with Asia-Pacific equity benchmarks also rising.

site_title: PSA International unit prices S$500m 10-year notes at 1.63%
summary: PSA International, a subsidiary of Singapore's port operator, is issuing S$500 million 10-year senior notes at 1.63% fixed coupon. The notes are unconditionally guaranteed by PSA International, which has a credit rating of Aa1 by Moody's. The proceeds will be used to refinance borrowings and for general corporate purposes. DBS is the sole bookrunner for the deal, which is expected to be issued on March 18, 2020.

site_title: ComfortDelGro expands UK presence through £7m taxi operator acquisition
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, a Singapore taxi operator, has expanded its UK presence through a £7 million acquisition of Liverpool City region's third-largest taxi and private-hire operator, AST. The acquisition brings the group's total UK investment to S$446.6 million, financing through debt and internal funds. AST operates across three licensing areas, managing over 700 self-employed drivers and 200 corporate accounts, complementing CityFleet's existing 400-taxi operation in Liverpool.

site_title: Temasek's ST Telemedia nabs majority stake in India cloud services firm
summary: ST Telemedia, a Temasek-owned investment arm, has acquired a majority stake in Indian cloud services firm CloudCover, with an undisclosed value. CloudCover, incorporated in 2015, offers automation-driven cloud services to technology unicorns and agile enterprises. The investment aims to accelerate CloudCover's market expansion and talent acquisition. This is ST Telemedia's third major cloud investment, following similar deals in the US and Singapore. The acquisition advances ST Telemedia's goal of building a global cloud IT platform, enabling governments and enterprises to adopt digital innovation and the cloud.

site_title: Xi pays first visit to virus epicentre Wuhan: state media
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping made his first visit to Wuhan, the epicentre of the coronavirus epidemic, on March 10, 2020. The visit comes as quarantine measures in the region have effectively controlled new infections, which have dropped dramatically in recent weeks. Xi will meet with frontline medical workers, officials, and residents to inspect the epidemic prevention and control work. The visit is a significant move by the Chinese government to show support and confidence in the efforts to combat the outbreak.

site_title: Singapore's condo resale prices and sales drop in February, hurt by virus outbreak
summary: Resale condo prices and sales in Singapore dropped in February due to a "triple whammy" of the coronavirus, Chinese New Year, and new unit supply. Prices declined 0.8% from January, with the biggest drop seen in non-central region homes. Sales volume fell 13.1% from the previous month, with the highest transacted price reaching S$16 million for an apartment in prime District 10. Experts predict sales may improve when the Covid-19 situation stabilizes, but demand may be tested by upcoming condo launches.

site_title: London hotel owner defies virus panic, plans US$1.3b sale
summary: A London hotel owner, Cola Holdings, is planning to sell its Westbury Hotel for approximately $1.3 billion, despite the global coronavirus pandemic. The seller is betting on the hotel's prime location in Mayfair and plans to redevelop the property, enhancing its value. The sale will be pitched as a safe-haven asset, and the company expects to receive bids from interested buyers, including luxury brands like LVMH. The sale will occur before the redevelopment, which may close the hotel for 2-3 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes in positive territory despite oil, virus fears
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.85% on Tuesday, closing at 19,867.12, after a 5% decline on Monday. The gains came despite concerns over a strong yen, a crash in oil prices, and the coronavirus. The Nikkei's recovery was seen as a sign of traders' confidence in the market, with investors brushing off recent threats from US President Trump to extend the rally.

site_title: IKEA tests selling through third party for the first time, on Tmall in China
summary: IKEA, the world's largest furniture retailer, has launched its first-ever sale on Alibaba's Chinese e-commerce platform Tmall, marking a significant shift in its business strategy. The six-month test in eastern China aims to increase accessibility and reach new customers, complementing its own stores and online presence. If successful, IKEA plans to expand the Tmall store to other parts of China, but not other markets. The move is part of IKEA's efforts to adapt to changing shopping patterns, following investments in online channels and new sales formats.

site_title: Joo Chiat's JK Centre up for sale at indicative price of S$34m
summary: A Singapore commercial property, JK Centre, is up for sale via tender with an indicative price of S$34 million (S$1,627 per sq ft). The freehold 8,491 sq ft property, completed in 2011, features a supermarket, retail units, and office spaces. It boasts a prominent corner location with double frontages and is near co-living and co-working spaces. The sale comes with no additional buyer's stamp duty and foreign ownership restrictions, offering investors potential for higher rental income and capital upside. The tender closes on April 15.

site_title: Tesla plans to expand car parts production capacity in Shanghai: government document
summary: Tesla plans to expand its car parts production capacity at its Shanghai factory, aiming to localise its supply chain in China. The company, which currently uses 70% imported parts, plans to add lines to make battery packs, electric motors, and motor controllers, and double its annual production of cooling pipes to 260,000 sets. The expansion is part of Tesla's goal to produce 500,000 vehicles globally by the end of 2020 and increase its output in Shanghai to 250,000 vehicles per year. The move comes as the company seeks to diversify its supply chain amid a coronavirus outbreak that has disrupted production.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades SPH to 'buy'; raises target price to S$2.25
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to "buy" and raised its target price to S$2.25, citing attractive valuations following recent market selloffs. The analysts noted the company's growing base of recurring income from aged care and student accommodation assets, which are more resilient to economic downturns. They also expect near-term upsides for SPH amid the Covid-19 outbreak, particularly in its media business due to increased health advisory advertisements.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to "buy" and raised its target price to S$2.25 from S$2.22, citing that valuations are attractive following the broad market selloffs in recent weeks.

site_title: Sasseur Reit to reopen Hefei outlet mall after virus-related closure
summary: Sasseur Reit's Hefei outlet mall will reopen on March 13 after a virus-related closure, following approval from the local government. The Reit's manager will continue to monitor the situation and implement cleaning and disinfecting routines. This reopening follows the previously announced reopenings of Kunming and Chongqing outlet malls. The company's financial impact from the Covid-19 outbreak remains uncertain and will be updated as necessary.

site_title: Heineken to pour US$183m into expansion in Brazil
summary: Heineken to invest US$183.14 million in expanding its Ponta Grossa brewing plant in Brazil, increasing production by 75% and focusing on Heineken and Amstel brands, its most important market worldwide.

site_title: Indonesia mulls 2032 Olympics bid for new capital city with SoftBank's help: sources
summary: Indonesia is considering a 2032 Olympics bid centered on its new capital city, a $34 billion "smart and green" city on the island of Borneo, in partnership with SoftBank's Masayoshi Son. The plan is in early talks with investors, with the government evaluating its suitability as an Olympic candidate city. This would be a new bid, separate from the existing bid for Jakarta, which is sinking into the sea.

site_title: Masks in luggage: How a Malaysian tech firm reopened its China factory
summary: A Malaysian tech firm, Qdos, reopened its China factory after securing 50,000 surgical masks from Malaysia. The masks were stuffed in employees' luggage upon their return from the Lunar New Year break. The company, which supplies five of the world's top smartphone makers, had initially struggled to secure masks in China due to the virus crisis. Qdos' decision allowed the factory to reopen and employees to return to work. However, the company has cut its sales growth outlook to the "low tens" due to supply chain disruptions.

site_title: China's Hubei province may allow residents to travel: state media
summary: China's Hubei province is considering allowing residents to travel in areas at a medium or low risk of contracting the novel coronavirus, according to a meeting chaired by the province's party chief. The plan involves using a "health code" mobile-based monitoring system, which has been rolled out in many local authorities in China. The decision aims to ease travel restrictions in the province, which is at the epicentre of the outbreak.

site_title: Vietnam's e-commerce market to surpass US$17b in 2023: GlobalData
summary: Vietnam's e-commerce market is projected to reach US$17.3 billion in 2023, growing at a 16.3% compound annual rate. The market has doubled in the past five years, with online spending increasing from US$3.9 billion in 2015 to US$9.4 billion in 2019.

images.alt_text: E-commerce market value in Vietnam (2015-23f), and share of payment tools (2019)

site_title: Singapore shares up 0.8% on Tuesday morning after sell-off
summary: Singapore's blue-chip index rose 0.8% to 2,804.94 points on Tuesday, reversing a morning decline, as investors bought counters on dips amid the ongoing Covid-19 situation and oil price war. The recovery comes after Wall Street's worst session since December 2008. Key advancers included Singtel, DBS, OCBC Bank, and Reits such as Ascendas and CapitaLand. The Asia-Pacific market was mixed, with Australia and Malaysia up, while China, Japan, and South Korea were lower.

site_title: Volatile coffee climbs to defy slump in equities, commodites
summary: Coffee futures rose 1.7% to $1.092 a pound, defying a slump in equities and commodities. The rally was driven by a shortage of high-grade arabica beans, particularly in Central America and Brazil. The US-based coffee director at Comexim predicted prices could jump as high as $1.50 if markets calm down. The tight supply situation is expected to last until the third quarter, when Brazil's new crop is released.

site_title: Despite virus, China consumer confidence remains envy of world
summary: China's consumer confidence remains high despite the coronavirus outbreak, with a reading of 139.4, more than double Japan's level. This is attributed to the limited availability of free press and restricted internet access, which reduces fear and panic. In contrast, countries like Japan, the UK, and Germany, which were already experiencing waning confidence, have taken a harder hit. The US, with a high percentage of households invested in stocks, is particularly vulnerable to a decline in consumer sentiment, which could lead to a vicious cycle of reduced economic activity and hiring.

site_title: Bank of Japan chief says market moves 'very unstable'
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that global financial markets are "very unstable" due to the coronavirus outbreak. The central bank has purchased 2.04 trillion yen worth of exchange-traded funds since October, aiming to control short-term interest rates and the 10-year government bond yield. Kuroda's comments come as the economic impact of the virus could be significant, and the BOJ's stimulus program is ongoing.

site_title: Mongolia locks down cities after reporting first virus case
summary: Mongolia has locked down its cities for six days after reporting its first coronavirus case, a French energy company employee who flew in from Moscow. The country had already sealed its border with China and banned flights from South Korea. The capital Ulaanbaatar and province centers are quarantined until March 16 to curb the outbreak. This measure follows China's lockdown of 56 million people and Italy's restrictions on the entire country.

site_title: Google restricts visits to curb coronavirus risk
summary: Google has restricted visits to its offices in Silicon Valley, San Francisco, and New York to curb the risk of coronavirus transmission, following Apple's decision to let employees work from home. The internet giant has also shifted to virtual job interviews and canceled its major annual gathering, Google I/O. Other tech companies, including Facebook and Microsoft, have also implemented similar measures to reduce the risk of infection. The move comes as the virus spreads globally, with several major events, including the TED Conference and the South By Southwest cultural conference, being postponed or canceled.

images.alt_text: Google on Monday began restricting visits to its offices in Silicon Valley, San Francisco and New York as it ramped up precautions against the deadly novel coronavirus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 3.04 points higher, or 0.21%, at 1,427.20. Trading volume reached 150.80 million lots worth RM77.64 million. Losers outpaced gainers 390-56.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Jardine Matheson to 'hold'
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB downgraded Jardine Matheson Holdings to "hold" from "add" with a lowered target price of US$52.53, citing uncertainty over the novel coronavirus outbreak affecting its subsidiaries. The conglomerate expects a challenging short-term outlook, but is optimistic about a fast recovery once the situation stabilizes. This move follows a downgrade of Hongkong Land Holdings to "buy" with a lowered target price, citing resilience in its Hong Kong office portfolio.

site_title: Co-working startup The Wing sees its worth shrink in WeWork deal
summary: The Wing, a female-focused co-working startup, has seen its valuation shrink from $365 million in 2018 to approximately $200 million, according to people familiar with the matter. The Wing's valuation was reduced after WeWork's botched initial public offering (IPO) and the sale of its stake in The Wing to a group of investors, including Hollywood talent powerhouse Creative Artists Agency (CAA). The sale valued The Wing at $165 million, with an additional $15 million in funding injected. WeWork recorded a loss of $17 million from its bet on The Wing.

site_title: Asia: Oil bounce supports stocks after 'Black Monday'
summary: Global stocks experienced a sharp rebound on Tuesday, following a 2,000-point drop on "Black Monday". Oil prices jumped 6% after plummeting by a third the previous day, providing support to under-pressure stocks. The Nikkei index in Japan rose 0.4% after earlier falling 3%, while the Shanghai Composite Index opened 0.61% higher. The market panic was driven by uncertainty over the coronavirus and a spat between Saudi Arabia and Russia over oil production. Analysts warned the panic had not stopped yet, with severe weakness in energy markets cascading into broader declines in commodity markets and equities.

site_title: 'If we sanitise, it will be fine': cruise fans ignore US alert
summary: Thousands of cruise fans ignored a US government warning to avoid setting sail on massive ships due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Passengers at PortMiami, the world's busiest cruise port, lined up to board the Norwegian Sky, with many expressing confidence that sanitizing would prevent the spread of the virus. Despite warnings from the US State Department and stock market losses for cruise lines, some passengers remained undeterred, citing precautions such as avoiding contact with others and washing hands.

site_title: South Korea reports 35 new coronavirus cases, total at 7,513
summary: South Korea reported 35 new coronavirus cases on March 10, 2020, bringing the country's total infections to 7,513. This marks the lowest rate of increase in new infections in 11 days. The Korea Centres for Disease Control and Prevention reported the data.

site_title: US Securities and Exchange Commission staff in Washington shows coronavirus symptoms
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) staff in Washington, DC reported a coronavirus symptom in one of its employees, prompting the employee to be treated and referred for testing. As a precaution, the SEC has encouraged its headquarters employees to telework until further guidance is provided.

site_title: Elon Musk dismisses astronomy concerns over Starlink network
summary: Elon Musk has dismissed concerns that his Starlink constellation of internet satellites will obscure the view of the night sky, predicting it will have "zero impact" on astronomical discoveries. Musk cited measures taken to reduce the satellites' reflectivity, including painting antennas black and placing sunshades. He also stated the network is primarily targeted at remote areas and won't affect traditional telecommunications companies. Musk aims to generate $30 billion in revenue annually and plans to use profits to develop rockets and spaceships.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment tumbles on potential coronavirus fallout: poll
summary: Singapore's business sentiment plummeted to an all-time low of -7.88 percentage points in Q2 2020 due to coronavirus health risks and potential economic impact, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index study. The index has dropped 12.96 percentage points from Q1 2019, with all six study indicators reporting negative numbers. The decline was caused by negative spillover effects of the virus, slowing Chinese demand, and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Japan readies 'state of emergency' coronavirus measures
summary: Japan's government approved a draft "state of emergency" bill that would grant Prime Minister Shinzo Abe the power to declare a state of emergency and impose drastic measures, including keeping people inside and commandeering buildings for hospitals. The measures are aimed at fighting the coronavirus, but Tokyo stressed that the situation had not yet reached that point. The bill would be subject to parliamentary approval, with the current situation not deemed to require such measures.

site_title: China Feb PPI down 0.4% year-on-year, CPI up 5.2%
summary: China's producer prices in February fell 0.4% year-on-year, entering deflationary territory due to the coronavirus outbreak. Consumer prices rose 5.2% year-on-year, exceeding expectations. The lockdown of Wuhan and surrounding cities likely slowed the world's second-largest economy in the first quarter. This slowdown raises pressure on policymakers, who are concerned about the impact on China's GDP growth. The data suggests a significant economic impact from the coronavirus outbreak.

images.alt_text: China locked down Wuhan and some cities in Hubei province, the epicentre of the outbreak, and imposed restrictions in other cities to contain the spread of the virus from late January.

site_title: New Zealand central bank does not need alternative policy at this time
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) Governor Adrian Orr stated that the central bank does not need to use alternative monetary policy at this time, but is prepared for possible unconventional steps. The RBNZ will maintain its official cash rate of 1.00% until it reaches the zero lower bound. Orr mentioned that forward guidance, negative rates, interest rate swaps, large-scale asset purchases, and buying foreign currency assets are being considered. The bank's cash rate is expected to be lower than current levels in two years, with a 20% chance of an effective zero bound.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks see small bounce at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded 0.98% at the open on Tuesday, driven by a small recovery from the previous day's rout. The Hang Seng Index rose to 25,285.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.83% and 1.14% respectively. Investors remain cautious due to the economic impact of the coronavirus and low oil prices.

site_title: Singapore's Pavilion Energy signs mid-term deal with SLNG for storage, reloading
summary: Singapore's Pavilion Energy has signed a five-year deal with SLNG for liquefied natural gas storage and reloading services, with access to 180,000 cubic metres of tank capacity on Jurong Island. The agreement supports higher LNG trading activities and will last longer than two years, marking the first such deal in Singapore. The deal is expected to enhance Pavilion Energy's trading capabilities and increase its LNG trading volume.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Pavilion Energy said on Tuesday it has signed a five-year deal with Singapore LNG Corp for liquefied natural gas (LNG) storage and reloading services in the city-state, the first such agreement signed for a term longer than two years.

site_title: Two US lawmakers exposed to virus before meeting Trump
summary: Two US lawmakers, Republican Representatives Doug Collins and Matt Gaetz, have been placed in self-quarantine after being exposed to the new coronavirus at a late-February conservative conference. Collins met with President Trump last Friday and Gaetz traveled with Trump on Air Force One on Monday. Neither reported symptoms, but took precautions out of caution. Five US lawmakers have now distanced themselves from others after coming in contact with coronavirus-infected individuals, following a trend of lawmakers taking steps to protect themselves.

site_title: Trump has not been tested for novel coronavirus: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump has not been tested for the novel coronavirus, according to the White House, as he has not had prolonged close contact with confirmed cases or symptoms. Trump's physician will continue to monitor his health. In contrast, at least two lawmakers who recently met with Trump at a conference have self-quarantined after a person who tested positive for the virus attended the event.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has not been tested for the novel coronavirus, the White House said on Monday, though at least two lawmakers with whom he has recently come into contact have announced they were self-quarantining after attending a conference with a person who had tested positive for the virus.

site_title: BHP in 'good shape' to act if coronavirus disruption brings M&A openings: chairman
summary: BHP Group chairman Ken MacKenzie stated the company is in "very good shape" to take action if supply chain disruption from the coronavirus epidemic leads to acquisition opportunities. Despite a potential hit to demand this year, BHP has returned $33 billion to shareholders and paid down debt to $12.8 billion, positioning it to thrive at the bottom of the economic cycle. MacKenzie also mentioned the company is looking at opportunities from other disruptions, such as climate change.

site_title: Aspial to issue S$50m 6.5% 3-year notes at par
summary: ASPIAL Corporation plans to issue S$50 million 6.5% 3-year notes at par, with proceeds to be used for refinancing existing borrowings and general corporate purposes. The notes, with a fixed coupon rate, will mature on March 20, 2023, and have been allocated to certain controlling shareholders. DBS Bank and OCBC have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners, with shares of Aspial closing down 2.5% to 15.5 cents.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday following US market rout; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.8% on Tuesday, following a 7% drop in US markets overnight. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,760.87 points, with 158 losers outnumbering 72 gainers. Trading volume was 135 million securities worth S$272.1 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip into bear market territory
summary: Australian stocks plunged into bear market territory, falling 3.9% to their lowest since December 2018, amid rising economic risks from the coronavirus and oil price slump. The S&P/ASX 200 index traded 0.7% lower at 5,720.60. Investors are seeking bargains, with heavyweight financials and healthcare stocks leading the losses, while energy stocks gained due to higher crude oil prices. The Australian government prepares a fiscal stimulus to ward off recession risks.

site_title: Biden hopes to continue momentum in key Michigan primary
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden urged Michigan voters to support him in the Democratic primary, seeking to bolster his lead over Bernie Sanders. Biden, a moderate former vice-president, campaigned heavily in Michigan, which is the top prize with the largest number of delegates at stake. Despite Sanders' efforts to right his listing ship, Biden is riding high, having won 10 of 14 states that voted last Tuesday. Biden's campaign is bolstered by endorsements from several high-profile former rivals, including African-American senators Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, who are touted as possible vice-presidential picks.

site_title: Armed gang steal US$15m in Chile airport heist
summary: A heavily armed gang stole approximately US$15 million from an armored security truck at Chile's Santiago airport, one of the largest heists in the country's history. The thieves arrived in the cargo area aboard two vehicles, threatened the guards, and made off with the money. This is the second significant heist at the airport, following a 2017 theft of US$19 million.

site_title: Wealth wipeout reshapes ranks of world's richest people
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic caused a significant market collapse, wiping out nearly $238.5 billion from the combined fortunes of the world's 500 richest people. Energy moguls suffered the largest percentage losses, with Wildcatter Harold Hamm's fortune dropping to $2.4 billion. Other notable losers include Mukesh Ambani, Jeff Bezos, and Warren Buffett. Meanwhile, only a few billionaires, such as China's Qin Yinglin, managed to gain wealth, with their fortunes increasing by $536 million and $143 million, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei down 3% in early trade
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 3.08% or 607.17 points to 19,091.59 in early trade, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to a crash in oil prices and coronavirus fears. The broader Topix index also fell 2.85% or 39.53 points to 1,349.44. Analysts expect the Nikkei to dip below 19,000, with the dollar trading at 102.89 yen.

site_title: Boeing shares plunge on coronavirus, 737 MAX wiring bundle setback
summary: Boeing shares plummeted 12% amid the spread of the coronavirus and pressure from US regulators over the safety of wiring bundles on the grounded 737 MAX jet. The FAA disagreed with Boeing's argument, and industry sources report airlines are requesting deferrals and cash payments. A new interim report from Ethiopian investigators also highlighted faulty 737 MAX systems in last year's fatal crashes. Boeing's CEO, Dave Calhoun, apologized to senior staff after a rare attack on his predecessor, and the company faces mounting anxiety and criticism over its handling of the crisis.

site_title: White House looks to bolster economy as coronavirus worries batter markets
summary: The US government is taking steps to bolster the economy amid growing concerns over the coronavirus outbreak, which has seen stock markets plummet and top health officials urge caution. President Trump is meeting with his economic team to consider policy measures, including paid sick leave, payroll tax cuts, or specific tax credits. Meanwhile, health officials advise older Americans to avoid big social gatherings, cruise ships, and airline flights, and several US universities are moving to virtual instruction. The number of confirmed US cases has reached 566, with 22 deaths, and the White House is weighing responses to the crisis.

site_title: China inflation slips but stays high on virus, food worries
summary: China's consumer inflation rose 5.2% in February, down slightly from the previous month's 5.4%, but still high due to the coronavirus epidemic and soaring food prices. The figure was in line with a Bloomberg forecast. Economists attributed the increase to heightened food prices and the cost of medical supplies during the epidemic, which has infected over 80,700 people. The slight decrease in inflation suggests a slowing economic impact from the virus.

images.alt_text: Pork prices in particular remained high, increasing 135.2 per cent in February, after a 116 per cent rise in January.

site_title: Covid-19: US plane diverted after passengers upset by sneezing
summary: A US United Airlines flight was diverted on Sunday after a group of passengers became upset over a passenger who was sneezing and coughing, sparking concerns about COVID-19. The flight was diverted to Denver's international airport, but after evaluating the passenger, who had allergies, the plane continued on to New Jersey. The incident was not a medical situation, and the airline stated the passenger was allowed to stay on the flight. The diverted flight was the latest incident highlighting concerns over the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: US regulators urge banks to aid borrowers hit by virus
summary: US banking regulators have urged financial institutions to aid borrowers affected by the coronavirus outbreak, easing oversight and rescheduling bank examinations for institutions facing staffing challenges. The Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation stated that banks should work constructively with borrowers and other customers in affected communities, while maintaining safe and sound lending practices. This move aims to support borrowers hit by the virus and alleviate pressure on financial institutions.

site_title: Threat of coronavirus pandemic now 'very real': WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned that the new coronavirus outbreak has become a "very real" threat of a pandemic, but still can be controlled. With global infections passing 100,000, WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized that containment and control are possible, even if it's considered a pandemic.

site_title: Fitch gives Starhill Global Reit a 'BBB' long-term default rating
summary: Fitch Ratings has assigned Starhill Global Reit a "BBB" long-term issuer default rating with a stable outlook. The ratings are driven by the Reit's cash flow visibility from long-term master leases and its prime retail properties in Singapore and Malaysia. However, Fitch notes that the Reit's risk of exposure to a sharp fall in cash flows is constrained by its high asset and tenant concentration. The rating also factors in a gradual moderation of the Covid-19 situation over the next few quarters.

site_title: Boris Johnson urges panic-buying Brits 'to behave responsibly'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged Brits to stop panic-buying amid empty store shelves due to coronavirus fears. Supermarkets imposed limits on goods, including toilet paper, hand gel, and tinned food. Johnson advised those stockpiling to consider others, as responsible behavior is essential. This comes as the UK faces a fresh blow to its economy, with its economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: US urges elderly to stock up on groceries as coronavirus surges
summary: US health authorities urge Americans aged 60 and over, as well as those with underlying health conditions, to stock up on food and medicine and prepare to stay home due to the rapidly spreading coronavirus. The CDC recommends having enough household items and groceries to last a period of time, as 15-20% of infected patients develop a serious illness. The agency also advises avoiding close contact with the sick, crowds in poorly ventilated spaces, and non-essential travel. The US has reported 22 deaths and over 550 cases, with the western state of Washington being the hardest hit.

images.alt_text: US health authorities on Monday urged Americans most at risk of getting seriously ill from the new coronavirus to stock up on food and medicine and prepare to remain at home, as the pathogen spread rapidly across the country.

site_title: Investors, analysts see market turmoil and recession as threat to Trump re-election bid
summary: US investors and analysts believe a coronavirus-driven recession and plummeting oil prices could harm President Donald Trump's re-election bid. The Dow suffered its largest one-day loss since 2008, with a near 10% drop from confirming a bear market. Analysts warn that a worsening economic outlook could hurt Trump's chances in November, despite his downplaying of the threat posed by the virus. The market turmoil is seen as a significant threat to Trump's re-election bid.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SATS, SIA Engineering, CAO, ComfortDelGro, Starhill, Aspial
summary: Singapore's aviation industry is bracing for the Covid-19 outbreak's disruption to persist. Companies such as Singapore Airlines, SATS, SIA Engineering, and China Aviation Oil are implementing pay cuts and slashing flight prices and change fees. ComfortDelGro Corporation is expanding its UK presence through a £7 million acquisition. Fitch Ratings has assigned Starhill Global Reit a BBB long-term issuer default rating. Aspial Corporation is offering S$50 million worth of three-year notes. The Singapore Exchange will appoint a new deputy chief financial officer.

site_title: Italy PM extends virus measures across whole country
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte extended virus measures nationwide, ordering people to stay at home and banning public gatherings and Serie A football matches. The measures, set to last until April 3, include closing schools and universities, restricting travel in and out of the country, and restricting movement between cities. Italy reported 97 new deaths, bringing the total to 463, with over half of the country's deaths outside China. The national restriction aims to combat the spread of the new coronavirus.

site_title: French culture minister tests positive for coronavirus
summary: French Culture Minister Franck Riester has tested positive for the novel coronavirus and is staying in his Paris home, where he is "doing fine". Riester had attended the National Assembly in Paris, where five virus cases were confirmed earlier. This marks the latest high-profile case of the virus in France.

site_title: Qantas grounds planes, CEO forgoes pay as virus spreads
summary: Qantas grounds most of its Airbus A380 fleet, cutting international flights by nearly 25% for six months due to the coronavirus epidemic. The airline will also reduce capacity out to mid-September. CEO Alan Joyce will forgo his salary for the rest of the financial year, while other executives will take a 30% pay cut. Staff are encouraged to take annual unpaid leave during the next six months. The airline's shares have lost nearly 38% of their value since the previous flight cut.

images.alt_text: Qantas announced on Tuesday it was grounding most of its Airbus A380 fleet and its CEO would forgo his salary as the airline slashed international flights in response to the coronavirus epidemic.

site_title: IMF to test working from home in case virus strikes
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has announced that all employees will work from home on Friday to test its remote work systems in case the coronavirus epidemic makes in-person work necessary. This comes as the World Bank has also been testing remote work procedures on a smaller scale. The IMF's Spring meetings, originally scheduled for April, will now be a virtual event due to the outbreak, which has sickened over 110,000 people worldwide. The move aims to strengthen the fund's readiness to continue operations during the crisis.

site_title: Virus going global means China's factories will get hit again
summary: China's factories are facing another hit as the coronavirus spreads globally, despite efforts to resume full production. Manufacturing firms report cancelled orders and fewer opportunities to gain new customers due to the virus in Europe and the US. Weaker demand from developed markets poses a fresh risk to China's restart, which could add to global recessions and cut $2.7 trillion off global output. China's economy is already facing its first quarterly contraction in decades and the weakest year since the early 1990s.

site_title: UN warns of virus impact on swelling youth unemployment
summary: The UN labour agency has warned that the COVID-19 pandemic could disproportionately affect young people's access to work, exacerbating rising youth unemployment. The looming global economic slowdown, triggered by efforts to combat the virus, is expected to disproportionately impact young individuals, who are already struggling with unemployment. The UN cautions that these measures could have severe consequences for the world's youth.

site_title: Make the most of S$4b package first, DPM Heng tells firms
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat advises companies to maximize the S$4 billion government package to help businesses cope with the coronavirus outbreak. He also announced the formation of a working group to support industry transformation and worker retraining. Other panellists at the forum emphasized the need for long-term support to help firms overcome short-term survival issues. The government has set aside an additional S$8.3 billion to spur economic growth over three years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end at eight-month low after oil price crash
summary: European stocks ended at an eight-month low on Monday, closing down 7.4% on the pan-European Stoxx 600 index, marking its worst day since the 2008-09 financial crisis. The drop was attributed to a crash in oil prices, which lost nearly 17% after a price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia. The crash deepened concerns of a global recession due to the coronavirus outbreak. European firms have lost nearly US$3 trillion in value since the outbreak.

site_title: US shale producers rush to cut spending, output as oil prices tank
summary: US shale producers are rapidly reducing spending and production in response to plummeting oil prices, which have fallen 20% in a single day. The decline is attributed to Opec's decision to pump full bore into a global market hit by the coronavirus outbreak. Shale companies need prices above $40 per barrel to cover costs, and at current levels, they are struggling to maintain profitability. Companies such as Apache Corp and Occidental Petroleum Corp have seen their stock prices plummet, and some are halting drilling and well completions to maintain cash flow.

site_title: To golf in your retirement, look further
summary: Retirees are looking beyond traditional golf communities for their post-work living arrangements. Analyst Scott Kauffman notes that these communities often prioritize green spaces, security, and amenities like clubs, restaurants, and pools. As a result, lesser-known locations may offer more attractive options for retirees seeking a relaxed lifestyle.

site_title: Founders' Memorial design chosen, to be completed in 2027
summary: Singapore's Founders' Memorial design, created by Kengo Kuma & Associates and K2LD Architects, has been chosen to be completed in 2027. The 5-hectare site in Bay East Garden will feature a linear design with lush greenery, a viewing gallery, lake, forest trail, and amphitheatre. The winning design was selected unanimously by a seven-member jury, praised for its unique blend of architecture, landscaping, and place-making characteristics. Construction will begin in 2022, and the memorial will be served by the upcoming Founders' Memorial MRT station.

site_title: Tesco sells Asia units for US$10 billion to Thai billionaire
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, has agreed to sell its businesses in Thailand and Malaysia to Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont's Charoen Pokphand Group for over $10 billion. The deal includes Tesco's 2,000 hypermarkets and convenience stores in Thailand and 70 shops in Malaysia. Tesco will return almost two-thirds of the proceeds to shareholders, generating a £5 billion special dividend. The sale is part of Tesco's restructuring efforts, including job cuts, to support its core UK business and eliminate its pension deficit.

site_title: Brazil: Sao Paulo exchange plummets more than 12%
summary: Brazil's Sao Paulo exchange plummeted over 12% on Monday, following a global market downturn triggered by the coronavirus epidemic and a sharp decline in oil prices. Petrobras shares fell 31%, while domestic airlines Gol and Azul dropped 17%. The real lost ground against the dollar, trading at 4.80, and Argentina's peso hit an all-time low. Analysts warn of volatile markets due to the coronavirus and economic slowdown, with Brazil's economy expected to continue struggling.

images.alt_text: Brazil's Sao Paulo exchange plummeted more than 12 per cent Monday as global markets recoiled from the coronavirus epidemic and a deep plunge in oil prices.

site_title: honestbee lays off estimated 70-80% of staff amid pivot to pizza joint
summary: honestbee, a Singapore-based startup, has laid off an estimated 70-80% of its staff, affecting around 104 employees out of 130, amid a pivot to a pizza joint. The move comes in response to the company's financial struggles.

site_title: Wearing mask against virus? System knows who you are
summary: A Chinese company, Hanwang Technology Ltd, has developed facial recognition technology that can identify people wearing masks, addressing a challenge posed by widespread mask-wearing due to the coronavirus. The system, which uses a sample database of unmasked and masked faces, can recognize individuals with a 95% success rate while wearing a mask and up to 99.5% without one. The technology is being used by the Ministry of Public Security and other clients in Beijing, with plans to expand to 20 provinces and potentially benefit the global fight against the virus.

images.alt_text: The system developed by Hanwang Technology still struggles, however, with facial recognition if the subject wears both a mask and sunglasses. But the firm expects foreign interest in the know-how.

site_title: Money FM podcast: If you have 10k to invest today, where are the opportunities?
summary: Michelle Martin discusses investing $10,000 with Swapnil Mishra, head of private wealth at Kristal.AI. Mishra advises diversifying across asset classes, particularly in Asia, which is expected to drive growth and gain from dollar diversification. He also highlights the importance of productivity gains in unlocking wealth creation and notes that markets are rising due to various factors, including de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) appointed Ng Yao Loong as its new deputy CFO, who will succeed Chng Lay Chew as CFO upon his retirement on September 30. CH Offshore, a vessel chartering firm, reported three years of consecutive losses, while DLF Holdings sold a Mercedes-Benz car for a loss, citing it as a "non-core asset." Sino Grandness Food Industry Group appointed Chan Chun Kit as CFO, and Silverlake Axis sold its shares in Finzsoft for NZ$4.4 million.

site_title: US, Russian oil producers to feel the squeeze as Saudis open oil tap: analysts
summary: Saudi Arabia's aggressive discounting of oil prices is set to significantly impact the global oil trade, particularly for US and Russian producers. With the lowest average production cost, Saudi Arabia can weather low prices better, while higher-cost rivals like the US and Russia will face financial strain. The move is expected to lead to a surge in demand for Saudi oil, reducing imports from higher-cost suppliers and amplifying the effect of the global oil price collapse.

site_title: Short-term visitors in Singapore must pay for Covid-19 treatment
summary: Singapore has implemented a new policy requiring short-term foreign visitors to pay for Covid-19 treatment, effective March 7. The country reported 10 new confirmed cases, including three imported cases involving foreign visitors. Singapore's total confirmed cases rose to 160. The Ministry of Health (MOH) prioritizes public hospital resources and waives testing fees for short-term visit pass holders for contact tracing purposes. Local cases are linked to private dinner functions and a church cluster. Grab has also reported a Covid-19 case among its employees, with offices closed for deep cleaning and disinfecting.

site_title: STI suffers biggest single-day dive since 2008
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 178.61 points, or 6%, to 2,782.37 points, its largest single-day loss since October 2008. The decline was driven by a worsening Covid-19 outbreak and a shock in the oil markets, with Saudi Arabia launching an oil price war. All 30 index components ended the day in the red, marking the lowest closing point since June 2016.

site_title: Singtel freezes wages except for operational, support staff
summary: Singtel has implemented a wage freeze across the organization, except for operational and support staff, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the business. Group CEO Chua Sock Koong stated that the move aims to strengthen financial resilience and lower costs. The company will also match staff donations to support those affected by the virus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Members of Singtel's management committee will lead the way by donating at least half a month's pay.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: US: Dow ends 7.8% lower, joining global rout on virus fears
summary: US stocks plummeted 7.8% on Monday, marking the worst session since December 2008, amid fears over the economic fallout from the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 23,851.02, while the S&P 500 slid 7.6% to 2,746.56. Oil prices dropped 25% due to Saudi Arabia's price slash, contributing to the sell-off. Economists now forecast a global recession, citing the virus's spread and disruption.

images.alt_text: Major Wall Street indices finished down more than seven per cent on Monday following an ugly session sparked by an oil price crash and fears over the economic fallout from the coronavirus.

site_title: Coronavirus to cause first annual decline in oil use in decade: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts the world will experience its first annual decline in oil consumption in over a decade due to the coronavirus outbreak. The decline is expected to be around 90,000 barrels per day, primarily driven by China's containment measures. Oil consumption in February fell by 4.2 million barrels per day, with China accounting for 80% of global oil demand growth last year. The IEA also warns that if China's economy does not recover quickly, demand could drop by 730,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Muhyiddin picks CIMB CEO as finance minister in new Cabinet line-up
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin appointed Zafrul Aziz, the CEO of CIMB Group Holdings, as his new finance minister. This move is seen as an attempt to boost fiscal credibility amid heightened global risks and domestic policy uncertainty. Zafrul Aziz is a non-political private sector banker, marking a departure from the previous finance minister. The appointment comes after Muhyiddin replaced Mahathir Mohamad last week, following a power struggle.

site_title: Frantic buying of Treasuries sees yield curve inside 1% for first time
summary: Treasuries saw a historic yield curve inversion as markets priced in a potential Federal Reserve rate cut to 0% in the coming months. The rally was fueled by the coronavirus crisis, oil price war, and economic contraction in major economies. Investors are now expecting almost 75 basis points of rate cuts by the Fed at the March meeting, with some speculating the US central bank may deploy unconventional policies, including negative interest rates, to combat the global recession.

images.alt_text: The latest leg of the blistering bond rally was fuelled by an all-out price war among the world's largest crude producers. Risk assets plunged with S&P futures dropping 5 per cent to hit circuit breakers.

site_title: Avoid cruises, says US State Department
summary: The US State Department advises Americans to avoid cruise ships due to the risk of COVID-19 transmission. A cruise ship, the Grand Princess, is being prepared to dock in Oakland, California, after 20 confirmed cases of the virus on board. Medical teams will assess the condition of passengers and crew, with those most in need of hospitalization being prioritized for treatment. Passengers will be quarantined at military bases across the US, while crew members will remain on the ship for their own quarantine.

site_title: Beleaguered aviation industry: Waiting for the skies to clear
summary: The global aviation industry is facing its worst turbulence since the 2002-2003 Sars crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Demand for air travel plummeted, leading to plane groundings, staff reductions, and cutbacks in plane orders. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) now projects a $113 billion revenue loss for global airlines, quadrupling its initial loss projection. Asia-Pacific carriers are expected to lose $28 billion, with China's domestic market accounting for $13 billion. The industry is expected to consolidate, with airlines with strong balance sheets expanding their geographical footprint through acquisitions.

site_title: Janacek cycle at Royal Opera House: Operas about strife, strength and survival
summary: The Royal Opera House is presenting the first cycle of Czech composer Leos Janacek's operas, starting with "Jenufa" from March 24 to April 9, followed by "The Makropulos Affair" until 2022. Director Oliver Mears calls the initiative "long overdue," praising Janacek's ability to create strong, charismatic female characters who survive in intolerable situations. The productions will feature the original Czech language, a departure from the English National Opera's tradition. Rising soprano Asmik Grigorian will make her London debut in the title role of "Jenufa."

site_title: Mapletree Investments gets 200m euro sustainability-linked loan
summary: Mapletree Investments has secured a 200 million euro sustainability-linked loan from OCBC Bank for general working capital and corporate funding purposes. The loan is linked to ESG targets and will have its interest rate reduced on a tiered basis if targets are met. The loan is one of the largest sustainability-linked loans for Singapore real estate developers and is the fourth sustainable finance transaction between OCBC and Mapletree Group.

site_title: Predicting random shocks
summary: Economists have long relied on the normal distribution model to predict random shocks, but a French mathematician, Benoit Mandelbrot, proposed a non-normal distribution model to better capture the unpredictability of events like the 2008 financial crisis. Climate change and the COVID-19 pandemic pose new challenges, requiring more sophisticated models and investments to be continuously adjusted. Economists are struggling to accurately predict the impact of these events, and central banks are best equipped to respond with swift and cooperative action, such as lowering interest rates.

site_title: Digitising land records puts India's poor at risk of loss of privacy and land
summary: India's national land record modernisation programme aims to digitise land records by 2021 to establish ownership and reduce conflicts. However, this push has raised concerns over the privacy of poorer communities, who could be more vulnerable to evictions, legal issues, and technology-related problems. Authorities claim the initiative will enable easier land sales monitoring, increased tax revenue, and reduced corruption. The programme's impact on India's poor remains uncertain, with experts warning of potential risks to their privacy and livelihoods.

site_title: As one of China's 'Detroits' reopens, global carmakers worry about disruptions
summary: Global carmakers face uncertainty as factories in China's Wuhan, a major automotive hub, reopen after lockdowns due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Supply chain disruptions and staffing shortages are expected, with some companies having difficulty accessing raw materials and parts. The lockdowns have already halted or partially halted production at over 97% of Hubei companies, with nearly 60% at risk of bankruptcy. If production does not resume quickly, vehicle assembly lines worldwide are at risk of slowing or shutting down, with General Motors' North American plants securing components for several months.

site_title: Covid-19: Italian cruise ship to dock in Singapore as scheduled
summary: An Italian cruise ship, the Costa Fortuna, is set to dock in Singapore on Tuesday as scheduled, despite being turned away by Thailand and Malaysia due to COVID-19 concerns. All passengers will undergo temperature screening, and those showing symptoms may be required to undergo a swab test. The ship has 60 Italian passengers on board and has declared no fever or respiratory illness symptoms. Singapore's authorities will check passengers' health before disembarkation.

site_title: Coronavirus shock-tests airline industry's cash 'fortress'
summary: The US airline industry is facing a significant shock due to the coronavirus pandemic, with carriers cutting capacity and adopting cash-saving measures. Despite having built up their defenses with strong balance sheets and reserves, the industry is being tested by a sharp decline in demand, particularly from business travelers. The US carriers are expected to continue to reduce flights and adopt more drastic measures if the peak summer travel season appears threatened. However, analysts believe the industry has adequate liquidity to carry it through the crisis until May, with some airlines already taking steps to re-examine their fleets and ground unneeded aircraft.

site_title: Boards and value creation
summary: Boards of directors can create value and drive success in today's fast-paced business environment by adopting innovative strategies and embracing change. This includes forming technology or innovation committees, bringing in non-traditional board members with expertise in innovation and disruption, and adopting a private equity mindset focused on key metrics and performance goals. Boards should also prioritize talent management, succession planning, and sustainability to drive long-term value creation and competitiveness. By doing so, companies can differentiate themselves and succeed in the face of uncertainty and disruption.

site_title: Global CO2 emissions from power sector down 2% in 2019: Ember study
summary: Global CO2 emissions from the power sector declined by 2% in 2019, the largest fall since at least 1990, driven by reduced coal usage in Europe and the US. Coal-fired power generation fell 3% globally, while China's coal-fired generation rose due to increased demand. The decline was largely due to cheaper gas, nuclear plant restarts, and slowing electricity demand. To keep within a 1.5°C warming limit, coal generation needs to fall by 11% annually, and the report emphasizes the need for a rapid transition to renewables to achieve this goal.

site_title: Over half of STI stocks dive to 52-week lows - bloodbath could continue
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 6% to 2,782.37, its largest single-day loss since 2008, due to the surprise oil price war and escalating Covid-19 fears. All 30 STI components fell, with 18 closing at 52-week lows. Analysts warn of further downside for equities as investors reassess global economic growth, with fund redemptions and earnings forecasts expected to accelerate.

site_title: US: Stocks trade halted for 15 minutes after bruising open
summary: US stocks halted trading for 15 minutes on Monday after suffering a 7% decline, triggered by a sharp drop in oil prices and coronavirus concerns. The S&P 500 fell 200 points to 2,764.21, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average sank 7.3% to 23,979.90. The Nasdaq Composite Index also plummeted 6.9% to 7,987.44, marking a global rout in markets.

site_title: An all-new BT app experience coming to you
summary: The Business Times (BT) is relaunching its iPhone and Android mobile apps with a new reading experience, designed to be more intuitive and easier to navigate. The new app features a streamlined navigation, cleaner layout, and redesigned interface, offering a faster and more secure experience. Key features include read-time indicators, improved bookmarking, and a curated feed on the home screen. The app will be rolled out in phases, starting with the iPhone roll-out, which began on March 9, 2020.

site_title: Edtech startup Zookal raises A$15m in Series B equity funding
summary: Singapore-based edtech startup Zookal has secured A$15 million in Series B equity funding led by existing investors Koh Boon Hwee and Unigestion. This round, which includes participation from Wee Hur Holdings, brings Zookal's total funding to A$25 million. The funding will support the company's growth and expansion in the education technology sector.

site_title: Aviation companies slash prices, waive fees as virus outbreak persists
summary: Singapore's aviation industry is bracing for the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak disruption, with companies implementing pay cuts and slashing flight prices and change fees. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines and Emirates are offering waivers on change fees and discounts on fares, while SATS announced a 15% pay cut for its president and CEO. Aviation-related counters have taken a beating in the market, with SIA and SATS losing 4.3-6.2% and 6.2% respectively, while SGSME is in a strong position to weather the disruptions. Analysts predict the measures will continue to reflect the severe impact of the outbreak on demand.

site_title: China's SMEs struggling to stay afloat despite Beijing's efforts to restart economy
summary: China's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to stay afloat despite Beijing's efforts to restart the economy. Many SMEs, including restaurants and catering companies, have been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with some forced to shut down indefinitely. The government has announced measures to support SMEs, including targeted liquidity support and rent waivers, but many business owners feel these measures are too little, too late. With over 25 million SMEs in China, accounting for 40% of the workforce, the situation is dire, with many SMEs forced to turn to friends and family for financial support or make difficult decisions such as layoffs or salary cuts.

site_title: Challenges of the new quarterly reporting regime
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has introduced a new quarterly reporting regime, requiring 109 companies with high risk to report their financials on a quarterly basis. The regime aims to provide more targeted and less arbitrary reporting, but critics argue that it may not be sufficient, particularly for companies with already well-documented problems. The new approach imposes a one-year grace period on companies not currently required to report, but some argue that it should extend to two or three years of clean audit opinion. The regime also raises concerns about "auditor shopping" and the potential for companies to manipulate their financial statements to receive an unmodified opinion. Despite some concerns, investors overwhelmingly support the quarterly reporting system, with 75% of respondents preferring it and 95% saying it would have a negative impact on liquidity if discontinued.

site_title: Germany reports first death cases due to coronavirus
summary: Germany has reported its first two confirmed death cases due to the coronavirus, an 89-year-old woman in Essen and another patient in the highly affected region of Heinsberg.

site_title: Retailers see need to invest in omnichannel strategies
summary: Retailers in Singapore are investing in omnichannel strategies despite the COVID-19 outbreak, viewing it as a long-term strategy. Brick-and-mortar retailers like Courts and HipVan are investing in online marketing and infrastructure to reach customers beyond physical stores. E-commerce retailers like Pomelo and Iuiga are also focusing on developing robust omnichannel strategies. Having a physical store can help brands cultivate consumer confidence and provide services like consultation and after-sales care, while the online channel offers information for shoppers.

site_title: Major Swedish fund fears rate cuts more than virus
summary: Sweden's largest investment fund, Folksam, is concerned that ultra-low interest rates pose a bigger threat to the pension industry than the coronavirus market sell-off. Fund CEO Ylva Wessen warns that prolonged low rates could hurt retirees' savings and undermine the industry's investing model. With central banks considering emergency rate cuts, Folksam is turning to alternative investments to mitigate the impact, but Wessen notes that these assets are expensive and highly competitive. The fund is opting to ride out market volatility rather than making major portfolio adjustments.

site_title: FX volatility up as yen gains 3%; commodity currencies slump
summary: The dollar fell 3% against the Japanese yen and commodity-linked currencies plummeted due to a 30% crash in oil prices and tumbling stock markets, causing a surge in currency volatility. The euro surged 1% to its strongest since January 2019, with a gauge of euro/dollar market volatility reaching its highest since April 2017.

site_title: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta 2019 pay up 2% to S$12.1m
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta's 2019 pay rose 2% to S$12.13 million, driven by a S$4.59 million cash bonus and S$6.27 million in shares. The remuneration also includes a base salary of S$1.2 million. Gupta, in his annual report, noted that new digital banking entrants in Singapore face challenges, including regulatory compliance and capital requirements, but may disrupt the market.

site_title: Gyms and coronavirus: what are the risks?
summary: The spread of the novel coronavirus raises concerns about transmission while working out at a gym. Gyms can be breeding grounds for the virus due to shared equipment and poor ventilation. To minimize risks, individuals are advised to avoid touching their faces, wash hands frequently, and maintain social distancing. Some gyms are taking precautions by providing hand sanitizer, increasing cleaning schedules, and rearranging equipment to promote social distancing. Ultimately, gym-goers must weigh the risks and benefits of exercising in a shared environment.

site_title: Pay cuts may seem right, but don't overdo it
summary: Several Temasek-linked companies have implemented pay freezes and bonus cuts for senior management amid the Covid-19 outbreak, with the goal of saving costs and maintaining confidence. However, this could potentially hurt confidence within the affected organizations and the broader economy, particularly if other firms take notice and consumers and investors become worried about the economic outlook. Clear communication and reassurance from employers are crucial to avoid a self-fulfilling prophecy of recession.

site_title: Lendlease names MD for data centre business
summary: Lendlease appoints Sam Lee as managing director of its data centre business, overseeing the $1 billion joint venture in the Asia-Pacific region. Lee, with 20 years of experience, will lead the sourcing and development of new data centres in Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, China, and Japan. He previously headed Global Switch's Singapore operations and was director of asset management at Digital Realty. Lendlease's CEO Tony Lombardo sees Lee's expertise as a key addition to drive the group's data centre strategy, enhancing its integrated capability across development, construction, and investment.

site_title: Accrelist: CPIB probes S$5,000 annual hongbao to unit's customer
summary: Accrelist executive chairman Terence Tea, along with two Jubilee Industries Holdings senior officers, including his sister Serene Tea Lay Sin, are being questioned by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) over a S$5,000 hongbao given to a customer at a Chinese New Year dinner. The probe also raised questions about a related Chinese New Year dinner and drinks expense. The trio has denied wrongdoing and provided explanations to the CPIB.

site_title: Cyber insurance - de rigueur but poorly understood
summary: Cyber insurance remains a growing concern for businesses in Singapore, with many underinsured against digital risks. The type of exposure - first-party (business-related) or third-party (customer-related) - is crucial to understanding and mitigating risks. Insurers categorize cyberattacks into these two types, but companies often struggle to comprehend the differences. As the threat landscape evolves, it's essential for businesses to actively manage and protect themselves against cyber threats to minimize potential exposure and long-term damage.

site_title: Bee Cheng Hiang turns to tech, serves up new lifestyle offerings
summary: Bee Cheng Hiang, a Singaporean company famous for its traditional food products, is venturing into app development to enhance its lifestyle offerings. The company plans to launch a custom app that will allow customers to order products, including bak kwa, for delivery or in-store pickup, and also offer personalized ordering options. Due to cost constraints, Bee Cheng Hiang is seeking an IT partner to develop the app. This move is part of the company's transformation from a product-focused to a lifestyle-focused business, aiming to meet evolving customer needs and stay competitive in the market.

images.alt_text: "We are always on the lookout for new technology and how we can use it. But we want to observe the new technology and be sure that it is ready to be rolled out," says Bee Cheng Hiang group general manager Daniel Wong.

site_title: Surging yen catches Japan's retail investors off guard
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, surged to all-time highs against the South African rand and Mexican peso, catching retail investors off guard. This follows a boost in net long positions on these currencies to the highest level since December, according to Tokyo Financial Exchange data. The yen's surge is attributed to rising interest rates in Japan and other countries, which makes the yen more attractive as a safe-haven currency. The yen's sharp increase has left investors reeling, highlighting the currency's volatility and unpredictability.

site_title: Onward tops US box office amid unsure coronavirus impact
summary: Onward, a Pixar animation, topped the US box office with an estimated $40 million over the weekend, despite a lower-than-expected start. The film's international take was also under projections. Meanwhile, the coronavirus has impacted global box office performance, with many theaters closed in major markets. Despite this, US viewership was down, but the virus seemed to have "zero impact" on the domestic market. The film received positive reviews, with an 86-point score on Rotten Tomatoes.

site_title: First coronavirus case detected at EU Commission
summary: The European Commission has confirmed its first coronavirus case among staff, a woman who recently returned from Italy and is currently in quarantine. This follows similar cases at the European Defence Agency and the Council of the European Union. The European Parliament has moved its plenary session to Brussels due to coronavirus concerns. Meanwhile, Belgium's health ministry has reported 239 coronavirus cases and limited tests to seriously ill patients and healthcare professionals due to reagent shortages.

site_title: Wanted: Tankers to stash oil as price war augers glut
summary: Oil prices plummeted as Saudi Arabia began offering its crude at deep discounts, sparking concerns of an oil-price war. The collapse in Brent futures, as much as 32% in a day, revived memories of the 2008-09 recession when traders stored oil on tankers to wait for better prices. Companies are now requesting offers for storage, with some shipowners and storage terminals seeing share prices rise. However, traders are cautious, with limited suitable vessels available and concerns about the costs and risks of long-term storage.

site_title: DPM Heng to speak at ST-BT Budget 2020 Roundtable
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will participate in a roundtable discussion, ST-BT Budget 2020, on Wednesday, sharing his views on the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on Singapore's economy, as well as longer-term structural issues. The roundtable will also cover topics such as vulnerable sectors, additional support measures, and monetisation options for seniors. The discussion will be moderated by Vikram Khanna and feature panellists from OCBC Bank, Ademco Security Group, and the Institute of Policy Studies.

site_title: Aussie watchdog sues Facebook over Cambridge Analytica breach
