summary: Australia's Office of the Australian Information Commissioner has initiated legal action against Facebook for alleged "systematic failures" in exposing over 300,000 Australians to a data breach by Cambridge Analytica. The watchdog alleges Facebook committed "serious and/or repeated interferences with privacy" by disclosing personal data without permission to an app, which then sold the data to Cambridge Analytica. Facebook has made "major changes" to its platforms to restrict data sharing and implement new governance protocols, but the company has refused to comment on the specifics of the matter.

site_title: Biden snags Booker endorsement, aims to knock out rival Sanders in Michigan
summary: Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden received a boost from former presidential hopefuls Cory Booker and Kamala Harris, who endorsed his campaign. Booker, a US senator from New Jersey, praised Biden as the candidate who would "restore honour to the Oval Office." The endorsements come as Biden seeks to knock out rival Bernie Sanders in Michigan, a crucial state in the Democratic primary. A recent poll found Biden leading Sanders by 24 percentage points among Democratic voters in Michigan, where Biden is set to campaign alongside Booker and Harris.

images.alt_text: Democratic presidential contender Joe Biden, who is seeking to deliver a knockout blow to rival Bernie Sanders on Tuesday as six states vote, received another boost on Monday when former presidential hopeful Cory Booker(top) endorsed his campaign.

site_title: Migrant worker recruitment platform Sama raises US$1.2m from Collaborative Fund, 3tvcp
summary: Sama, a Singapore-based migrant worker recruitment platform, has raised US$1.15 million in seed funding led by Collaborative Fund and 3T Venture Capital Partners. The funds will be used to grow the team and build the technology platform to match workers to jobs more efficiently. Sama aims to reduce high fees paid by migrant workers to secure jobs, currently up to S$10,000 in agent fees. The platform takes a fee of one month per year of the confirmed contract, drastically lowering prices.

site_title: EU leaders to hold video conference Tuesday on virus response
summary: European Union leaders will hold a video conference on Tuesday to coordinate their response to the coronavirus outbreak. The meeting, called by French President Emmanuel Macron, aims to address health measures, research efforts, and economic responses. France, the second-worst affected EU country after Italy, has banned public gatherings of over 1,000 people and closed schools in high-risk areas. The EU is responding to the outbreak, which first emerged in China last December, with more than 1,100 recorded cases and 19 deaths reported so far.

site_title: What Covid-19 means for international cooperation
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic may spark a new wave of international cooperation, potentially leading to a better model of globalization. The crisis has exposed the fragility of the current global socioeconomic infrastructure, which is highly interconnected and vulnerable to systemic risks. In response, policymakers may adopt measures to reduce global connectedness, but this could be counterproductive. Instead, a more effective approach is to build greater robustness through coordinated action, such as introducing global "circuit-breakers" to isolate systemic risks and providing support for functional redundancy in complex systems. This could lead to a more collaborative and resilient global response to future crises.

site_title: Sino Grandness appoints new CFO from April 1
summary: Sino Grandness appoints Chan Chun Kit as its new chief financial officer (CFO) effective April 1. Chan will oversee financial planning, internal control compliance, and financial reporting for the company and its group. This appointment was made in a regulatory filing on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Actor Max von Sydow dies in France at age 90
summary: Actor Max von Sydow, 90, has died in France, according to his wife. Born in Sweden, von Sydow had a long and varied career, starring in classic films by Ingmar Bergman and later in blockbusters like Star Wars: The Force Awakens and Game of Thrones. He began his career on Swedish theatre stages and met Bergman, with whom he collaborated on numerous films, including The Seventh Seal. Von Sydow passed away on Sunday, leaving behind a legacy as a cinematic icon.

site_title: Tesco to return US$6.6b to shareholders after sale of Thai, Malaysia assets
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, plans to return $6.6 billion to shareholders after selling its Thai and Malaysian assets to Charoen Pokphand Group for $10.6 billion. The deal is conditional on shareholder and regulatory approvals, and will help Tesco improve margins and revenue growth in its key business segments. The sale marks a retreat from Tesco's once-lofty global ambitions, as the company focuses on a UK-focused recovery plan.

site_title: DLF Holdings sells second car in less than a month
summary: DLF Holdings, an engineering firm, has sold a Mercedes Benz S320L for S$161,353, despite its net book value being about S$190,493. The sale, made in less than a month after selling a BMW, was considered "in the best interests of all shareholders" as the car was a depreciating non-core asset used for transportation purposes. The company plans to use the net proceeds for general working capital requirements.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Asia's equity markets plummeted as the coronavirus spread, with oil prices crashing. Citi downgraded Singapore banks to 'sell' and slashed target prices, while Singtel froze wages. Singapore Airlines and Emirates waived change fees for March flights. The S&P 500 fell 6%, with oil-related stocks taking a big hit. The US is set to announce higher tariffs on Vietnam's garment industry. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Equity markets collapsed on Monday as the rapidly spreading coronavirus fans fears over the global economy, while a crash in oil prices added to the panic with energy firms taking a hammering.

site_title: Malaysia picks bank CEO as finance minister in new Cabinet
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin appointed Zafrul Aziz, CEO of CIMB Group Holdings, as the new finance minister in a cabinet reshuffle amid heightened global risks and domestic policy uncertainty. Zafrul will lead a US$4.8 billion stimulus package to counter the economic damage from the coronavirus outbreak, which has weakened Malaysia's economy to a decade low. The appointment comes a week after the central bank lowered interest rates to counter the risks to the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 58.94 points to 1,424.16, with a massive 1,154 losers outnumbering 100 gainers. The trading volume was 6.4 billion lots worth RM3.4 billion.

site_title: ECB needs to look beyond banking giants for signs of financial risk lurking within the system
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has been criticized for being blind to potential financial risks in the euro zone banking system, specifically illiquid Level 2 and Level 3 assets such as interest rate swaps and unlisted equity investments. These assets are difficult to value and dispose of, and can be problematic during times of financial stress. Despite reducing bad loans from 6.8% to 2.9% since 2015, the ECB has been urged to look beyond major banking giants to identify these hidden risks, according to critics including the Bank of Italy.

site_title: Grab confirms one employee at Marina One office infected with Covid-19
summary: Grab confirms that one employee at its Marina One office in Singapore tested positive for Covid-19 on March 7, 2020. The employee, who is in hospital, does not handle day-to-day operations. All Marina One offices were closed, and deep cleaning was carried out. Employees in the affected offices are working from home until March 11. Grab is conducting contact tracing and prioritizing employee health.

site_title: Saudi Aramco shares open 10% lower as oil price crumbles
summary: Saudi Aramco shares plummeted 10% on Monday, marking the first time they fell below their initial public offering price, following Saudi Arabia's decision to slash oil prices and increase production. The move comes as oil prices dropped by a third, prompting concerns about the company's valuation and earnings. Analysts predict a 29% drop in net income and 38% below earlier estimates for 2020.

site_title: Dow slumps 2,000 points after oil shock
summary: The Dow Jones Industrials plummeted 2,000 points, or 5.51%, to 24,440.31, on March 9, 2020, amid a 22% slump in oil prices and concerns over a global recession. The S&P 500 fell 7% to its lowest since June 2019, and the Nasdaq Composite was on track for its biggest one-day percentage fall since 2011. Oil majors Chevron and Exxon Mobil led the declines, with the energy index falling 15.3% to its lowest level since August 2004.

site_title: Edtech startup Zookal raises A$15m from Koh Boon Hwee, Wee Hur
summary: Zookal, an Australia-based edtech startup, has secured A$15 million in Series B equity funding from investors Koh Boon Hwee and Wee Hur Holdings, bringing the total amount raised to A$25 million. The funds will be used to expand the engineering team and launch a monthly digital subscription for students. Zookal aims to reach 10 million students in Asia, making education more affordable and accessible, with plans to hit A$35 million in revenue this year.

site_title: SGX appoints Ng Yao Loong as deputy CFO from April 1
summary: SGX appoints Ng Yao Loong as deputy CFO, effective April 1, who will succeed Chng Lay Chew as CFO upon his retirement on Sept 30. Ng, formerly assistant managing director at the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will take on the role after seven years in senior positions.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases, CNY dinner at Safra Jurong biggest cluster
summary: Singapore reported 10 new COVID-19 cases, with six linked to a Feb 15 dinner at Joy Garden restaurant, now the largest cluster with 36 confirmed cases. The total number of confirmed cases stands at 160. Short-term visitors must now pay for treatment. Three patients have recovered, and 93 have been discharged. The health ministry will continue to waive testing fees for residents and long-term pass holders, but those admitted to public hospitals will need to pay for treatment.

site_title: Oil-related stocks take big hits on Monday, STI down 6%
summary: Singapore's STI fell 6% on Monday, with oil-related stocks taking the biggest hit due to sharp declines in oil prices. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and Russia failed to agree on output cuts amid the Covid-19 outbreak, leading to a 31.5% drop in crude benchmarks. This price war affected local oil-related stocks, resulting in a dismal session.

site_title: honestbee plans pizza joint despite staff going unpaid for February
summary: honestbee, a struggling startup, plans to open a pizza shop in Siglap despite not paying staff for February and owing them their final salary repayments. The company has shifted kitchen equipment and furniture to a shophouse unit and owns a wood-fired pizza oven purchased in 2018. honestbee's CEO, Ong Lay Ann, owns the shophouse, and the company will lease it for a year at the market rate. The pizza shop will offer fast food services for takeaway, utilizing existing technologies.

site_title: US, Russian oil producers to feel the squeeze as Saudis open oil tap
summary: Saudi Arabia has slashed export prices and signaled an output boost, sending Brent crude oil prices plummeting to their lowest since February 2016. The move is expected to give tough competition to Russian and US oil producers, who are already feeling the squeeze. Higher Middle Eastern oil production and lower prices will enhance choices, making it harder for other suppliers to sell their oil. Analysts predict harsh financial pain for US shale producers, with potential production declines and lower capital expenditures.

site_title: China signals progress in virus battle as Disney partially reopens
summary: China reported 40 new COVID-19 infections, the smallest increase since January, as the country's lockdown measures appear to be working. The country's death toll stands at 3,119, with nearly all fresh cases and 22 new deaths in Wuhan. China is considering lifting travel restrictions on Hubei province, which has kept 56 million people housebound. Disney's Shanghai resort partially reopened, while Ikea reopened 16 stores in China. Schools in some regions are set to reopen this week, and Wuhan's makeshift hospitals were closed, with some managers resuming work at the airport.

site_title: Lendlease names MD for data centre business
summary: Lendlease appoints Sam Lee as managing director of its data centre business, Lendlease Data Centre Partners, a $1 billion joint venture investing in Asia-Pacific data centres. Lee brings 20 years of experience in corporate real estate and asset management to the role, overseeing sourcing and development of new data centres across Singapore, Malaysia, Australia, China, and Japan. Lendlease CEO Tony Lombardo says Lee's expertise will drive the group's data centre strategy, augmenting its development, construction, and investment capabilities.

site_title: Thailand tourist arrivals in February fall 44.3% due to coronavirus
summary: Thailand's tourist arrivals fell 44.3% in February due to the coronavirus epidemic, with visitors from China plummeting 85.3%. The country's tourism industry is crucial to its economy, generating 11% of its GDP. The government has proposed a US$3.2 billion stimulus package to ease the impact, but Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced no cash handouts. Economists predict Southeast Asia's second-largest economy may grow less than 1% this year, down from 2.4% in 2019.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks plunge 4.2% on virus panic
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 4.2% on March 9, 2020, amid coronavirus fears and plummeting oil prices. The KOSPI index fell 85.45 points, marking its largest daily drop since October 2018. Foreign investors sold $1.09 billion worth of shares, citing panic selling. The number of global coronavirus cases surpassed 107,000, with South Korea reporting 69 new infections and one death, raising the national tally to 7,382 cases and 51 deaths. The KOSPI has fallen 11.05% this year.

site_title: China firm develops system to recognise faces behind coronavirus masks
summary: A Chinese firm, Hanwang Technology Ltd, has developed facial recognition technology that can identify people wearing masks, addressing a challenge in surveillance systems amid the coronavirus pandemic. The system, which can recognize individuals with a 95% accuracy rate while wearing a mask, has been rolled out to the market and is being used by the Ministry of Public Security to track individuals and detect crime suspects. The technology, which can identify people in a crowd of up to 30 within a second, also measures body temperature and can process results.

site_title: CH Offshore files notice of 3 years of consecutive losses
summary: CH Offshore, a vessel chartering firm, has filed a notice of three consecutive years of losses, with a loss of US$14.06 million in FY2019. The losses are attributed to an associate company and a provision for brokers' commission. The company is at risk of being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list due to its low market capitalization. CH Offshore's latest six-month average daily market capitalization is S$39.9 million, below the required S$40 million threshold. The company awaits notification from the SGX regarding potential listing on the watch list.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down more than 5% on virus fears, strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 5% on Monday due to fears over the novel coronavirus and a strong yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 5.07% to 19,698.76, while the Topix index fell 5.61% to 1,388.97. The decline was attributed to a plunge in oil prices and a weak dollar against the yen.

site_title: Cathay could fly freight-only services on passenger jets after Japan curbs
summary: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways may operate freight-only services on passenger jets to Japan, as the airline seeks to retain some services amid travel curbs due to the coronavirus. Japan's quarantine measures on Chinese and Hong Kong passport holders prompted Cathay to cut most flights to Japan for March. The airline is evaluating cargo operations, including retaining passenger services for cargo carriage only.

site_title: Senior management at China's Trip.com to take pay cuts
summary: China's largest online travel firm Trip.com has announced that senior management, including chairman James Liang and CEO Jane Sun, will take pay cuts of up to half their salary to cope with the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. The company, which has a strong liquidity reserve, will also suspend merit increases for most employees until the situation improves. This move is seen as a response to China's expected slowest economic growth in a decade due to the pandemic, which has killed over 3,600 people and spread globally.

site_title: Hesitation to digitalise causing Singapore SMEs to lose competitiveness
summary: Singapore SMEs are struggling to prepare for the digital economy due to hesitation and lack of resources. A QBE Insurance Singapore survey found that 57% of respondents believe financial support from the government is key to overcoming barriers to digitalisation, but only 31% utilized available government support in 2019. The survey also revealed that SMEs are concerned about digital risks such as data theft and intellectual property infringement, but few have insurance to protect against these issues. The government's Budget 2020 measures to help SMEs access more working capital and digitalise their business may not be fully utilized.

site_title: Gulf stock markets plunge at open on oil price crash
summary: Gulf stock markets plummeted on Monday, led by Dubai and Kuwait, as investors reacted to a 30% drop in oil prices following Saudi Arabia's price war with Russia. Dubai's benchmark index fell 9%, Abu Dhabi 7%, and Kuwait's premier index 9.5%. Analysts attributed the decline to low oil prices, low demand, and slowing global activity due to the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Australian PM mulls cash handout as part of fiscal stimulus: Sky News
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison is considering a cash handout as part of a proposed A$10 billion fiscal stimulus package to counter the economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak. The idea is facing opposition from Finance and Treasury officials, who are instead advocating for wage subsidies for small businesses and business tax incentives.

site_title: Singtel freezes all wages except for operational and support staff
summary: Singtel has implemented a wage freeze across its organization, excluding operational and support staff, in response to the financial challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Group CEO Chua Sock Koong stated that the move is necessary to strengthen financial resilience and eliminate costs. The company will also match staff donations to the Singtel Touching Lives Fund and contribute to other beneficiaries. Meanwhile, Singtel shares fell 4.1% on Monday, following the announcement.

site_title: Europe: London, Frankfurt stocks slump 8%; Paris sinks 4%
summary: The British and German stock markets plummeted, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 8.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index falling 8.1%, in response to crashing oil prices. In contrast, Paris's CAC 40 index declined 4.2%. This sell-off marked a significant downturn in European equities, with Milan's FTSE MIB experiencing a minor 0.3% decrease.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 4.23% on virus fears, oil price crash
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 4.23% on March 9, 2020, amid growing concerns over the coronavirus impact on the global economy. Energy firms were particularly hard hit due to a collapse in oil prices. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai index falling 3.01% and the Shenzhen index falling 3.79%. The downturn was attributed to fears about the economic impact of the virus.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index shed 4.23 per cent, or 1,106.21 points, to 25,040.46.

site_title: Solutions for sustainable healthcare financing in Asean
summary: Asean healthcare expenditure has increased by 250% despite lower life expectancy and Universal Health Coverage (UHC) index scores compared to developed nations. Research by KPMG Singapore suggests that countries can achieve the same life expectancy at 30% of current healthcare expenditures. The EU-Asean Business Council, KPMG in Singapore, and SANOFI launched the "Sustainable Financing Framework" to address sustainable healthcare financing in the region.

site_title: Australian F1 race without fans? Not a chance, say organisers
summary: The Australian Formula One race in Melbourne is set to proceed as planned, despite coronavirus fears. Organizers say there's "no chance" fans will be excluded, citing a record crowd of 86,000 at the Women's T20 World Cup final the previous night. Chief medical officer Brendan Murphy also stated there's no risk of community transmission in Victoria, allowing the event to proceed without restrictions. The event is expected to attract around 300,000 people, and teams are arriving from Italy, which has seen a surge in cases, but are expected to arrive safely.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI loses 4.5% on Monday afternoon
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 4.5% to 2,826.98 on Monday, its worst single-day performance since 2010. The decline was driven by concerns over the economic impact of Covid-19 and sharp oil price falls. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were particularly affected, with DBS falling 6.2%. The market saw a high volume of trading, with 1.15 billion securities traded, but all 30 bluechip counters were in the red.

site_title: Thailand says airlines may face virus medical bills in new rules
summary: Thailand's aviation regulator has introduced new rules requiring airlines to ask passengers from high-risk territories for health certificates before boarding flights. Passengers without documentation will be prevented from flying, and carriers will be liable for treatment costs if they fly someone who becomes sick with Covid-19. The new framework applies to six territories: China, Hong Kong, Macau, South Korea, Iran, and Italy. Travellers from these regions will undergo 14-day quarantine upon arrival, with more details to be announced.

site_title: Derivatives trading hits record high in Feb on Covid-19 concerns: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) derivatives daily average volume (DDAV) reached a record high in February at 1.2 million contracts, driven by concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. Total volume for the month was up 32% year-over-year, with equity index futures rising 26% and FX futures increasing 52%. The Straits Times Index posted a 4.4% decline, while ETF trading surged to S$356 million, more than three times the previous year. The market also saw the listing of two new companies, Elite Commercial Reit and Don Agro, which opened above their IPO prices.

site_title: Mapletree Investments gets 200m euro sustainability-linked OCBC loan
summary: Mapletree Investments has secured a 200 million euro sustainability-linked loan from OCBC Bank to fund working capital and corporate purposes. The loan is tied to ESG targets and will be reported annually. If targets are met, interest rates will be reduced. This is Mapletree's fourth sustainable finance transaction with OCBC, following the sponsorship of four Singapore-listed Reits and six private equity funds.

site_title: Hong Kong, China stocks end morning session with steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.50% in Monday's morning session, mirroring a rout across Asia due to novel coronavirus fears. The Hang Seng Index dropped 916.12 points to 25,230.55, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 73.22 points to 2,961.29. Energy firms were particularly hard hit by a crash in oil prices. The losses were in line with a decline in global markets, as traders reacted to ongoing concerns about the coronavirus.

site_title: Gyms and coronavirus: what are the risks?
summary: Gyms are taking precautions against the coronavirus, with many stepping up cleaning and disinfecting protocols, including using hospital-grade solutions. Equipment, such as barbells, can pose a risk of transmission if not properly disinfected. Experts recommend using diluted household bleach solutions, alcohol solutions, and common household disinfectants, and advise members to wipe down equipment after use. Additionally, frequent hand washing and avoiding close contact with others who may be sick are key to preventing transmission.

site_title: Malaysia names new anti-graft agency chief to lead 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysia has appointed Azam Baki as the new chief of its anti-graft agency, replacing Latheefa Koya, who led the 1MDB probe. Azam, a former deputy chief commissioner, will focus on recouping billions of dollars allegedly stolen from the state fund.

site_title: Gold wavers after topping US$1,700 amid market mayhem
summary: Gold prices surged to a 7-year high of nearly US$1,700 an ounce, before retreating, amid market volatility and expectations of easier monetary policy. The metal's price gain was driven by the spread of the coronavirus, sinking equities, and a collapse in oil prices. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets, with gold holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds reaching a record. The price increase follows a 18% surge in 2019, with Goldman Sachs predicting prices could reach US$1,800 an ounce.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hit new decade lows on oil, virus double whammy
summary: Australia and New Zealand currencies hit 11-year lows due to a slump in oil prices and coronavirus fears, driving investors to safe-haven bonds. The Australian dollar fell 1.4% to US$0.6547 and the New Zealand dollar fell 1.4% to US$0.6272. The Reserve Bank of Australia and Reserve Bank of New Zealand are expected to cut interest rates and consider unconventional monetary policies to mitigate the economic impact of the virus. The Australian government is set to unveil a fiscal stimulus package this week.

site_title: Dutch MH17 trial to start without suspects
summary: The trial of four men accused of murdering 298 people in the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014 is set to begin in the Netherlands without the suspects, who are still at large. Igor Girkin, Sergei Dubinsky, Oleg Pulatov, and Leonid Kharchenko, linked to pro-Russian separatists, face charges of murder and are expected to be tried in absentia. The trial, which could last a year, is seen as a significant step towards finding justice for the victims and their families, with international outrage over the tragedy still high.

site_title: SIA, Emirates waive change fees for March flights amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Emirates have waived change fees for March flights amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Emirates will waive fees for bookings made before March 31, 2020, allowing customers to change their itineraries without incurring penalties. SIA will also waive change fees for tickets bought between March 6 and March 31 for travel to and from all destinations. New travel dates must be booked before March 31, 2021, with fare differences to be paid.

site_title: US regulators will force Boeing to rewire 737 MAX jets: report
summary: US regulators plan to require Boeing to rewire all 737 MAX aircraft before allowing the planes to fly again. The MAX has been grounded worldwide since an Ethiopian Airlines flight crashed in March, following a similar fatal accident in Indonesia. The crashes were attributed to the anti-stall flight system, which investigators blame for uncontrolled nose drops. The rewire requirement is part of a broader effort to address safety concerns and allow the 737 MAX to regain certification.

site_title: Singapore banks close at new 52-week lows; Sibor falls
summary: Singapore banks closed at new 52-week lows on Monday, with DBS (down 8.04%), UOB (down 7.33%), and OCBC (down 6.76%). The three-month Sibor fell to 1.357% from 1.627% on March 3. Citi Research downgraded the banks to "sell" and expects short-term Fed interest rates to hit and stay at zero for nine months, squeezing net interest margins and raising asset quality risks.

site_title: South Korea warns about disorderly currency movements
summary: South Korea's finance ministry issued a warning about disorderly currency movements, citing excessive short-term speculation in the won. The won declined over 1% against the dollar, amid a global sell-off in riskier assets. The ministry is closely monitoring speculative transactions and urges investors to refrain from "herd-like behaviour" in the currency market. This verbal intervention is seen as an official warning to investors, highlighting the potential risks of disorderly market movements.

site_title: Petronas joins Exxon in seeking exit from Chad project: sources
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil giant Petronas is considering selling its 35% stake in a joint project in Chad with Exxon Mobil Corp, which includes oil fields and a pipeline. The project, completed in 2003, could be worth over $1 billion. Exxon is also exploring a sale of its 40% holdings. The move comes as Petronas shifts focus to the Americas to boost reserves. A deal could be affected by the massive plunge in oil prices, and both companies have declined to comment on the sale deliberations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 36.92 points or 2.49% to 1,446.18. Losers beat gainers 446 to 40, and volume reached 476.52 million lots worth RM109.28 million.

site_title: Alaska LNG passes major permitting milestone, hurdles remain
summary: The US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has released a final environmental impact statement (EIS) for Alaska Gasline Development Corp's proposed Alaska liquefied natural gas project. The report concludes that the project would provide economic benefits to the state but could cause significant adverse environmental impacts, including to permafrost, wetlands, and caribou. FERC is scheduled to issue its final order in June, and Alaska Governor Mike Dunleavy plans to review the report and evaluate next steps. The project, estimated to cost $43.4 billion, aims to liquefy 3.5 billion cubic feet of gas per day.

site_title: Hot stocks: Oil-related shares take beating after Riyadh sparks price war
summary: Oil-related shares plummeted in Singapore after Opec and Russia failed to agree on output cuts amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Saudi Arabia sparked a price war by slashing crude prices by $4-6 a barrel, resulting in a 25% drop in benchmark crude prices. Singapore-listed oil-related stocks, including Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries, slumped 7-9% in the session. Experts warn that oil prices could speed down to 2015/2016 levels if an agreement is not reached soon.

site_title: Coronavirus closed this Starbucks, but Seattle needs its coffee
summary: A Starbucks store in Seattle temporarily closed due to an employee testing positive for the coronavirus, prompting concerns among locals. The city has been hit hard by the outbreak, with 16 deaths in Washington state. The store's closure has affected daily routines, with many residents forced to adapt to new ways of gathering and working. While some, like a nurse, expressed concern over the economic impact, others, like a car salesman, found solace in their faith. The company has taken steps to reduce risk, including barring customers from using their own coffee containers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down more than 6% at break
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 6% at the break on Monday due to fears over the novel coronavirus and declining oil prices, which weakened the dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 6.15% and the Topix index fell 6.07%.

site_title: Asia markets collapse as virus spreads, oil prices crash
summary: Asia's equity markets plummeted on March 9, 2020, as the rapidly spreading coronavirus fueled fears over the global economy. Oil prices crashed, with Saudi Arabia slashing prices by $4-$6 per barrel, further exacerbating the decline. Energy firms suffered significant losses, while gold and the yen surged. The US Treasury yields hit new record lows, and trading floors were a sea of red, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Australia experiencing declines of over 5-7%. Analysts warn of a worldwide recession and further market volatility as the outbreak continues to spread.

site_title: Australia: Stocks plunge 7.3% at Monday close on oil rout, virus fears
summary: Australian stocks plummeted 7.3% on Monday due to fears over the novel coronavirus and plummeting oil prices, marking the worst day since the 2008 global financial crisis. The ASX 200 index closed at 5,760.60, while the All Ordinaries finished at 5,822.40. The decline was attributed to concerns over the spread of the coronavirus and the impact on the global economy.

site_title: Japan monitoring market moves as stocks plunge, yen soars: Suga
summary: Japan is closely monitoring market moves amid a 5% plunge in its benchmark Nikkei average and a 3% surge in the yen against the dollar, driven by concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that the government will take necessary measures for the economy without hesitation. He declined to comment on stock prices and foreign exchange. The yen reached a high of 101.69 against the dollar.

site_title: South Korea sees lowest new virus infections for 2 weeks
summary: South Korea reported its lowest new virus infections for two weeks, with 248 confirmed cases on Sunday, bringing the total to 7,382. This marks the fourth consecutive day of declining cases, with the lowest figure since late February. The country has had 51 deaths, with most cases linked to the Shincheonji Church of Jesus, a secretive religious group. Despite the relatively low fatality rate, scores of events have been cancelled or postponed nationwide due to the contagion.

site_title: France bans gatherings of more than 1,000 over virus fears: minister
summary: France has banned gatherings of more than 1,000 people in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus, as the French death toll reached 19. Health Minister Olivier Veran stated that officials will issue a list of events considered "useful to national life" that will be allowed to continue, such as demonstrations.

site_title: Uber, delivery services to compensate drivers who catch virus
summary: Multiple rideshare and food delivery companies, including Uber, DoorDash, and Instacart, plan to compensate their drivers who contract the new coronavirus. Uber has already started this process, offering up to 14 days of compensation to drivers diagnosed with Covid-19 or quarantined by health authorities. Other companies are in discussions to implement similar measures, marking a shift in how they treat their drivers as they prioritize health and safety amid the global health crisis.

site_title: As one of China's 'Detroits' reopens, world's automakers worry about disruptions
summary: China's Wuhan, a major automotive hub, is reopening after a coronavirus lockdown, but the car industry faces disruptions due to supply chain issues and staffing shortages. Factories remain on lockdown until March 11, and companies are concerned about accessing raw materials and workers. Automakers, including Honda and General Motors, have partially resumed production in other Chinese cities, but are still running below capacity. The potential disruptions could have significant long-term effects on the industry, with nearly 97% of companies in Hubei saying they will be bankrupt in three months if operations are not restored.

site_title: Indian Wells tennis cancelled over novel coronavirus concerns
summary: The ATP and WTA tennis tournament in Indian Wells, California, has been cancelled due to concerns over the novel coronavirus. Organisers had planned to implement extra health measures but decided to cancel after California's Riverside County declared a public health emergency in the area following a confirmed case of Covid-19. This is the first major US sports event to be cancelled due to the virus. The tournament was set to begin on Wednesday, with the health and safety of participants and the local community being the primary concern.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down over 3% on virus fears, oil prices
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 3% on Monday due to fears of the new coronavirus and declining oil prices, which also saw the dollar drop against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 3.41% to 20,041.83 and the Topix index dropped 3.24% to 1,423.83.

site_title: Covid-19: SIA cabin crew to wear surgical mask on board as safety precaution
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) cabin crew are now required to wear surgical masks on board as a safety precaution amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The measure, implemented from March 7, comes after two crew members were found to be infected with the virus. SIA had previously allowed crew to wear masks voluntarily, but now mandates their use to minimize risks for customers and staff. The airline has also taken other measures, including redirecting flights and stepping up cleaning regimes.

site_title: North Korea fires 3 projectiles: South's military
summary: North Korea fired three unidentified projectiles into the sea on Monday, marking the second such test in a week. The projectiles were launched from the Sondok area in South Hamgyong province in a northeasterly direction. The move comes as North Korea continues to refine its weapons capabilities during stalled nuclear discussions with the US. Analysts say the launch is a significant milestone for the North's short-range ballistic missile programme, with some speculating that Kim Jong Un may be preparing for a demonstration of a new strategic weapon.

site_title: Cruise ship heads to Singapore after rebuff by Malaysia, Thailand over virus fears
summary: A Costa Fortuna cruise ship is heading to Singapore after being rebuffed by Malaysia and Thailand due to concerns over the novel coronavirus. The ship, homeported in Singapore, departed on March 3 and will make a scheduled stop on March 10 as planned. Costa Crociere confirmed the ship's journey would continue to Singapore to end its voyage, despite being turned away from ports in Malaysia and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Those who are identified for testing but refuse to do so will be disallowed entry into Singapore.

site_title: Japan Q4 GDP revised down to 7.1% annualised contraction
summary: Japan's economy shrank 7.1% in the fourth quarter of 2020, revised from an initial 6.3% contraction. This is worse than economists' median forecast of a 6.6% decline. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP fell 1.8%, compared to the initial 1.6% contraction. The revised data highlights Japan's ongoing economic struggles.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge 3.8% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.8% at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1,012.60 points to 25,134.02. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.56% and 1.66%, respectively, due to coronavirus fears and a crash in oil prices. The declines were attributed to a weak global market sentiment and ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Sasseur Reit to reopen Kunming outlet mall after virus-related closure
summary: Sasseur Real Estate Investment Trust's Kunming outlet mall will reopen on March 11 after receiving approval from local authorities. The Reit's sponsor has also reopened five other outlet malls in other cities. This marks the return of the outlet mall to operations after a virus-related closure. The Reit's manager is working to reopen its remaining outlet malls in Chongqing, Bishan, and Hefei.

site_title: Pimco's Fel's says worst is to come with recession forecast
summary: Pimco's global chief economic adviser Joachim Fels warns of the "worst for the economy" still to come, citing a high risk of a technical recession in the first half due to the coronavirus outbreak. The US and Europe face dampened demand and supply, driving investors to safe havens, with Fels previously stating a 35% chance of recession in the next 24 months. Global markets are uncertain, with US stocks falling into correction territory and Treasury rates hitting an all-time low, amid an oil-price war and China's manufacturing slump.

site_title: Accrelist: CPIB probing S$5,000 annual hongbao to unit's customer
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) is probing Accrelist and its subsidiary Jubilee Industries Holdings regarding a S$5,000 hongbao given to a customer during a Chinese New Year dinner. The probe also includes a S$5,000 hongbao given by Honfoong Plastic Industries, a Jubilee subsidiary. Executive chairman Terence Tea and senior management staff Serene Tea Lay Sin and Natasha Teh have denied any wrongdoing. Their passports were initially surrendered, but were released after a paper bail sum was raised.

site_title: Citi downgrades Singapore banks to 'sell'; trio down 4%
summary: Citi Research downgraded Singapore banks to "sell" due to expectations of low short-term Fed interest rates and potential dividend cuts. The downgrade resulted in a 4% drop in shares, with DBS down to S$21.99, UOB to S$22.26, and OCBC to S$9.81. This is a rare "sell" call on the Singapore banks, following Citi's previous downgrade on March 4.

site_title: The fried chicken king of Asia loses US$2b on American gamble
summary: Philippine tycoon Tony Tan Caktiong's Jollibee Foods Corp has suffered significant losses, with its US$2 billion market value wiped off due to a decline in its US expansion and the coronavirus outbreak. The company's shares have dropped 18% this year, adding to its losses in 2019, its worst in two decades. Jollibee's US acquisitions, including Smashburger and Coffee Bean, have been money-losing, and the outbreak in China is threatening its sales. Despite efforts to narrow losses, Jollibee's valuation has shrunk to 28 times estimated earnings, making it one of the least-loved Philippine stocks.

images.alt_text: If 2019 was a bad year for Tony Tan Caktiong, the Philippine tycoon who built a fast-food empire that trounced McDonald's in his home market, 2020 is shaping out to be worse for his company's stock.

site_title: Gulf shares in panic sell-off after Opec+ failure
summary: The Gulf region experienced a panic sell-off after Opec's failure to agree on a production cut plan, prompting fears of an oil price war. Shares in Saudi Aramco plummeted below their IPO price, and the Saudi market dived 7.7% on its first day of trading. Other Gulf markets, including Dubai, Abu Dhabi, and Qatar, also declined significantly, with the Dubai market shedding 8.5% and the Qatar Stock Exchange dropping 3.5%. The price cuts by Saudi Arabia are seen as a response to Russia's exit from output cuts, and analysts predict a bloodbath in the energy market.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall most in over 11 years on virus fears, oil price crash
summary: Australian shares plummeted 5.6% on Monday, the largest intraday drop in 11 years, amid fears of a deeper economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak and a 20% oil price crash. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 338.50 points, or 5.5%, with energy stocks suffering their biggest ever intraday percentage drop. The country has recorded 60 coronavirus cases, with two deaths, and the prime minister warned of a potential $661 million treatment bill.

site_title: Will IoT be the answer to the looming food crisis?
summary: A growing number of farmers in Southeast Asia are turning to the Internet of Things (IoT) to increase food production and meet the demands of a global population expected to reach 9.1 billion by 2050. IoT-powered agri-tech combines data from sensor grids, analytics platforms, and machine learning to optimize farming practices and reduce waste. However, a significant gap exists in tailoring digital solutions to meet farmers' specific needs, hindering large-scale IoT implementation in the region. To address this, a shift towards building scalable and affordable digital solutions that create meaningful outcomes is necessary.

site_title: Global CO2 emissions from power sector fell 2% last year: study
summary: Global carbon dioxide emissions from the power sector fell 2% last year, the largest decline since at least 1990, according to a study by Ember. This drop was driven by reduced coal usage in Europe and the US, with coal-fired power generation falling 3% globally and 24% in Europe. However, China saw a rise in coal-fired power generation, accounting for half of global coal-fired power generation. To keep within a 1.5°C warming limit, coal generation needs to fall by 11% annually, and governments must accelerate the transition to renewable energy sources.

site_title: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta 2019 pay up 2% to S$12.1m
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta's 2019 salary rose 2% to S$12.13 million, reflecting an increase of about S$230,000 from the previous year. This marks his 10th year at Singapore's largest bank. Additionally, Gupta made a personal donation of S$500,000 to the Community Chest, citing support for communities in Singapore during challenging times.

site_title: Boeing's new CEO regrets blasting predecessor
summary: Boeing's new CEO, Dave Calhoun, has apologized for criticizing his predecessor, Dennis Muilenburg, in a recent interview, calling his comments "embarrassing and regretful." Calhoun had previously slammed Muilenburg for making "bets that were too risky" and damaging relationships with customers and regulators. The backlash has raised concerns about potential negligence claims and may lead to Congressional hearings. Calhoun's apology aims to distance himself from previous decisions and clear the way for Boeing's recovery, but some see it as a calculated move that strained credulity given his long tenure on the board.

site_title: Air New Zealand scraps earnings outlook as virus impact mounts
summary: Air New Zealand scrapped its annual earnings outlook due to the worsening impact of the coronavirus, citing "additional softness in demand" outside China. The airline previously warned of a potential NZ$150 million loss, but now believes the financial impact will be more significant. Flights into Asia are down 26% and services across its network have been cut by 10%. The airline has implemented measures such as a hiring freeze and unpaid leave to mitigate the effects, with its CEO offering to reduce his base salary by 15%. An updated earnings outlook is expected.

site_title: Oil down about 20% after Saudi price cuts
summary: Oil prices plummeted about 20% on Monday after Saudi Arabia cut its oil prices by $4-6 per barrel to Asia and $7 to the US, in response to Opec's failure to agree on production cuts. West Texas Intermediate fell to around $32 a barrel and Brent crude to around $36 a barrel. The move is seen as an "all-out oil war" by Saudi Arabia, with Bloomberg reporting the largest cut in 20 years. The failure to agree on production cuts is attributed to Moscow's refusal to tighten supply.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SATS, Sasseur Reit, UOB, Roxy-Pacific, BreadTalk
summary:
Key developments in Singapore stocks on March 9, 2020, include: 
- Singtel, AIS, and SK Telecom teaming up for a regional gaming joint venture, potentially engaging 800 million gamers.
- SATS announcing a 15% pay cut for its president and CEO amid further financial cuts, affecting fourth-quarter and full-year results.
- Sasseur Reit reopening its Kunming outlet mall on March 11 after local authority approval.
- UOB launching a savings account offering complimentary medical insurance for six female-related cancers.
- Roxy-Pacific disposing of a retail building in Japan for S$113 million.
- BreadTalk Group appointing an independent financial adviser for a voluntary cash offer to take the company private.

site_title: UK coronavirus cases rises by 30% to 273, third person dies
summary: The UK has seen a 30% increase in coronavirus cases to 273, with a third person dying after testing positive. The largest concentration of cases is in London, with 51 confirmed cases. The government has announced plans to invest in the health service and support companies struggling with short-term cash flow problems. Supermarkets have implemented measures to prevent shortages, and the environment minister will hold a call with industry representatives to discuss support for vulnerable groups. The government also plans to introduce emergency legislation to protect jobs in the health service.

images.alt_text: The number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in the United Kingdom rose by 30 per cent to 273, the government said on Sunday, and a third person who tested positive for the virus has died.

site_title: Money FM podcast: SBF launches scheme to help firms manage manpower needs during virus outbreak
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) launched a manpower management scheme to help firms cope with the COVID-19 outbreak. The initiative aims to support businesses in managing their workforce during the pandemic.

site_title: More pay cuts at SATS amid Covid-19; sees substantial impact to Q4, FY results
summary: SATS, an airport and food services provider, has implemented a series of pay cuts, including a 15% reduction for its president and CEO, amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its fourth-quarter and full-year results. The company expects substantial and adverse effects on profitability, with a drop in revenue across all markets. SATS is in a strong position to weather disruptions and is looking for opportunities in the crisis, despite a negative hit to short-term earnings.

site_title: India's Yes Bank founder arrested on money laundering allegations
summary: Yes Bank founder Rana Kapoor was arrested on Sunday on money laundering allegations, amid efforts to rescue the country's fourth-largest private lender. The Reserve Bank of India seized control of Yes Bank and imposed withdrawal limits of 50,000 rupees per 30 days. Kapoor was questioned for over 20 hours by the Enforcement Directorate before his arrest. The State Bank of India is ready to invest 24.5 billion rupees in Yes Bank as part of a rescue plan, and 23 potential investors have expressed interest in investing. Kapoor's arrest follows Yes Bank's struggles with bad loans and a liquidity crunch.

images.alt_text: The founder of India's Yes Bank was arrested on allegations of money laundering on Sunday, amid efforts to formulate a rescue plan for the country's fourth-largest private lender.

site_title: Emirates expects coronavirus to impact financial performance: internal notice
summary: Emirates airline expects its financial performance to be impacted by the coronavirus outbreak, according to an internal notice. The Dubai state-owned carrier has suspended flights to Iran and most of mainland China, citing a global drop in air travel. The airline reported a surge in half-year profit last November, but expects financial impacts due to reduced passenger numbers and increased costs. Emirates is reviewing routes, downgrading capacity, and taking out unprofitable flights to mitigate the effects of the virus.

site_title: Coronavirus may force Americans to avoid crowds, brace for quarantines, health official warns
summary: A top US health official warns Americans to brace for crowds and potential quarantines as the coronavirus spreads through US communities. With 19 US deaths and 450 reported cases, Anthony Fauci says 400,000 more tests will be available by Monday and 4 million by the end of the week. He cautions vulnerable individuals to limit travel and suggests the possibility of large-scale quarantines cannot be ruled out. The US Surgeon General also notes that cases will rise, with the average age of death being 80, and urges communities to prepare for more cases to prevent deaths.

site_title: Buybacks and director acquisitions surge
summary: Singaporean stocks experienced a 3.0% decline in the five-trading sessions from Feb 28 to March 5, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 6.2% in total return for 2020. In contrast, the iEdge S-Reit Index gained 3.3% due to the US interest rate cut. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Medics to board virus-hit California ship ahead of docking
summary: Medical officers are set to board the Grand Princess, a virus-hit cruise ship off California, to screen passengers for a "two-three day" operation. The ship has 21 confirmed novel coronavirus infections among 3,500 people on board. Passengers in need of hospitalization will be moved immediately to medical centers, while those not requiring treatment will be moved to military bases for a 14-day isolation period. Several hundred foreign passengers will be repatriated to their countries, and crew will remain quarantined on the ship.

site_title: Covid-19 coverage - with caveats
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has spread globally, with over 103,000 confirmed cases and more than 80,000 in China, resulting in over 3,500 deaths worldwide. Most common insurance policies have an exclusion on infectious diseases if it's a "known" event, leading banks and major insurers to extend assistance packages for existing clients. The World Health Organization reports 95 countries affected.

site_title: Iran Air says suspending European flights
summary: Iran Air has suspended all flights to Europe until further notice, citing "restrictions" imposed by European authorities for "unknown reasons". The decision comes as the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) previously banned Iran Air aircraft from European airspace due to necessary upgrades. The move follows a surge in Covid-19 cases in Iran, with 49 new deaths reported in the past 24 hours. The carrier's European flights include destinations such as Paris, London, and Stockholm, and the suspension affects multiple flights per week.

site_title: Saudis plan big oil output hike, starting price war
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to increase oil output to over 10 million barrels per day, responding to the collapse of its Opec+ alliance with Russia. The kingdom has started a price war by slashing pricing for its crude for foreign markets by the most in at least 20 years, offering unprecedented discounts to entice refiners to purchase Saudi crude. This move aims to boost Saudi oil exports and counter the influence of other oil suppliers, particularly Russia.

site_title: Sydney Opera House goes quiet . . . finally
summary: The Sydney Opera House has finally stopped making noise, with a recent visit by Lou Rosicky revealing a previously hidden mechanical system beneath the iconic structure. The system, which includes pipes, wires, and machinery, has been servicing the building's various systems since its construction in the 1960s. This marks a significant change for the Opera House, which has long been known for its distinctive sounds and vibrations. The exact cause of the noise is not specified, but it is believed to be related to the building's age and maintenance needs.

site_title: S$50m adviser fee pot linked to scheme timing, Hyflux asset value: Utico
summary: Utico, a potential white knight for Hyflux, has clarified that it plans to pay S$50 million as part of the restructuring agreement to "save time and money" by passing the scheme early. However, this amount is contingent on the timing of the scheme and the loss of value at Hyflux, which could reduce the payout to S$30 million. Utico's intention is to pay S$40 million initially, but the increased amount of S$50 million is being considered to accelerate the deal.

site_title: Climate crisis on back-burner as concerns grow about outbreak
summary: A global health emergency from the novel coronavirus outbreak has led to a temporary reduction in carbon pollution from China and beyond, with CO2 emissions falling by 25% and coal consumption declining by 36% in the past four weeks. However, experts warn that this reduction is short-lived and will be offset by increased economic spending on infrastructure projects, making it difficult to achieve the Paris Agreement's temperature targets. The crisis has drained the global economy of $9 trillion in value and could cost up to $2.7 trillion, making mitigation efforts harder.

site_title: Brazil: Women in several cities march against Bolsonaro
summary: Women in several Brazilian cities marched against President Jair Bolsonaro on International Women's Day, protesting his policies that have taken away women's rights, particularly those affecting workers. The protesters, including Marcela Azevedo from the group Women in Combat, criticized Bolsonaro's machismo and mocking of women. The marches were a response to the government's policies, which the protesters deemed unacceptable.

site_title: UOB, Prudential launch account with insurance
summary: UOB and Prudential Singapore have launched a savings account offering complimentary medical insurance for six female-related cancers, believed to be the first in Singapore. The UOB Lady's Savings Account provides coverage of S$1,000 to S$200,000 based on monthly average balance, and includes perks such as subsidized doctor visits and free annual health screenings. The move aims to address a 2017 survey finding that over 40% of women in Singapore lack critical illness protection, with an 80% protection gap in the country.

site_title: Italy set to impose lockdown on 16m people
summary: Italy is set to impose a lockdown on approximately 16 million people in the region around Milan, effective until April 3, amid a surge in coronavirus cases (5,883 on Saturday with 233 deaths). The restrictions, announced by Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, include bans on public gatherings, travel, and non-essential businesses, with severe penalties for non-compliance. The move comes as Italy's economy teeters on the brink of recession and the government struggles to contain the rapidly evolving national emergency.

site_title: UK finance minister signals huge response to virus crisis in Budget
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak signaled a massive response to the coronavirus crisis in the upcoming Budget, potentially ditching fiscal rules to borrow more and support the economy. Interest rates are low, allowing for borrowing, and Sunak acknowledged the official forecasts may be outdated due to the virus. He emphasized the government's fiscal responsibility but stated it can take "whatever action is required" to help tackle the crisis, sparking speculation about coordinated action, including interest-rate cuts.

site_title: Gray Kunz, Singapore-born Swiss chef who fused French and Asian cuisine, dies
summary: Gray Kunz, a Swiss-born Singaporean chef who fused French and Asian cuisine, has died at 65 after suffering a stroke. Kunz, who was known for his innovative cooking style and leadership in fine dining, worked at restaurants in Hong Kong, New York, and Shanghai. His cuisine combined "Old World" comforts with "aggressive" and "exciting" flavors, earning him a four-star review from The New York Times in 1994. Kunz was a pioneer in using Asian ingredients in fine dining and was a mentor to many young chefs, including Andrew Carmellini and Corey Lee.

site_title: Millionaires boost trading at Asia's private banks amid outbreak
summary: The coronavirus outbreak has led to a surge in trading activity among Asia's super-rich, boosting revenue for private banks such as Citigroup, UBS, and JPMorgan Chase. With travel restrictions and reduced golf activities, wealthy clients have more time to review their portfolios and trade stocks, resulting in a 30% increase in trading at JPMorgan's Asia private bank in February. The trading surge has also led to increased demand for structured products and currency trading, with some clients holding over 20% in cash to reduce risk.

site_title: Shipping group CMA CGM sees limited virus impact as China activity resumes
summary: French shipping group CMA CGM expects its operations in China to return to normal after the Covid-19 outbreak, with fleet capacity expected to return from mid-March. Despite market concerns, CMA CGM forecasts a limited impact on its performance this year, citing restocking and freight rate increases. The company's chief financial officer believes the longer-term effects of the virus will not be structural, and it is confident for 2020, with a potential financial impact estimated at 2-3% of 2019 core earnings.

site_title: 12 new coronavirus cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 12 new coronavirus cases, nine linked to a private dinner function at Safra Jurong, with 30 cases now confirmed in the cluster. Eight of the new cases are over 60 years old. There are 150 confirmed cases, with 90 recovered and 60 still in hospital, mostly stable or improving. The Health Ministry has identified 3,649 close contacts, with 615 currently quarantined.

site_title: Shoot now and risk firing blanks: Lagarde's Covid-19 dilemma at ECB
summary: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde is set to decide whether to cut the euro area's benchmark interest rate from minus 0.5% amid the coronavirus crisis. The decision comes after the Federal Reserve slashed interest rates, and investors are seeking more stimulus. Economists are split on the issue, with some forecasting a 10-basis-point cut and others expecting no change. The ECB may consider additional measures, such as stepping up quantitative easing or providing incentives for banks to fund virus-hit firms. Lagarde's decision will be crucial in addressing the economic impact of the crisis and maintaining financial stability.

images.alt_text: While Ms Lagarde has pledged to do what's needed, the limited space for monetary policy at the ECB puts her in a much tighter bind than her international peers.

site_title: Covid-19 pushes job interviews for college students online
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is forcing US colleges to adjust their job recruiting strategies, with some employers switching to virtual interviews and others cancelling in-person campus visits. Companies like Intel, Amazon, and PwC are adopting remote formats to reduce exposure risks. Many colleges are also implementing measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including prohibiting non-essential travel and cancelling events. While some schools have already finished their main job fairs, others are adapting to the new norms, with career centers advising students to politely decline handshakes and opting for virtual networking instead.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics eyes 'smart' factories to stay ahead
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a company that manufactures consumable parts and tools for the semiconductor industry, is investing in research and development to maintain its edge in the market. The company's CEO, Chris Borch, believes that automation and smart factories are key to boosting production without increasing headcount. Micro-Mechanics is also expanding its presence in the US market and has a strong client base, including Intel and Tokyo Electron. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, the company remains optimistic about its prospects and expects to see growth in the semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: Micro-Mechanics' factory in Suzhou has reopened after being closed for three weeks due to Covid-19. CEO Chris Borch says business has been encouraging, and things could look a lot better next quarter.

site_title: Infineon deal scrutiny raises trade threat to Europe tech firms
summary: US officials are scrutinizing Infineon Technologies AG's $8.7 billion acquisition of Cypress Semiconductor Corp., citing national security concerns and the potential for advanced US technology to fall into Chinese hands. The Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS) is urging President Donald Trump to block the deal, which could threaten Europe's ability to create its own semiconductor giants. This move raises a trade threat to European tech firms, including Infineon, which has Chinese customers such as Huawei Technologies Co.

site_title: Building a better tomorrow for women
summary: A Singaporean coffee company, Bettr Barista, has been helping marginalized women gain emotional strength and confidence through its holistic training program. The company, which is the first Certified B Corp in Singapore, has seen 70% of its workforce be women and 40% be graduates of the program. Through partnerships with DBS Bank, the company aims to create a sustainable and positive impact on the lives of women, with a multiplier effect on their families and future generations.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights grim vessel demand, low fixing levels, and softening bunker prices in the tanker and dry bulk markets. The Capesize market remains little changed, with voyage rates at new lows. The North Atlantic Basin shows signs of tightening, but low fixing volumes. The Panamax market saw better rates, with healthy fixture volume in the Atlantic and firmer bids. Supramax/Ultramax vessels saw improved rates, with demand for Supramax vessels to Algeria and Ultramaxes covering Far East trips. Handysize vessels saw improved rates in the Atlantic Basin, with a 34,000dwt ship fixed from Southwest Passero.

site_title: JPMorgan sees 'early signs' of stress on credit and funding
summary: JPMorgan strategist Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou warns of "early signs" of stress on credit and funding markets due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Supply chain disruptions and demand shocks are causing cash-flow problems for businesses, especially smaller companies and those in sectors like travel and lodging. If sustained, these shifts could amplify the economic fallout, leading to increased risk of ratings downgrades, defaults, and credit channel amplification. Market concerns are justified by rising median net-debt-to-Ebitda ratios, making companies more vulnerable to economic downturns.

site_title: Covid-19 to remain the top concern for investors
summary: Covid-19 cases in Europe and the US continue to rise, causing investors to remain unsettled, despite recent monetary and fiscal stimulus measures. The Dow Jones fell 1%, the S&P 500 1.7%, and the Nasdaq 1.9% last Friday. Singapore's Straits Times Index also fell 1.9% due to concerns over the outbreak's impact on the city-state's growth prospects. Analysts suggest that value in some listings has emerged after recent sell-offs, but growth prospects for the STI are expected to be lower, with a 4% growth forecast for 2020.

site_title: China says reports it fired laser at US plane last month untrue
summary: China's Ministry of Defence has denied reports that a Chinese warship fired a laser at a US surveillance aircraft in international waters west of Guam last month. The US Pacific Fleet had previously reported the incident, but China claims the US aircraft ignored warnings and endangered personnel, and that all Chinese actions were safe and professional. The incident occurred during a routine Chinese naval drill.

site_title: US excludes Chinese face masks, medical gear from tariffs as coronavirus spreads
summary: The US Trade Representative's office has granted exclusions from import tariffs for dozens of medical products, including face masks, hand sanitizing wipes, and examination gloves, imported from China. The exclusions were expedited amid the rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak, with many approvals granted within a month of application. The medical products were subject to a 15% tariff rate, which was lowered to 7.5% as part of the Phase 1 US-China trade agreement. The exclusions apply to about $370 billion worth of Chinese imports, excluding 25% duties on goods valued at around $250 billion.

site_title: Turkish central bank changes reserve requirement to channel loans to productive sectors
summary: The Turkish central bank adjusted reserve requirements to encourage lending to productive sectors, aiming to support sustainable growth and financial stability. The changes will focus on sectors like agriculture, manufacturing, and transportation, and are intended to reduce the impact of consumer loan growth on inflation and the current account balance. This move comes after the central bank signaled its intention to use macroprudential tools to curb rising consumer loan supply.

site_title: No more refills: Airlines in US step up measures to guard against Covid-19
summary: US airlines are implementing measures to prevent Covid-19 spread on planes, including eliminating wine and water refills, and limiting passenger interaction with serving trays and food baskets. Flight attendants will provide new cups or glasses for refills instead of bringing in personal bottles. These changes aim to reduce person-to-person contamination and enhance passenger safety.

site_title: FCOT should wait until DPU reflects AEI benefits before merging with FLT
summary: A Reit merger should wait until DPU reflects AEI benefits, not just market price. Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) proposed merger with Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) is protested due to FCOT's units not fully reflecting its underlying value and cash generating potential. FCOT's asset enhancement initiatives (AEIs) at Alexandra Technopark and China Square Central have yet to be fully reflected in DPU and market price. A merger without these reflected benefits may not be fair to unitholders.

site_title: Bigger correction to DAX expected
summary: The Deutsche Boerse AG German Stock Index (DAX) is expected to experience a bigger correction due to its failure to reach the psychological price target of 14,000 points in 2019. The index has weakened despite a strong run in 2019 and has been affected by the global Covid-19 pandemic, with a 11% drop in a single week. Technical analysis suggests a long-term weakness in the DAX, with a possible bullish pick-up after a rebound at a demand level, but also a likelihood of further downside below the 10,000 mark in the next two quarters of 2020.

site_title: China virus fight sparks outcry over female frontline staff
summary: China's fight against the coronavirus has sparked outrage over the neglect of female frontline staff, who face issues with menstrual products, ill-fitting equipment, and being given birth control pills to delay their periods. Women have rallied against discriminatory measures, with thousands of sanitary products donated to frontline workers and criticism of propaganda videos and hospital officials turning down donations. The incident has highlighted the growing public awareness of gender equality in China, with activists arguing that such portrayals "erase" women by reinforcing stereotypes.

site_title: Fear of fear grips markets as spread of outbreak shows no sign of slowing
summary: The global market experienced a wild week, with the US stock market finishing relatively flat despite a significant correction, while the Treasury market saw a surge in safe-haven long-term bonds. The spread of the coronavirus outbreak shows no signs of slowing, with over 106,000 cases diagnosed worldwide. Investors fear that precautions taken by businesses and consumers will cause a sharp economic slowdown, leading to a possible recession. The US Federal Reserve's emergency interest rate cut did little to ease fears, and the global economy's ability to recover quickly without a painful recession remains uncertain.

site_title: US$ hammered as US Treasury yields sink
summary: The US dollar fell to a 13-month low, posting its biggest weekly loss in four years, as US government bond yields dropped, hurting the greenback's appeal. The dollar index fell 0.7% to 95.995, down 2.2% for the week, its largest weekly decline since May 2016. This decline was attributed to the sharp drop in US government bond yields, making the dollar less attractive to investors.

site_title: Petrochemical sector faces drop in demand, rather than supply
summary: Singapore's petrochemical sector is more likely to face a drop in demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite supply chain disruptions in other industries. The Chinese market, which accounts for 40% of Singapore's petrochemical exports, is expected to see a slowdown in demand, with estimates suggesting a 350,000-1 million tonne drop in polyethylene demand. However, Singapore's petrochemical supply is expected to be ample due to its integrated ecosystem on Jurong Island, with companies able to source feedstock and sell products locally.

images.alt_text: While supply chain delays and disruptions have hit manufacturers in industries like electronics, Singapore's petrochemical sector is more likely to suffer from a drop in demand.

site_title: Thailand's 2020 growth could be nearly flat due to virus, says Citi
summary: Thailand's 2020 growth is expected to be nearly flat due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to Citi economist Nalin Chutchotitham. This is attributed to a 15.4% decline in tourist arrivals and a 18% drop in revenues. The impact of China's ban on outbound group tours is expected to last through the second quarter, erasing 60-70% of Thailand's arrivals from China.

images.alt_text: Thailand's growth could be virtually flat in 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on tourism, said Citi economist Nalin Chutchotitham in a March 1 note. She revised her full-year estimate to 0.2 per cent, down from 2.2 per cent previously.

site_title: (Driving) towards a greener future
summary: Singapore plans to phase out internal combustion engine vehicles by 2040, aiming to create a more sustainable economy. However, experts argue that making electric vehicles (EVs) cheaper is not enough, citing the need for ubiquitous charging infrastructure, trained mechanics, and reduced upfront costs. A car-lite society, where EVs and public transport are the primary modes of transportation, is the ultimate goal. To achieve this, the government should lower the cost of EVs and make bus and train travel free.

site_title: Meet Thailand's secret weapon in climate change battle
summary: Renowned architect Kotchakorn Voraakhom is working to mitigate Bangkok's vulnerability to climate change. The Thai capital is predicted to be one of the hardest hit cities globally by 2100, with rising sea levels and rapid urban growth posing significant threats. Voraakhom's approach emphasizes mindful development and sustainable design, as seen in her firm's Chulalongkorn University Centenary Park, which captures and filters rainwater. She aims to bring about change in Bangkok, which she believes has a "chance to make a difference" before it's too late, with the goal of creating a more sustainable future for generations to come.

images.alt_text: "At this moment we have a chance to make change . . . We have to do it right now to show the coming generations that this is possible. It is not about sitting and waiting and doing the same thing." - Kotchakorn Voraakhom, a renowned architect who preaches mindful development over mindless construction.

site_title: Amazon says working with state AGs to nab sellers engaged in price-gouging over coronavirus
summary: Amazon is working with state attorneys general to identify and prosecute third-party sellers engaging in price-gouging on the Amazon website, particularly over coronavirus-related products. Over 530,000 product offers have been removed due to price-gouging concerns, and "millions" of products making unsupported claims about fighting the virus have also been removed. Amazon has suspended thousands of accounts of price-gouging sellers and will conduct manual audits to spot evaders.

site_title: Covid-19 will reshape economic thinking, create big buying opportunity
summary: Covid-19 is reshaping economic thinking, with global markets anticipating a corporate earnings slump. The Caixin/Markit composite manufacturing and services purchasing managers' index (PMI) for February hit a record low of 27.5, indicating contraction. Panic buying is also evident, with shoppers stockpiling food, bottled water, and toilet paper in the US and UK. As companies begin reporting Q1 2020 numbers, investors are bracing for potentially frightening market reactions to ineffective rate cuts.

site_title: Boeing set to get blame in Ethiopian report on crash of 737 Max
summary: Ethiopian investigators have concluded that the 737 Max crash was caused by the plane's design, according to a draft report. The conclusions, which say little about the pilots or maintenance, contrast with Indonesia's investigation after a prior 737 Max crash, which cited multiple factors. The Ethiopian report will be published as an interim update before the anniversary of the March 2019 crash, with recommendations that could be altered before release. The US National Transportation Safety Board has received a copy of the draft report and can't comment on its contents.

images.alt_text: Ethiopian crash investigators have tentatively concluded that the crash of a Boeing 737 Max last year was caused by the grounded plane's design, according to a draft report that's being circulated to participants in the probe.

site_title: Singtel, AIS, SK Telecom make Series A investment in regional gaming JV
summary: Singtel, AIS from Thailand, and SK Telecom from South Korea have invested in a regional gaming joint venture, aiming to engage 800 million gamers in the region. The investment will partner leading international game developers, leveraging their content and expertise in Korean and South-east Asian gaming. The joint venture will focus on gaming content distribution, building on Singtel's e-sports efforts and AIS's e-sports expertise.

site_title: Singtel, AIS, SK Telecom make Series A investment in regional gaming joint venture
summary: Singtel, AIS, and SK Telecom have invested in a regional gaming joint venture, aiming to engage 800 million gamers in the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership, which includes a Series A investment, will leverage the partners' gaming and entertainment content, with Singtel contributing regional knowledge and digital assets, SK Telecom bringing expertise in Korean entertainment and gaming, and AIS providing e-sports and digital content expertise. The joint venture plans to create a new level of gaming experience by distributing popular Korean gaming content throughout the region.

site_title: Gold outshines all assets amid virus fears
summary: Gold prices are expected to surge amid virus fears and dovish central banks, potentially reaching the $1,700-$1,800 range. Analysts, including Jeffrey Halley and Howie Lee, believe that fear-driven demand will drive gold prices higher. However, some experts, such as Halley, expect prices to "top out" in the current range due to limited rate cuts by central banks. The emergence of a fast-acting vaccine could also trigger a decline in gold prices.
