summary: The coronavirus pandemic has led to a significant shift in global habits, as people change their ways to reduce the risk of contracting the virus and prevent its spread. From China to the US, countries are adapting traditional greetings and interactions, such as handshakes, kisses, and hugging, to more direct and cautious methods, like hand gestures, direct gazes, and waving. Experts recommend avoiding physical contact, and some institutions are even abandoning traditional greetings altogether.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower tracking US rout; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.7% on Friday, tracking a US rout, with the Straits Times Index dipping below the 3,000-point mark. Losers outnumbered gainers 107 to 43, with 60.8 million securities worth S$128.3 million changing hands. This marks the first decline in five days.

site_title: 9 in 10 of all people hold bias against women
summary: A UN study found nearly 90% of the world's population holds some prejudice against women, including sexist views on education, politics, and job markets. The highest percentages of sexist bias were found in Pakistan (99.81%), Qatar (99.73%), and Nigeria (99.73%). Countries with lower percentages included Andorra (27.01%), Sweden (30.01%), and the Netherlands (39.75%). The study highlights the need for education to address deeply ingrained biases and promote equality.

site_title: FWD promotes Khor Kee Eng to Singapore CEO
summary: FWD Group has appointed Khor Kee Eng as the CEO of FWD Singapore, subject to regulatory approval. Khor, a former chief financial officer of FWD Singapore, previously held the position of group chief actuary at Malaysia's Tune Protect Group. The appointment marks a significant move within the insurance industry in Singapore.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari says he supported rate cut as 'insurance' in face of uncertainty
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari said he supported the US central bank's emergency interest rate cut due to coronavirus uncertainty. He described the rate cut as "insurance" to mitigate potential economic impact. Kashkari stated that if the virus's impact is worse than expected, the Fed could cut rates further. However, if the impact passes, the Fed could raise rates again. Kashkari emphasized that the Fed's decision was a precautionary measure to address uncertainty, not a response to the virus itself.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, JSH, Singtel, Hongkong Land, Dairy Farm
summary: Keppel Corp's property arm will jointly develop a residential site in Jiangsu province with Chinese developer CIFI Holdings. Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH) reported a 3% fall in 2019 underlying profit to US$1.68 billion. Meanwhile, Keppel Corp's shares dropped 1.25% to S$6.31, and JSH shares fell US$0.20 to US$27.19.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Coronavirus could erase US$211b from Asia-Pacific economies: S&P
summary: A coronavirus outbreak could erode US$211 billion from Asia-Pacific economies, with Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Australia among the most exposed, according to S&P Global Ratings. The ratings agency cut its 2020 growth forecast for China to 4.8% and Australia to 1.2%. Other countries, including Hong Kong and Singapore, face contraction or flat growth. The outbreak has claimed over 3,000 lives worldwide and prompted monetary policy easings in major economies, including the US.

site_title: Katy Perry reveals pregnancy in latest music video
summary: Katy Perry has revealed her pregnancy in her latest music video, "Never Worn White." The 35-year-old pop star cradles a baby bump in the final seconds of the clip, which was released on Wednesday. Perry is engaged to actor Orlando Bloom, who has a son with model Miranda Kerr. This will be Perry's first child and Bloom's second. The singer shared her excitement on social media, joking about not having to suck in her stomach anymore.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.69 points or 0.58% to 1,482.34. The market saw 120.97 million lots traded worth RM41.67 million, with losers beating gainers 184 to 60.

site_title: First UK death confirmed in coronavirus outbreak
summary: The UK has reported its first death from coronavirus, with a 70-year-old patient in England dying from the virus while being treated at the Royal Berkshire Hospital. The total number of confirmed cases has risen to 115, with the patient believed to have contracted the virus in Britain. The UK government is taking measures to contain the outbreak, including asking people to work from home and reducing large gatherings, as it prepares to move into the "delay" phase of the outbreak.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on revived worries over virus
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on March 6, 2020, due to renewed concerns over the spread of the new coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.47% and the Topix index declined 1.60%. Health officials warned that many countries were not adequately fighting the outbreak, contributing to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday as worries reintensified over the spread of the new coronavirus with health officials warning many countries were not doing enough to fight the outbreak.

site_title: Tee International ex-CEO interviewed by CAD, removed from director post
summary: Tee International's former CEO Phua Chian Kin has been interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) following an investigation into alleged wrongdoing. He has been removed from his director post and surrendered travel documents. A PricewaterhouseCoopers Risk Services report found Phua had taken company funds to repay debts and margin calls. Tee International's operations continue as usual, and the company will keep the board updated on investigation developments. Phua has agreed to cooperate fully in the investigations.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon undergoes emergency heart surgery
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon underwent emergency heart surgery to treat an aortic dissection on Thursday, a condition where the inner layer of the aorta tears. He is "awake, alert, and recovering well" after successful surgery, according to the bank. The board of directors has asked co-presidents Daniel Pinto and Gordon Smith to run the bank while Dimon recovers. This is not Dimon's first health scare, as he previously battled throat cancer in 2014. The condition is treatable but can be fatal if the rupture stems through the outside aortic wall.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental full-year underlying net profit falls 37% to US$41.2m
summary: Mandarin Oriental reported a 37% decline in underlying net profit to US$41.2m for fiscal 2019, down from US$64.9m the previous year, due to the closure of The Excelsior in Hong Kong and renovation costs. The group posted a net loss of US$55.5m, and a final dividend of 1.5 US cents per share has been proposed. The company attributes its performance to the ongoing virus outbreak, particularly in Hong Kong, but expects benefits from renovated hotels and upcoming re-openings.

site_title: MUFG-Grab deal shows Japanese banks' growing interest in S-E Asia: Fitch
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) has invested US$706 million in ride-sharing firm Grab, marking a growing interest in South-east Asia by Japanese banks. The deal may deliver benefits for MUFG, but also increases risk. Japanese banks face challenges in generating revenue due to low domestic interest rates and high competition, leading them to expand into faster-growing markets. However, this strategy comes with higher costs and risks, which MUFG aims to manage. Fitch Ratings views the investment as "credit neutral" and notes that it is too early to determine whether benefits can be realized.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Friday's session sharply down
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading sharply down on Friday, following another sell-off on Wall Street, due to fears about the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.38% to 26,397.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.03% and 1.27%, respectively. The losses were attributed to global economic concerns and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Magnus Energy unit sells Perth property for A$1m
summary: Magnus Energy's subsidiary, Mid-Continent Equipment Group, sold a Perth property for A$1 million (S$931,260) on March 3, following the closure of the group's business last year. The property, which covers 2,521 square meters, was bought in 1993 and sat on freehold land. The sale price is close to the property's valuation of A$1.1 million and will be used as the group's general working capital, according to the company.

site_title: Japan household spending falls for 4th straight month, coronavirus impact looms
summary: Japan's household spending declined 3.9% in January from a year earlier, marking the fourth consecutive month of contraction. The decline was largely due to the global health crisis and threatens to push the world's third-largest economy into recession. If Japan experiences two consecutive quarters of decline, it will be its first recession in nearly five years. The Bank of Japan may take steps to support companies affected by the virus, while sluggish wage recovery and the impact of the sales tax hike have fueled concerns about private spending.

site_title: Coronavirus time bomb: America's uninsured and brutal work culture
summary: The US is vulnerable to the spread of the novel coronavirus due to its large uninsured population, estimated at 27.5 million people, and a culture of "powering through" when sick to avoid job loss. This can lead to undiagnosed and untreated cases, exacerbating the outbreak. The lack of federally mandated paid sick leave and high costs for medical care, with routine doctor's visits costing hundreds of dollars, further worsen the situation. Experts warn that the US' unique characteristics make it vulnerable to the virus, and the rising number of uninsured individuals may lead to significant health disparities if the virus spreads.

site_title: Qantas cancels more international flights as coronavirus spreads rapidly
summary: Qantas Airways has canceled more international flights due to the rapid spread of the coronavirus, cutting capacity to destinations including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Auckland. The airline has also grounded the equivalent of 18 planes and cut domestic capacity. Australia's tourism industry has been severely impacted, with international tourist bookings plummeting 56% over the last month. Airlines worldwide may lose $63 billion to $113 billion in revenue for passenger traffic in 2020, according to the International Air Transport Association.

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways said on Friday it would cut more international capacity this month as it grapples with falling demand due to an escalation in the coronavirus outbreak in countries beyond China.

site_title: Singapore sets up multi-agency task force to improve public hygiene in fight against Covid-19
summary: Singapore establishes a multi-agency task force, the SG Clean Taskforce, to boost public hygiene and cleanliness amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The task force, led by Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli, focuses on public spaces, personal hygiene, and social norms to reduce disease spread. Premises managers will be held accountable for cleanliness, with greater emphasis on environmental sanitation and certification programs. This move aims to counter the growing number of COVID-19 cases worldwide and eventual weakening of border controls.

images.alt_text: Singapore authorities are stepping up public hygiene standards in its latest salvo against the coronavirus outbreak as it acknowledges border controls may eventually become less effective.

site_title: 'Nut rage' heiress leads coup to overthrow younger CEO brother
summary: Heiress Heather Cho, infamous for her "nut rage" incident, is leading a shareholder revolt against her brother Walter Cho, 44, as CEO of South Korea's Hanjin Kal Corp. Cho, 45, has allied with an activist fund to push for professional managers to take control of the conglomerate, including the airline and hotel businesses. The revolt has been ongoing since Cho lent her support to the activist fund, which is the largest shareholder in the company. A board member vote is set for March 27, with Cho's removal as a board member also on the agenda.

site_title: Brexit preparations cost UK £4.4b: spending watchdog
summary: The UK's departure from the European Union has cost taxpayers £4.4 billion in extra government costs, according to a National Audit Office report. This includes £1.9 billion on staffing costs, £1.5 billion on building new systems and infrastructure, and £288 million on external advice. The spending figures represent a minimum estimated level, due to limitations in the data provided by departments. The UK is currently in a transition phase until the end of the year, with ongoing negotiations with the EU to agree a trade deal.

site_title: Warren says not ready to make endorsement in Democratic race
summary: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren announced she won't endorse either remaining Democratic presidential candidate, Joe Biden or Bernie Sanders, citing she wants "a little time to think" after dropping out of the race following Super Tuesday's results. Warren failed to win a single state, including her own.

site_title: Oil slides as demand worries overshadow Opec deal to deepen supply cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as the coronavirus epidemic continued to impact global demand, outweighing Opec's agreement to cut crude output by 1.5 million barrels per day. Brent crude fell 2.2% to $49.99 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate fell 1.9% to $45.90. Opec is proposing the cut be extended until year-end, but Russia has indicated it will back an extension rather than deeper production cuts. Analysts expect global oil markets to be oversupplied in the second quarter, with global oil demand forecast to fall 2.7 million barrels per day in the first quarter.

site_title: Airlines grim as trade group sees potential US$113b hit from virus
summary: Airlines face a potential revenue hit of up to $113 billion in 2020 due to the coronavirus, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). The forecast, which ranges from $63 billion to $113 billion, is significantly bleaker than a previous estimate of $29.3 billion. The virus has led to widespread cancellations, with more than 95,000 infected and over 3,200 deaths worldwide. The IATA has appealed to governments for support, citing the need for relief on taxes, charges, and slot allocation.

site_title: US announces US$8.3b in coronavirus funding as cases surge
summary: The US government has approved a $8.3 billion spending bill to combat the coronavirus, significantly exceeding President Trump's initial request of $2.5 billion. The funding is aimed at addressing the surge in cases and deaths, now at 11, with the virus spreading to 14 states and infecting over 180 people. Officials stress that the overall risk to the public remains low, and urged people not to panic or buy masks, which could create a shortage.

site_title: Bankers try to keep IPO party going amid coronavirus market jitters
summary: Bankers are trying to keep the IPO party going despite market volatility fueled by the coronavirus outbreak. Despite some companies, like Warner Music Group and Cole Haan, putting their IPO plans on hold, others, such as Passage Bio and GFL Environmental, have successfully raised funds. Biotechnology companies are less affected by market turmoil, with the sector seeing a 50% increase in IPO activity year-to-date compared to 2018. Companies are advised to wait for market conditions to calm down before listing, with volatility expected to impact IPO proceeds.

site_title: Coronavirus triggers work-from home trend in Seattle
summary: Tech firms in Seattle, including Amazon, Facebook, and Google, are recommending employees work remotely to contain the coronavirus outbreak, which has claimed 10 US fatalities in the state. Amazon told over 50,000 employees in the region to work from home until the end of March, while Microsoft advised employees to work from their residences for the next couple of weeks. The measures aim to reduce risks and protect vulnerable individuals, such as those over 60 years old or with medical conditions, amid a global outbreak that has killed over 3,000 people.

site_title: Europe: Shares back in red as virus fears persist; miners lead losses
summary: European shares declined 1.4% on Thursday as concerns over the coronavirus outbreak outweighed optimism over monetary stimulus. The death toll rose to over 3,300, with several companies issuing profit warnings. The resources sector, led by miners BHP Group and Rio Tinto, was the worst performer. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates by 10 basis points next week, but warn that it may not be enough to mitigate economic damage.

site_title: Bank of England has 'ammunition' to tackle economic effects of coronavirus: Governor
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that the central bank has "a lot of ammunition" to combat the economic effects of the coronavirus, despite already low interest rates. He suggested lowering the key interest rate to 0% and using asset repurchases and liquidity mechanisms. This reassessment comes after the US Federal Reserve lowered its interest rate to a record low in response to the global economic risk posed by the virus. Carney's comments precede the Bank of England's next meeting, where a potential rate drop is anticipated.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Victoria And Albert Museum in London showcases the history of the kimono in "Kimono: Kyoto To Catwalk," running until June 21, 2020. Meanwhile, a new permanent exhibition "SINGAPO人: Discovering Chinese Singaporean Culture" explores the unique culture of Chinese Singaporeans. In other news, a one-night-only cooking event "Women of Taste" features three female chefs, a new rooftop eatery "VUE" opens in Singapore, and Netflix's "Next In Fashion" premieres with a fresh format and experienced contestants. Additionally, a campaign by Edelman raises awareness about shelter dogs and a bottomless brunch supports gender equality at Monti in Singapore.

site_title: US tests stranded cruise ship passengers for coronavirus
summary: US health officials conducted tests on nearly 3,500 passengers and crew of the Grand Princess cruise ship off the coast of San Francisco, following the death of a 71-year-old man who had previously been on the ship and died from the coronavirus. The ship was prevented from docking in San Francisco due to the outbreak. The testing is aimed at determining if any passengers or crew have contracted the new coronavirus, with some showing flu-like symptoms.

site_title: Trump prepares scorched earth campaign against Biden
summary: President Donald Trump is preparing a "scorched earth" campaign against Democratic frontrunner Joe Biden, questioning his cognitive abilities and accusing him of corruption. Trump has publicly mocked Biden's verbal stumbles, suggesting he's senile, and tarring him as corrupt. Despite this, Trump fears Biden more than rival Bernie Sanders, whom he considers easier to beat. Trump will likely focus on Biden's age and past corruption allegations, including the investigation into his son Hunter's job in Ukraine, in his campaign against Biden.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump makes no secret of the scorched earth campaign he'll mount against Democratic frontrunner Joe Biden - complete with questioning the former vice president's cognitive abilities and accusing him constantly of corruption.

site_title: US: Dow ends 3.6% lower as virus fears batter stocks
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.6% to 26,121.28, as fears of the coronavirus pandemic continue to batter markets. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with losses of 3.4% and 3.1%, respectively. Airlines, cruise companies, and other travel-oriented shares were particularly hard hit, with losses ranging from 10% to 14.1%. Market experts warn of potential economic downturns and consumer spending slowdowns due to the virus, citing uncertainty and potential layoffs.

site_title: Crushing It
summary: Chanel has launched mini versions of its iconic Coco Crush ring, available in 18K beige gold, yellow gold, and white gold with or without diamonds. The mini rings can be worn individually or stacked for a minimalist look, priced at S$1,800. This marks the fifth year of the Coco Crush collection, which has expanded to include earrings, bracelets, and necklaces. The quilted pattern, a signature motif for the House of Chanel, has been a central element of the collection since its debut in the 1920s.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks plunge nearly 5% on coronavirus fears
summary: Brazil's Sao Paulo stock exchange plummeted nearly 5% on Thursday due to fears over the economic impact of the new coronavirus outbreak, which has disrupted trade with China, Brazil's largest trading partner. Airline stocks were particularly hard hit, with Gol and Azul down 19% and 14% respectively. Brazil reported eight confirmed coronavirus infections, with health officials investigating 636 suspected cases. No deaths have been recorded in Brazil. The market slide comes as Brazil's economy, the largest in Latin America, heavily relies on exports to China.

images.alt_text: The Sao Paulo stock exchange plunged nearly five per cent on Thursday on fears over the economic impact the new coronavirus outbreak will have on Brazil, whose largest trading partner is China.

site_title: Haidilao billionaire opens family office in Singapore
summary: Shu Ping, billionaire co-founder of Haidilao International Holding, has opened a family office in Singapore to manage her wealth, which is valued at around $7.7 billion. This move comes as the company faces a critical test due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the majority of its revenue coming from mainland China. Shu Ping's family office, Sunrise Capital Management, is the sole shareholder and director of the entity, which is based in Singapore, a city-state offering tax breaks and incentives to attract billionaires.

site_title: TikTok taps cyber security chief from ADP
summary: TikTok has hired Roland Cloutier, a cyber security expert from ADP, as its new Chief Information Security Officer. Cloutier will oversee cybersecurity in the newly created role, following scrutiny over TikTok's handling of personal data from the US Committee on Foreign Investment. This move aims to strengthen the platform's cybersecurity measures.

site_title: Retail Reits have priced in Covid-19 impact, say analysts
summary: Retail Reits in Singapore have partially priced in the impact of temporary rent-relief measures, with prices rising 4.3% since the US Federal Reserve's rate cut. Despite being 4.5% below pre-Covid-19 levels, the Reits have seen a 9.3% year-over-year gain, driven by double-digit price jumps from Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Mapletree Commercial Trust. Analysts expect benign interest rates to support demand for Reits, and imminent acquisitions will bolster share prices, mitigating the short-term impact of rent rebates.

site_title: Federal Reserve postpones Denver conference
summary: The US Federal Reserve postponed the 2020 National Interagency Community Reinvestment Conference in Denver due to concerns over the coronavirus outbreak. The event, co-sponsored by three other regional Federal Reserve Banks, was set to take place from March 9-12. The decision was made out of an abundance of caution to safeguard the health and well-being of over 1,300 registered participants. This decision follows other cancellations of conferences worldwide, including the IMF and World Bank's Spring Meetings and the ECB's conference on European financial integration.

site_title: Boards and value creation
summary: Boards of directors need to innovate and adapt to disruptors in the business world, creating value through strategic transformation and embracing digital technology. This can be achieved by forming innovation committees, adopting a private equity mindset, and prioritizing talent management and sustainability. Boards should focus on succession planning, overseeing talent development, and factoring in demographic and diversity considerations. Additionally, sustainability, encompassing environmental, social, and governance concerns, should be prioritized to drive value creation and competitiveness. By doing so, boards can help their enterprises differentiate and succeed in an age of disruption.

site_title: ADB opens Singapore office
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has opened a new office in Singapore, marking a deeper collaboration with the city-state to tackle climate change, financing, and building quality infrastructure. The office will comprise 12 specialists and aims to enhance cooperation on development challenges, with ADB seeking to increase private sector investment to one-third of its total operations by 2024. Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and ADB President Masatsugu Asakawa attended the office's opening, emphasizing the importance of infrastructure investment and synergies between their ecosystems.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How concerned should we be about infectious diseases like Covid-19?
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses the concern level of infectious diseases like Covid-19, with experts weighing the risks and benefits of various measures. The panel considers factors such as the virus's transmissibility, mortality rate, and the effectiveness of vaccines. They also examine the economic impact of lockdowns and social distancing measures. The conclusion is that while the risk of severe illness remains, the overall threat is manageable, and a balanced approach is necessary to minimize harm while preserving economic and social stability.

site_title: Wipo nomination boosts Singapore's global standing as hub for IP enforcement, resolution
summary: Singapore's nomination of Daren Tang as the head of the United Nations World Intellectual Property Organization (Wipo) has boosted the country's international standing as a hub for IP enforcement and dispute resolution. The nomination is seen as a testament to Singapore's trustworthiness and strong IP credentials, which is expected to attract more foreign companies to set up their IP assets in the country. With a strong IP protection regime, efficient legal system, and tech-friendly ecosystem, Singapore is poised to become a safe haven for IP assets, further solidifying its position as a global IP leader.

site_title: Bank of Canada sees rate cut cushioning the economic blow of coronavirus
summary: The Bank of Canada cut its overnight interest rate by half a percentage point to 1.25% in response to the coronavirus outbreak, aiming to soften the economic blow. Governor Stephen Poloz stated that the Canadian economy's resilience could be tested by the outbreak, but the rate cut should provide immediate impact. The central bank is prepared to cut further if needed, and there is a 70% chance of another rate cut in April. The move is also expected to cushion the blow from weaker-than-expected domestic data and other economic challenges.

site_title: No change to Straits Times Index components
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents remain unchanged following the March 2020 quarterly review, with no additions or deletions. The next review will take place in June 2020, and the STI reserve list, comprising the top 5 non-constituents by market capitalization, will be reviewed for potential replacements in the future. The FTSE ST methodology ensures the indexes accurately represent the investable universe for benchmarking purposes.

site_title: Millions of students stay home as countries shut schools in global virus battle
summary: Millions of students worldwide, approximately 290.5 million, are staying home due to school closures caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Italy has shut schools and universities until March 15, while South Korea and Japan have postponed the start of the next term. The International Monetary Fund has urged a global response to the epidemic, offering $50 billion in aid to low-income countries. The virus has spread to 80 countries, infecting over 95,000 people and killing over 3,200, with the majority of deaths and infections in China.

site_title: Lawmakers press Amazon, eBay to take tougher stance over fake goods
summary: Lawmakers are urging Amazon and eBay to take stronger actions against third-party vendors selling fake, stolen, or unsafe goods on their websites. Representatives from both companies testified that they are using machine learning tools to identify fake listings and plan to support law enforcement. Amazon has been proactively scanning its website for false claims, while the Department of Homeland Security recommends that the Trump administration seek permission to take action against third-party marketplaces selling counterfeit merchandise. The goal is to prioritize consumer safety and accountability over profit.

site_title: Coronavirus causing widespread disruption, could get worse: Fed
summary: The Federal Reserve warned that the coronavirus outbreak is causing widespread disruption to US industry, with businesses anticipating further disruptions. Despite moderate growth, the outlook is becoming uncertain. The Fed's beige book survey notes that the US economy is facing challenges, and the situation could worsen.

site_title: Los Angeles port hit hard by Covid-19
summary: The Port of Los Angeles, the US's largest port, has been severely impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak, with a 20-25% drop in business last month compared to February 2019. Officials forecast a 15-17% decline in container volume activity for Q1 2020, mainly due to cargo from China. The facility's executive director, Eugene Seroka, attributed the decline to the virus's spread.

site_title: The importance of governance for high-quality companies
summary: Governance is crucial for high-quality companies to meet increasing standards, guidelines, and social demands. Regulatory backlashes and public backlash via social media can be devastating to a firm's reputation and profits. Effective management of data is vital, but regulations like GDPR pose significant risks. Poor governance can lead to short-termism, capital misallocation, and excessive risk-taking, ultimately destroying shareholder value. Companies with strong franchises and high returns on operating capital employed are more vulnerable to poor governance, highlighting the importance of effective governance in sustaining high-quality companies.

site_title: Spring Summer Trend Report
summary: This spring and summer, the fashion industry is embracing a "street smart" approach, with a focus on tailored, chic pieces. Key trends include Bermuda shorts, the summer tunic, and the vest, which can be styled in various ways for both casual and formal looks. The season also sees a resurgence of feminine styles, with emphasis on delicate details, luxurious fabrics, and classic silhouettes. Denim is also a major player, with creative twists and bold colors. The Tropicana trend, inspired by Jennifer Lopez's iconic Versace dress, continues to thrive, and the industry is also exploring the revival of 1970s-inspired styles, such as trouser suits and satin suits.

site_title: Alan Vinogradov, Co-founder of Sneaker Con
summary: Alan Vinogradov, co-founder of Sneaker Con, is hosting the show's largest-ever edition in Singapore in June. The event will feature over 180 vendors, 30,000 guests, and celebrity sneakerhead Sean Wotherspoon's exclusive designs. This marks a significant expansion for Sneaker Con, which has previously toured 40 cities. Vinogradov's enthusiasm for the sneaker market contrasts with concerns about its saturation, with some predicting it may have reached its peak.

site_title: Modern Masculinity
summary: Tom Peacock-Nazil, a 31-year-old Briton, left his finance job to co-found Seven Clean Seas, a Singapore-based social enterprise combating ocean pollution. After witnessing plastic waste on a Thai beach in 2018, he realized the need for commercial solutions to clean the oceans. Partnering with a vegan condom company, Einhorn, he created a for-profit model to remove plastic waste. Seven Clean Seas has mobilized over 3,800 volunteers and recovered 50,000 kg of plastic, and has secured funding from major hoteliers and technology companies. Peacock-Nazil believes this work aligns with his modern concept of masculinity, which emphasizes eco-awareness, community service, and equality.

site_title: Pioneer's Smart Unit Receiver lets you add Android to your auto
summary: Pioneer's Smart Unit Receiver allows users to add Android to their auto system, providing entertainment on the go. This innovation marks a significant shift from traditional in-car entertainment, which relied on CDs and cassette players. The receiver features a removable tablet, enabling users to access various mobile apps, videos, and games. This technology is a response to the evolution of mobile entertainment and provides a new way to experience entertainment while driving.

site_title: ARA completes acquisition of majority stake in Logos
summary: ARA Asset Management has acquired a majority stake in logistics property firm Logos Group, with existing shareholders Ivanhoé Cambridge and Logos' founders exiting as shareholders. The deal combines ARA's global fund management capabilities with Logos' Asia-Pacific logistics expertise, creating a logistics real estate development and investment management platform. Logos will operate as ARA's exclusive platform for logistics assets globally, offering ARA's investors a suite of products in the private and public markets. The acquisition marks an exciting milestone for both companies, with plans to expand the logistics platform in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Can corporate governance be tailored to support innovation?
summary: A recent article explores the potential of tailoring corporate governance to support innovation. Current corporate governance rules prioritize shareholder protection over fostering innovation. The emphasis on safeguarding minority shareholders' interests may hinder the development of innovative organizations. To reconcile these objectives, companies may need to strike a balance between independence and innovation. This requires a reevaluation of control mechanisms and board independence.

site_title: Singapore's robust IP ecosystem sees surge in patent filings by China firms
summary: China companies have seen a surge in patent filings in Singapore, with a 55% average annual increase over three years to 1,554 in 2019. Heavyweight tech firms like Alibaba are leading the charge, citing Singapore's strong intellectual property regime and alternative dispute resolution framework. Chinese investments in Singapore have also risen, with over $41.8 billion in investments between 2014 and 2018. The uptick in patent filings is driven by diversions from the US and Europe, as well as fertile ground for tech development in Southeast Asia.

site_title: 1,000 CapitaLand tenants get rental rebates
summary: CapitaLand, Singapore's largest mall operator, will provide rental rebates to 1,000 of its 3,500 tenants, starting with a 25% rebate on fixed rent components for April and May. This move comes after the Restaurant Association of Singapore accused CapitaLand of not delivering on its promised 50% rental rebate to F&B operators. Industry analysts say the impact on CapitaLand's financials will be minimal, with a potential 1.8% dip in FY20 DPU.

site_title: 3 Singapore-based startups secure funding in seed, Series A rounds
summary: Three Singapore-based startups secured funding in seed and Series A rounds. Payments startup hoolah raised an undisclosed eight-figure sum in its Series A round, e-sports tournament platform provider ESPL secured an undisclosed investment from 500 Startups, and research consulting services provider Arches raised US$450,000 in its seed round. The funding will be used to expand hoolah's operations in Malaysia and fuel further growth, while ESPL will use its funds to roll out its platforms to 10 countries and Arches to strengthen its team and develop its expert data platform.

images.alt_text: hoolah's Series A round raised an eight-figure sum. It pays partner merchants upfront for consumers' purchases and takes on the credit and fraud risk. Partners pay a transaction fee per customer order.

site_title: Empowering women is key to unlocking Singapore's economic potential
summary: Singapore's economic potential is hindered by the underrepresentation of women entrepreneurs, despite having favorable conditions for entrepreneurship. According to the Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs, women make up 44% of the workforce but only 26.3% of business owners, and the number of male entrepreneurs is increasing faster. Increasing gender equality in the workforce could add S$26 billion to the country's GDP by 2025. A lack of confidence and self-perception may be a stumbling block for female entrepreneurs in Singapore, with only 17% believing they have the required skills and knowledge.

site_title: Arcc Spaces to open flagship project at One Marina Boulevard
summary: Arcc Spaces, a Singapore-based flexible workspace operator, is set to open its flagship project at One Marina Boulevard next month. This marks the company's fourth project in Singapore, expanding its regional footprint in Kuala Lumpur, Yangon, Beijing, Shanghai, and Hong Kong.

site_title: A second look at Rosso di Montalcino shows up its inconsistency
summary: A recent tasting of Rosso di Montalcino, a Tuscan red wine, revealed inconsistent quality among the 20 bottles sampled from the 2016 and 2017 vintages. While some wines showed promise, many were unbalanced, dominated by tannins, acidity, or a lack of one or the other. The inconsistent quality may be attributed to differences in microclimates, altitude, and soils, as well as varying production methods. However, a few standout bottles, such as the 2016 Uccelliera and 2017 Ciacci Piccolomini d'Aragona, demonstrated balance and structure, suggesting that the potential for high-quality Rosso di Montalcinos exists, but not yet consistently delivered.

site_title: USD struggles as traders price in more Fed cuts
summary: The US dollar fell 0.4% against the euro, reaching a two-month low, amid expectations of further interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve to combat the economic impact of the novel coronavirus. Money markets are pricing in a 25-50 basis point cut at the next Fed meeting and by April. The euro also benefited from traders unwinding carry trade positions, while the Japanese yen rose against the dollar. The decline in the dollar is attributed to low US yields, potential monetary easing, and the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Government announces measures to encourage use of electric vehicles
summary: Singapore's government has announced measures to encourage the use of electric vehicles (EVs), including higher-powered EV motorcycles and buses. Starting April 1, higher-powered EV motorcycles with a top speed of 50 km/h will be allowed on expressways, and all new public buses will be cleaner energy buses. The government also plans to expand public charging infrastructure from 1,600 points to 28,000 by 2030. Additionally, the government will work with the private sector to improve charging provisions at private car parks and introduce a new EV road tax structure, with an additional S$200 per year for electric motorcycles.

site_title: Dairy Farm net earnings up almost 4 times to US$324m
summary: Dairy Farm, a Pan-Asian supermarket and convenience store operator, reported a 282% increase in underlying net profit to US$324 million in 2019, driven by cost-cutting measures and a turnaround in its South-east Asia grocery retail business. Despite a 5% decline in revenue to US$11.2 billion, the company attributed the growth to its space optimisation plan, new store formats, and improvement programs. The company's chairman, Ben Keswick, expressed optimism about the group's transformation momentum, but noted that the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak may impact performance in the remainder of the year.

site_title: Strong growth in Singapore's ultra wealthy population: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's ultra-high net worth individual (UHNWI) population is expected to grow by 29% over the next five years, ranking eighth in the world for fastest growth. The city-state's UHNWI population comprises 3,300 individuals, with a growth rate of 10% in the 2018-2019 period. Asia's UHNWI population is expected to increase by 44% over the next five years, with Singapore set to benefit from the region's rising wealth. UHNWIs in Singapore plan to alter their investment strategies to offset the global economic slowdown, with property being the largest allocation at 28%.

site_title: Analysts downgrade Singapore banks after US Fed rate cut
summary: Analysts have downgraded their ratings for Singapore banks following the US Federal Reserve's 50 basis point interest rate cut, citing a compression of net interest margins. DBS Group Research and CGS-CIMB have downgraded their ratings, with DBS and UOB seeing lowered target prices, while OCBC's rating remains "hold". The analysts expect a decline in net interest margins due to the rate cut and ongoing competition in mortgages and loans, with DBS being more rate-sensitive due to its US dollar-denominated loans.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Slight confusion at Le Fusion
summary: Lè Fusion, a neo-Asian eatery in Robertson Quay, Singapore, has received mixed reviews for its eclectic menu that blends French, Italian, Chinese, and zichar cuisines. The restaurant's attempts at fusion often result in confusing dishes, such as the Imperial Double Boiled Soup and Crispy Pork Roulade, which lack cohesion. However, some dishes, like the Braised Abalone Seafood Rice and Infamous Angus Beef Chinese Pasta, show promise. With some editing and refinement, Lè Fusion could potentially become a polished dining experience. Rating: 5.5.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Accrelist and Jubilee Industries deny any relationship with Honfoong Plastic Industries, which is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). Keppel Corp's subsidiary, KEPPEL Land China, jointly develops a residential site in Taicang City with a 49% stake purchase for $99.5 million. Jardine Strategic Holdings reports a 3% fall in 2019 underlying profit, and Singtel's long-term issuer credit ratings are lowered to A from A+ by S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: The makings of a man
summary: Actor Mahershala Ali stars in Zegna's #WHATMAKESAMAN campaign, exploring masculinity, identity, and style in a rapidly changing world. The luxury brand, led by artistic director Alessandro Sartori, aims to redefine traditional notions of masculinity. Ali, a 46-year-old African-American Muslim, embodies the complexities of contemporary manhood, showcasing qualities such as dignity, openness, and vulnerability. Through his experiences and perspectives, Ali highlights the evolving nature of masculinity, encouraging men to be truthful to themselves and adapt to change.

site_title: HSBC Singapore aims for 40% of women in senior roles by 2022
summary: HSBC Singapore aims to have 40% of women in senior roles and half of managerial positions held by women by 2022, up from 30% currently. The bank also plans to develop a "structural framework" to remove barriers and encourage equal opportunity. This goal is part of a broader trend in the global banking industry, with HSBC joining peers such as Citi and Standard Chartered in committing to greater female representation in senior ranks.

site_title: Opec backs biggest oil cut since 2008 crisis
summary: Opec has agreed to cut oil output by 1.5 million barrels per day (bpd) in the second quarter of 2020, the largest cut since the 2008 financial crisis, to support prices hit by the coronavirus outbreak. The deal, conditional on Russia and other non-Opec states joining in, aims to reduce the global supply by 3.6% and is expected to bring Brent oil prices near US$51 a barrel. However, Russia has not supported the fresh cut, and a meeting between Opec and Russia is set for June 9 to determine the group's overall output reduction.

site_title: Gender bonds as an investment in equality
summary: The 2020 Global Gender Gap Report highlights a widening gender pay gap, with women earning 15.7% less on average than men in the Philippines, despite being the most gender-equal nation in Asia. The gap persists due to complex factors like pay discrimination, unequal caring responsibilities, and a divided labor market. Innovative solutions like gender-equality bonds, which invest in businesses majority-owned by women or with women in leadership positions, can bridge existing gaps and promote gender equality. Companies must also implement transparent reporting mechanisms to track progress and create a virtuous cycle of gender lens investing.

site_title: Epidemic could cost airlines US$113b in lost revenues: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) warned that the coronavirus epidemic could cost passenger airlines up to $113 billion in lost revenue this year, tripling its previous forecast. The warning comes as Flybe, a British regional carrier, collapses and Norwegian Air scraps its profit forecast. Airlines worldwide are cutting flights and costs, warning of a hit to earnings, amid the spread of the virus, which could plunge the global economy into recession.

images.alt_text: The failure of Flybe comes less than two months after a rescue deal for the firm was agreed.

site_title: 2020 Porsche 718 Cayman GTS review: The joy of six
summary: Porsche has reintroduced a six-cylinder engine in the 718 Cayman GTS model, replacing the turbocharged flat-four engine. The new 4.0-liter engine produces 400 horsepower and 420 Newton-metres of peak pulling power, generating its power without a turbocharger. The GTS model offers a high-performance sweet spot, with features like a six-speed manual gearbox, sports suspension, and Porsche Torque Vectoring. The car is designed to provide a balance between track-day ability and daily drive comfort, with a price tag of $402,488.

site_title: The gender of business leaders will be irrelevant sooner than you think. Here's why
summary: Business leaders will increasingly become irrelevant due to the growing importance of diverse teams and ideas in the knowledge economy. As companies recognize the value of diversity, biases in favor of men may hinder progress. The author suggests that rather than focusing on gender inequality, efforts should be made to double down on diversity in all its forms, starting with gender balance. With equal pay and flexible work arrangements, women will have more career opportunities, and senior management teams may become more gender-balanced by the end of this decade, making the gender of business leaders less relevant.

site_title: Singapore's climate action: It is time to be more ambitious
summary: Singapore's climate action is urged to be more ambitious, following global trends of nations declaring net-zero carbon emission targets by 2050. Despite the government's commitment to adapting to climate change impacts, its mitigation policies can be improved, with a need for stronger measures to reduce carbon emissions. The government should consider implementing whole-of-society sustainability initiatives, investing in infrastructure for sustainable lifestyles and production methods, and collaborating with local businesses to ensure a sustainable transition from carbon-intensive industries.

site_title: STI dips as Covid-19 worries spike in US
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower at 3,018.27 after a state of emergency was declared in California and Washington due to the Covid-19 outbreak, derailing the US market and affecting Asia-Pacific equities. Reits continued their ascent, while banks extended their declines as investors anticipate rate cuts. Trading volume reached 1.74 billion securities, with Reits such as Ascendas Reit and CapitaLand Mall Trust leading the gains.

site_title: Is it time to buy China banks in light of virus outbreak?
summary: China banks may benefit from a proactive fiscal policy and flexible monetary policy in response to the coronavirus outbreak. However, asset quality risks and potential loan loss provisions pose caution. Large Chinese banks, such as China Merchants Bank and China Construction Bank, may offer re-rating opportunities if they increase fee income contribution. The banks' balance sheets are cleaner, but concerns remain about potential "national service" and huge deratings in the past. Investors should focus on quality picks, considering factors such as dividend yields and provision coverage ratios, amid expected volatility and limited business visibility.

site_title: Hongkong Land net profit dives on revaluation losses
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a record underlying net profit of $1.08 billion for 2019, but its net profit slumped 92% to $198 million due to losses from revaluation of investment properties. The company's revenue fell 13% and earnings per share declined 92%. The Covid-19 outbreak is expected to impact the group's development properties in mainland China and retail properties in Hong Kong, with chairman Ben Keswick warning that the extent of the impact will depend on the duration and geographic extent of the outbreak.

site_title: HDB resale market 'resilient' in February
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore remained resilient in February, with 1,668 flats sold, 13.1% fewer than in January, but prices increasing by 0.7%. The median transaction over X-value (TOX) was a positive S$2,000, indicating buyers "overpaid" for flats. Despite the Chinese New Year and virus outbreak, the market remained robust, with prices 1% higher compared to February 2019.

site_title: Outbreak could hit major transport projects: Khaw
summary: Singapore's major transport projects, such as Changi Terminal 5 and Tuas Port, may be impacted if the Covid-19 outbreak drags on, said Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. The outbreak's disruption to global supply chains could delay project timelines, affecting the new MRT stations and next-gen ERP system. However, the government will speed up over S$100 million worth of cycling path and road construction projects by up to three years, and channel over S$60 billion towards expanding and renewing its rail network over the next decade.

site_title: Biden makes a comeback, but don't write off Bernie yet
summary: Former Vice-President Joe Biden made a stunning comeback in the Democratic presidential primary, winning nearly 50% of the vote in South Carolina after three earlier losses. His victory came after African-American voters, who had initially backed Senator Bernie Sanders, rallied behind Biden, who had served as Obama's VP and fought for civil rights. Biden's win shifted the momentum in his direction, with more donors and campaign endorsements. He went on to win several other states, including Alabama, Arkansas, North Carolina, and Virginia, and is now considered a strong contender for the nomination, potentially beating President Trump in November.

site_title: Blackstone leaning towards India, its 'strongest performer'
summary: Blackstone Group, the world's largest alternative asset manager, is leaning towards investing in India due to the country's economic slowdown and credit crisis. India is considered Blackstone's "strongest performer" globally, with the company having invested $6 billion in the country over the past 18 months. Blackstone is scouting for opportunities as financiers focus on recovering from the crisis, which began with the collapse of an infrastructure financier in 2018. The company has already acquired several Indian businesses, including a shadow bank and manufacturing companies.

site_title: What Singapore can learn from Europe's green building journey
summary: Singapore can learn from Europe's green building journey by prioritizing speed in implementation. Europe's strong political leadership and early adoption of green building rating systems, such as the EPBD, have driven significant reductions in energy consumption. To catch up with cities like Paris and London, Singapore must increase its green building penetration rate to 64% by 2025. The country should adopt new technologies quickly, collaborate with the industry and public authorities, and implement green building standards for both new and existing buildings. Education and government efforts are also crucial to drive industry adoption and mitigate the effects of climate change.

site_title: US consumer comfort hits 10-week low
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a 10-week low, dipping to 63 in the week ended March 1, amid mounting virus fears. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index, which tracks buying climate sentiment, hit its lowest level since June. Despite this, other sentiment measures remain elevated, and the Federal Reserve's emergency rate reduction may help underpin confidence as concern about the coronavirus spreads.

site_title: Going down the rate-cut rabbit hole
summary: Central banks are preparing to intervene with monetary and fiscal support to combat the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, stock markets are struggling to make sense of the crisis, with markets becoming increasingly volatile. The effectiveness of these tools in mitigating economic damage is being questioned. This week's policy panic has raised questions about the impact of crisis on economies and businesses.

site_title: One year after 737 MAX crash, aviation giant Boeing is at a crossroads
summary: Boeing, one year after the 737 MAX crash that killed 157 people, is at a crossroads. The company remains grounded worldwide and faces criticism for its approach to cost-cutting over safety. After a leadership shake-up, former employees and analysts say Boeing must reform to prevent future disasters. New CEO David Calhoun is trying to balance investor and engineer demands, but experts question whether he can change the company's culture, which prioritizes cost-cutting and shareholder value over technical expertise and safety.

site_title: Money markets say a BOE cut is nailed on, less so for the ECB
summary: Money markets predict the Bank of England (BOE) will cut interest rates this month, with a 25 basis-point decrease likely, as incoming Governor Andrew Bailey seeks more evidence. In contrast, the European Central Bank's (ECB) decision is less certain, with odds of a 10 basis-point rate cut at around 85%. The ECB's rate remains in positive territory, and recent comments from President Christine Lagarde and policy maker Francois Villeroy De Galhau have been mixed, potentially setting up a disappointment from the bank.

site_title: Prepare for long-term virus impact: Gan
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong warns that the country needs to prepare to live with Covid-19 for a long time, anticipating a significant increase in new cases as the virus spreads globally. The situation is evolving, posing a high risk of importation of cases into the country, particularly from neighboring countries. Minister Gan's comments come as the number of infected individuals outside China continues to grow at "alarming rates".

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Daren Tang will become the head of the United Nations World Intellectual Property Organization (Wipo). The country's transport infrastructure projects may be delayed due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak. Retail sales in Singapore fell 5.3% in January, while excluding motor vehicles, sales rose 0.6% year-on-year. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower. Meanwhile, international news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariff announcements, the Asian garment industry's concerns over higher tariffs, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: EU's Barnier says serious differences in UK talks but deal possible
summary: EU's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said Britain and the European Union have "very, very serious" differences over their future relationship, but an agreement is still possible. After a first round of talks in Brussels, Barnier stated that the two sides have many divergences, some of which are difficult to reconcile. Despite these challenges, he expressed optimism that a deal can be reached, citing the need for an agreement to be in place by the end of the year.

site_title: Tech innovation can take Asia's fintech to the next level
summary: Asia's fintech sector is poised for significant growth with the adoption of digital currencies and central bank digital currencies (CBDCs). China's state-backed Digital Currency Electronic Payment (DCEP) project has catalyzed this trend, with 80% of the world's central banks exploring CBDCs. Asian markets, such as India, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, have high mobile wallet adoption rates, and countries like South Korea and Singapore are adopting digital-first approaches. The development of CBDCs could enable greater financial inclusion and disintermediate legacy systems, potentially shifting the economic centre of gravity towards the East.

site_title: CPFIS funds post average gains of 14.9% in 2019
summary: CPFIS funds in Singapore posted average gains of 14.89% in 2019, with unit trusts recording 15.97% and investment-linked insurance products 14.21%. These returns outperformed the MSCI World TR USD and MSCI AC Asia ex Japan Index, which gained 26.67% and 16.92% respectively. For the three-year period, equity funds led the way with 22.33% growth, followed by mixed assets and bonds. However, market experts warn of ongoing concerns over the coronavirus pandemic and trade uncertainty, advising investors to monitor developments.

site_title: Of Grit and Grace
summary: DBS Group Head of Institutional Banking Tan Su Shan, a senior banker for over three decades, has been a driving force for female empowerment in the workplace. After a recent crisis, she demonstrated calm leadership, prioritizing communication and transparency. Tan has been instrumental in promoting digitalization, reverse mentoring, and reverse mentoring, and has worked to increase gender equality within the organization. She is also a strong advocate for sustainability and has invested in eco-friendly fashion brands. With her commitment to making a positive impact, Tan has earned the respect of her peers and employees, and is poised for future leadership roles.

images.alt_text: Tan will be the first female CEO at DBS.
Tan Su Shan, DBS’ group head of institutional banking and newly appointed deputy CEO, will take over the helm from CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025.

site_title: BMW M135i review: Meet the fastest 1
summary: BMW's M135i is a high-performance variant of the 1 Series hatchback, boasting 306 horsepower from its 2.0-liter turbocharged engine and all-wheel drive system. The car's performance is characterized by exponential power buildup, making it a top contender for hot hatch enthusiasts. The M135i also features a spacious interior, generous headroom, and a user-friendly BMW Intelligent Personal Assistant with voice-operated control. With a starting price of S$243,888, the M135i competes with the Volkswagen Golf R and Audi S3, offering a balance of performance and practicality.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.08 points to 1,491.03 on Thursday, driven by a gain of 516 to 350 stocks. The market saw a volume of 145.1 billion lots worth RM85.8 billion.

site_title: Elizabeth Warren suspends 2020 Democratic White House bid
summary: US Senator Elizabeth Warren has suspended her 2020 Democratic White House bid, citing disappointing finishes in early states. She trailed behind front-runners Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden, placing third in her home state of Massachusetts. Warren's departure could provide a boost to fellow liberal Sanders, but voters often don't follow ideological lines. Warren's campaign focused on battling corporate influence in politics, proposing sweeping anti-corruption measures, and relied on grassroots donations. The decision comes a day after former Mayor Michael Bloomberg also dropped out of the campaign.

site_title: Swiss negative rates make homes unaffordable: report
summary: Switzerland's negative interest rates have made owning a home increasingly unaffordable, according to a Credit Suisse Group report. A single-family property can cost more than 10 times the average annual salary, with apartments costing 5 times and single-family homes costing 7 times. Buy-to-let financing now accounts for 17% of new mortgage business, and rising prices are putting rental yields under pressure. The country's strict affordability criteria have made home ownership for the average household out of reach.

site_title: 5 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore
summary: Singapore reported 5 new Covid-19 cases, with 4 linked to a private dinner function at Safra Jurong on Feb 15 and 1 imported case from a Turkish Airlines flight. The new cluster brings the total cases in Singapore to an unspecified amount.

site_title: Chinese soy crushers set to add to ballooning soyoil inventories
summary: Chinese soyoil inventories are expected to rise further, reaching 1.65 million tonnes by end of March, denting prices that have already lost 15% in 2020. The world's largest soybean crushing sector has recovered from coronavirus-led cutbacks, with demand still expected to remain sluggish. Chinese buyers continue to purchase soybeans from South America due to decent crush margins, contributing to the expected increase in inventories.

site_title: MAS sees a spike in scam calls
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports a surge in scam calls impersonating the regulator, with nearly 100 public members reporting incidents on the same day. The scam calls claim to warn of abnormal account activities, threatening to close the account within two hours if action is not taken. MAS advises recipients not to disclose personal information and to block or report suspicious numbers. The authority emphasizes that genuine MAS officers will never ask for personal banking information or security login credentials, and that such calls are a result of spoofing technology used to mask actual numbers.

site_title: 290 million students out of school as global virus battle intensifies
summary: Almost 290 million students worldwide were forced to stay home due to the global COVID-19 battle. The virus has infected over 95,000 people and killed more than 3,200 globally. Italy became the latest country to shut schools, with the US raising its death toll to 11 after a fatality was declared. The IMF urged a global offensive against the epidemic, while California declared an emergency following its first coronavirus fatality.

site_title: Former UN chief Javier Perez de Cuellar dies at 100
summary: Former UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, known for his peace-making efforts, died at 100 in his native Peru. Perez de Cuellar served from 1981 to 1991 and was credited with brokering a ceasefire in the Iran-Iraq war, securing American hostages' release, and leading peace talks in El Salvador. Current UN Chief Antonio Guterres expressed condolences, while Peruvian President Martin Vizcarra praised Perez de Cuellar as a "distinguished Peruvian, a democrat through and through." Perez de Cuellar's remains will be at the Peruvian foreign ministry before burial.

site_title: US: Wall St sinks at open as coronavirus fears prompt California emergency
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Thursday as coronavirus fears prompted California to declare a state of emergency, leading to a 1.55% drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 1.74% and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 2.53%. The decline was driven by crippled travel demand and airline stocks, as well as rising coronavirus deaths in the US.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track Wall St rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 2.08% on Thursday, following a surge on Wall Street, as investors reacted to global central bank moves to combat the coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 26,767.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.99% and 1.78% respectively. The rally was driven by the positive market sentiment, despite uncertainty over US trade policies and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore's ambassador to Kuwait to join as non-executive director, says Hyflux's potential investor Aqua Munda
summary: Singapore's Ambassador to Kuwait, Zainul Abidin Rasheed, will join Aqua Munda as a non-executive director. Rasheed, a former senior minister and member of parliament, was appointed alongside Rashed Mubarak Alhajeri, a senior government and private sector executive from Abu Dhabi. Aqua Munda, which has offered to buy Hyflux's debts, made the announcement through the Singapore Exchange. The move follows criticism from Utico, a potential white knight for Hyflux, over Aqua Munda's lack of transparency.

site_title: High-powered electric motorcycles allowed from April 1
summary: Singapore allows high-powered electric motorcycles with power ratings exceeding 10 kW to be registered on public roads starting April 1. Electric motorcycles with a top speed of 50 km/h and above will also be permitted on expressways. A new tax structure will be implemented, with an additional S$200 annual tax for electric motorcycles, increasing to S$300 by 2023. The government aims to expand public charging infrastructure from 1,600 points to 28,000 by 2030, using the CHAdeMO fast-charging standard.

site_title: Hongkong Land's full-year earnings drop 92%
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a 92% drop in net profit to US$198 million for the full year ended December 2019, mainly due to lower property valuations. Underlying net profit jumped to a record US$1.08 billion. The company's investment properties business remained stable despite social unrest, while a higher contribution from mainland China's development properties offset losses from other markets.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall
summary: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits fell to 216,000 last week, suggesting the labor market remains strong despite the coronavirus outbreak. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a half percentage point to 1.00-1.25% to address economic concerns. Economists attribute the labor market's resilience to its stamina, which could keep the longest expansion on record on track. Job cuts by US-based employers also fell sharply in February, with global outplacement firm Challenger reporting a 16.4% decline to 56,660 job cuts.

site_title: New coronavirus infections may drop to zero by end-March in Wuhan: Govt expert
summary: Wuhan, the epicenter of China's coronavirus epidemic, is expected to see new infections drop to zero by the end of March, according to a government expert. Mainland China reported 139 new confirmed cases, bringing the total accumulated number of cases to 80,409. The number of new cases in Hubei province, where Wuhan is located, has remained in single digits for seven consecutive days. Authorities have imposed sweeping restrictions to contain the outbreak, including transport suspensions, lockdowns of cities, and extending a Lunar New Year holiday.

images.alt_text: Medical staff arranging materials after all patients were discharged at a makeshift hospital set up in a sports stadium in Wuhan. Almost all regions outside Hubei province, where Wuhan is the capital, had managed to halt new infections by the end of last month, the expert said.

site_title: No changes to the Straits Times Index constituents
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents remain unchanged following the March 2020 quarterly review. The next review will take place in June 2020, and the index reserve list includes Mapletree Industrial Trust, Suntec Reit, Keppel Reit, Keppel DC Reit, and Netlink NBN Trust. These stocks will replace ineligible constituents due to corporate actions before the next review. The FTSE ST methodology ensures the indexes accurately represent the investable universe for benchmarking purposes.

site_title: Dairy Farm FY2019 underlying net profit falls 10%
summary: Dairy Farm, a Pan-Asian supermarket and convenience store operator, reported a 10% fall in underlying net profit to US$321 million in FY2019 due to disruptions in Hong Kong caused by social unrest. Revenue fell 5% to US$11.2 billion, while operating profit for its grocery retail business rose 282% to US$63 million. The company attributed the improvement to its space optimisation plan and South-east Asian grocery retail business. A final dividend of 14.50 US cents per share was declared, and the roles of chairman and managing director will be separated in June.

site_title: STI closes 0.2% lower on Thursday as Covid-19 worries in US spike
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower at 3,018.27 on Thursday, despite improving sentiment due to monetary and fiscal stimulus measures. A state of emergency in California and Washington due to the Covid-19 outbreak led to a decline in US futures and Europe, causing the STI to fall. The market had been trending upward due to positive investor sentiment, with the STI up 0.4% the previous day.

site_title: Hugo Boss sees coronavirus hit to sales spreading from Asia
summary: Hugo Boss warns of significant impact from the coronavirus on its first-quarter results, with sales falling particularly in Asia, where more than half its stores in China have been closed. The company expects a gradual normalization by mid-year but still foresees a major hit to 2020 results. Currency-adjusted sales are forecast to rise from zero to 2% in the full year, with a single-digit decline in Asia/Pacific.

site_title: Research consulting startup Arches raises US$450,000 in seed round
summary: Singapore-based research consulting startup Arches has raised US$450,000 in its seed round of fundraising, with participating investors including Vietnamese accounting firm I Glocal and eight angel investors from the private equity industry. The funds will be used to expand its database of experts, strengthen its team, and develop its expert data platform. Arches plans to expand its business operations in multiple countries, including Singapore, Tokyo, and Uzbekistan, and enhance its business development and sales function to optimize its client-expert matching system.

site_title: Covid-19: CapitaLand to give 1,000 tenants rental rebates
summary: CapitaLand, Singapore's largest mall operator, will give rental rebates to 1,000 tenants, including a 50% rebate on fixed rent components and the release of one-month security deposits. The move comes after the Restaurant Association of Singapore accused CapitaLand of not delivering on promised rental rebates. Industry associations urge other landlords to follow suit, citing cashflow issues and the need to foster long-term relationships with tenants.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open
summary: European stock markets diverged on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% to 6,812.16 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.3% to 12,166.90 points. Paris CAC 40 also increased 0.3% to 5,480.32 points. The divergence reflects mixed sentiment, with mining and healthcare stocks supporting gains, while US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: HSBC Singapore to lift female representation in senior roles to 40% by 2022, up from 30%
summary: HSBC Singapore aims to increase female representation in senior roles to 40% by 2022, up from 30%, with a goal of having half of managerial positions taken by women by the same year. The bank has implemented initiatives to promote transparency and remove biases from decision-making processes. This move follows similar commitments from global banking peers such as Citi and Standard Chartered, and comes amid a broader push for greater female representation in the financial industry.

site_title: Keppel Land China to jointly develop residential site in Jiangsu
summary: Keppel Land China has agreed to jointly develop a residential site in Taicang City, Jiangsu, after acquiring a 49% stake in the company for 498 million yuan (S$99.5 million). The remaining stake will be held by Shanghai Shengji Industrial, a subsidiary of CIFI Holdings. This partnership marks Keppel Land's entry into the Jiangsu market, expanding its presence in China's property sector.

site_title: Opec backs biggest oil cut since 2008 crisis, awaits Russia
summary: Opec agreed to cut oil output by 1.5 million barrels per day (bpd) in the second quarter of 2020, its largest reduction since the 2008 financial crisis, in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The move is conditional on Russia and other non-Opec states joining in, with Saudi Arabia pushing for a 1.5 million bpd cut. The cut, which would reduce global supplies by 3.6%, aims to support prices hit by the virus outbreak, which has disrupted demand and growth forecasts.

site_title: Dutch trial seeks justice for MH17 families
summary: The Netherlands is set to put four suspects on trial over the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in 2014, killing all 298 people on board. Igor Girkin, Sergei Dubinsky, Oleg Pulatov, and Leonid Kharchenko will be tried for their alleged roles in bringing a Russian-made missile to Ukraine. The trial, which is expected to last a year, will provide some closure for the victims' families, who have been seeking justice for over five years. Despite the suspects not being physically present, family members will be able to attend the trial, which is seen as a significant step towards accountability.

site_title: Insurer Aviva posts record £3.2b operating profit
summary: Aviva, Britain's second-largest insurer, posted a record £3.2 billion operating profit in 2019, a 6% increase. Despite a dip in UK life business profits, the company saw strong overall business growth in general and life insurance. Aviva's operating ratio weakened slightly to 97.5%, but the company aims to improve business performance and enhance returns through disciplined action on expenses and underwriting. The company will pay a 30.9p dividend per share, up 3% and in line with forecasts.

site_title: Former UN chief Javier Perez de Cuellar dead at 100
summary: Former UN Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, known for his peace-making efforts, died at 100 in his native Peru on Wednesday. Perez de Cuellar served as UN chief from 1981 to 1991 and played a crucial role in ending the Iran-Iraq war, securing American hostages' release, and brokering peace agreements in Cambodia and El Salvador. Current UN chief Antonio Guterres expressed his condolences, calling Perez de Cuellar a "remarkable and compassionate global leader" who left the world a better place.

site_title: California declares state of emergency over coronavirus crisis
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency due to the coronavirus crisis, as the death toll in the US reached 11, including the first fatality in California. A cruise ship, the Grand Princess, was held off the coast for testing after passengers and crew developed symptoms. The state is deploying government resources to identify cases and slow the spread of the virus. Congress has agreed to provide over $8 billion to fight the outbreak, with Vice-President Mike Pence set to visit affected areas to review containment efforts.

site_title: Japan Post leads US$26.4m round for Singapore adtech startup AnyMind
summary: Japan Post Capital led a US$26.4 million funding round for Singapore-based adtech startup AnyMind Group, bringing the company's total funding to US$62.3 million. The funds will be used to expand into India and the Middle East, grow its digital-out-of-home advertising solution, and launch a direct-to-consumer offering for influencers. The investment reflects AnyMind's growth in Asia and its potential in the digital marketing space.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher after global stimulus measures
summary: South Korean shares rose for a fourth consecutive session, closing 1.26% higher at 2,085.26. The gains were driven by global stimulus efforts to combat the coronavirus, including emergency funding from the IMF, World Bank, and US House of Representatives. However, rising US infections remain a risk, and markets are expected to remain volatile through March. South Korea reported 438 new cases, with a death toll of 35, but new infections are slowing, raising hopes the epidemic's peak may be over.

site_title: Singapore e-sports company ESPL snags funding from VC firm 500 Startups
summary: Singapore-based e-sports company ESPL secured an undisclosed investment from US VC firm 500 Startups as part of its seed round fundraising. The investment will support ESPL's expansion into 10 countries, rolling out branded tournaments and platforms. ESPL focuses on mobile ecosystems for amateur e-sports leagues globally, with a national franchise model allowing participation in global competitions. The startup has franchise partnerships in South-east Asia and Latin America, and plans its first season to run from April to November 2020.

site_title: Italy may raise Covid-19 support spending to 5b euros: deputy minister
summary: Italy's government is likely to increase its COVID-19 support spending to 5 billion euros, Deputy Economy Minister Laura Castelli said, citing the need to "raise the bar as much as possible" to help the economy. This would surpass the 3.6 billion euros already promised by Economy Minister Roberto Gualtieri. Rome is also considering asking for a temporary suspension of the European Stability and Growth Pact.

site_title: ARA completes acquisition of majority stake in Logos
summary: ARA Asset Management has completed the acquisition of a majority stake in logistics property firm Logos Group, creating a logistics real estate development and investment management platform. The deal combines ARA's global fund management capabilities with Logos' Asia-Pacific logistics expertise, offering a suite of products in the private and public markets. The acquisition was cleared by Singapore's competition watchdog after a proposed merger between Logos China Investments and ARA Logistics was also approved last year. Logos will operate as ARA's exclusive platform for logistics assets globally.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB sees value in Amara; maintains 'buy'
summary: RHB Research maintains its "buy" recommendation on Amara Holdings, citing its undervalued shares at a 44% discount to RNAV. Despite a 14% dip in earnings due to the Covid-19 outbreak, the research house lowered its price target to S$0.78 from S$0.88.
