Amara's FY2019 net profit declined 11.9% to S$28.2 million, but revenue edged up 1.1% to S$105.3 million. The company declared a S$0.02 dividend per share, representing a 5% dividend yield.

site_title: Water treatment firm Memiontec debuts on Catalist at 22.5 S cents
summary: Memiontec Holdings, a water treatment company, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at 22.5 Singapore cents apiece, unchanged from its IPO price. The company operates in Singapore, Indonesia, and China, with over 20 years of experience in water and wastewater management services. Memiontec has built a "sizeable regional business" and is well-positioned to tap into growing demand for treated water, particularly in Indonesia. The company's IPO represents about 15.2% of its enlarged share capital, with the remaining stake held by co-founders and strategic investors.

site_title: M1 inks MVNO partnership with Wi-Fi services provider Geenet
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has partnered with Geenet, a Wi-Fi services provider, to offer mobile services to dormitory residents. Geenet will utilize M1's mobile network infrastructure to provide integrated Wi-Fi and mobile services, including data, SMS, and international calls. The partnership aims to capture a larger market share by targeting a new and untapped group of customers. Geenet currently offers Wi-Fi services to over 20 dormitories, and the new mobile service option will be available to its subscribers.

site_title: S$1b expansion of Singapore's cycling path network to be brought forward
summary: The Singapore government plans to accelerate the expansion of its cycling path network, aiming to reach 800km of paths by 2023, two years ahead of the original target of 2025. The S$1 billion expansion is part of the Islandwide Cycling Network programme, which will improve cycling infrastructure across the island. The move is expected to enhance cycling safety and encourage more residents to adopt environmentally friendly transportation options.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rallies more than 1% on US gains
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.09% to 21,329.12 on Thursday, driven by a sharp rebound on Wall Street following Joe Biden's strong Democratic primary performance. The broader Topix index gained 0.88%. The rally comes ahead of US GDP data and US-EU trade talks, which traders are monitoring for further market direction.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best day in 2 months on Wall Street lead; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to a two-month high, driven by a surge on Wall Street, where former US Vice-President Joe Biden's strong performance in the Democratic presidential primaries boosted the S&P 500 index. US services sector activity jumped to a one-year high, and a US$8.3 billion spending package to combat the coronavirus spread was announced. Australian healthcare stocks rose 2.7%, while financial services firms Macquarie Group and Insurance Australia Group also advanced. New Zealand's benchmark index gained 2% for a three-day winning streak.

site_title: Singapore shares resume Thursday afternoon trading, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,034.18 on Thursday, as investor confidence remained strong due to monetary and fiscal stimulus measures. Volume traded 865 million securities, beating its 2019 intraday average. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: South Korea reports 438 new coronavirus cases, less than previous day
summary: South Korea reported 438 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 5,766, with three more deaths, for a total of 35. Hospitals in hardest-hit areas continue to struggle with new patients. The US military in South Korea has six cases, including two new ones.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on Wall Street cheer, global stimulus
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, tracking gains on Wall Street, as global stimulus efforts boosted sentiment. The Kospi index rose 6.4 points to 2,065.73, despite foreign investors selling 124.6 billion won worth of shares. The country reported 438 new virus cases, raising the national tally to 5,766, but new infections were seen slowing, supporting hopes that the peak of the epidemic may be over.

site_title: HDB resale market 'resilient' in February even though fewer flats change hands
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore remained resilient in February, despite a 13.1% decrease in flat sales compared to January. Fewer flats changed hands due to seasonal fluctuations, with 1,668 units sold. Prices inched up by 0.7% during the month, reversing the 3.3% increase in January. This suggests a continued demand for HDB flats, despite the decrease in sales.

site_title: UK regional airline Flybe says it is entering administration
summary: British regional airline Flybe has collapsed, entering administration due to the spread of the novel coronavirus. All flights have been grounded and the UK business has ceased trading with immediate effect. Flybe, which avoided going bust in January after receiving a tax holiday, cited the heavy toll of the pandemic on airlines. The airline's collapse is the latest blow to the UK's aviation industry, which has been severely impacted by the crisis.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts downgrade Singapore banks after Fed rate cut
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB and DBS Group Research have downgraded Singapore banks, expecting a 10-12 basis point compression in net interest margins in FY2020 due to the Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut. They also forecast a 25-50 basis point rate cut in March/April, further compressing loan yields. DBS has been downgraded to "hold" with a target price of S$24.33, while UOB and OCBC Bank remain "hold" with lower target prices.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on gains as central banks take action
summary: Asian markets continued their gains on Thursday, building on a surge in Wall Street, as global stimulus measures and central bank actions boosted confidence. Following a recent rout, equities have shown a revival, with China slowly recovering from lockdowns. Despite rising death and infection tolls, investors remain optimistic, with the Singapore stock market reaching a 5-day rally.

site_title: UBS hardens energy lending as sustainable investments rise
summary: UBS reported a 50% increase in sustainable investments to nearly $500 billion in 2019, accounting for 13.5% of its total invested assets. The bank's lending to the energy and utilities sectors fell 40% to $1.9 billion, as it tightened its rules. UBS aims to be a leader in sustainable investing and has defined core sustainable investments, including impact investing, as part of its strategy to shape a positive future. The bank's chairman, Axel Weber, emphasized the importance of taking a leading role in the transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Switzerland's UBS said the value of its 'sustainable' investments rose by more than 50 per cent to nearly US$500 billion in 2019, while lending to the energy and utilities sectors fell by 40 per cent as it tightened its rules.

site_title: Payments startup hoolah raises 8-figure sum in Series A round
summary: Payments startup Hoolah has raised an eight-figure sum in its Series A round led by Allectus Capital, with additional investors including iGlobe Ventures, Genting Ventures, and Max Bittner. The funds will be used to expand in Malaysia, build an omnichannel solution, and double down on its recently launched presence. Hoolah's "buy now, pay later" payment solution allows customers to pay for products in interest-free instalments, with partners including HipVan and Sennheiser. The startup is currently hiring across sales, marketing, and technology functions in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Funds from hoolah's Series A round will be used to double down on the startup's recently announced launch in Malaysia and to fuel further expansion. It will also build an omnichannel solution which will enable customers to shop online and in-store.

site_title: Microsoft asks staff in Seattle area, Silicon Valley to work from home
summary: Microsoft has asked employees in the Seattle area and Silicon Valley to work from home due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The request, effective until March 25, aims to limit exposure and make the workplace safer. Executive Vice-President Kurt DelBene stated that these measures will ensure employee safety and create a safer environment for those who need to be onsite. This decision follows cases near Microsoft's headquarters and in California, joining other US companies in adopting remote work arrangements to combat the virus.

site_title: Wuhan doctor recounts fears and hope at coronavirus frontline
summary: Frontline doctor Ma Yonggang in Wuhan reports a slowdown in new coronavirus cases, with only 3-4 new patients admitted daily and 3-4 recovered patients discharged daily. The makeshift hospital, which initially struggled with shortages of medical supplies and crowded conditions, has improved with basic facilities such as patient exercise areas and bathrooms. Ma, the hospital's deputy director, expressed sadness over the loss of medical workers, including whistleblower Li Wenliang, and remains committed to fighting the virus.

site_title: Vietnam Air passengers quarantined on virus exposure threat
summary: A Vietnam Airlines flight from Nagoya to Ho Chi Minh City was quarantined after a Japanese passenger tested positive for COVID-19. 51 passengers were placed in quarantine, while 22 others were allowed to continue their journey. Two security staff and six employees at a business lounge were also isolated due to close contact with the infected passenger. Vietnamese authorities are investigating the passenger's previous travel history in Cambodia.

site_title: Singapore retail sales fall 5.3% in January due to drop in motor sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 5.3% in January, primarily due to a 5.8% drop in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales increased 0.6% year-on-year. The total sales value for January was S$4.1 billion, with 5.8% coming from online sales. This marks a deeper decline than the 3.4% fall in December.

site_title: Australia's Myer counting on clicks as coronavirus keeps shoppers at home
summary: Australia's Myer Holdings reported a 37% fall in profit for the six months ending January 25, citing the impact of cutting unprofitable brands and a decline in tourist numbers due to the bushfire season. The company, however, saw a 25% jump in online sales to A$168.2 million. Chief executive John King attributed the online growth to the coronavirus, which is expected to continue impacting brick-and-mortar stores. Myer's underlying profit rose 0.5% to A$41.5 million, and the company suspended its dividend.

site_title: Haidilao hotpot queen opens family office in Singapore to manage wealth
summary: Shu Ping, the billionaire behind Haidilao International Holding, has opened a family office in Singapore to manage her wealth, worth around US$7.7 billion. The office, Sunrise Capital Management, will provide personalized services to her and her husband, Zhang Yong, who also have substantial ties to Singapore. The move comes as Haidilao faces a critical test due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the company's revenue heavily reliant on mainland China.

site_title: Singapore's major transport infrastructure projects may be delayed if outbreak drags on
summary: Singapore's major transport infrastructure projects may be delayed if the Covid-19 outbreak drags on, said Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. The projects, including Changi Airport's Terminal 5 and new MRT stations, could be impacted by disrupted supply of construction equipment and materials. However, Khaw emphasized that the outbreak will eventually subside, and Singapore's economy will recover. The government is working with contractors to find alternative sources of equipment and materials, and urged companies and workers to use the lull period to transform and grow.

site_title: Opec divided on how to combat coronavirus fallout
summary: OPEC ministers are meeting in Vienna to discuss production cuts in response to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil prices. The European benchmark of Brent fell to under $50, a level not reached since 2017. The group's previous attempt to support prices by agreeing on production cuts has been undermined by abundant supply and the virus's effect on global demand, particularly in China. The success of the summit depends on the alliance between Russia and Saudi Arabia, with some members opposing further cuts, while others, like Iran and Saudi Arabia, support deeper reductions to stabilize the market.

site_title: Australia toilet paper truck catches fire sparking new tissue tizzy
summary: A delivery truck carrying toilet paper in Brisbane, Australia, caught fire, sparking panic over the availability of toilet paper amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Shoppers have cleared shelves, and supermarkets have limited purchases. The government has urged against stockpiling, and Prime Minister Scott Morrison has attempted to calm concerns. Australia has reported 53 coronavirus infections and two deaths. The incident has contributed to a sense of urgency over toilet paper availability, exacerbating the shortage.

site_title: S$60b earmarked for expansion, renewal of rail network over next decade: Khaw
summary: Singapore plans to spend over S$60 billion on expanding and renewing its rail network over the next decade. The expansion includes the completion of the Thomson-East Coast Line, North East Line, and Downtown Line by 2024-2025, and the Cross Island Line by 2029. The government also aims to renew the North-South and East-West Lines by 2023. The Transport Minister, Khaw Boon Wan, emphasized the need for investment in good operations and maintenance to prevent problems like those experienced by SMRT. The goal is to expand the rail network to 360km by 2030.

site_title: Startup Zuzu Hospitality expands to Vietnam; makes key country hires
summary: Zuzu Hospitality, a hotel tech services provider, has expanded to Vietnam with the launch of sales offices in Ho Chi Minh City, Danang, and Hanoi. The startup has hired Ho Vu Phuong Chi as head of sales and Nhung Nguyen as country manager. Despite the Covid-19 outbreak, Zuzu plans to acquire independent hotel partners to help them access new channels of demand. The company is now working with over 2,000 hotel partners across eight markets in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Australia bans travellers from South Korea in bid to slow coronavirus
summary: Australia has banned travellers from South Korea to slow the spread of the coronavirus, Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced. The country will also extend its travel ban to mainland China and Iran, and conduct enhanced screenings of travellers from Italy. The decision aims to "afford the best protection and enable us to slow down the rate of transmission," Morrison said.

site_title: Nestle vows to plant 3m trees in Mexico, Brazil to help set off emissions
summary: Nestle is launching a reforestation project to plant at least 3 million trees in Mexico and Brazil, aiming to offset its carbon emissions and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The project, in partnership with non-profit One Tree Planted, will cost $45 million and prioritize renewable energy, alternative packaging materials, and carbon absorption. The initiative is part of Nestle's broader sustainability efforts, including a commitment to reduce global temperature rise and invest in environmental protection in regions like Mexico, where the company sources key products.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher; markets cheer Biden's strong show
summary: Australian shares rose 1.9% on Thursday, tracking Wall Street's gains after Joe Biden's strong showing in the US Democratic presidential primary contests. The Federal Reserve's surprise rate cut and the US House of Representatives' approval of an $8.3 billion bill to tackle the economic impact of the coronavirus also boosted sentiment. Markets cheered Biden's less likely stance on taxes and regulations compared to Bernie Sanders. The S&P/ASX 200 index recovered from a 1.7% fall on Wednesday, with healthcare and technology stocks leading the gains.

site_title: No records of alleged loan transactions with Thong Soon Seng: Magnus Energy
summary: Magnus Energy Group stated it is unaware of a person named Thong Soon Seng, who allegedly owes the company S$5.1 million, including interest. The company has no records of loan transactions or transactions with Thong Soon Seng. Magnus Energy's board does not know who Thong Soon Seng is and has found no records of transactions with him. The company received a letter of demand from the alleged debt.

site_title: Singapore's intellectual property chief to take top job at global agency
summary: Singaporean Daren Tang, 47, is set to become the next director general of the United Nations World Intellectual Property Organization (Wipo), succeeding Australia's Francis Gurry. Tang, who is currently CEO of Singapore's Intellectual Property Office, was selected from 10 candidates and will begin his six-year term on October 1. His nomination must be confirmed by the Wipo General Assembly on May 7-8. Tang's appointment marks the first time a Singaporean has led a top role in a UN organization, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong congratulated him on the nomination.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking Wall Street rebound; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, tracking a Wall Street rebound, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 12.75 points or 0.4% to 3,037.78. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 20, with about 50.2 million securities worth S$86.8 million changing hands.

site_title: Virus looms as election issue for New Zealand's Ardern
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's re-election plans face a potential stumbling block as the global coronavirus outbreak emerges as a key issue. A poll shows 47% of voters are dissatisfied with the government's handling of the virus, with 55% wanting stronger travel bans. Ardern's Labour Party trails the National Party in polls, and her government may struggle to form a government without coalition support. The election is scheduled for September 19, and Ardern's popularity overseas may not translate to voter support at home.

images.alt_text: The global coronavirus outbreak is emerging as a potential stumbling block for New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's re-election plans, with a poll on Thursday showing unease over her government's handling of the crisis.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 4.09 points or 0.27% to 1,494.04. The index saw 98.79 million lots traded worth RM42.07 million, with gainers beating losers 204 to 39.

site_title: In celebration of women's achievements
summary: International Women's Day is celebrated globally on March 8, focusing on gender equality. Top banker Tan Su Shan is a role model, advocating for female empowerment and inclusivity in finance. She co-founded the Financial Women's Association and promotes reverse mentoring to stay updated on tech and digital developments. Tan also supports philanthropic missions in Cambodia, showcasing her commitment to making a difference.

site_title: China reports 139 new coronavirus cases, death toll pass 3,000
summary: Mainland China reported 139 new confirmed cases of coronavirus infections, bringing the total to 80,409. The death toll rose to 3,012, with all new deaths occurring in the central province of Hubei, the epicentre of the outbreak. The majority of deaths, 23, were in Wuhan, the provincial capital.

site_title: Accrelist says no relationship with other owners of unit linked to probe
summary: Accrelist and its subsidiary Jubilee Industries have denied any relationship with the remaining 30% owners of Honfoong Plastic Industries, which is under investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). The investigation relates to expenses and a payment made by Honfoong Plastic Industries during the Chinese New Year period. Jubilee acquired the firm in 2018 and its pre-acquisition management team continues to be involved in managing the business. Accrelist's executive chairman, Terence Tea, has been asked to assist with the CPIB probe.

site_title: US lawmakers seek to step up pressure on UK to reverse Huawei 5G decision
summary: US lawmakers have proposed legislation to step up pressure on the UK to reverse its decision to allow Huawei to build portions of the UK's 5G networks. The bill would require the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US to review the UK's place on the foreign investment whitelist. The move comes after the Trump administration barred US companies from using Huawei equipment due to national security concerns. The UK has been exempt from increased US scrutiny, but lawmakers want to ensure the country's networks are secure.

site_title: 1.52b yuan bargain purchase gain led to FY19 income surge: Yanlord
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a surge in FY19 income, driven by a gain of 1.52 billion yuan (S$303.6 million) from bargain purchases of 1.52 billion yuan. The company more than doubled its other operating income and other gains to 1.90 billion yuan. The gain arose from acquiring additional interests in three firms, including Yanlord Investment (Singapore), United Engineers, and WBL Corporation, resulting in a net fair value gain. This was also contributed by a 168 million yuan increase in interest income and a fair-value gain from put liability.

site_title: Obama on coronavirus: skip the masks, stay calm
summary: Former US President Barack Obama advised people to take "common sense precautions" against the coronavirus, recommending hand-washing and staying home if sick. He urged calmness, saying masks should be reserved for healthcare workers. The US death toll from the virus rose to 11, with over 130 infected nationwide. The government has allocated over $8 billion to combat the outbreak. Obama's comments come as the World Health Organization faces shortages of protective equipment due to high demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on stable yen, rallies in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a sharp rebound in US shares and a halt in the yen's appreciation against the dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 1.15% to 21,343.74, while the broader Topix index rose 1.16% to 1,519.90. Analysts attribute the rebound to a surge in US shares and a lull in the yen's appreciation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord, Cheung Woh, Tee Int'l, Trek 2000, Accrelist
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a 166% surge in other operating income and gains for FY2019, partly due to a 1.52 billion yuan gain from a bargain purchase. Cheung Woh Technologies signed a confirmation letter to sell its Tuas property for S$6 million. Shares of these companies fell and rose, respectively, after the announcements.

site_title: Airline executives tell Trump: planes getting cleaner amid coronavirus concerns
summary: US President Donald Trump met with airline executives to discuss the impact of the coronavirus on the industry. Executives from top airlines, including Southwest, United, American, and JetBlue, reported increased efforts to sanitize planes amid concerns. Trump noted that while the virus is affecting the airline business, domestic travel may have a positive impact, while international travel will be substantial. The executives stated they have made changes to cleaning procedures, including using gloves and promoting hand-free greetings, and did not request financial assistance.

site_title: Sanders speaks with rival Warren as she weighs campaign future
summary: Bernie Sanders spoke with rival Elizabeth Warren, who is assessing her campaign future after a disappointing Super Tuesday. Warren's campaign manager said she was talking to aides to consider her path forward. Sanders expressed respect for Warren's time and space, while acknowledging his own disappointment in Tuesday's contests. Warren's loss in her home state primary and failure to finish in the top two in any state has led to speculation about her campaign's future, with pressure to endorse either Sanders or Joe Biden if she ends her White House bid.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.48% on Thursday, following a surge on Wall Street, as investors awaited fresh stimulus from governments to ease the impact of the coronavirus crisis. The Hang Seng Index reached 26,348.16, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.81%. The rally was also driven by expectations of positive economic data, with the US GDP set to be released later in the day.

site_title: Evia Real Estate to sharpen focus on ECs, commercial real estate
summary: Evia Real Estate, a Singaporean developer, plans to focus on executive condominiums and commercial real estate to build recurring income. Managing partner Vincent Ong cited a supply overhang in the private residential market, citing 30,473 unsold units, as the reason for this strategy. Evia is marketing its 548-unit OLÁ Residences EC in Sengkang and scouting for commercial properties, such as offices and shopping centers. The company is also exploring a loosening of cooling measures or tweaks to the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for developers.

site_title: No time to release a film: latest Bond delayed on virus fears
summary: The new James Bond film, "No Time To Die," has been delayed until November 2020 due to concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. The film was initially set for a March 31 release in London and April global rollout. With over 93,000 infected and 3,200 deaths worldwide, the decision was made to postpone the release to ensure a safe theatrical experience. The film will now be released in the UK on November 12, 2020, with US and worldwide releases following on November 25, 2020.

site_title: Cheung Woh Technologies eyes S$6m sale of underused Tuas head office
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies is selling its underutilized Tuas head office in Singapore for S$6 million to Yi Hui Metals. The property, previously used for manufacturing, has been relocated to Malaysia. The sale is seen as beneficial for the company, allowing it to realize the property's value and improve its cash position. The transaction is subject to the formalization of an option to purchase within two weeks.

site_title: Philippines inflation slows for first time in four months in Feb
summary: The Philippines experienced its first slowdown in inflation in four months in February, with consumer prices rising 2.6% from the previous year, down from a 2.9% rise in January. Core inflation, excluding volatile food and fuel items, eased to 3.2% in February from 3.3% in January. This marks a decline from analysts' expectations of a 3.0% rise. The easing inflation rate is a positive sign for the country's economic growth.

site_title: Fed says coronavirus causing disruptions, widespread concern
summary: The Federal Reserve reported that the coronavirus outbreak is causing disruptions to the US economy, with businesses warning of further disruptions in the coming weeks. The Fed's beige book survey noted concerns about the virus, tariffs, and tight labor markets. In response, the Fed cut interest rates by a half point to boost confidence and shore up the economy. The US Congress approved an $8 billion emergency spending package to combat the disease's health and economic consequences. Economists warn that second-quarter growth may take a major hit due to the virus's impact.

site_title: Twitter tests vanishing tweets to keep up with Snapchat, Facebook
summary: Twitter is testing "Fleets," a feature that allows users to send ephemeral tweets that vanish after 24 hours, similar to Snapchat and Facebook. The test is being conducted in Brazil, and the goal is to encourage users to share thoughts they might not have expressed in a permanent tweet. Twitter product lead Kayvon Beykpour said the new format could lead to a substantial change in how users interact with the platform. The company aims to learn how customers use the feature and adapt it if successful.

site_title: Dairy giant Fonterra chairman to retire
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, announced that chairman John Monaghan will retire in November after a three-year term. Monaghan cited the company's new strategy and debt reduction efforts as reasons for his departure, amid a record net loss of NZ$605 million. Fonterra is refocusing on its core business after a string of poorly performing offshore investments and a chairman-elect will be named by August.

site_title: NEWSand, NEWOil part of efforts to be circular economy
summary: The Singapore government is exploring the possibility of producing NEWSand on a commercial scale, a by-product of incineration bottom ash or slag, to support the country's transition to a circular economy. NEWSand can be made from various sources and has different forms. This initiative aims to promote sustainability and reduce waste.

site_title: Five more bus captains file lawsuits against SBS Transit in pay dispute
summary: SBS Transit has been served a writ of summons by Carson Law Chambers on behalf of five bus captains in a pay dispute over allegedly uncompensated hours and duties. The five captains claim SBS Transit breached their contracts by not compensating them for rest days, public holidays, and night shifts. The company intends to defend against all allegations vigorously, with a trial estimated to take around three months. This is the latest round of lawsuits filed by 13 drivers, including eight who previously filed lawsuits last year.

site_title: Ex-Uber self-driving head owes US$179m to Google in contract dispute
summary: A San Francisco County court ordered Anthony Levandowski, former head of Uber's self-driving technology unit, to pay Google $179 million to settle a contract dispute. The arbitration panel found Levandowski and colleague Lior Ron engaged in unfair competition and breached their duty of loyalty when they started a rival autonomous vehicle technology company using Google technology and employees. This ruling is the latest in a multi-pronged legal battle between Google and Uber's Waymo, with Uber likely to be responsible for the payments due to its indemnification policies.

site_title: New coronavirus cases in LA, New York as lawmakers reach funding deal
summary: The US cities of Los Angeles and New York reported 10 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to over 130 infected and 9 deaths in the country. A funding deal worth over $8.3 billion was reached by lawmakers to combat the outbreak, exceeding President Trump's initial request of $2.5 billion. The cases in LA were linked to close contact with a man who tested positive in northern Italy, while New York reported cases among family members and a neighbor of the infected individual.

images.alt_text: The United States' two biggest cities reported 10 more coronavirus cases on Wednesday, as lawmakers in Congress reached a deal to provide more than US$8 billion to fight the outbreak.

site_title: Cancelled bookings, empty rooms: coronavirus takes toll on tourism
summary: The coronavirus pandemic is taking a devastating toll on the global tourism industry, with many hotels and travel companies reporting cancelled bookings and empty rooms. In Italy, over 3,000 confirmed cases and 100 deaths have led to school and theater closures. Industry experts predict a 1.5% decline in international travel this year, with Asia Pacific expected to take the hardest hit, a 10.5% decline in visitor arrivals forecast. Hotels are offering discounts and loosening cancellation policies to attract bookings, but many are struggling to stay afloat, with some reporting losses and considering closure.

site_title: More central banks likely to follow Fed into easing, but effect could be muted
summary: The US Federal Reserve made an emergency 50 basis point rate cut to 1-1.25% to combat the Covid-19 outbreak, with other central banks expected to follow suit. However, the effects may be limited. The move surprised many and is its largest since the 2008 global financial crisis. Strategists predict a potential easing of monetary policies globally, but the impact on economies remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe: Shares up on defensive plays as stimulus hopes laced with caution
summary: European shares rose 1.4% on Wednesday, driven by gains in defensive sectors such as utilities and telecoms, as investors cautiously welcomed monetary stimulus to offset the economic impact of the coronavirus. The Stoxx 600 index led gains, with Danish wind farm developer Orsted A/S surging 5% and healthcare stocks jumping. Despite a 90% chance of an ECB deposit rate cut, concerns over virus uncertainty persist, with IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva warning of wiped-out global growth in 2020.

site_title: United Airlines tightens its belt as coronavirus hits demand
summary: United Airlines is implementing cost-cutting measures due to the coronavirus epidemic, citing diminished demand. The airline will freeze new hiring, delay salary increases, and reduce its international and domestic schedules by 20% and 10% respectively. Employees can apply for voluntary unpaid leaves of absence, and merit salary increases are postponed until July 1. These measures aim to help the company "weather a crisis like this" and are in line with United's efforts to adapt to the uncertain environment.

site_title: Flybe nearing bankruptcy: reports
summary: British regional airline Flybe is reportedly on the brink of bankruptcy due to the coronavirus epidemic's impact on travel, despite a failed attempt to secure a £100 million state loan. The airline, which employs 2,000 people, has struggled since being purchased by a consortium last year, citing weak demand and fierce competition. A financial resource shortage may force Flybe to collapse by the end of this month, according to reports.

site_title: Covid-19: Lessons for US from China on financial stability
summary: The US can learn from China's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in terms of financial stability. China has taken steps to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), including cutting interest rates and setting up a re-lending facility, to mitigate the impact of the outbreak. In contrast, the Federal Reserve has been hesitant to take bold action, with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell describing its current policy stance as "appropriate" without committing to future changes. This approach may not be sufficient to support the US' SMEs, which are in worse financial shape than their Chinese counterparts.

site_title: Singapore leads in Asian outbound real estate investment for 2019
summary: Singapore led Asian outbound real estate investment in 2019 with US$15 billion, surpassing Korea's US$12.5 billion. Asian investment volume dropped 17% year-on-year due to a lack of large portfolio transactions. Despite Chinese investors pulling back, Korean buyers increased their investment, with Paris attracting US$4.9 billion in deals. Singapore investors favored office assets, followed by industrial and logistics, and residential assets, including student housing. The market is expected to shift towards assets with stable income streams in 2020.

site_title: Follow the Federal Reserve? Why central banks will not be rushed on coronavirus response
summary: The world's major central banks are hesitant to rush into a coronavirus response, unlike the Federal Reserve, which recently cut interest rates by half a percentage point. The Bank of Canada followed suit, but other key central banks in the euro zone, Japan, Britain, and Switzerland are cautious and may not make similar moves. This is due to the ongoing disruption of global supply chains, slowing industrial activity, and impact on financial markets, making a swift response less necessary.

site_title: US lawmakers told of security risks from China-owned TikTok
summary: US lawmakers have expressed concerns over the security risks of China-owned social media app TikTok, citing potential exploitation by Chinese intelligence services. A Senate hearing revealed officials from the FBI, Justice Department, and Homeland Security have warned of the app's connections to the Chinese government in Beijing. Senator Josh Hawley introduced a bill to ban TikTok from all US government devices, calling it a "major security risk for the American people." The app's data collection practices, including personal biometrics and location data, have raised concerns about potential data transfer to Chinese entities.

site_title: It's too late to fight Covid-19 in US by curbing travel
summary: The US is unlikely to effectively curb the spread of COVID-19 through domestic travel restrictions, experts say. With the virus already widespread across the country, cutting off transportation options would do little to slow its spread, and may cause more harm than good. The World Health Organization and other experts also downplay the potency of travel restrictions, citing past research that suggests they have limited effect in containing outbreaks.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Helping SMEs through Covid-19
summary: The Money FM podcast "Helping SMEs through Covid-19" discusses various challenges and solutions faced by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The episode covers topics such as tenant issues, loan targets, and business rebranding. Meanwhile, recent news includes a specialist centre opening in Japan, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and an otah business rebranding heritage for a younger generation. These stories highlight the ongoing struggles and innovations in the Singaporean business landscape.

site_title: ABSD: Govt to take case-by-case approach for troubled projects
summary: Singapore's government will adopt a case-by-case approach to troubled construction projects, rather than extending the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) timeline to six years. Minister of State Zaqy Mohamad stated that the government is monitoring the construction industry closely and will adjust policies as necessary to ensure a stable property market. The government has also implemented measures to help builders cope with the COVID-19 situation, including allowing prefabricated construction projects to install partially completed modules on site.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 4.5% as stocks continue volatile run
summary: US stocks surged 4.5% on Wednesday, recovering from the biggest weekly losses since 2008, as investors reacted to a strong performance by Joe Biden in the Super Tuesday primaries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 27,090.86, gaining almost 1,200 points, after plummeting 800 points on Tuesday. The rally comes amidst ongoing coronavirus worries and US-EU trade talks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

site_title: Fragrance Group boss selling Sentosa Cove villa for S$24m
summary: Fragrance Group boss Koh Wee Meng is selling a sea-fronting villa in Sentosa Cove for S$24 million, or S$2,464 per square foot. The property, on a 99-year leasehold site, features eight bedrooms and a swimming pool. The sale price is the highest for a bungalow transaction in Sentosa Cove since 2019, but analysts say the market remains attractive for well-located villas, with foreigners and permanent residents keen on viewing activity.

site_title: EU executive seeks to crack down on gender pay gap
summary: The European Commission aims to introduce laws to combat the gender pay gap across the EU, with women earning an average of 16% less than men. The strategy proposes "binding measures on pay transparency" and aims to boost the EU's GDP per capita by up to 10%. Currently, 13 EU member states have no pay transparency measures in place, and only four companies in the FTSE 100 index have female CEOs. The EU's data shows significant disparities in education, health, and corporate boards between men and women.

site_title: Quadria Capital raises US$595m fund for healthcare-focused deals
summary: Quadria Capital, a Singapore-based private equity firm, has raised US$595 million for its second healthcare-focused fund, exceeding its initial target of US$400 million. The firm plans to deploy the funds within eight years and aims for exits in as little as five years. Managing partner Amit Varma stated that severe underfunding of public healthcare hampers sector development, with Asia's healthcare market expected to reach US$4.2 trillion in the next five years. Quadria has made over 20 investments, cumulatively treating 17.5 million patients and managing 2,500 hospital beds.

site_title: After the turmoil: New government in Malaysia has its work cut out
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, faces a daunting task after the collapse of the Pakatan Harapan coalition. The transition was peaceful, with no civil unrest, and institutions of state continued to function normally. However, the new government's ability to tackle corruption trials and continue major projects, such as the High Speed Rail and Johor-Singapore Rapid Transit System, is uncertain. With Umno now the largest party, there is a risk that corruption trials may be dropped, and joint projects may be put on hold due to political will and tenacity.

site_title: Construction sector to adopt digital solutions to boost productivity
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to support the construction sector's digital transformation with S$139 million in funding. The government will help small and medium enterprises adopt digital solutions to boost productivity, with up to 70% funding support available. Additionally, S$120 million will be earmarked for public sector agencies to adopt design for manufacturing and assembly (DfMA) technologies. The government aims to achieve a 70% DfMA adoption rate by 2025 and introduce new professional conversion programmes to prepare mid-career entrants for new job roles in the sector.

site_title: Lego classics build growth for Danish toymaker in shrinking market
summary: Lego, a Danish toymaker, has defied a shrinking toy market with a rise in sales, driven by the latest versions of its classic kits and revamped stores and website. The company's sales growth resumed in 2017 after a decade of double-digit growth, with 190% tariffs on its products failing to hinder its growth. Lego's family-owned model, led by CEO Niels Christiansen, has successfully adapted to the changing market, resulting in a strong financial performance.

site_title: Australian shops limit toilet paper purchases amid coronavirus panic
summary: Australian major grocers have implemented strict limits on toilet paper purchases amid coronavirus panic, with Woolworths Group Ltd limiting sales to four packs per shopper and Costco Wholesale Corp limiting bulk buys to one. This comes as the country records its fourth case of local transmission, with four cases involving people who caught the disease despite not having left the country. The move is seen as a response to widespread panic buying, with shoppers stockpiling goods and social media filled with images of overloaded shopping trolleys.

site_title: Flexible working: The next step to cracking the glass ceiling
summary: Singapore ranks last among 16 countries in terms of working women's rights, with women earning 9% less than men despite similar job roles. Flexible working is seen as a key solution to advance gender equality, with 85% of Indian business employees believing it keeps mothers in the workforce. Newer working models, such as job-sharing, offer flexibility without sacrificing salary or benefits. Businesses with inclusive policies are more successful, with women's talent and leadership vital to growth and profits. Flexible working can drive inclusivity and diversity, making the workforce more accessible for working parents and women.

site_title: India's top court strikes down banking ban on crypto currency
summary: India's Supreme Court overturned a 2018 ban on banking institutions handling cryptocurrency transactions, allowing exchanges and traders to use banks. The ban, issued by the Reserve Bank of India, had led to plummeting trade volumes and business closures. However, the industry still faces hurdles, including a government panel's recommendation to ban private cryptocurrencies and impose heavy fines. The government has yet to act on these recommendations, and the court's ruling may signal a shift towards regulations rather than a blanket ban.

site_title: Oil gives up gains even as Opec works on big output cut
summary: Oil prices ended lower, giving up early gains, after major oil producers, including Saudi Arabia, struggled to bring Russia on board for deeper supply cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $51.13 a barrel, down 1.4%, and US WTI at $46.78 a barrel, down 0.9%. Opec+ is seeking to cut 1 million bpd in supply to balance the market, but Russia has yet to agree, citing a surplus in the market. Analysts predict oil demand will remain weak due to the coronavirus outbreak, with forecasts cutting prices to $45 a barrel in April and $50 in the second quarter.

site_title: COE prices largely unchanged; down slightly across the board
summary: Singapore's COE prices remained largely unchanged in the latest bidding exercise, with slight decreases across categories. Category A COE premium for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$32,699, down 0.9%. Category B COE closed at S$32,801, and the open category COE ended at S$32,500, down 2.5%. Commercial vehicle COE price ended at S$24,202, down 3.3%. The slight price drops are attributed to the ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: Fed's rate cut thrusts Singapore banks into thicker fog
summary: The US Federal Reserve's surprise rate cut has added uncertainty to Singapore banks, with analysts expecting a 1-2% hit to revenue from the novel coronavirus outbreak. The rate cut may need to be revised, with DBS expected to take the biggest hit at 8% cut to profits and dividends. Loan growth is expected to slow to 1.5% in 2020, and Singapore banks' non-interest income, including wealth management, may provide a lifeline to growth. Analysts warn that the outbreak's impact may stretch beyond mid-2020, and the Fed's rate cut may not contain supply or demand shocks.

site_title: Profitability drive, business pivot cited as reasons for CXA layoffs
summary: CXA Group, an insurtech startup, has laid off 12 staff in Singapore, out of a 319-strong regional team, mainly in marketing and roles that have been automated. The layoffs are part of the company's efforts to become profitable, with investors requiring a "clear path to profitability". CXA is seeking to raise US$50 million in Series C funds and has pivoted towards white-labelling its software in partnership with insurers and banks. The company aims to break even by mid-2021 and has denied plans to cut 40 staff, contrary to a previous report.

site_title: Two new Covid-19 cases take total tally to 112; 79 have recovered
summary: Two new Covid-19 cases in Singapore bring the total to 112, with 79 having recovered. A 62-year-old woman who works at a preschool was among the new cases confirmed by the Ministry of Health. One patient was discharged after recovering from the virus.

images.alt_text: Two new cases of the coronavirus (Covid-19) disease were confirmed by the Ministry of Health (MOH) on Wednesday, including a 62-year-old Singaporean woman who works at Creative O Preschoolers' Bay at International Business Park.

site_title: The case for greater gender diversity in non-profit boards
summary: Non-profit boards in Singapore are urged to prioritize gender diversity, with a goal of achieving 30% women representation by 2025. Despite a 27.4% female board presence, many IPCs struggle to increase diversity, citing a lack of willing women candidates. To address this, NPOs should cast a wider net, use executive search firms, and grow the pool of first-time directors. Tokenism is not beneficial, and boards must prioritize diversity that aligns with the organization's needs. Embracing diversity and inclusion is crucial for NPOs to serve diverse communities effectively and advance their mission of public good.

site_title: Ezion proposes scheme of arrangement to address US$740m debt
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based operator of liftboats and jack-up rigs, has proposed a scheme of arrangement to address US$740.9 million of unsecured and unsustainable debts and bonds. This move aims to tackle the company's financial struggles, which have been exacerbated by the downturn in the offshore and marine (O&M) industry.

site_title: How the young can impact the future
summary: A group of young Singaporeans, including 25-year-old Lim Kai Ning, are pitching ideas for a mobile app to help the unemployed find employment and those in careers upskill and stay motivated. The project, developed through the Youth Action Challenge (YAC) in partnership with Citi Foundation and UN Development Programme, aims to address career resilience in a rapidly-changing job market. The winning team will receive up to SGD 50,000 in grants to turn their idea into reality.

site_title: US dollar inches up after Fed rate cut
summary: The US dollar rose after the Federal Reserve (Fed) cut interest rates by 50 basis points to a target range of 1.00-1.25% to combat the effects of the novel coronavirus. The euro remained near two-month highs, while the dollar recovered from earlier losses. The Fed's emergency rate cut was seen as a positive move for the US economy.

site_title: Lewis Hamilton has Schumacher's biggest F1 records in sight
summary: Lewis Hamilton is poised to challenge Michael Schumacher's F1 records, with 91 wins and seven titles within his sights. The 35-year-old Mercedes driver starts the new season in Australia, where he will face off against rival Max Verstappen and Ferrari's Charles Leclerc. Despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Hamilton is confident of another year of dominance, having averaged 10 wins per season for the past six years. The upcoming season promises an epic battle of the generations, with sweeping changes to technical and sporting rules set to take effect in 2021.

site_title: Honeywell unveils plan for 'most powerful' quantum computer
summary: Honeywell has announced plans to launch the world's most powerful quantum computer, which will tackle complex scientific and business challenges. The company, in partnership with Cambridge Quantum Computing and Zapata Computing, aims to accelerate its efforts and find new ways to deploy quantum computing. The new computers will enable industries such as materials, transportation, and finance to explore new molecular structures, optimize logistics, and develop faster and more precise software applications. Honeywell hopes to address computing challenges that have been impractical to tackle with traditional computers.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps after Biden's Super Tuesday surge
summary: US stocks surged over 2% at the open on Wednesday following Joe Biden's surprise lead in the Democratic primaries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 466.27 points, the S&P 500 opened higher by 42.38 points, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 150.01 points. This rally followed Biden's strong performance in the Super Tuesday primaries, lifting investor confidence.

site_title: Singapore targets fridges and air-cons in fight against climate change
summary: Singapore aims to reduce hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) used in refrigerants and air conditioners, with plans to restrict commercial chillers and household appliances starting in 2022. The government will also launch a climate-friendly label, grant support for companies switching to alternative refrigerants, and train technicians to handle refrigerants properly. A S$24.8 million package will help households switch to energy-efficient appliances, and the country will ramp up solar energy generation, with plans to make its waterworks fully solar-powered by 2021.

site_title: S-Reits steal the show after Fed rate cut
summary: S-Reits in Singapore experienced their largest single-day gain of 3.3% after the US Federal Reserve's 50-basis-point emergency rate cut, boosting confidence in the economy. The iEdge S-REIT Index surged 47.4 points, with industrial- and retail-related Reits performing best. Local lenders, however, fell as the Fed cuts are expected to impact net interest margins. The Straits Times Index ended 0.2% higher, despite 11 of its 30 components ending in the red.

site_title: SingPost to cut, freeze upper-level management pay as part of Covid-19 measures
summary: SingPost, a Singapore postal services provider, will implement temporary Covid-19 measures starting April 1, including a 5% pay reduction for senior staff and a pay and promotion freeze for assistant and senior vice-president levels. A hiring freeze will also be implemented across the organization, except for essential roles. The measures will be reviewed quarterly and are part of a broader response by Temasek-linked companies to the virus situation, including other cost-cutting measures and pay reductions.

site_title: Trek former executive director pleads guilty to inflating profit, deceiving EY
summary: A former executive director at Trek 2000 International, Poo Teng Pin, pleaded guilty to conspiring to inflate revenue and pre-tax operating profit by 2% and 406% respectively in 2015. Poo was tasked to create a fictitious $3.2 million sale to boost the company's financial performance. He was also charged with deceiving external auditors EY and falsifying invoices and financial statements. Poo will be sentenced on April 14. Founder Henn Tan and CFO Gurcharan Singh have also been charged, with their cases pending.

site_title: Coronavirus shreds airlines' playbook for crisis management
summary: Airlines are adapting their crisis management strategies due to the rapid spread of coronavirus worldwide. In response to declining demand, airlines such as JetBlue and US majors have suspended change fees for new reservations, but none offer guaranteed refunds. This approach aims to encourage hesitant travelers, but critics argue that it's not enough. The US Travel Association forecasts a 6% decline in international travel to the US over the next three months, while European carriers warn of a "deflated booking environment" until the virus spreads less.

site_title: Covid-19: BCA to allow partial installation for PPVC projects
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore has announced that it will allow partial installation of prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) modules for projects delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This move aims to ease cashflow concerns and allow projects to continue with minimal disruption. The government is also urging main contractors to submit progress payment claims fortnightly instead of monthly, and has advised government agencies to consider extensions of time requests for project delays.

site_title: Biden's Super Tuesday surge reboots Democratic presidential race
summary: US President Joe Biden surged to victory in at least eight of the 14 states where Democrats held primaries on Super Tuesday, outperforming expectations. He won states in the South, Massachusetts, Minnesota, and Texas, and amassed hundreds of delegates. The Democratic establishment is now embracing Biden, betting he is more electable than Senator Bernie Sanders, a liberal champion. Biden's campaign is regaining momentum, but Sanders remains strong among liberal voters and younger voters. The two candidates will battle for the party's nomination, with Biden focusing on building an electoral coalition and Sanders advocating for government-run healthcare and progressive policies.

site_title: Buyers of light goods vehicle get green incentive
summary: Singapore has introduced a Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) to incentivize the purchase of clean light goods vehicles and penalize polluting ones. The scheme offers a S$30,000 incentive for the cleanest vehicles and a S$10,000 surcharge for the most polluting ones. The CVES applies to new and used imported light goods vehicles and goods-cum-passenger vehicles, and is built on the existing Vehicular Emissions Scheme for private cars. The scheme aims to reduce emissions and improve air quality in Singapore.

site_title: SoftBank CEO hosts 'pre-IPO summit' in New York
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son hosted a "pre-IPO summit" in New York, introducing portfolio companies to Wall Street investors who may back their stock market debuts. The event aimed to address poor performance of some SoftBank-backed companies following their listings. The gathering included nine companies, such as Cohesity and OakNorth, and was chaired by Son and BlackRock CEO Larry Fink. The event comes as SoftBank faces pressure to rein in its investment style and defend its track record, particularly after the failure of WeWork's IPO plans.

site_title: Going from a bad dream to a nightmare?
summary: A Bernie Sanders presidency could be worse than President Donald Trump's, according to the article. Both Trump and Sanders have tapped into populist rage, but their supporters have shown a lack of civility and adherence to basic rules of public discourse. Trump has failed to deliver on many of his campaign promises, while Sanders' socialist policies, including nationalizing large sectors of the economy and confiscating wealth, are deemed unrealistic. A Sanders presidency would likely lead to drastic cuts in the US defense budget, reduced military presence abroad, and strained relationships with allies.

site_title: Rupee falls sharply against US dollar on virus fears
summary: The Indian rupee plummeted 0.4% to 73.6 per US dollar, becoming the worst-performing Asian currency, amid fears of the coronavirus outbreak. India has reported 28 positive cases, including 15 Italian tourists. A broad dollar weakness triggered by a US Federal Reserve rate cut also contributed to the decline. Economists predict the rupee may fall to 75 per dollar, surpassing its record low in October 2018. The outflow of foreign funds has weighed on the rupee, with 127.5 billion rupees pulled from sovereign bonds in the past 12 days.

site_title: HDB to do away with re-offer of balance flats exercises
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore will discontinue the re-offer of balance flats (ROF) exercises, allowing most unselected flats from the sale of balance flats (SBF) exercises to be offered directly for open booking. This change aims to simplify the process, reduce the need for balloting, and enable home-seekers with urgent needs to access flats more quickly. The move also supports unwed parents and seniors, with simplified Silver Housing Bonus (SHB) and Lease Buyback Scheme (LBS) enhancements.

site_title: CAD swoops in on Tee Int'l after PwC report flags possible wrongdoings
summary: Tee International, a mainboard-listed company, has been investigated by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) after a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers Risk Services (PwC) raised concerns about possible wrongdoing. The PwC report found that former group CEO Phua Chian Kin had taken company funds to repay personal debts and margin calls. Tee has been asked to provide documents and assistance to CAD, and the company's business operations remain unaffected. The investigation is ongoing, with Tee stating that the company will monitor the progress and make further announcements as required.

site_title: Wanted: A clear, careful strategy to forestall a messy Brexit
summary: The UK and EU are in the final round of negotiations on a new trade and partnership deal following Brexit, with a comprehensive agreement unlikely this year. The UK government is pushing for a "broad outline" of a deal by September, but talks are becoming increasingly complex due to the UK's lack of experience in trade negotiations and the US deal being delayed. The UK-US trade deal, which could boost the UK's economy by only 0.16%, is also facing challenges, with concerns that its benefits have been exaggerated and its ratification may be delayed due to the US election. A disorderly Brexit remains a possibility, posing significant risks for both the UK and the EU.

site_title: 2 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Two new COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total number of cases to 112. The new cases include a 62-year-old non-teaching staff member at a preschool and a 43-year-old permanent resident who recently returned from Malaysia. One patient, Case 61, was discharged after recovering. Both new cases have no recent travel history to affected regions. Contact tracing is underway to establish potential links to previous cases.

site_title: CXA chief cites profitability drive amid fund raising as reason for layoffs
summary: CXA Group, an insurtech startup, has laid off 12 staff in Singapore due to investors' demands for a clear path to profitability. The layoffs are part of the company's efforts to automate manual processes and focus on white-labelling its software. CXA is seeking to raise US$50 million in Series C funds and aims to break even by the first half of 2021, despite previously targeting profitability this year. The company has raised US$58 million to date and is building a tech hub in Vietnam.

site_title: Uber loses French case, driver declared employee
summary: France's top civil court ruled that Uber has effectively employed one of its drivers, declaring them an employee rather than an independent contractor. The ruling rejected Uber's appeal against a 2019 decision, which found the driver had a work contract due to Uber's control over the driver through its app. This decision will impact all platforms inspired by Uber's model, with estimated 150 Uber drivers already filing cases to requalify as employees.

images.alt_text: France's top civil court dealt ride-hailing giant Uber a setback on Wednesday with a ruling that it had effectively employed one of its drivers.

site_title: Japan coronavirus cases hit 1,000 mark as Tokyo insists Olympics on track
summary: Japan reported 36 new coronavirus cases, pushing the total to over 1,000, with most cases linked to a quarantined cruise liner. The Tokyo Olympics are still on track, with organizers dismissing speculation of a cancellation. The virus has spread worldwide, with over 80 nations affected and a global death toll of over 2,980. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has taken measures to prevent the spread of the virus, including school closures and work-from-home policies, but the Olympics' future remains uncertain.

site_title: Investors pile in on Reits after Fed rate cut; STI up 0.2% on Wednesday
summary: Investors in Singapore's real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) surged after the US Federal Reserve's 50-basis-point rate cut, with the iEdge S-REIT Index gaining 3.3% to its largest single-day jump. Reits, seen as beneficiaries of reduced borrowing costs, outperformed the broader market, with industrial- and retail-related Reits performing best. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,025.03, despite local lenders falling due to the expected impact of Fed cuts on net interest margins.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.31 points to 1,489.95 on Wednesday, driven by a strong volume of 3 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion. Losers narrowly outnumbered gainers 481 to 413. The index closed higher despite the uncertainty of US trade policies.

site_title: Virus disruptions may cause 20% cargo decline at US ports
summary: The novel coronavirus is causing a significant decline in cargo volume at US seaports, with estimated first-quarter cargo volume down as much as 20% from the prior year. Cancelled sailings to and from Asia, where the virus has had the most impact, are a major contributor to the decline. The Port of Los Angeles, the largest US container port, saw cargo volumes fall 25% in February, potentially dragging the total container volume in the first quarter down 15%. The economic impact of the virus is being felt globally, with over 90,000 confirmed cases worldwide.

images.alt_text: The Port of Los Angeles, the largest US container port, saw cargo volumes fall roughly 25% in February compared to the prior year, the authority has said.

site_title: StarHub, M1 might serve each other better by tying the knot
summary: Singapore's mobile market may be ripe for consolidation, with TPG Telecom's presence potentially forcing StarHub and M1 to merge. The market's four operators, including TPG, Singtel, StarHub, and M1, have led to concerns about reduced innovation and economies of scale. TPG's protracted trial period has also led to price distortion, prompting the incumbents to submit a joint bid for 5G spectrum. The Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) may be prepared for consolidation, citing market exits as part of competition in the telecom market. A merged entity could serve customers better, invest in new technologies, and prevent destructive competition.

site_title: Tee International ordered to provide documents and assistance to CAD on ex-CEO's remittances
summary: Tee International has been ordered by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) to provide documents and assistance in investigations related to former group CEO Phua Chian Kin's alleged unauthorized remittances of company funds. The company must furnish documents, including financial records and emails, and grant access to its computer systems. The investigation does not affect the company's business operations, which will continue as normal, according to Tee International's statement.

site_title: Croatian designer launches 'cheerful' virus mask line
summary: A Croatian fashion designer, Zoran Aragovic, has launched a "cheerful" collection of virus masks despite them not providing protection against the novel coronavirus. The cotton masks, inspired by Disney characters, pop art, and comic books, have sparked interest across the country, selling dozens of units since production began two weeks ago. Aragovic aims to combat fear of the virus with positive items, labeling his masks as "cheerful fashion accessories" rather than medical masks.

images.alt_text: The idea for a designer mask was spontaneous," Zoran Aragovic, owner of the BiteMyStyle brand, told AFP.

site_title: Thai quarantine flip-flop throws holidays into doubt
summary: Thailand's health minister Anutin Charnvirakul initially ordered 14-day quarantine for travelers from eight countries, but later reversed the decision after posting an announcement. The countries included China, South Korea, Japan, and others, sparking confusion among tourists and travelers. The government has struggled to balance health concerns with the impact on the tourism industry, which is a significant contributor to Thailand's economy. The decision was met with public concern and criticism, highlighting the government's handling of the return of undocumented laborers from South Korea.

site_title: Saudis want Opec+ to cut more than 1 million barrels a day
summary: Saudi Arabia is urging Opec+ to agree to an oil-output cut of more than 1 million barrels a day to compensate for the hit to demand from the coronavirus. This represents a larger cut than the technical committee's recommendation of 600,000 to 1 million barrels a day. The proposal aims to stop the oil price rout, which has slumped 16% last week. However, Russian resistance and the risks of the pandemic continue to pose challenges, with Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh refusing to comment on possible production curbs.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei flat as investors eye Democratic race
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed flat on Wednesday as investors eyed the US Democratic race, with Joe Biden seizing momentum after Super Tuesday victories. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.08%, while the Topix index fell 0.17%. Investors were cautious despite the US Federal Reserve's surprise rate cut.

site_title: IMF chief says virus spread will hold 2020 global growth below last year
summary: The International Monetary Fund's Managing Director, Kristalina Georgieva, stated that the continued spread of the coronavirus will push 2020 global growth below last year's levels, likely at 2.9%, due to the outbreak's economic impact. The IMF will revise its forecasts downward in the coming weeks. Georgieva emphasized that the duration of the outbreak and the effectiveness of mitigation measures will determine the economic impact, but declined to say if the crisis could push the world into a recession.

site_title: Bloomberg drops out, backs Biden in Democratic presidential race
summary: Billionaire former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg has ended his presidential campaign and endorsed Joe Biden for the Democratic Party's nomination. Bloomberg cited a lack of a viable path to the nomination after failing to deliver convincing wins on Super Tuesday. He spent over $500 million on campaign ads and had won more than 15% of the vote in several states. Biden has consolidated support among moderates, leaving a one-on-one contest against Senator Bernie Sanders. Bloomberg's exit marks the end of a novel electoral strategy and a significant shift in the Democratic presidential race.

images.alt_text: Billionaire former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg ended his presidential campaign on Wednesday and said he was backing Joe Biden for the Democratic Party's nomination to challenge President Donald Trump in the November election.

site_title: Hyflux says nTan fees 'fully justified', terms from Utico 'best possible'
summary: Hyflux has defended the S$25 million advisory fee paid to nTan Corporate Advisory, saying it is "fully justified" given the firm's role in navigating the water treatment company's restructuring process. nTan advised the board to secure a rescue package from Utico, which includes a S$50 million allocation for preferred shareholders. Hyflux claims this deal would have left senior unsecured creditors with no returns if the company had gone into judicial management. The company will undertake a "reallocation exercise" for the S$50 million pot of money set aside for professional advisers' fees.

site_title: South Korean airlines contend with virus-related travel restrictions
summary: South Korean airlines are struggling due to widespread travel restrictions imposed by 55 countries in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The country's foreign ministry reported the restrictions, and airlines are cutting costs and seeking government support. Budget airlines requested emergency funds and reduced airport charges and taxes. The South Korean government is discussing support measures with aviation executives to mitigate the impact of the crisis.

site_title: Astaka allays concerns over key persons' cessations and CEO choice
summary: Astaka's sponsor, Novus Corporate Finance, denies being aware of concerns over executive and director cessations, including the retirement of two independent directors and the resignation of the CEO and CFO. CEO Khong Chung Lun, 32, is seen as a qualified and experienced leader, having previously held a senior position in a Malaysian property developer. The company's operations have been heavily involved in the group, and he has been working under the leadership of Zamani Kasim since 2015. The stock closed flat at S$0.088 on the day the responses were published.

site_title: Offshore ownership of Chinese bonds breaks new high
summary: Foreign ownership of Chinese yuan-denominated onshore bonds reached a record high in February, with international investors holding over 1.95 trillion yuan (S$389.64 billion). This marks the 15th consecutive month of increases, with government bonds rising 2.3% and policy bank bonds up 6.8% from January. The growth is attributed to the phased inclusion of Chinese bonds in global indices, such as the Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index.

site_title: Fashion house Jean Paul Gaultier to name designer for each new collection
summary: French fashion house Jean Paul Gaultier has announced it will name a new designer for each seasonal Haute Couture collection. Japanese designer Chitose Abe, founder of Sacai, will be the first to take part in this new concept, presenting the next collection in July 2020. The idea of different designers interpreting one brand was conceived by Jean Paul Gaultier in the 1990s. The brand, owned by Spanish company Puig, aims to breathe new life into its Haute Couture collections with this innovative approach.

site_title: Tech firms offer business solutions for handling Covid-19 at special rates
summary: Tech firms offer special rates for Covid-19 business solutions, including remote working and visitor management tools, to help firms adapt amid the outbreak. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and SGTech have curated 50 packages of infocomm technology solutions, available at promotional rates, including extended free trials. Participating firms such as Cisco, Microsoft, and telcos M1, Singtel, and StarHub are offering the solutions to support business continuity and digitalization.

site_title: HDB to do away with re-offer of balance flats exercise: Lawrence Wong
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) is eliminating the re-offer of balance flats exercise, allowing most unsold flats to be offered directly for open booking. This change aims to speed up the access of home-seekers with urgent needs to flats. Additionally, Minister Lawrence Wong announced support for unwed parents, simplification of the Silver Housing Bonus (SHB), and enhancements to the Lease Buyback Scheme (LBS). The SHB will be simplified with reduced requirements, increased cash bonuses, and a maximum bonus of S$30,000.

site_title: Mastercard to lead Series B round for Indonesia's Digiasia Bios
summary: Mastercard is leading a Series B funding round for Indonesia's Digiasia Bios, a fintech holding company. The payments technology giant will provide capital and strategic assistance to expand financial services for individuals and micro, small, and medium enterprises in the digital economy. Digiasia will also leverage Mastercard's banking and cybersecurity expertise. This investment follows existing partnerships with companies like iRMA, Metrodata, and Western Union.

site_title: Dented valuations amid virus spread could offer Asia M&A buys
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has created a grim market environment in Asia, potentially leading to strategic acquisitions as companies look to expand their businesses. Valuations in the region are trading at or below historical averages, making it an opportune time for cash-rich or strong shareholders to pursue mergers and acquisitions. Reits, in particular, are expected to be active bargain hunters, taking advantage of the economic downturn to acquire and grow assets. While there has been no immediate uptick in M&A activity, historical trends suggest that companies in Singapore and the region have historically made significant acquisitions during economic slumps.

site_title: Vietnam among most sensitive to China supply shocks: report
summary: Vietnam is the most vulnerable Asian economy to China supply shocks, with 15.1% of its imports being "China critical goods" (CCG), according to a Deutsche Bank report. This vulnerability is largely due to its reliance on textile intermediates from China, which account for nearly half of its imports in this sector. In contrast, Thailand is the second most vulnerable, with a CCG share of 11%, while Indonesia and the Philippines follow. Singapore and Malaysia are the least vulnerable, with CCG shares of 3.5% and 2.6% respectively.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets waver at open
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% to 6,725.69 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index fell 0.2% to 11,963.41 points. The Paris CAC 40 index also lost 0.2%. Asian markets rose despite a Wall Street sell-off fueled by concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut. The US central bank's move aimed to combat economic fallout from the coronavirus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with losses, easing 0.24% to 26,222.07, after the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut was seen as a sign of concern over the virus's impact. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.63% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.36%. The losses followed a mixed day of trading, with stocks swinging in and out of favor.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index eased 0.24 per cent, or 62.75 points, to 26,222.07.

site_title: COE prices largely unchanged; down slightly across the board
summary: COE prices remained largely unchanged in Singapore's latest bidding exercise, with slight decreases across categories. Category A COE premiums for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closed at S$32,699, down 0.9% from S$32,999. Category B COE closed at S$32,801, down 0.1% from S$32,889. The open category COE decreased by 2.5% to S$32,500, while commercial vehicle COE prices dropped 3.3% to S$24,202.

site_title: Magnus Energy fires legal salvo at 7 former directors and officers
summary: Magnus Energy Group has filed a lawsuit against 7 former directors and officers, claiming damages for alleged breaches of duties and obligations. The company is seeking S$107,745.11 in respect of overpayments made to former CEO Luke Ho, or alternatively, damages. The lawsuit alleges breaches in transactions involving the acquisition of GCM Resources shares, loans to an Indonesian contractor, and other deals. The defendants include Ho, former chairman Kushairi Zaidel, and former COO Koh Teng Kiat. Magnus is seeking costs, interests, and other relief as the High Court deems fit.

site_title: Norway court absolves Rex International unit of compensation claims
summary: A Norway court has acquitted Lime Petroleum, a 90%-owned unit of Rex International, of compensation claims made by Gulf Hibiscus for financial losses suffered due to Lime's restructuring. The court ordered Gulf Hibiscus to pay Lime's legal costs and fees amounting to NOK 5.79 million. Gulf Hibiscus had claimed around US$35 million in compensation, but the ruling was made on Tuesday. Rex International shares were trading flat after the announcement.

site_title: Some Singapore retailers to offer cash allowances to staff, loans to businesses amid virus outbreak
summary: A group of Singapore retailers, including Pure Senses, Wok Hey, and Pink Parlour, are offering cash allowances to workers and interest-free loans to businesses to support staff affected by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The retailers will provide a monthly cash payout of S$30 to workers earning below S$2,000 and match the cost of the allowance for companies that pledge to support the cause. Pure Senses is also offering S$50,000 in interest-free loans to businesses, with a minimum paid-up capital of S$20,000.

site_title: Fed cut alone not enough to boost confidence: Chan Chun Sing
