summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stated that a single interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve is insufficient to boost confidence in the global economy amid the coronavirus outbreak. The Fed's rate cut on Tuesday was the first emergency move since the 2008 financial crisis. Chan expressed concerns about the global economy's potential for a U-shaped or L-shaped recovery, and while Singapore's manufacturing outlook remains cautiously optimistic, the city-state's economic growth forecast for 2020 has been lowered to 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said it'll take more than an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve to boost sentiment in the global economy amid a spreading coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Singapore introduces measures to cut HFC emission; S$24.8m climate-friendly package for households
summary: Singapore has introduced measures to cut HFC emissions, a key contributor to climate change, with a S$24.8m climate-friendly package for households. Starting from 2022, the country plans to restrict the supply of commercial watercooled chillers and household refrigerators and air conditioners using high-potential HFCs. This move aims to reduce the emission of these gases, which can trap more heat in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide if leaked during installation.

site_title: Tourists across globe cancel bookings as virus halts travel
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant decline in global tourism, with over half of hotel bookings in northern Italy's Lake Como region cancelled in just three days. The virus has spread to Europe, South Korea, and Italy, resulting in a US$47 billion monthly loss for the industry, according to the Global Business Travel Association. Airlines and package tour operators predict almost US$30 billion in lost flight sales. The outbreak has hit local economies hard, with businesses from Parisian luxury boutiques to Asian street-food stands relying on tourists.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon trading, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday with a 0.1% decline, as the Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.17 points to 3,015.39. The US Federal Reserve announced a 50 basis point emergency rate cut to boost confidence in the economy amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Despite the Fed's move, markets remained volatile, with the Fed's swift action potentially indicating that the global economic fallout could be worse than expected.

site_title: Sea's Q4 revenue surges on Garena, Shopee growth
summary: Sea Ltd, the Singapore-based group that owns e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, reported a 177% surge in Q4 revenue to US$777.2 million, driven by growth in digital entertainment and e-commerce segments. Despite the increase, the company remained in the red with a net loss of US$281.9 million. The digital entertainment segment accounted for over half of revenue, thanks to a larger active user base and success of self-developed game Free Fire.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on foreign buying after Fed rate cut
summary: South Korean stocks closed 2% higher on Wednesday, driven by foreign buying after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The won strengthened against the US dollar, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreign investors purchased 150 billion won worth of shares, snapping a seven-session selling streak. The Kospi surged 2.2% to 2,059.33, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix closing up 3.6% and 1.6%, respectively. The Bank of Korea pledged to take market stabilizing measures if needed, amid the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak in South Korea.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A group of Singapore retailers are offering cash allowances to staff and interest-free loans to businesses amid the novel coronavirus outbreak. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US tariff announcement and seeks a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup has set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. In other news, a Malaysian agency is set to seize about RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and Thailand's Thaksin is confident that his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case will be cleared.

site_title: Super Tuesday triumph for Biden sets up one-on-one battle against Sanders
summary: Joe Biden won nine of 14 states on Super Tuesday, including surprise wins in Texas and Massachusetts, setting up a one-on-one battle against Bernie Sanders. Biden, who was on life support just weeks ago, emerged as a consensus champion for the moderate wing of the party against Sanders. Biden leads Sanders in delegates 385 to 325, with more than one-third of the delegates up for grabs. The campaign continues through the next two weeks, with nearly another 1,000 delegates up for grabs, including the swing state of Florida on March 17.

site_title: Hyflux to rejig adviser fee pot after WongP's exit, finds nTan fees 'fully justified'
summary: Hyflux is set to reallocate its adviser fee pot after WongPartnership's (WongP) sudden withdrawal as its lawyers. The firm initially planned to distribute the S$40 million pot to 24 advisers, but Utico has increased the pot to S$50 million if the rescue package is supported. Hyflux's board believes adviser nTan Corporate Advisory's fees are "fully justified" and will be paid out of the enlarged pot, with a success fee of up to S$25 million payable to nTan.

site_title: SingPost to cut, freeze upper-level management pay as part of Covid-19 measures
summary: SingPost will implement pay reduction and freezes for upper-level management staff starting April 1 as part of Covid-19 measures. Senior vice-president and above staff will see a 5% pay reduction, while assistant vice-president and above staff will have pay and promotion increments frozen. A hiring freeze will also be implemented, except for essential roles. The measures will be reviewed quarterly and are expected to have no impact on SingPost's future growth plans.

site_title: Australia: Shares close at 9-mth low
summary: Australian shares closed at a 9-month low on Wednesday, falling 1.7% to 6,325.40 due to growing fears of a global economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak. Despite a surprise rate cut by the US Fed, investors overlooked faster-than-expected economic growth of 0.5% in the last quarter. Travel restrictions and a clouded growth outlook for the current quarter contributed to the decline.

site_title: Cybersecurity startup Horangi snags partnership with Tokio Marine Insurance Singapore
summary: Cybersecurity startup Horangi has partnered with Tokio Marine Insurance Singapore, marking the global insurance company's first partnership with a cybersecurity firm in the Asia-Pacific region. Through this partnership, Horangi will provide cybersecurity services to TMiS clients, offering potential rebates. The collaboration aims to unlock deep tech innovation for corporations, demonstrating the value of startup partnerships in driving innovation.

site_title: Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme dangles carrot and stick
summary: Singapore's new Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) offers a S$30,000 incentive for clean light goods vehicles and a S$10,000 surcharge for polluting ones. The scheme applies to new and used imported vehicles, with the cleanest vehicles receiving the incentive and the most polluting ones facing the surcharge. The CVES is built on the existing Vehicular Emissions Scheme for private cars, and will be complemented by the enhanced Early Turnover Scheme starting April 1, 2021. The aim is to reduce air pollution from commercial vehicles, which are a major source of emissions in Singapore.

site_title: Ex-CISO of cryptocurrency exchange Gemini joins cybersecurity firm Horangi
summary: Jim Rouse, former CISO of Gemini, has joined cybersecurity firm Horangi as its vice-president of cyber operations. Rouse brings extensive experience from top organizations, including Sony and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He will help Horangi build a world-class cybersecurity team and tackle complex cybersecurity problems. Horangi's co-founder Paul Hadjy stated that Rouse's leadership and multidisciplinary experience will benefit customers by streamlining their organizational capabilities development.

site_title: Australia stores ration toilet paper amid coronavirus panic buying
summary: Australia's major grocers have restricted toilet paper sales amid panic buying due to coronavirus fears. The country has reported 42 cases of the virus, with three local transmissions. To address shortages, Woolworths Group Ltd has limited sales to four packs per shopper and Costco Wholesale Corp has restricted bulk buys to one per customer. Other products, such as milk and disinfecting products, are also being rationed. The government has confirmed a third case of local transmission without travel history, fueling concerns about community spread.

images.alt_text: Australia's major grocers put strict limits on purchases of toilet paper on Wednesday after a rush of panic buying related to coronavirus fears emptied shelves, as the country recorded its third case of local transmission of the disease.

site_title: Tax evasion: Indonesia's luxury car 'owners' cry foul
summary: Indonesia is cracking down on tax evasion by the wealthy elite, with a 21-year-old construction worker, Dimas Prayitno, being identified as a victim. Prayitno owns a Rolls-Royce but claims to have bought it from a friend, despite owing US$15,000 in taxes. The issue highlights the country's rampant tax dodging, which costs Indonesia billions in lost revenue annually. Jakarta is moving to pass bills aimed at boosting the economy and adding to the middle class, with tax evasion a major concern. The government is cracking down on tax evasion by the wealthy elite.

site_title: New normal in virus-hit China: High-tech tracking and elbow greetings
summary: China has implemented new measures to combat the coronavirus, including high-tech tracking, temperature checks, and social distancing protocols. The country has also introduced a rating system for travelers, where individuals are classified as green, yellow, or red based on their movements. These measures have led to increased surveillance and restrictions on travel, with some cities experiencing "sold-out" trains due to limited ticket availability. The government's efforts have been met with criticism over concerns of mass surveillance, but the measures appear to be effective in slowing the spread of the virus.

site_title: China approves use of Roche arthritis drug for coronavirus patients
summary: China has approved the use of Roche's arthritis drug Actemra (Tocilizumab) to treat severe coronavirus patients with lung damage and elevated Interleukin 6 levels. The National Health Commission published the guidelines, which allow for the prescription of Actemra to patients showing serious symptoms. Although there is no clinical trial evidence on its effectiveness, a three-month clinical trial is set to recruit 188 patients. Roche has donated 14 million yuan worth of the drug, and Chinese drugmakers are racing to develop biosimilar alternatives.

images.alt_text: China will use a Roche Holding AG arthritis drug to treat some coronavirus patients in severe conditions, health authorities said on Wednesday, as the country seeks to build up treatment regiments to help the infected recover.

site_title: 5 bus captains file lawsuits against SBS Transit over overtime pay dispute
summary: Five bus captains of SBS Transit have filed lawsuits against the company over unpaid overtime pay, claiming they were not compensated for rest days, public holidays, and night shifts. The captains, including one Singaporean and four Malaysians, worked for 3-8 years and are represented by lawyer M Ravi. SBS Transit has confirmed the lawsuits and stated it will vigorously defend against the allegations. This is the latest round of lawsuits filed by 13 bus captains, who also claim underpayment for overtime work and lack of rest days.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Japfa to 'buy' on strong Q4 results
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded agri-food firm Japfa to "buy" with a target price of S$0.84, citing strong Q4 results and a recovery in operations. Japfa's core net profit rose 193% to US$72.1 million, driven by improved livestock prices. The research house expects continued growth from Japfa's poultry operations in Indonesia and higher pork prices in Vietnam, offsetting concerns of swine volume contraction. Japfa shares were trading at 57 Singapore cents, down 0.5 cent or 0.9% at 10:15am on Wednesday.

site_title: Huawei finds 5G heaven in Switzerland with 'Fitbits' for cows
summary: Huawei is deploying 5G technology in Switzerland, with the country's second-largest telecom operator, Sunrise Communications Group AG, testing the next-generation wireless network in partnership with the Chinese company. Cows in the village of Taenikon are wearing Huawei's 5G-connected neck-straps, allowing farmers to monitor their health conditions remotely. Switzerland is building a network with Huawei, with several entities, including banks and pharmaceutical companies, testing the technology. The country is ahead of other European nations in rolling out 5G technology, with the European Union's security recommendations unlikely to affect Switzerland due to its non-membership in the bloc.

site_title: Malaysia's new prime minister delays parliament session by two months
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has delayed the start of parliamentary proceedings by two months, amid opposition efforts to challenge his government with a confidence vote. The decision comes after Muhyiddin's appointment as Prime Minister on Sunday, following the resignation of 94-year-old Mahathir Mohamad. The delay is seen as a strategic move to allow the new government to establish its authority and prepare for potential opposition challenges. King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah appointed Muhyiddin, stating he believed the new PM had the support of a majority in parliament.

site_title: Australian dollar up on growth surprise, dive in US yields
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.35% to US$0.6606 following unexpectedly strong economic data, while the US dollar fell. The data showed the Australian economy expanded 0.5% in the December quarter, lifting annual growth to 2.2%. However, economists warn that bushfires and the coronavirus will likely lead to a contraction in Q1 and increased risk of recession. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has already cut rates and is expected to ease further, with a 20% chance of a move below 0.25% by year-end.

site_title: Japan lifts evacuation order for part of disaster-hit Fukushima town
summary: Japan has lifted an evacuation order for a part of the town of Futaba, near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, ahead of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. The move allows workers to stay in the area, but residents cannot return due to infrastructure shortages. The town's full evacuation order was lifted 9 years after a 2011 earthquake and tsunami damaged the plant, causing a meltdown. Residents are expected to return in the spring of 2022. The lifting of the evacuation order coincides with the Olympic torch relay, which begins on March 26, showcasing Fukushima's recovery from the disaster.

site_title: Singapore's waterworks to be 100% solar-powered, PUB to lead coastal protection
summary: Singapore's waterworks to be fully powered by solar energy by 2021, with the national water agency PUB leading coastal protection efforts, said Minister for Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli. Two 1.5 MWp floating solar systems will be deployed at Bedok and Lower Seletar Reservoirs, and a 60 MWp system at Tengeh Reservoir, the world's largest floating solar system. The move is part of the government's efforts to ramp up solar power generation.

site_title: Logistics startup Moovaz bags Series A funding from SCAngels, SGInnovate
summary: Singapore-based logistics startup Moovaz has secured an undisclosed Series A investment from government-owned deeptech investor SGInnovate and Supply Chain Angels (SCAngels). The funding will aid operational efficiencies and tap into YCH Group's business know-how, supply chain processes, and network. Moovaz aims to disrupt the relocation industry by solving challenges such as under-utilisation of capacities and information asymmetry. The investment is in line with Singapore's Research, Innovation & Enterprise 2020 plan, which has committed over half of its S$19 billion earmarked for research and innovation.

images.alt_text: YCH Group executive chairman, Robert Yap (centre in white); Moovaz CEO, Lee Junxian (on Mr Yap's right); SCAngels partner and YCH Group chief investment officer, James Ong (on his Mr Yap's left); as well as SGInnovate assistant director, David Toh (next to Mr Ong), pictured together with the Moovaz team.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing after shock Federal Reserve cut sinks Wall Street
summary: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates in a surprise move, but Asian markets fluctuated after the US market declined by nearly 3% due to concerns over the economic impact of the new coronavirus. The cut was seen as a limited response to mitigate the fallout, with investors and experts calling for governments to step in with fiscal measures to support struggling economies. The move sent safe-haven assets like gold and US Treasuries soaring, while oil prices also rose as Opec advisers suggested a potential output cut.

site_title: China reports fall in new virus cases for third day, 38 more deaths
summary: China reported 38 more deaths from the new coronavirus, bringing the nationwide death toll to 2,981. The total number of infected people is over 80,200. For a third consecutive day, the country saw a fall in fresh cases. This marks a slight decline in the virus's spread in the country.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tee Int'l, Eagle Hospitality Trust, UOL, Frasers Property, Travelite, Mencast
summary: Key developments in the Singapore stock market include: Tee International's external investigator summary revealing former CEO Phua Chian Kin's admission of taking company funds, Eagle Hospitality Trust's sponsor and manager taking initiatives to preserve portfolio performance amid market uncertainties, UOL and Frasers Property securing bids for state land tenders, Travelite Holdings seeing no change in shares after a property purchaser exercised an option to buy, and Mencast's associated company securing a contract renewal with an oil supermajor.

site_title: China's central bank keeps short-term rates steady despite Federal Reserve easing
summary: China's central bank kept short-term borrowing costs steady on Wednesday, despite the US Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) skipped open market operations and left reverse repurchase agreements unchanged. Analysts expect the PBOC to make targeted reductions to the reserve requirement ratio or lower benchmark deposit rates to support key sectors, rather than matching the US move to lower rates.

site_title: Singapore healthcare-focused PE firm Quadria Capital closes 2nd fund at US$595m
summary: Quadria Capital, a Singapore-based private equity firm, has closed its second fund at US$595 million, exceeding its initial target of US$400 million. The fund will focus on the healthcare sector in Asia, which is expected to reach US$4.2 trillion in the next five years. Quadria Capital has already made two investments into global healthcare businesses and currently manages over US$1 billion in active capital. The firm's managing partners noted that the region faces significant challenges, including severe underfunding of public health expenditure and demographic changes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.6 points or 0.11% to 1,480.24. Volume was 40.25 million lots worth RM16.93 million, with losers beating gainers 159 to 52.

site_title: Taiwan's central bank to stabilise forex market after Fed cuts rates
summary: Taiwan's central bank plans to stabilize its foreign exchange market following the US Federal Reserve's rate cut in response to the coronavirus. The US dollar weakened against the Taiwan dollar by over 0.7% on Wednesday morning. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the US decision on Taiwan's economy, which is heavily reliant on exports.

site_title: South Korea reports 516 new cases of Covid-19, bringing total to 5,328
summary: South Korea reported 516 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 5,328, with 34 deaths. The country's president declared a "war" on the virus after a record spike in infections. President Moon Jae-in apologized for shortages of face masks and promised support for virus-hit businesses. The country's worst epidemic outside of China, South Korea's COVID-19 cases surpass 5,000.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains, rising 0.14% to 26,321.56, despite concerns about the impact of the new coronavirus on the economy. The Shanghai Composite Index also increased 0.27%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.63%. The moves were influenced by the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut, which sparked mixed reactions among investors.

site_title: Alita Resources probed for potential listing rule breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is investigating Alita Resources, a lithium miner, for potential listing rule breaches following complaints received. The deed administrators stated that they have referred the matters to relevant authorities outside of SGX RegCo's scope. This probe comes after Alita Resources was informed of the investigation by SGX RegCo. The investigation's outcome and any subsequent actions remain unclear at this time.

site_title: China to ramp up petrols exports amid virus, adding to regional glut
summary: China plans to increase petrol exports in March and April, amid the coronavirus outbreak, which could add to a regional glut. The exports are expected to rise to 465,000-530,000 barrels per day, surpassing the previous record. This could exert downward pressure on petrol margins in the region, where supply is also increasing. The virus is expected to reduce demand by up to 730,000 barrels per day in the first quarter, leading to a regional petrol supply surplus of 120,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Hong Kong's Bank of East Asia to review assets, halting legal battle with Elliott
summary: Bank of East Asia (BEA) has agreed to review its business portfolios and assets with Elliott Management's support, halting a four-year-old legal battle. The review will focus on enhancing the value of existing businesses and assets, as well as strategic alternatives for non-core assets. This pause comes ahead of a scheduled seven-week hearing in a Hong Kong court in early May. BEA's statement also indicates Elliott will apply for a pause of the proceedings.

site_title: Gold forges higher with Fed's cut stoking demand for havens
summary: Gold prices surged over 8% this year, reaching a seven-year high, following the US Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut and economic concerns amid the coronavirus health crisis. The Fed's move, along with other central banks' easing, fueled demand for gold as a safe-haven asset. Bullion-backed exchange-traded funds saw record holdings, driving prices up. The rally, which began in 2011, is expected to continue as policymakers seek to mitigate economic fallout.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as Fed cut fails to quell jitters; STI down 0.2% at open
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% at open on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street losses, despite the US Federal Reserve's half-point interest rate cut. The Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 6.50 points to 3,013.06, with Golden Agri-Resources and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding among the biggest losers. The US central bank's rate cut failed to quell investor jitters amid the Covid-19 outbreak, with stocks in the Asia-Pacific region also showing mixed performance.

site_title: SoftBank CEO hosts 'pre-IPO summit' in New York as he courts investors
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son held a "pre-IPO summit" in New York to introduce portfolio companies to Wall Street investors. The event, attended by institutional investors and chaired by Son and Larry Fink, aimed to boost confidence for upcoming initial public offerings. The summit included nine SoftBank-backed companies, following a year of poor performance for some listed companies. Son is under pressure to defend his investment style, with some companies, including WeWork, trading below IPO prices. SoftBank may spend up to two years investing in a bridge fund to build investor confidence.

site_title: Broker's take: Citi slashes target prices for Singapore banks on Fed rate cut
summary: Citi Research has lowered its target prices for Singapore banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC by 4-8% following the US Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut in response to the Covid-19 outbreak. The new target prices are S$24.40 for DBS, S$24.40 for UOB, and S$11 for OCBC. Shares of the banks were down in morning trading, with DBS at S$23.90, UOB at S$24, and OCBC at S$10.53. The rate cut is expected to impact earnings estimates for the banks.

site_title: Win each for Sanders, Biden as first Super Tuesday polls close: US networks
summary: Joe Biden won the Virginia primary, while Bernie Sanders took Vermont, both crucial wins on Super Tuesday. Biden aims to stall Sanders' momentum, but Sanders leads in delegate count with 1,357 delegates at stake. A strong performance for Biden is necessary to prevent Sanders from taking a lead into the party's convention in July.

site_title: S&P cuts US growth forecast again as virus spreads
summary: S&P Global Ratings has cut its US growth forecast again due to the rapidly spreading coronavirus outbreak, now expecting 1% growth in the first and second quarters, down from a previous forecast of 2.2% in the first quarter. The outbreak is expected to be a "material headwind" for the US economy, with a longer and deeper impact than anticipated. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates by half a percentage point to shield the economy from the virus, while Australia's central bank has also cut interest rates to a record low.

site_title: Magnus Energy receives letter of demand for S$5.1m
summary: Magnus Energy Group, a CATALIST-listed oil and gas firm, received a letter of demand for approximately S$5.1 million from solicitors acting on behalf of Thong Soon Seng. The demand is for repayment of loans allegedly borrowed by former CEO Luke Ho in 2016. The company has not commenced legal proceedings and is seeking independent legal advice. Magnus Energy's shares have been suspended since August last year, amid a board tussle and controversy surrounding Ho's tenure.

site_title: Hong Kong cuts base rate following Fed's emergency move
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority cut its benchmark interest rate to 1.50% following the US Federal Reserve's emergency 50 basis point reduction to combat the coronavirus epidemic. The move is an automatic response to the Fed's action, as Hong Kong's economy faces pressure from the virus and months of political unrest. The city's government has unveiled a giveaway-packed budget to support the economy, which is projected to record a deficit for 2020. The rate cut aims to provide relief to the battered economy.

site_title: South Korea unveils 11.7t won stimulus to fight novel coronavirus
summary: South Korea has unveiled a 11.7 trillion won (S$13.6 billion) stimulus package to combat the novel coronavirus outbreak, the country's largest outside China. The package includes 3.2 trillion won to cover revenue deficits and 8.5 trillion won as extra fiscal injection. It will be used to fund medical institutions, small- and medium-sized businesses, and childcare subsidies, with loans available to affected exporters and job retraining programs for those who have lost their jobs.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades Mapletree Logistics Trust to 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) to "buy" and raised its target price to S$2.08 from S$1.65. MLT outperformed the Singapore market, driven by its domestic consumption focus and e-commerce exposure, which accounts for 70-75% of its business. Analysts noted potential near-term weakness in China, but mitigated this by MLT's growing e-commerce revenue. The trust's inclusion in the Straits Times Index and MSCI Singapore Index could increase trading liquidity and lower bid-ask spreads.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as Federal Reserve rate cut fails to rein in virus fears; New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares fell 1.7% as investors fled to bonds due to fears of a global recession amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Reserve Bank of Australia's rate cut was insufficient, and the US Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut also failed to calm market concerns. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined, with tech firms, oil & gas companies, and financials taking the biggest hits. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.3%, with Air New Zealand dropping 3.5% after a passenger tested positive for the virus.

site_title: Northern Europe poised for record warm winter
summary: Northern European countries, including Sweden, Norway, Denmark, and Finland, are experiencing one of the warmest winters on record. Temperatures have been 4-7 degrees Celsius higher than normal, leading to record-breaking blooms of cherry trees in Stockholm and little to no snow in capitals like Oslo and Helsinki. The warm winter has also resulted in severe flooding, destroying farm land and crops, and has been described as "the winter which never arrived."

site_title: Australian economic growth picks up but outlook cloudy on virus fears
summary: Australia's economy expanded by 0.5% in the latest quarter, erasing recession fears despite bushfires and the coronavirus crisis affecting tourism and travel. The annual growth rate is 2.3%, below the 2.75% considered "trend". The revision of the previous quarter's growth to 0.6% from 0.4% suggests a stronger-than-expected performance. The outlook remains cloudy due to ongoing virus fears, but the data provides some relief to policymakers.

images.alt_text: Australia's economy expanded by more than expected last quarter, erasing the risk of a recession even as as raging bushfires and the coronavirus crisis wreaked havoc with tourism and travel at the start of the new year

site_title: No square to spare in Australia as stores cap toilet paper 'panic buying' over coronavirus
summary: Australia's Woolworths Group and Costco Wholesale Corp have capped toilet paper purchases amid "panic buying" due to coronavirus concerns. The limits, set at 4 packs per shopper for Woolworths and 1 pack per shopper for Costco, aim to ensure every customer has access to the essential product. The move comes as supermarkets struggle to keep up with demand, with some stores experiencing empty shelves and shoppers stockpiling toilet paper. This contrasts with other countries where governments are imposing travel restrictions and encouraging stockpiling of long-lasting food.

site_title: Coronavirus sends Hong Kong Feb business activity plunging to record low: PMI
summary: The coronavirus epidemic has dealt a severe blow to Hong Kong's businesses in February, with the adjusted IHS Markit Hong Kong Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) plummeting to 33.1, a record low. The virus has killed nearly 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 in China, a vital source of trade for Hong Kong. The outbreak has also battered the city's retail and tourism sectors, which have been affected by months of political protests. Business confidence has plummeted, with a majority of firms anticipating lower future output due to concerns about the virus' impact.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US rout, higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending falls on Wall Street after the US Federal Reserve's surprise rate cut. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.89% and the Topix index fell 1.30%. The yen strengthened against the dollar due to the rate cut. The US market had also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs.

site_title: US death toll from coronavirus jumps to nine
summary: The US death toll from the novel coronavirus has risen to nine, all in Washington state, primarily in a nursing home in Seattle. The outbreak has led to the suspension of new admissions and a ban on family visits. Nationwide, over 100 confirmed cases have been reported. US President Donald Trump visited the National Institutes of Health for an update on vaccine development, stating that the government is not considering domestic travel restrictions at this time.

images.alt_text: The US death toll from the novel coronavirus rose to nine on Tuesday, all in the state of Washington and many of them residents of the same nursing home, officials said.

site_title: Virus spurs Chinese interest in vegan eggs as protein source
summary: A San Francisco-based startup, Just Inc, is fielding inquiries from Chinese food manufacturers seeking plant-based egg alternatives amid the coronavirus outbreak. The companies are looking to reduce reliance on animal products, which have been linked to the outbreak. This comes as China experiences protein shortages due to African swine fever and the outbreak. Impossible Foods and Beyond Meat are also planning to enter the Chinese market, with Impossible Foods already starting the approval process. The demand for plant-based foods is expected to increase due to the crisis.

site_title: Honeywell unveils plan for 'most powerful' quantum computer
summary: Honeywell has announced plans to launch the world's most powerful quantum computer, which will tackle complex scientific and business challenges. The company achieved a breakthrough in quantum computing and partnered with Cambridge Quantum Computing and Zapata Computing to accelerate its efforts. Quantum computing uses qubits to perform trillions of calculations per second, outperforming traditional supercomputers. The technology is expected to impact industries such as materials, transportation, finance, and pharmaceuticals, with Honeywell collaborating with JPMorgan Chase and Microsoft to develop financial and enterprise applications.

site_title: Oil lower on coronavirus fears despite Fed rate cut and hopes for Opec+ output cut
summary: Oil prices ended slightly lower due to falling equities, but were supported by the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut and hopes for Opec+ output cuts to stabilize prices. The global benchmark Brent crude fell 4 cents to $51.86 a barrel, while US crude rose 43 cents to $47.18 a barrel. Despite Opec's planned rate cuts, concerns over severe global demand destruction from the coronavirus outbreak continue to weigh on prices.

images.alt_text: The global oil benchmark ended Tuesday slightly lower under pressure from falling equities, but the losses were contained slightly as top producers considered more output cuts to support prices and the Federal Reserve cut US interest rates to support the economy.

site_title: In Sanders country, many supporters fear he can't win
summary: In Vermont, where Senator Bernie Sanders has strong support, many of his supporters are hesitant to vote for him due to concerns he can't win the White House against the party establishment. Despite his reputation for forming broad coalitions, some fear his democratic socialist views may be a liability. Sanders has a long history in Vermont, serving as mayor and a member of Congress before becoming a senator. His home state's voters have consistently backed him, but this Super Tuesday could be a test of his national appeal.

site_title: Google cancels developers gathering due to coronavirus
summary: Google has cancelled its annual Google I/O event due to coronavirus concerns, citing health and safety as the top priority. The event, scheduled for May, was expected to draw thousands of developers worldwide. The cancellation joins a growing list of global events cancelled or postponed due to the virus, including a game developers conference in San Francisco and Facebook's F8 conference. Google will explore alternative ways for its developer community to connect and collaborate online.

site_title: US lawmakers seek to force intelligence release on Khashoggi death
summary: US lawmakers are pushing to force the release of an intelligence report on Jamal Khashoggi's 2018 murder, which they claim President Donald Trump is blocking to protect Saudi Arabia. Despite a 2019 congressional order, the intelligence chief has kept the report classified, citing national security concerns. Lawmakers, including Representative Tom Malinowski and Senator Ron Wyden, are seeking to declassify the report, which could reveal who ordered Khashoggi's killing and the circumstances of his death. If successful, it could lead to a full Senate vote to defy Trump's objections.

images.alt_text: US lawmakers vowed on Tuesday to force the release of an intelligence report on the killing of Saudi dissident writer Jamal Khashoggi, accusing President Donald Trump of blocking it to protect the kingdom.

site_title: World Bank unveils US$12b aid package to combat coronavirus
summary: The World Bank has unveiled a $12 billion aid package to help countries combat the coronavirus outbreak. The package aims to provide fast and effective action to address the needs of countries affected by the pandemic, particularly those that are poor and least equipped to respond. World Bank President David Malpass emphasized the need to recognize the extra burden on these countries. The aid package is designed to provide immediate support to countries to help them mitigate the spread of the virus.

site_title: Don't skimp on rent relief, Chan Chun Sing tells landlords
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing urged major landlords in Singapore to pass on 15% property tax rebates to affected tenants, as some landlords have been slow to roll out rental relief packages amid the COVID-19 outbreak. Chan emphasized the importance of the long-term relationship between landlords and tenants, warning against short-sighted decisions that could harm the economy. Several major landlords, including APM Property Management and Lendlease, have announced plans to pass on the rebates to tenants, while others are still waiting for clarity on eligibility.

site_title: Japan services sector activity shrinks on coronavirus hit: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector activity shrank at the fastest pace in nearly six years in February due to the coronavirus, threatening to push the economy into recession. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 46.8, its lowest reading since April 2014. Consumer and business sentiment are taking a sharp hit from a deepening slowdown in China, with new business contracting at the fastest pace in eight-and-a-half years. Economists predict Japan's economy is "exceedingly likely" to slip into recession unless it sees an exceptional rebound in March.

images.alt_text: Japan's services sector shrank at the fastest pace in nearly six years in February as a jolt from the coronavirus threatens to push the economy into recession, dashing hopes of a domestic-led recovery.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Mester sees possible economic impact from coronavirus outbreak
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester warns that the coronavirus outbreak may weigh on the US economy's growth in the first half of the year, citing concerns about reduced spending by households and businesses. The Fed has cut interest rates by half a percentage point in an emergency move to protect the economy. Mester notes that the virus's impact on economic activity is uncertain, and the Fed will closely monitor the situation before making its next policy decision in two weeks.

site_title: Federal Reserve leads charge against economic hit from coronavirus
summary: The US Federal Reserve led a global response to the economic risk posed by the coronavirus, cutting interest rates by half a point to 1.0-1.25% in an emergency move. The decision, announced just 15 days before the next policy meeting, aims to boost confidence and mitigate the impact of the virus on the US and global economies. However, some economists worry the aggressive move may unsettle investors and have little effect, while others question whether it's too little, too late, given the virus's potential to disrupt economic activity and supply chains.

site_title: Protective gear to fight virus 'rapidly depleting': WHO
summary: The World Health Organization warned that protective gear to fight the new coronavirus is rapidly depleting, citing panic buying and market manipulation. The global supply of masks, goggles, and other equipment is being severely disrupted, compromising countries' ability to respond to the pandemic. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus expressed concern that this is causing a significant impact on the response to the outbreak.

site_title: Europe: Stocks, bonds steady after rising on emergency Federal Reserve cut
summary: European stocks and bonds steadied after a brief spike in reaction to the US Federal Reserve's emergency 50 basis point rate cut, aimed at countering the economic fallout from the coronavirus. The rate cut, the first since 2008, pushed the pan-European Stoxx 600 index up 2.1% and lifted the pound 0.5%. German bond yields briefly fell, while Italian bond yields declined 9 basis points. Despite concerns over the Fed's actions, investors remained positive, citing strong US economic fundamentals.

site_title: India postpones naval exercises over coronavirus fears
summary: The Indian navy postponed the Milan 2020 naval exercise due to concerns over the spread of the novel coronavirus, citing safety concerns and travel restrictions. The multinational exercise, which involved over 40 countries, was initially set to take place in 2020.

site_title: How to disinfect your space on an airplane
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Major airlines emphasize plane cleanliness, but some travelers take extra measures to sanitize their airplane space. Experts advise washing hands, choosing a window seat, and disinfecting hard surfaces with wipes. The coronavirus can survive on surfaces for up to nine days, but sanitizing with soap and water or disinfectant wipes can kill the virus. Travelers are encouraged to keep their hands away from their faces, avoid touching surfaces before washing hands, and use paper towels to minimize germ transfer. By following these tips, travelers can reduce their risk of infection on a flight.

site_title: US may pay for uninsured coronavirus patients
summary: The US may invoke an emergency law to pay for uninsured patients infected with the coronavirus, according to a senior Health and Human Services official. This would allow federal reimbursement at 110% of Medicaid rates. The move comes as public health experts warn that the 27.5 million uninsured Americans may be reluctant to seek treatment, fueling the spread of the disease. The Trump administration has been criticized for policies that made it harder for people to enroll in Medicaid or sign up for insurance.

site_title: Canada to help businesses hit by coronavirus: PM
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau signaled his government's readiness to help Canadian businesses affected by the novel coronavirus epidemic. Trudeau stated that the government will assess the potential impact and consider measures to minimize the economic impact. Canadian Finance Minister Bill Morneau and other G-7 leaders agreed to use policy tools to keep economic growth from being throttled by the virus. As of Tuesday, Canada has reported only 29 cases of the virus, with Trudeau stating the risk of spread is relatively low. The Bank of Canada is expected to cut interest rates in response to the US Federal Reserve's emergency rate cut.

site_title: Ukraine prime minister resigns after six months
summary: Ukraine's Prime Minister Oleksiy Goncharuk has resigned after six months in office, following a leaked recording of him questioning President Volodymyr Zelensky's economic grasp. Despite initially refusing Goncharuk's resignation, Zelensky accepted his departure, replacing him with Deputy Prime Minister Denys Chmygal. The move comes after criticism of the government's performance on economic issues. Goncharuk had been nominated by Zelensky last August, but the president's refusal to accept his resignation led to the resignation. A parliamentary vote to approve Chmygal's appointment will be held on Wednesday.

site_title: Facebook to scale back on its Libra plans: The Information
summary: Facebook plans to revamp its Libra digital currency project, offering digital versions of government-backed currencies, including the dollar and euro, as part of its digital wallet launch. The company will still offer the proposed Libra token, despite regulatory scrutiny. Facebook initially faced skepticism from regulators worldwide, but has made changes to its plans. The company's digital wallet is expected to launch with digital versions of government-backed currencies, marking a shift from its original Libra plans.

site_title: Singapore 'must emerge stronger' by working together: Chan
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for the country to "emerge stronger" amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. He urged businesses to diversify supply chains, expand into new markets, and invest in digital economy agreements. The government has introduced grant and tax schemes to support companies, including the Market Readiness Assistance grant scheme for SMEs. Senior Parliamentary Secretary for Trade and Industry Tan Wu Meng also highlighted the importance of cooperation among SMEs, trade associations, and chambers, and the launch of advisory schemes to take SMEs to new markets.

site_title: IMF, World Bank to hold April meetings in 'virutal format'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank have announced that their spring meetings, set for April 16-18 in Washington, will be held in a "virtual format" due to the coronavirus epidemic. The meetings, which typically attract thousands of officials and participants from 180 member countries, were deemed too large and risky to hold in person. The decision was made by IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva and World Bank President David Malpass, who emphasized the importance of maintaining a productive dialogue with stakeholders despite the shift to virtual format.

site_title: Alphabet's Waymo raises US$2.25b for driverless cars
summary: Alphabet's self-driving car unit, Waymo, has raised $2.25 billion from private investors, venture capitalists, and automotive companies, including Silver Lake Management and Magna International. The funding is expected to help Waymo commercialize its autonomous driving technology and may lead to the company's potential spin-off as an independent business. This deal marks the first time Waymo has taken outside funds, and the company plans to expand its driverless fleet to new locations, including the Middle East. Waymo's CEO, John Krafcik, sees this funding as validation of the company's work and a step towards its goal of becoming a standalone business.

site_title: Trump holds phone call with Taleban political chief Baradar
summary: US President Donald Trump held a 35-minute phone call with Taleban leader Mullah Baradar, days after signing a historic deal with the insurgents. The call came amid a dispute over a prisoner swap, which has raised questions about the peace talks between Kabul and the Taleban. The US-Taleban agreement calls for the withdrawal of foreign forces within 14 months, subject to security guarantees and prisoner releases. Baradar urged Trump to take determined actions on the withdrawal, warning of further involvement in the war.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump spoke by phone call with the leader of the Taleban, the insurgent group and the US leader said Tuesday, days after Washington signed a historic deal with the militants.

site_title: China airlines offering 'cabbage prices'
summary: Chinese airlines are offering extremely low fares, colloquially referred to as "cabbage prices," as they restore seat capacity following COVID-19-induced cuts. Chinese carriers are adding nearly 3 million seats, primarily for domestic routes, with some routes costing as little as $18 for a 3.5-hour journey. Despite a significant recovery, China's overall capacity remains around half of its pre-pandemic levels. This move aims to boost revenue, which plummeted by 37 billion yuan in February, resulting in losses of over 10 billion yuan.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Why aquaculture matters
summary: Singapore is developing its first Smart Floating Fish Farm, a significant step in the growth of aquaculture. Co-Founder of Singapore Aquaculture Technologies, Michael Voigtmann, explains the importance of aquaculture for the nation's food security. This development supports Singapore's efforts to increase its aquaculture industry, which is vital for the country's food supply. The Smart Floating Fish Farm is expected to play a key role in this growth, providing a sustainable and efficient way to produce seafood.

site_title: 5G's potential needs to be underpinned by security systems
summary: Singapore plans to roll out commercial 5G services this year, with the goal of strengthening its digital economy. However, the country's focus on speed over security raises concerns about the potential for cyber threats and vulnerabilities in the global telecom carrier ecosystem. The government must prioritize data collection and interpretation, and implement multi-layered defense mechanisms to address different attack vectors. Insecure infrastructure poses a significant risk, and Singapore must ensure its 5G networks are resilient and secure by design to avoid compromising critical infrastructure.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble amid scepticism of Federal Reserve rate cuts
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.9% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 800 points to 25,917.41, as investors expressed skepticism over a surprise Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also slid 2.8% and 3.0% respectively. The 10-year US Treasury hit an all-time low amid concerns over the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 25,917.41, down 2.9 per cent, a loss of nearly 800 points.

site_title: 2,000 surgical masks stolen from French hospital
summary: Around 2,000 surgical masks were stolen from Conception hospital in Marseille, France, amid the coronavirus outbreak. The masks, accessible only to staff and patients who have undergone surgery, were taken from a secure area. The hospital has enough masks to continue operations normally, but ordered more and increased security. The theft occurred as President Emmanuel Macron announced the requisition of all face mask stocks and production for coronavirus patients and health professionals. This is the second reported mask theft in France, following a 6,000 mask heist in Kobe, Japan, in mid-February.

images.alt_text: Around 2,000 surgical masks have been stolen from a hospital in the southern French city of Marseille in the midst of a coronavirus outbreak, health authorities said on Tuesday.

site_title: Olam to sell remaining 50% stake in Indonesian sugar JV for more than US$80m
summary: Olam International has agreed to sell its 50% stake in Indonesian sugar joint venture Far East Agri to Mitr Phol Sugar for between US$82.5 million and US$85 million. This sale is part of Olam's six-year strategic plan to divest and prioritize businesses with sustainable growth potential. The deal is expected to be completed by end-March 2020 and will result in a post-tax capital gain of about US$37.5 million to US$40 million for Olam.

site_title: Capital Group launches New Economy Fund amid virus worries
summary: Capital Group has launched the New Economy Fund in Singapore and Hong Kong amid the COVID-19 pandemic, despite darkening outlook for equities. Investment director Andy Budden is optimistic, expecting a modest rebound later this year, and views the fund as a buying opportunity. The fund, which manages $2 trillion in assets, offers exposure to companies at the cutting edge of the new economy, including technology, healthcare, and communication services.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Thakral Corp adopts a twice-yearly dividend policy, with the quantum of dividend at the board's discretion. Travelite Holdings' unit YG Marketing sold a property for S$3.9 million. Mencast Holdings' Vac-Tech secured a 5-year contract renewal for hazardous waste disposal services. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: HK's property insiders in buying mode
summary: Hong Kong's property market, hit by the COVID-19 outbreak and anti-government protests, has seen real estate insiders buying up assets, with the Woo family planning to take Wheelock & Co private. The move values Wheelock shares at 52% more than their last trading price, despite a 64% discount to its estimated end-2020 book value. This trend may not be unique, with other companies, such as Hopewell Holdings and New World China Land, also taking private. The discount on Hong Kong property shares reflects the dominance of controlling family shareholders, raising concerns about minority interests.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit launches IPO at US$0.80 per unit
summary: United Hampshire US Reit has launched an initial public offering (IPO) at US$0.80 per unit, raising gross proceeds of approximately US$394.6 million. The Reit, which will be Asia's first US grocery-anchored shopping centre and self-storage Reit, invests in grocery- and necessity-based retail, which is expected to be recession-resistant and cycle-agnostic. Key investors include cornerstone investors Kuang Ming Investments and Kasikorn Asset Management, with a total of 82.2% of units committed. The Reit will list on March 12, 2020, offering a 7.4% yield for the March-to-December period of 2020.

site_title: Covid-19 or not, Scorpions will rock you like a hurricane
summary: Scorpions, a German hard rock band, is set to perform a double bill with Whitesnake in Singapore, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Frontman Klaus Meine underwent emergency kidney stone surgery after a show in Melbourne. The tour is being promoted by a local Singaporean promoter, ensuring the event will proceed without a hitch.

site_title: Yen and franc gain as investors still see uncertainty
summary: The Japanese yen and Swiss franc gained against the US dollar on Tuesday as investors tempered hopes for global monetary easing due to uncertainty over the economic impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. The dollar fell 0.5% to 107.67 yen and 0.9573 francs after a draft G7 statement failed to include fresh fiscal or monetary pledges. Investors expect central banks to provide stimulus, but acknowledge the virus will cause economic damage, leading to safe-haven demand for the yen and franc.

site_title: Hon Hai expects normal China operations by end-March
summary: Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, also known as Foxconn, expects its Chinese factories to return to normal operations by the end of March after resolving labor shortages caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Currently, factories are operating at about 50% of seasonal capacity, but are expected to ramp up over the month. Despite this, chairman Young Liu warned that it's difficult to quantify the full impact of the disruption on demand, and sales in the March quarter are expected to decline.

site_title: How Singapore can lead biopharma innovation
summary: Singapore is poised to lead biopharma innovation, driven by its robust intellectual property (IP) protection and supportive ecosystem. The city-state is home to 50 biopharmaceutical research and development centers and 50 manufacturing plants, with international companies such as Pfizer and Merck having regional hubs here. However, Singapore's patent term extension (PTE) regime is not aligned with international standards, making it less attractive to companies. Aligning PTE with global best practices could create new incentives for research and development, boosting Singapore's competitive position as a hub for biopharma innovation and driving economic growth.

site_title: Accrelist chairman assisting with CPIB probe
summary: Singapore-listed Accrelist chairman Terence Tea and two Jubilee Industries Holdings senior management staff have been requested by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) to assist with investigations into alleged expenses and a payment made by a subsidiary during the Chinese New Year period. Tea has recused himself from the nominating committees' assessments and has provided full assistance to the CPIB. The companies' boards have accepted their roles and duties should continue, ensuring business continuity.

site_title: Nam Cheong bags 6 OSV chartering deals worth RM116.4m
summary: Malaysian offshore vessel builder Nam Cheong has secured six chartering deals worth RM116.4 million (S$38.5 million) for its offshore support vessels. The contracts include options to extend, increasing its total order book to RM318.2 million. The vessels will be operated in East Malaysia waters to support foreign oil majors' drilling activities. This deal is expected to positively contribute to Nam Cheong's financial performance for FY2020 and 2021, following a significant increase in revenue from vessel chartering in FY2019.

site_title: China's insurance industry an attractive long-term play as its population gets older and richer
summary: China's insurance industry is poised for long-term growth due to its rapidly ageing population and increasing wealth. The country's elderly face significant challenges in retirement savings and healthcare expenses, creating an opportunity for private insurance to play a bigger role. China's growing middle class also drives demand for better health protection, with a large health protection gap of $169 billion. Two domestic giants, China Life Insurance and Ping An Insurance, are well-positioned to capture the industry's massive growth potential.

site_title: China investors bet on local government-backed bonds
summary: Chinese investors are betting on local government-backed bonds as Beijing is unlikely to allow state companies to fail when needed to shore up the virus-hit economy. Yields on three-year bonds sold by local government financial vehicles (LGFVs) with AA ratings dropped 40 basis points on average, with some bonds in Wuhan seeing yields plunge 50 basis points. LGFVs are receiving direct support from Beijing, and an estimated 1.7 trillion yuan of onshore LGFV bonds will mature in 2020. The renewed enthusiasm for state-backed investments has come at the expense of private companies, highlighting challenges in pushing forward with long-term structural reforms.

site_title: SoftBank CEO tells US investors he'll be more careful and listen
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son reassured US investors that he will be more cautious in his investment decisions, promising to listen to their concerns after facing pressure from hedge fund Elliott Management. Son attributed past blunders, including the WeWork investment, to his tendency to give founders too much autonomy. He pointed to successful investments like Uber and Arm Holdings as examples of his approach's potential, but acknowledged that some investments may fail. Son also expressed confidence in WeWork's new CEO, Sandeep Mathrani, to turn the company around, but cautioned that it could take years.

site_title: US vehicle fleet sets new record for fuel efficiency in 2018: EPA
summary: The US vehicle fleet set a new record for fuel efficiency in 2018, averaging 10.7 kilometres per litre, a 0.09 kpl increase from the previous year. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also anticipates a 10.8 kpl average for the 2019 model year. However, the agency is working to finalize rules to roll back Obama-era requirements through 2026, citing market challenges and the need for credits to comply. The Trump administration proposed freezing fuel efficiency standards at 2020 levels through 2026, which environmentalists and California reject, citing potential fuel cost increases for consumers.

site_title: Tech schemes for mid-career workers: MCI
summary: Singapore has launched the TeSA Mid-Career Advance programme, a train-and-place initiative for mid-career workers aged 40 and above to transition into tech-related jobs. The programme provides funding support for trainees' salaries, training fees, and living allowances, and aims to place 2,000 Singaporeans in firms over the next two to three years. The initiative is part of the government's efforts to help firms and workers benefit from digitalisation, and follows other moves to support digitalisation and cybersecurity development.

site_title: Malaysia cuts key rate as global central banks act to boost stimulus
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, cut its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.5% to provide a more accommodative monetary environment and support economic growth amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This move follows global central banks' efforts to boost stimulus, with the Federal Reserve, Bank of England, and others pledging to act in response to the rising risk to their economies. Analysts predict further rate cuts, with some economists suggesting there is room for another cut, although timing will depend on the growth outlook.

site_title: Banks in fast and furious chase to offer car loans online
summary: UOB and OCBC are racing to offer car loans online, with UOB aiming to finance one in four new car sales in the next 18 months and OCBC launching its digital solution to make instant approvals within 60 seconds. Both banks plan to partner with a large number of car dealers to simplify the process. UOB currently partners with 17 dealerships, while OCBC has secured deals with 11 authorized car distributors, including major brands. The digital loan applications use the national data repository, MyInfo, to streamline the process.

site_title: Europe's richest man eyeing London's Ritz Hotel
summary: Europe's richest man, Bernard Arnault, is among 13 potential bidders for London's Ritz Hotel, which is being sold by the Barclay brothers for up to £800 million. Luxury brands, including LVMH, have increased investments in high-end hotels to cater to the world's wealthiest consumers. The sale is complicated by a dispute between the Barclay brothers, with Frederick Barclay alleging he was secretly recorded at the hotel. The sale price could be impacted by the ongoing coronavirus outbreak and the dispute. Multiple parties are vying for the five-star hotel.

site_title: Is Shanghai on track to IFC goal by 2020?
summary: Shanghai is on track to become an international financial centre (IFC) despite the Covid-19 epidemic, according to the Chinese government's efforts. Key measures include the release of the Plan for Accelerating the Establishment and Implementation of the Shanghai Fintech Hub, which includes 25 innovative working measures. Shanghai has made significant progress in building a global fintech centre, with the Shanghai Municipal Financial Regulatory Bureau stating that the main framework of the Shanghai IFC is basically in place. However, Shanghai still faces competition from Beijing and Shenzhen, and its standing as a financial centre trails that of Hong Kong and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Shanghai's measures to soften the impact of the Covid-19 epidemic include improving financial services, increasing funding support and implementing financial support for epidemic efforts, hard-hit industries and SMEs.

site_title: Top bids for Canberra private housing sites below expectations
summary: Singapore's 99-year leasehold residential state land tenders closed with mixed results. Top bids for two private housing sites in Canberra Drive were below expectations, with the lowest bids at S$568 psf ppr and S$578 psf ppr. In contrast, an executive condominium (EC) site in Fernvale Lane drew a healthier participation rate and top bid within expectations, with Frasers Property securing the top bid at S$555 psf ppr. Market watchers attribute the mixed results to the current oversupply of private homes and expected weaker economic conditions amid the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Feb electronics PMI sinks to seven-year low on Covid-19 fears
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and electronics sectors experienced a contraction in February, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) sinking to a 7-year low of 47.6. The electronics sector's PMI dropped 2.5 points, reversing January's optimism, while the manufacturing PMI lost 1.6 points to record a contraction of 48.7. Economists attribute the decline to Covid-19 fears, citing disrupted global supply chains and increasing infection rates worldwide.

site_title: Virus could wipe out shipping industry's profits
summary: A virus affecting the shipping industry could potentially wipe out profits due to the economic impact of the outbreak. However, China's efforts to control the Covid-19 outbreak and the successful recovery of a crew member from a cargo ship in Singapore suggest a positive trend. The incident highlights the measures being taken by authorities to contain the virus and prevent its spread among crew members and the general public.

site_title: Firms that hire and train mid-career and older workers to get S$2 billion in govt help
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has announced a Senior Worker Support Package (SWSP) worth S$2 billion to support firms in hiring and training mid-career and older workers. The package, which runs from 2020 to 2022, provides up to S$1.3 billion in support. This initiative aims to address the shortage of skilled workers in the workforce.

site_title: Sustainability wave: The tectonic shift transforming investing
summary: Financial markets are on the cusp of a sustainability wave, expected to reshape capital flows and asset prices over the next several decades. Investors need to adapt, as current financial theories and models are outdated. Research has linked companies with better sustainability characteristics to better return prospects, empowering security selection and enhancing portfolio returns. This "sustainability premium" will be a crucial consideration for investors, with the potential to drive significant reallocation of capital.

site_title: Why UK Chancellor should defer key fiscal decisions from budget
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak is considering deferring key fiscal decisions from the March 11 budget due to economic uncertainty over the coronavirus epidemic and Brexit negotiations. The Comprehensive Spending Review (CBR) in autumn may provide a clearer economic outlook, allowing the government to focus on manifesto pledges rather than balancing the budget within three years. Markets expect the government to renege on fiscal rules, and the UK's trade negotiations with the EU are uncertain, with a potential no-deal outcome. Sunak may delay difficult decisions to the autumn for greater clarity on the economic outlook.

site_title: Trump insists US Fed should 'further ease' rates
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted that the Federal Reserve should "further ease" interest rates, despite the recent rate cut. Trump believes the Fed is not doing enough to stimulate the economy, comparing it unfavorably to other countries. He has long clashed with the Fed over monetary policy, seeking to boost economic growth ahead of the November elections.

site_title: EP minimum salary goes up to S$3,900 from May 1 this year
summary: The minimum salary for the Employment Pass (EP) in Singapore will increase to S$3,900 from May 1 this year, with older and more experienced candidates required to earn higher salaries to qualify. The new salary criteria aims to ensure EP holders are of good calibre and do not undercut local wages. The Local Qualifying Salary (LQS) will also be raised by S$100 to S$1,400 monthly from July 2020. The changes will apply to EP renewals from May 1, 2021.

site_title: Public-private funding to steer businesses through choppy waters
summary: The Singapore government has launched the SG Together Enhancing Enterprise Resilience (Steer) scheme to support businesses amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Enterprise Singapore (ESG) will match up to S$1 million in funds raised by trade bodies to support businesses in areas such as working capital, growth efforts, and capability upgrading. The scheme aims to help companies navigate economic uncertainties and prepare for recovery, with the first fund set up by the Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC) receiving S$225,000 from ESG.

site_title: Drop the politics, fight virus with 'permanent preparedness'
summary: The US needs to adopt a "permanent preparedness" approach to responding to public health challenges like the coronavirus, rather than relying on ad hoc responses and emergency funding. This requires professional competence, financial resources, and coordination with public health experts. The Trump administration's response to the outbreak has been marred by confusion, misinformation, and politicization, which has hindered the public's trust in government. Experts recommend a long-term, predictable funding approach, rebuilding public health infrastructure, and ensuring clear communication and coordination between government agencies, state and local health departments, and laboratories.

site_title: India restricts export of some ingredients, drugs
summary: India restricts the export of 26 pharmaceutical ingredients and drugs, including paracetamol, amid concerns over the coronavirus pandemic. The move aims to protect domestic production and supplies. The country, the world's main supplier of generic drugs, gets almost 70% of its active pharmaceutical ingredients from China. This restriction is expected to impact global supplies and prices of these essential medicines.

site_title: IMDA to roll out network of 1,000 parcel locker stations
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) plans to roll out a network of 1,000 parcel locker stations nationwide by 2022, aiming to have a station within 5 minutes' walk of every Housing Board block. The initiative, valued at SGD 10 million, complements existing commercial parcel lockers and doorstep deliveries, with 200,000 parcels delivered daily. The network will improve delivery efficiency and competitiveness, benefiting residents, merchants, and logistics providers. The IMDA will partner with e-commerce marketplaces and logistics service providers to launch the program.

site_title: Singapore bars visitors from Iran, northern Italy, S Korea over Covid-19 fears
summary: Singapore has banned visitors from Iran, northern Italy, and South Korea from entering or transiting through the country due to COVID-19 concerns, starting March 4. The measure is part of enhanced precautions, including swab testing for symptomatic travelers, amid a global surge in cases.

site_title: Fed cuts rate by half point in urgent move
summary: The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by half a percentage point in an emergency move to shield the country's longest-ever economic expansion from the COVID-19 pandemic. The rate cut brings the target range to 1-1.25% and is a response to evolving risks to economic activity. The Fed also stated that it will closely monitor developments and use its tools to support the economy. Markets reacted positively, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 gaining 1.3% and 1.4% respectively.

site_title: Nikola Corp to go public at over US$3.3b valuation
summary: Nikola Corp, an electric vehicle maker, plans to list on the Nasdaq by merging with a publicly traded special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), VectoIQ Acquisition Corp. The combined company will be valued at over $3.3 billion, led by CEO Trevor Milton and controlled by Nikola shareholders. The transaction, expected to close in the second quarter of 2020, will be funded by VectoIQ cash and a $525 million private placement of common stock.

site_title: Morgan Stanley cashes in on the rise of Asia's richest
summary: Morgan Stanley is doubling down on its wealth business in Asia, aiming for double-digit revenue growth and a "high 20s" pre-tax income margin in 2023. The bank plans to recruit 30-35 relationship managers in Singapore and Hong Kong, increasing its regional headcount to 150. Despite challenges from trade tensions and the Covid-19 outbreak, Morgan Stanley remains optimistic about the region's ultra-wealthy market, driven by its "one-firm approach" to serving high-net-worth clients. The bank's strategy aims to capitalize on its existing offerings and build on its record profits from last year.

site_title: Architecture's top prize awarded to two women
summary: Dublin-based architects Yvonne Farrell and Shelley McNamara have been awarded the Pritzker prize, becoming the first female duo to receive the prestigious architecture award. The pair, known for their blocky, brutalist-inspired structures, were recognized for their "integrity," "generosity," and commitment to environmental responsibility. Their unique style, which emphasizes craft and site-specific aesthetics, has gained international fame, with notable projects in Ireland, Britain, France, Italy, and Peru. The duo co-founded Grafton Architects in 1978 and continue to work and live in Dublin.

site_title: European stocks jump, bond yields slide after Fed's emergency rate cut
summary: European stocks surged 3.2% after the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by 0.5 percentage points in an emergency move, citing evolving coronavirus risks to economic activity. German bond yields fell to -0.59%, while Italian yields dropped 9 basis points to 1.06%. Britain's pound rose 0.6% to US$1.2825. The Fed's rate cut was seen as a risk-on trade, with investors reacting positively to the move.

site_title: US stocks surge into positive territory on surprise Fed rate cut
summary: US stocks surged into positive territory on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve announced a large interest rate cut to counter the risk of recession due to the coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 1.4% and 1.2%, respectively. The rate cut reversed early market weakness after a G7 statement failed to provide specific measures to boost growth. The unexpected move lifted investor confidence and boosted stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fail to sustain early gains
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index slipped 6.86 points to 26,284.82, failing to sustain early gains after a strong performance on Wall Street. Shanghai stocks, however, rose 0.74% to 2,992.90, with the Shenzhen Composite Index gaining 1.03% to 1,888.92. This follows a rally in US stocks, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

site_title: STI reverses five sessions of losses
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% higher, ending a five-session losing streak, driven by investor expectations of central bank support measures to mitigate the economic fallout from the Covid-19 outbreak. Asian stocks, including those in Australia, China, and Hong Kong, also gained, while Japan fell. Analysts point to the "risk-on" mood in markets, with Reits performing well, and central banks' willingness to lower rates to support the economy.

site_title: Malaysian turmoil: A view from the market
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's appointment has led to significant share price fluctuations in companies with familial ties to the government. Thriven Global, whose executive chairman and major shareholder is Muhyiddin's son Fakhri, saw its shares more than double on the day after Muhyiddin's swearing-in, closing at 43.2% gain. In contrast, Opcom Holdings, which is 15.3% owned by Muhyiddin's son Mukhriz, plummeted 14.8% on the same day after Muhyiddin's appointment as Prime Minister. These share price movements reflect market speculation about the potential impact of Muhyiddin's government on companies with strong familial ties to the ruling party.

site_title: Handshake? No thanks: coronavirus changes global habits
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant shift in global habits, with people adopting new ways to reduce the risk of contracting and spreading the virus. This includes avoiding physical contact such as handshakes, hugging, and pecks on the cheek, instead opting for direct gazes or hand gestures. As a result, people are changing their habits at work, home, and in worship to minimize the risk of transmission.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips as G7 statement underwhelms
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as the G7 statement failed to outline measures to cushion the economic blow of the coronavirus epidemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Despite policy assurances, investors remain cautious, driven by tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: E-commerce aggregator iPrice raises US$10m in Series B round
summary: E-commerce aggregator iPrice has raised US$10 million in Series B funding led by ACA Investments, a Japanese investment bank. The company, which aggregates products from over 1,500 merchants, operates in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Thailand. With 1.5 billion products available, iPrice aims to increase profitability to 30% Ebitda margin in the next two to three years. The funding will support the company's expansion and beyond price comparison features, such as product discovery and seller information.

site_title: Sanders looks to take charge on Super Tuesday, Biden hopes to catch up
summary: Bernie Sanders is poised to take a significant lead in the Democratic presidential primary on Super Tuesday, with over one-third of the delegates up for grabs. Joe Biden aims to gain ground by targeting moderate voters and taking down upstart Michael Bloomberg. Sanders holds a 60-54 delegate advantage over Biden and leads in polls in California and Texas, while Biden focuses on winning states with high African-American populations. The outcome could provide clarity in a muddled primary race that has seen several candidates rise and fall.

site_title: Tornado rips through Nashville, killing at least nine
summary: A powerful tornado struck Nashville, Tennessee, killing at least nine people, flattening buildings, and leaving tens of thousands without power. The tornado damaged an airport and multiple homes, with some people still trapped. Schools, courts, and district offices were closed, but polling sites were open.
