Over 44,000 customers lost power, with reported damage to substations, distribution lines, and power poles. This is not the first tornado to occur on Super Tuesday in Tennessee, and the city is among the country's fastest-growing cities.

site_title: Norway wealth fund to push firms for more non-financial data
summary: Norway's $1.1 trillion wealth fund will push 9,200 firms to provide more and better data on their social and environmental impact, starting this year. The fund aims to measure "externalities" and assess sustainability risks, using established standards such as the Global Reporting Initiative and Carbon Disclosure Project. Companies are expected to provide data on CO2 emissions, climate policies, and performance against sustainability goals, including Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions. The move follows increasing demand from institutional investors for non-financial data.

site_title: China censored virus news for weeks, say researchers
summary: China censored online discussions on the new coronavirus weeks before officially acknowledging its severity, according to a report by researchers at the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab. Censorship began as early as December 31 and targeted general terms related to the virus, with over 3,100 deaths and 90,000 infections reported worldwide. Social media companies were reportedly pressured to censor information, with over 500 blocked keywords on WeChat from December to mid-February. This censorship may have hindered public health efforts and limited public access to crucial information.

site_title: Indonesia picks island near Singapore to treat virus patients
summary: Indonesia plans to build a hospital on Galang Island in Riau province to treat patients infected with the coronavirus, near Singapore. The facility will be constructed with the army's help and will be more accessible than a quarantine site in Sebaru Island near Jakarta. Indonesia reported its first two cases of coronavirus infections, and authorities are tracking a dance community and cruise ship crew members for potential exposure. The move comes as the deadly epidemic continues to spread outside of China, where the first cases were reported.

site_title: Tee International ex-CEO borrowed funds for personal use; laws may have been breached
summary: Former Tee International CEO Phua Chian Kin admitted to borrowing company funds to repay personal debts and satisfy margin calls, breaching company laws. An external investigator report found that funds were transferred under his instructions, with CFO Yeo Ai Mei executing the majority shareholder's orders. The company's internal controls were also found to be broken, and the Singapore Exchange and Companies Act may have been breached. Phua and his offshore company Oscar have since repaid the funds, and Tee International is reviewing the findings and addressing the issues.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 11.7 points higher at 1,478.64 on Tuesday, with 3.1 billion lots traded worth RM2.5 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 456 to 410.

site_title: In an emergency move, US Fed cuts interest rate to battle coronavirus
summary: The US Federal Reserve cut interest rate by a half percentage point to 1.00-1.25% in an emergency move to shield the economy from the coronavirus. The decision, made unanimously among policymakers, aims to prevent a global recession and boost economic activity. Wall Street stocks surged after the announcement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 1.4%. The move reflects the Fed's urgency to act in response to the evolving risks posed by the coronavirus.

site_title: Skype co-founder's Oriente secures US$20 million in debt funding facility
summary: Oriente, a Hong Kong-based online lending startup, has secured a US$20 million debt funding facility from Silverhorn Group, which can increase to US$50 million. The funding will be used to grow and diversify Oriente's loan book, and extend its reach to consumers and micro-enterprises in the Philippines through its mobile lending app Cashalo. Cashalo has been downloaded over 6.5 million times and has a user base of over 2.5 million consumers, with a 20% month-on-month growth rate.

site_title: Toyota names new finance chief in executive shake-up
summary: Toyota Motor Corp appointed Kenta Kon as its new chief financial officer, effective April, as part of a restructuring effort to streamline operations and improve production systems. The company will scrap its six executive vice president (EVP) roles, with four remaining EVPs retaining their current responsibilities without the EVP title. President Akio Toyoda cited the need to reduce management layers to effectively communicate with the next generation of leaders. Current CFO Koji Kobayashi will continue as chief risk officer.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp named Kenta Kon as its next chief financial officer on Tuesday and said it would scrap executive vice president (EVP) roles as part of a drive to streamline the company's structure, improve production systems and cut costs.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust takes initiatives to counter coronavirus impact
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has implemented initiatives to counter the impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak on its portfolio. The trust has secured a new income-guaranteed parking management contract at 12 hotels starting in April 2020. Additionally, it has enhanced its dynamic pricing strategy, partnered with major brands for revenue management support, and appointed new corporate revenue directors. The trust also plans to consolidate property management at its Denver assets and bolster its events department to expand into new areas. Despite the challenges, the lodging market in the US has experienced a lesser impact than surrounding markets.

site_title: Electronics PMI sinks to lowest since December 2012 on coronavirus fears
summary: Singapore's electronics and manufacturing sectors experienced a contraction in February, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) for electronics sinking to 47.6, the lowest since December 2012. The manufacturing PMI also contracted to 48.7, marking the first decline after two months of expansion. The contraction is attributed to the coronavirus outbreak, which has disrupted global supply chains and impacted the sectors. Economists predict further decline in the coming weeks, with potential knock-on effects on global consumption sentiment and Singapore's export performance.

site_title: Shanghai says visitors entering from virus-hit countries must be quarantined
summary: Shanghai has implemented a 14-day quarantine rule for visitors entering the city from countries with "relatively serious virus conditions." This applies to all people regardless of nationality, according to Xu Wei, an official with the city government. The move comes as the city follows similar rules announced by the neighboring province of Guangdong earlier in the day.

site_title: Two new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, one linked to Wizlearn Technologies
summary: Singapore reports two new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 110. One case is linked to Wizlearn Technologies, with contact tracing underway. No new patients were discharged, maintaining the number of fully recovered individuals at 78.

site_title: Covid-19: SilkAir to 'indefinitely suspend' flights to Hiroshima from March 27
summary: SilkAir, a regional wing of Singapore Airlines, will indefinitely suspend flights to Hiroshima starting March 27, 2020, due to weak demand caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The last flight, MI867, will operate on March 26. Affected customers will be contacted and re-accommodated on other flights. This decision follows Singapore Airlines' announcement to suspend various flights globally from February to May, amid the outbreak.

site_title: STI registers first gain in five sessions, up 0.4% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) registered its first positive closing in five sessions, rising 0.4% to 3,019.56 on Tuesday. The gains were attributed to expectations of central bank support measures to curb the economic impact of the Covid-19 outbreak. Asian stocks also followed suit, with benchmarks in Australia, China, and Malaysia finishing with gains, while Japan closed lower. Investors are betting on a coordinated response by G-7 central bankers, with real estate investment trusts (Reits) among the best-performing counters.

site_title: Banks in Europe step up coronavirus contingency trading plans
summary: Banks in Europe are implementing contingency trading plans to prepare for potential disruptions due to the coronavirus outbreak. Financial firms are readying out-of-town offices, splitting shifts, and isolating teams to ensure continuity of trading. This follows similar preparations made in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and New York. With the virus spreading to 53 countries and over 100 deaths, European banks are taking heightened precautions to mitigate risks and maintain operations.

site_title: Jokowi warns against hoarding as virus triggers panic buying
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo warned against hoarding food and essential goods amid the COVID-19 outbreak, urging people not to buy in bulk or fearfully stockpile. The country's first confirmed cases sparked panic buying at supermarkets, with reports of empty shelves. The government guarantees sufficient goods, but authorities face criticism over the nation's health system's ability to detect the virus.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's commuter train officials distribute free-protective masks to the passengers following confirmed cases of the novel coronavirus disease.

site_title: Singapore to bar new visitors from Iran, northern Italy, South Korea due to Covid-19 worries
summary: Singapore has introduced additional measures to curb the spread of COVID-19, banning new visitors from Iran, northern Italy, and South Korea who have traveled to these areas within the last 14 days. Returning Singapore citizens and residents with travel history to these regions will be issued a stay-home notice for 14 days. All work pass holders with recent travel history to these areas will require Manpower Ministry approval before entering Singapore. These measures are part of Singapore's efforts to contain the global outbreak.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets up 1.5% at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose 1.5% at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up to 6,751.54 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index at 12,017.53 points, and Paris CAC 40 at 5,413.76 points. The rally comes as investors await a coordinated economic response from G7 finance ministers to the coronavirus.

site_title: Frasers Property unit tops bids for Sengkang EC site; UOL-led consortium is highest bidder for a condo plot in Canberra Drive
summary: Frasers Property unit topped bids for a 99-year leasehold site in Canberra Drive, Singapore, with a nearly S$129.20 million offer. UOL-led consortium secured the highest bid for a condo plot in Canberra Drive, at S$270.2 million or S$650 psf ppr. The Fernvale Lane EC site also drew seven bids, with Frasers Property unit FCL Lodge emerging as the highest bidder at S$286.54 million or S$555 psf ppr.

site_title: Japan's Kirin says won't part with non-beer assets, braces for proxy fight
summary: Japan's Kirin Holdings has refused to sell non-beer assets, despite activist investor Independent Franchise Partners' demands. The UK-based firm owns 2% of Kirin and wants the company to focus on beer, shed cosmetics and drug investments, and use proceeds to buy back shares. Kirin CEO Yoshinori Isozaki said proposed board members by IFP didn't know enough about the company, and instead, the company's own proposed members are more suitable for the task. A proxy battle is expected at Kirin's annual general meeting on March 27.

site_title: UBS's Ermotti to become Swiss Re chairman
summary: Swiss Re has nominated UBS Group Chief Executive Sergio Ermotti to become its chairman, replacing Walter Kielholz starting in 2021. Ermotti is set to step down from UBS in November. This move follows a Reuters story confirming the appointment.

site_title: China oil refining profits plunge 42% in 2019 as overcapacity grows
summary: China's crude oil refining profits plummeted 42% in 2019 due to overcapacity and weak domestic demand. The industry's average utilization rate was 76%, below the global level, indicating a capacity glut. Profit margins in the petrochemical sector also fell 13.9% in 2019, with the total profit for China's petroleum and chemical industry down 14.9% from 2018. The industry body warns that overcapacity will remain a dominant issue in the long term.

site_title: Thermo Fisher to buy Qiagen for 9b euros in lab tie-up
summary: Thermo Fisher Scientific agreed to buy Qiagen, a Dutch laboratory equipment maker, for approximately 9 billion euros. The deal is worth 39 euros per Qiagen share, a 23% increase from Monday's closing price. This acquisition will be one of the largest for Thermo Fisher, following its 2014 purchase of Life Technologies for $13.6 billion. The deal revives discussions that broke off late last year and comes as the healthcare industry has seen increased activity in mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks trim gains as coordinated G7 response hopes dashed
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.58% to 2,014.15, but trimmed gains after a Reuters report indicated a lack of immediate stimulus measures from the G7. The benchmark KOSPI has fallen 8.35% this year. Foreigners sold $257.16 million worth of shares, while the country reported 600 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total infections to 4,812 and fatalities to 34. Investors remain cautious amid concerns that global central bank actions may not meet expectations.

site_title: G7's draft coronavirus statement makes no direct calls for fiscal, monetary support: source
summary: The G7 is drafting a statement to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus, but it excludes direct calls for fiscal or monetary support, disappointing financial markets. The statement, expected to be released on Tuesday or Wednesday, will pledge cooperation among the seven major industrial powers. Despite this, the US Federal Reserve has already indicated its willingness to support the global economy, and other central banks have followed suit with rate cuts. Analysts question the effectiveness of rate cuts in addressing the epidemic's economic impact.

site_title: Metech chairman quits amid 'new business direction'
summary: Metech International chairman and CEO Simon Eng has resigned amid the company's "new business direction and investment parameters". Eng will step down on March 3, while Liu Changsheng, a non-executive director, will take over as non-executive chairman. The company is searching for a new CEO and hopes to appoint one "as soon as possible". Eng's resignation follows the disposal of the company's electronic waste management business and a regulatory notice requiring the company to re-elect Eng as director due to undisclosed past warnings from regulatory authorities.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit launches IPO at US$0.80 per unit
summary: United Hampshire US Reit, a real estate investment trust, launched its initial public offering (IPO) at $0.80 per unit, citing the "retail apocalypse" will not significantly impact its investments in grocery- and necessity-based retail. CEO Robert Schmitt noted brick-and-mortar stores still play a crucial role in these sectors, which are recession-resistant and cycle-agnostic. Online penetration for grocery sales remains low, at around 2%, compared to higher percentages for other categories. The IPO aims to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: Pope tests negative for novel coronavirus: Italian newspaper
summary: Pope Francis has tested negative for the novel coronavirus, according to an Italian newspaper. The 83-year-old Roman Catholic leader had cancelled a Lent retreat and most audiences due to health concerns, having part of one lung removed decades ago. This news comes as the Vatican has taken precautions to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: Say nothing at all: Ronan Keating chided for Singapore coronavirus post
summary: Irish singer Ronan Keating faced criticism for a social media post claiming ships near Singapore were not allowed to dock due to the coronavirus. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore responded, stating that ships arrive or leave every two to three minutes and there can be up to 1,000 ships at any time. Keating removed the post after users pointed out its inaccuracy, with one user referencing his song "You Say It Best When You Say Nothing at All."

site_title: Malaysia cuts key rate as global central banks act amid virus
summary: Malaysia's central bank reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.5% in a bid to boost economic growth amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move follows similar rate cuts by other central banks, including Australia and Indonesia. The bank expects a gradual improvement in domestic growth in the second half of the year, but warns of key downside risks from the pandemic's impact on tourism and manufacturing. This is Malaysia's lowest interest rate since July 2010, and comes as the government prepares to implement a fiscal stimulus package worth RM20 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down on scepticism about G-7 virus action
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Tuesday as investors expressed skepticism about the G7's virus action, leading to a 1.22% drop in the Nikkei 225 index. The broader Topix index also fell 1.36%. This move comes amid concerns about the effectiveness of the G7's measures to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks lost early gains and closed lower on Tuesday as investors grew sceptical about the outcome of a G7 financial chiefs meeting on measures against the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Technicals suggest Bitcoin's rally may have more room to run
summary: Bitcoin's price rally may have more room to run, according to technical indicators. After its worst week since November, Bitcoin reclaimed its lower band and may test the upper limit, potentially reaching around $10,600. The Stochastic line is nearing the oversold level of 30, bolstering the chances of a short-term rally. Bitcoin fell 14% last week amid equity-market selling, but investors believe it will recover as the coronavirus impacts global growth. Some see Bitcoin as a safe haven asset during global instability.

site_title: Swiss economic growth slows in Q4 as exporters struggle
summary: Switzerland's economic growth slowed to 0.3% in Q4 2019, the lowest since 2012, due to a decline in exports and industry struggles. The country's economy grew 0.9% in 2019, below its long-term average growth rate of 1.7%. The slowdown was attributed to difficulties in neighboring Germany, which is Switzerland's largest export market. Despite this, the chemical and pharmaceutical industry helped bolster overall economic growth. The impact of the coronavirus on the Swiss economy is expected to lower its forecast for 2020.

site_title: BMW bets on new EV to reclaim crown in entry-level luxury sedans
summary: BMW is introducing its new electric vehicle, the i4, to reclaim its position in the entry-level luxury sedan market, which has been dominated by Tesla's Model 3. The i4 features a sleek design, low-slung aerodynamics, and a range of up to 600 kilometers. BMW aims to sell 140,000 electrified cars in Europe this year, with the i4 and iNEXT SUV set to debut in 2021. The company's CEO, Oliver Zipse, has downplayed comparisons to Tesla, saying the i4 is "the first real dynamic car from BMW" and a key part of the brand's electromobility strategy.

site_title: Lindt promises sweet dividend and further growth
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli has proposed a 75% increase in its dividend to 1,750 francs per registered share for 2019, marking its 175th anniversary. The company reported a 5.1% increase in net profit to 511.9 million Swiss francs last year, with a 6.1% increase in full-year organic sales growth in January. Lindt aims to maintain its mid- to long-term organic sales growth target of 5-7% per year and steadily improve its operating margin.

images.alt_text: Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli on Tuesday proposed a sweeter payout to shareholders, increasing its dividend by 75 per cent to mark its 175th anniversary. Chocolate makers are facing sluggish growth, particularly in saturated US and European markets, as consumers often opt for healthier snacks these days, but Lindt has fared better than peers thanks to its upmarket positioning.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Chan Chun Sing, a Hong Kong politician, urged landlords to lower rents for tenants affected by the COVID-19 downturn. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US's surprise tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia's agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. In other news, a Thai court is expected to clear Thaksin Shinawatra's daughter of suspension as PM in an ethics case.

site_title: NYC sues Airbnb software partner in escalation of feud
summary: New York City sued Guesty Inc., a startup providing services for Airbnb listings, in a lawsuit filed in state court in Manhattan. The city alleges Guesty's business model helps people flout laws against short-term rentals, impacting New York's housing market and neighborhoods. Guesty had attracted $60 million in funding and claims "full integration" with Airbnb, sparking the city's concerns. The lawsuit seeks records and testimony to determine Guesty's impact on the city's housing market.

site_title: China's Baosteel to issue up to 3b yuan of bonds amid virus outbreak
summary: China's Baosteel, the country's top listed steel producer, plans to issue up to 3 billion yuan in bonds to boost working capital amid the coronavirus outbreak. The three-year bonds will also be used to repay debt. The move comes as Beijing provides financial support to affected businesses, allowing for debt financing and issuance. The coronavirus has led to a record-high steel products stockpile and reduced orders for Baosteel, resulting in a 5% drop in orders in March and a potential 2-3 billion yuan loss in first-quarter profit.

site_title: SoftBank CEO tells US investors he'll be more careful
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son reassured US investors that he will be more cautious in his investment decisions, following pressure from hedge fund Elliott Management. Son acknowledged that he had not given enough weight to investors' opinions and the company's independent board members. He pointed to SoftBank's stock trading at a discount to asset value as an opportunity for investors to buy in. Son also defended his investment approach, citing the potential for successful startups like WeWork's new CEO Sandeep Mathrani to turn the investment around, but warned that some investments may fail.

site_title: Dutch economic growth to slow on hit from coronavirus
summary: The Netherlands' economic growth is expected to slow to 1.4% in 2020 and 1.6% in 2021 due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a government policy adviser. This marks the lowest level of growth in seven years, with the forecast slightly more optimistic than a previous estimate of 1.3% expansion in 2020. The CPB warned of major uncertainties surrounding the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap 7-day losing streak on rate cut; New Zealand surges
summary: Australian shares ended a 7-day losing streak, closing 0.7% higher at 6,435.7 points, following a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia to 0.5%, its lowest level. The central bank cut rates to cushion the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. Despite gains, the country's top four lenders slipped. New Zealand shares surged, however, after the article's date is from March 3, 2020.

site_title: Slow but steady: China fights to get economy back to work
summary: China is making slow but steady progress in recovering from the coronavirus outbreak, with the economy likely running at 60-70% capacity last week, according to a Bloomberg Economics report. Industrial demand is increasing, with some companies ramping up output, particularly those making medical equipment. However, many factories remain idle due to logistics issues, staff shortages, and limited supplies. The government is using electricity data to show a resurgence in output, but some firms are running machinery even when empty, and air pollution levels are slowly recovering.

images.alt_text: China is making slow but steady progress in its effort to get back to work, as it battles the coronavirus outbreak that has killed almost 3,000 people and sickened tens of thousands.

site_title: Majority of promising AI startups are still based in US
summary: A study by CB Insights found that 65% of the top 100 AI startups are based in the US, despite a decline in US-based investments to 39% from 71% between 2014 and 2020. US-based companies are working in healthcare, retail, and transportation, with notable startups including Butterfly Network, Faire Wholesale Inc, and DataRobot. The research highlights the importance of addressing industry-specific needs and pushing the boundaries of core research in AI development.

site_title: 'Unprecedented' mental health issues seen in Hong Kong amid virus fears
summary: Hong Kong is experiencing unprecedented mental health issues amid the coronavirus outbreak, with anxiety levels soaring due to fears of the epidemic and the 2003 SARS outbreak. The city's existing issues with depression and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) from the anti-government protests have worsened, with medical experts attributing the surge to the added stress of the current crisis.

site_title: North Korea weapons test was 'long-range artillery': KCNA
summary: North Korea conducted a "long-range artillery" drill, firing multiple launch rocket systems and a larger calibre rocket from a forest area, according to state media. The test came as the country battles a coronavirus outbreak and as tensions remain high over nuclear negotiations with the US. The launch was described by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un as a demonstration of the country's "iron will and ardent patriotism" to defend its homeland. The test appears to be in line with the North's efforts to "normalise" its military activities and frame them as part of routine rocket artillery drills.

site_title: Australia cuts interest rates to record low on coronavirus fears
summary: Australia's central bank slashed interest rates to a record low of 0.50% amid coronavirus fears, citing global growth expected to be lower in the first half of 2020 and the significant domestic impact of the outbreak. The Reserve Bank of Australia warned of uncertain economic effects, particularly on education and travel sectors heavily reliant on China. The bank is prepared to ease monetary policy further if necessary, following similar actions by other major institutions worldwide.

site_title: Olam to sell 50% stake in Indonesian sugar JV for more than US$80m
summary: Olam International agreed to sell its 50% stake in Indonesian sugar joint venture Far East Agri for between US$82.5 million and US$85 million. The sale is part of Olam's six-year strategic plan, focusing on sustainable growth potential and divesting underperforming assets. The deal is expected to complete by end-March 2020 and will result in a post-tax capital gain of US$37.5 million to US$40 million.

site_title: Australia to use biosecurity law to restrict movements of coronavirus patients
summary: Australia will restrict the movements of people suspected of having the coronavirus using a little-known biosecurity law, according to Attorney-General Christian Porter. The law allows for the prevention of movement from persons in and out of specific places, including venues with high-risk transmission. The government has already stopped foreign travelers from entering directly from China, where the virus originated, and has confirmed 38 cases of coronavirus, including one death. Prime Minister Scott Morrison urges Australians to remain calm and carry on with normal processes.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading, up 0.9% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading with a 0.9% gain, reaching 3,033.60 points. The market's improvement is attributed to central banks' pledge to support the economy amidst the Covid-19 outbreak. The blue-chip index saw 253 advancers and 115 decliners, with Ascendas Reit and CapitaLand Commercial Trust among the top performers. Local banks, including DBS and OCBC Bank, also saw gains.

site_title: New government network of 1,000 parcel locker stations for Singapore's logistics firms
summary: The Singapore government plans to launch a nationwide network of 1,000 parcel locker stations by 2022, aiming to have a station within five minutes' walk of every Housing Board block. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will own and operate the network, which will complement existing commercial parcel lockers and doorstep deliveries. The move aims to enhance Singapore's last-mile delivery infrastructure, benefiting residents, merchants, and logistics service providers with greater access and delivery efficiency. The initiative has received support from e-commerce marketplaces and logistics service providers.

site_title: China's Geely invests US$326m to build satellites for autonomous cars
summary: China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group invests $326m to build satellites for autonomous cars in Taizhou, with plans to produce 500 satellites a year by 2025. Geely's technology arm, Geespace, aims to launch a commercial low-orbit satellite network by the end of this year, offering high-speed internet, navigation, and cloud computing capabilities to self-driving cars. This investment is part of Geely's efforts to meet demand for high-speed connectivity capabilities, enabling faster software updates in its cars.

site_title: Erupting Indonesian volcano spews massive ash cloud
summary: Mount Merapi, Indonesia's most active volcano, erupted on March 3, 2020, spewing a massive 6,000m ash cloud that forced an airport closure and coated nearby communities with grey dust. Authorities temporarily closed the international airport in Solo city and warned residents to stay out of a 3km no-go zone due to possible danger from flowing lava and pyroclastic flows. The eruption was the most powerful since 1930, killing hundreds in previous major eruptions.

site_title: Tencent extends warranty for Nintendo Switches in China as virus hits sales
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent is extending the warranty for Nintendo Switch consoles sold in China via official channels before March 31 by six months due to the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on sales and logistics. The company, a local partner of Nintendo, aims to mitigate the effects of the virus on its console game sales in the country.

site_title: SMEs to get digital access to overseas opportunities, more Industry Digital Plans
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will gain digital access to overseas opportunities through the Grow Digital scheme, which includes e-commerce platforms for business-to-business and consumer transactions. The initiative will provide smart-matching with potential clients, financing, and logistics integration. Additionally, the Industry Digital Plans (IDPs) will be expanded to support SMEs in 23 industries, offering guidance on digital solutions and training. This aims to help SMEs transform their businesses and upskill their workers.

site_title: Opec to try to stem oil price plunge amid coronavirus slowdown
summary: OPEC is set to meet in Vienna to discuss cutting oil production amid a sharp drop in global demand due to the coronavirus outbreak. The group, led by Saudi Arabia, aims to stem the plunge in oil prices, which have fallen around 30% since early January. Analysts predict a cut of 600,000-1 million barrels per day, but the success of the meeting depends on the alliance between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which has been sending mixed signals. The International Energy Agency has revised down its forecast for oil demand in 2020 due to the epidemic, further complicating OPEC's decision.

site_title: Ping An's OneConnect partners V3-led digital bank consortium
summary: Ping An's OneConnect has partnered with V3-led digital bank consortium Beyond as its strategic technology partner. OneConnect will develop digital banking products and services for Singapore's small and medium enterprises. The partnership, announced on March 3, 2020, follows OneConnect's decision not to apply for a digital banking licence in Singapore, opting instead to serve digital bank aspirants with its "digital bank-in-a-box" suite of solutions. OneConnect has extensive implementation experience in South-east Asia and China.

site_title: WHO says world in uncharted territory as US coronavirus toll rises
summary: The world is in uncharted territory as the COVID-19 pandemic continues to spread globally, with over 90,000 infected and 3,100 deaths reported. New cases have dropped dramatically in China, but surged abroad, with the US death toll rising to six. The US is now facing a potential epidemic, and the World Health Organization (WHO) warns of community transmission, but containment is possible with the right measures. The WHO chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, says the world has never seen a respiratory pathogen capable of community transmission but can be contained with the right measures.

images.alt_text: Globally, the virus has killed more than 3,100 people and infected over 90,000 even as a clear shift in the crisis emerges, with nine times as many cases recorded outside China as inside, according to the World Health Organization.

site_title: Japan's Abe says ready to top up fiscal spending if coronavirus hits economy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has announced his government is prepared to deploy further fiscal stimulus measures to protect Japan's fragile economy from the coronavirus. With over 1,000 infections and 12 deaths, Abe is focusing on halting the spread of the virus. The outbreak coincides with Japan's preparation to host the summer Olympic Games in July and August, raising concerns about potential negative economic growth. Abe's pledge comes amid criticism of his handling of the crisis.

site_title: Australia's national newswire to close
summary: Australia's national newswire, the Australian Associated Press (AAP), will close in June after 85 years, citing the "unprecedented impact" of digital platforms distributing content for free. The closure affects up to 180 staff, with around 30-50 jobs being made available at shareholders Nine and News Corp Australia. The decision was made despite AAP being a critical part of Australian journalism since 1935. The company's subediting business, Pagemasters, will also close in August.

images.alt_text: Australia's only national newswire will close after 85 years in operation, with staff told on Tuesday their jobs will come to an end in June.

site_title: OCBC enables instant car loan approvals
summary: OCBC Bank has introduced a digital car loan approval process that allows customers to apply and receive approval within 60 seconds. The process leverages the national data repository, MyInfo, and the bank's real-time KYC and credit assessment system, eliminating the need for hard-copy forms and sensitive personal information sharing. 11 authorized car distributors in Singapore will use the new process by the end of the month, with the goal of onboarding one in every two OCBC Bank customers digitally by the end of the year.

site_title: Putin proposes to enshrine God, heterosexual marriage in constitution
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has submitted proposed constitutional changes to parliament, which include enshrining God and traditional heterosexual marriage in the constitution. The amendments also ban giving away Russian territory and protect historic truth, sparking debate about Putin's intentions. The changes, which include transferring authority to parliament and strengthening the role of an advisory body, are set to be voted on in April. Analysts see the reforms as a step towards Putin's potential succession, while opponents argue he aims to remain leader for life.

site_title: Bye-bye handshakes: how coronavirus is changing global habits
summary: Global habits are changing to reduce coronavirus transmission, with people opting for direct gazes, hand gestures, or no physical contact. This shift affects daily life, from work and home to worship and social interactions. As the virus has claimed 3,060 lives worldwide, individuals are adapting their routines to minimize risk.

site_title: Star US dancer Hallberg to take over top Australian Ballet post
summary: US dancer David Hallberg has been appointed the new artistic director of the Australian Ballet, replacing David McAllister who is set to retire in December. Hallberg, 37, is the first American to hold the position and has been a guest artist at the Australian Ballet for a decade. He brings a "unique artistic lens and global view" to the role, according to Australian Ballet chair Craig Dunn, marking an exciting new era for the company. Hallberg's appointment is seen as a significant cultural development for Australia.

site_title: RF Fund Management eyes US$50m fund for fintech, proptech investments in Asia
summary: RF Fund Management, a Singapore-based subsidiary of RF International, is launching a US$50 million private equity fund focused on fintech and proptech investments in Asia. The fund, set up under the new variable capital companies (VCC) framework, will leverage RF International's expertise in North Asia and South-east Asia. Five fintech companies in Singapore, two real estate tech firms in Japan and Indonesia, and an automotive tech firm in China are among the identified investees. RF Fund Management plans to adopt blockchain technologies and has ties to ICHX Tech, a MAS-regulated capital markets platform.

site_title: Global property deals stall as virus keeps China money home
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is causing a crisis in global property deals, particularly in the US, where Chinese buyers are a significant source of revenue. With travel restrictions and quarantines in place, deals are languishing and potential purchases are being delayed. Chinese buyers spent $13.4 billion on US homes in 2019, but sales involving Chinese clients have dropped by 20% in Singapore. Realtors are facing logistical challenges, and luxury properties are being sought after in countries like Australia, where the virus has boosted demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 14.41 points to 1,481.35, up 0.98%. Volume was 204.97 million lots worth RM104.65 million. Gainers beat losers 313 to 34.

site_title: SMEs, trade groups to get more help to team up for industry growth
summary: Singapore aims to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with new measures, including more assistance from trade associations and chambers (TACs). The government will provide strategic roadmaps with TACs to help SMEs adopt longer-term plans for industry transformation. The Singapore Business Federation will launch a market advisory scheme to take SMEs into emerging markets, while the Enterprise Leadership for Transformation (ELT) programme will help 900 SME business leaders develop business growth plans. The government also plans to expand the GoBusiness Licensing portal to support small and micro companies.

site_title: App that detects jaundice in newborns could save lives in Asia and Africa
summary: A new smartphone app can detect jaundice in newborn babies, potentially saving lives in Asia and Africa. The app uses a simple eye check to identify jaundice, a liver problem that causes 114,000 newborn deaths and 178,000 cases of disability annually. The app, led by researchers at the University College London, could be a low-cost solution for healthcare professionals in poorer regions, particularly in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa where most deaths occur. The app's results were published in the journal PLOS ONE.

site_title: Covid-19: Singapore will match business support funds raised by private-sector groups
summary: Singapore's government will match up to S$1 million in funds raised by private groups to support businesses amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Under the SG Together Enhancing Enterprise Resilience (Steer) programme, Enterprise Singapore will provide 20% of the funds raised. This initiative aims to enhance enterprise resilience and support businesses in the year ahead.

site_title: LMIRT's Jakarta mall contributed to plunge in fair value, S$34.8m impairment: manager
summary: LMIRT's Jakarta mall, Lippo Mall Kemang, contributed to a S$65.3 million decrease in fair value in 2019 due to the expiry of master leases and a challenging car park business environment. The mall's manager is actively managing tenancy mix to mitigate the impact. The trust also recorded a fair value loss of 674.3 million rupiah, with S$34.8 million of this attributed to impairment on Lippo Mall Kemang.

site_title: China reports 125 new virus cases, lowest number in six weeks
summary: China reported 125 new Covid-19 cases, the lowest number in six weeks, on March 3, 2020. The National Health Commission also announced 31 more deaths, all in Hubei province, raising the nationwide toll to 2,943.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB initiates coverage on IREIT Global with 'buy', S$0.92 target price
summary: RHB Research has initiated coverage on IREIT Global with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.92, citing the trust's attractive yield and exposure to the resilient German economy. The portfolio has a weighted average lease to expiry of 4.2 years and leases with built-in rent-escalation mechanisms. Analysts expect IREIT to acquire the remaining 60% stake in a joint venture by the end of the year, driven by low borrowing costs. However, the Reit's gearing of 39.3% is considered high.

site_title: Keppel unit completes 50% acquisition of US senior housing firm
summary: Keppel Corp's subsidiary, Keppel Capital Senior Living, has completed the acquisition of a 50% stake in US senior housing operator Watermark Retirement Communities (WRC). The initial purchase price was adjusted due to the sellers' responsibility for future capital call obligations. This acquisition is a strategic move by Keppel to expand into the senior-living sector, offering customized solutions to Singapore and Asian markets. The deal is expected to provide Keppel with more options to grow its assets under management and recurring management fees.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound 2% on RBA rate-cut hopes; New Zealand jumps
summary: Australian shares rose 2% on Tuesday, rebounding from seven consecutive declines, as investors anticipated a possible rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia to cushion the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 1.9%, with tech, healthcare, and mining sectors leading gains. New Zealand's benchmark index also jumped 3.7% as investors pinned hopes on a coordinated global monetary policy response. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut its cash rate to 0.5% from 0.75%.

site_title: South Korea reports 600 new novel coronavirus cases, 3 more deaths
summary: South Korea reported 600 new novel coronavirus cases and 3 more deaths, bringing total infections to 4,812. Anger and fear over the virus' spread have gripped the country, with a religious sect at the center coming under scrutiny. The surge in cases has raised concerns about the country's ability to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Covid-19: Chan Chun Sing calls on landlords to 'do their part' as tenants clamour for lower rents
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing urged major landlords to "do their part together" amid the Covid-19 outbreak's impact on businesses, particularly in the retail and food services sectors. The call comes after landlords and tenants clashed over promised rental rebates, with some landlords taking a long time to roll out their packages. Chan emphasized the importance of landlords sharing benefits with tenants, saying it's a long-term relationship that benefits both parties. The government has already announced targeted support measures, including a 15% property tax rebate for certain commercial properties.

site_title: Asia tracks Wall Street surge on hopes for policy response to coronavirus
summary: Asian markets surged for a second day, driven by hopes for a global policy response to the coronavirus. The Dow and S&P 500 on Wall Street rose over 5% and 4.5%, respectively, after central banks pledged support with monetary easing. The positive sentiment also boosted oil markets, with dealers betting on major producers cutting output. Despite the rally, the virus continues to spread, with 3,100 deaths and 91,000 infections reported, and the World Health Organization warning of "uncharted territory."

site_title: Hong Kong's property insiders are in buy mode
summary: Hong Kong's property market, severely impacted by the COVID-19 outbreak and anti-government protests, is seeing a surge in buying activity among insiders. Wheelock & Co, a holding company, is set to become private after its controlling family offers a buyout deal, valuing shares at a 52% premium to the last trading price. Despite a 6.5% drop in residential prices, the discount on Hong Kong property shares reflects the dominance of controlling family shareholders, fueling concerns about minority interests.

site_title: New scheme to get Singapore mid-career professionals into tech-related jobs
summary: Singapore has launched a new programme, TeSA Mid-Career Advance, to train and place mid-career professionals aged 40 and above in tech-related jobs. The pilot initiative, part of the TechSkills Accelerator (TeSA) programme, works with participating firms to hire and train such citizens. The goal is to address the shortage of skilled professionals in the tech industry. The programme aims to provide opportunities for mid-career individuals to transition into tech-related roles, regardless of their background in infocommunications and technology.

site_title: Australian government says working closely with central bank on coronavirus response
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the government is working closely with the Reserve Bank of Australia to respond to the coronavirus outbreak. Morrison stated they are aligned in understanding the challenges and necessary responses. The RBA is expected to cut interest rates to a record low 0.5% in its monthly rate review decision. This move is seen as a response to the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Australia racks up Q4 current account surplus but virus uncertainty weighs
summary: Australia reported a Q4 current account surplus of A$1 billion, driven by robust resource exports to Asia. However, the outlook is uncertain due to the rapidly spreading coronavirus epidemic, which threatens to impede trade and economic output. The epidemic has also led to a decline in prices for Australia's top resource exports and a decline in services exports. Economists predict a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia to mitigate the economic impact, with 17 of 40 surveyed expecting a cut. Annual economic growth is forecast to pick up to 2%.

site_title: G-7 finance ministers plan call on Tuesday on coronavirus: sources
summary: G-7 finance ministers plan a conference call on Tuesday to discuss the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The call, scheduled for 12:00 GMT, aims to address the global economic downturn, which the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development warned is the worst since the global financial crisis. The call follows the OECD's warning to governments and central banks to fight back against the slump.

site_title: Buttigieg endorses Biden for US president ahead of 'Super Tuesday'
summary: Pete Buttigieg endorsed Joe Biden for US president ahead of 'Super Tuesday', providing a boost to the former vice-president's White House hopes. Buttigieg, a centrist, previously competed against Biden in the Democratic nomination battle. The two are now united in their desire for a moderate candidate to beat leftist Senator Bernie Sanders. This endorsement comes as Buttigieg dropped out of the race just one day earlier, uniting the two centrists in their pursuit of a moderate candidate to face President Donald Trump in November.

site_title: US sanctions, charges two Chinese linked to North Korean hack
summary: US authorities have sanctioned two Chinese citizens, Tian Yinyin and Li Jiadong, for allegedly laundering over $100 million in cryptocurrency stolen in a 2018 North Korean cyberattack. The two were accused of working with the Lazarus Group, sponsored by North Korea, which stole around $250 million from a cryptocurrency exchange in 2018. The US has frozen their property and assets and banned trade with them under sanctions. They have also been indicted on charges of money laundering conspiracy and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business.

site_title: ECB ready to take 'targeted' steps on coronavirus: Lagarde
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to take "targeted" measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak, according to ECB President Christine Lagarde. The bank's readiness to act comes as governments and central banks worldwide are facing pressure to support growth due to the pandemic. Lagarde's comments suggest the ECB could consider ultra-cheap loans, liquidity operations, and other tools to bolster the economy, potentially including a rate cut. This move would be in line with similar signals from the US Federal Reserve and Japan's Bank of Japan.

site_title: Australia government spending up in Q4, adds slightly to growth
summary: The Australian government's spending on operational items rose 0.7% in the December quarter to A$94.27 billion, adding 0.1 percentage points to GDP growth. Investment in assets decreased 0.4% to A$24.65 billion. These findings suggest a slight boost to economic growth, with forecasted growth of 0.4% in the previous quarter and an annual pace of 2.0%.

images.alt_text: Australian government spending on operational items rose 0.7 per cent in the December quarter from the previous quarter to an inflation-adjusted A$94.27 billion (S$85.7 billion), the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Agri-food sandbox, product design space among government's new innovation ideas
summary: Singapore is launching a regulatory sandbox and innovation factory to support its emerging agri-food tech industry. The Agri-Food Innovation Park in Sungei Kadut will open in mid-2021, with a regulatory sandbox for farms and a Food Regulatory Connectivity Initiative to get Singaporean food standards recognized abroad. The Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology's Innovation Factory will also be opened in 2021 to support product design and development. These initiatives aim to help agri-food tech companies access new markets and expand their customer base overseas, creating jobs and driving growth in the sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 1.20% to 21,600.74, and the Topix index up 1.25% to 1,544.87. The move follows G-7 talks on the spread of the novel coronavirus, which have eased concerns.

site_title: Australian consumer confidence slides as coronavirus spooks
summary: Australian consumer confidence fell to a five-and-a-half year low, dropping 3.2% to 104.8, due to the spread of the coronavirus and its impact on the stock market. The coronavirus sparked a huge sell-off in the market, wiping out around A$200 billion in wealth. Despite this, consumers remain content about their personal financial circumstances, with a measure of financial conditions firming 3.8%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates again amid speculation of fiscal stimulus.

site_title: UK plans to include onshore wind, solar in next round of support auctions
summary: The UK government plans to include onshore wind and solar power in its next round of auctions to meet its climate targets. The contract for difference (CfD) scheme guarantees a minimum price for renewable projects, and the next round will start in 2021. This move aims to increase the use of renewable energy in the UK, as the country seeks to reduce its carbon footprint and achieve its climate goals.

site_title: Twitter advises nearly 5,000 global employees to work from home
summary: Twitter is advising nearly 5,000 global employees to work from home due to concerns over the Covid-19 coronavirus. The company has suspended non-critical travel and canceled the South by Southwest conference. While employees in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea are required to work from home, other offices will remain open for those who choose or need to come in. Twitter aims to optimize remote participation for internal meetings and tasks.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady; Italy extends coronavirus-driven slide
summary: European shares closed 0.1% higher, rebounding from a 12% slump last week, as traders awaited central bank stimulus following the coronavirus outbreak. Oil & gas companies led gains, while travel & leisure stocks declined 2.7%. Italy's death toll rose to 52, and traders expect the US Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by 50 basis points. The European Central Bank is also expected to cut rates by 10 basis points at its April meeting.

site_title: Google's self-driving sister, Waymo, gets first outside investors
summary: Waymo, the self-driving unit of Alphabet Inc, has raised $2.25 billion in its first external investment round. The company expects to add more outside investors and has announced its self-driving trucking business will be called Waymo Via. Founded 11 years ago, Waymo is considered the leader in developing self-driving technology, but analysts believe it and its rivals are still years away from building large-scale businesses around that technology.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open of trade on Tuesday, tracking a strong performance on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.48%, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.77%. This follows hopes for a global response to the coronavirus outbreak, with investors seeking reassurance.

site_title: Singapore boosts grant, tax schemes to help companies go global
summary: Singapore has expanded its grant and tax schemes to encourage companies to venture abroad amid the global Covid-19 pandemic. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing has doubled down on helping local businesses, doubling the grant limit from S$20,000 to S$100,000 and extending the Market Readiness Assistance scheme for three more years. The Double Tax Deduction Scheme for Internationalisation has also been extended to Dec 31, 2025, providing tax breaks on certain overseas market development and investment activities. The government aims to strengthen support for companies going international to differentiate Singapore from other countries.

site_title: Democratic primaries 'rigged' against Sanders: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump claims the Democratic primaries are "rigged" against Bernie Sanders, citing a lack of delegate lead despite Sanders' national frontrunner status. Trump's comments come as Sanders faces competition from surging Joe Biden after a South Carolina win. The Democratic White House race has also seen the withdrawal of centrist rivals.

site_title: Singapore shares climb at open following gains on Wall Street; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.1% at the open on Tuesday, tracking gains on Wall Street overnight, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,039.61. Gainers outnumbered losers 188 to 24, led by Rex International and Reenova Investment. Local banks also gained, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB rising 1.2%, 1.2%, and 0.6% respectively. The gains followed a 5.1% surge on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rebounded after a historically bad week.

site_title: Nam Cheong bags 6 OSV chartering contracts worth RM116.4m; names new CFO
summary: Nam Cheong Limited, a Malaysian offshore vessel builder, has secured six chartering contracts worth RM116.4 million (S$38.5 million) for offshore support vessels. The clients are foreign oil majors, and the vessels will operate in East Malaysia waters. This contract, combined with a previous RM54.8 million order, is expected to contribute positively to the company's financial performance. The company has appointed Chong Chung Fen as its new CFO, effective March 1, and its total order book now stands at RM318.2 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, MCT, Perennial, Frasers Property, UOL, Top Glove
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include CapitaLand, Mapletree Commercial Trust, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings, as commercial landlords and tenants dispute property tax rebates. Top Glove settled legal actions with Adventa Capital. Keppel Corporation's subsidiary acquired a 50% stake in US senior housing operator Watermark Retirement Communities. Chinese authorities approved Aoxin Q&M Dental Group and Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology to resume operations, while Nam Cheong won charter contracts for offshore support vessels. Accrelist and Jubilee Industries Holdings faced corruption investigation requests.

site_title: Coronavirus spreading fast outside China but stigma is more dangerous: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) stated that the new coronavirus is spreading rapidly outside China, with almost eight times as many cases reported globally in the previous 24 hours as inside China. The WHO's chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, emphasized that stigma is more dangerous than the virus itself, and that the fight against the coronavirus should become a bridge for peace. The global death toll has exceeded 3,000, with outbreaks in South Korea, Italy, Iran, and Japan being the greatest concern.

site_title: Indicted Netanyahu claims victory in Israel vote
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu claimed victory in the country's general election, with exit polls indicating his right-wing Likud party would secure between 36-37 seats, giving him a strong position to form the next government. The election, held amid the coronavirus epidemic, saw Likud's main challenger, the centrist Blue and White party, projected to take 32-33 seats. Netanyahu's trial is set to open on March 17, raising concerns about "unprecedented" legal uncertainty.

site_title: All units of Luxus Hills' final phase sold
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates has sold all units in the final phase of its 999-year leasehold landed development, Luxus Hills (Contemporary Collection) in Seletar Hills. The developer set a new benchmark for pricing, with average inter-terraces selling for S$3.35 million (S$2,070 per square foot). The 39 units, including five-bedroom homes with smart home features, were sold through private previews, with nearly two-thirds of homes taken up. The sale marks a successful conclusion for the final phase.

site_title: Death toll from novel coronavirus in US rises to six: officials
summary: The death toll from the novel coronavirus in the US has risen to six, all occurring in Washington state, with five in King county and one in Snohomish county. This marks the first reported US fatalities from the virus.

images.alt_text: The number of US deaths from the novel coronavirus rose to six on Monday, all in the state of Washington, officials reported.

site_title: Accrelist, Jubilee executive chairman assisting with CPIB investigations
summary: Executive chairman of Accrelist Ltd and Jubilee Industries Holdings, Terence Tea, along with two Jubilee senior management staff, have been requested to assist with Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) investigations. The investigations relate to certain expenses and a payment made by a Jubilee subsidiary, Honfoong Plastic Industries, during the Chinese New Year period. Tea and one of the staff members have posted bail and are providing assistance to the CPIB. The companies' boards have accepted the decision to allow Tea to continue his roles and responsibilities, citing ongoing investigations and no formal charges.

site_title: The driving force in Irish politics? Finding a decent place to live
summary: Ireland's housing crisis has led to a shift in the country's politics, with the left-wing party Sinn Fein gaining popularity among younger voters. The crisis, rooted in the 2008 financial crash, has rendered thousands homeless and pushed many into the private rental market. Sinn Fein's proposed plans to freeze rents and build 100,000 homes have resonated with housing protests, making the party a key player in Ireland's splintered political scene. The crisis has also unmoored voters from the center-right consensus, highlighting the impact of housing on European politics.

site_title: New York governor says coronavirus spread 'inevitable'
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo warned that the coronavirus will spread in the city, calling it "inevitable" after the first confirmed case in a healthcare worker who visited Iran. The 39-year-old woman has mild symptoms and is recovering at home, with her husband also expected to test positive. Cuomo announced $40 million to contain the spread, with a goal of testing 1,000 New Yorkers daily, and increased public place cleaning. Despite concerns, Cuomo reassured residents that the facts defeat fear, and the city has experience dealing with health crises like Ebola and Sars.

site_title: Bets on big Fed rate cuts rise as virus spreads, ECB vows action
summary: Traders are betting on a significant dose of stimulus from the US Federal Reserve amid growing concerns over the economic impact of the coronavirus. Futures pricing indicate a 100% chance of a half percentage-point rate cut at the Fed's March meeting and another by July. Global central banks, including the Bank of Japan and European Central Bank, are preparing monetary rescue measures. Finance ministers from seven major economies will meet to discuss coordinated action, but doubts remain about the effectiveness of such measures due to the nature of the threat and low interest rates globally.

site_title: SATS buys UK aviation food company Monty's Bakehouse for £26.7m
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based aviation services provider, has acquired UK-based Monty's Bakehouse for £26.7 million (S$48.4 million). The acquisition aims to bring Monty's Bakehouse products to Asia customers, enhance food solutions, and support growth into new segments. SATS plans to develop sustainable food packaging solutions and set up an innovation centre in Singapore. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on SATS' financial performance.

site_title: Federal Reserve vs coronavirus: What can the US central bank do?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is prepared to take action to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has acknowledged the evolving risks to economic activity and stated that the Fed will use its tools to support the economy as needed. However, many economists warn that a rate cut may be ineffective in addressing the virus's impact on supply chains and that acting too quickly could hamper the Fed's ability to react to a potential downturn. The Fed's traditional tool, the federal funds rate, remains at a very low range, and policymakers are considering alternative measures, including coordinated global responses.

site_title: US: Dow ends up 5.1% as stocks bounce back after rout
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 5.1% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 4.6% and 4.5%, respectively. The gains came after global finance heavyweights announced a coordinated response to the coronavirus epidemic. The Dow ended at 26,703.32, while the S&P 500 finished at 3,090.23 and the Nasdaq at 8,952.16. Despite concerns over the virus's impact on the economy, stocks bounced back as investors anticipated fiscal and monetary easing.

site_title: Self-reliant Huawei gets around US chip ban
summary: Huawei, barred from US suppliers due to national security concerns, is ramping up production of devices with its own HiSilicon division, which manufactures base stations integral to high-speed wireless networks. The Chinese technology giant has increased its in-house capabilities to produce the necessary components, effectively bypassing the US chip ban. This move allows Huawei to maintain its self-reliance and continue producing essential equipment for its wireless networks.

site_title: Oil up over 4% as hopes of Opec cut, stimulus counter virus gloom
summary: Oil prices surged over 4% on Monday, reversing losses triggered by the coronavirus outbreak, as hopes of deeper Opec cuts and stimulus from central banks countered demand concerns. Brent crude futures rose to $51.90 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose to $46.75 a barrel. The International Monetary Fund and World Bank offered support, while Opec+ members are considering an additional production cut. The move reverses a six-session losing streak triggered by worries about the virus's impact on oil demand.

site_title: Money FM podcast: How can the SBF-YBLN HOPE Fund help SMEs?
summary: Mark Lee, CEO of Sing Lun Industrial, and Alex Chua, CEO of Goldbell Financial Services, discuss the SBF-YBLN HOPE Fund, a $5 million initiative to support SMEs. The fund aims to provide financial assistance to small businesses, helping them navigate the challenges of the pandemic and post-COVID recovery. The discussion highlights the fund's potential to provide a safety net for SMEs, enabling them to invest in growth and expansion. The HOPE Fund is seen as a vital resource for Singapore's SME community.

site_title: China ordered to slash state media staff in US
summary: The US has ordered Chinese nationals to be cut by nearly half from working for Beijing's state-run media in the US, reducing the number from 160 to 100. The move comes after China expelled three Wall Street Journal reporters and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo vowed reciprocity. The US is not explicitly expelling the remaining 60 staff members, but they are expected to leave the country. The decision is seen as a response to China's increasing surveillance and intimidation of American journalists in the country.

site_title: Sales at 2 property projects buck cautious sentiment from virus outbreak
summary: Sales at two property projects in Singapore defied cautious sentiment due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Luxus Hills sold its final units, while buyers snapped up 392 out of 522 units at The M over two weekends. These sales indicate continued demand for new private homes in Singapore, despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, exceeding expectations. The US stock market opened lower due to fresh tariffs imposed on Canada by the Trump administration. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC to deepen green finance cooperation.

site_title: Coronavirus death toll tops 3,000 as airlines cut flights
summary: The global death toll from the new coronavirus surpassed 3,000, with nearly 90,000 infected in over 60 countries. Airlines cut flights, and stock markets experienced volatility. The World Health Organization urged countries to stock up on ventilators to treat severe cases. Africa is considered vulnerable due to widespread conflicts, poor health infrastructure, and crowded cities. The US, China, and Iran reported significant increases in deaths, with the US announcing its first case. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control increased its risk assessment for Europeans to "moderate to high."

site_title: Capitalising on diversity of thought in a collaborative space
summary: Flexible workspaces have evolved into hubs for intellectual exchange, offering diverse perspectives and ideas. Companies like Microsoft have adopted shared spaces to boost productivity and innovation. These collaborative environments provide a community for professionals from various backgrounds and industries, fostering cross-pollination of ideas and creativity. Technology plays a key role in these spaces, ensuring efficient use of resources and promoting productivity. By bringing together employees, startups, and freelancers, collaborative spaces can dissolve barriers and lead to greater harmony among working professionals, ultimately driving business growth and innovation.

site_title: Delta, American airlines suspend several Milan flights
summary: Delta Air Lines and American Airlines have suspended flights between US airports and Milan due to the spread of the novel coronavirus in Italy. Delta suspended flights from New York's John F Kennedy International Airport to Milan Malpensa, while American Airlines suspended flights from several US airports to Milan. The suspension is temporary and aimed at reducing the risk of coronavirus transmission.

site_title: Muhyiddin promises to fight graft, abuse of power
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin vowed to combat corruption and abuse of power in his government. He pledged to appoint clean and integrity Cabinet members and improve enforcement of laws and regulations. Muhyiddin accepted the premiership to stabilize the country amidst political turmoil and the COVID-19 pandemic. His administration faces the challenge of reviving the country's weak economy, which grew at its slowest pace in a decade in the fourth quarter of 2019.

site_title: Two new Covid-19 cases confirmed - one linked to Science Park cluster; four cases discharged
summary: Two new Covid-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total number of infected people to 108. One case is linked to the Science Park cluster and a 34-year-old Filipina foreign domestic worker. Four cases have been discharged.

site_title: Citi high-flyer to steer Grab on its digital bank path
summary: Former Citibank Singapore head of retail banking Charles Wong is set to join the Grab-Singtel consortium bidding for a digital full bank licence in Singapore. Wong, a veteran banker, led the turnaround of Citibank's retail banking unit and is likely to play a key role in the new bank. Grab holds a 60% stake, while Singtel holds 40%. The consortium aims to offer low-cost financial products to the underbanked population, with Wong's expertise expected to drive the business.

site_title: Germany's ice wine harvest fails because of an unusually mild winter
summary: Germany's 2019 ice wine harvest failed due to an unusually mild winter, marking the first year without an ice wine harvest nationwide. The country's wine institute attributed the failure to temperatures below minus seven degrees Celsius, a condition necessary for the production of the sweet dessert wine. The failure has raised concerns that ice wine could become a rarity in future years, with vintners facing the challenge of dealing with rising temperatures and long, hot summers.

site_title: Chinese cities offer perks to revive car sales in virus-hit market
summary: Chinese cities Guangzhou and Xiangtan are offering incentives to boost car sales, which have been hit by the coronavirus. Guangzhou plans to reintroduce subsidies for electric vehicles, while Xiangtan will offer 3,000 yuan in cash for locally made car purchases. These measures aim to counter declining auto sales in China, where car sales dropped 18.7% in January and 89% in the first 23 days of February. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers expects a 10% decline in auto sales for the first half of the year due to the virus.

site_title: From enterprise transformation to better jobs for Singaporeans: What more can be done?
summary: Singapore's government aims to support enterprises and workers through digitalization, productivity, and innovation efforts to build long-term competitive strengths. The "virtuous cycle" concept, introduced in Budget 2020, encourages enterprises to invest in digital transformation, upskilling their workforce, and creating better jobs for locals. Key areas for improvement include assisting enterprises in understanding digital capabilities and job redesign, supporting SMEs in human capital management, developing digital learning roadmaps for workers, catalyzing a mindset shift on upskilling and career mobility, and enhancing the role of trade associations and chambers.

site_title: Tee International CFO resigns amid unauthorised payments probe
summary: Tee International's group CFO, Yeo Ai Mei, resigned amid an investigation into unauthorised payments, which totalled S$3.75 million to former CEO Phua Chian Kin and Oscar Investment. The payments were initially classified as legitimate expenses, but later deemed unauthorised. The company's board appointed a committee to determine the extent of the issue, leading to Yeo's resignation. A probe into the payments is ongoing, with Yeo serving a six-month notice period.

site_title: Singapore air transport sector gets help to reskill amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore's air transport sector is receiving a reskilling initiative as part of the Stabilisation and Support Package to aid businesses and protect jobs amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The package, worth S$10 million, will benefit over 8,000 workers by providing 90% funding support for salaries and course fees for retraining and reskilling. This includes enhanced absentee payroll support and sector-specific training programmes. The move aims to help companies manage excess manpower and upskill workers for a potential recovery.

site_title: Invisible Man emerges with US$29m opening at US box office
summary: The Invisible Man debuted at the top of the US box office with a US$29 million opening weekend in North America. This marks a successful attempt by Universal to remake a classic monster property, following the 2017 commercial failure of The Mummy. The studio had scrapped plans for an interconnected Dark Universe after the Mummy's box office bust.

images.alt_text: Above: The Elisabeth Moss-led thriller which cost US$7 million to make, not including marketing fees, is already a financial hit for the studio
Above: At the premiere of The Invisible Man in Hollywood last week (from left) Michael Dorman, Aldis Hodge, Elisabeth Moss, Oliver Jackson-Cohen and Storm Reid.

site_title: Japan Feb factory activity shrinks on Covid-19 hit
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted sharply in February, marking its sharpest decline in nearly four years due to the Covid-19 outbreak. The manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 47.8, its lowest since 2016, and stayed below the 50.0 threshold for the 10th month. This contraction raises concerns over global growth and pressure on Japanese policymakers to boost manufacturing.

site_title: Dollar weighed down by rate cut prospects
summary: The US dollar retreated to one-month lows against a basket of currencies due to the prospect of a full-blown rate-cutting cycle to counter the economic damage from the coronavirus. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's statement hinted at a rate cut, and investors are expecting a 50 basis point cut at the March 18 meeting. This has led to a decline in the dollar index and a rise in the euro, while other currencies such as the yen and Australian dollar also strengthened.

site_title: Emirates Group sees slowdown due to Covid-19
summary: Emirates Group, a state-owned holding company, has experienced a "measurable slowdown" in business due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has asked staff to take paid and unpaid leave, with over 100,000 employees affected. Emirates has also cancelled flights to mainland China and Iran, citing the spread of the virus in those countries. The company is seeking flexibility in work arrangements to cope with the crisis, which has impacted its operations and revenue.

site_title: Fitch downgrades ratings for Singtel and Optus
summary: Fitch Ratings has downgraded Singtel's long-term foreign- and local-currency issuer default ratings and foreign-currency senior unsecured rating to A from A+, citing weaker-than-expected growth prospects and capex pressure. The ratings agency also lowered Singtel Optus's ratings to A- from A. Fitch expects Singtel's net leverage to rise to around 2.5 times in the financial years ending March 2021 and March 2022, driven by intense competition in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: To defend democracy, we have to reform it
summary: Voters worldwide are increasingly dissatisfied with democracy, with 51% of citizens in 27 countries reporting dissatisfaction, according to the Pew Global Attitudes Survey. This sentiment stems from a disconnected political class, with politicians often more concerned with special interests than ordinary people. Reforms, such as reducing money in campaigns, direct democracy at the local level, and using technology to improve voting, are proposed to address these issues. However, the disconnect between politicians and voters is a fundamental risk to modern democracy, and liberal democrats must lead the charge to reform and revitalize democratic institutions.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector slumps in February
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted to a record low of 40.3 in February due to the Covid-19 outbreak, which halted production and supply chains. The Caixin/Markit Manufacturing PMI also fell to 35.7, the fastest pace on record. The non-manufacturing PMI dropped to 29.6, the lowest since November 2011. The Chinese government has implemented stimulus measures, but growth is expected to be negative for January and February, with under 3% growth for the first quarter of the year.

site_title: HSBC Singapore on track for targets in merged arms
summary: HSBC Singapore is on track to meet its targets for growing its headcount and revenues in its retail banking and wealth management segment. The bank's focus on Asia, particularly Singapore, Hong Kong, and China, is expected to drive growth, with combined assets of US$1.4 trillion and a pre-tax profit of US$136 million in 2019.
